I liked it but also hated it lol-.. The 3D designs are nice, but I preferred the drawn ones. ALSO I DO NOT WANT TO STARE THE MAP EVERYTIME SIGMA WALKS TO SOMEWHERE. 두 개의 게임 묶음으로 기본적으로 양쪽 다 방탈출게임이라는 방식이라서 방 안을 탐사하고 힌트를 얻어 수수께끼를 풀어 문을 여는 부분은 굉장히 재밌었습니다. 중간중간 도저히 답을 모르겠다 싶은 퍼즐도 있어서 공략 도움을 받긴 했지만, 전반적으로 난이도는 조금 궁리하다 보면 알 수 있는 딱 재미를 느낄 정도의 어려움이었습니다. 게임 하면서 노트 펴놓고 메모하고 풀이 궁리하는 건 또 처음이라 묘하게 신기한 느낌이기도 했구요. 

 스토리는 독특한 설정과 서로 믿지 못하는 인물들관의 관계로 굉장히 흥미로웠습니다. 얘는 무슨 짓을 한 걸까, 왜 저러는 걸까, 이 다음에 어떻게 나올까 하고 계속 다음 이야기를 궁금하게 만드네요. 진엔딩까지 가는 과정이긴 하지만 선택에 따라서 이야기 흐름이 휙휙 변하고, 각각의 루트마다 밝혀지는 비밀들이 있어서 하나씩 까먹는 맛도 정말 좋았습니다. 커다한 하나의 이야기 흐름에 필요한 요소들을 각각의 루트에 뿌려놓고 그걸 하나씩 알아가게 만드는 구성도, 게임의 흥미를 잃지 않게 만들어 주어 좋았습니다. 독자적인 설정들로 이야기가 구성되다 보니 내용이 한 번에 이해되지 않아 다시 읽어보게 되는 점은 조금 귀찮았지만요. 

 다만 이야기 전체로 보자면, 조금 불만이 생기는 부분도 있습니다. 1편인 999 쪽은 이야기가 그래도 마무리가 되는 편이라 괜찮았는데, 2편인 선인사망은 그냥 3편의 프롤로그네요. 전 루트 마치고 엔딩 본 다음에 이야기 마무리를 안 지어주는 건 좀 황당했습니다. 뭔가 빠뜨린 게 있나 이 루트 저 루트 뒤지다가, 검색해 보고서야 후속작으로 이어진다는 걸 알았네요.  진엔딩 도달하면 궁금했던 게 모두 해소되고 남은 몇 가지 의문점으로 후속작으로 이어지는 게 깔끔하고 좋은데, 이야기의 마무리를 다음작으로 넘겨버리다니요. 3편도 하긴 할 거지만, 뭔가 굉장히 찜찜한 기분으로 마치게 돼서 그 부분은 별로였습니다.

既読スキップはしたくないから困ったもんだ。
ポリゴンも可愛くないしシステム面でも９時間から劣化してるし、
ストーリーが気になるだけにめっちゃストレスが溜まった。

あ、９時間のほうは普通に楽しかったです。ハイ。
Scratches that escape room itch.

Zero Escape:  The Nonary games is comprised of two games.  999, and VLR.  WHAT a GREAT value for the money!!!  TWO great games in one package for the price of one.

First of all I have to say that I thought that 999 and VLR had two different types of writing.  I liked 999's story more, as it was very well written, and the ending WAS AMAZING with no loose holes.  VLR also had a great story but the Main ending was too convoluted and confusing honestly.  WAAAAY too convoluted.  Having said that I still liked it very much.  

The voice acting in both is awesome.  As for the puzzles, 999's puzzles are way simpler for one, and also better explained.  In VLR the puzzles sometimes have obscure or poorly translated descriptions so you don't even know what you're supposed to do in some of the puzzles.  

The other thing that bugged me about VLR was that the door system wasn't as interesting as in 999.  Chromatic doors vs Digital Roots which was way more straightforward.

Anyways in conclusion I have to say that The Nonary Games is one of my all time favorite games, AND Visual Novels. 

P.S. Do yourself a favor and play the game with the JAPANESE voice acting which is infintely better than the lame English Voice Acting.

Full Disclosure: I did not and will never play VLR. The game is probably great but the art style makes me wanna cry and vomit simultaneously.

THAT SAID, 999 will make you do math (debatably cool) and leave you reeling from logically consistent super interesting plot twists (objectively cool). Getting to know all the characters and see how they interact as they let you, Junpei the player, do all the heavy lifting in EVERY PUZZLE is a blast. I waited for sale, cuz well, I did only play about 25% of the available content (VLR is much longer) but after playing I would totally say 999 is worth the full $30 by itself.

Loving this series because they put many theories and effort into the puzzle and connected them by a brilliant way. Even when you think you get the gist of the story, it still can outsmart you and blown your mind.
However in VLR, you just waste time seeing they setting up for the third game. Gameplay wise, 999 gameplay abit frustrating to get other ending due to the choice ( usually you have to start from the first choice to get another ending ) and do over the puzzle again from head to start. VLR is very good in term of gameplay because you can just click and skip puzzle to complete all the endings.

[h1]你说的对 [/h1]

A really fun puzzle game with a lot of amazing story and enough endings and twists to leave you wanting more, as you are curious about every single one. I love the complexity of the puzzles, that are still not too difficult. It's beautifully set up and you'll just want to know what's behind each door. And who Zero is of course!

Brilliantly, uniquely atmospheric on a level gaming as an art form rarely ever approaches. Although the second game has its pacing issues and the endings of both tend towards the convoluted, nothing can detract from the shockingly fully realized vision brought to bear by the dialogue, art, and sound design. Indisputably Uchikoshi's masterpiece.

Very good 999
good VLR

Really good visual novel combo where the narrative is well interspersed with puzzles.
999 is excellent through and through.  It spins a mind-boggling original yarn with interesting characters and clever puzzles and is consistently engaging throughout.
VLR is a bit of mixed bag.  It does tie back into the original well, but the pacing in the middle of the game really suffers.  It goes on far too long with too much repetition in the middle with very little new information, which really hurts the game overall.  It does pull itself together in the end with a series of very cool reveals, some obvious and others not so.  But overaall 999 is the far superior game.  But if you want to complete the trilogy it makes sense to see both games through.

Very fun game! Both 999 and Virtue's last reward come with it, so pretty good deal.

But yeah, it's got an amazing story, interesting characters and some really fun puzzles to solve. My only qualm with the game is that sometimes it's really hard to find what you're looking for in some of the puzzles. I had to spam click the whole screen several times to get past certain stages. I think it would be better if it was easier to see key items/key areas of the screen (I got stuck on one stage for almost an hour because I didn't notice a key item). 

The story is just insane though, the twists and turns are kinda insane. Can't wait to try zero time dilemma (the final game).

Highly recommend though, it's one great journey.

These games are not masterpieces, but by the time I'd completed each one I'd gotten attached to a few of the characters. The puzzles are mostly good, a few outstanding ones being either braindead-easy or illogically challenging (you might miss an object due to poor artistic choice, an item might be poorly detailed, and specifically in VLR's case, you might need to switch to Easy to get any proper clues), and VLR's characters aren't anywhere near as well-rounded as 999 (it literally has characters infodump their backstories fairly late into their exclusive timeline after many screens of obnoxious interactions, rather than flesh them out as the story unfolds like in the first game), but the plot of both always began with a slow burn and went uphill from there.

I can only hope Zero Time Dilemma ends the series on a satisfying note.

To keep this short, the 999 remaster is fantastic, and the VLR port is a subpar sequel but a passable game that you would also receive with buying The Nonary Games. I’m mixed on VLR and might even be wrong on being so critical of it as I did enjoy parts of it, but the padding and weaker characters drag the whole game down low enough that I’m even hesitant to say 999 fans should play it.

Setting aside ZLR for the moment, I'm mostly sure for most people this pc re-release is the ideal way to play 999. I do think there's significant value added with the voice acting, remastered 999 graphics (maximum possible 1080p versus the DS' 192 pixel resolution), and as small as it can sound, yes, the new addition of a route flow chart. I do want to address the DS release did make unique use of the DS' dual screens, but I can’t really imagine preserving that nuance on pc where most people only have one. In all my time playing there were only two times where I even thought there might be a difference in adaption, and I wasn’t really impacted by them. So, I acknowledge something small might be lost there. That said, again, I do enjoy the voice acting performance and the graphical overhaul so this would be my preferred way to play and my platform to recommend to others regardless.

I don’t have a ton of criticism to give regarding 999 because it gets so much right. To begin with it was already a well-constructed narrative with wonderful presentation and characters. With the benefits of the remaster, it’s monstrous. I can’t overstate how much better the game looks being brought up from DS graphics to 1080p. The store page doesn’t even mention this, but the musical tracks themselves have been remastered in terms of bitrate. If I reach, I can maybe say the failing is maybe the puzzle difficulty, which I generally enjoyed but seemed a bit scattered. Also, I think average all ending completion time might be 20 hours which might be short for the $30 price point if you just wanted to buy it for this alone.

Conversely, I'm a lot less positive on VLR after revisiting it. VLR does have more content and ideas floating around than 999. It's just that the nature of the narrative and the gameplay has you seeking out a bunch of different endings with route variations that don’t feel super satisfying to play through. The different endings mostly act as a carrot on a stick to continue replaying. The game ends up being not just padded out by extra game over routes, but also and mainly by swathes of unchanged dialogue and events shared between routes. There is a skip text feature I made gratuitous use of because there was so much I had seen already re-occurring between routes, but there's no option in the menus for “don’t skip unseen text.” Skipping around in this fashion didn’t feel like the right thing to do, even though I must assume this is the intended fix with its inclusion. I’m then unsure if this is fair criticism because these re-occurring events do allow the writing to setup character moments and seemingly integral plot beats, and narratively it makes sense why the same events often happen in different routes if plots are already in motion in the background. The thing is it repeats often enough it’s still aggravating to the point that it feels like a legitimate flaw and worth talking about.

This is a weird frustration to express. I mentioned weaker characters at the beginning of this. It hurts to say this as I wish the inanimate product VLR well, but it’s overwhelmingly true. People are caricatures for most of this game. Sensibly, you get a bit more insight as to who a person is supposed to be and what their motivations are at the end of their routes, but before that everyone might as well be a closely guarded blank face. Most don’t really get into character conflict or development outside of the structure of the main plot. This is just a weird thing to get wrong where in 999 they didn’t have hours between opening doors where they could just stand around and chat. Early on in VLR you might have some downtime moments before a new set of doors unlocks, but even that little bit soon gets traded out for completely on rails and automatic investigation sections where you’re often looking for other items of interest or other people to talk to over more matters of practicality. Outside of their end routes most only really talk casually as teammates in puzzle rooms, and that usually only totals a few lines not explicitly about the puzzle. To end me droning on, let me just say what little characterization that’s squeezed in the whole game just isn’t enough to get me to like seeing most of these characters for the playtime I’m expected to spend with them. I don’t need persona-esque dates, but seeing people act as people and try to hold any conversation about nothing in their life-or-death situation or something like that might go a long way to sell them as being alive in the first place.

While I don’t think I recommend VLR, I will commend it for being narratively interesting with a billion twists, even if it does so with a stilted roster. The twists do act as highs that reinvigorate interest, which when there’s enough of them even let someone let me want to finish the game. Going for the different endings hoping for interesting twists and conclusions was a bit like gambling, which was fun in a sense. Still not worth your time.

I waited to finish both games to give a review. And although I suffered some major delays due personal stuff, allowed me to digest both stories slowly.

Both games take full advantage of its medium to create a story arround it. The puzzles can go from basic to challenging, with a few ones you might really need to pull a walkthrough due how complex or RNG based can be (They're scarce in that regard however). One thing both games suffer is that for the better experience you must play routes in certain order, specially Virtue which requires to play certain routes first to continue others.

To be honest both have some ups and downs. Personally I enjoyed 999's story and setting more, since Virtue is mostly playing arround the major reveals of 999, and many of Virtue's bad endings are just "You have chosen poorly try again". However, because Virtue focuses more on the twists of its predecesor, manages to pull various curve balls on its own reveals. 999 has a major problem where characters become exposition dumps out of nowhere just to set a reveal hours of game later. Meanwhile, the 3D models in Virtue makes some characters' expressions/animations upsetting and weird (e.g. A character might be screaming out of frustation, but the model is smiling), and given in the last segments of the game uses proper artwork for various scenes, I really don't know why they bothered to use okay-ish 3D models besides highlighting a pair of important animated cutscenes. There's also nitpicky questions which both games didn't leave clear in the end (Mostly semantics about how certain things work, not major plot holes), so unless Zero Time Dilemma covers them up you better check a wiki or something.

I highly recommend to atleast check a "route order" guide to get the best experience, as while I did that with 999, with Virtue I went through the route with the most plot reveals first until reaching a story lock (Which most reveals in that moment of the route were already set on 999, so aren't really major spoilers overall). I also recommend you to not lower the difficulty of Virtue since unlocks an epilogue, otherwise you'll have to speedrun through the puzzles for a few hours.

[i]This review contains NO spoilers for both games[/i]
[h1]2 in 1[/h1]
Zero Escape: The Nonary Games, contains both “Zero Escape: Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors” and “Zero Escape: Virtue’s Last Reward”. That’s why this review will be split into two sections, both discussing different games. This had to happen, since both games have very different strong and weak points.

[h1]General Idea[/h1]
Both games are visual novels with escape room puzzle segments. You and 8 other people find yourself locked in a weird place, in which you are forced to play a death game. You solve puzzles and mysteries, to finally be able to escape. Very important mechanic in those games is the flow chart. There are certain decisions you can make that completely change routes or scenarios you will find yourself in, and everything is shown to you in that graph. There are multiple endings that you can get that completely change how the story plays out.

To be perfectly honest with you, I have spent an enormous amount of time writing this review. I had a very hard time gathering my thoughts about those games; the final verdict changed several times. 999 and Virtue’s Last Reward have some very questionable game design decisions. Most of the problems with the first installment were fixed in the second. However, the second game came with a completely different set of flaws, and almost brought me to my wit’s end. That's why those games have to be played mainly for the story; if you are looking for anything else, unfortunately you may consider skipping “the Nonary Games”.

[h2]999[/h2]
[h3]”I swear it gets better”[/h3]
Have you ever been recommended a show by a friend, but they explicitly said that it gets good after over 2 seasons? Well this game is basically just like that show - the first 4-5 hours of the game were tedious and boring. The main filler are the escape rooms, which are fundamentally flawed. But even that wouldn't be a problem, if not for the fact that the plot is advancing really slowly, and every twist happens very late into the game. In the beginning and even in the middle there is almost nothing happening. I was borderline napping in my chair on multiple occasions. Half of the game consists of overly long dialogues that just dump a ton of information on you, but it's understandable, since the story tends to dive deep into Sci-Fi territorium.

Although, I sometimes felt like a tourist in an insane asylum. Characters often go off on these massive tangents, about things I thought would be important, but turned out to be completely unrelated to anything. For example: you find some random object, and a random character (that has no business knowing all that stuff they are about to say) has a 30 minute long tantrum, about some random SciFi thing that ultimately has almost nothing to do with both the object you just found, and anything else in the game.

[h3]Accessibility, over enjoyment[/h3]
Escape rooms are quite well designed, their theme is often really interesting… but that's the only thing I can say about them, out of one simple reason - everything gets immediately spoiled to you by other characters. That’s why the escape rooms became annoying breaks that you are forced to take between pushing the story forward, and nothing else really. The worst part is the frequency of those breaks. On average, every hour of the game has around 30 minutes of mandatory and monotonous puzzles.

[h3]Aesthetics[/h3]
Graphics are decent. 2D sprites with a handful of animations, and 3D escape rooms that are interactable using only 2D mechanics. They are quite well made though: escape rooms always have a cool theme and the 3D in them works wonders; characters are really expressive, you can really tell what kind of person they are just by looking at them.
When it comes to music 999 has some memorable songs, but nothing crazy. Voice acting is really good, although very inconsistent. Sometimes in important story moments dialogues are silent, but some random joke chit-chats are fully voiced.

[h3]Amazingly written, and very thoughtful[/h3]
I was amazed how everything tied up together in the end. There were tons of plot points thrown at the player, but everything made perfect sense thanks to the ending. I tend to make a lot of theories when I play games like these and on a second look at my notes, I realized that the game always had me where it wanted me to be. The perfected line of thinking I was taking, completely unaware of its intentionality, always led me to the biggest shock possible. It's crazy that a non-indie game left me somewhat alienated, and with the “I have been played with” kind of feeling. I tried looking for some sort of plot holes, to potentially get my sense of control back, but to no avail. I must admit this story stumped me, but in a good way.

[h2]Virtue’s Last Reward[/h2]
[h3]Artificially raising the game running time[/h3]
The second installment of the series took me almost 28 hours to complete. I can confidently say that I have spent at least 5 hours watching an unskippable door opening animation, followed by a slowly moving dot on the map, showing you where you went. Every time your character moves, you are taken hostage and forced to watch how EVERY existing door, between your starting point and destination, is opened.  Why developers cared to add this transition is beyond me. The only thing it does is wasting your time.

[h3]Paranoid schizophrenia[/h3]
As in the first game, characters often go off on these massive tangents about sci-fi concepts. And luckily, this time all of it is important to the plot; there is no useless information. Unluckily however, they tend to repeat themselves, over and over again. There are some more advanced thought experiments here I'll admit, but characters will go above and beyond, to ensure you fully understand everything. That makes many dialogues absurdly and needlessly long.

[h3]Mastery of plot twists[/h3]
Just like in 999, the game really likes to play with you. Even an old stager like me, fell into many traps made by the writers. Every single plot twist is a surprise, and it's not like you just didn't have enough information. Everything you need to know is told to you beforehand. The game even assumes you may expect the same trickery used in 999 and does things totally differently. My understanding of the plot was flipped on its head multiple times, and I loved every second of it. It is a special, perfectly thought-out story, that you won't be bored off.

[h3]Forcing 3D[/h3]
For some unknown reason, developers decided to swap perfectly fine 2D sprites with 3D models. Characters end up looking more dull and blank, but the biggest downgrade are animations. They look really stiff and unrealistic, making many potentially sad moments - a joke. Both escape rooms and backgrounds stayed the same quality.  Music on the other hand is surprisingly more memorable.

[h3]Actually good filler?[/h3]
Escape rooms in this installment are surprisingly better than in the first one. Cool thematic stayed, but spoilers are gone. Characters won't tell you everything you have to do right away, only after it's clear that you are stuck. They are still not very challenging, but this time, even at their worst, they still give you a tiny spark of joy.  Minigames on the other hand, are not that consistent; they are either really fun, or absurdly unintuitive, rage inducing and simply cruel.

[h2]Few words[/h2]
These games are not perfect by any means. And mind you, even the story is not perfect either: some flat and boring characters, a lot of god-awful dialogues, nearly 0 symbolism and inconsistent world building also hold these games back. But mysteries and plot twists are so well thought out and innovative, that I just couldn't bring myself to not recommend Zero Escape. At the end of the day, “The Nonary Games” are not for everyone, but for a relatively small group of people this is a must-play.

One of the worst games I've ever had the misfortune of experiencing. Made worse because the gameplay (escape rooms) is very good, and the story was almost excellent. So why is it so terrible? The writing is all over the place to the point of nauseating confusion. The game slowly eases you into something absurd that I, personally, had a very tough time buying into, but fine, if it stuck to that, then I can accept it. But it didn't. Right at the very end it introduces the stupidest deus ex machina I have ever seen, all to 'reinforce' a dumb plot twist. The entire game hinges on this twist and it's so god awful that I have to call it one of the worst games I've ever played. Oh and this is just the first game. I tried to play the second one, but the graphics were traumatising thanks to the uncanny valley nature, and the controls rendered it impossible to play with just a mouse, which is what I could just about muster up the attention to use for the last game. 28 hours of wasted time, several of which were dealing with bugs that made it crash more than once. DO NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME

En este "juego" vienen las primeras 2 entregas de la saga de Zero Escape: 999 y Virtue's Last Reward. La idea de los juegos es simple, estás atrapado y tienes que encontrar la forma de escapar. 

999 se me hizo un juegazo, aunque empieza algo lento, pero el desenlace de todo te deja pegado al monitor. No soy tan fan de VLR a comparación, 999 era una increíble historia contenida por si sola, VLR intenta conectar todo y hacerlo mucho más grande que termina sufriendo a mi parecer. Visualmente, no son juegos muy bonitos, pero al menos la intriga de 999 hace que valga la pena.

Played this games like 10 years ago for the first time. I love them ♥

+ well-balanced between the escape and story parts. The puzzles neither too easy nor unsolvable, perfect for a person who loves it.
+ amusing characters. Everyone's presence is making sense and there's always a story behind it. The second game also has a charismatic villain moniker.
+ extremely well English voice acting for a Japanese title.
+ good music, improved navigation, vast variety of the storylines  (all of it about the second game compared to the first)

- sometimes unnecessary info dumping.
- the sequel is way more enjoyable than the first game of the series, but you should play the first to grab the sense of what's happening after.

999 and VLR are both hands down the best visual novels I've ever played in my life. 
I rarely ever go out of my way to 100% unless I absolutely feel in love with it. I did just that.
Both 999 and VLR offer phenomenal story telling, great characters, challenging yet fantastic escape room puzzles, and great art. If you remotely care about visual novels, you should absolutely not skip out on these two gems.

剛通關999的時候，真的差點要給這遊戲負評。因為結尾實在讓人太不滿意，密室難度也非常低，幾乎只要仔細點完整間房間，就能輕鬆通關，感情線也非常惹人出戲，無法理解為何本作會被稱為密室逃脫的傑作。

幸好，善人死亡的密室難度原地升級，雙密碼和難度切換設計，終於不再出現NPC雞婆插嘴的現象。光是前期的艙室就讓筆者卡關一陣子，不過謎題的難度也不到解不出來的程度，只有[spoiler] 滾骰子想偷懶、醫療室棋盤 [/spoiler]兩個部分有參考攻略。
喜歡密室的筆者感到非常開心w，但是走路系統超級浪費時間的意義不明，每次都等到生氣RRR
善人死亡的遊戲時間也比999多，花費時間是25小時左右，最末段的劇情也比999有趣[strike]很像是畫大餅[/strike]，喜愛密室還是可以考慮在特價時候買來玩。

Шикарнейшие новеллы. Множество твистов, особенно во второй части, последние часы чтения которой голова просто кипела от информации. Есть лишь один минус: в первой части есть неофициальный перевод, а вот во второй придется уже переводить все самому( хотя язык там используется не очень сложный, большинством персонажей по крайней мере).
时长、剧情都超出预期，不愧是打越钢太郎，期待新作。

[h1]9/10[/h1]

[b]Overall[/b]
I first started playing 999 on 3DS years ago and despite finishing an entire run I never went back to complete the story. I'm glad I did as going back to the game took me on an expansive journey I would have missed out on otherwise! Be prepared for slow pacing with this game as it likes to drip-feed information in such a way to create a long suspense before you start to piece together what's going on - this goes for both 999 and VLR. If you're likely to become frustrated at playing for hours without understanding the bigger picture, or mundane dialogue between characters, the payoff might not seem worth it. Great for fans of mystery visual novels or escape room puzzles, especially if you like "never saw it coming" twists (or, like me, if you like being able to say "I saw that coming!" once in a while). Characters are for the most part very well fleshed-out and purposeful even if you don't feel some details are at first. I enjoyed the music and overall atmosphere even where it's quite minimal.

[b]Puzzles[/b]
This game is not purely escape room puzzles so you may find that if you want a pure puzzle game this has too much filler. The puzzles themselves range from satisfyingly "just complex enough" to "let me look this up or I'll be here all night" - at least in my case I did get a little frustrated with the sheer amount of number puzzles, especially in 999. For the most part, puzzles function well and follow a twisted kind of logic without being too obscure.

[b]Endings[/b]
There are multiple endings in both games which you will need to view in order to get the "true" endings of the game. Expect to be replaying multiple times as once really isn't enough! I would recommend going through your first playthrough of both games completely blind just to get a feel for them before you start methodically unlocking other routes. There are flow charts in both games allowing you to skip to other parts of the timeline - this worked extremely well in VLR in particular. You can also automatically skip any dialogue you've already seen which is a godsend (please don't be like me and forget you can do any of this and actually replay through multiple puzzle rooms in 999 manually). If you're left confused and bewildered at the end of 999 definitely forge ahead to VLR, but be aware that there is a third game in this series (Zero Time Dilemma) which concludes it and is not included in this collection.

[b]Achievements[/b]
Achievements are pretty easy to get as they mostly correspond to completion of routes in the game. VLR does have an extra layer where you need to find an extra password in each escape room to unlock additional in-game files but other than that you can't really miss the achievements.

Definitely one of my favorite visual novel series of all time at this point. The story and character development in both games is so rich and rewarding. The puzzles are challenging but still manage to be a ton of fun.  I cannot wait to play the third game and finish the series out. The second game sets up for the experience perfectly and makes you so excited for it. There is also so much play time in this series it is well worth the price. If you like visual novels and puzzle games, this game is absolutely for you,

一代像是精心设计过的五道菜法餐，有一条主轴贯穿整个游戏，所有对话、情节、机制、谜题都围绕着主轴展开。短短几个小时通关，把谜底解开后，其中有猜对的部分，有意想不到的部分，让人不由回味。
二代更像是量大份足的自助餐，开始时开心地这拿点那拿点，也不管菜搭不搭，到了最后撑得不行也腻了。虽然剧情量更充实，选择肢更多，谜题也更烧脑，但大量的概念、设定和线索堆在眼前，真的是“要素过多”，让人一时难以消化。而且一代是现代背景，即使是虚构的部分也感觉多少能让人接受：“说不定真的可以”；而二代是近未来背景，加上几乎两三倍的游戏时长，和过程中没能完全消化的内容，到了结局就有种“彳亍口巴，你说啥是啥吧”的疲惫感。当然，二代本身还是很优秀的，只是相比之下体验有些不同。
但二代（包括后面三代）的角色3D化实在是不敢恭维。不知道为什么这么执着于3D人物...3D模型摆拍的事件CG表现张力远不如画的。就算是为了模型复用节省成本，那对话时放立绘放表情差分不香吗，立绘都是现成的，多画几个表情也花不了多少钱（也一直很想吐槽《血污夜之仪式》的这个问题）。即使不去想几年前3D的技术力问题也还是出戏。
最后说点题外话，查了一下《极限脱出》和《弹丸论破》三代基本都是同时期前后脚出的，真的不感觉撞吗？
im deranged

В общем, не дайте себя обмануть - в этой игре очень неудачно соединены две игры. Стиль обоих игр одинаков - это визуальная новелла с очень запутанной тайной, периодически прерывающаяся на очень качественный квест (в принципе, квест от первого лица, в котором с тобой болтают люди в формате визуальной новеллы - это очень классная находка).

Первая игра, как и каждая игра серии, повествует о девяти людях, запертых в странном комплексе и играющих в смертельную игру. И первая игра получилась очень свежей и интересной, а местами и страшной. Более-менее все вопросы получают ответы, а концовка прям очень радостная и приятная (и затянутая настолько насколько положено быть затянутой хорошей концовке). Всем очень рекомендую.

Однако, почему-то эта пачка включает в себя и вторую игру. Она сиквел первой, она похожа на неё, но она в два раза больше и в неё напихали слишком много сюжета - причём не особо весёлого сюжета. Более того, вторая игра представляет собой незавершённый сюжет, который вроде как должен завершится в части "Zero Time Dilemma", но я забыл. Очевидно, было бы лучше объединить вторую часть с третьей - я бы с лёгкой душой поставил им обеим дислайк. А так - не могу.

В обоих частях классная музыка, в обоих очень хорошая квестовая составляющая, Да и идеи неплохие. Просто во второй части с ними перемудрили; я почти уверен что сюжет второй части более "стыкуется и продуман", но кому это важно когда ты час подряд выслушиваешь сложные схемы и не особо пытаешься вникнуть?

Но первая часть выгодно выделяется персонажами, рисовкой - потому что рисованных персонажей во 2-ой части заменили 3d-модельками - и более приятной-удобной для прохождения схемой сюжета. Во второй части очень многое повторяется, что, наверное, логично - но не так интересно.

Итоговое резюме: первая часть хороша, вторая хуже т.к. нудная. Рекомендую спиратить и пройти только первую ))))))

I'm sorry to everyone who really enjoyed this game but I was thoroughly disappointed by these games. 

Just to be safe I'm gonna spoiler tag this whole thing but there are no major spoilers.

[spoiler] I'm a big fan of related VN games like Danganronpa, YTTD, and other similar games; so I thought this was right up my alley but it really wasn't. 
As a whole I found all of the characters wildly less interesting, and the story not meaningful. Any plot I found myself getting interested in would have a very meaningless and unsatisfying end to it. Tons of scenes are just random exposition dumps that exist solely to explain the ending, which makes so little sense that the main character even comments that there is no explanation for certain major points.

Also the fanservice is beyond excusable. Lotus, Alice, and VLR Clover's designs are total nonsense and lose major points with me. Also there apparently a fanservice Clover flash game that was on Spike Chunsoft's website? Absolute nonsense and should never have even been considered for actual content for the game. There is no excuse. 

I have to admit I feel like I'm missing out on something because people praise this game as a great story but it comes off to me as forced nonsense. So much of it just totally misses the base with me and feels dumb. 

I could only bear so many exposition dumps, nonsense fanservice, and unsatisfying conclusions before I had to give up during VLR. I really wanted to like Zero Escape though. [/spoiler]

It's seriously surprising how both of these games somehow look AND play worse than the original DS version of the first game. They work, but play like crap and are riddled with image compression artefacting.

Sure, I mean, the originals still were unbalanced kusoge as follows:

1) solve a small addition puzzle
2) click through 30 minutes of visual novel
3) solve a small minesweeper puzzle
4) read two hours of visual novel
5) solve a sudoku puzzle
6) read one hour of VN

But now they're somehow worse, too. You see where this goes.

The soundtracks are terrific, but the puzzles are easy and they're unevenly interspersed in the visual novel. The characters switch personalities on a dime and the plot doesn't hold up at all. I may change opinions if something truly miraculous awaits late at the end of the second game, but so far I've just kind of loved listening to these games while hating playing them.

This is hard to decide whether I recommend this collection or not. On one hand, 999 is a masterfully-written game with a lot of moments that are insane and make you think. On the other hand, VLR takes all the good aspects of 999, but makes them either worse or just straight up make them terrible. I absolutely recommend this collection just for 999 but I cannot bring myself to recommend the sequel with its ugly presentation, terrible cast, weaker setting, and inferior puzzles (some are very clever though). I try to beat every game I play but I could not stomach more than 12-13 hours of the sequel. Maybe I'll give it a second shot in the near future but currently I can't sit through it. I'd say wait for a sale for the collection and give VLR a shot if you are curious. This is a half recommendation, but I'll still say try them out.

999 is a great game! One of my favorites of all time! Admittedly, translating this game from DS to computer screens caused some things to be lost in the process, but as someone who never played this on the DS, I didn't feel like I lost too much (though I am a little bummed to say the least). I'd still recommend it - the voice-acting is great, and it doesn't require you to restart from the beginning every time like the DS did. The story and characters are all fantastic, and it's easily the peak of the series. There's not much more I can say other than go play it yourself!

VLR, on the other hand...

I have...unpopular thoughts on VLR. After I initially finished it a few years ago, I had very negative thoughts on the experience and considered it worse than ZTD. Over the years, I saw other people's glowing reviews of the game, and figured I was just letting a few sour parts of the game spoil my opinion. So, I ended up changing my tune. That is until I recently watched a livestream of the game and remembered that no, it wasn't just a few things, and yes, I do not like this game very much.

I've seen some people say they liked VLR until the end, but I'm the opposite. The hours and hours and HOURS of playing before you finally get to the end are a slog. Most of the characters are uninteresting, a disappointment, or both. Luna, K, and Tenmyouji's endings were the only ones I ended up caring about, but even then Luna's is the only one that really stands out. As for Sigma and Phi, I hated them so much. To her credit, Phi gets less annoying over time, but she's still absolutely infuriating for the first several hours of gameplay. Sigma, on the other hand, is a pervert protagonist whose antics either boarder on or are just straight up sexual assault, which makes it extremely uncomfortable to play as him. 

But like I said, I enjoyed the ending, and I still liked some characters a lot. Hell, I have an amateur homemade Luna cosplay sitting in my closet right now. The overall writing's good, and I've since retracted my belief that it's the worst in the series. I'd still highly recommend both of these games to anyone. I may not like much about VLR, but like I said, my opinions aren't the same as everyone's. Who knows. Maybe you'll like it more than 999. Or maybe you'll hate it like me and we can go out for drinks sometime to rant about it.

TLDR: Just play these games.

There are a few things I want to note... these are not cons, they're just adjustments. If you've played the DS game then you might be curious to what changed.

First off, this sounds silly but hear me out. In 999 one of the inside parts of the story goes on about rats in a maze and how each time the rats did the maze it was faster and faster. In the original DS version of the game, there were no "teleport to this point of the story" map system like the 3rd game has. You had to go back through all the puzzles manually. For me, adding the teleport option takes away that part of the story. This wasn't ruining for me because I've played this game fully through on the DS and fully through here.

Other thing is that at the end of 999 (first game) the final puzzle changes. Spoiler free: The DS game you had to flip the whole DS upside down while working on it, and the second monitor on the DS really hit home and made you feel more with the characters during the final puzzle's incident. This version it changes into a bit harder puzzle, kinda-meaningful still, but it removes that essence because ... well  i mean you can't really flip your computer monitor upside down :D

STILL

[h1]Play Virtues Last Reward through this collection, but not 999[/h1]

Zero Escape: 9 hours 9 persons 9 doors is a great game, as is Virtues Last Reward, but [b]I just can't recommend playing 999 in particular via this collection[/b]. Since the game is no longer displayed over the two screens of the DS the script has been significantly altered to allow all descriptive text previously displayed on the bottom screen to be communicated through dialogue. This not only leads to characters saying really obvious things along the lines of "I'm opening this door!" (where the DS version would've just narrated this) but also leads to the characters either talking to themselves out loud or saying things out loud that shouldn't really be said. There's a relatively gory moment in the game (or at least a moment described as gory in the DS version) where the characters now have to say every part of this out loud, when they're in stunned silence in the original game. The game is extremely tonally different because of these changes.

There's a "novel mode", where you can actually still see the original DS narration, however the character dialogue remains the same. This means characters repeat the exact same things the narration has just detailed, and the game is still incredibly tonally different from the original even with this mode enabled. In my opinion the graphical upgrade and voice acting really isn't worth losing a lot of what made the original game great, especially since some of the voices are really subpar. This is also without me even taking into consideration that a large plot moment is essentially ruined if you aren't playing the DS version, as it utilises the dual screens. It's communicated in a really awkward way and everyone I know who played the Nonary Games version had to have this moment explained, whereas in the DS version it's much easier to understand.

It is worth mentioning though, this version of the game includes a flowchart. There are multiple choices you can make in this game such as deciding which rooms to go into. In the DS version of the game you will have to play from the start if you want to visit other rooms. The text fast forwards if it's dialogue you've seen previously and then slows down again when you get new dialogue. I can understand someone finding this tedious and as such wanting to play the Nonary Games version instead, which lets you skip to these decisions, but again, this undermines the major story moment I mentioned previously and makes the story a lot harder to understand. There's a story beat that you can miss entirely in the Nonary Games version as it requires you to complete the same area twice. It gives a lot of context to events that occur later in the game, somewhat foreshadowing them, and is something you're required to see in the DS version. Since you don't have to replay the game from the start in this version, the changed scene can be missed entirely. I won't deny that the flowchart is massively convenient, but I personally think that restarting every time puts more emphasis on the things that have changed while also reminding you of the events of the game prior to those changed moments, since you can't just skip them entirely.

I would recommend either playing the original DS version on actual hardware or emulating the DS version, as cumbersome and annoying as it probably sounds. 999 is one of my favourite games and one of if not my favourite DS game, but it wouldn't be had I played it through this collection.

Virtues Last Reward though, yeah it's great, play it in this collection. It's not been visually updated whatsoever unfortunately but every other version of VLR apart from the Vita version has a potential softlock bug that can result in you losing a significant amount of progress and even all of it if you saved all in one file. VLR is the best game in the trilogy in my opinion even though 999 is the best standalone game. Would still recommend this collection for the best version of VLR, but would advise against this version of 999 being your first playthough.

You [b]may[/b] like this version of 999 just as much if not better than the original, but just be warned that your mileage may vary. I really don't like recommending this version whatsoever, but if it's your only way to play this game it does the job. Trust me, DS emulation is way easier than you might think. The DS is also not region locked if you live in Europe and can only find American copies online (if you want to play on official hardware), but if you [b]really[/b] want to play this version that's fine. It's better that more people can experience the overall story, regardless of the issues this version has.

I like Saw-like deadly-games where you and some strangers try to escape. I also like solving point'n'click riddles too so I really loved this game. And this is finally a game where your decisions can change final outcome.

It has similarities to Danganrompa, Gnosia or Your Turn To Die, but those aren't clones of each other, I wouldn't look at this game at category better/worse version of "X".

What else:
+ plot is interesting, there is a lot of reading but I liked it
+ characters have some depth and aren't oriented over just single trait
+ animations, it's simple but looks very good
+ I like psychological/philosophical/science pieces that were put in story
+ most puzzles are really fun to solve, for few ones I stuck but there are in-game hints. Anyway I feel ratio between fun/engaging and boring/irritating is pretty good
+ there are hidden jokes if you are stubborn enough to click many times over environment :>
+ I really like math (digital root) motive which drives game, it blows my mind how such simple mechanic drives participants crazy :>
+ multiple paths & endings, single path doesn't explain all mysteries so you can have more fun with game

- most of music is okayish but there is no real banger
- game pace is rather slow, expect best plot twists at later stages (it isn't a real con but some people may see it that way)

tl;dr; if you like interactive books with logic puzzles and death motive in background I really recommend purchase.

Je vais rédiger mes avis sur les deux jeux de ce "pack"

[h1]999 :[/h1]

7/10
❤ Une intrigue qui semble "simpliste" mais qui se révèle vraiment surprenante plus on avance dans le jeu
❤ L'ajout de doublage sur la version steam (avec un super casting !)

❤ L'ajout d'une flowchart (MERCI)

✖....mais souvent trop simples. Il n'y a pas vraiment de balance avec des énigmes plus dures (une seule m'a mise un peu mal sur tout le jeu)

[h1] Virtue's Last Reward :[/h1]

8/10

❤ Un scénario qui arrive à aller encore plus loin que son aîné...juste le scénariste est un grand malade (ou un génie)
❤ UN TWIST, DES TWISTS, QUE DE TWISTS!!!!!!!!!

❤ Des personnages qui ont chacun leur importance et auxquels on s'attache, même les pires ;)
❤ Une ambiance sonore toujours au top
❤ Le système de flowchart qui prend une place à part entière dans l'histoire (et c'est ce détail qui devient tripant!)

✖ Pourquoi la 3D...........
✖ Les séquences de déplacement sur la map, répétitives et lentes
✖ Les décors sont fades
✖ La version steam pas vraiment adaptée pour la souris ; le déplacement dans les salles pouvait être laborieux
✖ La toute fin, confuse et qui semble incomplète

I'm gonna play each game spaced out a bit, so here's my review for 999, I'll edit in my review for Virtue's Last Reward in after I beat it.

999: An extremely fascinating and gripping mystery that feels perfectly crafted to solve MOST of your questions at the end, but leaves a bit up to your imagination, too.  The only thing I hated were some of the puzzles being a bit too close to being straight-up math problems.  Other than that, I had a really fun time with this game!  I'm excited to play Virtue's Last Reward soon.

VLR: A great follow-up to the first game, mostly.  It manages to create a new narrative based on what was established in the first game.  But I'm not a fan of the 3D models they use in this game, they're way too simple and look cheap.  I realize this game was originally on handhelds, but it doesn't translate super well.  But the puzzles and story were worth it, though.  I definitely can't wait to see what happens next in Zero Time Dilemma.

Zero Escape 999: Great game overall, with an incredibly interesting setting and gameplay segments, a smart plot, and well-written characters. What this game does exceptionally is the tension it builds along with the pacing. You want to know what's going to happen so much due to the huge veil of mystery covering the characters and the plot. However, most puzzles are easy to medium (at max) difficulty-wise.

Zero Escape Virtue's Last Reward: It is an amazing sequel to the first one. I found myself liking it more. Great twists that have a stronger impact on the story and the escape rooms are WAY better designed and some are actually challenging. The cast is also great here as well. As for the story, I found it more thrilling as well ,with many great mysteries, and plot is overall better.

This duology is a must-play for thriller enthusiasts.

I would recommend these games overall just for the story alone, but if Steam had a middle option instead of simply Yes/No - I would pick that instead. As someone who fell in love with this series back when 999 originally came out on the DS, my expectations were high. I knew some things may be tweaked going from two screens to one, but I think it was a bit overkill. 

Adventure Mode changes more than expected. I also don't entirely get the point of doing it this way, either. It may have been less obvious 999 was a visual novel back in 2009 (the genre was certainly less popular in the west); but that's definitely not the case now. This is tagged Visual Novel, so that people who both want and are used to the typical VN can experience it. Why strip that down, when it added SO much to what made the original great? Adventure Mode not only rewords or removes descriptions that really added to the atmosphere, like when [spoiler] the 9th man goes boom, the description of his body afterwards was a powerful show of how serious things were. [/spoiler] This is still tucked away in Novel Mode, but most people aren't going to switch modes past the start in this version; especially first time players. They attempt to improve this in Adventure Mode via character dialogue, but there are times when it is notably unnatural. Things that should be internal thoughts are spoken out loud, or things that should be very obvious to the player - probably to serve as reminders/hints. Either way, it's excessive and in my opinion hurts the immersion. Keeping it to Novel Mode for immersion, with voice acting to keep things engaging would have helped to stay more true to the original. 

The true ending puzzle being different was also an unpleasant surprise. That is another very intense moment in 999 as a whole, and the setup/visuals are important for that. Again, I understand that an adjustment had to made for 2 screens to 1, but even the original being a side-by-side split screen would be better than what they did here. That's aside from them changing the puzzle entirely. Why do that? 

I will give some props to the flowchart feature, something the original desperately needed. But even this is not perfect, as it doesn't properly label all new dialogue if it's not essential to a path. I still want to see this dialogue, especially when it comes to getting to know the characters. 

This may be seen as a smaller complaint, but [spoiler] why did the syringe ending from the iOS version not get added to this version? [/spoiler] It didn't use any new assets/CG's, but it plugged a plot hole and would have been a good addition that felt more like a bonus; since many players don't even know it exists at all.

As of writing this I have poked around in VLR some, but not enough to compare differences as I have with 999. The display looks fuzzier with some characters and interfaces, but that's all I have noticed at the start. I would be less likely to recommend VLR as a whole however, because though it also has a good story: I personally am not a fan of the art style change, not as interested in the characters, and think 999 was better as a standalone game. But it does have its own mystery worth solving. I would not recommend ZTD at all.

Like I said, I DO still recommend these despite my own issues with them. New features and tweaks aside, the core story in 999 is still the same here and it is one of my favorite games ever made. VLR was less impressive, but the story still stands up well enough to want to get most of the endings. The voice acting is lovely, the cleaned up sprites in 999 are easier on the eyes, and seeing both games on bigger screens is always welcomed. Please pick this up if able, you won't regret it.

If you want an interactive anime with escape rooms in it, play this game. Both of the included games are great. Interesting stories are presented in an engaging way. The puzzle rooms feel polished, and they work really well with the plot/themes. Both games have super nice features that keep you from wasting time, and it makes it easy to want to keep playing.

WARNING to new players before anything else: when you play VLR, do NOT read anything in the secrets tab, even the secrets from the [i]very first room of the game[/i] will spoil tons of stuff you don't even know exists. Whoever decided to just casually throw that in has some [i]very[/i] bad karma coming their way.

Big Pros:
[list]
[*] Ludonarrative harmony. I won't go too into detail, as it's best to go in blind, but this is a series that makes great use of its medium. It makes a great use of themes and powerful ideas, and the whole thing is woven together really well.
[*] Strong plot that leads you along for wanting to understand more. When I started the game, I was a little put off by what felt like a contrived premise, but the stories develop masterfully, and it doesn't take too long to get pretty invested. My only objection is that it sometimes leans too hard on plot devices that are a [i]little too convenient[/i] for a mystery, but it's forgivable.
[*] Overall great characters. Occasionally someone's behavior will be really confusing, but that confusion is intentional, and you understand after playing more. Less occasionally you finish the game and their actions still aren't super convincing. But mostly it tracks.
[*] Good voice cast, double for the second game. I saw someone complain about the voice acting, and I feel like they've never heard bad voice acting in their life. The main character's performance in 999 is a little unpolished, but in kind of an earnest and relatable way imo.
[*] Nice looking, consistent art (with a couple exceptions in game 2). I prefer the hand-drawn art in 999 to the simple 3D animation of VLR; one particular character, for example, has a smile as their resting face, which makes more unpleasant conversations [i]really[/i] awkward. But overall I think both were well done. The 3D animation is more of a gesture, similar to a reaction drawing you'd expect from a visual novel, rather than the full scene animations of something like a Telltale game.
[/list]

If I have to take marks off, here they are:
[list]
[*] The controls change between the games, no idea why. Controls that exist in both are just mapped to different buttons [i]for some reason[/i]. Beyond that, they changed the way you interact with puzzle rooms in VLR, and I don't like it as much. I get what they were going for, but it feels clunkier.
[*] The sexual comments are... often too much. 999 is a bit better about it, but they both have some classic anime nonsense that doesn't really fly [i]especially[/i] considering the situation the characters are in. It's not all bad, some of it I really liked, but some of it is [i]pretty dang bad[/i] imo. For the good, there are some fun double entendre scenes where one character is talking about sex and the other doesn't realize it, and there are some good sexual suggestions or jokes between characters that you've watched develop a close relationship. I'll even let it slide when a character's internal monologue expresses sexual desires: [i]keyword internal[/i]. But it's really uncomfortable when the main character, the person representing your agency in the world, actively sexually harasses other characters. Women will express that comments made them uncomfortable, then he'll do it again. It's slimy and it doesn't add anything to the game, they could literally be removed and it would be a flat improvement.
[*] It's not really fair to put this into the "bad" column, but it doesn't really belong in the good column either: all games of this series have at least one character with their breasts HANGING OUT. It's impossible to ignore, and yet none of the characters seem to notice it, which is cool I guess. VLR is particularly egregious, as this character is wearing jewelry in lieu of a shirt.
[*] I know I said the games have a lot of features that save you time, and they do. But also [i]woof[/i] VLR has a lot of annoying unskippable cutscenes where you travel to a different room and it animates every room you pass through and every door you open.
[*] Sometimes a scene in VLR has drawn art, and it's a lot worse than the first game's art.
[*] This bundle is kind of a bummer because VLR isn't the best stopping point for the story, and it was pretty clear that the third game, ZTD, is very closely tied to VLR, not just as a sequel. I thoroughly enjoyed VLR, but the ending feels a little like it's missing something.
[/list]

So there you are. Play it. The game parts are good. The anime parts are good.

Just finished the 999 remake and lemme tell ya the twist in the true ending was definitely handled better on the DS. Honestly, as a long time fan of the series, nothing can top that moment for me. The remake though does bring a coat of fresh paint to the game with the voices and updated graphics. Although, I think I would still recommend playing 999 on the DS solely for the fact that the twist is done better in it and the fact that the remake defaults to the “adventure mode” style of reading which totally lessens the impact of the twist. I wish there was only Novel mode or a setting to have one be set for the whole game as I found myself accidentally switching the modes many times. 

I did have the game crash on me twice, both right before a door animation was supposed to take place. I am playing on the Steam Deck so it could be some shenanigans with compatibility. Save often cause if I hadn’t played this game before I would have defs raged over losing like 1-2 hours of gameplay.

Ho terminato di recente Zero Escape, entrambi i videogiochi, due opere intitolate "Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors" e "Virtue's Last Reward". Consiglio con tutto me stesso questi due videogiochi per la loro storia e i personaggi davvero ben scritti, curati e caratterizzati. 
Una Visual Novel a tema Escape the room davvero ben curata, che si evolve attraverso un diagramma di flusso, caratterizzato da una miriade di finali, che mettono un sacco di suspence al "lettore" o meglio definibile giocatore. In entrambi i giochi vengono trattati alcuni temi scientifici in modo molto chiaro e lineare permettendo a chiunque di capire bene di cosa si stia parlando anche per immergersi meglio nella storia; sono presenti inoltre riferimenti alla letteratura, letterati ecc...
I personaggi sono davvero originali, sia da un punto di vista di design che di personalità, è importante anche notare come ognuno di loro sviluppi un comportamento diverso e un carattere totalmente differente in base alla "route" (scelte in gioco) che si prende. I character si sviluppano sempre in un modo inaspettato ed è una storia che fondamentalmente è caratterizzata da colpi di scena e suspence fino alla fine.
L'ambientazione è molto interessante anche per i misteri che ne racchiude e anche per questo la ritengo un'esperienza di gioco davvero piacevole che va provata. 

Buon divertimento a chiunque voglia provarlo!

This is not strictly a negative review, here's the cliff notes:
The game has two sections. The story section has it's highs and lows, but the puzzle sections are mostly consistent.
If you like puzzle games, get it. Otherwise, the story is as great as some make it out to be, and in my opinion the bad
outweigh the good. If it was half as long, it would be a much better game.

The Good:
- Puzzles are well done, except a few in VLR with clunky controls / badly planned leaps of logic
- Specific plot mechanics (disregarding the overarching plot) is interesting enough to keep you going, and most plot twists are interesting/unexpected
- Characters are most of the true to their personality and are fleshed out.

The Bad:
- Horrible Pacing: deliberately holding back information, redundant writing / conversations that either repeat things or go nowhere except add suspense (which is fine, but gets tiring after 20 hours), nonscientific blabbering, the list goes on. For both 999 and VLR it will seem like 80% of plot is revealed in the last parts of the game. Again, this is fine own it's own, but combined with all the redundancy makes for a bad experience in the story sections. I find myself constantly clicking to fast forward.
- Story Issues: plot holes, contrived endings and unnecessary plot twists that seemingly are just made for the sake of it. 
- Bad Port: there will be moments where controls feel clunky in both games, unnecessary door animations, bad UI.
We just came through that door, if we go back we'll just hit a dead end.

It doesn't take long to look at my profile and surmise that I really enjoyed this series. Oftentimes, it is one of the first things that someone learns about me. I originally played the NDS version about 5 years ago. Since then, I've bought a complete physical of the NDS version and I've bought this. 

I don't want to say much because there isn't much to say. Playing this without any knowledge of whatever's going on is probably the world's best roller coaster. I was, in no way, ready for anything I was going to experience while playing this. It's absolutely best experienced blind and fully invested into. I got into this because I was looking for things to play on the NDS one day when bored, and I went into it knowing absolutely nothing, and I 100% believe that is the best way to experience this.

Both versions have their pros and cons. A lot of time in the NDS version comes from skipping text and speedrunning rooms because the NDS version lacked a flow chart. The NDS version lacked voice acting, and a flow chart; but it had a final puzzle that was far better than the final puzzle in this game. You're given a flow chart in this game, which helps a lot, and the voice acting is pretty nice too. In getting this, you also get VLR. It's entirely up to you which version to play, I don't necessarily have a preference. The only thing is this: if you're going to play the PC version, play the game in novel mode. If you don't, you miss out on vital plot points and narrative beats. 

Don't question things here and there. Just try to enjoy the ride.

[h1] Mais díficil de entender que Evangelion. [/h1]

É um título bem exagerado mas anyway. Não sou acostumado em escrever muitas reviews, mas pra essa belezinha eu quero me esforçar um pouco a mais. Eu não conhecia praticamente nada de Zero Escape, mas já tinha jogado outro jogo da Chunsoft, o AI: Somnium Files (que platinei também) no Xbox. Acabei pegando o Nonary Games na gamepass e, bom, platinei ele lá e rushei pra platinar ele aqui (por isso consegui em 9h de jogo, skipando todo o diálogo e história basicamente, por que já tinha visto no Xbox). Mas, cara, acho que eu deveria ter tomado meu tempo jogando ele aqui também.

Eu sabia que o Uchikoshi não batia bem da cabeça desde Somnium Files, mas pelo jeito ele já era assim desde o primeiro Zero Escape. Me deparei com uma história complexa de viagem no tempo, telepatia, mundos paralelos, [i] telepatia entre mundos paralelos, [/i] o de sempre. Eu sempre curti como ele conseguiu usar o tema da light novel com várias rotas pra criar uma narrativa em que tomar outras decisões não serve só pra "ver o que rolaria", mas sim sendo tudo canônico pra se chegar em um único final.

[b] 999: Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors  [/b]

O primeiro jogo é meu favorito. No momento dessa análise não joguei o último, o Zero Time Dilemma, mas mesmo assim acho que não vou gostar tanto quanto o primeiro. A história tem uma escala bem menor, e, mesmo com muitas pontas soltas pra sequência, ela definitivamente é a mais fechada e menos complexa da série.

Também acho que possui os personagens mais carismáticos, retirando a única que eu não gosto de todo o cast (Clover coff coff), todos eles possuem momentos bem legais.

Outro ponto que sustenta meu favoritismo são os desenhos. Retirando os ambientes em 3D, os personagens, algumas cenas e animações são em 2D e cara, eu acho 100% mais bonito e interessante que modelos em 3D. É engraçado como essas animações são para movimentos simples, mas são fluidas e bem feitas.

O senso de perigo e tensão também é bem maior nesse jogo que no sucessor, Virtue's Last Reward. Algumas partes, caso houvessem agência do jogador, [spoiler](como ao procurar pelo desativador do bracelete)[/spoiler] deixariam a situação ainda mais tensa, mas entendo não ser necessário. Tudo tem um limite de tempo para os personagens fazerem. Isso os deixa cansados, com fome e sono.

Os dois jogos são visual novel, ou seja, história pacas (nem compre pensando encontrar outra coisa caso tu não curte ler, sério) mas tem as partes de escape room (basicamente um monte de puzzle pra tu vazar da sala). Os puzzles em 999 são bem tranquilos (não que sejam fáceis, mas as dicas fazem sentido e eles te dão um empurrãozinho) e eu me vi olhando na wiki a solução bem pouco, só pra solucionar uns de matemática por que sou muito ruim de conta básica e pegar algum item que por algum motivo não consegui ver, mas se tu for dedicado tu não precisa pesquisar, sério.

O que eu mais acho incrível em todos os jogos da Chunsoft é como eles integram mecânicas pra contar a história do jogo. É muito díficil falar desse tópico sem spoilers, mas em 999, presta atenção no sistema de trocar as falas de ADV pra Novel, e em VLR presta atenção no Flow Chart.

Você tem finais interessantes para cada rota, e o final verdadeiro deixa muitas perguntas, mas consegue ser satisfatório.

[b] Virtue's Last Reward [/b]

Aí a gente chega em VLR. Sabe aquela história maluca, mas com uma escala pequena que mesmo quem não fosse acostumado com o tema poderia acompanhar? Então, joga pela janela, por que foi isso que o Uchikoshi fez nesse jogo.

Eu não consigo criticar a decisão dele, por que o produto final ficou incrível e, em questão de qualidade, é um jogo tão bom quanto 999. Fiquei mais emocionado nele do que no antecessor, sendo sincero. Entretanto, porém, contudo, todavia, eu não consigo gostar dele mais que 999, e a direção que a série tomou... well, me preocupa.

Eu vou sanar essa preocupação com Zero Time Dilemma, mas enquanto isso, o resumo de VLR é: pega os conceitos do antigo jogo, e em vez de ser algo pequeno que afeta algumas pessoas, coloca isso numa escala global. Sério. É literal.

O cast é legal, mas não tão interessante quanto 999, e o que mais me pegou foi o cenário. Pra dar um contextualização com o mínimo de spoilers, os dois jogos se tratão sobre uma rapaziada (9 pessoas) que são raptadas e postas pra jogar um jogo de vida ou morte (Nonary Games). Ou eles escapam, ou morrem, basically.

Em 999, eles tinham 9 horas pra escapar, se não o barco iria afundar. Quando passassem por uma porta, se não achassem um sistema que desativasse uma BOMBA no corpo deles, well, caboom, mortos. Era tenso. As intrigas eram sérias. 

Em VLR, tem muito mais briga que no primeiro, mas nenhuma delas parece afetar muito o grupo. Além disso, nada de limite de tempo. O inimigo deles não era o cenário, mas sim eles mesmos, já que as regras do Nonary Game mudaram e colocaram um jogo de trair ou se aliar com alguém do grupo. No começo, parecia muito interessante, pois eu pensei que assim focariam mais nas intrigas dos personagens. Eu estava enganado, viu. No máximo era um "ai, não confio mais em ti", e eu sinceramente não conseguia me importar. Só teve UMA personagem que sempre que eu tinha que trair ela só pra seguir na rota, eu me sentia meio mal. [spoiler] Luna maravilhosa [/spoiler]

Por isso eu não sei bem como reagir a VLR. 999 me deu uma visão sobre a história que o Uchikoshi queria contar, e VLR, mesmo tendo uma mensagem super bacana no final, ele apresenta outra coisa muito diferente, mesmo sem quebrar nada do primeiro jogo.

E cara, eu não curto os puzzles do VLR. Não todos, claro, achei um aqui e ali interessante e tudo o mais, e algumas salas eu passei tranquilo. Mas a medida que tu vai progredindo, tu precisa pegar tanta informação, que eu real só fiquei sem paciência. Perto de pegar os últimos finais, eu meio que só parei de usar o sistema de anotação e só pesquisei mesmo.

Tem mais umas coisinhas sobre os puzzles mas well, anyway.

[h1] Conclusão [/h1]

O título da análise é meio meme, na real. Assim, depende da pessoa. Eu sou bem acostumado com plots que inventam essas noia de viagem no tempo, existencialismo, e tudo o mais, e Somnium Files me deu uma base boa do que eu poderia esperar com Zero Escape, então eu não precisei re-jogar ou ver uma explicação de 40 minutos pra entender cada jogo. Se você prestar atenção dá pra entender o que tá rolando.

Mas pra quem não gosta de ler uma história pesada (por que, querendo ou não, ela é), já deixo avisado que é bem capaz que tu não vai curtir de jeito nenhum. Eu sou super fã de visual novels e afins, e conheço gente que não se dá bem com esse tipo de narrativa. Com o tempo eu comecei a entender o porquê e well, cada um com seus gostos.

De resto, o jogo todo tem as clássicas piadas japonesas que não fazem sentido nenhum quando traduzidas; o Sigma, protagonista do VLR, ao contrário do nome, é mais Simp do que tudo e tem uns fetiche estranho; e tu ganha de brinde mais um pacote de fan service aleatório. Se tu é acostumado com umas parada assim (o que já não é bom, mas to no mesmo barco) isso não te incomoda. Por sorte, todos esses sintomas clássicos de mídia japonesa são poucos e se perdem no meio da história, então dá pra relaxar.

De qualquer forma, você se encaixando em umas das situações que citei ali ou não, eu recomendo de todo jeito. É uma história bem escrita. É um ótimo exemplo de como a narrativa pode ser aliada da gameplay e vice-versa. É uma forma de abrir seus horizontes em questão de gêneros de jogo e histórias.

1代NDS，2代3DS打通了，怀念那时候躺被窝游玩的时光

In case you hadn't noticed by now, this game is actually the first two games of a trilogy bundled into one game. 999, the first game, feels like a homecooked meal--by that I mean that it uses the flavors of all the classic adventure games I played growing up such as Professor Layton and Ace Attorney while still standing out as a unique adventure game. The chemistry of the cast is fantastic, the 2D art based off of real rooms in the Titanic is gorgeous, the puzzles are the right level of difficulty, and the way numbers are consistently used in both the plot and in the gameplay is phenomenal. I applaud the writers for meticulously weaving this story together, even if it does have some holes. Junpei is a compelling protagonist. He's good at filling the everyman role, though he's not a typical goody two-shoes like similar protagonists such as Phoenix Wright. You'll be forced to make decisions, some good, some bad, some deadly, to reveal different elements of the story and learn Zero's secrets. The only thing that didn't work for me was the pacing. The characters are supposed to be on a strict time limit before they're all brutally executed, yet they waste an hour and a half at the very beginning trying to figure out what's going on. Then they also have long conversations about random scientific factoids; they end up being useful exposition for the plot, but there's no reason the characters should know that. I also typically despise timers in puzzle games, but I think a timer in this game would have contributed to the tension and atmosphere; it could have been set to an hour long or so.

Virtue's Last Reward is a hodgepodge of things that worked and things that didn't. I'm not a fan of the 3D sprites; they're just not very clean or expressive. I think the omission of the numbered bracelets and digital roots detracted from the charm of the game, as the thing that thematically tied the entire first game together as a whole disappears. The numbered bracelets are replaced with colored bracelets, and the colors end up having very little to do with the story. There's a new mascot called Zero III, who seems to be a half-hearted attempt at emulating Monokuma from Danganronpa; he's a cute animal/AI hybrid who loves making animal puns and delights in the suffering of the game's participants. He only appears during the beginning of the game and very briefly at the game's finale, which I think lessens his impact as an antagonist. There are also now dozens of endings instead of just six, some of which end in Sigma's death/game failure and others which reveal important information about the characters. Unfortunately, this makes for a lot of backtracking through the story. One of the opening scenes has to be read a total of six times, and you can't just skip through it all because each version has slightly different dialogue that can't be quickly skipped on your first read-through. You also can't skip many of the transition animations, which are often long and boring. If you've ever wanted a game that gives you breaks to check your email or go to the bathroom, this is that game. I'm also just not as attached to this cast of characters. Their chemistry as a whole isn't as strong as the first game's, as many of them stay within designated cliques and don't interact outside of them until the plot absolutely requires it. Returning characters also go through a complete 180 on their personalities. When you finally do get to the finale, the sci-fi logic is so convoluted that it'll be a miracle if it makes any sense to you. I know I've been largely negative so far, but there are parts I do like. Sigma and Phi's chemistry is great, Dio is a great antagonist, and Luna and K are adorable supporting characters. The mystery is engaging enough, and some of the character endings really pack an emotional punch (one in particular is a fan-favorite moment from the entire series). This game also expands on the first game's morphogenetic field system, which is awesome (though I won't spoil what that is for new players).

I think if you like games with rich stories, you'll enjoy The Nonary Games for sure. Just be prepared to get a few bones mixed in with the meat.

While I haven't played the PC release, I have played the DS/3DS originals and would heartily recommend them.

999 is a fantastic visual novel + puzzle game mix that hooked me as my first real go for either genre. The puzzle difficulty is about perfect for me personally, leaning towards easy as long as you are thoroughly investigating each room. It's a fantastic game that could have stood as a stand-alone title. There are a few changes that were made in this release that are understandable, but make things slightly weaker than the DS version.

Virtue's Last Reward continued the world of Zero Escape with positive results. It is another solid entry with the same blend of visual novel and puzzle that worked well in the 999.

Great bundle of two adventure games with very impressive amount of scientific/fantastic references which even make sense majority of time.
I think the gameplay/story complexity was almost ideal in 999 here, in later entries it becomes a little too high. A good thing is neither part of this bundle lets you get stuck in some advanced part of the story before you are supposed to know the answer (which happened to me in "Zero Time Dilemma"). With that, flowchart with jumping feature makes multiple save slots quite redundant.
The drawing style in 999 was also the most attractive for me, switch to 3D models in other parts was a bit repulsive.
These worked smoothly with Proton on Linux for me without additional adjustments, which is also nice.

剧情很神很牛逼，打了前三个BE之后休息了一段时间一口气打通关了。久闻打越大名知道他的神级代表作ever17，但因为各种原因一直没接触他的作品，今天终于通关了999我我要说一句打越钢太郎牛逼。
但是我不得吐槽一下游戏里男女主角的感情线（我有预感打越的剧本中的感情线可能都会完全不合我的口味）。我可能已经过了看那种少年救赎/拯救少女、感人至深的二次元中二剧情的年纪了，[spoiler]真结局最终谜题前那一段男女主角CV深情呼唤着对方的名字还反复重复了好几遍，女主角：“淳平kun呜呜呜打斯克dei救救我怎么办我肯定不行的肯定解不开的呜呜呜我好害怕”[/spoiler]……我整个人地铁老人看手机只想赶紧skip快进到剧情，明明我是一个共情能力很强泪点也很低的老二次元了，类似的中二剧情也看了不少而且其实很喜欢这种套路和情节，但是这游戏里所有煽情的片段都看得我浑身起鸡皮疙瘩，真的有点生理上不适，要不是因为太在乎后续剧情了我会直接关掉游戏的程度…………
最后吐槽一下最终谜题，我在那里卡了至少20分钟没解出来，个人认为应该是对于hint汉化的时候出了点问题看起来有点意义不明所以很让人感到迷惑，本来是想独立解出来的但是因为卡太久了很暴躁本来想在网上直接搜答案也没搜到，相关问题下面只有一些通关玩家写的还是很迷惑的提示。也可能是因为我熬夜通关脑子有点不清醒了思路转不过弯了被自己误导了，总之最后解开了谜题后发现答案完全没有我想象的这么难这么复杂，其实完全就是三分钟就可以解开的简单谜题但是我自己把我自己绕进了死胡同……

2022.7.6 13小时全成就通关第一部999

This is a duology of the first two games of the Zero Escape trilogy: 999 and Virtue's Last Reward, originally released in 2009 and 2012, respectively. The cool thing about visual novels is that they don't age like other games; it's all about the writing, after all. And while both stories have slightly animesque aesthetic, they feel much more 'western' in their sensibilities. They both feature pseudoscience, character drama, branching paths, games of life and death and are heavy on plot twists. They also both alternate between 'novel' and 'escape the room' gameplay sections. 

They're similar enough that most of what I'll say here applies to both of them - but don't worry, they're both completely fresh experiences; they are simply written with similar mindsets and tropes. If you're familiar with visual novels, let's just say this is STEINS;GATE meets Danganronpa. 

I'll get into a bit more detail now, if you'd like. No spoilers.

[h1]Would you like to play a game?[/h1]
The core concept is simple. A group of people are trapped in a facility and forced to play a game in which you either win your freedom or die. The mastermind is someone called "Zero" - a mysterious figure who never shows their face. The game involves opening doors, cooperating, logic games; all sorts of things.

Of course, the question quickly appears. Why are we forced to do this? Who is Zero? Why us? Why indeed, and these questions are the main driving force of the plot, along with the quest to escape.

On the way to solve those mysteries, our hapless bunch of survivors will dabble in pseudoscience, consider strange theories and sometimes make use of them, discover each other's dark secrets...  But it wouldn't be fun if the characters themselves were uninteresting.

[h1]Anime, but less so[/h1]
While this is very much a Japanese game, the characters are a lot less animesque than you'd think. Hell, both games contain black characters, which is pretty much unheard of in Japanese media. The characters are also very diverse when it comes to age, and there are no teenagers present. So you'll have young people, middle aged people, even old people, and yes, of both genders. The fanservice is mostly kept to a minimum, although both games contain a designated bodacious babe.

The intense plot twists are also very animesque - but in a good way. The first game in particular is hard to put down because you're constantly bombarded with information that twists everything around and puts things in a new light. The mysteries are well crafted and follow the rules of fair whodunnit; a tasty morsel for armchair detectives.

[h1]Escape the room[/h1]
The game is peppered with sections where you have to use those adventure game skills to progress by searching for keys under pillows and entering weird passwords found behind paintings. They're alright - just the right combination of disturbing and interesting. And no, there will be no "cut off your finger" kind of things, so if you're squeamish, no worries.

Also, those sections often are excellent foreshadowing for what's going to happen later. At first it might seem pointless, and you will be given a fair share of red herrings - but when you finally reach that true route, everything comes together in a mind-blowing supernova of emotional, pseudoscientific glory. And yes, you're expected to play many routes - not necessarily all of them, but more than one; it's impossible to go straight to the good ending, for reasons that the story itself explains at some point.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
All in all, it's a good time. It's exciting, engaging, leaves you asking for more. And while the first game has a satisfying ending, the second is very much a setup for the conclusion of the trilogy, Zero Time Dilemma. That said, rest assured that the whole saga of those three games has a decisive and complete ending in the third game; no loose plot threads, and everything comes together nicely in the end.

I strongly recommend the entire trilogy if you like weird stuff and don't mind reading.
