Takes a bit to get going, but once you've taken off you're in for a wild ride.  999 and VLR are two great visual novels with wide selection of fun escape rooms and puzzles.  The story is fun and twisty, the characters are memorable, and the soundtrack's pretty good to boot.  I'd recommend looking up an ending order guide for 999, but VLR is definitely a game worth going into blind.  

There's only a few flaws I can think of.  The script in both games (especially 999) is unfortunately overwritten and can get in the way of the mystery and characters.  A couple of puzzles have really poorly explained mechanics as well.  Other than those two gripes, however, it's a easy recommend.
nonnary

This is easily one of the best pieces of fiction ever and it alone can prove that video games can be a viable story telling medium. Theres obviously visual novels before and after it and they may be better but for me this is my favorite visual novel.

With the exception of the third nonary game (not included within this collection), the nonary games are a very good buy. What makes the nonary games different from other detective games is that it forces you to go down all the different routes to uncover the true mystery, each path being unique and all very interesting to go down, piecing together fragments of information to progress. I thoroughly enjoyed the stories of both games, and though the gameplay puzzles in the second nonary game weren't necessarily the best, i enjoyed almost all of it's other elements (which yes, includes the art, which may seem quite ugly at first, but got used to and imo actually adds on to the horror in some way).

I didn't get engaged with the story until 5 hours in when I went into the 4th escape room and I didn't actually liked it until I got an ending.

In the end I got all endings and while I stil think the story wasn't really for me I did like the true ending a lot and I understand how perfectly written the story was.

As for the puzzles, they all give you a lot of clues and they are perfectly beatable for somebody like me who randomly loses their intelligence and perception sometimes.
The series is just absolute masterpiece, nothing more to add.

I've heard the zero escape series for so long and it's appreciate me so much.

Let's start with 999 which is the first game of the series. The game push you to survive all the times. If you not good at puzzle but want to give a try, you might take this game for a trial. The soundtrack is not good but drive the emotion in right place. Finally, the best part of the game is narration and story of all characters which made you enjoy about 20 hours.

The virtue's last reward is the sequel which level-up the series so much. The soundtrack not great but trigger a signal for player in the right moment. Narration and Storyline are upgraded in the amazing way with a lot more interactive and choices. The puzzle is difficult for solve by yourselves every room. The two things I hate are control system which awful for gamepad and there a lot of non-necessary dialogue which pretend me from rushing this game by the way.

If you play VN for a while and want to try difficult puzzle VN game with a stylish plot-twisted. You might be appreciate this game for sure.

It's very hard to get into this game because you have to read/click through to an entire wall of text any time you want to interact with an object. And if you're switching from checking clues to interacting with an object, or realize you need to check a clue again, or try your clue on a different item, you have to read through the entire wall every single time. Done with an object? No you're not, you need to read through another wall of text before you leave the item! Ready to interact with it? No you can't do that yet, read this wall of text first!
Check this out. You will not be disappointed.

When I started these games, I didn't know what to expect. I didn't know anything about their plots, or the game's genres, or game-play. I bought them off of a recommendation, having never heard of them.

These are my favorite games now.

Please do not spoil them for yourself: experience them in real-time. They are the best-written games I've ever played. They're intelligent and witty; they're complex and heart-breaking. The characters are all fleshed out, and the interactions feel human. The tension becomes dire early on and didn't let up for the months of time it took me to get through it (I play games slowly).

The music is outstanding; the dialog is expressive; the voice-acting is sublime.

These characters feel like family, and these games did something no other games ever have: they made me feel like a part of them, more than just a player.

Please play them yourself!

Two of my favorite games of all time in one collection. I've replayed these games twice on my own, and then about three times showing the game to different friends, and I never get tired of it. Feels like every new time I play, I'm learning something new that I hadn't before.

So yeah, that's why I have over 300 hours on this game.

Would absolutely recommend. Went into this mostly blind but found 999 to be a brilliant game, and one of the best VN's I've played. VLR I enjoyed less but it was still pretty great. I wish there was a third game but that does not exist. It never has. Don't look for it. 

The story and atmosphere of 999 is what really sells it for me. It felt like a genuine mystery with multiple well thought out twists in it. The characters were great and I was hooked right to the end, the whole aspect of being trapped in a confined space really adds to this. The continuation of the story in VLR was also intriguing although it suffered glaring plot holes and a plot that goes off the rails. I understand that the games are detached from reality a bit but some of the story elements in VLR were just completely stupid but it is possible to ignore if you just don't think about it too much. I also didn't like the characters as much as they felt more 2-dimensional, with the exception of Phi. I know people who enjoyed VLR more than 999 though, so maybe it is just down to preference. 

The gameplay for both games is pretty standard VN broken up with point and click puzzle rooms. The puzzle rooms in 999 where quite underwhelming and none of them really gave any challenge, with slightly better puzzles in VLR. They weren't bad, just not very puzzling.

I think it took maybe around 40 hours or so to complete both games, with VLR being the longer of the two. Again, would highly recommend this.

You like puzzles? You like reading? You like crazy storylines? Here, these are the games for you. 
I had one bug, where in VLR, when there were the start and end sequences of the puzzles, the sound bugged and it looped a few times before resuming, but nothing game-breaking.

极限脱出系列作为打越钢太郎的优秀作品，十分值得体验一番。作为悬疑推理解密ADV游戏，极限脱出并非使用单纯的线性叙事方式，而是通过玩家的不同选择，来刻意的分化故事的叙事走向，变成多条世界线，每条世界线有自己的线性故事流程，或许没有体验过的玩家可能会觉得这样子不就是碎片化的叙事或是乱序叙事，但打越钢太郎通过自己的剧本创作能力，让每条线都会互相产生影响，从而引出极限脱出的核心设定，为了不剧透，就不过多赘述。
  作为一款十年前就在掌机上推出的老游戏，其游戏玩法和剧本内容还是值得现在的玩家去体验游玩，而解密的部分也并不硬核，只要动动脑大部分都可以轻松解决。
  当然作为ADV游戏方面，虽然剧本设计精妙，但也还是会让人产生一点过于吃设定的感觉，少了一点深度的推理，但是无伤大雅。在999中有些地方会有重复解密的问题，可能会有些乏味，但在之后的善人死亡避免了这一点，所以如果对极限脱出系列有兴趣，还是非常推荐体验游玩。

If you enjoy problem solving, somewhat repetitive game play, escape rooms and a story with a twist + continuity, this is for you. But if you get frustrated with having to "jump around" just to get to the end of one storyline, "strong maybe" would be my recommendation. You have to give this game time and maybe sacrifice a notepad or two. Otherwise 999 is really enjoyable murder mystery, and easy to learn. Virtues Last Reward is more challenging, but has also more rewarding plot lines than 999. The story is very well thought for these two (excluding few Deus Ex Machinas) and the continuity between these two and the Zero Time Dilemma is also mind blowing at times. I hope no one takes too seriously the science in these games.

However, if I have to criticize something: 
1. If you don't work meticulously towards "True Ending" in both games, story seems really messed up and without an actual storyline. I understood VLR way better after finishing 999, and the third game Zero Time Dilemma makes more sense now that I finished VLR. Notepad is recommended for little details that are unused in puzzles/endings.
2. I can't remember is the game tells you this, but you can skip the rooms and choices you've already done in the flowchart. I didn't realize it until I clicked something in the timeline by accident in 999. So you really don't have to do the same choices and rooms over and over again, unless in VLR you want to get all the files.
3. Maybe it's a port issue, but moving around + some puzzles in VLR were ANNOYING to operate. Yes, it was made for DS/Vita originally, so it might not be optimal for mouse clicking. Recommending controller for VLR. 999 works fine with the mouse.

(9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors Review)
999 is the best game I've ever played. Even if it's PC and Console port counterparts ruin the original story and plot, for me I sadly I understood the original idea of "Novel" and "Adventure" being the top and bottoms screens, which allowed me to imagine that. Before going into the ports of 999, I recommend that you understand that the Novel and Adventure screens are two completely separate entities, and that will allow you to enjoy the story a lot more. This is not a game that should be for Gameplay. It's a narrative game, and personally that's the kind of game I like. The gameplay personally is not very entertaining, it's fun, but for me, it felt more like a roadblock, however in specific endings there were some that I really liked because it added more exposition into the story. 

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Story: 10/10.
Music: 10/10.
Art: 10/10.
Gameplay: 6/10.
Replayability: 2/10. (It's a story game.)
Overall: 10/10. The greatest game I've ever played.

nonbiney games!!!

I wish you could rate the two games separately. 

999 is great. Fun escape room mechanics, story that's just convoluted enough to be an adventure. Really my only complaint is Seven's constant mocking of Lotus's age and looks and drooling over Clover. Sir, I'm pretty sure you are 40, you weird pervert, and Lotus has the best design in the game.

Virtue's Last Reward is awful. The escape rooms are still fun, but it's really only worth playing to get you up to speed for the next game [spoiler] since it's basically just an extended prologue anyway [/spoiler]. The characters are pretty uniformly obnoxious and I hate having to spend hours in Sigma's head - he's an idiot, he's gross and he makes terrible decisions ([spoiler] gee, Sigma, the guy blackmailing you has locked himself in a soundproofed box. Seems like a good time to strategize with the rest of the team, maybe make a plan to tackle him when he comes out. Nope, you're just going to die? Okay. [/spoiler]). Also, apparently the game thinks the player is stupid and/or is desperate to triple the running time, because they explain everything no less than three times in a row. I don't actually need a second example of the prisoner's dilemma when I [i]just lived it[/i]. Plus, none of the twists are particularly exciting. 

Tldr: 999 is the best in the series, VLR is worth playing, but barely.

Two parts visual novels, one part room escape puzzle games.

Both 999 and VLR are great in their own right, and have really good characters and writing that deals with some very interesting subjects, neat puzzles 
[i](though 999's are a little too easy)[/i], and top notch music[i](though VLR kinda overuses some tracks)[/i].

Highly recommend this.

Dois excelentes jogos!

Primeiramente, a história de ambos são sensacionais com elementos incríveis como um enredo tão intenso interessante, viciante e, de certa forma, bem complexo. Ambos os jogos lidam com teorias do campo científico que podem confundir um pouco quem não é TÃO ligado assim nelas, no entanto ambos os jogos se dão o esforço de explicar tudo de uma forma concisa e completa para que assim o jogador entenda o que está acontecendo na história do jogo e como essas teorias científicas (que são BEM reais) se encaixam na história com: cenários, personagens, mecânicas e os múltiplos finais que você pode conseguir (recomendo todos).

Segundamente, a gameplay. Ambos os jogos, e até mesmo o terceiro (ZTD), possuem uma gameplay simples. Consiste basicamente em uma Visual Novel com elementos de Escape Rooms que vão te fazer pensar um pouco. Preparem suas calculadoras e bloco de notas porque, se você for tão ruim de memória e matemática como eu, talvez você precise! kkkkkkkk 

Em suma, recomendo muito os jogos e espero que se divirtam com esse emaranhado de informação que são esses jogos!

9時間9人9の扉は面白かったです。
ご都合主義の展開も多いですが、少年マンガ的なノリもありますので熱さとノリでプレイ中はほぼ気になりませんでしたので、１作目はオススメです。
ただ、善人シボウデスはプレイしていて苦痛でした。
スキップできない移動ムービーがイラつくのも、3Dがイマイチな造形でキャラクターの魅力が薄れることもまだ我慢するとしても、１作目と比べて登場キャラクターの性格が悪い人が多すぎて、本当にイライラします。
「いや「善人シボウ」って書いてるでしょ。そういう趣旨なんで」という話なんでしょうけど、
そうは言っても、善人が少なすぎて「なんでこんなクズとアホのために長々とプレイせにゃならんのだ？」という気持ちにさせられます。

キャラクターに魅力がない分、ストーリーに魅力があれば続けるモチベーションも沸くんでしょうけど、どうなんですかね？
これってそんなに魅力的なストーリーです？？って感じでした。
（どこまで行っても、謎の超理論ありきですので「へー、この世界ではそーなんだー」という印象です）

ダブルパックですので避けられないですが、１作目だけを「お手軽脱出ゲーム」として遊ぶのが個人的にはオススメです。

( je fais cuire mon riz alors j'ai le temps vite-fait de mettre un avis sur le jeu )
La réal est déglinguée par rapport au jeu d'origine; les gens qui ont conçu le port n'ont pas fait d'efforts pour conserver l'esprit original, ce qui tue l'apogée de l'intrigue ( et empêche les larmes de couler sur nos joues ).
( maintenant mon riz est cuit donc je vais la faire dans le détail )

J'adore 999 et VLR. Je trouve que ce sont deux bons jeux narratifs.
Je recommande ces jeux sur leur système original, c'est à dire sur DS et 3DS ( ou émulateurs avec filtrage bilinéaire ), mais pas cette version PC.

À l'heure où j'écris ces lignes, je n'ai fini que le port de 999 donc je ne m'adresserai qu'à son sujet, et que de ce qui diffère du jeu d'origine ! ( mais ça me suffit à ne pas recommander le logiciel )

Graphiquement, il est excellent. Tout est bien plus plaisant à regarder que dans l'original, qui est limité par la résolution DS de 240p. Ici, on a le plaisir d'avoir les personnages et décors dans des standards plus communs et ça fait plaisir.
Le doublage ( japonais - je n'ai pas utilisé la version anglaise ), absent de l'original, est pas mal. Cependant, je regrette l'absence d'option pour avoir les "voix" originales des personnages en petis 'bips' de tonalités différentes. La musique, elle, est de meilleure qualité que l'originale, pour la même raison que les images.

Cependant, maintenant que le son et l'image sont expédiés, il reste ce qui lie le tout, la réalisation.
( je ne parlerai pas du scénario car il est identique au deux versions du jeu )

Il y a deux modes d'affichage du texte : Novel mode et Adventure mode.
Adventure mode affiche le discours parlé en bas de l'écran, mais [b]que[/b] le parlé. Et là c'est grave.
Il y a 3 types de discours dans le jeu : le dialogue, le monologue interne, et la narration. Seuls dialogues et monologues sont affichés dans l'adventure mode, ce qui supprime toute la narration du jeu. Ce ne serait pas un problème si la narration était inutile à la compréhension du retournement de situation final [spoiler]( or, la narration fait le retournement de situation )[/spoiler]. Chose atroce, le Adventure mode est le mode par défaut, ce qui fait que l'on peut ne pas se rendre compte du manque de narration. Pire encore, le Novel mode passe en Adventure mode automatiquement de manière régulière.
Mais cataclysmiquement davantage, c'est que le Novel mode, avec tout le texte ( donc le BON mode de jeu ), s'affiche PAR-DESSUS les images. Dans le jeu d'origine, il ne s'agissait que de la narration, tandis que le discours parlé était en bas de l'écran ( comme dans le Adventure mode ). [b]POURQUOI[/b] ne pas avoir repris la réal du jeu d'origine, qui était certes scindée en deux écrans, la faire dans un seul ( ce qui n'aurait géné [b]PERSONNE[/b] ), permettant de profiter du texte intégral et des images / animations remasterisées ?!

[b]Mais l'abjection sur le cake d'atrocités[/b] c'est que la scène finale avec la résolution de l'histoire a été altérée pour convenir à un écran unique, à la place de faire du mode d'affichage d'un seul écran quelque chose de créatif pour retransmettre honnêtement cette scène. Alors qu'elle constituait l'apogée du jeu, et la raison principale pour laquelle on peut recommander 999, elle est ici d'une absence émotionnelle profonde, tant d'artifices sont usés pour nous la transmettre.
L'expérience frappante de la résolution du dernier puzzle a par contre été complètement supprimée pour nous laisser un micmac incompréhensiblement artificiel à la place.

Je le redis, si ce jeu vous intéresse, jouez-y avec la version originale ;D
( et après avoir séché vos larmes, allez jouer à VLR )

Great VN/Puzzle hybrids.

Playing them chronologically (999 first, VLR second) is recommended. VLR has a handy note feature to write down passwords/work for puzzles.

Overall I'd give them a +1.

999 review: What an experience I urge you not to look into this game at all do not spoil yourself. Do look up a spoiler free guide that will take you through the endings as getting every ending in orders of 1-6 really make the story come together in a certain way that makes the story flow seamlessly while you scramble to determine the truth. The only other game series that game me the same thrill and desire for the truth was Danganronpa. If you are a fan of Danganronpa I urge no I Implore you to play this game and just feel those emotions flow once more. This is such a unique story tied to the game design its really wild what they did here. 
         Im still freshly mindfucked from beating this game and I just want even more. I just really wanted [spoiler] A front shot of Alice cuz from the back Goddamnnn [/spoiler] This story really throws curb balls consantly and will have you second guessing and doubling back on information. The only real con to this game other than replaying the events over and over for different endings and not having a straight up skip section button is the math puzzles are tedious as hell especially if you hate math get ready to bust the guide out for this one.


          VLR Review: Wow what can I say. They took this idea established in the first game and made it even crazier. Made it dependent now on the prisoners dilemma a much more interesting and difficult notary game. The plot is even crazier and takes even more advantage of game mechanics. 24 endings a daunting task but well worth the investment.  VLR further goes down the rabbithole of [spoiler] time travel and dimension hopping with the use of ones mind[/spoiler]. You thought 999 was difficult to follow you aint seen shit yet. Just wait for this rounds mind fucking. 
          VLR improves on what 999 did in every way except certain puzzles being tedious and the changing of the 2D animeish models to the 3D models. Had the models been a higher res and able to convey emotions better ( and have teeth) I would not mind heck I probably would have preferred it but alas it doesnt age very well compared to the 2d models of 999. The other massive issue I have with this game that actually really fucking bothers the shit out of me is [spoiler] Sigma constantly getting antagonized hard when he would pick any betrayal options or when he would get 9 points he would have really bad endings and almost never escaped while almost everyone else gets to escape when they had the points. Its such bullshit he really should of escaped almost all those 9 point scenarios.[/spoiler] But the plot twists are even more crazy than 999. 
             There's a good chance you won't be able to predict certain things unless you are extremely keen. The funniest part ? VLR ends on an even bigger cliff hanger than 999. You are left with more questions than answers just like the previous title but now you really left hanging. Heck I wasn't sure I finished the game until I saw I had all the trophies.
          I gotta say I did not [spoiler] See Sigma being zero coming that was a wild plot twist same with akane and junpei being in the game low key as fuck[/spoiler] If you loved 999 your going to drop to your knees with this one. I'll see you guys in ZTD hopefully they will have some answers for us.
It's pretty good

Review for 999 only since I haven't had the time or motivation to play VLR except for the veeery first puzzle:

I dropped this for a year halfway through 999 (well, sort of—two bad ends in), finally came back recently to finish it off on my friend's recommendation. Being vague not to spoil anything, the main plot point is pretty cool, and comes with some music I really loved that worked great to build up the atmosphere. The reveal at the end mostly explains the strange behaviours of the other characters throughout the story, but in my opinion doesn't make the writing's flaws much better. Could be personal taste but I still don't like the constant pseudoscience/conspiracy theory info dumping. It's simultaneously too out there for me to suspend belief properly, especially given the random timing the characters choose to do so, and a bit spooky in a way I don't enjoy. The story's ending wasn't particularly satisfying, though may be remedied by VLR (again I wouldn't know). So it has some good moments, but it can be a slog to get to them. For context I was about 6 hours in when I originally dropped it, and I don't think I would have come back if not for my friend. I wouldn't say I regret picking it up again but I'm pretty meh about it. 

The puzzles are just okay. Didn't have too much trouble except for one where I got stuck due to a silly oversight. The puzzles didn't give me any Aha!/Eureka moments which is what I would play a puzzle game for. I hear they get harder later in the series but can't vouch for that.

2022.5.4，999通关纪念，善人死亡打完再说。
15个小时左右通关，流程不算太长，而且大部分时间都是在看密室。相比较于剧情，感觉密室设计的很突兀，有些密室里的谈话或者互动或者埋伏笔，就算是正常的剧情也可以完成，在正常的剧情中穿插密室，然后在密室里面放剧情，仅从游戏体验来看，比较不友好。
另外，这作除了终章的拼图，最后一处密室是在图书馆旁边的杂物间，打完之后建议直接找个攻略视频通关，找没有批话的，NDS双界面的视频，终章演出双屏体验更好。
另外找攻略时，B站有个叫天堂的up，小标题上有剧透，而且批话特别多，建议不看。

2022.5.14，善人死亡通关纪念。
无与伦比的剧本，终章全部都是爆点。虽然在打越的剧本中插入密室逃脱这个做法很粪，但粪不掩瑜。
剧情中和别人闲聊重复了多次的信息和物品定义是伏笔，不合理的地方是伏笔，连凑数的死亡线都有伏笔。
之前过死亡剧情的时候还在吐槽，别人开老九门能闪过其他人的攻击，唯独主角闪不过去，没想到这里都能埋伏笔。
然后有关这作的攻略，刚出来门三选一，建议按123或者213的顺序打，我是123顺推，不过打完之后觉得最优顺序应该是213。
然后如果不想打密室，可以参考B站yqymyxs的视频攻略，关掉弹幕就行。

剧情：打越钢太郎的剧本不用说了，无敌。999节奏更紧凑些，游戏初期很快就能代入，推理起来也方便；善人死亡毕竟基于前作，不用交代太多基础世界观，因此剧情和人物（名字一开始都记不清）庞大复杂得多，就是前期推起来有点头痛，另外结局有点意犹未尽，几个BE也是比较敷衍。

my favourite door opening/closing simulator.

jokes aside 999 is one of the best games of all time in my opinion. a true masterpiece. it's been over 6 months since i first played this game and i still think about it every day. the music is still always stuck in my head and the characters, especially junpei and akane, are living rent free in there too. i genuinely have zero complaints about the whole trilogy, even though a lot of people don't like zero time dilemma. these games mean a lot to me; i was so immersed especially going through 999 for the first time - it was a nice escape from reality. you will never ever find any other game that gives the same feeling. zero escape has its own special charm that no other visual novels have - the story is incredibly unique and keeps you wanting to learn more. the way you are given small bits of information through different escape rooms is brilliant because of the realisation when you get to the true end where everything starts to make sense, like all the pieces of the puzzle finally fit together. VLR is also a very good game, love the whole theme of alliance or betrayal and its ending was certainly interesting. both are near flawless games. some will say 999 was better on DS but the voice acting in this version is top tier. junpei's voice actor is my personal favourite with his iconic 'What the hell?!' every 5 minutes. overall, these 2 games are amazing, i highly recommend them to anyone who likes Your Turn to Die and Danganronpa although ZE takes a lot more thinking. perfect story, characters and music. the escape rooms are also very fun! i was debating buying this for quite a while but it ended up being one of the best decisions i've ever made. soooo worth it. you will have no regrets and will be heavily invested within the first 10 minutes. if you enjoy 999 and VLR i recommend playing the 3rd game ZTD as well, but it won't be everyone's cup of tea.

thank you Uchikoshi for making one of the best and most memorable games of all time. i just wish it would get the recognition it deserves.

Spike Chunsoft never fails to disappoint me.

Both games are genius puzzle/adventure games, where the main game loop is split between escape rooms and visual-novel style dialogue. The puzzles are quite good, with some real difficult ones. If you're willing to work through them, I was able to complete both games without a guide. My favorite thing about the game is probably the characters though. There are so many weird and cool ones, my personal favorites being K and Clover. The stories are gripping too, with a connected story that had me very confused and surprised throughout the entirety of both games. 

I will say, if you are unable to suspend your disbelief, they are filled with a lot of fake science jargon and convoluted plots, so they may not be for you. If you are also not a fan of reading long stretches of dialogue in between game play, this is also not for you.

Overall, I'd give this game a 9/10. It's not quite Danganronpa, but it is still very good.

极限脱出999我是在PC上用小鸡模拟器玩的NDS版，NDS有上下两个屏幕可以同时看到两个画面，steam版只有一个屏幕需要玩家自己切换画面，两个能同时看到的屏幕这个设定对剧情很重要，玩家自己切换画面玩体验会比较差。999解谜难度适中，剧情也比较紧凑。作为系列开山之作很优秀。善人之死解谜难度比较大，涉及到很多计算费脑子容易卡关。剧情有一点拖沓，各角色刻画不如第一部吸引人。建议喜欢999男主的玩家做好心理准备再去玩第三部零时困境。

I don't even know how to put my love and appreciation for these games in words... I just finished VLR today and WOW!! Both of these games completely blew me away! 999 was amazing and VLR really brought everything to a whole new level!
I really had no expectations coming into these and all I knew is that the games had escape rooms, were visual novel style, and had some choice-based aspect. I cannot believe I haven't checked them out sooner!!  Many times throughout both games I was left in shock, jaw dropped! The story and details are so good and thought-provoking! I was SO immersed into these games that I was constantly trying to piece together the mysteries on my notepad the whole time and was feeling so many emotions constantly.
Another aspect I really liked were the subtle thriller aspects, and the soundtrack really helped to build up really tense moments. I also loved the 2D art style in 999! I know a lot of people complain about the art style of VLR but after a few hours getting into the game I didn't mind.
That being said, if you aren't a fan of visual novel/escape room games you may struggle to enjoy them as much as I did, but  if you do, boy do I recommend!!! Can't wait to play ZTD!

RMS Titanic was a British passenger liner, operated by the White Star Line, which sank in the North Atlantic Ocean on 15 April 1912 after striking an iceberg during her maiden voyage from Southampton, UK, to New York City. Of the estimated 2,224 passengers and crew aboard, more than 1,500 died, which made the sinking possibly one of the deadliest for a single ship up to that time.[a] It remains to this day the deadliest peacetime sinking of a superliner or cruise ship.[4] The disaster drew much public attention, provided foundational material for the disaster film genre, and has inspired many artistic works.

RMS Titanic was the largest ship afloat at the time she entered service and the second of three Olympic-class ocean liners operated by the White Star Line. She was built by the Harland and Wolff shipyard in Belfast. Thomas Andrews, who was the chief naval architect of the shipyard at that time, died in the disaster.[5]

Titanic was under the command of Captain Edward Smith,[6] who went down with the ship. The ocean liner carried some of the wealthiest people in the world, as well as hundreds of emigrants from Great Britain and Ireland, Scandinavia and elsewhere throughout Europe, who were seeking a new life in the United States and Canada.

The first-class accommodation was designed to be the pinnacle of comfort and luxury, with a gymnasium, swimming pool, libraries, high-class restaurants, and opulent cabins. A high-powered radiotelegraph transmitter was available for sending passenger "marconigrams" and for the ship's operational use.[7] The Titanic had advanced safety features, such as watertight compartments and remotely activated watertight doors.

The ship was equipped with 16 lifeboat davits, each capable of lowering three lifeboats, for a total of 48 boats; the Titanic carried only 20 lifeboats, four of which were collapsible and proved hard to launch while the ship was sinking.[8] Together, the 20 lifeboats were capable of holding 1,178 people—which was only about half the number of passengers on board, and only one-third of the number of passengers that the ship could have carried at full capacity (this was consistent with the maritime safety regulations of the era). In addition, when the ship sank, many of the lifeboats that had been lowered were only about half full.
those were definitely video games

I never played the original release of the game and as such i cannot speak to the conversion from DS to PC.

However, I thought the games were amazing! I don't think I've experienced this great a VN since Higurashi. In fact, like higurashi, half the fun for me was to have a notepad beside me while playing and figure out the who, the what, and the why, along with the characters (999 was much harder in that respect than VLR).

It is not a perfect game however. Between the very limited in-game menu and launcher, it's very annoyingly difficult to change game settings; the graphics, particularly in VLR have not aged well. I feel like they wanted to make use of the 3DS's "new" 3D technology, but the 3D models have aged much worse than the 2D models from the first game; also the story is somewhat complicated [spoiler] that is the risk with any story that involves timetravel as an integral part of the plot. [/spoiler] 

Having said that, the story is amazing, even if the main character is an idiot some times...

The Nonary game was indeed an intriguing story.
999 is an excellent puzzle game for new-comers in this medium, the puzzles were neither too hard nor too easy and the characters constantly guided the player through the deadlocks, but after the ending I kinda understand why this game should have been exclusively on the DS since the story executive can only work perfectly alongside with the DS game system so the Steam lost a bit of charm which can only be experienced on the original supposed platform.
VLR on the other hand, work perfectly on other platforms with no story element was missed, but the puzzles were astronomically harder compared to 999 for someone who is terrible at Mathematics like myself. The game system executed the story extremely well with numerous twist-and-turn making blind choices really entertaining, but characters-wise almost none of them was lovable in contrast to 999.

So far the puzzles are interesting. It isn't particularly hard yet, but the flow feels satisfying. i do wish more emphasis was put on what search was, since it is very useful. also accidentally started over messing with timeline before it was explained,

Fantastic! If you love Phoenix Wright games and are a fan of the show Squid Games (although these precede the show). It puts you the main character in a very suspenseful-frightening situation. I say Phoenix Wright because it is a visual novel but with an adventure point and click style of play; in no way is this game comparable other than the gameplay, there is no trial if you like that side of Phoenix Wright I would recommend the Danganronpa series. In this you solve puzzles to figure out your way through the game. I definitely recommend this! You won't be disappointed if you like visual novel style games!

The downside to these games? MATH.

Otherwise, great visual novel/puzzle games! 999 can be played stand alone yet the intricate story that's weaved in VLR sucks you in and connects the two in such a satisfying way.

Definitely recommended if you don't have math anxiety, the community guides are incredibly helpful in that area.

At first I bought this game in the summer for my birthday because why not and it seemed fun. After playing around. losing my progress and finally today only finishing 999 I can say without a doubt that this is one of the best games I've ever played and I haven't even touched the second game. The way the story slowly but beautifully shows you how everything is connected and how each ending shows you the pretty or ugly sides of the characters. It's such a masterpiece. The escape rooms vary in difficulty but I usually find them fun aside from the frustrating puzzle here and there. I would totally recommend this game or 999 at least because it felt so real to me. When the characters (or Junpei) yelled I yelled, when they questioned things I questioned things, when they cried I cried, when they laughed I laughed and finally when they smiled I smiled too. This game has been such a journey and I can't wait to see what VLR has in store for my playing experience. :D

Je recommande ces deux jeux mais en particulier le premier, je m'explique :

Les énigmes sont pas trop difficiles mais certaines m'ont fait ruminer dans Virtue's Last Reward, même en cherchant la solution sur internet la logique n'as parfois aucun sens. Par exemple l'énigme dans la pièce avec les robots, où il faut se souvenir des yeux rouges "Left" pour l'oeil gauche, et "Right" pour l'oeil droit, mais quelle droite et quelle gauche ?? Dans certaines énigmes c'est assez évident et intuitif mais dans d'autres c'est bourré d'incohérences et il faut tenter plusieurs combinaisons avant de deviner.

L'histoire de VLR n'est pas aussi bonne que celle du premier jeu, sans trop spoiler, le retournement de situation à la fin où on se rends compte dans quel lieu on est, n'as aucun sens. 
Pareil pour d'autres retournement de situations, où, quand on se rends compte sur le moment, tout au long de l'histoire ça n'aurait pas pu marcher, parce que bon sang faut pas abuser ils sont pas débiles les personnages... et pourtant à cause de ces incohérences tout porte à croire que si. 

Graphiquement parlant j'ai eu beaucoup de mal à passer de la 2D à la 3D pour les personnages mais on s'y fait. Le plus dérangeant était probablement la voix du personnage principal qui n'as pas été doublée. 

Les musiques sont excellentes mais manque de variété étant donné qu'ils reprennent la plupart des musiques du premier jeu. 

J'ai eu aussi beaucoup de mal à m'attacher aux personnages du second jeu car leur background et leurs secrets étaient beaucoup trop pas originaux, ils ont pas innovés pour le coup.

Two masterpieces. Highly recommend playing 9 hours, 9 persons, 9 doors how it was originally meant on the DS if at all possible. It's very unique and important in a way plot-wise, only something two screens can do. Although less impactful in the remaster with the final puzzle being butchered, it is still very good for the quality of life changes and if you like voice acting added in.

This game is long, but it was 100% worth the time it takes to play! The puzzles are just the right amount of difficult and fun, and the twists don't stop coming. I just love this game!!

Absolutely one of the best Mystery/Puzzle Visual Novel out there and can't recommend it enough. The puzzle's aren't overly complicated and are fairly simple once you get the hang of it although a few of the puzzle in the game can be quite annoying and pain in the ass. Both of the 999 and VLR's Escape Room are filled with different themes that kept it fresh throughout the entire game. The included voice acting definitely make me more immersed into the game but it is fine without it as well because the mystery element of the game keeps me on the edge of my seat. Both of the game is by no means perfect but all I can say without spoiler is that the story is interesting and have many plot twists which i thoroughly enjoyed. If i were to choose between 999 and VLR, I would give the edge on 999 because i felt more attached to the characters and the story. The OST for both games are amazing and fits perfectly with their respective game. 

If there's one thing i would to complain about the game is that they didn't include the SWIMSUIT PHI. I waited so long for it yet until the end I didn't get anything at all. Jokes aside, the game does have it's flaws such as the translation sometimes may be slightly off and some of the terms where changed from Japanese to English making it less accurate which honestly doesn't break the game at all, you can still play the game fine. I personally don't mind it but i do hope they include the SWIMSUIT scene.

 [*] Визуальная часть - мертва. Она не только не прошла проверку временем,она еще и ужасна даже по меркам того времени.Ужасные 3д модельки от которых устают глаза,как и в некоторых головоломках. Анимации и ролики на пару секунд как небесная мана раз в 10 часов.

 [*] Сюжет мыльная опера в которой довольно сложно понять механику некоторых вещей.Да и сама часть некая ~25 часовая почти бессмысленная подвязка к 3й части в которой должен быть самый сок.
[*] Логика персонажей решивших принять участие просто гениальная ,мы готовы ради своей цели умереть,но умереть от 0 поинтов в игре на смерть мы не хотим.
[*] Концовки где 9 поинтов. Если какой-либо персонаж наберет его свободно отпустят побубнев чутка.Но если 9 очков у sigmabolls ,то тот получит по шее ,в смерительную рубашку и смэрт.
[/list]

ゲームの内容上ネタバレはできないので全体的な所感を書いていきます。

・ゲームのイメージとしては脱出ゲームになった逆転裁判といった感じです。
他に言い換えるとするならシュタインズ・ゲートやEver17などのinfinityシリーズに脱出ゲームが組み合わさったゲームといったイメージになります。
・1作目（9時間9人9の扉）の難易度は結構低めで、脱出ゲームを経験していない人でも進めることは容易だと思います。
・逆に2作目（善人シボウデス）はヒントが1作目より乏しく謎解きの難易度はそれなりです。
ただ、難易度がHARDとEASYの二つあり途中で変更可能なため、詰まったら難易度を変更して突破することはできます。
・2作目は1作目から話が繋がってるため、こだわりが無ければ“1作目→2作目”という順にやることをお勧めします。

ゲーム自体は結構面白かったので脱出ゲームやADV好きにはおススメです。
ただ、全シナリオを見た後でも「結局あの件は何だったんだ…？」という粗さや未解明な点がちょいちょいあったのが不満点になります。

An issue I sometimes have with visual novels is that there isn't anything to play. There are some with a lot of choices, and others that you mainly click through. Some of those clicky ones are fantastic, of course- I love Higurashi- but this game isn't one of those. It's a visual novel, well, two visual novels, with plenty of routes to play through, and escape rooms to complete. The escape rooms are sometimes easy and sometimes harder. The game allows you to skip around, replay dialogue, or view only new content as you try to collect all of the endings with its flowchart system. The story is wild and kept me interested the whole way through.

In this case, you've really got to see all the endings to understand the full picture. In 999, the true ending cannot be the first one you get; it isn't possible. You'll have to try again, choosing different options, to get a new ending. I recommend getting all of them, personally. A spoiler-free guide is also helpful, just to find the correct routes. In VLR, the story is told through the various endings, and you learn new information by picking different combinations of choices. There's really no guide necessary. You can play the choices in any order, and the game will stop you at certain points to have you play through different routes before you can progress that section of the story any further.

Basically, I strongly recommend this game. For fans of escape rooms, psychological dramas, anime, and visual novels, there will be something to enjoy.

999 and VLR were both life-changing games for me and I was so happy to be able to experience them again in this bundle! 999 remake did a fantastic job with its great voice acting and additions to the quality-of-life such as a flowchart which easily made me consider whether this game is better than the DS version. For narrative purposes, I do believe the original 999 is better, but you are still going to enjoy this version even if it is your first go around. 
VLR is pretty much just a port so there's nothing too much to say there in terms of differences, but just know you are still getting a fantastic game that definitely lives up to its predecessor.

Este pack incluye dos juegos en uno, la primera (Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors, 999) y segunda parte (Virtue's Last Reward). Para vivir la experiencia completa, recomiendo jugar a ambos en ese orden, y continuar con la tercera y última parte (Zero Time Dilemma), que se puede comprar aparte también en Steam.

Advertir que ninguno de los dos están traducidos al castellano. Y en ellos hay mucho texto y conversaciones, aunque el nivel es bajo-medio. 

El primero es un juego más corto y conciso, con puzzles relativamente sencillos (a mi parecer). Tiene un final más o menos cerrado, aunque dejando cosillas en el tintero y apertura a una continuación. Es un juego divertido, intrigante y con una historia atrapante. Adoro las conversaciones aleatorias que tienen los personajes de vez en cuando y que te aporta información importante del juego a base de historias y recuerdos que cuentan sus protagonistas, de forma muy espontánea y natural. El clímax de la historia es bastante original, aunque un poquito "lioso" en su entendimiento (no entro en detalles para no spoilear).

Con respecto al segundo, hay cosas que me han gustado más y otras menos. Es un juego más largo, con más finales y conversaciones, lo que te permite conocer mejor a los personales y sus respectivas historias. Por otro lado, los puzzles son mucho más variados y desafiantes, lo cual es maravilloso para los amantes de este género. A mi parecer, su punto fuerte y débil al mismo tiempo es el "enrevesamiento" de la historia, conectada directamente con la anterior entrega. Es sumamente interesante enterarte de todo lo que pasa y darle un sentido, ya que se nota mucho mimo en la forma de contar la historia y en las ideas que quiere el juego plantear, pero a la hora de ejecutarlas se puede hacer algo lento o tedioso (muchos finales, mucho "dar vueltas" en la rama de decisiones). Sin embargo, en el final del juego se resuelven muchos de los temas y enigmas planteados, dejando otros abiertos súper importantes que espero continúen en la última parte. Y de las peores cosas que tiene este juego son las transiciones yendo de un lugar a otro. Es horrible. Tampoco me convence el diseño 3D de los personajes, pero supongo que te acabas acostumbrando. 

A pesar de los puntos flacos de ambas entregas, creo que la experiencia es lo suficientemente interesante y original para jugarla. ¡No os la perdáis si os gusta el género, una buena historia y los giros de guión! Eso sí, juntos suman una media de 60-70 horas. Una duración bastante alta para el promedio de novelas visuales.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is a collection of the 1st and 2nd games in the Zero Escape Trilogy, by the names: (999:  Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors) and (Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward).

I just finished playing the 2nd game, and I thought I'd collect my thoughts here (SPOILER FREE) while the games are still fresh in my head.

Zero Escape 1 (999):

The game was originally released in 2009 on the Nintendo DS, and it is a point and click, escape room-mystery novel. This remastered steam version allows for both Mouse & Keyboard, and Controller use. I personally used the latter option. 

There are a lot of reasons why you might want to check out this game, whether you being a fan of puzzle solving, detective novels, or anything the psychological-mystery genre has to offer. 
The story is very well thought out and contains a lot of interesting, and hard to predict plot twists.
Almost all of the characters are very well-written with fleshed out personalities and backgrounds that make them relatable and very likable (for the most part). 

In terms of graphics, it is definitely a little bit dated, but it looks really good considering the game is more than 10 years old by this point. I can confidently say that the sound quality is a 10/10, and the voice acting is perfect in both the JP and EN language. 
Overall, [999: Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors] gets a strong 9/10 from me.

Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward:

Virtue's Last Reward, or "VLR" was released less than 3 years after it's previous entry, in 2012, on the Nintendo 3DS and Playstation Vita. 
This one is going to be more of a hit or miss for some people, mainly due to the "shift" in artstyle.
VLR made the jump from animated 2D sprites, to full-on CGI character models. But the thing is, as mentioned before, this was an early 3DS game. So as you can imagine, the quality of the visuals is not that great. 
But for those that don't really get bothered by stuff like that, I've got great news!

As I mentioned before, 999's story is really, really good. Arguably, I'd say VLR has an even better story. Now of course, that is entirely subjective, and I can't exactly tell you why I feel this way since that would include major spoilers. So just take it with a grain of salt.

When it comes to sound, same as before, it is flawless. Especially, the voice perfomances for the cast of VLR is outstanding, and the soundtracks are great too.

Overall, [Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward] gets a 9,5/10 from me. The visuals lowers its score slightly but the characters, the story and the overarching mysteries more than make up for it.

Conclusion: This is mainly a way for me to gather my current thoughts in text-format so that I have a way of looking back in the future, with the added bonus of hopefully convincing someone to give the series a go. 

I am super happy that I found this series, and I regret not having done so earlier.
Looking forward to playing the 3rd game, see you (maybe) with a "review" after I'm done with that! :)

Two amazing story-based experiences in one neat package.

Both 999 and VLR take place in an isolated area where you have to escape. To break free, you'll have to solve interactive escape rooms along with 8 other people who each have their own share of secrets. There are multiple routes and endings based on your decisions, and each answer opens up twice as many questions for a fun and enriching experience.

I can't recommend these games enough. They both have amazing stories and were super addicting to play through.

The first game is a 9/10. The puzzles were decent, intuitive, logical and If you're playing the game just for the story I recommend doing it with a guide so that you don't spend too much time on trial & error solving the puzzles but that's what zero escape is, solving escape room puzzles.

The second game "graphical improvement" felt more like a downgrade. They went from 2D to 3D and everyone knows 2D > 3D [strike]when it comes to waifus[/strike]. It can also get very repetitive when trying to unlock the true ending, you can fast forward the repetitive dialog but then there's some alternative dialog that happens and you have to read/listen the same dialog because you may actually skip the one sentence that got changed. The puzzles becomes exceedingly harder, which is a good thing for fan of the series.

I wouldn't go out of my way to say this game is a masterpiece as a lot of people claim. Most of them are probably getting exposed to the Schrodinger cats cliche in VN's for the very first time. 

I would give the 2nd game a 9 for the memes but it's a 7/10 imo. Visual downgrade, the pacing was slow and repetitive, the puzzles were good.

Play them in order and to completion to enjoy the next one in the intended way.

The puzzles are good. Maybe 1 or 2 puzzles in each game need a nudge clue if you really take you time.

The puzzles become stronger as the series progresses. 

If you like escape rooms/VERY unique story and presentation/different endings/good characters that you mostly care about then this series is for you (Please play and complete them in order. please!)

If they make another in this series, I'd buy it ASAP!

The Zero Escape series is one of the best series I've ever gotten to play among the mystery, who-dunnit genre. Playing 999 and then getting to play VLR on the 3DS perfectly encapsulated why the Zero Escape franchise made itself scoot into the 3 iconic games that define the who-dunnit genre, alongside the Ace Attorney and the Danganronpa franchises. 

I played VLR first on the 3DS, and while it wasn't convenient for story chronology, it was what got me hooked to the series, and I recall cowering in bed with the lights off regretting my choices to play in the dark. The sheer thrill and terror that comes with the Zero Escape games is just astonishing, and the level of fright that accompanies new information is an experience on its own. 

I got to witness that thrill once again in 999 through its ported remake. The story, the connections, the intricacy in detail of each character and the inevitable realisation of the impact of the number '9' made 999 one of the best journeys I get to say I experienced. It has taken me back to playing Ace Attorney and Danganronpa like I was talking to their sibling. Zero Escape just hits a special place in my heart. 

These three games are what have made me love the genre so much, with how effortlessly they combine thrill, mystery, and excitement, whether its pointing fingers at players stuck in an underwater ship, escaping the confines of a barred-up high school, or finding the identity of a killer who took the life of a prosecutor's father. 

For players who wish to experience the fright that comes with escaping out of a locked room and running away from an anonymous killer, try Zero Escape for a try. For Danganronpa or Ace Attorney fans looking for more excitement much like games like there, try the Nonary Games. I implore to you all. You won't regret it.

As far as a super story rich game, or games here goes as it contains Nonary and Virtue's Last Reward, it's really good all in all. Individually I have specific criticisms but I like how the games have been so far.

Nonary games between the two is my absolute favourite. How the plot goes and how literally the concept (which I won't explain as it would expose spoilers imo) plays out is really well done. Escape rooms were really well done although there was one minor hiccup that I had to look online to clarify, which was really the misclick of the wrong precise place (not a puzzle, just to interact with something you logically would know how to do but the game has something else you can interact with to block the way). The soundtrack is pree nice as well, and I do wish that there was one as part of the games you can still get (as far as I'm aware you only snagged the mini-OST if you pre-ordered the game?).

I was a little put off of Virtue's Last Reward's transition to 3D but it still makes the game work well with it's puzzles, which some I admit were arguably hard. The plot did stretch out a lot more which made skipping through repeat dialogue tedious even with the skip function. But given the games do all follow the storyline-ish, it does make sense. It was good, but not as great as the original Nonary game.

If anything the both shared which I would give criticism about, it's really just the soundtrack not being separate to purchase digitally on here past the one condition you pre-ordered it before the game's release. As far as it is on the internet, 999 is hard to find, and VLR is around somewhere...

Zero Escape is a classic series with interesting themes, great puzzles, and brilliant plot twists, and I dived into it only with the best expectations. But after 70 hours of playing, I can say that this series is for those who are gifted with unwavering strong tolerance to tons of bullcrap it offers throughout the course of the game.

Writings for some routes are flawed and nonsensical. It's not unusual for the characters to think and act inconsistently just so the routes can end in their respective manners. For real, there is no need to provide us 9+ endings in VLR if you're just gonna half-ass half of them.

God, it was so infuriating. Both 999 and VLR had promising start but towards the end I really couldn't care less. Some characters needed to shut the fuck up that I found myself aggressively pressing the spacebar, then discovering brilliant feature called allskip, then proceeding to drop the game at once - and for all, who knows.

If I could give this game a sideways thumb or a "recommend to certain people" then this game would get that. There's a lot to love and a lot to hate about the entire Zero escape trilogy. 

Pros: 
-A lot of plot twists, [b]most[/b] of which are foreshadowed brilliantly and leave you reeling when you put them all together.
-Impressive voice acting. The english localization had a lot of talented people. The only voice that got annoying was Zero III in VLR, and I can't even bring myself to hate that because Cindy Robinson came across like she was having the time of her life.
-Characters are distinct, three-dimensional, and layered. Even with the... high volume of dialogue (and I don't mean it was loud), it took a while for me to get tired of seeing these characters interact. 
-Your choices actually matter, even the ones that look like they don't. In VLR, whether or not one character dies depends on what color your first door choice is. 
-Even with all the flaws I'm about to list, the story and gameplay had me hooked from minute one. I didn't want to shut down my computer at night to go to sleep because I wanted to see more.

Cons: (Most of these are about VLR)
-Some of the plot twists just outright don't make sense, particularly in VLR. [spoiler] Turns out that the whole thing takes place on the moon, but also they had a disease that slows down your brain so they didn't notice the lower gravity, except for Phi who figured out she could jump ultra-high and nobody else tried it. Even then, Phi didn't realize that she was somewhere with lower gravity than Earth. Why? No reason. Nothing about the "it was on the moon" plot twist makes any sense. [/spoiler]
-A couple of plot points are treated like they're important only to get dropped almost immediately. 
In 999 and VLR: [spoiler] Alice being implied to be the frozen egyptian priestess at the end of 999, only to find out that her name and ethnicity and jewelry and hairstyle and face shape and general appearance are all a coincidence. [/spoiler]
In VLR: [spoiler] Luna revealing that the bracelets can be taken off with aluminum foil only for it to never come up again. [/spoiler]
-MATH. SO. MUCH. MATH.
-The characters never shut up. Good god, they don't stop TALKING. Once I figured out how to enable Allskip in VLR (options from the main menu), it got easier when I went back to parts of the flowchart I'd been to before. As far as I'm aware, there is no such option in 999, so when I accidentally triggered June's lecture on the Titanic for the third time, my only option was to spam click through it. 
-The story towards the end of 999 and throughout all of VLR is very dense and hard to follow at times. 

Pro/Con: (Depending on who you are)
-These games are very cerebral. Obviously they're puzzle games, so that's kind of a given, but characters will frequently go off on tangents about subjects that I've only ever seen in textbooks until now (or, more often, never heard of at all). The very concept of the game hinges on concepts in quantum physics. Yes, I'm serious.
-Characters are often hypocritical and get mad at the main character for things they themselves have done. This can either be seen as more realistic or more annoying.

This is mostly a review of 999. Though VLR is just as good, if not better, it takes a long time to get going.
And I truly believe this game is worth the price for the first title alone. There will be no spoilers, considering the need to preserve player experience, but I hope I can convince anyone reading this of why they should buy The Nonary Games. 

999 was my first ever visual novel from a couple years back. 
It was my first spark of passion for games and writing beyond just curiosity. 
And for the longest time, it was my favorite game of all time. 

As the years went by, my love for it held strong, but that position didn't. 
Maybe I was forgetting the exact details. Or the captivation of new favorites; Nier Automata, FF7, etc
held priority. 

But in the span of a single replay, this game took back that spot. 
I can't begin to explain how masterful this game truly is. 

Every mechanic, character, design choice, dialogue intention and setting are crafted to serve the story. 
Not a second is wasted. Real world integration manages to make it grounded and relatable throughout. 

That's inspiring to say the least. 

Now, the game isn't without flaws. 
From the somewhat hamfisted conversations to the repetition of details just pointed out; 
It can get annoying, even halfway through the game. 

But trust me when I say that it's worth every second. 
Especially when that halfway point is only about 7 hours and filled with tons of interesting/necessary setup. 
Setup that pays off. 

I have played and experienced so much since my first playthrough of this game as a kid, even so, no piece of media has managed to blow my mind this much. 

I'm proud to say that 999 has changed my life. 
It's the reason for so much of who I am today and coming back to it, only reaffirms that. 
This game deserves to be tried. It may not be loved by many. Some may even hate it. 
But for those willing to give it a chance. I promise you won't regret it. 

I've said thank you to a lot of creators and for me, it's the greatest showing of respect.
Thank you Kotaro Uchikoshi. Thank you Zero Escape.

Now, where to begin... There are many things I wish to tell you... But unfortunately, our time is limited. As such, the information I can provide is also limited. I have chosen two things of great importance to tell you. 

First, I will tell you about termites. Hm, in retrospect, I suppose that's a rather odd thing to say. I imagine you look rather bewildered right now. Perfectly understandable. The person who kidnapped you and threatened you with death is lecturing you about insects. I suspect it hardly seems fair. Nonetheless, this is very important. In a way, it will determine your fate. So I ask that you listen carefully.

 Have you ever seen a termite mound? They are splendid structures. Some might even call them works of art. Termites are natural architects, and their mounds are both structurally sound and make excellent use of space. So are they following some sort of plan as they build? Are there termite blueprints, detailing which room goes where? No. Of course no. Each termite is simply an oblivious cog in a tremendous machine programmed by millions of years of termite DNA. It is doubtful an individual termite has any idea what its contributions are helping to create. But a human does. We can appreciate the elegant forms of their alien cathedrals... We can see the simple beauty of their perfect functionality... We can understand the splendid planning of their structure...

 In other words, only an intelligence of a higher order can understand the beauty of what the termite builds. Now consider humans. Why are we alive? Why do we love, and give birth? Why do we create? From where do our cultures spring? There are many theories, but no one knows the truth. We are oblivious cogs in a tremendous machine programmed by millions of years of human DNA. No doubt you see now what this analogy is supposed to illustrate. Yes, I mean to say humans are not different from termites. We trudge through our lives with no greater understanding of our ultimate goal. You might say we don't understand what we're building. Only an intelligence of a higher order than ours can understand what we're doing. Imagine how we might look to such an intelligence... We may be building some structure so perfect and elegant we can't even perceive it. Whatever it is, we've likely been building it on a dimension just above the ones we know since time immemorial.

 If we are like the termites, then what we've created is almost certainly something of tremendous beauty. And you are about to catch a glimpse of it. Or have you already...? Well, that's enough on that subject, I think. Consider what I've said.

[i]Please note that while I'm giving this collection a thumb down, it is primarily to provide a counterpoint to the many very positive reviews provided by others. If I could give it a thumb sideways, I would. Escape room puzzles are fun, after all.[/i]

I kept hoping while playing both of these games to completion that I would reach a point in the narrative where everything would click, and all of the characters' ramblings about weird pseudoscientific concepts and philosophical questions would make perfect sense, and I'd be able to appreciate the masterpieces of storytelling so many people seem to think these games are.

Unfortunately, that wasn't to be, and I'm left here after completing VLR wondering if I'm being too critical, or if others went into these games expecting something completely different than I was expecting, and were thus able to be satisfied by what they got. In either case, masterpieces these games are not.

Let's start with the pseudoscience, psychobabble, and philosophical musings that underpin the plot. Real conspiracy-theory tier stuff, referencing some famous and some less-famous experiments and ideas from real life. Normally, I'm not opposed to any of this kind of thing in my stories--in fact, I generally quite like it when it's integrated well. But in the case of both of these games, in spite of these things being integral to the narrative, they are revealed to the player almost exclusively via long-winded infodumps from various characters who really have no business knowing so much about any of that stuff. And because the writing is at best padded heavily for length, and at worst infuriatingly repetitive, the way these characters deliver their treatises is just about as palatable as an "I'm 15 and this is deep" Reddit post.

Let's talk about the writing a bit more. While 999 is the worse offender by a long shot, even in VLR, the dialogue is insanely redundant, and I'm not talking about similarities in the branching paths of its storyline. Characters repeat themselves and say the most braindead obvious things imaginable [b]incessantly[/b]. Even a simple phrase of agreement, which any normal person would say in a few words, is stretched out into several sentences requiring two, three, sometimes more clicks to progress due to the visual novel format of the game's story segments. Fully 60% of the word count in 999 could and should have been cut completely, and I'd say about 50% of VLR's probably should have been edited down as well.

Finally, let's talk about the characters. In retrospect, this is where 999 actually succeeds over its successor--the terrible writing in that game does unfortunately hide some pretty solid characterization. But in the case of VLR, I came to the end of that game thoroughly confused about just who most of the characters were supposed to actually be. With few exceptions, the characters in VLR completely collapse under the weight of its convoluted plot. Because most of its many story branches need to lead to some clue that is relevant to a different branch, in each branch several characters are required to do or say things contradictory to their personalities or motivations. And the brief hand-waving that is done each time this happens does very little to help the sense that most of the characters in VLR are who they are only so long as the plot doesn't require them to be someone else for a moment to get where it needs to go.

I reached a moment near the true end of VLR where everything I've just described had me so frustrated that I almost turned the game off and uninstalled it. Truth be told, the only thing that kept me going to the end was knowing that if I completed it, I'd never again feel the need to go back and replay the damn thing, and nobody would ever be able to tell me that my opinion on it was invalid because I hadn't reached the true ending.

I do still intend to play Zero Time Dilemma to completion, if for no other reason than to see where its plot goes and what mechanical tweaks it makes to the escape room puzzle systems of these games. But I'm no longer hoping for a masterpiece, that's for sure.

[i]Note: I don't begrudge anyone else their enjoyment of these titles, but I have seen the comments on some other negative reviews of these games, and I categorically refuse to accept any assertion that these games are well-written, that they deal with philosophy or science in an intelligent way, or that they are objectively masterpieces. They are not, and if you feel the need to set me straight on this, please read a book before you comment. Preferably something at a higher reading level than Harry Potter. Thank you.[/i]

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games é uma coletânea de 2 jogos (999 e VLR), sendo o segundo a continuação do primeiro. A premissa do game envolve 9 pessoas que foram sequestradas e acordaram em um local misterioso, sem absolutamente nenhuma memória de como pararam neste lugar, No entanto, apesar do primeiro jogo ser muito bom, o verdadeiro brilho está no segundo, que eu pessoalmente considero um de meus jogos favoritos.
  Porém, leve em conta que jogar o segundo antes do primeiro é um dos piores erros que qualquer humano poderia cometer, então não cometa este equívoco. Outro grande "erro" (este sendo opinião minha) é jogar o jogo com a dublagem em inglês em vez de japonês, visto que a dublagem original é imensamente superior a inglesa.
  Para finalizar essa introdução, a forma ideal de se jogar é no modo "difícil", que apenas limita/corta dicas. Jogar nesse modo também dá o player pedaços de informação que só estão disponíveis nessa "dificuldade"

  Deixarei uma coisa clara antes de continuar: Esta análise é extremamente superficial, pois MUITAS coisas nesse jogo, sejam pequenas ou grandes, podem ser spoilers que vão arruinar a experiência do jogador, portanto eu irei me limitar nesse quesito. Outra coisa para se destacar é: NÃO PESQUISE NADA EM WIKIS. Se estiver preso em algum canto do game, eu recomendo fortemente tentar passar através da insistência, e se mesmo assim não funcionar, procure através de gameplays no youtube, jamais wikis.
  Seguindo a ideia acima, eu irei citar pontos positivos e negativos do jogo, que irão incentivar ou afastar o leitor de comprar esta obra-de-arte

Pontos Positivos:

 -Eu posso começar dizendo que esse é com certeza, o meu jogo com a tag "Visual Novel" favorito. Eu possuo uma certa experiência envolvendo esses tipos de jogos (Danganronpa, AI, Ranging Loop etc), então possuo base para falar sobre, e citarei o por que disso

-Uma das melhores narrativas que você encontrará caso seja fã de ficção científica, conceitos e ideias criativas relacionadas a ciência e plot twists geniais. Não só isso, toda trama e narrativa envolve do começo ao fim uma história extremamente cativante e imersiva, e pelo menos para mim, eu nunca deixei de criar teorias sobre o que estava acontecendo em determinado momento e sempre tive o prazer de continuar jogando e me surpreendendo cada vez mais

-Atmosfera profundamente imersiva. Pessoalmente, eu me senti constantemente em uma "vibe" de mistério com cautela, somados a "cacete, isso é genial", durante o rumo do jogo

-A construção e desenvolvimento de personagens é um ABSURDO. A empatia criada, a imersão na narrativa junto a eles, as teorias e deduções feitas pelo player...é simplesmente genial a forma que tudo foi esquematizado e planejado

-A trilha sonora não é tão diversificada assim. Porém, ao meu ver, cada música combina muito bem com seu respectivo lugar, e eu não enjoei delas

-Um dos grandes pontos de Nonary Games, são os puzzles dele. O primeiro jogo apresenta puzzles simples e divertidos, com alguns poucos "difíceis/complexos". Não lembro de ter encontrado nenhum puzzle frustrante de difícil, seja mecanicamente ou por pura complexidade no primeiro jogo. Meu amigo, isso muda tão rápido no segundo jogo...O segundo jogo possui os puzzles mais difíceis e criativos que eu já encontrei durante toda a minha vida, necessitando de uma grande quantia de matemática e lógica para solucioná-los. 
Não entenda errado, eu pessoalmente adorei cada um deles, sentindo uma ENORME satisfação ao completar cada um, não só por superá-los, mas também pois sabia que logo em seguida descobriria cada vez mais da maravilhosa narrativa . Não negarei que me frustei em alguns, mas faz parte do processo, eu diria

-Sinceramente, para a quantia de conteúdo, nível de narrativa, personagens e tudo, o preço do game não é caro. O jogo faz jus ao seu valor

Pontos Negativos

-Puzzles difíceis agradam e afastam as pessoas, seja devido a complexidade deles ou paciência necessária. Admito que em alguns puzzles fiquei algumas horas preso

-A qualidade artística cai do primeiro para o segundo jogo. Apesar disso, sinto que devo expressar minha opinião aqui, e dizer que ao meu ver que a "arte" do segundo jogo combina com ele

-Durante o segundo jogo, há diversas vezes uma quantia bem grande de cutscenes que envolvem um mapa 2D, mostrando uma animação de desloque de um Ponto A até um Ponto B. Fica a dica: 2 Cliques no CTRL pula uma cena em que o player já visualizou (incluindo diálogos já previamente vistos)

- O jogo abrange uma quantia BEM GRANDE de puzzles. Porém não vamos esquecer que isso é uma visual novel. A quantia de texto é claramente superior em quantidade aos puzzles. Isso não provocou nenhum problema para mim, até porque eu amo isso, mas deixarei avisado. Não se esqueça que o jogo possui a ausência de uma tradução PT-BR

Conclusão:

  Nonary Games é sem sombra de dúvidas um dos meus jogos favoritos, possuí suas falhas, mas que ao meu ver, não atrapalham a gameplay e experiência fantástica que o player irá presenciar e descobrir.

I hadn't played 999 or VLR on their original releases, so I cannot reliably tell whether or not this is is a good port. These are both great games, though, and I have enjoyed going through this series.

Overview: Mystery VNs with escape room puzzle gimmicks. Simultaneously goofy and grim, mix anime with a sprinkling of Saw.

Here are the specific reviews for each game.

9 Persons, 9 Hours, 9 Doors: 
A young man named Junpei wakes up in a ship's cabin and has to escape it when it begins to fill up with water. Meeting 8 other people, he learns they have all been kidnapped by a gas-masked psychopath named Zero to play the Nonary Game: they have 9 hours to explore doors marked with numbers, and try to find the door with a 9 on it and escape the sinking ship. If they break the rules of the game, they explode.

Overall it's a great game with plenty of twists and turns that requires you to replay to get all the endings and piece together Zero's motivations, why each person was selected for this game, and what exactly is going on. The characters are enjoyable, and the last two endings bring everything together nicely. Although there is one mystery that is left purposely unsolved as a red herring, but the rest of the pieces fit together perfectly.

The game was made for the DS, and that doesn't translate entirely well for the Nonary Game port. Apparently the final puzzle was changed, but more importantly on the DS cutscenes were shown on the top and bottom screens simultaneously, while the NG port instead has the option of switching between Adventure and Novel modes. Let me just say this now: unless you are replaying the game and skipping through dialogue, you should leave things on Novel mode.

Overall, though, this game is (fittingly) a solid 9/10.


Virtue's Last Reward"
Another young man named Sigma wakes up in an elevator with a girl named Phi. Escaping and meeting up with seven others, they realize they too have been abducted by Zero and forced to play the Nonary Game. Except this time, it's the Ambidex Edition. Rather than numbered bracelets and bombs, the crew has colored bracelets ready to poison them if they lose or step out of line. Exploring the chromatic rather than numbered doors, and then voting with or against each other in a prisoner's dilemma inspired game, there is a greater emphasis on suspicion and betrayal in this game than the mostly cooperative cast in 999. Especially as the bodies start to pile, amd their AI host, Zero Jr., assures them the mastermind is among the group.

This game is still excellent and worth checking out once you finish 999, though it does have its flaws. There are retcons to connect the plots of the two games, a returning character is written slightly OOC, and the true ending is a lot less conclusive than in 999 as you'll likely have figured out most of the mystery solved by then only to end up with a bit of a cliffhanger. This game was originally on the 3DS, and the character models are different as a result. It's a bit hard to take seriously at times, like looking at awkward dolls. 

Still, if you can handle the puzzles being more difficult and the storyline even more out-there than the first, this is a worthy sequel with an improved atmosphere and plenty of fun changes in its mechanics.

-Note of how to read this review-

This review will be divied in 3 categories: 
The Review of the two games without any spolier, 999 review with some spoliers and vlr review with some spoliers. 
You have to know that every comments of the games, even the trailers of the game are big spoliers.

I can't recommend this game enough. After days hyperfixating on it, it sure has given food for thought. 
This is not your typical killing game, puzzlewise and storywise. 
The puzzles were fun and satisfying to complete, and it's had me cheering irl more times than I'd like to admit. The escape room structure gives it plenty of variety, and if you've ever been to one irl you will definitely enjoy this. 
Storywise, there is a lot of text, and at times you can get lost, but it all falls into place eventually. 
I did like 999 more than VLR, on all aspects: the lower stakes make it more personal, and the characters just hit closer to home. Not to imply that VLR is worse, just that it is far more complex. 
I am yet to play ZTD, but I can already tell that this franchise won't be easy to forget. It already holds a place in my heart. 
Definitely one of my best purchases.

I highly recommend it! This is a wonderful ride !

Zero Escape una novela visual que intercala historia con puzles que simulan un "escape room".
Es cierto que tiene sus fallas: puede resultar repetitivo y, en el segundo juego, cierta animación para moverse de una sala a otra es extremadamente tediosa. Aún así, me parece un juego muy recomendable.
La clave del éxito de Zero Escape es, además de sus múltiples finales, su historia. Introduce una variedad de teorías un tanto esotéricas y de ciencia ficción que, de hecho, te dejan pensando como si estuvieses en una clase de filosofía. A medida que avanzas puede resultar un poco enrevesado, pero con el suficiente grado de atención y aceptación es todo muy disfrutable. Para resumir, es uno de eso juegos que te dejan la cabeza dando vueltas después de jugarlos.
