PRELUDE

The following review is only for "999". I have not completed "VLR" yet, but it plays similarly.


REVIEW, PART 1

What is "9 persons, 9 hours, 9 doors"?

The game that usually is abbreviated as "999" is part of the "Nonary Games" series of visual novels. The both games in this package, "999" and "Virtue's Last Reward" consist of the novel parts as well as Escape Room puzzles to be solved, which are interwoven with the story and - despite at first feeling tacked on to have a gameplay element - being an integral part of it.

In 999, the PC version adds the Flow, which is a chart of all events that happened and information where the storyline splits up. This is helpful as in the Nintendo DS version you had to replay the game entirely from the beginning when you finished one of the endings - here you can jump to any point in the story, "Radiant Historia" style, to continue from there and possibly making different decisions (or replaying Escape Room puzzles if you want so).

The game is played entirely with the mouse, keyboard inputs are optional to assist you. This means you can shortcut with the keyboard, but can't play the entire game with it. I didn't test the gamepad functionality, but supposedly you can play through the entire game, including the Escape Room puzzles, with the gamepad only.

The story revolves around the "Nonary Game". You awaken - after being abducted - in a confined space with several beds. Water enters through a broken window. Soon you figure out, you are on a ship and meet with other people. The nine of you must escape by playing the "Nonary Game". Within nine hours, the nine people must solve escape room puzzles and find a way out, but due to numbered doors through which only 3-5 people can go at a time, it is necessary to split up all the time. The story develops in a way that includes not only horror - without becoming a horror game, i.e. there are no werewolves, zombies or other monsters (other than your fellow humans), the setting itself is just horror - but also crime and mystery. In the end, you want to escape, but to do so you must also find out why you are there, and you will also find out that there is a reason why exactly the people were chosen for the Nonary Game that are there.

The gameplay really consists mostly of following the story, making important decisions every now and then, and solving the escape rooms in-between. All in all, it took me around 20 hours to see everything[spoiler], including one permanently missable ending (the only one that gives no Steam achievement and is not needed for one). The reason why the ending is permanently missable has an in-story explanation, so I don't want to spoiler it. But it is a bad ending at first where you might or might not miss vital information. If you have that information, the game continues there[/spoiler].

The soundtrack is fitting, similar to other visual novels such as "Phoenix Wright", which however would be more of an adventure game in my opinion. The voice-acting is not completely done but on important lines, which is irritating. The acting itself is fine for the genre - in an action game it would lack panick and urgency.

Overall, 999 is a classic, it was one the instant it came out. So the question here is not if I would recommend it - obviously I would - but if I would recommend the Steam version, and for what price.
The latter depends entirely on what you are willing to spend on it. Personally, I think the best value is gained by waiting for a sale and getting the bundle with all three of the "Zero Escape" games.

Supposedly - from the time that other reviewers have - the second game in this package, "Virtue's Last Reward", adds another 30 hours of gameplay, totalling a bit over 50 hours. I am a bit over 10 hours in it, and from what I saw so far, it takes 8-9 hours to reach the first (non-)ending there, and then due to the "flow" mechanic, and due to other endings maybe being reached shorter, the time of 30 hours might be fitting to reach all endings. This however would be the topic for part 2 of this review after finishing said game.

Recommended: Yes, but wait for a sale and get all three "Zero Escape" games - the two in this pack and "Zero Time Dilemma" in the "Zero Escape Trilogy" bundle. After all, you want to experience the entire story of all games, once you play them. They are different enough to not feel old after the first game, but also seem to reference each other, so playing them in a specific order, that of releases (999, then VLR, then the Zero Time Dilemma) is recommended, according to the forum.

So far after just playing 999 its fantastic. The DS version, not this one.

BUY THIS AND THEN PLAY THE DS VERSION OF 999 INSTEAD. THE DIALOGUE HAS BEEN BUTCHERED HERE.
The reason is because of the two modes, the dialogue has been made very weird sounding in order to accommodate players who only read dialogue for Adventure mode. It's a great read and the narration is so well written, it's a shame a better solution wasn't though of for the port.

Personally I absolutely adore horror books (but not jump scares that are found in video games or movies) and this is a great thought provoking story. After playing Virtue's Last Reward, I can't tell what perplexes me more the explanation of the ending or how only 16.6% of people have read through both of these. After all not 100% either of these would be like leaving a mystery novel unfinished. Once I played it I realized what had been missing from the DS version of 999, the skip feature. Sure it has auto skip and all skip but the DS version of 999 featured something where if you pressed right on the dpad the game would fast forward and automatically stop when you reached a new piece of dialogue. The reason it disappoints me that neither of these games have this feature anymore is that even in VLR even when go down a different branch (even though it doesn't intersect like it does in 999) there are still several sections that intersect between the different ends of the flowchart. It can be quite difficult to tell where to stop to get to the new dialogue. Now onto the story itself, it was really good I liked how it ran with what the first game had, until the end where is got confusing. I think the reason this is (without going into spoilers) as they used still images to explain the ending when really a slight bit of maybe some dots on those image could've really helped out here. For the twist villain in this game (the villain but they're not zero) it was really quite obvious, as opposed to the first game where I was quite surprised, this one was really more like someone just begging for you to guess if they're the villain. The most this game did with it's ending was help me understand the original game's ending easier, but failed to do so with it's own. The animation looked quite nice. But overall I do prefer the 2D style of 999 better. Maybe it was the way the characters move their lips to try and make the vowel shapes to sync with the voices would either look like it matched really well or really distracting and off. The soundtrack was quite good, I want to say it reuses a lot of tracks from the first game. The voices for the characters sound quite good as well, Zero III was the perfect mix of annoying and fun (if you don't like Zero III's voice they go away in the very beginning, you don't hear too much of them compared to the other characters), and the others did a good job as well. The gameplay is the same as 999 except there's a ton more characters and instead of most of the endings being about a different way you died it's more about a character you learned the most about. This game took me 32 hours and 47 minutes to beat. The way I see this after playing through it would be: a nicely wrapped present, but when someone tries to tell you how to open the present you get all confused and make more of a knot then you started with. I picked this up during a new years sale for $8.99 or $9 and at $30 I'd still say it's a fair price if we're going by the dollar per hour system. Now even after all this I'd still recommend this to people who've ever enjoyed a mystery book or if this sounds interesting to.

新年凌晨通关按耐不住心中的震撼，特来写一篇评测来倾诉自己的感想。
首先，作为第一作的999整体质量仍然非常出色，和很多大佬说的一样推荐用nds模拟器玩，因为核心诡计与双屏协同有关，可以获得更好的游戏体验。
真正要说的是第二作，善人死亡。我直接吹爆，什么叫完美回收伏笔啊？什么叫叙述诡计啊？同样是打越钢太郎的作品，这部在我心中的地位已经超越了ever17，相比之下没有ever17前期平淡的日常，全程都在高能，剧情锁的设置让所有线路环环相扣的完美衔接在了一起，以至于前中期也不会觉得无聊。伏笔极其多，建议游玩的时候做笔记来记录疑点。真结局路线中带来的被欺诈的快感也更胜一筹。解密方面，除了最后那个解密难度实在过高，其他的解密都恰到好处，很有意思。
缺点可能就是游戏没有延续999的立绘，而转变成了较为粗糙的3d建模，得适应一阵子。
归根结底，我只能说，打越钢太郎，不愧是你！！！

This game has the best storytelling I've seen from a video game, and shows how Chunsoft's good writing and engaging gameplay that uses thought-provoking philosophy to explain supernatural occurances is second to none. The need to find out what is going on and why drove me to want to binge the game. The characters are all dynamic and have shown motives and hidden motives, some never being explicitly revealed at once, making you connect dots and draw conclusions yourself. It's a series I will always think about, and my interest in it led to wanted to play the original version on DS. If you enjoy deep storytelling and puzzles, definitely pick it up.

『善人シボウデス』（プレイ時間35時間程度）：

長かったあああああ！
長い！
本当に長い！

ここまでボリュームのある内容をよくまとめているなあという感動がありました。
でも、もう少し短くできたんじゃないかなあとも思ってしまいました（スキップできる部分を増やすとか）。

主人公みたいに記憶力がすごいのなら大丈夫かも。

『9時間9人9の扉』の方は2日間ぶっ通しでプレイしてクリアしましたが、
『善人シボウデス』の方はプレイし始めてから早1か月が経ちました。

こっちは毎日寝る前にちょこちょこやるのに向いていると思います。

The Nonary Games are genuinely some of the most interesting games I've ever had the pleasure of playing, and I'm super fucking glad I decided to push on and finish them. 

999 captivated me from the start and never stopped holding my interest to the end, the visuals and music and characters are so fucking perfectly crafted that I didn't even mind the slightly jank as fuck information dumps and storytelling at points (which is just endearing honestly LMAO), even if the ending had me kinda confused and unsatisfied 

VLR is fucking insane because I had genuinely never been more bored and uninterested with a novel at that point, especially coming hot off of 999. I gave it 7 hours and then dropped it for better shit that I felt like playing more but randomly picked it right back up a few days ago just to finish it and get through it, and holy shit it is one of the most interesting and 4-dimensional games I have ever played. Overall, I would say the overall information presentation alongside the general lore and background of this game flowed a lot better and was cooler than 999, but the best parts of the game are the insane methods it uses to fuck with you and trickle information in a way that leaves you grasping for more, trying desperately to find the rest of the puzzle pieces because the picture looks so fucking cool from what little you have. I can't say shit about the things I like most about this game because they're extreme spoilers and a blind playthrough is very necessary LOL but it truly is a game that gets better the more pieces you put together, which is exactly what a mystery game should strive for.

999 and VLR are both flawed games in a lot of ways, and while these did detriment the experience for me a bit, I can't recommend these two games enough. The mind-bending nature of the both of them as well as the insane but endearing and lovable writing that comes out of both of them absolutely blew me away, and they're both fucking fantastic because of it.

This was a surprisingly scary game.
Not really the Jumpscare/Freaky kind of scary, it's more like "The Twilight Zone" type of scary.
Psych horror is an overused tag, but it works here.

You shouldn't assign any tropes to this based off the first impression, though. I was super skeptical when I saw the chick dressed like a- well, yknow, and I thought the "Sci-Fi" meant that it would just be Gadgets and Space and that crap, just like I thought the Horror aspect would just be "ahh! scary face!" over and over. I also thought that your choices wouldn't make any differences, like in TellTale games or most VNs. I also assumed the Psychological Horror stuff would just be generic DokiDoki Fnaf crap, I could go on and on...

None of those assumptions were true. The game isn't anime-y, the game isn't cheap with it's horror (like Outlast or Fnaf or any of that crap I used to play), the Sci-Fi isn't focused on the typical cliche stuff. The choices matter, the suspense was real, the imagery was effective, and jeez the scarier stuff got to me more than I thought it would.

It's genuinely one of the most thought-provoking games I've ever played. 

That said, this definitely does require quite a fair bit of attention. Not only is there a lot of plot details to remember, but giving the Acting and Soundtrack enough time is essential (both of which are incredible, which is rare for VisualNovels).
In other words, don't skim the dialogue, don't half-pay attention, this isn't effective as a casual game. This game is like the polar opposite of Danganronpa when it comes to tone, so don't expect a pink-blooded anime giggle-fest like that game was. 
I would actually recommend this game to people who usually hate Visual Novels and Anime, since this has very little of either despite the surface artstyle (which is more comicy than anime).

I bought this game 4 times. One for myself, and three more times for other people I wanted to experience this. It's the only game out of the hundreds I have that I have bought multiple times.

This game will freak you out if you let it (which you should).

If there's one thing I hate, it's puzzle games. If there's one thing I hate MORE than puzzle games, it's visual novels. ...Surprisingly, though, I've found that I really like the Zero Escape games. Don't let the genre fool you, these games are jam-packed with funny, interesting dialogue and a story that makes every little issue (the pacing in VLR is bad at best, I'll admit) minor in the grand scheme of things. The twists in these games pack an impressive punch, but what is more impressive is the attention to detail paid to each of the characters. The story feels full and the settings/plotlines are intriguing enough to make every subsequent playthrough after getting your first ending rather fulfilling. In my opinion, 999 is by far the better of the two, but VLR isn't a bad game by any means.

The writing is honestly not too great..., as if it were by an elementary schooler. Plot devices are thrown around without significant foreshadowing. Great game(s). I only bought this because I really like the Dangonronpa series and I tried Zero Escape Time Dilemma. Then I read the reviews and realized that that was the third game in the series, with this game containing the first two. I'm not a big into anime, visual novel, manga, etc. I like some puzzle games, but I really enjoyed the Nonary Games for the story.

999 was amazing. Great art style, the puzzles were good. I'm not a puzzle person, and I figured these out easy enough. Only had look to up solutions a couple times. At the same, they're rewarding and don't make you feel dumb. Awesome story as well.

VLR, was good, not great. No idea why they changed the art style so drastically. Story was good, but pretty convoluted compared to 999. I would not blame people for finding it confusing. The puzzles are hit or miss. Some of them I found very obtuse and difficult because it was so unclear about what to do. Like I said, I only gave up and looked up hints in 999 puzzles a few times, in VLR I had look up hints many times. But I still wouldn't say it's a bad game, just some mediocre execution on some points. The story is also very long, and you have to sit through a lot of dialogue to find out everything. I finished every good ending to get to the end. It just keeps going when you think it's done. So many twists and turns. Nothing is what it seems.

But overall, I like this bundled game a lot and would recommend it, especially on sale. Fans of visual novels, puzzle games, and narrative heavy/mystery games will enjoy this series.

Ce jeu m'a donné une vraie claque ! Positivement parlant.

Bref, j'avais peur de m'ennuyer car pas trop habituée à être spectatrice quand je joue à des jeux vidéos et ce ne fut à aucun moment le cas.
Le jeu est en anglais, certes, mais très franchement inutile d'être bilingue pour comprendre et apprécier cette histoire. Un niveau lycée est amplement suffisant.
Pour la première fois dans ma vie de gameuse, j'ai voulu rejouer et faire toutes les fins possibles afin de savourer chaque instant et surtout ne louper aucune information.
Jouez-y sans hésitation ! vous ne le regretterez pas ! <3

I've originally played 999 back in 2012 on my old Nintendo DSi, and even now it's still one of my favourite games ever. It might be a personal thing, since I do feel like the first title comprises everything I love in a game: immersive music, mysterious and interesting characters, puzzles that make you work for it and genuinely fantastic lore. 
I waited until I got this bundle to play the second game, and even though it took some time to get adjusted to the different 3D character sprites, story itself, characters and puzzles are still as good as the first game! I might just be more attached to 999 because of the nostalgia factor, but once I got properly into the second game, I was hooked!

If you like games such as Ace Attorney, Persona, Hotel Dusk, Professor Layton, The Room, Danganronpa... Do yourself a favour and get this one :3 It's two games in one, you can't miss!

如果一个游戏做的重制版破坏了游戏原本的核心体验，新的叙述方式把原来最惊艳的叙述直接废掉，甚至把原本的名场面搞成了一个平平无奇的转折点……

Virtues Last Reward is good but some of the puzzles feel a little nonsensical in my opinion but the story is just as if not a little better than the first game.

I would recommend this game bundle it is well worth the price and you are sure to find plenty of things that you love during your playthrough!

I'm writing this review from the perspective of someone who just got the true endings in all three games in the trilogy.

And I'm going to issue a warning here. These games are weird. I personally think they are stupid as all hell getting worse with each entry. 
There is somewhat of a decent story hidden in there somewhere, buried under a huge pile of filler. Most of the extra endings add nothing to the plot or characters, but you're still expected to watch all of them before you're allowed to continue on the true path. Either because there's an arbitrary cut off point or because one character will randomly blurt out an important password at the end of these routes.
None of the true endings in any game explains why anything happens exactly the way it does, considering it's all so ridiculously specific und meticiosly planned for no apparent reason. The escape room puzzles don't tie into the narrative at all.

Although speaking of which, while the puzzles are fairly easy in all three games, Virtue's Last Reward at least actually has a number of pretty decent ones to solve. And there's usually a nice balance between story and gameplay sections.

The Storytelling, though, doesn't hold up in any of the three entries. Plot twists come out of nowhere and hinge on the idea that everyone involved is incapable of observing their surroundings and everyone having temporary selective amnesia in some cases and people being awkwardly vague when describing things or the game straight up lying to the player in other cases. Or even worse, in the first game it's very easy to miss the entire point of the story by choosing the wrong narration option...

The whole plot is built on some loosely connected esoteric concepts, which more often than not don't hold any deeper meaning and are dropped as quickly as they are brought up when a random character pulls an entire Wikipedia article straight out of their ass to explain it to you. Sometimes, however, they spent so much as 3 to 6 hours desperately trying to convince you why the gigantic plot holes in these games are not, in fact, a complete ass pull. It's so pathetic.

In the end they build up this huge and ridiculously complex story and world for no payoff at all. I think the first two games are still somewhat worth playing despite the glaring weaknesses, but considering the way this whole story is so monumentally set up, only to get in way over its own head with pointlessly specific details and contrived explanations, I don't think it's gonna be very satisfying. You're either left with a cliffhanger in the middle or a lame, unconclusive finale.

So I've been wanting to play this game since it came out on the DS... Only at the time I didn't have one and resigned myself to never being able to play this game, forgot about it over the years and then was finally reminded of its existence by my cousin on Thanksgiving this year. He's got good taste in games so I decided to get it and give it a go since he also mentioned it was on steam. I'm not very far yet but I'm really enjoying it. 

The first thing I liked about this game is the art style. The characters are distinct without being outlandish looking. I also like that there is some animation to the sprites (talking and occasional other movement), it wasn't something I wasn't expecting but it's a nice. 

The puzzles are challenging for me (I'm not that good at puzzle games, bare that in mind.) HOWEVER while they've challenging I can still get through the game without getting stuck, which is nice because I don't know how to articulate how frustrating it is to play a game where you're too stupid to solve the puzzles and can't continue playing. (Also want to say thank you to anyone who's ever made a walkthrough, you're the reason I've gotten through any games that are not solely a visual novel.)

Saw Special Agent Mizuki Okiura play this game on a Nintendo Switch in the promotional video for Nirvana Initiative, I felt like I'll have to give it a try. Overall, it's a thrilling experience, although the true ending can be perplexing. That said, the plot becomes much clearer after diving into the 'stable time loop theory,' a recurring theme in various Japanese games and anime like Attack on Titan. One piece of advice: Stay away from the Chinese version. A Funyarinpa should always be called a Funyarinpa, not 浮世繪.

VLR improves on the escape rooms, but didn't quite deliver a great story like 999 did for me (I think this was in part due to the not so great 3D models as well as some of the characters).
Both of these games are still great, and their stories can get pretty mind-boggling, so be prepared ;)

曾经在模拟器上玩过 999 和善人死亡的汉化版。后来购买了合集……并以英文模式日文语音玩完了 999。（纯粹是为了听语音。）
这里说说一开始模拟器玩的时候的感受。
首先是 999，序章真的很恐怖，体内装着的炸弹吓得我连续几天失眠。
然后是善人死亡……因为晚上睡觉不自觉的思考剧情发展……还是几天失眠……
遗憾之处在于这系列作品除了密室内可以移动视角和交互外，密室之间只能根据剧情行动，而不像弹丸论破能够自由的在建筑物之间走动。
对于 999 的重制，因为游戏支持且只支持单显示器，以前双屏的诡计也没了。还有双屏同时播放的动画（比如序章的船外观视频和倒计时同时播放，还有结尾的数独游戏。）
善人死亡，可能因为一开始就是多平台发布的，3DS 和 PSV，所以不需要太考虑这个问题。

999는 좋았는데 선인사망은 좀 별로

999는 스토리가 깔끔하게 끝났다. 목적도 달성했고 탈출도 했고 작중 중요한 것들은 다 알려줬고 후속작으로 떡밥을 넘기지 않아서 이거만 하고 꺼도 스토리는 완성

선인사망은 스토리가 지저분하게 끝났다. 목적은 달성했고 일단은 탈출도 성공했다지만 막판에 시그마가 점프하는거로 끝나고 나머지는 후속작에서 알려주겠다고 끝내버렸다. 우리의 싸움은 지금부터다 하는 그 엔딩이다.

999는 극한탈출이라는 이름에 걸맞게 탈출에 대한 동기가 명확하다. 빨리 안 나가면 니들 죽는다고 알려주고 게임 시작부분에서부터 빨리 안나가면 익사한다는 느낌을 줘서 긴박감이 느껴진다.

근데 선인사망은 나갈 수 있는 방법과 조건은 제시하는데 나가건 말건 니들 맘대로 해라 하는 느낌이다. 작중에 폭탄이네 살인사건이네 해서 탈출해야 하는 이유가 생기긴 하는데 게임 주최자가 시작부터 나가야 하는 동기부여를 하는 999보다는 너무 부자연스럽다. 몇몇 엔딩은 아예 구조대 불러 올 테니 기다려라 하고 끝나는데 당연히 긴장감이 없다.

999만 하고 꺼도 딱히 문제는 없는데 선인사망 하면 결말을 제대로 맺지 않았기 때문에 시간의 딜레마도 사야 제대로 엔딩이 나옵니다.  가능하면 세일할 때 번들로 둘 다 사시는 게 좋은 것 같습니다.

Review for Virtue's Last Reward: Very well designed hybrid between a visual novel and "escape room" game, where nine people wake up in a strange building and have to complete different puzzle rooms in order to escape. After each room, everyone must choose to ally or betray the people they played with, which affects the number of points that is shown on everyone's bracelet. If someone gets 9 points, that person can escape. If someone gets zero points, that person dies.

The story events and their outcome are based on the choices you make in the game (ally/betray, the people you team up with etc). To get the "real" ending, you have to explore all different story outcomes. While you discover something new in each storyline and you get new puzzle rooms each time, it does become a bit repetitive after a while. It took me over 30 hours to get the true ending, and I'm pretty sure I'd enjoyed the game more if it was 10 hours shorter. The true ending is also rather complex, I had a hard time following what was really going on. 

Despite these issues, this game is definitely worth playing because it does so many things right!

It's only fault is the lack of skip choices for dialog, in playing a game with alternative endings that's made to be played multiple times it would be nice to have the option to skip certain repetitive dialog to get to the puzzle faster.  All in all the story is great, I tend to see a few endings gain criticism, but I think the game captures motives and mentalities wonderfully.

[h1]Spoiler-freie Review[/h1]

Ich kann die beiden Remaster von [b]"9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors"[/b] sowie [b]"Virtues Last Resort"[/b] nur jedem Escape-Room und Visual-Novel-Freund empfehlen. Die Grafik wurde etwas aufgehübscht und die Steuerung wurde vom Nintendo DS an den PC perfekt angepasst. Die verschiedenen Routen der Novel werden mithilfe einer Flowchart dargestellt und es kann je nach Lust und Laune hin- und hergesprungen werden. So kann man jedes Ende der Geschichte erleben, ohne dass man sich etwas "kaputt macht" oder ganz von vorne anfangen muss (wie in der DS-Version von 999).

[h1]9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors[/h1]

Ich mochte die Geschichte um Junpei und Akane (und die anderen 7 Gefangenen) sehr gerne. Ich habe vor vielen Jahre mal die DS-Version ausgepackt und nach kurzer Zeit wieder weggelegt. Und jetzt, knapp 10 Jahre später, habe ich das Spiel in 4 Tagen durchgesuchtet. Die Rätsel in den Escape-Rooms waren alle fair und ohne Onlinehilfe lösbar. Die Geschichte war gut geschrieben und man weiß bis zum Schluss nicht wirklich, wer "Zero" ist (auch wenn man natürlich viele Vermutungen hat). Auch die japanische Sprachausgabe war (im Gegensatz zur englischen) großartig und hat die Texte schön untermalt. Ich kann jedem nur Empfehlen, das Spiel im Novel-Modus zu spielen, da der ADV-Modus (Adventure-Modus) fast alle Gedanken des Protagonisten weglässt und nur die wirklich gesprochenen Texte wiedergibt. Mit knapp 27h für alle Enden war die Länge vollkommen okay.

[h1]Virtues Last Resort[/h1]

Virtues Last Resort ist der Nachfolger von 999. Protagonist ist nicht mehr Junpei, sondern Sigma, der zusammen mit Phi und 7 anderen Gefangenen versucht eine neue Version der "Nonary Games" zu lösen. Nach meinem 999-Marathon habe ich 3 Tage später mit VLR angefangen und ihn nach 6 Tagen mit knapp 32h auf der Uhr beenden können. Auch hier kann man im Flowchart hin- und herspringen, um die verschiedenen Enden dieser Visual Novel zu erleben. Die Charaktere sind gut geschrieben und man fühlt mit diesen bzw. entwickelt unglaublichen Hass ihnen gegenüber. Einzig und allein die ganzen unnötigen, perversen Sprüche des Protagonisten waren in meinen Augen nach einiger Zeit unnötig. Auch hier ist die japanische Sprachausgabe wieder perfekt getroffen. Der englischen konnte ich leider wieder nichts abgewinnen. Es gibt in diesem Teil außerdem die Möglichkeit, die Escape-Rooms auf "Easy" oder "Hard" durchzuspielen. Ich kann jedem nur empfehlen, es auf "Hard" zu probieren, bevor man es auf Easy stellt. Fast alle Rätsel sind mit etwas nachdenken und kombinieren möglich, auch wenn ich im letzten Raum scheinbar einen Bug hatte. Wisst ihr, wie das Rätsel geht, könnt ihr den Raum später nochmal auf "Hard" stellen und trotzdem 100% bekommen. (Aber Finger weg von den Golden Files, die spoilern ungemein!)

[h1]Zusammenfassung:[/h1]

Beide Spiele sind dank des Remasters auch heute noch wunderbar spielbar und haben nichts an ihrem Charme verloren. Mit knapp 60h Spielzeit ist es die 25 € definitiv wert. Im Angebot für 6 € ist es für mich ein No-Brainer. Das Spiel hat natürlich seine kleineren Schwächen, aber im Großen und Ganzen sind beide Spiele ein toller Zeitvertreib und eine intensive Erfahrung für alle Escape-Room-Fans.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games includes both 999 and Virtue's Last Reward, which are both masterpieces in the visual novel genre. The games are mystery games with "escape the room" style gameplay, though what really makes these games great are the narratives. The stories are incredibly well written and are full of suspense and drama. The games also explore some philosophical and scientific themes as well which are very thought provoking. Overall, I highly recommend these games as they are some of my favourite games of all time.

[i]"Recommanderiez-vous ce jeu à d'autres personnes ?"[/i] [b]OUI OUI OUI ET OUI[/b]

[u]SPOILER FREE[/u]

Tout d'abord Zero Escape: The Nonary Games est une duologie composé de 999 et Virtue's Last Reward. A peu près 20h de jeu chacun. Je parlerai des 2 séparés. 


[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
Enlevés et placés dans un lieu inconnu, 9 personnes se retrouvent forcés de participer au jeu "Nonary Game" par un mec appelé "Zero".


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b]- 999 -[/b]
Alors il faut savoir déjà que la meilleure version pour 999 c'est la VN version car les scènes sont bien plus détaillés qu'avec seulement les textes en bas d'écran. Le jeu est en 2D, des sprites vraiment plaisant et des décors vraiment sympathiques. C'est le jeu qui m'a le plus plu au niveau de l'esthétisme. On joue le personnage "Junpei" et le but du jeu c'est de sortir d'ici (yes merci j'avais pas compris). Dans l'histoire on sera amené à plusieurs choix qui donneront lieu à plusieurs routes, voir fins. Bien sûr, pour avoir la véritable fin il faudra faire toutes les autres avant. Aussi, les personnages seront souvent bloqués dans des salles et il faudra résoudre l'énigme en triffouillant un peu tout et n'importe quoi pour résoudre l'énigme de la salle entière. Prenez votre temps, lisez bien les dialogues quand les personnages vous aident et ça ira tout seul. YOU FOUND IT!

[b]- VLR -[/b]
Concernant VLR, le 2D est abandonné et laisse place au 3D. Au début, la transition est HORRIBLE mais au fur et à mesure de l'histoire on s'y habitue. On s'y habitue trop vite même ahaha. Ici, on joue le personnage "Sigma". Comparé à 999, VLR est un peu différent au niveau des règles du jeu mais c'est facile à comprendre promis !! Prenez votre mal en patience et vous y arriverez. VLR est plus long que 999 mais sa longueur en vaut son contenu. Une masterclass on a rien pu faire. 


[h1]Ce que j'ai le plus aimé[/h1]
[b]-999 et VLR-[/b]
L'histoire super bien construite et les personnages très bien développé. Ni trop court, ni trop long. Des arguments qui se tiennent et des plot-twist très ingénieux.
Les OST sont iconiques et les voix japonaises sont superbes. Les seiyuus retranscrivent correctement les émotions voulus et nous mettent dans le bain très facilement. J'ai beaucoup aimé. 
Les différentes fins étaient toujours une surprise. Impossible de prévoir et toujours plus de questions après chaque fins.
Les énigmes étaient trop trop bien. J'ai jamais autant aimé faire des énigmes que dans Zero Escape: The Nonary Games !
Vraiment aucun sans faute. Peut être le format qui a été changé de la 2D à la 3D mais même avec on réussis à s'immerger et être hypnotiser par ce magnifique jeu. 
Aussi ce que j'ai plutôt aimé dans VLR c'est que pour skip certaines scènes c'était plus rapide que dans 999. Parce que oui parfois on se retape les mêmes scènes mais ce qui est INCROYABLE c'est que ça arrête de skip quand les dialogues n'ont jamais été lu !!!!!


[h1]Overall[/h1]
Je ne regrette absolument pas avoir fait cette duologie fantastique. J'aimerai le conseiller à tout mes amis si seulement j'en avais ahaha. C'est bien pour ça que je fais des critiques. Pour que, vous, lecteurs pouvez lire ce que j'aime et que vous y prenez plaisir aussi. Une saga dont je ne tairais jamais le nom. Qui ne sera jamais oublié par moi-même. Mesdames et Messieurs, Zero Escape : The Nonary Games.


Il y a un troisième jeu qui se nomme Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma que j'ai commencé, je vous en dirais des nouvelles. Voilà. Merci. SEEK A WAY OUT!

[999 review] clever n quirky little game, but keep in mind tht you have to get every ending for maximum enjoyment (even then still only a ~20 hr playtime depending on your reading speed/puzzle solving skills). replaying certain segments can be tedious but the flowchart is a godsend n the characters are entertaining. you dont NEED to investigate every single thing but you should just to see all the silly little interactions. the story gets VERY pseudo-sciencey so if thts not your thing you may not enjoy the twists as much. overall a solid science fiction/mystery title, should go without saying but go in as blind as possible

[h1] This is mystery death game where every possibility matters. If you consider escaping alive...[/h1]

First of all this is not Danganronpa, more something of a Steins;Gate. This is not a narrow death game focused on killing. It is death game focused on room riddles something like Saw but without needless violence. Puzzles segmented with VN scenes and hell amount of choices. Enough to make most brains fry...

Really good stories with both of these Nonary Games. First one is much more appealing with visuals, UI and animations. But back to story so... Imagine building picture and with each failure you have to restart, but something changes... seems familiar right? Yes. There is plenty of rewinding you cannot build perfect pictures if you miss any puzzles. Everything needs to be uncovered and measured, but even then story will not unfold on it's own.

The second game is hard demanding much more focus. Again watching characters that are multi-layered is rewarding, not a single one can be underestimated. That's the best part of all Nonary Games. people react on our choices and try to make their own reasons. Well written story, everything becomes more clear with each rewind... but it demands hell of patience. Thankfuly there is Flow chart system, so after first playthrough you may easily seek and jump straight to the other paths.

[h1]前言[/h1]
本作品包含两部游戏：《极限脱出：999》和《极限脱出：善人死亡》。均强烈推荐！！！！！
《极限脱出：999》有完整的汉化补丁。
《极限脱出：善人死亡》有3DS移植版汉化，具体体现为"菜单主界面"、”存档界面“、”剧情-区域移动提示词“（玩了就知道了）、”密室-道具名称“、”密室-小游戏文字解说“、”文件-HELP“等没有汉化成功。
[h1]《极限脱出：999》剧情简介[/h1]
主人公淳平在一天晚上回家后，被神秘人士ZERO麻醉，醒来后，发现自己被关在一个游轮上，逃离了身处的房间后，他遇到了其他人，他们的目标是完成游轮上的解谜，使用自己腕表的数字，找到并打开最终的9号门[spoiler] 真的是这样吗？ [/spoiler]
[h1]《极限脱出：善人死亡》剧情简介[/h1]
主人公西格玛是位普通的大学生，在圣诞节前夕，进入车内准备开始回家时，被不明人士“ZERO”[spoiler]貌似不是这个名字[/spoiler]麻醉，醒来后发现自己身处一个电梯，遇到了神秘少女[spoiler]PHI[/spoiler]。逃离了电梯后，人工AI：ZERO-三世告诉他们要利用手上的腕表[spoiler] 和《999》中不同 [/spoiler]和CD（Colored Door）完成AB游戏，打开9号门。故事由此展开。。。
[h1]主要玩法（两作均有）[/h1]
1. 游戏分为ESC和NOVEL，ESC需要玩家开动脑筋，找到脱离房间的方法，NOVEL部分则是有声小说，为游戏剧情的主要呈现。[spoiler] 其中《999》可以切换NOVEL部分的ADV或者NVL版式 [/spoiler]。
2. NOVEL部分存在选择，你的选择会影响你最终剧情的走向，查看流程图可以快速跳到选择的地方，不需要重打剧情。
3. 关键剧情存在剧情锁，你需要阅读流程图或者找到剧情中的一些关键信息，才可以解开剧情锁，《999》中以“锁”的形式在流程图中展现，《善人死亡》中以“问号”或者“提示：TO BE CONTINUED...”的形式表示。
4. 《善人死亡》中的解谜默认为[HARD]模式，你可以切换为[EASY]，但是一旦切换，你只有重开或者完成现在的[EASY]才可以回到[HARD]，每个密室互不干扰，[HARD]（默认）下没有任何提示。[spoiler] 《善人死亡》中只有完成其他所有线的16个密室的[HARD]难度才可以走到最后的剧情。 [/spoiler]
[h1]游戏流程[/h1]
《极限脱出：999》：12-16小时。
《极限脱出：善人死亡》：24-32小时。
不同的时间主要取决于每个人解谜的速度。
[h1]后记[/h1]
推荐的理由除了有“剧情足够精彩”外，还有更重要的是 打越钢太郎 能把[strike]伪科学讲得头头是道[/strike]。《善人死亡》中，剧情被分散在不同的分支中，一些密室中也有剧情的线索，使玩家在解谜的时候也不至于枯燥乏味。
游戏中大量涉及了很多数学、物理、化学[spoiler] 指的阿米诺反应 [/spoiler]、生物方面的知识，使得具有一定的科普意义（确信）。
如果说《999》是个开端，《善人死亡》则将整个系列拔高到了空前的高度，精心设计的剧情，严密的逻辑，让我不得不怀疑，打越钢太郎 是不是跟 小高和刚 一样[strike]放飞了一次再也飞不起来了[/strike]，当然《AI：梦境档案》也是很优秀的作品。
总之，如果你是轻微穿越科幻爱好者+解谜游戏爱好者+视觉小说爱好者+轻微二次元+剧情党。
最后，玩过《STEINS;GATE》的玩家强推，理由就是玩了再一次感动，

A game where there is a lake filled with red herrings and you have to catch them all to be able to actually start fishing.  

Highly recommended if you enjoy a compelling story, science fiction themes, and solving logic puzzles.

The games follow a simple formula. You're kidnapped by Zero, who is the mastermind of a game that you either beat or die trying. The cause of death ranging from backstabbed by your teammate to intravenous poison due to failing at a test.

999 features one of the best combinations of Visual Novel and gameplay that you'll find in the market, with actual, human characters and a compelling story, where you'll have to team up with quite the cast of characters to try find out what's the common link between everyone and why are you here.

It's sequel, Virtue's Last Reward, sadly doesn't live up to its predecessor, the characters becoming far more one-dimensional and the plot becoming far more confusing for the sake of it, without an actual reasoning like 999. It does feature much more interesting puzzles at least!

Still, 999's story is worth the 20 bucks of admission price and VLR is just the cherry on top.

I was gonna write a review about the game, but now that you are reading this, have you ever heard about the morphogenetic fields theory?

This theory holds that there is a sort of "field" where the forms, structures, patterns, etc, of everything in reality are "stored". This included abstract things, like language, song, thoughts, inspiration, culture, customs, and ideas. Any information contained, transmitted, or created by matter is held in the morphogenetic field. In the Zero Escape series, people who can communicate by accessing this field are known as espers. If the morphogenetic field theory is true, however, then it would mean that, in a sense, all humans are espers of a sort.

ZERO ESCAPEシリーズ三部作の1に当たる「9時間9人9の扉」と
2に当たる「善人シボウデス」のパック。

どちらも9人の男女が謎のZEROと呼ばれる犯人に拉致され
デスゲーム的なルールに則りながら謎の建造物から脱出するという脱出ADV。
ストーリーが進むほど様々な真実が発覚し規模感も大きくなる。
「ストーリーに整合性がない」と言われれば無い所もあるが
ゲームという性質上様々な選択肢でストーリーや探索相手が変化するのを鑑みるとよく出来てると思う。
むしろ数字をテーマにしているのにその組み合わせを変えてよく整合させたなと思う。
基本的には真エンディング+補完エンディングという形です。

・9時間9人9の扉
設定がソリッドシュチュエーションサスペンスと言うこともあってライトと言うと語弊があるかもしれないが
比較的テイストが軽くキャラクターも表面上は全員善の皮をかぶって進む。
多少タイムパラドクス的な要素もあるがそこまで「あのときああだったから～」みたいな
脳みそとろける視点を持たなくても取り敢えず進めば大丈夫。
ストーリーも面白く後半に行くにつれて9人の関係性も見えてきて楽しい。

・善人シボウデス
基本的には「9時間9人9の扉」と同じように良く練られたストーリーや
1を上回る度肝を抜く展開＆規模感・・・と褒めたいのだが
他の方も言われてるようにテンポ感がものすごく足を引っ張る。
ドアを開くたびエレベーターの乗るたびに入る演出が最初は許せるが時間を経るごとにイライラさせる。
確かに1でマップの全景を見たいという欲求には駆られたが流石に駄長すぎる。
さらにこれは1もだがSKIP機能の使い勝手が悪いことで上の演出を見ざる得ないケースが多い。
あとMEMOが必要な仕掛けが多いためMEMO機能があるのだが信じられないくらい使いにくい。
メタルギアソリッドのように画面スクショみたいな機能にできなかったのか。。。

っと善人シボウデスに関してはストーリが良いだけに他で粗が目立つが
個人的には楽しかったしセールが掛かったときだと2000円で三部作全てが買えたのは
お得すぎるという他ないクオリティー。
468やダンガンロンパや携帯アプリのループザループが好きな人には刺さると思うし
AIソムニウムより断然良かったと思う。
古い作品だけどサウンドノベルの老舗チュンソフトらしい良さがある。

999 and Virtue's Last Reward, the two games included in this rerelease, are classics.

The stories based around paranormal pseudoscience are goofy taken out of context, but very easy to get wrapped up in, not least because the character's are endearingly written. Twists are fun and obviously thought out.

Part of me likes the games simply because I have a fondness for the escape room games I played in flash when I was younger, and the puzzles are good. Some are infuriating (Q room, VLR pantry) and some aren't fun to do twice (cargo room), but most are solidly built puzzles that make you think a little.

The presentation is pretty good. 999s 2D portraits hold up better than the 3D models of VLR, but honestly I didn't even notice VLR's graphic jankiness most of the time. The soundtracks for both games are really good too, often atmospheric and tense. And of course the voice acting holds up too, though not all performances are born equal.

I really think that these two games are more than the sum of their parts. If you like the things I said above, it might even be full price. But sales can go as low as five bucks, and for the price of a cheeseburger, this pack is a steal.

Overall - I enjoy the game more than i hate it, but there are also a lot of issues with the game. Personally the pay-off of finishing the game was worth it, but I cant say the same for other people.

蠻不錯玩的一個密室逃脫遊戲,整個遊戲謎題大多圍繞在數字根,難度不會太高,只有幾個跟數字根無關的謎題比較難解.

再來就是視角問題,這遊戲是採用固定視角,每個地方都只有固定幾個視角,有些場景就很容易迷失方向位置,(雖然說沒有太大影響,因為這那幾個地點)有些房間門口剛好就跟視角垂直,不仔細看會漏掉了.

如果你喜歡解謎的話,我是蠻推薦這款遊戲的..這遊戲有包含了999和LVR,我目前只玩了999幾個結局就花了快20小時,整套玩完應該要3~40小時,這個價錢來說是相當划算的.

[h1] La saga des Zero Escape ... Quelle dinguerie [/h1] 

Bon, je vais pas vous faire un vieux résumé Wikipédia, mais en gros, le directeur et le scénariste sont une même personne qui est, Kotaro Uchikoshi, il fait principâlement des VN ( Visual Novel ), et du coup c'est lui le papa des Zero Escape, et aussi surement de la incoming trilogie AI : The Somnium Files . Bien que les deux premiers jeu n'ont un gros succès au Jpaon, elle aura tout de même eu une communauté très soudé et fidèle, ce qui aura permis de finir la série en sortant le dernier jeu Zero Time Dilemna en 2016 . Il a aussi fait le scénario de l'anime Punch Line, ainsi que sur sont jeu vidéo . Puis, en 2018, il quitte Spike Chunsoft avec qui il avait réalisé les deux premiers jeu Zero Escape, pour créer sa propre société, Too Kyo Games, et il embarqua avec lui l'équipe de Danganronpa et un autre du jeu Infinity ( Takumi Nakazawa ), pour nous sortir un anime ( The Girl In Twilight ), mais surtout le jeu AI : The Somium Files, ou cette fois ci il était libre, et était sa seul limite . 

Au début il faut savoir qu'il travailler chez KID ( qui a fait pepsiman en gros ), puis l'a quitté pour être en freelance, et faire ces jeux lui même, sans aucune contraintes, puis au final, il ira chez Spike Chunsoft, car il a des bouches a nourrir, celle de sa femme et sa fille . Et la, révélation, Spike Chunsoft lui demande de faire un visual novel, qui pourrait attirer plus de gens, avec des éléments de gameplay novateur, et de la, lui est venu de rajouter des puzzle ( qui sont plus des escape room ), et pour avancer dans l'histoire il fallait finir ses escape room . Et donc le premier jeu dans lequel il fera cela est  Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors . Et comme dis précédemment, le jeu fut quasiment un échec au Japon, mais en NA, se sera tout l'inverse, ce qui le poussera à faire la suite de ses jeux . 

Et la même chose arriva pour le deuxième jeu Zero Escape, même si cette fois ci au Japon il avait des commentaires positifs, cela ne sera pas accès pour qu'il soit un succès, à l'inverse encore une fois de NA .

Après cela, il demande a Spike Chunsoft si il était possible de faire un jeu en crowdfunding, car a cause des deux échecs de ces jeu au Japon, son dernier jeu n'était pas sur de sortir, et SC lui répondit non . 

Et après que les fans eux-même créent un crowdfunding pour montrer a SC qu'il voulait une suite, ils acceptèrent, et le dernier jeu de cette série incroyable était enfin conclu . 

Puis il quitta le studio, mais cette fois si avec une équipe, et non tout seul, comme écrit précedement au dessus .

Sa philosophie est, d'écrire une histoire dont tout le monde se souviendra, en négligeant l'aspect qualité . Et pour cela il s'aide du Ennéagramme de personnalité ( en gros, il y 9 types de personnage, [b] Leader, Médiateur, Perfectionniste, Altruiste, Battant, Romantique, Observateur, Loyaliste, Epicurien [/b] ) . D'ou le nom du jeu  Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors . 

Et pour finir avec le Wiki, il s'inspire de thème scientifique, philosophique et idéalisme, ainsi que la théorie de [b] Rupet Sheldrake [/b] ( résonance morphique, chercher sur Internet, trop long a expliquer sur cette évaluation, qui est déjà beaucoup trop longue et beaucoup trop bourré de fautes d'orthographes ), et le [b] dilemne du prisonnier [/b] ( la même ) .

Et pour parler enfin du / des jeux, ils sont tout simplement incroyable, on a une histoire incroyable, et pour ne pas se faire chier, on a fourni avec des escape room, qui du coup nous empêche de nous ennuyer a force de trop avoir écouté les personnages ( car perso, le VN ne m'attire pas trop, mais le fait de rajouter un élément de point and click, ou on a l'impression de jouer le personnage lui-même, je trouve l'idée excellente pour un non casu ) .

J'aime énormément l'ambiance musicale de ses jeux, je pense que ses deux jeu Zero Escape ont vraiment la meilleure bande son, est de loin, car quand on y joue, en tout cas moi, je ne savais pas a quoi m'attendre, je cherchais juste un jeu à faire, du coup j'ai chercher sur Internet jeu avec une histoire cool, et paf, Zero Escape . Et quand on ne regarde même pas la bande annonce, et qu'on arrive direct dans le jeu, que rien ne nous est expliqué ET que l'on doit s'échapper avant de mourir, sa donne vraiment envie de savoir pourquoi on est la, et donc de suivre histoire, bref .
Et étant aussi un trouillard, le fait d'avoir des escape room assez glauque a mon sens, ainsi que avec des OST qui représentait exactement les sentiments qu'on avait quand on était dans une de ses pièces, était une expérience incroyable .

J'ai pas trop envie de continuer a dire des choses sur ce jeu, car je préfère que la personne qui lit sa ( si il y en a une haha ) joue au jeu, et se fasse son propre avis, mais personnellement, pour le prix, et le temps de jeu, bien que les graphismes soit peut-être daté, l'histoire en vaut le détour . Et si j'aurais réussi a faire acheter ou bien juste regarder un let's play de ce jeu a quelqu'un, mon évaluation sera réussi à mon sans :)

Ok, let's start with 999! The gameplay was immersive as hell, I loved every ending and interactions. The porting to the PC engine can make the game lose a bit of it's narrator's charm, since the DS had double screens which separated pieces of dialogue and narration (I recommend using NOVEL mode) , but it doesn't make the experience worse in the slightest. In fact, the porting gave us AMAZINGLY-voiced characters (which is quite helpful, considering the long story and huge amounts of dialogue/text), plus the reworked art and a the story flowchart. There are some key points and small changes to the dialogues that must not be missed to unlock some endings, so the player must sometimes replay scenes they already read through just to get that extra info, but it's worth it, I swear.

As for Virtue's Last Reward, I found it quite different from 999, especially the endings and requirements that need to be met to access. From the 7 endings I currently reached, 4 of them require OTHER endings to be finished first in order to unlock those I found, but I think I just got bad luck with my choices, considering I still have a bunch of endings to reach! The game doesn't get as repetitive as 999, since you don't need to read through all that text to experience those small changes in dialogue, so jumping from timeline to timeline feels easier. Very dense story, I suggest you keep track of each route's details since they can get jumbled up if you don't replay the game from the beginning when switching timelines. 
Overall, I would pick 999 over VLR, but that does not mean VLR hasn't an amazing story as well!

Top 5 Nintendo DS game "[b]999: 9 hours, 9 persons, 9 doors[/b]" and its absolute stellar 3DS sequel "[b]Virtue's Last Reward[/b]" are visual novels that alternate narration with escape room puzzles.
If you're new to the genre don't worry as you're gonna get hooked in this synister and chilling story.
About this, there is no visual horror, this is more of a psychological thriller and it nails the sweetspot of being chill-inducing without actually getting gross in any way.

It pains me to see how underrated this saga is despite it being an absolute masterpiece. If you came here because you heard about AI: the Somnium Files play this first since it's cheaper and  a [b]MUCH[/b] better experience.

I recommend this game to anyone who likes Danganronpa, or mystery games in general. It's got great characters with awesome voice acting and an incredible story! In my opinion, 999 had better puzzles and art but VLR had way more enjoyable characters, music, and the story makes you sit and think for a while to understand what you went through. I loved every moment of the 2 games and I hope by some luck we get a new game similar to this! 
It's worth the full price of $30, as you're basically getting 2 games in 1.

(Обзор только на 999, в ВЛР еще не начинала играть, но игра уже окупила себя в пять раз по ожиданию-реальность) Лучшая детективно-пазлвая-новельная-временнопетельная-головоразрывательная-лорноподрывная игра. 10 из 10. Без шуток. Хоть там и было пару моментов которые подзатянутые, но это моя вина, так как мне было интересно что дальш, но лень было читать. Так что, с перерывами когда устаешь будет играться вообще на одном дыхании! Сюжет интересный, кто что и как ты с начала не догадываешься, а только посмотрев хотя бы 2-3 концовки постепенно начинаешь собирать клубочек из того, что говорили люди. При чем каждая фраза нужна, и тут нет пустых диалогов, как может показаться. Так что я настаиваю на том, чтобы те, кому нравятся пазлы, в особенности квест комнаты, и кому хочется еще и интересного сюжета, прошу, поиграйте в этот шедевр)

Не знаю, существует ли в какой-либо другой видеоигре сюжет лучше, чем в 999, но по моему скромному мнению он является таковым во всей трилогии Zero Escape. Таких хитросплетений истории и копаний в философию не в каждой хорошей книги-то найдётся. Ну, и да, головоломки здесь тоже очень хороши. 
В общем, если вы - любитель визуальных новелл, но не играли в Zero Escape, то вы - не любитель визуальных новелл ;)

NOTE & TL;DR: "Reviewing" this is complicated. If I could, this would be a (mostly) Positive review for 999, and a (heavy) Negative review for Virtue's Last Reward (VLR). If you're okay with 999 only for what you're paying, great, go for it! But VLR, at least to me, brings this down so much as a package that I am forced into not recommending it in general.

I think these are games that essentially need to do two things right: the characters must be interesting, and the story compelling. In short, I believe 999 does that well enough, and VLR fails hard at both.

Concerning 999: I really liked all the characters, and while (no spoilers) the story went crazy at the end, I still had a good time through the vast majority of it, so overall, I still found it enjoyable. I do have two complaints:
- As I mentioned, the ending did leave a sour taste in my mouth; it just went bonkers, and I personally don't like that, I would prefer more logical explanations; maybe only a touch of sci-fi/fantasy in it is okay, but this was too much.
- The game, at least on my machine, stutters a lot in certain scenes. I mean, it's a visual novel, it's not like performance is really important, but I swear at least to me it started really getting in the way, the text would display in completely wonky speeds, animations would somewhat freeze and it looked weird AF. Not sure what is up with that, this game should run fine in a toaster nowadays, and my machine isn't even bad.
Regardless, overall, still worth it.

Concerning VLR: this is where things go wrong. Dear Lord. 
Now, the characters just didn't click with me, and that immediately compromises all the rest; and this is the hardest part to comment on, because I can't really just justify or expand it in any way, I just really didn't care about them at any point, and that's a shame. 
But to me the gravest sin this game commits is how much it stops you from progressing. Maybe I was just EXTREMELY unlucky in the paths I choose, but I can't even count how many times I was down a certain path only to be met with a "To be continued..." which locked that tree. Like, seriously. It happened once. Then again. And again. And again. And AGAIN. AND AGAIN. AND AGAIN. AND- HOLY F*CKING SH*T, JUST LET ME FINISH ONE F*CKING TIMELINE. JUST ONE. PLEASE. But no, you MUST follow the specific order of endings the devs chose, otherwise you get locked out. From a certain point of my playthrough, I had absolutely no idea what was happening in any timeline, because I was locked out of some many of them I just couldn't keep up with it anymore and everything completely lost its meaning. It was frustrating AF. 
And that's to say nothing of the fact that most of the endings ("bad" and "normal" ones included) make NO SENSE. Characters act completely irrationally and differently from how they use to, distances and time completely lose any meaning and are super inconsistent, they just any excuse possible to end the game there since you made "a wrong choice" and don't even reveal anything useful. Dammit, if there's nothing to actually choose, if you're not gonna at least write something decent to set reasonable consequences of a bad choice, then don't even give me an option, don't waste my time. 
There are other problems, but they don't bother me as much (models look awful, some puzzles are re-used from the previous game, the true ending is even crazier than the first game, etc.). All these I can easily forgive. But bad writing in a VN? Nah, I'm sorry. No way. It's not like there were no good moments, there were definitely some, but I legit almost dropped this game completely multiple times. Only reason I didn't was because I was so deep into it time-investment-wise, I thought I should just get it over with. 
So yeah, I kinda hate it, unfortunately. There's good in there for sure, but waaaaaay too much frustration. And that's a real shame.

In conclusion, I can recommend 999, but not VLR. If you're fine with that for the asking price, awesome, I hope you have a blast.

善人死亡在总体上还是好评的，Luna线与tureend的剧本与伏笔回收都是加分项，天明寺的身份揭露与zero水中倒影印象也比较深刻。但是善人死亡我个人不喜欢的地方也很多，善人死亡比起前作的核心更偏向了解密上，可是谜题设计的趣味性和难度以及因为多线路所衍生的大量解密房间都让我这种特别讨厌解密游戏的玩家在反复的失去耐心。
另外一点是从2d转到3d这点，善人死亡作为2012年的游戏所展示的3d建模放到2021年的今天简直是惨不忍睹，相较于999的画风简直是被完爆了。
当然这都不是我讨厌善人死亡的主要原因，我最讨厌善人死亡的一点是剧情模式里，在地图上行走与不断开关门黑屏等待音效播放完成的大量冗长无聊的演出时间，真的特别烦特别恶心。
作为999的续作，对上一作中最大谜题神秘的爱丽丝设计与处理更是让我失去了对本作最大的兴趣。
优劣对比后还是能够给一个推荐，在剧本上善人死亡作为ADV是出色的，但是解密的过程游戏性对我来说就很难算得上是喜欢了，如果总体满分是10分的话善人死亡勉强给到7分999则是8分。

Я наткнулась на Zero Escape в поисках аналогов визуальных новелл в жанре смертельной игры, и вошла в серию без малейшего понимания о том, что она представляет собой геймплейно, а также абсолютно без каких-либо надежд получить тот же эмоциональный отклик, какой получила в других немалоизвестных проектах Спайков. Сначала часть головоломок поставила меня в ступор, но потом я втянулась, а по мере знакомства с персонажами потеплела и к тем, кого сначала недолюбливала. Диалоги очень занимательные, персонажи тут как будто действительно активно участвуют в поиске выхода вместе с главным героем, а не взваливают все на его плечи; решение головоломок всегда логичное и не слишком сложное (хотя блокнот все же пришлось для удобства и скорости иметь под рукой), что значит решать их одно удовольствие. Пробег всех развилок и нахождение истинной концовки того стоит, тем более когда система рутов более чем упрощает это дело.

If you like escape room games (or solving puzzles and riddles in general) and if you are up for a great, intense story with a lot of plottwists and different timelines, which might or might not influence each other - this game might be right up your alley. And if you liked Danganronpa, like myself, you will most likely like this series as well. 

Other than that: Graphic is alright (it's a port from handheld consoles after all) and the controls take a little getting used to.

先说结论，现在有汉化补丁，如果想补票的朋友可以入手二刷，不推荐初次游玩的朋友购买steam版。

==============================================================================================

打越钢太郎的EVER17，在当时给文字游戏玩家带来了极其优秀的叙事诡计，再加上之前的MO2，可以说非常合我脾胃。也是为了他制作的999，才入手了NDS。

使用NDS进行游戏，通常是上屏负责演出，下屏负责操作，两者各司其职，进行完整的游戏体验。而999也不例外，使用了这样的操作逻辑，但也正是这样的上下双屏，被打越钢太郎非常狡猾的利用了。当玩到结局关，一切真相揭晓，用手中的NDS做出那种前所未有的操作，游戏沉浸感与爽快感直接拉满。

steam版是单屏幕，将NDS原有的双屏合为一个屏幕，震撼感会直接减半，缺少结局打破双屏固有思维模式的游戏体验。
steam版是全语音，NDS版则是部分语音，也是不能忽视的一点。

所以个人对于999的游玩推荐，是先在NDS模拟器上玩，如果觉得合胃口，购买steam版二刷体验全语音。
如果觉得感觉全语音更加重要，单纯想要体验剧情，不在意剧情与NDS的结合，可以选择购买steam版。

Honestly, the first game is worth it on its own, so the second game is more of a bonus. That being said, both are very very good games. They both feature very well-crafted puzzles and genuinely unique and interesting plots; they're all the more impressive on that front considering they're around ten years old now. That is to say, they feel fresh and new [i]now[/i]. The first game in particular can still manage to throw even veteran visual novel players for a loop, and it manages to do so in a very concise play time. The second can become a bit irritating at times, due in large part to an almost fetishistic obsession it seems to have with not letting you reach any endings. But sticking through it to the end is quite rewarding, especially for those who were strongly invested in the first game. Just be ready and willing to write things down; you'll need to!
Es un juego desafiante en sus acertijos y rompecabezas. Algunas veces me quedo bastante tiempo tratando de resolverlos. Recomendable si te gusta el pensamiento lateral.

I must honestly say that the Zero Escape series is some of the best games I have ever played. The story is so captivating and the gameplay is well balanced between dialouge, puzzles and decisions. Definitely recommended the Zero Escape games to everyone who loves science, puzzles or visual novels!!!

[h1] Characters [/h1]
999 and VLR has some of the funniest characters I have ever seen in a video game and they are made interesting in the narrative, making learning about them all the more fun. Of course, some are better than others but are well written and fit into the story very naturally. Love em!

[h1] Story [/h1]
The story is amazing. I was hooked the moment I played this game for the first time. You find yourself trapped in a strange place and must escape and try to find out the mystery behind why you have been brought there. There are many endings and multiple choices to choose from making it eventually conclude in an amazing conclusion. This is true for the both games included in this bundle (leading into Zero Escape Time Dilemma, the last game in the trilogy which is not included in this bundle). There are tons of extra files and secret interactions to find too if you want which is a delight which gave me a good amount of brain food and laughs. They also incorporate real science and philosophy into everything, making it much more engaging as you try to understand how the game works.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
The main gameplay consists of story and dialoge but occassionally you will get to play escape sequences in form of escape rooms where you must find a way to escape by getting items, solving puzzles and playing minigames. It is a very clever way based on the notion of trying to escape from the place you find yourself trapped in and always feel so rewarding to solve. There were just some puzzles that may not be the best, but compared to how great the puzzles are in general it feels simply perfect. It just is fun. And if you aren't a fan of puzzles there even is an easy mode specifically for them in VLR!

[h1] Overall [/h1]
Truly a masterpiece in my eyes. My aboslute favorite games of all time. Although don't get overhyped due to my bias since I love the abundant science nerdy talk in the games. Play through it yourself if it sounds like something you would like!

[i]Это обзор только на первую игру серии, то есть на Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors.[/i]

[h1]Не просто новелла.[/h1]

Игра представляет из себя чтение текста, оформленного в виде визуальной новеллы, и решение головоломок.

Не стоить пугаться местных головоломок, поскольку они сделаны достаточно умело, что позволяет любому игроку решить их самостоятельно без поиска ответов в гайдах. То есть тут не нужно будет сидеть над одной загадкой часами, как в некоторых квестах, потому что они все логичны, плюс другие персонажи дают полезные подсказки.

[h1]Атмосфера здесь это не просто слово.[/h1]

Игра замечательно удерживает внимание благодаря своей атмосфере. А на атмосферу тут работает все: сюжет, персонажи, озвучка, загадки, музыкальное оформление. Герои ведут себя вполне реалистично для незнакомых людей, оказавшихся в нестандартной ситуации (но не забываем накидывать сюда рамки сюжета).

[h1]Найди путь к спасению![/h1]

Всего концовок в "девятках" 6 штук (хотя основных 5). Сразу настоящую концовку вы не сможете получить. Потому что по задумке автора вы сперва должны открыть другие концовки, чтобы сложить пазл  происходящих событий. Однако вовсе не обязательно получать прям все остальные концовки для получения настоящей. Стоит заметить, что после получения True End вы не получите ответ на все вопросы. Вероятно сложенный вами пазл является лишь частью более большого пазла всей трилогии Zero Escape.

[h1]Мыло или графон?[/h1]

Графончик хоть и подтянули, но он все равно мыльноват.

[h1]Достижения.[/h1]

Достижений в первой игре всего 8 штук. Получить их легко, особенно благодаря местной системе быстрого возвращения к сюжетным точкам, в которых вы делаете выбор. В итоге можно не создавать много сейвов.

[b]Моя оценка[/b] этой игре [b]1+2+3+4+5+6+7+8+9=55=5+5=10=A[/b] из [b]10[/b]

The puzzles! The puzzles from 999: Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors are really enjoyable and make sense in the situation. 因为是Spike Chunsoft就直接入了，搁置了很久。虽然是远古时代的硬核解密，
但在整个游玩过程中依然获得了非常不错的体验。上下两部作品的情节真的脑洞
大开，两者的承接关系也把整个三次nonary game的总体时间线展现的更加清晰。
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
游戏性方面：
初玩《999》时给我的感觉就完全是一个带有轻度解密的AVG，解密的难度不是
非常高，剧情的悬疑程度也处于较浅层，而且为了游戏结局的需要感觉强行设计
了很多莫名其妙的Bad End，还好这些都在之后的第二作得到了改进。

到了第二部《善人死亡》，解密难度大提升，如果说《999》中谜题算是小品级
的话，《善人死亡》的谜题做起来就像再解数学题，没有草稿纸极大概率要卡，
虽然破关之后也确实会有更强的爽感。对于剧情，在第一部建立了完整世界观的
情况下，很自然的引出了关键设定，承接《999》的同时成功地续写了故事，甚
至还有上代角色出场，对于购买合集版的玩家极度友好。
而在剧情方面，《善人死亡》也超过了前作的水准，打到了略微烧脑的程度，在
不同时间线上做文章，虽然略感强行，但还是尽可能避开了悖论和违和感，而这
种非线性叙事的剧本风格也提高了理解剧情需要的思考。新增的SECRET文档对
于补充剧情设定也起了很大的功效，叙事功底拉满。
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
音画质量：
由于是09年和12年发布与3DS平台的上古游戏，移植之后的高分辨率版本也完全
拯救不了画质，界面和游戏操控体验也不佳，不过说实话密室的3D建模还是可以
的，而剧情阶段双语言全语音可以说是完全值回票价。好像最难受的可能还是没
有中文，只能摁啃生肉，极大降低剧情阅读和理解速度，还好对解密没啥影响......

《极限脱出：999》
当时是吃了别人的安利才去玩的这个游戏，用nds模拟器玩的盗版，当时只是随缘玩玩看没想到剧情这么牛逼，最后真结局的时候哗的一下突然什么都明白了，拼命啪啪啪鼓掌到处去搜这个游戏的资料，然后发现还有第二部善人死亡的预告，当时就怀着期待和热切的心态等到了第二部，然而跑3DS平台了，没钱买nds就更没钱买3ds了，只好放弃，这次终于补票了。
我的叙述性诡计初恋作，涉及了很多伪科学，也是让我对这类作品上瘾的初心。
《极限脱出：善人死亡》
觉得善人死亡只是大型预告片的人一定没打过彩蛋！！虽然已经从别人嘴里或多或少知道了一点，但是自己打起来的时候真的是不一样的感觉！！跨越不同的世界线，从不同的世界收集情报，如果说第一部的视角我们真正操控的是零，那么这一部我们真正操控的是玩家自己。
最喜欢的角色是Luna，最嗑的是Sigma和Phi，然而第三部，万恶的第三部，呃啊啊啊啊.......
还有一代的角色，剧透一下参与的人必你以为的要多得多，而且把一代好多坑都填上了，比如ice9和Alice，AB游戏也很有意思，把我的一代滤镜全碎了，脑洞也很牛逼，实际上零真正计算的人是隔着屏幕那头的玩家也就是我们自己，绝了！

首先感谢亲友肉霸霸推荐！是很不错的解密游戏！

然后说游戏本身。
999代入感还是蛮强的，人物也很有特色，整体花了14小时通关，难度适中。
善人死亡，分支更多流程更长，除了陆战棋那边真的看不太懂找了攻略之外其他基本都是自己玩儿的。
说实话善人死亡槽点还是很多的，首先这莫名其妙的人物建模就很劝退……999的画风就很好啊为啥不延续……其次左右挪动画面的变成了鼠标拖动，虽然比QE切换自由但是有时候真的拖不动，好累。而且动画里一直在开门关门地图上位置移动好烦啊还不能直接跳过，再加上第一次走的线路就遇上剧情锁，所以中间一度没啥耐心继续玩了。但是后面大家的秘密逐渐显现，尤其是[b]（此处涉及剧透请谨慎阅读）[/b][spoiler]先怀疑我自己是机器人，最后揭晓我只是机械臂而露娜才是机器人（难怪每次投票她都是协力！），使我受到了莫大的冲击……还有意识来回穿越外加老年茜的那段解说……[/spoiler]整的我完全一脸懵逼……仿佛懂了但没完全懂……不管怎么说解密部分还是很不错的~

当然善人死亡也是一部非常精彩的作品，只是 steam 版是我第一次玩善死，在内心的触动上没有 999 那么深。

Anyway, the game is intertaining. The voice actors do a good job. Some dialog is a bit too slow for my taste because they keep explaining things I already know to quite some lenght. I wish there was some sort of "I'm not stupid" mode. That isn't to say that you don't have to think during this game. EDIT: I've seen all endings of 999 now (some are more intense than others) and started playing the other game in the bundle. So far, I think it's a bit inferior. The controls aren't as spot on (which is to be expected when you go from 2D to 3D) and the characters seem way too calm for the situation they're in. Maybe it'll pick up though.

999: 9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors

Sadistic, ominous, and addicting are all words that could be applied to 999. I like the word badass. It's a tale unlike anything I've seen before and the cast is eclectic but not overtly strange. Everyone here feels like people and not bundles of tropes and caricatures. But you don't need to look at Lotus's cleavage for too long before you remember that the game is still Japanese. Another cornerstone of the mystery visual novel Triforce with Danganronpa and Ace Attorney, 999 feels far more Westernized than the other two, often reminding me more of classic 2000s adventure games than of traditional visual novels, such as Steins;Gate.

The game is structured around escape the room puzzles, which are my least favorite kind of puzzle. And yet... I never found myself in desperate need of help like I usually am in these scenarios. Maybe I was just having a particularly good couple days, or maybe the puzzles are easier or perhaps even... better designed. Either way, it was surprisingly fun.

The story is the real selling point, though, and I won't spoil it. So... play 999. It's amazing. If you don't like it... well... play it anyway.

So I'm giving this game a 1/10 because not nearly enough people have played it. And that upsets me. Grrrrrrr.



Virtue's Last Reward

Much like 999, VLR has multiple endings. And, much like 999, all of the endings are part of the overall story. If you reach one of the endings and then stop, you're not really experiencing the game how it's supposed to be experienced. All the endings lead to one combined ending, which makes the game actually somewhat linear. It also makes the game excruciatingly long. For over 40 hours, I pushed through this game, hotly anticipating answers to all my questions and to have a resolution that could match the incredible last couple hours of 999. But Virtue's Last Reward is basically a 40-hour teaser for the next game in the series, Zero Time Dilemma. Characters are taken from the first game, warped beyond recognition and then thrown back at you with the expectation of emotional payoff and the story never really reaches a resolution.

As for the puzzles, there are infinitely more of them and each one has another side puzzle on top for you to get additional information about the world and characters. I encountered far more puzzles that stumped me than the first one and I did have to stop playing for a bit, but... they're still fun for the most part. I didn't enjoy it as much as 999, but this game made me feel like I wasted my time way more than that one did.

So, in conclusion, Virtue's Last Reward gets a 9/10. I, honestly can't think of any complaints. Everyone loves this game, which means it's objectively more worthwhile than I am.

it's got a good story and I like it. the puzzles can be frustrating, but they're not impossible to do without a guide and while I've only beaten the first game the second game has been a large improvement so far and I think it will continue to be really good

I initially wrote a super long review for this but then my dumb-ass accidentally clicked onto another steam tab. So it's gone now.

Both of these games are fucking awesome. Even if you're new to visual novels, I'd still urge you to play this - since the first game, 999, has such a compelling narrative with a good amount of  satisfyingly consistent plot threads. The second game, VLR, is when things get a bit more crazy, with a ton of different plot lines criss-crossing each other. That has its own personal charm, but it is definitely not as accessible as the first game. Puzzles in both games are rewarding and satisfying, even more so with how details and recurring motifs begin to tie in with the overarching themes of their narratives. I absolutely adore the flowchart system and the unconventional structure of the narrative - that is definitely what makes Zero Escape as unique as it is. 

I'd recommend approaching these games with a little patience and a bit of tolerance for the occasional anime trope/lewd moment, which can either be kinda fucking funny, or a little immersion breaking - it really depends on your taste. But what awaits you is some of the most shocking, satisfying and compelling payoffs in a video game narrative. If you enjoy Danganronpa or other similar visual novels, I urge you to try this. It's criminally niche compared to others in the genre. It's so fucking good - can't decide which one's better right now though. Maybe I would've if I got to keep my initial long review.

play

Can't recommend it enough. I got started with this series to fill the void left by the Danganronpa saga, and this left an even bigger hole in me now ;-;

The way the games handle the branching of the storyline with each decision, and how they seamlessly integrate it with the lore of the game is simply genius. Explaining it any further would fall under the spoiler territory, and the last thing I want is to be the cause for someone's inability to experience ZE in it's full essence... Its a storyline that can only work as a video game, or a stupidly huge novel with decision making gimmicks. 

The games manage to preserve the feeling of mystery from start to end; throwing various plot points that make next to no sense to you throughout the course of the game which fall into place very well as you uncover more and more info. Couple that with the spine chilling setting, the subtly revealed backstories of all the characters, and the overarching plot, it makes for some of the best visual novel if not video game in general, to be developed. 

Personally, the fact that these games break the fourth wall and try to take full advantage of the medium is in itself worthy of bonus points. There are very few games that pull it off very well, and the ZE trilogy make it into that list.

About 999: I played this game in 2018 and completely forgot to review it because I thought I would "definitely play the 2nd game in a bit so I'd review both of them together" (didn't until this day). But I convinced a streamer I like to play it and after watching the entire gameplay I felt like reviewing it. I'll then update it after playing the 2nd game. 

999 has a really interesting story. It's full of mysteries, and even though you don't understand what's happening at the beginning, at the end you'll be like "OOOOOOOOOOOOOH. OKAY. THAT MAKES PERFECT SENSE." and you'll probably start talking about things you'd never thought about before (and keep talking about it for a while).

It has some great characters, and the voice acting is really good. I had a lot of fun unveiling its mysteries and finding out what was really going on. I did get tired of some puzzles, but I think that's on me. I'm lazy and, in the middle of the true ending, I honestly just wanted to know what the hell was going on and not solve any more puzzles.

I hope I find the strength in me to start the second game soon enough.

A highly entertaining and intelligent pair of games that are definitely more than worth their price, given the playtime and enjoyment they'll be able to provide to anyone who is remotely interested in mystery visual novels. I bought them on sale but I would have easily paid full price for the bundle.

I'll admit that I only picked up the games after seeing Mizuki playing 999 in the AI: The Somnium Files Nirvana Initiative trailer, but it was one of the best decisions I made.

999 is one of the most memorable videogames I've played in the past years, and I'm certain that I'm going to hold it close to my heart for quite a while. There's no point in spoiling the story, but I think that the best way to describe it is as something that remains timeless despite being written over a decade ago. It isn't just a "mystery visual novel" but yes a game that gains its own unique identity after you experience it from start to finish. 

Virtue's Last Reward, while not comparable to the first game in the series, makes for an extremely solid sequel to an otherwise complicated series. Needless to say, it only manages to mix things up further; so if you are willing to see how far Uchikoshi's imagination can go, I think it's a perfect addition to the franchise. The storyline is truly intelligent, and the way it uses the game mechanics in order to further emphasize this story is a great demonstration of how something's medium is able to bring out its full potential if used right. 

Despite 999 being my favourite game, I'd say that Luna's route rivals it as one of my favourite moments in Zero Escape. She's extremely precious!

I've heard that Zero Time Dilemma is an unsatisfying ending for the trilogy, so I'm still not sure if I'll pick it up or not, but I would love if the series was rebooted after AI2 is released. Other than that, I'll state once more that these games are definitely worth a play!

小时候玩过NDS版999，因为没有3DS，善人死亡视频通关。
现在都有了PC版，也都有了汉化，当然再玩一遍喽，38个小时，全成就完美通关。
先说999，novel和ADV模式切换虽说不如NDS双屏震撼，但依旧是个良心的移植。不得不说chunsoft移植游戏质量都蛮不错的。新增的flow系统也挺赞，当然了新玩家可能会因此略过一些重要剧情，因为很多东西都是在“密室逃脱”的过程中讲述的（因为有一部分剧情和谜题存在一定的关联），通过flow跳过解谜的话有概率跳过一些没看过的剧情，一定程度上也影响游戏体验。
善死体验相比视频通关好了不少，特别是剧情锁。一开始自己瞎玩确实到处碰到锁，但是随着后期信息越来越多，通过平行世界之间的信息传递解决危机难题，吊锤幕后黑手，那感觉真的爽。类似的体验我在玩yuno的时候也有。
最后说一句，打越yyds！

重複的優點就不多贅述了，這邊就分享一些自己體感上的缺點
(提到重要劇情時會適時黑底防雷，建議破完再看)


[b]【999】[/b]

1.鋪陳偏短，對角色和背景還在摸索時一下就發生各種大事，劇情發展節奏偏快而帶給玩家的震撼度就降低了些。就有點像看到美食是用狼吞虎嚥的吃法，吃完後一會飢餓感又上來的那種空虛感。

2.NDS原版改編成steam版的差異
如果你是只有破完steam版的999，務必去找影片補一下NDS版的999。因為原始的999是以NDS的雙螢幕做設計，雙螢幕的方式才能呈現最原始且更有感覺的遊戲體驗，看了就能了解之間的差別在哪。

還有最後[spoiler]的解謎(PASSWORD跟9)steam版的是改編過後的，原本是要解一個茜視角的數獨，感受有差。[/spoiler]

不過steam版有高畫質、加入各種大咖聲優配音跟盡量還原這些點還是相當讚的!!


[b]【VLR】[/b]

1.令人出戲的模組。有點半成品的感覺，講到驚訝或害怕的台詞時有角色的臉卻是在笑(不雷是誰XD)以及CG模式也都是直接用這模組呈現，不如改回999那樣的2D立繪還比較好。

2.沒必要的過場動畫，地圖要素對劇情也沒有這麼重要，如果是重要的地方就算了，但每次移動都要跑完地圖上點點的移動過程跟開關門的動畫，白白浪費掉很多無意義的時間。

3.收尾[spoiler]很嘔，ED播完本來以為最後跳來跳去可以有結果了，結果突然卡掉。翻了翻路線圖才發現真的沒了，雖然說有要繼續破第三部回收伏筆的心理準備，但這樣收尾個人不太喜歡。[/spoiler]


[h1]總結[/h1]

整體來說仍是瑕不掩瑜的精彩作品，密室的解謎越來越有挑戰性。
如果有喜歡其他打越編劇的視覺小說作品的話，這兩部遊戲也一樣會讓人感到驚艷!

Both the VNs (999 and VLR) contained within this are excellent. The stories are among the most cleverly-crafted I have ever come across. Please don't read about these games before starting them - the less you know, the better.

The puzzle difficulty is hard enough to require careful thought, but not so hard that it necessitates looking up the answer (with the odd exception).

I would strongly recommend this to anyone who enjoys VNs with puzzle sections.

Years ago I played these two games, so bear with me on that. But I wanted to reinforce that these are two of the best games ever made. 999 is a total masterpiece that can stand on its own and yet also integrates wonderfully with the sequel, VLR, a fantastic addition to the series.

Absolutely wonderful characters and overarching plot. Some of the jokes can be a lil bad, but the extremely high quality of the rest makes up for it. Escape rooms are never -too- complicated but can be tough, yet very satisfying to get through. It's incredibly addicting to keep playing to see what happens next. The reveals are G O O D, man.

If you're curious about length, 999 took me ~20 hours and VLR ~50. Incredible deal for the price. If you finish these up and enjoy it, the game that takes place between these, Zero Time Dilemma, is also available. General reception is... "mixed" and I'd have to agree, so if you're burned out after finishing these two you still hit the large highlights of the series.

9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors is one of the most unique visual novel experiences ever made.
With unique puzzles, interesting characters, a deep (sometimes confusing) yet intriguing story it is a must play for anyone who enjoys visual novels and/or puzzle games.

Virtue's Last Reward is an excellent follow-up that does everything 999 did and ups the ante to 200%.
Everything that made 999 so amazing and memorable is present and accounted for.

If you enjoy games like Danganronpa, Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney, or anything like it you will undoubtedly enjoys these as well.

"Plaudite! Acta est fabula!" ~

Zwei Spiele, welche mich bereits vor Jahren schon gefesselt haben. Hier bekommt 'WTF' eine ganz neue Bedeutung. Ich werde das mal ein wenig aufteilen.

999:
Der erste Teil der Trilogie (auch zeitlich gesehen) und somit auch der kürzeste. Es hat ungefähr 7 Stunden gebraucht um die 6 Enden zu erspielen. Die Geschichte ist sehr durchdacht und verzwickt. Man kann leicht mit einigen der Charakteren sympathisieren und pickt sich schnell einen Favoriten aus. Die Story ist darauf angewiesen, dass man verschiedene Entscheidungen trifft und manchmal passieren dann sehr unerwartete Dinge. Die Rätsel sind meist sehr gut machbar, wobei immer direkt zwei Escape Rooms aufeinander folgen. Teilweise gab es aber auch Räume, bei denen ich nicht so genau wusste, wie sie zu lösen waren und auch etwas mehr Zeit investieren musste. Vorallem auch bei sehr großen, unübersichtlichen Räumen. Alles in allem aber hat das nichts an dem Erlebnis der Story geändert. 

VLR:
Der erste Teil der Reihe, den ich damals gespielt habe. Mein All-Time-Favorit. Auch um einiges Länger wie der Vorgänger. Hier hab ich dann doch schon meine 27 Stunden Spielzeit erreicht. Die Charaktere sind so unterschiedlich und tiefgründig, meist sehr unvorhersehbar. Die Musik im Hintergrund ist immer sehr atmosphärisch und passt perfekt. Die Rätsel und Escape Rooms sind auch auf dem schweren Schwierigkeitsgrad sehr gut machbar. Man trifft viele Entscheidungen, welche in vielen unterschiedlichen Enden resultieren. Die Story war sehr spannend und hat sich gut durch die verschiedenen Wege gezogen. Man hat immer ein bisschen mehr erfahren und konnte das 'Puzzle' immer weiter zusammensetzen. Am Schluss wurde dann auch nochmal alles richtig erklärt. Das Spiel ist oft sehr technisch/mathematisch weswegen ein gutes Englisch-verständnis vorausgesetzt wird. Sonst würde es auch einfach keinen Spaß machen. Was ich noch als wichtigen Tipp geben möchte: zwischendurch gibt es Sachen, die man sich wirklich notieren sollte da sie in anderen Enden benötigt werden.

Ich empfinde diese Trilogie als Must-Have trotz der fehlenden Deutschen Übersetzung. Für einen Preis von 25€ auch total okay. Ich bereue den kauf nicht. Die Spiele wären es mir immer wert gewesen. Man muss sich einfach drauf einlassen, denn es ist ein ganz anderes Visual-Novel Erlebnis. Ich kann und werde es jedem empfehlen. Das Entwicklerstudio hat sich bei mir einen hohen Platz verdient und sie werden auch in Zukunft noch viele ihrer Spiele an mich verkaufen können. Denn sie wissen einfach was sie tun.
