I want to first state that the game I recommend is specifically 999, not Virtue's Last Reward. 

  999 was definitely a fun experience, especially with friends. The puzzles were challenging, but still fun. Most of the characters were enjoyable, to varying degrees, and the voice acting was passable. Nothing special. The story got convoluted near the end of the true route, though. There were a handful of "macguffin-y" moments. Besides that, I enjoyed playing through the various routes and solving the mystery as we went.

  Despite liking the first game, and finding the third funny enough to warrant completely mastering, I have no motive to finish Virtue's Last Reward. The models look unpolished and unappealing. I find the characters generally unlikable, along with their voice acting. The atmosphere is... dry. Maybe if someone were to convince me enough to finish it with them, I might, but as it stands, it shall remain abandoned.

999 and Virtues Last Reward have some of the best stories and characters in the history of video games. The gameplay is fun and rewarding but can be confusing and frustrating at times. If you like a game with multiple endings or games with an amazing story or puzzle games in general, then you owe it to yourself to buy and play The Nonary Games.

First, you play the story and know nothing. Then, you play the story and try to know something. Then, you play the story so you can change something. When you know everything, it's incredible, and then - you win.

These two visual novels are a single player (extra convoluted) variant of the party game Mafia, except traveling in time and witnessing alternate realities are both perfectly legal game moves. All wrapped in compelling murder mysteries with some sci-fi themes on the side. Both games start out slowly to get the player used to  mechanics, but eventually everything comes together into stories that deliver dozens of inexplicable twists one after another. Before the plot reaches top speed, it is supported by engaging and detailed character development, and a lot of escape room puzzles - their design is undoubtedly one of the best in the genre: presented in an intuitive form that makes all solutions logical, yet still very satisfying.
8/10 Worth playing, but not one of the best games in the genre

Предисловие:
Приобретая данный товар мы получаем сразу две игры из серий Zero Escape, а именно 999 и Virtues last reward.
[h1] 999 [/h1]
Обозрею только первую часть, так как вторая часть проходится гораздо дольше из за моих плохих знаний в английском.
Что мы имеем? Игра представляет собой Визуальную новеллу с элементами пазла. НО, не просто пазл, типо собери 3 в ряд, головоломки в игре гораздо интереснее) По сравнению они больше напоминают квест или же эскейп румы. Сейчас о них пойдет речь.
[h1] О сюжете и эскейп румах и дедукций[/h1]
В игре у каждого персонажа есть браслет с номером от 1 до 9, и по правилам игры они могут проходить через двери также от 1 до 9, только если их общий цифровой корень равен номеру данной двери. Это правило буквально является главным. Однако при входе игроки должны решить квест комнату.
В данных комнатах очень много абдуктивных и математических загадок и пазлов. Жаль, только, что по сравнению с Zero Time Dilemma, они заметно короче и пазлы в некоторых комнатах не такие уж и сложные. Но простить это можно, учитывая, что это первая игра в серий.
По итогу выяснится, что среди испытуемых есть убийца. Тут в дело вступает немножечко логики, дедукций. И если брать в учет главное правило, то это тайна быстро разгадывается. Рекомендую испытать это на собственном опыте!
[h1] Немного о порте [/h1]
Игра перенесена еще с старенькой нинтендо дс. Однако та имела два экрана, что я считаю было интереснее, но имеем, что имеем. К слову, порт очень годный, в игру добавлено сюжетное древо и встроенный калькулятор цифрового корня, что облегчает немного прохождение.
[h1] Стоит ли брать? [/h1]
Издатель реально клоун. Поэтому советую дождаться скидок и прикупить.
Либо же бегом за Нинкой дс или 3дс!

999 is a masterpiece. I don't think I can say more than what other people already have said. However, you're better off emulating 999 than playing this port. I initially played it on DS and replayed it on steam (as well as watched a few people play it on my account, hence the massive playtime, lol), and there are some noticeable issues with the port. The most I can go into it without spoiling the game is that the DS version had dialogue split between two screens, and in the move to one screen, the dialogue severely suffers in ways you would not expect. There's an excellent YouTube video on this subject if you've already played the game and are curious. With that said, I just urge you to take my word for it. This game is best experienced on a DS. I know the port does introduce a flowchart which is quite handy, but the handiness doesn't make up for the other issues, unfortunately. 

Virtues Last Reward runs great in the port and I have no qualms on it, lol. Except for the fact that its just a bit better to play on 3ds (you have two screens, and in escape rooms you can cross reference files against the puzzles much easier). But if you don't have a 3ds or would rather just play it on PC, its a very solid pick. 

Overall, I can recommend this port, but you should at least experience a portion of 999 as intended first.

Things to note:
[olist]
    [*]Zero Escape: The Nonary Games contains 2 games: Nine Hours, Nine Persons, NIne Doors and its sequel, Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward. The 3rd game in the series, Zero Time Dilemma, is sold separately.
    [*]This is a PC port for both games, with no technical issues that I recall.
    [*]This is mainly a visual novel, with some escape room puzzles as "The Nonary Game".
    [*]The main gimmick of these games are the multiple possible timelines, as such you have to get all the endings for a complete narrative.
    [*]A portion of the puzzles involve mathematics, from single-digit addition to simple algebra. About 5% of the puzzles are objectively bad, though most of them aren't mandatory (and none of them are the math ones).
    [*]Game gets a bit preachy to ensure the dumbest of players can follow.
    [*]Anime fanservice exists, but mostly relegated to visual design of certain characters. Stomachable.
    [*]For Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward, solving optional puzzles will give you Silver or Golden Files. [b] Do not [/b] read them until you've finished the game.
[/olist]

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is a fantastic duology, with two amazing games. The characters in both games are very memorable, and while the overall scenario is rather dark (the Nonary Games are essentially murder games, in a way), the amount of gore depicted is actually surprisingly mild.

I don't recommend the third game, which isn't included as it doesn't actually include a Nonary Game, but I highly recommend giving these two a whirl!

The first two games in the Zero Escape trilogy bundled together for $30 is an absolute steal. Both games have similar premises and build off each other's storyline, but the twists they have in the story is absolutely fantastic. The puzzles are also well thought out and intricate. More so in the second game (Virtue's Last Reward), the first game (9 hours, 9 persons, 9 doors AKA. 999) tends to be centered more on one main gimmick that gets old pretty quickly. 

I will say though, this series gets really hard to follow, really fast. Both games also suffer from plot dumps at both the beginning and ending of the games. The second game is a bigger offender of this that the first, but that doesn't mean the first game gets a free pass.

There's also a LOT of reading. The games are voice acted, but there's several parts where there's no voices and you just gotta read for while. Not quite as long as a Visual Novel, but it can feel like it sometimes

The price gets pretty low during sales considering the age of these games, but $30 is well worth it in my opinion. Fans of puzzle games will enjoy the puzzles, and those who like a good story will find a good one here.

The puzzles and story are fabulously done, even if the timeline does make my brain hurt.

[b]The dazzling presentation of a top-notch visual novel. [/b]

If you're looking for a really great story, mystery, Choice matter, Conspiracy theories, interesting experiments, emotional, and puzzle game. I can't recommend this game enough! Please, take a look. It's such a shame this game is so criminally underrated. and if you're a newcomer to this genre. This game is the best to start with: there are no pacing issues: It really has almost pitch-perfect pacing compared to other Visual novels games, which are so slow progress.

[b] The Story:[/b] 
The BGM, the Story itself, and the last Puzzle are mixed up perfectly. A unique and great story concept, and well-written characters: their background and motivation line up with their action and dialogue very well. 

[b] The Gameplay (Puzzle & Choice matter):[/b] 
sublime and clever puzzle design, brain-melting puzzles, it's really challenging, really a top-tier puzzle design, especially in VLR.
The choice matter is freaking a lot. and almost ALL choices have actual consequences.

[b] The soundtrack:[/b] Good, So Emotional, Memorable.

The annoying things are just you have to finish the game 10-20 times, to get the true ending, and wanky terrible animation of VLR.

WHAT(999)
Absolutely insane story telling combined with great puzzles in the escape room sequences. Probably the best in the genre.

This game is a compilation of the first two games in the Zero Escape franchise: Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors (999) and Virtue's Last Reward. Released as a port of the DS-based system, certain elements of function have been retained from the two-screen setup, while other elements have been awkwardly transposed to benefit a single-screen play experience. Graphics also linger at the lower fidelity of their original system, but transcend the confines of their pixels over the course of the game to render the setting transfixing and the characters memorable. Fans of Danganronpa will take fluidly to most game mechanics and the large everyone-is-important cast. The writing (and math!) is well-researched and seems determined to educate the players on topics as far ranging as Game Theory, the White Star Line's flagship steamers, and ESP. With dozens of hours of content and multiple endings (all plot important!), the Zero Escape trilogy is a solid addition to your library at full price. Do yourself a favour and pick it up today!

Two top notch puzzle/escape room visual novels. The mystery aspect is great, and both games are able to tackle higher level topics without leaving the reader clueless (similar to something like steins;gate). 

Both games have cliffhanger endings, so be aware that if you enjoy 999, you are going to need to play VLR to have lingering questions answered. And then VLR has questions that don't get answered, so you have to play Zero Time Dilemma. Additionally, both games have questions that go unanswered because the author wants you to come up with your own conclusions. 

Both of these games were made on very old hardware, so there's a few janky things about the puzzle rooms and UI that would've been smoother on the touch screens of the DS systems/Vita. They don't ruin the experience but make the rooms slightly more annoying than they should be.

Virtue's Last Reward has a particularly annoying nitpick: any time your character in the novel mode moves to a new area, the game HAS to show you on the map how they're getting there, and it is super slow. I feel like I spent a fair bit of time during the novel sequences looking at my phone waiting for the character to get to the next room.
Also, the VLR 3D character models are decent, but the animations are ass. Would've been way better if they kept the drawn models from 999.

Would absolutely recommend regardless of any flaws.
played this on my vita years ago and being able to play through the amazing story and meet the characters again is great, definitely one of my favorite games! :)
I would not recommend if you don't play all three games in order and that you play all of them

For context: I played the last game in the trilogy (Zero Time Dilemma) a few years back and I actually played it twice. Only now have I played the these two games. So I do recognize some of the characters and I may be a bit biased for ZTD. I was interested in the series since I enjoy puzzle games and an interesting sci-fi story.

TL;DR : Highly recommend if you like puzzle games, but is VLR really that good that ZTD is popularly regarded as the worst of the trilogy?

999: Relatively short and simple story, compared to the other two games, which I think is one of its greatest strengths. I played ZTD, but I was still happily surprised by some of the plot twists. I would also like to say that I appreciated its storytelling and its emotional moments. The escape rooms aren't that hard, but still enjoyable as the first game of the series. Not much to say about this one, since a lot of my thoughts are for VLR.

VLR: It's almost twice as long as 999, so bigger plot, more possibilities. That's not necessarily a bad thing, but the thing is that at the start, I was engaged by the plot and I was still riding the high of just finishing 999, but halfway through, it felt somewhat like a chore instead. 
999 always you to easily go back to certain important points of the story without much hassle, but that does not seem to be the case for VLR. I honestly think I broke my mouse with the amount of left click mashing I did to go (skip) through a considerable amount of dialogue I pretty much already seen. There's an autoskip option which fast forwards, but that makes it tricky to pause and play again at normal speed.
  
Ok, so the next paragraphs are the meat of my review:

One notable improvement from 999 are the escape rooms. The escape rooms and puzzles are much harder and more memorable. As escape rooms and puzzles are one of the main reasons I played this game, I would already recommend others to buy/play this game. However, some of the instructions are vague and unclear that I wouldn't judge you if you looked at a walkthrough online. [spoiler] The two times I looked at a walkthrough was when I knew what to do but I had to be creative to actually think of the solution (tangram, it wasn't actually a walkthrough I just peeked at a solution using Google images) and the other time was a little bit my fault as I didn't notice something on one of the hints but mostly the game's fault for being unintuitive (dice game map, for some reason, the square you start on is part of the counting which shouldn't be for real life dice board games like monopoly). [/spoiler] I myself occasionally lucked out by just doing random things and sometimes I wouldn't be sure why what I did was correct. In 999, I thought fixed camera angles for the escape rooms were a negative point (it actually makes it a little easier, but more importantly, the switching of camera angles in 999 is not that intuitive and therefore, confusing), but I appreciated them after playing VLR. VLR gives you freedom with left-right camera movement, but the camera follows a certain path in each room (which is occasionally annoying) and moving the camera (at least using keyboard and mouse) is annoying too (wasd is somewhat slow, dragging with mouse sometimes doesn't feel right). Also, up-down camera movement is not that possible, even though you would sometimes want to do such movements (like the needed item is barely visible with the usual angle and elevation, though such moments are rare). 

Regarding the plot, for some reason, it does not resonate with me as much as it does with most of the playerbase. Maybe it's because I played ZTD first? When I think of ZTD, though I don't even remember most of what happened [spoiler] including the part that's most relevant to the rest of the trilogy [/spoiler], but there are some moments I really cherish. I don't think VLR reached the emotional highs of ZTD. What VLR has are better plot twists. Some of the plot twists I correctly guessed, as I already played the other two games, but some still caught me by surprise, including one at the end. However, the problem is that some of best parts are hidden behind some of the most draining exposition dumps. I really don't appreciate that after going through some of the hardest escape rooms in the trilogy, I would be met with a mountain of text, some of which you've already seen before. I mean, the repetition due to the innate structure of the story (remember when I said it felt like a chore?) is also quite draining. It also doesn't help that some endings are really just "Oh read this!". Remember that plot twist at the end which I was surprised by, it happens after a) an interesting escape room b) a MOUNTAIN OF EXPOSITION, c) a couple of scenes. [spoiler] At one point, they give you a diagram to explain the plot and I thought that that made it obvious that the plot was too complicated and longed for the relative simplicity of 999. It's not that I don't like sci-fi, I liked ZTD, but this was not that enjoyable [/spoiler] By the time the twist was revealed, I was already drained and could only be slightly amused. OH WAIT, this was followed by a big fat "Play the next game to know the entire story!", which unfortunately for the creators, they run out of money for and it was a miracle that ZTD was even released. My point is that the payoff of the game isn't even that big, since you would have to play another game.  [spoiler] Consider as well that having ZTD as essentially VLR Part 2 puts some restrictions on what could happen in ZTD [/spoiler]

You may think after reading this that I hate this game, but I actually don't. The escape rooms and plot twists make this game worth it. It's just that the flaws of VLR are so obvious that I'm surprised that people a) aren't talking about them and b) think that ZTD is the black sheep compared to this.

I will be replaying ZTD after writing this review to see if it's really that bad.

Trust me when I say these are some of the best visual novels I've ever played. Well worth the money even at full price. You won't regret any of the time you spend scratching your head while trying to solve puzzles and make sense of the mystery of the Nonary Game!

[i]Note: I have played both games in this launcher at least twice each, my initial playthrough being many years ago, and my most recent playthrough in a group environment being during 2023/2024. Most of these hours are unlogged due to the play session being hosted by other people.[/i]

This is one of those games that makes me wish Steam's recommendation system had more nuance.

[i]9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors[/i] remains one of my absolute favourite story-based games. It is a wonderfully woven mystery that gradually unravels into a very clear picture, and the story stands up even if you already know the twists. Each ending feels like a reward or offers some contribution to the big picture. Please consider giving 999 a chance. 

[i]Virtue's Last Reward[/i] is... well.
I used to think it was okay. I didn't outright enjoy it as much as the first game, but I had a good enough time that I was happy to leave a positive review lumping both games together as "worth a shot."

Though I don't regret the 51 in-game hours with friends over the past year, I absolutely regret the fact that they were spent playing Virtue's Last Reward. Usually bad media is made better with friends, but not even that could save this game. Due to our route order, it took roughly 20 hours to get a single named ending. There was a significant lack of narrative catharsis in a majority of the endings, including the first several we got. Even the true ending was — while much more cathartic — infuriating in its own way.

With the unskippable repetitious dialogue across entirely separate routes, the hour-long segments of explaining the same thing three times in a row with only slightly different takes each time (I'm not exaggerating), the never-ending map screen animations, the characterization of returning characters feeling entirely off, the unintuitive puzzles, and the overall bloated feel the entire game had, I do not feel that [i]Virtue's Last Reward[/i] respected my time. If you would still like to play it, please, avoid the wiki for sake of spoilers, but absolutely use a guide. I genuinely believe that is the only possible way you may enjoy this game.

Played 999 on the DS and just platinum-ed Virtue's Last Reward on my Vita.

Visual Novels being a niche genre as it is, I can understand if many are apprehensive or just haven't heard of this series at all. But I would implore you to check this series out. 

If you prioritize stories in the video games you play such as I do, I'm thinking you'll be quite impressed with how much this game pushes the envelope in terms interactive storytelling. Not to mention the soundtrack is one of the most low-key amazing, focus-inducing, hauntingly serene music you'll find in video games today. 

Games rarely send chills up and down my spine. This game did more than once.

'The Nonary Games' is fantastic and thought-provoking and most definitely worth a shot.

Great blend of visual novel and puzzle games, the Zero Escape series is chock full of great characters and a story so insanely wacky yet strangely sensible that it could only come from the wonderfully creative Kotaro Uchikoshi, who also did the writing for AI: The Somnium Files. The series is full of the most unexpected plot twists I've ever seen, and the story is immensely satisfying from the beginning of the first game to the ending of the third. The character models and animating are, well... not the best, but they aren't the reason the game is so enjoyable. Everything else is so good that it's easy to give the visuals a tolerable pass!

A lovely set of games that finds you in a puzzle battle for survival, finding a nice middle ground between a visual novel and a series of escape rooms to tell a thrilling narrative with multiple endings to discover. Voiced in Japanese and English which is nice to have the choice. If you're looking for a Corse Party with a bit less horror elements, and with a larger focus on puzzle solving, then I think you'll enjoy the nonary games!
Great puzzle and visual novel aspects, very unique and interesting stories.

Sans le moindre doute, [b]Nonary Game[/b] et surtout son premier opus "[b]999[/b]" plaira aux amateurs de mangas typés thriller psychologique tels que [i]Death Note[/i], [i]Liar Game[/i], [i]Doub[/i]t, [i]King Game[/i] et plein d'autres bandes dessinées et animés nippons. Et comme dans ces oeuvres du pays du soleil levant, nous retrouvons dans Nonary Games des personnages stéréotypés : la jeune fille jolie et fragile, la bimbo, le colosse, le punk rebelle, le ténébreux. Et ces protagonistes, tout aussi peu originaux qu'ils soient, sont en revanche embrigadés dans un scénario halelant bourré de rebondissements. 

Et croyez-moi, l'aventure vaut le coup d'être vécue ou plutôt jouée, rejouée et re-rejouée. Car il vous faudra plusieurs "runs" pour comprendre les tenants et aboutissants de l'histoire et découvrir la véritable fin. Un vrai chef d'oeuvre que j'ai dévoré pendant une bonne dizaine d'heures, m'attachant aux personnages, et tombant de ma chaise une bonne paire de fois.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2528094292
Si la bande son est plutôt monotone et parfois peu adaptée aux situations, les doublages en japonais sont en revanche vraiment excellents. Je vous recommande donc d'y jouer de cette manière et non en doublage anglais, même si cela reste une question de goûts. Quant aux sous-titres, ils sont certes uniquement en anglais mais de très bonne qualité et la traduction du japonais n'a pas du être une mince affaire tant les mots sont importants dans ce jeu. L'intrigue est en effet complexe, et bourrée d'éléments qu'il vous faudra comprendre afin de raccrocher les wagons. Les protagonistes heureusement feront de même en expliquant régulièrement leurs déductions. Dommage d'ailleurs que le jeu n'en profite pas pour demander l'avis du joueur lui même, afin de s'assurer qu'il a bien assimilé les différents détails et relations. On est en effet la plupart du temps sur un jeu narratif de type visual novel.

 Heureusement, les scènes narratives vont régulièrement place à des phases d'énigme sous forme d'escape game. Comme dans SAW, mais en moins gore, les infortunés personnages devront s'échapper d'une pièce en résolvant des puzzles tout en prenant garde à leurs coéquipiers. Les puzzles ne sont pas bien compliqués mais nécessitent néanmoins de réfléchir un peu, notamment dès lorsque ça parlera de chiffre et de codage.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2528324230
Pour cette review, je ne mentionne que "999" : 9 hours, 9 persons, 9 doors. Mais ce "Nonary Games" contient en réalité deux jeux, le second étant Virtue’s Last Reward. Je ne l'ai pas encore fait, mais nul doute que le scénario me passionnera. Dommage toutefois que dans cette suite, les graphismes de type BD aient laissé place à une sorte de... de... de truc plutôt moche en fait. Mais bon, je m'y ferai sans doute une fois que je serai happé dans le terrible jeu de la mort et les rouages de son scénario.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2528201671

*本作包括极限脱出系列999和VLR两部。
《999》：7.5/10，时长约20h
就算解谜一般，流程冗复，打越作品的一个迷人之处在于提出的主题概念非常有趣。借由古早民科边角料堆砌而成的形态形成场，给人的讶异感却要甚过人类补全计划和意识赛博空间：“就像信息在它们之间迅速地传播”，我们又从大脑这面显示屏上读取到了什么？这充满温情与危险的贸然之旅，仍能在游戏交互的实验性中再感动玩家数十年。
《善人死亡》：8/10，时长约30h
零时困境超大型预告片，解谜篇挖的坑比答案还多。播片比密室好玩暂且不提，打越作品里的人设和吹水也就一直这样，本作在形态形成场的基础上又设计了一整段精巧的时空弹弓，对时间的单向箭矢做了巧妙的调度；同时，多轮博弈和色彩分组的分支更增加了剧本架构的复杂性。也正是如此，善人死亡虽然显得比999更精致，却在不断蓄积叙事势能的同时，折旧了玩家的情绪张力，结局里没有磅礴的感动，只有惊疑与讶异。矛盾的动机被另外的谜题替换，留下这个时空无喜无悲的烂摊子——玩家像Tenmyouji一样唏嘘着月球往事，却永远无法理解Akane空白的半生，只能重返地球——庆幸的是，Phi最后也没告诉Sigma那不能说的秘密：另一个“我”对历史与未来神秘的部署，为追寻青鸟的此刻的在场者，留下了可把握的持存的尊严。

SPOILER FREE REVIEW -
Sets an incredibly high standard as far as visual novel style games go. Zero Escape: The Nonary Games has some absolutely amazing and natural English voice acting, a deeply interesting mystery story with enjoyable and memorable characters no matter which route you go down, and an overall unique style that kept me absolutely enthralled. The characters just having long discussions about scientific theory is honestly one of the most interesting and engaging parts of the game, to the point where I can still remember a ton of those discussions of the top of my head. The puzzles are challenging but rewarding, giving the player plenty of "Eureka!" moments. There are a few that can admittedly be frustrating but those would be times I can count on a single hand. And hey, the price is an absolute bargain even when not on sale considering you're getting two full length games. 

Whenever I play a visual novel now, the Zero Escape series has become the standard I have to compare it to because of the amazingly high quality games they have produced. They take full advantage of the medium, including turning tropes of the genre on their head, to tell an engaging and mind-bending story. I wish there were more games like it, and really hope to see more from the studio.

**THIS REVIEW IS FOR THE FIRST GAME ONLY (999)**

Just finished playing my 2nd favorite game of all time once again. It's been 7 years since the first time I played it (should have waited two more years...)

999 (9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors) is a graphic novel thriller/adventure game that takes place on a giant cruise liner. You are one of the 9 characters. You wake up in a bedroom on the boat, have no idea where you are or why you're there, and you essentially play an escape room to get out of that initial room, solving logic and number puzzles along the way.
Eventually you get to know the other 8 characters, who at first seem to have no relation to you at all. As the story unfolds and you progress through more escape rooms, everything begins to make sense and culminates in what is one of the tightest, most intricately woven plots of all time in any genre.

There are thematic elements of controversial scientific theories, many times used as metaphors during the escape rooms and parts of the narrative. The number '9' is very central to the plot as well, which at first is obvious from the title but you find out more later on. You also learn a bit of history and basic number theory, though most of it is fiction.

One of the rare 10/10 perfect games, an incredible piece of art. And though it was intended to be a stand-alone, it actually spawned two sequels as well. The original release was on Nintendo DS but it's now also on Steam (obviously) and PS4 with updated mechanics and voice acting, along with its sequels. 

Why are you still reading this? Go buy this game!

Please Play Zero Escape

Pretty Good for a hybrid Visual Novel.

As stated above "The Nonary Games" are fundamentally visual novel based games, so there's going to be quite a lot of dialogue and text to skim your eyes upon. Thankfully however, these remasters feature full, voice overs for those that get tired or . . . don't feel like reading; despite that being its format.  Yet the hook for both "9 Hours 9 Persons 9 Doors" and its sister title "Virtues Last Reward" is that these are also part of the escape the room / point and click genre, so the player will most likely be fully immersed and pulled into the main character's shoes. 18 characters all held captive in mysterious facilities, no clue where they are or why this is happening. All they know is they are part of two sadistic "Nonary Games" and must escape or they die. Get the gist? 

Now this is why I good time and will recommend. 

Seek A Way Out

The puzzles are good. 999's are admittedly easier yet were not too easy to the point I solved them all under a minute. In other words it was at an acceptable difficulty to the point it was welcoming and wouldn't scare me off. They were all fair. Then moving on to the second game VLR, the rooms felt more challenging. While writing this, I actually have sitting next to me, a full sheet of paper covered in notes for all the puzzles that  left me scratching my head. Some proved frustrating but like the first game, all were fair and an answer was waiting for you. For a sequel the first game almost felt like a warm up, therefore I will say the increased brain power necessary was appropriate. 

Mystery Story (Non-Spoiler)
Omg the story for these two games is CRAZY. Without spoiling I'll just say listen to everything these characters tell you even if its the 5th explanation, ya might need to. The story of "The Nonary Games" is as much of a puzzle as the rooms themselves. The narrative takes full utilization of its flow charts. Each timeline your choices take you, will give pieces to the work's jigsaw puzzle until you get the full picture. 9 characters stuck in an unknown place, with an unknown ringleader, with an unknown cast, with an unknown purpose. But its your job to connect all the fragments. Yes this will take "multiple" playthrough's and yeah it will get repetitive (VLR with its 26 endings God Dang it!!!) But trust me, the 99 hours I've played of this well woven, minding bending journey was worth all that time. 
I don't want to say more else I'll ruin it all. 

So if you'll excuse me I'll be moving onto "Zero Time Dilemma" while in fear of my own subconscious.

[h1] ミステリーではない、むしろ熱い展開のSF冒険 [/h1]
本作のネタバレを極力避けて、本作の特徴を説明する方法を思いついたので、実践してみることにする。
諸兄は、綾辻行人作「Another」という作品をご存知だろうか(小説でもアニメでもどちらでも可)。とある中学校では「怪奇現象」が起きて、子供たちがさまざまな事故で死んでいく、というのが大筋のスタートだ。いやAnother本編のネタバレも避けたいが、どうしてもこれを語らぬわけにはいかないので、Zero EscapeもAnotherも見たいからネタバレは困るという人はここまでにされたし。
できる限り「ボカした言い方」を使うと、Another本編のネタバレはこのように書けるだろう：[spoiler]タイトル「もうひとりの」の通り、元凶となった存在が「あの人」だったわけだ。序盤の「あの子」の印象が強く(まぁ眼帯っ子だし登場時間も長いし)、いわゆるミスディレクションで正解から遠ざけられていた。[/spoiler]その答えを導き出すために[spoiler]「あの子の目」が役に立った、という展開である。[/spoiler]しかし、これをミステリー作品として解釈しようとすると困ったことになるだろう：超能力者が事件を解決する、というような、無茶苦茶な話となるのだ。その点を酷評する人も事実多い。ノックスの十戒「2. 探偵方法に、超自然能力を用いてはならない」等も参照されたし。
しかし、Anotherもまたミステリーではなかったとしたら、この点も解決する。たとえば、AnotherはSFならぬ「ホラー・フィクション」であり、超常現象は解明されるものではなく、その混乱の中に追い込まれた人物たちがどのような行動を起こすのかを描いた群像劇であると考えたら、どうだろうか。
Zero Escapeシリーズ(3作)も、同様である。本作『Zero Escape: 9時間9人9の扉』(洋題では"Zero Escape: 9 Hours 9 Persons 9 Doors"、略称として"999"と呼ばれる)も、ストーリーの前半50-60%くらいがミステリー的進行をしながら語られ、脱出ゲーム部分は超科学的なこともなく、読者は超能力のちの字も考えずに進めていくだろう。しかし本作は、繰り返すが、ミステリーではないと考えるべきである。ミステリー的進行と考えてしまうことこそ、「Another」が展開したようなミスディレクションの結果であり、本作は※重大なネタバレ※[spoiler]サイエンス・フィクションの世界で展開される、時間旅行冒険[/spoiler]なのだ。
本作『Zero Escape: 善人シボウデス』(Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward、略称VLR)も同様である。直接的な続編であるため、前作にあたる『999』を完全にクリア(Steam実績[spoiler]ヒッチハイク[/spoiler]の獲得に相当)してからでないと、ストーリーが見えてこない(いや、クリアしても尚、最初のしばらくは見えてこないのだが)。また、本作ではより知的好奇心をくすぐる要素がいくつか増えており、例えば作中ではラテン語の格言がたびたび引用されているほか、文字を入れ替えるとメッセージになるアナグラムが多用されている(完結編『Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma』にも同様、っつか[spoiler]タイトル自体もアナグラムだし……[/spoiler])等、物語の展開の最中に脱出ゲームとは異なる楽しみが追加されている。前作に続き本作も※重大なネタバレ※[spoiler]サイエンス・フィクションと選択的時間旅行[/spoiler]であり、前作からの様々な布石が繋がっている。もちろん、本作も完結編に繋がってゆくのだが。
 
ゲーム自体について、そろそろ話題を進めておこう。
◎[u]脱出ゲーム部分について[/u]
『ZE:999』では最悪手詰まりしたとしても、同じ部分を何度も調べることで、その場に居合わせたキャラ(主人公ひとりの場合は心の声)が、徐々にヒントを述べてゆくので、よっぽどのことが無い限りクリアは万人に可能だろう。よっぽどっていうのは例えば「ネジで留められている」という言葉の意味を理解できず「ドライバーを探す」とか「持っているドライバーでそのネジを外す」とか思いつけないような学のない人間のレベル。また『ZE:999』ではそのヒントを出したところでペナルティーも無いので割と気楽である。尤も、脱出ゲームの最中に※重大なネタバレ※[spoiler]脱出とは関係ない部分で話を聞く部分[/spoiler]がある等、気楽ではあるが気を抜けないのも事実だが。
『ZE:VLR』では『999』で何度も調べているとキャラが勝手に答えを言うのが面白くないという意見があったのだろうか、脱出ゲーム部分は「HARDモード：ノーヒントで展開される」と「EASYモード：手詰まりしてるとヒントという横槍を突っ込まれる」が存在する。これは脱出ゲーム開始ごとにHARDで始まり、任意のタイミング(+とある強制条件)でEASYに切り替え、そして不甲斐ない主人公に代わり取り巻く女の子たち(男も居るがたいていの脱出ゲーム部分は女の子が取り巻いている)に手取り足取りされるのだ。……で、HARDモードでクリアすると、本作のストーリーをより深く味わえる「シークレットファイル」がすべて解禁できる(EASYでは半分しか解禁されない)。
◎[u]ストーリー部分(内容ではなくシステム面など)について[/u]
『ZE:999』にも『ZE:VLR』にも、オートモードが存在するので、たとえば2画面にして片方流しっぱなしにして、分岐や脱出ゲームに差し掛かったら操作する、というような使い方も可能。オートが使えないというレビューが散見されるが、設定を詳しく見ていないのだろう。本作ではクリック進行、オート読上、スキップの3つが選べるが、厳密にはスキップは未読オート読上と未読スキップ(設定画面から選べる)となるので4種類あり、物語パートではCtrlキーで切替可能である。まぁ、ノベルゲーム(もとい旧来からあるエロゲ)のエキスパートたる諸兄にとっては冗長な説明であっただろうか。
『ZE:999』ではそのシステム的な部分が※ややネタバレ※[spoiler]クライマックスを印象付ける[/spoiler]役割を担うが、そこまで重要な要素ではないだろう。まぁ熱い展開であることに変わりない。操作がしづらいという意見がまれにみられるが、大抵は環境の問題。
『ZE:VLR』はシステム面については一般的なノベルゲームであるのでとくに記載することはないだろう。一点だけ注意しておきたいのがデバイスとの互換性である。ジョイスティックを常設している、もしくはジョイスティックが使用可能なデバイスを装備している場合、左上方向に入力されっぱなしになるというバグに遭遇した人が多数いる。私の環境ではLogitech G13キーボードに、使っていないがジョイスティックの機能が装備されているので、デバイスマネージャーからジョイスティック機能を無効化(使ってないのだしまぁいい、必要なら後で戻せる)し、WIndows再起動の後、そのバグは回避できた。
 
おすすめできるか、というならば、現代のライトノベル的展開が好きな人なら◎、ミステリーを求める人には×、としておこう。
価格はどうか、ミステリー物ではないにせよ「1度きりの熱い体験」である(2度目からはネタバレ状態、まぁそれもいいのかもしれないが……)、2作でこの価格ならとりあえず○、というところだろう。
品質はどうか、日本語に不自然な表現は無い◎、英語は訳でなく書き直しされているので良好◎、グラフィック面は現代の作品と比べるとそりゃ見劣りするだろうが別に画面の外にあるリアル映像と同じ品質で人間が爆死するのを見たくはないだろうし十分○、サウンド面も良好○(印象に残る曲が無いのが残念だ、私の場合FLATの「ひこうき雲の向こう側」のメニュー画面「止まない雨はないから /Wiredscape」のような印象の残し方があったら◎なのだが……)
プレー時間、スキップをある程度使用して15+20+20時間で、全文オートで読み上げさせた場合は推定25+40+50時間、それだけあれば長編小説換算で8冊以上というところ(うち2冊ちょっとが脱出ゲーム部分に相当)か。そう捉えるとなかなかボリューム感があった。
 
あ、もちろん『Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma』もクリア済。上記「おすすめできるか」は『ZE:999』『ZE:VLR』『ZE:ZTD』の三部作総じての結論。よかった。
 
 
あと言わせてくれ……四葉かファイみたいな人と付き合いたい。いや冗談だけど。あ、でもファイみたいに知性高い人っていいよね。それはさておき999とVLRとZTDの登場キャラ(999の9人目とかは除くとしても)、没個性的な人がいないのもなかなかよかったかな。
 
一つだけ、ZTDでのCチームの女の子の声、朝田詩乃/ペリーヌ/クラピカ/アラネア/峰不二子(feat.沢城みゆき)(初瀬いずなのような声じゃないのでOK、あれはあれで需要ありそうだが)のような大人びた感じなんだけど、999の頃(作中では[spoiler]2029[/spoiler]年)と比べると多少なり成長してるようだった。まぁ発売日を比較すれば当然なのだが(沢城みゆきさんのWikipediaページで「茜」を検索、6件中4件が該当。999、VLR、999+VLRダブルパックつまり本作、ZTDの4つが見られる)。
 
あぁそうだ、プロデューサーの打越氏が4Gamer.netとの対談をしてたので、それを見ておくのもいいかも。

I loved this game on 3DS and I'm so glad I get to keep it long-term on my PC. This is my favorite Visual Novel, hands down. The story is delightfully absurd, the mystery builds with great pay-off, and I love how the meta game comes into play.

I also enjoy the puzzle solving/escape room mechanics, although I'll note that this whole series does have some issues with precision clicking. I didn't think it was as bad as 999, but have some patience when you are clicking around the room.

Like before, some of the puzzles are so ridiculous that I don't expect anyone to know them off-hand, but generally "easy" mode lets you still solve them so you can progress the story (then come back in hard-mode and complete the room). When you play this game, have pen and paper handy to take some notes, though. That will be necessary before the end.

Despite some of the mechanical flaws, this is still a delightful game. I'm apparently playing through it for the 3rd time and still discovering things I hadn't noticed before. I suspect I'll come back every few years and play through it again (once I've forgotten some of the solutions/twists).

EDIT: I wrote this while playing through the second part--Virtue's Last Reward. 999 is also an awesome game, although it has more graphic blood than VLR. 999 does have slightly more frustrating controls and requires more fast-forwarding/replaying the whole room puzzle to get to the final ending, but it's still an awesome game. The voice acting is stellar.

999 is a masterpiece in narrative and characters. The storytelling for 999 has tons of mystery and memorable moments and different routes with their own different endings. The characters are also memorable as their names are easy to remember and each have their own unique personality and stories to tell. Every puzzle is satisfying to beat especially if you solve them on your own.

VLR is the sequel to 999 and is packed with more mystery than the first game since there are so many routes that you can take throughout the game. Each unlockable ending leaves you with more unanswered questions than answers. Which is the beauty of this game.

Recommended to those who love escape room type games and also those who can stand the visual novel reading aspect of the game.

999: 40% escape room, 60% visual novel

I adore 999 to high heaven, I originally watched a playthrough of it on YouTube in search of a fun series to get attached to, and I certainly found it in 999, so much so that I purchased it for myself. I will say (even though I've yet to actually reach the ending in my own playthrough) that the story in this game is absolutely brilliant, there are little to no loose ends left wandering upon 100% completion. Oh, I bet you're wondering why you would want to 100% this game. Well, I'll tell you! Without spoiling, of course. This game has many endings, and you're going to want to play them all if you want to learn every little secret it has to offer. Playing different routes is a lot of fun, it's actually almost possible for many people to have their own unique run of the game, there's that much variety. I confess it's actually impossible to complete in one go, not because it's too hard, but because that's how the game is designed, and I love it so so much. The puzzles can be a bit dragging if you only want to play for the visual novel aspect, but they don't take very long if you just use a guide (not that you want to skip them if you're a puzzle-lover, like me), and believe me, it's definitely worth the effort. The story completely blew me away, I'd beg the heavens for an anime if not for the fact that visual novels are the perfect medium for a story like this. Anyway, to summarize, this game is amazing and I cried so much over it. Please enjoy it as much as I did.

打越的剧情不错。然后就是前两部比第三部好（毕竟第三部缺钱做的）。第一部的剧情和解谜，相比原版（nds）改动有点大，而且因为没有nds的双屏，使得叙事手法改变了，玩家也就失去了体验打越这么牛逼的叙事诡计手法的机会。所以强烈建议这个前两部最好还是使用原版的平台游玩，或者使用模拟器也行。尤其是第一部，完美利用了NDS的双屏的优势来完成这一叙事诡计，这在当时那个年代真的是创举

I've played this entire series 12 times before playing the port. This was my thirteenth time going through the series. They're still a masterpiece. They still made me cry. They still made me laugh. They still broke my brain a little. The Zero Escape series is the most important media in my life. I'm an atheist, so it's probably the closest thing I have that passes for a religion. I don't care if that sounds crazy. These games are incredible, and anyone with even a passing interest in them should play them. [strike]Also, if you're a longtime fan like me and you haven't already, play AI: The Somnium Files, also by the same brilliant writer Uchikoshi![/strike]
In terms of the port, I could echo what everyone else has already said. The music has aged like wine and getting any ending is cause for a mini dance party. The new voice acting in 999 is extraordinary. The sudoku replacement is unfortunate, but the port is still better than the original for purely accessibility reasons. The graphics look less good on a big screen, even when "upscaled" to the surprise of nobody. If you're a visual novel fan, you're not here for the art. You're here for a story that's going to change your life, and I promise you this will deliver. There isn't much else I can really say that wouldn't be a spoiler. I love these games. Play them.

I played these games a very long time ago - Virtue's Last Reward was one of my favourite videogames growing up - so I wanted to refresh myself on these a bit before writing this review. And goodness but did that turn out to be intense. Steam says I played something like 30 hours of these over the last two weeks, I got completely engrossed in the end.

They hold up! Extremely well! 

Anyway, it's a game about escape rooms. The less you know about the story, the better, so we'll just be talking about those. Following the spirit of point-and-click adventure games, you collect widgets and plug them into wadjets, all in the name of unlocking a door and escaping a room. It's like Sam and Max or whatever! You also solve puzzles which cover a good variety of themes and concepts, it's no Layton but they're plenty satisfying. Like Phoenix Wright games, most of the actual puzzle-solving is done in designated puzzle-solving areas and then the rest of the time you can just chill out and enjoy the story without having to think about all that stuff. It creates a good work/play balance where you're driven to get through the escape rooms because the story is gripping you that bad.

Anyway, we haven't touched on Uchikoshi's main strength, which is his character writing. In all his games, the characters are utterly charming, they trade quips, they spark and bounce off each other. They can make lowbrow sex jokes as readily as they discuss quantum mechanics, and they never stop feeling like real, believable people. It's a rare talent and he shows it off to the max in these games. (This is also one of the main selling points of his most recent game, Somnium Files, I think, with Aiba being an example of the 'sarcastic female sidekick' trope up there with the legendary Maya Fey.) Basically, you will love these dorks by the time you're done.

These are still two of the best mystery VNs I've ever played, I'd consider them mandatory for fans of the genre alongside things like Umineko, Ace Attorney, Higurashi, Danganronpa, and so on. Nobody does pulse-pounding twists or gives you chills like Uchikoshi and these games were his virtuoso performance.
打越纲太郎永远滴神！

these are long games. take frequent breaks and treat every endings as a chapter. You will get more enjoyment out of it that way unlike me who rushed it. Also theres no wrong order to play it imo so have fun.

Welp, Spike Chunsoft really know how to craft intriguing mysteries and interesting characters. All the puzzles in 999 felt fair and the game itself gives you enough hints to avoid being stuck. Virtue's Last Reward, however, was harder, and I found myself stuck on hard mode a fair few times. I would say going Easy mode is a more enjoyable way to play the game as there's more dialogue with the characters and there's no real penalty for doing so, except having to come back later on Hard for extra stuff at the end.
Great Visual Novel, definitely recommended for any fans of the genre, or intriguing stories, mysteries and characters.

刚把999通完，steam第一次写长评，胡乱说一些吧（无剧透）
        首先感谢汉化组，其次感谢春软，让我能玩到极限脱出这个神奇的游戏。还记得17年三代零时困境初体验时给我的惊艳，但那时我还上高三，因此后来几年才逐渐开始深入探索这个ip，并在两年前打通了三代，这里主要谈谈极限脱出的开篇之作——极限脱出999。
        极限脱出999个人认为非常适合给初入avg的新人安利。首先得益于其“9人9小时脱出游戏”以及开局就见血的设定，游戏一开始就能抓住玩家的眼球，并使玩家在游戏中能够近乎全程保持高度的刺激感和沉浸感，闭锁空间类似生化危机式的开门使得玩家对每一个大门的背后抱有强烈的好奇与恐惧。虽然说999应该是极限脱出系列中最血腥的一代，但打越也绝对没有因为故意为了营造恐怖悬疑气氛而滥用血腥暴力，悬疑气氛可以说是恰到好处。
       其次是剧情，999的剧情个人认为应该是三代中最厉害的，短小精悍，差不多12小时六个结局的流程以及最后真相大白的快感都能让你大呼过瘾。鉴于这类游戏最可怕的便是剧透，因此不便透漏，这里仅谈一谈世界观相关的内容。对于这类游戏，一般都会存在一个现实世界中已证伪或暂不可考的理论作为游戏世界观的基石，在999中这一理论叫“形成场理论”，对这个理论的解释贯穿了999的整个流程，并且毫无疑问与真结局以及整个极限脱出系列密切相关。这个形成场理论（后续作品叫不叫这个名字我已经忘了）最厉害的地方在于用形成场理论能够很好的解释玩家在游戏中一次次重开，最终努力达成（能够达成）真结局的行为，换句话说玩家进行游戏的过程恰恰是对于这个形成场理论的演绎过程！生动的向玩家演绎了什么叫“脱出有时，轮回不止”。
        解谜方面，作为极限脱出系列的开篇之作，999的谜题可以说是相当简单，这也说明这个系列解谜最开始的本质就是紧张剧情的调节剂。虽说是9小时脱出，但基本只要一进入解谜，便远离了剧情悬疑紧张的氛围，玩家可以喝一杯茶，慢慢的点来点去，一点点摸索探索，在获得了解谜成功的成就感后再次踏上紧张的剧情中去。这不仅给了打越以时间空间用来通过具体实例为玩家灌输游戏的世界观，同时相比于其他电子小说来讲不至于使玩家疲劳脱戏。二代三代的解谜难度比999要有所上升，使得优秀的谜题也成为整部游戏的重要组成部分，而不是仅仅成为一种调节节奏的手段。
        最后再谈谈steam版的有关内容，目前三部皆有汉化，其中999是画面提升版。这里着重讲一下steam版999与2ds原版对比。steam的优点是添加了全人物语音，cv中有樱井孝宏，同时增加了flow功能使得在通关一个结局之后直接返回关键点回溯，还有就是能够开启未读剧情大跳使得云玩家可以半途转正。前两点都是极大提升游戏体验的大改动，纯平，四叶和一宫的cv表现足以值回票价。但steam有一个缺点便是，这个游戏是按照2ds的机器设计的，这一点至关重要，至关重要！尤其是在真结局中或许只有2ds才能达到如此精妙的表现力，这点steam版的单屏在最后的表现要大打折扣。但我还是推荐入steam版，最后一小部分可以再用b站的2ds流程过一遍。
        啰嗦了怎么多，最后还是推荐各位能够亲身体验一下09年起打越钢太郎精心创造的游戏世界，感受一下米国玩家拼尽全力用蓝鸟计划也要拯救的极限脱出系列带来的魅力！

[h1]Эталон SCI-FI детективной новеллы с загадками и выборами[/h1]

Сразу возьмите на заметку, что вы покупаете две игры, а не одну, чего я не знал, собственно, когда покупал. Это сборник из первых двух игр в серии: 999 и virtue's last reward (далее VLR). Третья продаётся отдельно (в любом случае, пройдя полностью первые две вы и третью купите) под названием zero time dilemma.

Обе игры идут по одному и тому же принципу:
-9 человек похищают и заставляют играть в игру на выживание, связанную с числом 9 (отсюда и название The Nonary games)
-ГГ вообще понятия не имеет почему именно его похищают.
-Обе истории как-никак взаимосвязаны.
-Вам придётся решать различные квест комнаты.
-Различные выборы обоснованы сюжетно очень хорошо.
-Сюжет интригует очень сильно.
-Игры вначале не цепляют вообще, но к середине ты уже просто спать не можешь, хочешь узнать что происходит.

Это то, что их объединяет, теперь уже по отдельности разберём.

999, плюсы и минусы:
+ Саундтрек вполне хорош для новеллы с загадками, но не сравнится с той же Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc, у которой саундтрек просто божественен.
+ Спрайты персонажей нарисованы, что, по-моему, гораздо лучше, чем в VLR, где они являются 3D модельками с отвратительными анимациями. 
+ Дизайн персонажей очень хорош, как и их история и взаимотношения.
+ Сюжет на месте и интригует не хуже, чем у той же Данганронпы или Quantum break (Да, он имеет отношение, т.к. они оба завязаны на путешествие во времени и выборе)
- Короткая по сравнению с VLR и в ней меньше развилок.

Теперь о VLR:
+ Она БОЛЬШАЯ, в ней гораздо больше квест комнат и гораздо больше развилок.
+ Концовка сильнее чем в 999
- Чертовы 3D моделькки персонажей просто отвратительны, на них больно смотреть.
- Некоторые головоломки просто запредельно непонятные.

В целом пак я бы оценил так:
- История: 10 из 10
- Графика: 3 из 10
- Саундтрек: 5 из 10
- Геймплей: 7 из 10 (Достаточно занимательно)
- Отдельный респект за нормальных гг, которые не конченные дураки

Только из-за сюжета я готов купить третью игру, но только по скидке.

Рекомендую к ознакомлению. (По скидке разумеется)

本测评严重剧透啊！！慎重阅读！本游戏剧情很好，但是我仍然是不推荐！为什么呢？











游戏没有官方中文，但是很感谢汉化组为本游戏献上了高质量的汉化。
首先第一部999，画面高清化了，人物立绘都很漂亮，也加了语音，代入感更好，但是关于有说nds更好的，就是因为下屏的茜视角，可能带入感和剧情解释上更好，但是steam也是可玩的，毕竟可以在多次游玩打全结局的时候快进文本就很方便也不墨迹。谜题难度适中，人物也不是很啰嗦，剧本神作，非常推荐一玩。本人10小时一口气全结局打出。

而二代善人死亡上我要给差评，而且是很差。剧情先不说合理不合理，但是人物非常墨迹，推理也非常墨迹。
首先操控上作为第二代竟然比一还繁琐累赘。
举个例子，在选择紫门进酒吧，解密道具多到有10个酒瓶和3个杯子及多个地球碎片，在999里直接道具栏里点着选取就可以了，在二代里要点左右的箭头让道具旋转，转到了才能选取上，道具一多操作就很麻烦。密室里的视角也是，和一代完全不同，要按住鼠标旋转像fps一样，但是设计的又很不灵敏和不流畅，导致游戏解密体验极差。更不用说设计不合理的谜题了，这个游戏十分让人劝退。移植的可以说非常垃圾。
玩了60多个小时，最后感觉，原来我只是玩了一个序章
VLR这个3D真的很有时代特色，还是最喜欢999的cg和立绘，画师的画风和人设真的非常戳人，结果二代游戏里面完全看不到

淳平：“好啦，我们快走吧。”
淳平说着迈出一步……
就在这时，他的胳膊又被抱住了。

紫：“我都说了等一下啦！”
淳平：“干嘛啊！”
紫：“淳平君……不害怕吗？”
淳平：“哈！？”
紫：“我……很害怕……这种事……还是第一次”
之前没和男人单独坐过电梯？？？

紫：“可能会……湿的”
湿！！！？？？

紫：“听说……下面是湿的……”
淳平：“这、这个嘛，你当然会湿了……”
淳平：“而且也没听说过上面会湿的……”
紫：“的确……是这样……”
淳平：“……”
紫：“可以吗？”
淳平：“怎么好像……”
紫：“湿了也无所谓吗？”

淳平：“这、这个怎么说呢……对我来说……当然是湿了才好……”
紫：“好厉害啊淳平君！真是有气魄！”
淳平：“是、是吗……所有男人都是这么想的吧。”
淳平：“能去的地方就一定要去。这就是男人。”
紫：“好、好帅啊，淳平君！我太崇拜你了！”

淳平：“其实也没那么严重啦……”
紫：“我……很害怕……非常……”
淳平：“是、是吗……你说是你的第一次啊。”
紫：“嗯……”
紫：“所以我可能会承受不住，马上就去了的。”
淳平：“去了！！？？？”
紫：“嗯。就是升天的意思。”
淳平：“升天！！！？？？”
紫：“就是呼啊～一下，意识就模糊了……”
紫：“我听那些有经验的人说，就是这样的。”

紫：“就算是男人也肯定能进去。一直这个状态的话……”

[h1] Zero Escape: The Nonary Games [/h1] 

The Nonary Games sind die ersten beiden von drei Teilen der Zero Escape Reihe.
"Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors (999)" & "Virtue´s last Reward (VLR)" - beides Nintendo DS Spiele, hier jedoch nochmal etwas überarbeitet.
Ich selber machte oft den Fehler, auch hier gilt "[i] wer lesen kann (und will) ist klar im Vorteil [/i]", beim anschauen des Bundles, mich zu wundern warum Steam mir nur 2 Spiele anzeigt obwohl von einer Thrillogy die Rede ist.

Ich bin mir immer noch sehr unsicher ob diese Visual Novels etwas für mich sind aber ungeachtet dessen, die beiden "The Nonary Games" haben es geschafft das ich sehr beeindruckt bin.

[h1] mein erstes Visual Novel [/h1]
Sehr viel weiß ich nicht was diese Art von Spiel betrifft, eigentlich weiß ich gar nichts. 

Es ist im Grunde wie eines dieser Bücher die einen die Möglichkeit geben bestimmte Entscheidungen zu treffen und die einen dann sagen, [i] Gut, da Du Dich hier "dafür" entschieden hast, ließ bitte auf Seite X/Y weiter)[/i]. Das Spiel ist in 2 Teile aufgeteilt, ein Teil der wie ein Hörbuch ist und ein Teil wo wir aus einem Raum entkommen sollen.

Die Zutaten sind recht simpel, im Kern ist es natürlich eine Geschichte, eine japanische Geschichte genauer gesagt. Ich muss es so hervorheben da Japaner die Erzählkunst einfach um einiges weiter gelevelt haben als der Rest der Welt. Was aber auch bedeutet, man erwartet immer etwas mehr als von anderen Geschichten.

[h1] mein erster Eindruck nach Einem der Enden... [/h1]
... denn beide Spiele haben mehrere Enden. Wo die Vernetzung bei 999 noch recht überschaubar ist, gibt es in VLR direkt einige mehr. Was bedeutet, die Geschichte hat sehr viel mehr Fazetten.

Am Anfang hatte ich kleine Schwierigkeiten warm zu werden mit dieser Art von Spiel. Die Grafik, auch wenn aufgehübscht, ist vom Nintendo DS. Und auch wenn das zweite Spiel schon etwas besser aussieht, ist Grafik hier nicht der Star. Irgendwann hatte ich ein Ende erreicht und dachte mir ...
... "[i] hmmm?! Als ich mich informiert hatte, hieß es unglaublich gute Geschichten. [/i]"

Neben der eigentlichen Geschichte, das 9 Leute irgendwo aufwachen und keine Ahnung haben wo sie sind oder warum, behandeln die Spiele auch Themen, die zum Einen irgendwie in die Geschichte eingebunden sind und zum Anderen sich auf reale Dinge beziehen. Waren jeder Zeit interessant und super, wirklich, hat mir echt gut gefallen. Doch auch das konnte für mich noch nicht erklären warum diese Spiele angeblich einen solchen guten Ruf haben.

Und allgemein, das mag auch an meiner Person liegen aber zum größten Teil auch daran das die Nonary Games uns bewusst im Dunkeln lassen aber dennoch immer wieder kleine Häppchen fallen lassen die unseren Gedanken Futter bieten, so wir denn auch gut aufpassen und mitdenken. Schon sehr früh misstraute ich den Leuten. Das zweite der Spiele hebt diese Mechanik sogar hervor da es hier auch sowas wie ein Spielelement ist. Am Ende war es so, das jedes Ende zwar Antworten lieferte aber auch neue Fragen aufwarf. Diese Fragen, im Zusammenspiel mit der Geschichte, haben gemacht das man mehr wollte.

[h1] die Rätsel [/h1]
Auch hier wusste ich einige Zeit nicht so recht was ich davon halten soll. Aus den immer wieder eingestreuten EscapeRooms zu entkommen lockert das Spielgeschehen angenehm auf. Die ganze Zeit spielen Zahlen und Mathematik eine Rolle, weshalb einen das Spiel auch einen Taschenrechner gibt.

Ganz oldschool habe ich jedoch Stift und Papier rausgeholt und über die ganze Zeit Sachen aufgeschrieben, was sich als sinnvoll herausstellte. Da ich bestimmte Informationen später nochmal nutzen konnte. Wir können jederzeit zu jedem einzelnen Raum in der Geschichte zurückkehren und ab diesem Punkt weiterspielen. 

Aber so richtig schwer war keines der Rätsel. Aber auch das macht Sinn, denn sie sollen keinen Frust verursachen, da es im Kern eine Geschichte ist. Aber keine Sorge, all zu leicht macht es einen das Spiel dann aber auch nicht. Es ist jederzeit von Vorteil wenn man bestimmte Dinge im Kopf selber nochmal durchgeht.
 
[h1] Fazit [/h1] 
Obwohl ich am Anfang unsicher war, muss ich sagen, ich habe den Kauf nicht bereut.
Ich habe das Ganze als Hörbuch wahrgenommen und ja, diese Geschichten sind verdammt interessant, beziehen sich auf reale Dinge und regen zum Nachdenken an. 

Aber man muss sich darauf einlassen können, darf sich von der Optik nicht abschrecken lassen und sollte den Geschichten etwas Zeit geben. Vielleicht sollte man noch im Hinterkopf haben das es sich hier um 2 Nintendo DS Spiele handelt.

Doch diese Geschichten, wie sie erzählt werden in diesem Setting können durchaus überzeugen. Und ich kann auf jeden Fall verstehen warum diese "Zero Esacpe" Spiele einen so guten Ruf haben.

进入【极限脱出：9时9人9门】收获以下体验：

▶教一位看起来比较可靠又有精神的大叔认人
▶叫一位王子般的盲人知识青年优雅起床醒来
▶看一位银发时尚小痞子如何秀自己脑子好使
▶把一位疯狂爱兄的合法萝莉用嘴遁唠进怀里
▶给一位多年没见的青梅竹马当一次工具舔狗
▶帮一位凶神恶煞的刀疤大汉回忆起自己是谁
▶在一位穿得还没我洗澡多的程序媛敲键盘时偷瞄她的巨乳
▶有一位.......有第九人吗？无所谓了。

进入【极限脱出：善人死亡】收获以下体验：

▶与一位爱听话又圣母心还不进食的完美八字眉护士时刻调情
▶看一位播音腔有失忆症的机械和尚坐电动摇车开心地像个一米八的孩子
▶把一位干啥啥不行背刺第一名的拉跨马戏团团长摁在地上摩擦
▶瞅一位整天没事不是孙子就是老婆在纸片上的老头子丢人现眼
▶抱一位爱生病也没啥存在感的小孩跑东跑西跑到他爷爷不用带他捡垃圾
▶劝一位年龄越大衣服越少的合法萝莉长大一岁少点病娇多搞百合
▶听一位几乎等于啥都没穿却意外很可靠的褐皮御姐不断说些荤段子
▶等一位总是想证明自己是C罩杯的三无少女兑现诺言穿泳衣给我看

Great games, both of 'em. The nonary games offer facisnating stories mixed with some fun escape sequences that will remind you of those escape games you might have played on your browser (rip adobe flash). Plenty of memorable characters and music too. The escape sequences have plenty of brain teasing puzzle that aren't always easy to solve (be prepared to use your brain a lot). The only issues i have is that Virtue Last Reward's 3d rendered characters looks rather awkward compared to 999's animated sprites. Also, some of 999's endings might require you to play through sections you already played (though thankfully, you have a handy feature that allows you to jump at any of the previously played sequences to view them again and see the different outcomes). Besides that, i highly recommend this excellent bundle of classics if you like games like Danganronpa, Phoenix Wright or Professor Layton.
amazing story. im like like like.

999+善人死亡的合輯
冒險解謎的遊戲來說，劇情十分優秀(與腦洞大開)
喜歡偽科學SF與超展開的人應該會滿喜歡此作
不過也因為劇情環環相扣的緣故，也需要將各個故事線一一跑過才可以理解各個展開
如果只跑一兩條線的話可能會一頭霧水(像是角色莫名死了或黑化)
雖然沒官方中文，不過巴哈上倒是有人整理中文包有興趣可以去找找

999 : 故事的起點，在這次推出合輯裡追加了故事語音與流程圖
以往就算有SKIP還是得需要重頭跑好幾次才能跑到新路線，這次只要選項選對Flag有開啟並使用流程圖跳章節即可
可省下重複解謎的時間
可惜在Flag的說明上沒有詳細指示(希望玩家不要直衝?故事)，可能要自行稍微摸索才知道怎樣跑出新路線
語音部分倒是沒什麼缺點，各個知名聲優都表現得很不錯

不過因為移植到PC的緣故，捨棄了原本NDS上雙螢幕的劇情對話(伏筆)以及修改最後解謎的難度是有點可惜的地方
謎題整體上不會太難，就算不知道也可以多點擊幾次讓組隊的同伴們給出俏皮的提示
另外故事上雖然每個段落都會很莫名的插入偽科學冷知識可能會覺得莫名跳痛，
不過當各個伏筆解明讓冷知識都變得有意義的時候倒是會讓人覺得原來如此阿

善人死亡 : 
接續999的時間點，起初就給出四葉與ALLICE兩個前作人物吊足胃口
此外比起上作的緊張的氣氛，這次倒是加了不少詼諧點讓氣氛變得稍微輕鬆點(SIGMA比純平還會搞笑阿)
劇情倒是一樣的腦洞大開就是了，比起上作人物背景解明後的理解
這次某幾個人的身分解開後真的會下巴掉下來(ry
謎題上這次倒是難了不少，以及追加額外的文件Bonus謎題
好在這次可以調整難度，以及文件的追加謎題並不是必要解開
(雖然要解成就還是要用HARD拿到全文件成就就是了)

可惜這作起開始改使用3D演出，人物在對話上的動作僵硬不少，
如果能保留前作的2D動畫可能會加一點分回去

The work they put into this game is amazing. I had it on my DS, but I don't remember getting the true ending on it. It seems easier to skip back and forth on the pc, but I only worked out that I could skip all the dialogue at about the 3rd play through. 
This is a choose your own adventure novel and yes it is a novel. There is so much dialogue that I actually was playing another game on my tablet at the same time lol. 
I still haven't finished all the endings, but will have a break and play the next one in the series before I try again. I am sick of doing the same puzzles over again. 
I had one issue where it didn't save when I got down the true ending branch and had to do a massive section again, so I recommend saving regularly. 
The one part that really annoys me is how everyone says 'huh' constantly and Jumpy's overacting when people die. The screaming and crying when he has only known these people for a couple of hours. I am sure the voice actors had heaps of fun, but it is laughable.

Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors (999 for short) is the first game of the Zero Escape trilogy whose story is something that I would probably hold on to for quite a while - because it’s just /that/ gripping.

It’s a great visual novel with a True Ending that is only ever going to be satisfying if you’ve unlocked all the other endings first. I wasn’t disappointed when I got the bad endings during my first playthrough; they almost felt like “puzzles” in their own right as they’d only given me more hints that point and build up well to the big reveal in the final ending and the route I should take to get there. And when I /was/ getting there, I got chills each time it was about to reveal something that might align with what I’d expected (and suspected), but then it turned it around and hit me with another twist.

The cast is pretty well-defined, each with their own unique set of motivations, goals, and backstories.Talking about them can get quite spoiler-heavy, so I’ll say one minor thing I appreciate. While the puzzles were relatively easy, I had to randomly click on things too much at some parts in the game when I was taking too long to solve one; during those times, the characters would throw in some jokes that were actually quite funny. It helped ease the growing tension and suspense brought by the Nonary Game’s high stakes - which were made more apparent by the chilling background music.

There’s a flowchart that allows you to jump to an earlier point and make another decision/route if starting the game all over again is too much of a hassle. I personally have no qualms about restarting the game and redoing the puzzles (and I’m not just saying that because I may or may not be completionist). Exploring other dialogue choices during the Novel sections allowed me to pay closer attention to the scenarios. When the science concepts and terms were thrown in, I found it a bit jarring at first, but it eventually made so much sense that I couldn’t imagine the story working any other way. It made smart use of those actual, real concepts in blatantly unrealistic, inconceivable ways that I had no other choice but to suspend my disbelief. And it was all worth it thanks to its solid storytelling from start to finish.

Virtue's Last Reward (VLR) was a bit of a letdown. For one, I personally wasn’t a big fan of the 3D models used for the characters. I wish they had just stuck with sprites the same way they did for 999. It’s just a personal preference, though, and it doesn’t really take away from the experience. That’s just the first of my complaints, which are, thankfully, just as minor.

The story didn't leave as much of an impression on me as 999 did, but it had its highlights. It continued to build off of the use of science concepts to drive the narrative forward. The handling of these concepts this time around, though, were a little too on-the-nose and made the plot a lot more convoluted as a whole. While I liked VLR’s overall direction as a concept, it could’ve been done better. Take the bad endings and all those locked paths, for instance.

Getting hit with a “to be continued” at almost every route started to get repetitive and, well, quite annoying. While I understand how they’d been essential to the plot, it tended to muddle the progression and tension for me a bit, which was probably what contributed to my lack of “satisfaction” with some of the endings - the True Ending, especially. 999 was more self-contained, and despite leaving the players with a post-credit scene that hinted at a sequel, it still felt complete. VLR didn’t feel the same way. I also wished there had been more variation with the bad endings. Most of them felt contrived for plot convenience. This is also why I still largely prefer 999, whose bad endings felt a lot more significant.

But like I said, VLR definitely has its own charm. The escape room puzzles have been the most fun for me, and I definitely preferred them to 999’s. The characters, while not as compelling as those of 999, were funny and entertaining enough to also get attached to them in the end - so that when the sad parts hit, they hit hard. And they /really/ did. Two of the characters’ endings had me bawling.

In spite of all my complaints (especially with the repetitiveness of some of the routes), it helped me get used to the overall vibe of Zero Escape. If I could only make jumps myself like in visual novels, I’d start from the beginning, when I bought this game on a whim while it was on sale, and play it again for the first time.

A pair of sci-fi mystery adventure games about people put through a series of escape rooms with potentially deadly consequences. I came over to Zero Escape by way of Danganronpa, and one thing they definitely have in common are the extremely elaborate plotlines that seem like they should collapse in on their own plotholes but then the writers go "nope we thought of that" and are full of twists and reveals. Overall I enjoyed the writing way more than the puzzles, especially the puzzles of the second game which get pretty adventure gamey at points with some of the solutions (combine pool cue with wrench to make key??) but no matter how tedious they got the writing kept pulling me along so I could find out what happens.
The perfect game for people who watched the Saw movies and thought "this plot needs more characters giving 1000-level Philosophy lectures"
Virtual escape rooms, interesting puzzles and exciting story-line.

A universe I would just love to dive into. If it isn't Dangan Ronpa, Nier, Drakengard or Silent Hill lore then it's definitely Zero Escape. I love the games and it's story.

I only had wished there was perhaps a fourth game giving more closure to the questions left unanswered.

These two games are absolute joys to go through. Puzzles are a joy to go through, and both 999 and VLR host a detailed (if not absurd at times) story that leaves room for a sequel (Zero Time Dilemma, which is not in this package).
I first heard about this from Nintendo Power Magazine, and I'm not surprised that I remember the characters after about 10 years, the art style for 999 is extremely memorable, and although VLR switches to 3d, the 2d art you do end up getting is still fantastic and well done.

This series is very underrated! I've been a fan of escape games since I was little and was thrilled to find out that a series used escape games as a mechanism but had an underlying story. And boy.... when the story is fantastic. I will admit it took quite some time to get in, because I was confused as to what was happening. But then when I finally started to understand, I was wrong, and learned something new. This game subverts expectations in such an interesting way. My only gripe with it is that sometimes it felt slow, as as someone who was replaying this (first time I played it was on the PS4), the slow cursor speeds in VLR absolutely killed me. I still recommend this game though, and won't say much about the plot without spoiling things, but if you're reading this, do give it a try!

This is a collection of the first two zero escape games, Zero Escape: 9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors (which i will refer to as 999), and Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward (which I will refer to as VLR). Both games are visual novel puzzle games highly focused on their story, with slight aspects of horror thrown in there. The main gameplay comes in the form of escape rooms that break up the story sections. The story is extremely well done on both games, Lovable characters and intriguing mysteries across the board (VLR IS THE GOAT)
As ports of nintendo ds and 3ds/Psvita games, they run suprisingly well. I had no technical issues playing the games, but there is a small component of 999 that is missed by playing on something other than the ds (Don't look it up though because its MASSIVE spoilers). I highly recommend.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is a collection of two older games, 999 and its sequel, Virtue's Last Reward, ported from handhelds to modern systems a few years ago, with the third game in the trilogy, Zero Time Dilemma, sold separately. If you really enjoy games that are interesting and unique narrative experiences, I would stop reading this review right now and play these games without reading anything else about them. I think Zero Escape is great, but it's best experienced knowing as little as possible going in. If you still want to know more before making a purchase decision, this review will give a basic description of what the games are, but I'll be keeping some things intentionally vague to avoid spoiling the experience. I've played the DS version of 999 before, so I can make comparisons between that and the PC version, but this was my first time playing Virtue's Last Reward, so I can't comment on any differences in this port. Both games are reviewed separately.

999: Nine Hours, Nine Person, Nine Doors:

999 is a visual novel with escape the room puzzle sections between the story sections. After each puzzle, the story will lead to a decision point where the story can branch in a few different directions like a choose your own adventure novel. There's a handy flowchart to easily keep track of which branches you've already seen, which I don't remember existing in the DS version. You are meant to go back and see every branching path. 100% completion is pretty much mandatory if you want to get the full story, but I think it's worth it. Repeating sections you've already seen sounds annoying, but it's actually not that bad. You can jump around to any point on the flowchart and there's a fast forward button that you can safely use because it will stop once you reach a line of text you haven't seen before. 

The puzzle sections are really easy for the most part, especially when you consider that the game has a built in crutch with other characters chiming in and all but giving you the solution if you take long enough. There was only one puzzle in the game that really stumped me, and it was more because I was overthinking it than anything else. If you're disappointed by the lack of challenging puzzles, you'll get more of that in VLR. Oddly, they changed the very last puzzle in the game in this version. Some people have criticized this change and maybe they're right, but I don't think it's a huge deal. I won't comment further to avoid spoilers. 

Visually, the game looks fine, but it's nothing special, which isn't surprising for a port of a DS game. The game now has a higher resolution and has been touched up a bit, but otherwise doesn't look any different from the DS version. The 2D sprites for the characters are nicely drawn and animated. The environments and objects in the escape room sections do the job and give you enough information to figure out the puzzles, with stuff you can interact with highlighted when you click on it. I can't remember ever having to pixel hunt for tiny objects, like in older adventure games. 

The music and audio are decent and fit the game well enough. The biggest new addition in this port is full voice acting for all characters outside the puzzle sections, with options for both English and Japanese audio. I played with the English dub. I think the voice acting is mostly fine and, having played the DS version, is a nice addition to make the experience fresh, but it's nothing special. The only voice I really didn't like was that of the main character. I thought everyone else did an adequate job, some better than others. Maybe the Japanese VAs are better, but I can't comment on that.

Overall, 999 is great and can stand on its own as a complete experience, even if you chose not to play its sequels. Highly recommended. 

Virtue's Last Reward:

As the sequel to 999, Virtue's Last Reward should only be played after completing 999. While I guess you could play this on its own and still have a good experience, it doesn't stand on its own nearly as well as 999; despite a new setting and cast of characters, VLR greatly benefits from having prior knowledge of the events of 999. It's a more ambitious game, taking a concept used in 999 and greatly expanding on it in a really cool way. It's also twice as long as 999, taking me 30 hours to play compared to 999's 15. The basic concept is the same, with the game broken up into story and escape room puzzle sections, with decision points marking branching paths in the story. Again, I would consider 100% completion mandatory for the sake of the story, even with the increased length. Again, the flowchart and fast forward button make it easy to jump around as needed. 

The puzzles in VLR are significantly harder than they were in 999, though if you don't like the puzzles and are just there for the story, there are now difficulty options. It's set to hard by default, where you get basically no hints from other characters, with the option of switching to easy at any time, where it's more like 999 and the game will all but give you the answer if you take long enough. In every room, there's a safe with two passwords; one gives you the key to escape, which is mandatory, while the other is optional and gives you a gold file with additional background information related to the story and setting. I played on hard all the way through, getting all the gold files as I went. I found myself stumped a lot more often than in 999 and I found some of the adventure game moon logic pretty frustrating at times, though I may just be bad at puzzle games. Play on whatever setting you're comfortable with. I don't think it really matters when it comes to the story.

Visually, I think this game is actually a downgrade from 999, though this may come down to personal taste. Instead of 2D sprites, VLR introduces full 3D models for every character, which I don't think look all that great in comparison to 999, though I eventually got used to it. Maybe it's more palatable on a tiny handheld screen, but blown up to a higher resolution on a bigger monitor display, I wasn't really a fan. Again, you get used to it, but this was probably my least favorite thing about this game. 

Like 999, the audio in this game is fine. Music is good. I think the voice acting is a bit better on average than in 999, though again, some VAs were better than others. Again, I played with the English dub and can't comment on the quality of the Japanese VAs. 

Overall, Virtue's Last Reward is a great followup to 999. The way the plot slowly unraveled with its unique structure was really cool to see. I have a few questions, nitpicks, and things I didn't like regarding the ending of the game, but I hope to see some of that addressed in Zero Time Dilemma, the conclusion to the trilogy. Highly recommended.

Half visual novel, half puzzle escape rooms, very Japanese, extremely complicated plots that take sharp turns into the weirder end of scifi and conspiracy, branching narratives that feed into each other in a complicated layer cake of weirdness.  I have now completed them, and thrown into the recycling a small shrubbery of actual literal paper notes. 

If you like escape room puzzle games, you will like this. The plot is weird, the characters are mostly fun, and the reveals are appropriately twisty. The puzzles aren't too crazy, but you may need a notebook.

Это та игра, после прохождения которой вы будете жалеть о том, что невозможно всё забыть и насладится игрой вновь. Вы будете завидовать тем, кто никогда в неё не играл и недоумевать: почему столько лет вы проходили мимо этого самородка. Геймплей - решение головоломок. Иногда простых, иногда весьма сложных. Запаситесь ручкой и тетрадкой, с их помощью загадки будут даваться проще. Но заклинаю вас, ни в коем случае, ни при каких обстоятельствах - не читайте руководства до тех пор, пока не пройдёте игру! Иначе вы рискуете заспойлерить себе сюжет, а он бесподобен. Именно ради него стоит играть в эту игру. Не лишайте себя удовольствия насладится сюжетом и его поворотами. Игра (на самом деле их тут две - первые две части трилогии) великолепна, герои - великолепны, история - великолепна. Если вы ещё не играли в серию игр Zero Escape и сейчас размышляете: "а стоит ли?", знайте: я вам завидую.

I want to do 2 quick-ish reviews for both games and give my opinions for them as a bundle.

-------------------------------

First off, Zero Escape: 999. This game is a fucking masterwork. Unironically the best Visual Novel i've played and a masterclass of story telling. How can you make every character so enjoyable and have the story so investing. It's complicated, especially once you get to the final ending when everything becomes headache material, but it's still a massively enjoyable time. The escape rooms are great, but the real genius is the storytelling. All 9 participants are distinct, and while they're designs imply a role in a game like this, they have a completely subverted role and personality. Honestly, the characters aren't as much characters with how they're written, they feel like normal people. It's amazing how well done it is.
All of it results in one of the best moments i've ever experienced. That last puzzle is a fucking masterpiece, and while it's apparently better in the DS version, it's easily a masterwork here. I cannot recommend this game enough. It's amazing. Easy 10/10, no question here.

-------------------------------

VLR is a step down, but it's far from bad. I think technical aspects let the game down, namely character models and some puzzles being weaker and vaguer than 999, but the story is still incredibly told and builds off 999 in an immaculate way. Hot damn that final twist is jaw-dropping. Confusing? OH ABSOLUTLEY, but it's amazingly well handled. The characters are amazing, I love the setting and mystery. The game is handled so well, it's insane how everything is built to that twist. I think the characters are weaker than in 999, but Luna and Tenmyoji more than make up for it.
I do love this game. It drops the ball in a few areas, but it's still an amazing game. 9/10 (haha funny 9 number go brrr)

-------------------------------

As a whole? Fucking pick it up. What are you doing, these games are masterclasses in game storytelling! Buy it, it's genuinely amazing. 10/10 overall.

This game comes with 2 out of the 3 games in the Zero Escape trilogy. 999 and Virtue's Last Reward. Both games are charming for different reasons, but both have very captivating mysteries and twists to them, these games honestly go pretty hard when they hit.

I'l start it out like this: You'll play the game through with your choices, then go back to complete all the routes in this game. You can jump around and skip dialogues you've seen too, so the backtracking isn't you just sitting through the stuff, and you'll pretty much know the paths you have to go through. I suggest with 999, you actually play with a spoiler free guide, otherwise you'll have to be taking much longer to find out what to do, but ultimately the story is king here. 

With Virtue's Last Reward, the game becomes a lot cleaner for a blind playthrough in that you never are confused where you have to go because of the flowchart, at least knowing what routes you can do at any one point without a guide. 

~~~~~~~~

Both games are based on decisions changing the path of your story, but unlike most visual novels, the justification for the branching paths are actually there in the actual plot/lore of the game, in that you are actually going back in time. The games put 9 (including you) characters into pretty much a visual novel captive situation where you have to make choices on your routes, solve escape room puzzles that are pretty solid, in 999 you make dialogue choices, and in vlr, you ally or betray people. The routes can go out of wack easily, but often give you info that functions to build the overarching story, and also allows you to functionally find the true path with the actual info you find in the different routes in the games.

I will say that Zero Escape's characters aren't as cosplayable as say, Danganronpa, and they aren't all as extra, but they also seem more akin to authentic characters and not one note characters, also you see atypical characters in this game overall, and even if one or two through both game you might dislike, both have honestly pretty like-able casts of characters that feel relevant to the whole. 

Overall try to not spoil yourself on the story, know that you'll get fed advances in the plot piecemeal during the middle parts, but by the end of both games, you'll be well fed with interesting plot, and there are strong mysteries to both of the first two titles (haven't played the third yet, won't right away cuz of genre fatigue after 40 hours of nearly 40 hours in the second game)

I'd suggest this package, it's a good value on a purely financial situation, I enjoyed my time, was genuinely surprised by a lot of what was going on, etc. Do keep in mind that you should want to push for the true endings and to pay attention to dialogue you haven't seen (also learn about the skip and flow chart functionalities before going into the game so you don't waste any time clicking through stuff or watching repeated scenes)

The 3d art in vlr can be jank at times though, but 999 and virtue's last reward are both good visual novels.

These games are old but since they are "visual novels" and puzzle games they still hold up fine. Both games have fantastic stories that will have your mind absolutely reeling by the end of it. This is really what you're here for. The puzzles in 999 are relatively easy and the puzzles in VLR are harder, but both were in a good spot of not being too easy or too hard so felt rewarding enough to play through. But it's the very complex multi-layered stories that really carry these games through. By the nature of how the games' plots are setup, you have to repeat many sections of it over and over, with each playthrough exposing new wrinkles in the story, ultimately leading to the big huge reveals. The repetition might be a little tiring at times but in the end it's totally worth it. I do have my criticism -- VLR's characters being not very likable, Zero Jr's voice actor being annoying, the aforementioned repetition, the constant use of ellipses tiring my finger trying to click through, some stuttering and lagging from a game that totally shouldn't... but in the end the mind-explosion-level story was enough to have me overlook those things.
