终于通完了善死，谜题方面没那么瓜了，相比999进步了很多.但有一个缺点就是，室内空间视角的转换特别容易让把人晃晕，解谜过程中建议不要频繁切换视角。再一个就是剧情出现的提示（一串密码，数字一类的）最好用自带的备忘录记一下啊！我玩的时候就没注意这个，结果到了需要用到的时候差不多都忘完了......
剧情方面只能说还是一如既往的打越啊哈哈，尤其是善死这个及其复杂的路线发展，填坑挖坑，一般的脚本真的hold不住。

999: Snake is best boi = good game (not perfect but the characters are likeable and the story makes....kind of sense at least)

VLR: This game should be forbidden. No, seriously. How can a game be THAT bad. I have wasted 48 hours of my life. 

First off, the animation: Half of the game's playtime is wasted with pointless animations of the player character moving from one place to another. Some dialogues and scenes which have already appeared in other timelines are skippable but the absolutely unnecessary animations of one blinking dot moving on a map which doesn't even provide you with any viable information just made me lose my sanity. 

Next, the dialogue: Most of the game's dialogue is filled with "...". Like, what is the matter of all of this? If the characters don't know what to say, then don't waste time stretching the "conversation". And even if the characters have something to say, it often doesn't even have context or content. There are moments, especially at the beginning, in which you get snippets of unresolved mysteries and wonder if you'll eventually get more information about them...but no. You get some of the most random statements which will never be mentioned again.

*SPOILER*

Next....Dio: He's the main antagonist and the problem is, he is not even good at it. The game basically shoves the fact that Dio is one of the bad guys into your face and doesn't even try to hide this. It doesn't come as a surprise that he killed almost everyone from the cast. 

And now to the *sigh* story: The game tries to stretch the story as much as possible. The developers chose to split things up and placed them into random paths instead of answering them in one go. This results in getting random endings (which are btw not even real endings).
And in general, you get heavily confused because you have to remember so much stuff which happened in other timelines (+ also the fact that some things did and didn't happen in some of the timelines). 
Some of the timelines even have the exact same events in which the endings are just slightly changed.

At the end, you are left with more questions than answers and with the feeling that nothing that happened in this game mattered at all. The motivation to keep playing diasappears eventually completely.

And what left me unsatisfied the most is...the real, true ending is not an ending. The game doesn't come to a conclusion and just stops. 
It feels like the developers gave up in the middle of the production. I have never played a game which made me so frustrated in my entire life. I know that there is still "Zero Time Dilemma" left to play which (I heavily doubt it will answer all the questions) is probably some kind of sequel or prequel, tbh I have no idea. I have no hopes.

P.S.: Luna is the most bearable character and she's not even human.

P.P.S: Zero Jr. should be deleted from the files.

Edit: I played ZTD for 1 hour and had to quit because it was SO BAD. I was joking with a friend that it couldn't get worse than VLR but oh well...

This review was made after completing both titles with all the achievements.

Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors (999):
The start of the trilogy.
16 hours playtime, an introduction of this whole bracelet-related games. (My first game in the trilogy is actually ZTD, so that's that)
6 endings, whether it is bad or not, that's the total of it.
Junpei and Akane, present and past, transmitter and receiver.
It all begins here. Each endings... even if you hit a certain wall because you didn't meet the criteria will make sense later on after you found the keys needed for it. And it's complementing each other, too, to explain why is this and that despite we might still have lingering questions.
Like: "Is that ALL-ICE aka Alice... in *that* Ending?"

Virtue's Last Reward (VLR):
The second title in the trilogy.
But judging by the timeline its the last part of the story supposedly, but... being the second is the better placement overall since ZTD tried to tie in all the things that can't be explained in this game yet, regarding the "history" in the past.
36 hours playtime, a thrilling and some can be heartbreaking moments at certain choices or endings.
9 labeled endings, plus one kinda canon ending, and an alternate ending, plus plenty of GAME OVERs.
Sigma and Phi, two jumpers, two persons, one destiny.
It still kinda be a little confusing to me on the diagram of timeline of the jumps that was explained by AK and KK at nearing end of the whole game.

But overall the few games that's keeping me in front of my screen focused and tense.
Akane, Junpei, Sigma, Phi... I will see you guys in the last trilogy, Zero Time Dilemma.
I can understand now how it is very much better than the annoying Danganronpa series' mini games, because... hey, puzzles are not like shooting stuffs, or driving cars thru roads looking for letters or something like that.

You like thrilling experience, science stuffs, puzzles, plot-twists, and STORY?
YOU better buy this and ZTD, or you are next of the Nonary Games participant.
See you guys on the Decision Game's Zero Time Dilemma. Heading out.
OVERWHELMINGLY RECOMMENDED!!!

999: The first game probably has the best puzzles out of all of them, not too hard and not too easy, with a good cast of characters and a great visual art style for the cast. The branching story lines are all very interesting, but I feel some of the characters get underused and the ending doesn't hold up that well.

VLR: The second game probably has the best cast of characters minus one bad egg, The great sprite work is replaced with 3d models that most of the time make you wish they didn't jump to 3d, and the few times there is a cut scene the models and movement are sometimes janky. The puzzles range from super easy to unfairly hard which isn't fun, and the different branches constantly reuse plot lines and show the same exact scenes which is annoying, most of the endings are enjoyable and the ending isn't as smart and hinted in hindsight as some people think.

Je me suis procuré ce jeu sans vraiment savoir quoique ce soit à son sujet. J'avais juste entendu que
c'était sympa et je me le suis pris en réduction pour jeter un coup d'oeil.

Je ne me doutais pas du tout que j'allais jouer à une telle pépite, j'ai rarement autant été impressionné par une histoire de cette qualité. Alors que vous pensez avoir appris quelque chose d'important, derrière ces secrets se cachent des révélations encore plus grandes.

Dans le premier jeu 999, vous incarnez Junpei, un jeune étudiant qui se fera kidnappé pour être forcé à jouer au Nonary Game.
Le protagoniste est enfermé dans un bateau avec 8 autres participants, ils doivent réussir à s'échapper
en moins de 9 heures sans quoi le bateau coulera, assurant la mort aux joueurs. Sur le chemin, plusieurs puzzles et secrets sinistres vous attendent.

Cette mini-collection contient aussi sa séquelle, Virtue Last Reward. Si vous aimez le premier jeu, il vaut largement le coup d'oeil.

C'est un peu difficile de parler du jeu sans spoil (rien que le thème de l'histoire du jeu serait un spoil),
mais si vous êtes intéressé par une histoire bien ficelée et cohérente, parsemée de mystères et de retournements de situations, Zero Escape est surement l'une des meilleurs pépites du genre.

The writer tried to create an epic world with a story but he just can't handle what he wants. So whenever theres a plot hole, quantum physics and superpowers.

A lot of people love this series, but somehow it gets more disappointing in the next one. I suggest you stop here.

999几年前在手机其实打通几条线了，但是模拟器版本要重复谜题太麻烦了而且想玩善人死亡就投奔pc合集版了
优点：短小精悍，设定有趣，结局颠覆也很好的集合了所有衍生的设定。flow系统很好的避免了重复解谜，节约了时间。（不过999的谜题算是比较简单无聊的那种。）声优好评，氛围不错。打越佳作代表，值得一试。
缺点：太短所带来的人物塑造不足，仅剩的篇幅多交给了设定。流程短，没办法。紧凑，但没有r11那么抓人。本作的核心诡计还是充满打越前作的既视感，不过玩得明显更熟练了。pc系统在某个关键体验上由于机能问题无法还原nds的体验造成最终体现出来的效果没那么震撼，非常可惜。凭借nds机能实现的欺诈，本来真的是神来一手，
题外话：茜（整个系列）可能是我这么多年游戏记忆中最难以评价的女主了。每次想到极限脱出，总会想到她，总是想说点什么，但是最后什么都说不出来。极限脱出这个系列也算是比较坎坷。零时困境虽然也算是圆了但也比较跳脱系列了。总之，哎，淳平真难.

不考虑续作零时困境中坑没填等等的问题，善人死亡真的太强了。
几乎是全面超越了999。各种元素一应俱全。
虽然一大堆地方没看懂，但我对着电脑卧槽了半个小时。
虽然我对着电脑卧槽了半个小时还没搞懂，但总的来说我还是很震撼。
玩就是了。三部的巅峰。
唯一的问题就是，挖了一堆坑。还全放在最后。

简单的总评
999是引子，打越花了一部十几个小时的游戏告诉了你设定和这个设定的初级玩法，（不是指游戏玩法，而是剧情设定的玩法）
然后，
恭喜你入门了。
然后善人死亡反手把两倍以上时长和二十几条路线复杂化之后砸在你脸上。顺带又挖了更多的坑。
然后零时困境
抱歉没有然后了。

打越在极限脱出身上所埋伏笔之多和设定上迈的步子之大都可看出其对于之前某个成名系列超越的野心。本系列在各种诡计和欺诈套路的运用上更加信手拈来。即使第一作简短略乏力，第二作挖坑不止，强吊人胃口，第三作零时困境碍于各种问题风评不佳，甚至和前两作产生割裂，后两作强行3d导致的画面不流畅，建模粗糙等等等等。这个系列本身仍然是不能简单以新瓶旧酒来盖棺论定的。
至少九人游戏作为前两作的合集，排除技术，画面上的问题，仍然讲述了相当惊艳的故事。也有许多亮眼的地方。flow系统也非常符合打越meta式的剧情。极限脱出作为打越风格的代表作是完全没有问题的。

期待其后的新作。（不过AI梦境yysy很一般）
另外打越的感情戏要出彩真的全得靠设定。
剧情故弄玄虚。密室逃脱游戏和主线剧情关系不大。
Don't know what the fuck is going on and I love it
Great storyline and shit, you know it
Some of the best story telling I've seen in a LONG time

昔懐かしいFlash時代に流行った脱出ゲームと、ノベルゲームを組み合わせたゲームです。
ノベルのほうはSF寄り。

【脱出ゲーム】
Flashの物は黙々と画面をクリックしたり謎解きするだけのものが多いですが、本作はキャラ同士の掛け合いがあって楽しく遊べます。
9時間9人9の扉のほうは難易度がだいぶヌルい。善人シボウデスのほうは程よい印象。（難易度を下げることもできます）

【ノベルゲーム】
・9時間9人9の扉
キャラがみんな個性的で、魅力にあふれていて良かったです。
プレイ時間も20時間ほどで、手堅くまとまっていて楽しめました。良作ですね。

・善人シボウデス
こちらはプレイ時間40時間ほど。
いわゆる並行世界もので、大筋は同じで細部が少しずつ異なっているのですが、複数の世界線を行ったり来たりしなければならないため「この世界線では何がどうなってたっけ？」と少し混乱します。
また、ゲームといえども善人キャラ相手に裏切りを選ばなければ先に進めない仕様は少しストレスが溜まりますね。どうしても協力を選ばなければならない状況に迫られた感動のシーンでも仕様上裏切りを選べてしまったり。ギャグかな？と。
ただ、ラストのストーリーの盛り上がり方は大変良く、様々な伏線が一気に回収されていく様は爽快でした。まあまあ良作です。

【総評】
脱出ゲームとSFノベルゲームに興味がある方にならオススメできます。
続編の刻のジレンマ含め計100時間近く費やすことになりますが…。

ダンガンロンパと比較している方がいましたが、どちらかというと同じ並行世界ものであるSTEINS;GATEや428に近いです。
これはしょうがないことなのですが、並行世界ものはどうしてもストーリーや物の例えが似通ってしまうので、やればやるほど「これはもう見た」となって興が冷めてしまう不遇なジャンルですね…。


以下、一番何これ？と思ったこと（ややネタバレ）
[spoiler] 善人シボウデスで四葉が普通に他人を裏切りまくってて、その度に「四葉くん！？」「4つのリーフワード！あれだけ言ったのにもう忘れてしまったのか！？」「信頼！信頼だよ！思い出して！」「あの時流した涙は偽物だったのか…？」と思いながらプレイしてました。 [/spoiler]

I'm not gonna get into the gameplay or the story because I think people should play this series with as little knowledge as possible, but if I had to recommend it to someone with being as vague as possible, I'd say: If you enjoy escape rooms and mysteries, get this game.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is a pack contains 2 of the 3 games from the Zero Escape trilogy. I would describe them as a puzzle-solving visual novel. All of the characters in both games are well written, and the twists go undetected right until they are revealed! This game is so good that I have gone out of my way to purchase this game for a friend just to get people to experience this awesome game!
Its pretty good

(NB: actual playtime is much lower, game was often left idle for long periods of time)
Zero Escape: 999 and Virtue's Last Reward are a mashup of escape room puzzles with a branching life-and-death narrative.  999's rooms consisted of more traditional adventure puzzles, finding clues and objects and using them in the right places.  VLR's puzzles were more of the logic variety, the sort you'd solve on paper or a spreadsheet (if you find those difficult, there is also an easy mode that provides additional hints).

The narratives are pretty interesting and engaging.  999 provides enough hints in the various to be continued and game over routes that you can figure out what's going to happen in the true route.  VLR provides a longer story with more threads, but ends up instead with outright spoilers and surprise reveals instead although the story made up for it in other ways and that does not stop it from being engaging.

Localization is very much on the donuts side: if you expect the text to match the voice, you will be frequently disappointed.  The localization text is however relatively clever and consistent when taken on its own.

Aside from localization, the only other point of critique I have is an all-or-nothing skip that will happily skip unread text while you are trying to get through large blocks of previously-read text where you changed one condition.

Deaths will happen.  Game overs will happen.  Each one will get you closer to the goal and each one is necessary*.  Each new branch will reveal new details and take you deeper into the story, until finally you Escape, probably having had a lot of fun along the way.

(*some game overs in VLR are unnecessary and can be skipped entirely)

Previo a decidir comprarlo y jugarlo había oído mucho hablar de estos juegos, pero hasta que no lo lancé ni me había dado cuenta de que era un juego de Spike Chunsoft y la verdad es que fue una sorpresa para bien. 

A diferencia de los juegos de Danganronpa, por los que seguramente conozcáis al desarrollador, estos juegos no están tan enfocados en el tema de Murder Mysteries si no que están más inclinados a los puzzles y las Escape Rooms. Cada uno de los juegos tiene una serie de salas donde tendremos que resolver unos puzzles recogiendo objetos e interpretando guías que encontraremos tanto en el entorno como en los propios objetos (un papel, una tablet con información, etc...).

A pesar de contar con estos puzzles, la mayor parte del juego es una novela gráfica, donde la historia se irá desarrollando en base a las decisiones que hayamos ido tomando mientras vayamos jugando. Al ser una novela gráfica, hay múltiples finales y obtenerlos todos ayudará a entender un poco más sobre el misterio global que nos presenta el juego (¿quién es Zero? ¿por qué está cada uno de los personajes ahí? ¿cuál es el objetivo del Nonary Game?).

Esta versión cuenta con dos entregas distintas: Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors (999) y su secuela Virtue's Last Reward (VLR). El primero es bastante simple y pasárselo no requiere más de 10 horas, pero en Virtue's Last Reward le dan una vuelta y consiguen aumentar bastante la cantidad de horas que se irán en resolver todo el misterio, por lo que comprando este juego vas a tener garantizadas MUCHAS horas de gameplay y de entretenimiento (en mi caso, 35 horas, pero puede variar).

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list][*] Plot twists muy típicos de Spike Chunsoft, con un misterio general que se irá desvelando poco a poco.
[*] Escape Rooms con una dificultad justa, ni muy complicadas, ni especialmente fáciles (especialmente en Virtue's Last Reward).
[*] Personajes interesantes en ambas entregas.
[*] Banda sonora notable, que ayudan a la inmersión.
[*] El apartado gráfico pese a no ser muy actual ha conseguido envejecer decentemente. Recordemos que es una novela gráfica.
[/list]

[h1]Contras[/h1]
[list][*] No disponible en Español, y tampoco he encontrado ninguna traducción por fans que aplicar.
[*] En VLR hay muchas rutas que acaban en un final 'Game Over' similar, que podría haber sido desarrollado un poco más para darle más variedad.
[/list]

Si eres fan de las novelas gráficas tipo Dangaronpa, Phoenix Wright y similares definitivamente tienes que darle una oportunidad a este juego. En todo momento me encontré atrapado en su trama (en la de los dos juegos) y sin duda alguna merece la pena para quienes disfrutamos de este género.

Eso si, prepara una libreta para tomar anotaciones, porque en VLR harán falta.

Not every moment is great, but they always build up and pay off. The puzzles are fun and keep things varied. If you like visual novels these are definitely worth playing.

几年前先玩的《零时困境》，那是被新颖的叙事方式所震撼，现在把前两作补了（三代的汉化补丁出得更早一些），感觉这两作比《零时困境》强多了。极限逃脱系列叙事结构是总分总，相较于普通AVG多了一段将各分支剧情合并到一起的剧情总线。这种叙事结构虽然很有新意，但也有缺点：如果分支路线过多过长的话，玩家会花费相当多的时间才能看到最终的总线高潮部分。
一代分支路线少而且短，总体叙事节奏快，相当程度上克服了这种叙事结构的内在缺陷，是AVG里难得的精品。
二代以及之后的三代增加了很多分支，而且每条分支都挺长，虽然分支剧情上增加了相当多的铺垫，但终究难以抵挡叙事节奏过于缓慢带来的疲劳感。不过有失必有得，二代整体的剧情复杂程度远超一代，自然最终结局所带来的震撼感也更强，只能说1代2代各有千秋。

Two amazing murder mystery games in one very fairly-priced package. Unforgettable characters and music will accompany you while exploring a heavily scientific story that blends reality and fiction in a way that makes you doubt what you know and what was actually made up.
Multi-route visual novel sections and intricate puzzle sections are executed and balanced very well to leave you with just enough information to always be on the edge and thinking when you're not busy solving some serious braincrackers.

Completionist addendum:
Basically gets completed by just doing a full run of both games, no missable achievements if you don't skip any puzzles.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is a collection that includes the first two entries of a trilogy, [b]999[/b] and [b]Virtue's Last Reward[/b]. 

I would personally sum these two up as follows: [i]"Visual novels with escape room gameplay that have an intriguing story with lots of twists"[/i]

Basically, you read a lot of dialogue and occasionally you are in a room where you have to solve some riddles and puzzles in order to be able to progress. The puzzles are mostly interesting and fun while the story and dialogue keeps you on the edge of your seat for the most part, as things are very confusing and ominous. As you get closer to the end of each entry, several mysteries that came up throughout the story are solved and your mind gets blown on a regular basis. 

This game is for you if you if you want to experience an intriguing story and don't mind the fact that the puzzle solving and making several decisions throughout the games is the only "playing" you do. I can't recommend playing [b]999[/b] and [b]Virtue's Last Reward[/b] enough. Definitely give them a try!

[b][u]Note[/u][/b]: My playtime is only for Virtue's Last Reward because I had played [b]999[/b] on the 3DS years before. [b]999[/b] should be about 20 hours long.

[b]Zero Time Dilemma[/b] is the third entry in the trilogy. Once you completed the two games in this collection, that is where you go next.

I wanted to write this review after finishing the first game in the series (999) but decided to finish the second (Virtue's Last Reward), as well, in case it changed my opinion of the Nonary Games package.

If you are somebody who enjoys Visual/Kinetic Novels, Point-and-Click Adventures, Science Fiction Books, or Escape-the-Room games, both 9 Persons 9 Hours 9 Doors, and Virtue's Last Reward will be an absolute joy to play. Both titles are written with compelling narratives and characters, and are crafted with an astounding attention to detail. The love that the creators brought to these games is tangible throughout both stories.

It took about 25 hours to fully complete both games (including every ending from both game). There is more content in VLR via an easter-egg system of sorts (ambiguity is intentional to avoid anything remotely spoiler-related!).

These 2 games are certainly worth the 30 dollar price, but I got them on sale as part of the Spike Chunsoft Developer Sale running in late 2020. If the titles go on sale again, you shouldn't hesitate to pick them up, even if you might not think they are in your wheelhouse.

As for which game of the two is better, I know many people believe that 999 is the stronger title. I agree, in terms of how the characters are written into the story, but I personally enjoyed the overarching narrative of VLR more than I did the story of 999. I cannot stress enough, however, that both games are masterpieces in their own right.

Overall, both titles are 10/10 games and deserve all of the praise they receive! I hope that my review helps you in making a decision as to whether these titles are for you :)

I can't understand how people say this is a great series, it's a headache that get's worse with each game, and I only played it through because of Sunken Cost Fallacy. I'm just going to do a general review of the series because I don't want to spend any more time on this damn game than I have to. TL:DR at the bottom.

♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ where do I begin, this game has some promising elements but they all gets drowned out my everything else. It's a fine game at times and frustratingly bad at other times. One of the only consistently good things I can say about it was the art-style in the first game, and I say first game because they get rid of it in the 2nd and 3rd games for some pretty crappy 3d models, so even that's not consistent, The voice acting is sometimes good, and at other times half-assed. The puzzles are sometimes fun, and at other times tedious, repetitive, and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. The plot is decent at it's best moments, and underwhelming, predictable, full of holes, and boring a lot of the time. The game is filled with so many annoying control-elements and feels like ♥♥♥♥ to play.
I can sense that there are some talented individuals that worked on this, and I don't mean to be rude, but these games really took a turn for the worse. I'm only being harsh on this game because I can see some of the good in it and want to hold it to a high-standard, but it just isn't fun in the end. I really hope that AI: The Somnium Files is better than this and I can see their talent shine on it. Go play games like Phoenix Wright or Danganronpa if you are interested in this type of game and haven't played them yet. They have their problems, but are much more enjoyable in the end.


TL:DR: I really want to like this game, and while there are some things I like, I just can't like this series. The controls, graphics, story, voice acting, characters, and puzzles, all are decent at the best times, and horrible at worst. If you want recommendations for other games to play, I recommend Danganronpa and Phoenix Wright. It's not worth getting into this series.

[i]Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors[/i]

A phenomenal blend of visual novel and escape the room gameplay. the way the story branches out the how you NEED to do the rest to see the true ending and how they all link up is marvelous. Definitely a must to try out if you like either of the two style of play I mentioned. A shame that the big twist and the ending was slightly compromised due to not being on the DS, but the improvements make up for it

[i]Virtues Last Reward[/i]

While not as good as the original, Virtues Last Reward is a worthy successor to 999. Definitely a bit too drawn out in some places, particularly with the hallway segments and there being way too many dud endings. The Nonary Games é um bundle composto por 2 jogos distintos: "Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors" (999) e "Virtue's Last Reward"; ambos sendo jogos que misturam visual novel com escape room.

Os puzzles de ambos os games são bem interessantes e construídos, além do enredo de 999 ser muito bom, porém há um problema na trama, que para mim se perde já no final de 999, mas que não prejudica a qualidade do jogo como um todo.

Já no caso de Virtue's Last Reward há uma enrolação sem limites na história, não possui personagens interessantes e é muito devagar nas animações, sendo irritante acompanhar cada passagem de cenário sem poder acelerar a transição. A junção de tudo isso faz com que o jogo não possua um saldo positivo na experiência, mesmo considerando o plot twist do final.

Se quiserem história boa, joguem Steins Gate pls

Platinado e:
- recomendado Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors
- NÃO recomendado Virtue's Last Reward

《極限逃脫：九人遊戲》是一款帶有解謎的文字冒險遊戲。
此遊戲包含了《9小時9人9扇門》（以下簡稱《999》）與《好人不長命》。
由於我先前已玩過《999》，所以底下的評論會著重在《好人不長命》上。
另外，這系列是「帶有解謎的文字冒險遊戲」，若你偏好在解謎上，這系列就不太適合你。
劇透部分建議玩完後再觀看。
遊戲沒有內建中文，不過你可以到[url=https://forum.gamer.com.tw/C.php?bsn=17453&snA=83&tnum=2]巴哈[/url]下載非官方中文化檔，有所有《極限逃脫》系列的中文化。

遊戲沒有內建中文，

[h3]《9小時9人9扇門》特點[/h3]
[list]
[*] 優秀的2D繪圖
[*] 小說部分全語音
[*] 多結局
[/list]

[h3]《好人不長命》特點[/h3]
[list]
[*] 全3D
        本作捨棄了《999》所採用的全2D繪圖，只剩部分事件是2D繪圖。
        遊戲中絕大部分的事件都是3D。
        人物建模不佳，而且幾乎沒有任何光影效果。
        解謎部分也是3D，與999的最大不同是場景較大且可以自由旋轉（但無法上下移動）。
        場景建模比人物好。

[*] 解謎難度更高
        解謎有分難度（Easy與Hard）。
        影響到卡關時人物是否會做更深一步的提示與解額外謎題獲得的額外檔案（Easy少拿一些
        ，Hard 全拿）。

[*] 小說部分全語音
[*] 更多結局
[*] 遊戲篇幅更長
[/list]

[h3]系統上的共通缺點[/h3]
[list]
[*] 流程圖有暴雷的可能
[*] 系統操控方面對於鍵鼠來說不是很方便
[*] 劇情回顧（Log系統）不佳
    沒有重播語音功能
[/list]

[h3]《好人不長命》心得[/h3]
※ 不要先看白金檔案（Hard全拿的情況下），因為它會直接暴雷你後面那段劇情。
[*] 開關門、走路動畫實在是太久了
        遊戲中有一堆開關門、走地圖的動畫，而且幾乎一模一樣（除了門上的字外）。
        但如果你沒有跑過這段劇情的話，是不能跳過的，實在很令人煩躁。

[*] 遊戲節奏不佳
        這代缺少了999前期所營造的緊張、危機感。
        而且將能夠推進劇情的部分擺到太後面（或著是我太早碰到太多To be continued.），
        前中期玩起來會有點煩悶。

[*][spoiler] 形態形成場[/spoiler]
        [spoiler]10、1年前的九人遊戲都是為了這個假說所設計的，結果這代卻說特務機關其實早就知道了。
        還訓練、增強這一項能力。我是覺得很硬要。[/spoiler]

[*][spoiler] 副標題的意涵[/spoiler]
        [spoiler]到最後我還是無法體會副標題的意涵，「好人不長命」。[/spoiler]
[/list]

[h3]結論[/h3]
[spoiler]也許是《999》本身很完善了，玩到最後劇情上《好人不長命》與《999》的關聯並不高，基本上只有部分設定與部分人物沿用而已。
而且很可惜的，《好人不長命》不是一個完整的故事，想知道後面的故事的話，就要買《刻之困境》了。
由於我比較喜歡《999》的那種氛圍，所以我的評價是《9小時9人9扇門》>《好人不長命》。[/spoiler]

It is 2 games in 1.

999 is the more dated one, with a tightly knit story and interesting characters, the escape rooms are not a particular challenge. Globally pretty good.

VLR is a lot more elaborate, with a more complex story, albeit a bit too complex at times for the actual depth. It has more repetition but the flow chart and skip tools help alleviating this. The escape rooms I think are a big step up and were all quite enjoyable with some hard thinking at times.
The 3D is uh, off-putting and somewhat deterrent, but can be adapted to if you don't look too much at the faces. (It's also making the escape rooms much better)

After careful pondering, I determined that VLR, despite its shortcomings, was still the best out of the two, with 999 having the most memorable moments.

So, in the end, I greatly recommend this, as the experience it gave was worth it.
game good

An exercise in how much a format of a story can shape your understanding of it. That's as much as I can say without spoiling anything.

SPOILERS FOR 999
[spoiler] The first game was originally released for the DS, and while the effort to convert is there, The first game is incredibly medium specific. I don't think the plot twist with the narrator works quite as well here, but the writing as whole is still really good.  I loved piecing together the story through time travel and resolving the contradictions and paradoxes that come from that. [/spoiler]

SPOILERS FOR VLR
[spoiler] This takes everything I loved about 999, and just amps up the scale. The plot twists, the time travel, and the pseudoscience-y themes particularly. Luna's ending in particular was a highlight. my only real criticisms is that this game only exists to set up the third game,  and that the story isn't as tightly told as the first. [/spoiler]

In short, if you like mind screwy stories that play with your expectations using the format it's told through, this is a pretty good series.

The Nonary Games are a bundle of two games, 9 People, 9 Doors, 9 Hours and Virtue's Last Reward. Fortunately, both games are great so the positive review applies to both.

999 and VLR are games that are both hybrids of the visual novel, choose-your-own-adventure and puzzle game genre. Both games are made by ChunSoft with Uchikoshi as the writer and producer for both games. Both games are lauded for their trope-subversive characters. Both games feature a story line filled with mystery and unexpected, dramatic twists.

This remaster brings many of (much needed) QOL improvements to 999 that VLR had. These are very welcome and make the game play experience much nicer. Further added in this remaster is voice acting for 999, though the English voice acting is very inconsistent. Characters like Lotus and Ace have generally great voice work, but Junpei and June's voice acting is... well, it's there. VLR was written with the DS's unique dual screen in mind, and while this port works around it as well as can be expected, this does mean some clever details of the original are lost. This does not hamper the game play or story significantly.

Unfortunately, Virtue's Last Reward's port has a bug related to the character's facial animations. Lip syncing does not seem to work properly and Clover in particular seems to be frozen on a light smile - which can be inappropriate when she's meant to look shocked. Other than this, the port is executed well aside from some minor jank in the control scheme.

Here is a quick summary of what makes both games great:
- Great music.
- Atmospheric environments that suit the mood of the games perfectly.
- An interesting cast of characters whom all have interesting development.
- Well written stories full of unexpected twists and clever, subtle details.

What 999 does better than VLR:
- A more concise, self-contained story.
- Better pacing.
- 2D character sprites are unique and gorgeous, with short but characterful animation.

What VLR does better than 999:
- Better twists and individual character development.
- More interesting, engaging puzzles with a welcome hard mode.
- Spreads out exposition a bit better.

[h1] Zero Escape должна по праву считаться шедевральной классикой среди визуальных новелл[/h1]
 
Обойдусь без душнины и истории разработки, кем и как всё это создавалось, вы можете выяснить сами, я хочу выделить множество аспектов, которые выделяют эту новеллу среди кучи шлака, напичканого "японщиной". 

Первое, что бросилось мне в глаза - нормальные, человеческие персонажи. Никто из них лишний раз не кривляется, не орет и не ведет себя, как имбецил - ояш из типичного аниме. Каждый хорошо прописан, обладает своим характером и раскрывается по ходу повествования. 

Геймплей тут прост - исследуй и решай головоломки, попутно читая диалоги ( к ним еще вернемся), а еще новелла иногда дает нам выбор, который будет иметь последствия и возможность выйти на одну из концовок.
Загадки, порой, попадаются весьма сложные (мейби я тупой прост) иногда я зависал по полчаса на какой - то из них. Игра не щадит и не дает поблажек, сиди и думай над ответом. Зачастую там будет затрагиваться математика, информатика, еще чаще логика, ну и один раз попалась химия (не всё помню, но большинство из них - всё - таки логика, которая требует неординарного мышления.) Хочу добавить, что они не выбиваются из темпа игры и отлично вписаны в сюжет.

Вот кстати о диалогах, в игре полно философских, научных и псевдонаучных размышлений, до кучи фактов, о которых вы, возможно узнаете впервые и обо всём этом размышляют персонажи. Юмор, кстати тут есть. И очень даже неплохой. Пару смех*ечков поймать можно. 

Музыка - изумительна и до жути подходит под ситуации. Эмбиент и звуки также подобраны шикарно. Скрип корабля в любой ситуации пускает табун мурашек. Еще стоит упомянуть хорошую графику, подправленную переизданием.

Однако всё, что я описал выше, скорее всего лишь фон, наполнение. Конечно, это играет немаловажную роль, но шедевром я эту новеллу назвал не поэтому. 

[b]Сюжет[/b] - он бесподобен. Поражает именно то, насколько он тут продуман. От самого название 999, до финальных титров, вас будет ожидать отличная, проработанная до мелочей история. 
Тут несколько концовок и чтобы открыть истинную, нужно пройти все ветки, но это не тоже самое, что мы видели в других новеллах. Тут абсолютно всё взаимосвязано. Каждая концовка лишь приоткрывает завесу тайны и держит интригу до конца. Каждый факт, упомянутый где либо, каждое ружье - стреляет и выдает сюжетный твист.  Сложно описать текстом, да и не нужно, не хочется портить вам ощущение. Я дал вам достаточно уверенности, что эту новеллу СТОИТ прочитать, если вы любитель жанра, а если даже новичок, то это самый лучший старт, который можно представить.

6 раз перепроходить игру не обязательно, в переиздании добавили возможность скипать прочитанное и удобно начинать нужную вам ветку. 
Игра полностью и достойно русифицирована. Но только одна из двух частей. Заверю, что можете смело брать, т.к первая часть вполне самостоятельна и дает оценить себя без сиквела.

Минус из-за внезапного повышения региональных цен в России. Считаю это несправедливым. Отрицательный этот обзор именно из-за этого, но не относится ни к самой игре, ни к создателям. Только к конченной cтудии Spike Shunsoft.

I played through these games on their initial releases, but decided to go back to them on PC. There are several quality of life features and improvements in this collection, especially when it comes to 999 such as the introduction of voice acting and the flowchart which really help to reduce some of the biggest annoyances I had with that game. Не так давно всё же решил ознакомиться с игрой, а вернее серией игр Zero Escape, потому что слышал, что то там, то там, её вроде как хвалят. И знаете что? Мало хвалят! За последние МНОГО лет не припомню, чтобы игра так щедро и часто дарила такой искренний ВАУ-эффект. Каждый день и каждый, проходя её разными вариантами и складывая паззл воедино я оставался с каким-то неподдельным детским восхищением. Столь умная, интересная, крепко переплетённая история, в которой не один или два сюжетных поворота, а целое изобилие! История столь умна и хороша, что никогда не устареет. Даже через десятки лет, решив ознакомиться с серией впервые она будет приводить в восторг. Я не боюсь её перехвалить, эта серия она стоит многих хороших, и абсолютно справедливо их заслуживает.

И это лишь две части серии, после которых жизненно необходимо пройти и третью, чтобы на её фоне, картина целиком заиграла ещё ярче.

999:
It's been a while since I remember but I remember being absolutely awestruck by the storytelling. At points, character will talk about ideas that are totally bizarre and uncommon, and I got super lost but also super interested in what everybody had to say. As I played more and learned more, it all started to make much more sense and culminate in a way that made me excited over a visual novel, whose main gameplay consists of reading really cool text. 10/10 for the first time through, and a wonder to watch others go through and see what their decisions are.

VLR:
Same concept as 999. Lots of scientific theories and thought experiments that sounded really cool, but didn't seem to have any effect on the story or gameplay, until you start unlocking endings. VLR tells the story in a more interesting way, and expands on 999's previous story. This really feels like a well developed sequel that furthers the story of 999, and really speaks to what a sequel should be. Like 999, everything you know, love, and will come to realize all culminate at the very end, and feels like a very satisfying ending, even if it hurts my peanut brain. 10/10 would try to ABCDE but it's actually EDCABEDBAE one more time

If you did not know, Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is a remaster bundle of both "Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors" and "Virtue's Last Reward".

Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors, or 999 for short, is a Visual Novel puzzle escape room game. You are trapped in a ship, with 8 others, and must find the number 9 door in order to escape certain doom. In order to progress through the ship and find the door you must complete puzzles to unlock more areas. There are branching choices and different endings. With the paths you chose you'll get knowledge of even more things that carry over to a new path you follow. You'll gain more and more knowledge and start to theorize why you've been put there, who put you there, why me and these other 8 people specifically. Just as you think you've figured it all out, the game hits you hard with a plot twist and blows your fucking mind. Everyone here is connected in ways you cannot imagine. Every route means something and makes even more sense once you have finished more routes. This game is fascinating to me, in the way it utilizes the visual novel and puzzle genre in ways I've never seen and ever will see again.

So yeah, 999 is great, but what about Virtue's Last Reward, or VLR for short? VLR takes what you know about 999 and throws it out the window miles far. This isn't a bad thing, it's a really good thing. While 999 asks you for consent, VLR does not ask consent, does not use lube, no condom and goes rock hard even after you've been ravaged multiple times and in need of a break. Analysing VLR is extremely difficult just, because of the sheer amount of information it flows at you. I won't be able to do that part justice and the only thing that would is the game itself. Just beware that this game will eradicate your brain multiple, a lot, a fuck ton of times. It will take you weeks to even digest the surface level of what VLR is. This isn't a flaw per se. For me it is the game's greatest strength and the aspect that makes this game stand alone unlike any other game, hell even any other medium piece.

There are a lot of other reasons these games are great, the puzzles are really good, the music practically carries the atmosphere and the characters are good and fun. I just wanted to go into detail about what made these games special. That made these games pioneers in my eyes of Visual Novel storytelling.

A 10/10 visual novel bundle. (I don't think I would consider visual novels much of a game, but that is up to debate)

It has a lot more repitition that drives me insane (If I have to 'learn' that this is map B and that the other map was map A one more time...). Plus even with the auto to run through dialogue you've seen before, there'll be lots of moments of clicking through and the scene transitions of doors and moving across the map really REALLY nearly killed my enjoyment of the game. THAT SAID if you can stomach through and get through this game, yeah. Its got parts you might work out and feel smart, and other parts that make you feel completely blindsided. Its great. Just not a patch on 999.

The Nonary Games contient 2 jeux : 999 et VLR, donc une critique par jeu :


Zero Escape 999 : Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors

Zero Escape 999 est mon 1er visual novel et je n'ai pas été déçu. Les persos sont intéressants et attachants, avec des personnalités variées et crédibles. Alors oui ce sont tous des génies mais ça ne me gêne pas du tout, ça permet de créer des situations inédites et captivantes. Les musiques sont bonnes et participent à l'ambiance très immersive. L'univers du jeu est cohérent en mélangeant science et fiction.

J'ai fait le jeu sur PC et j'ai donc eu droit au voice acting excellent. Je suis bien fan du système de Flow, très bien fait (et pas frustrant comme j'en avais peur). Skip les dialogues est facile et rapide et je n'ai eu aucune énigme à refaire 2 fois donc gros GG pour ça. J'ai vraiment pas galéré à 100% le jeu (toutes les fins) sans aucun guide, le seul endroit où j'étais mauvais c'était certaines énigmes (qui sont d'ailleurs en moyenne OK/sympa).

Pour l'histoire je préfère rien spoil mais c'est évidemment le point fort du jeu et son atout principal. J'ai personnellement bien aimé en plus d'avoir été surpris plus d'une fois.

-

Zero Escape : Virtue's Last Reward

Zero Escape VLR est le 2e épisode de la série, et il complète très bien le 1er. 
Le nouveau cast est toujours rempli de persos intéressants et attachants, mieux développés que dans 999. On échange ici les jolis artworks en 2D pour des modèles 3D assez moyens, mais avec quelques animations (un peu trop limitées). Le doublage est très bon, les décors OK et les musiques sympathiques.

J'ai préféré les énigmes, plus variées et moins frustrantes à mon goût (sauf 1 sur les 16). Le système de skip est malheureusement moins bien fait, on doit donc se taper des trajets sur la carte et des portes qui s'ouvrent lentement à répétition, ce qui est le plus gros point faible du jeu à mes yeux.

Mais le scénario bon sang. Encore plus de plot twists. Encore plus de petits détails. Encore plus de thèmes, de questions, de "C'EST PAS VRAI", "COMMENT J'AI PU RATER ÇA", et autres "QUOI ?!". Un pur plaisir d'enchevêtrements à travers des histoires parallèles bien ficelées. L'ajout d'une partie confiance/trahison qui donne bien plus de poids à nos choix. Des fins plus originales et inattendues. Le monde futuriste est toujours très cohérent, les petites histoires et les nombreuses références très agréables. L'univers de Zero Escape et sa narration sont du jamais vu pour moi dans un jeu vidéo.

***REVIEW FOR 999 ONLY***

I had heard a lot about this game over the years, both good and bad. The biggest complaint I heard was that since you need to get most/all of the bad endings before you can get the true ending, you had to play through the ENTIRE game again. This was true until this version we released. As you play the game, you will create a flow chart of all the points in the game. Once you finish one route, you can go back to the start, and then go to the flow chart and start exactly at any decision point and simply make another choice. This makes getting all the ends so much easier and a lot more fun. The other thing I heard about this game was how good it was.

I was a bit worried it would just have a bunch of cliche anime nonsense and fan service (there is some but after a while it kind of just becomes noise you don't even notice any more) but oh man was I wrong. My SO and I have have been playing it together as an alternative to tv or movies and its been a serious blast getting DEEP into this story. We really love all the characters and the whole world is really fun to get to know. If you are looking for a well written and engrossing story with AMAZING characters, get this game!

We can't wait to finish 999 and get started on VLR and see where all this is leading too!

"I have no idea where I am, who I am, or even what day it is." - K

This phrase sums up the entire VLR

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is a bundle of two visual novel room escape games: 9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors (shortened to 999) and Virtue's Last Reward (shortened to VLR). 999 is a DS game that has had some improvements made to it, including adding the flowchart system found in VLR (a 3DS game) that lets you skip having to redo puzzle rooms when getting different endings. Getting different endings is the entire point of both 999 and VLR and in both games the true ending is locked behind getting all the rest of them. Buyer beware though, the games are much more story focused than puzzle focused. There will be long stretches in 999, and especially VLR, where you sit through tons of dialogue. I didn't mind it though, as I found the story to be engaging in both cases. 999 took me around 35 hours to 100% and VLR took me around 50 Hours to 100%. Overall, I felt that 999 had the better story, but VLR had the better puzzle rooms. That is subjective though, both are great and I could easily see someone arguing the exact opposite. I recommend playing 999 first, you can play VLR without playing 999, but there are A LOT of references to 999 in VLR and some spoilers as well.

Pros:
-Great Stories
-Great Puzzle Rooms
-Memorable, likeable and fun characters in both games (I especially like Snake and Clover in 999 and Luna and Phi in VLR)
-Nice Sound Effects

Cons:
-VLR's ending took me a while to understand what was going on and wasn't as satisfying for me as 999's.
-One puzzle in 999 didn't quite transition from the DS very well, it clearly relied on the Dual Screen.
-Perhaps too long of periods of time between puzzle rooms for some people
Just look at my game time if you wanna know how passionate I am about this game

I say most because there IS a third game that ties together any loose ends but.. that's it's own beast.

The Nonary Games es una compilación de dos juegos: "Nine Hours, Nine persons, Nine" doors (o 999) y su secuela "Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward" (VLR), originalmente lanzados para Nintendo DS y Nintendo 3DS respectivamente.

Ambos juegos tratan de un grupo de nueve extraños que son secuestrados y obligados a participar en el "Nonary Game", donde deben escapar de múltiples habitaciones, resolviendo variados puzzles para sobrevivir (aires de saw?).

El juego alterna entre secciones de novela visual, donde avanza la trama, y secciones de escape.
Las secciones de escape son del típico formato "escape room", donde hay que ir resolviendo puzzles y obteniendo pistas o piezas para resolver otros puzzles, y asi hasta encontrar salida.

Los puzzles son buenos y variados, no cae en la misma categoría que grandes como Myst, no veo ese nivel de complejidad en los puzzles, diría que es algo más cercano al nivel de dificultad de juegos como The Room o los puzzles medianos de Professor Layton.

La trama del juego es interesante y está bien llevada, algo a tener en cuenta es que hay elementos de ciencia ficción, incluyendo abundante pseudo-ciencia. Esto se siente más en VLR que en 999.

Siendo en parte una novela visual, el diálogo es abundante. Entre habitación y habitación pueden pasar fácilmente unos 20 minutos de diálogo de por medio sin ningún tipo de interacción por parte del jugador, y no recomiendo ignorarlo porque puede dar pistas sobre cómo progresar en el juego.

En cuanto a lo visual, hay contraste importante entre 999 y VLR, los escenarios y el diseño de personajes se sienten más consistentes y mejor logrados en 999. El diseño extravagante de los personajes de VLR en conjunto con el uso de modelos 3D (bastante malos) en lugar de sprites y los entornos aburridos dan una mala primera impresión, esto no se traduce a la jugabilidad ni la trama, ya que VLR brilla en ese sentido.

Resumiendo, es un buen juego de puzzle, con un desafío medio, y una buena novela visual, recomendable para quienes busquen juegos de puzzle y una trama decente. No lo recomiendo para quienes buscan solamente un juego de puzzle para pasar el rato, porque van a tener que lidiar con horas y horas de diálogo.

先说steam移植的优点：flow可以跳剧情不用打在密室中一遍又一遍打吐。
steam移植的缺点：把整个故事的表现力降低了一个等级。原版nds分上下屏，上屏是对话，下屏是叙述。steam画虎不成反类犬，搞了个novel和ADV的双模式，意义不明。novel模式就是把对话和叙述放在一起，一行对话一行叙述，ADV就是索性连叙述也看不到了，我就好奇这算哪门的ADV模式？[spoiler] 对比原版下屏叙述是女主视角的表现，高下立判。 [/spoiler]
密室难度中等偏下，偶尔卡关还有提示，实属不错。虽然有推理的成分，但是凶手1周目差不多能看出端倪。[spoiler] 把腕表拿走啥的太老梗了 [/spoiler]
真结局倒是让人眼前一亮，黑幕的身份我倒没有特别惊讶 [spoiler] 双人黑幕确实还让我吃了一惊，但是9年前死掉的小女孩是茜一说出来几乎都能猜到，不过打越再次反转，搞出时间loop让未来的男主救9年前的小女孩还是让人大吃一惊的。 [/spoiler]
男女主的感情写的实在让我梦回《三体2》中罗辑和庄颜，最后两个人坐在山坡上稍微拉回来一点，中间各种脸红心跳崩溃我通通地铁老人看手机。你以为男女主是青梅竹马？不，他们只是失散多年的小学同学。我就不明白了，怎么前一秒还是很久不见的小学同学，后一秒就各种我喜欢你你喜欢我。就算是吊桥效应，也完全没吊起来啊。
 [spoiler] 说一个我非常喜欢的设计，就是男主越偏离焚烧炉，女主高烧就越厉害，有一个结局女主直接高烧到凭空消失，妙啊。 [/spoiler]

这个游戏目前我无法理解的bug或者谜题：
[spoiler] 1. 女主和santa表上数字到底是多少？感觉就像是提了一嘴他们表上的数字不是原来的数字就完了。如果他们中确实有一个是9，那么原本鸟巢男的9号就是6号了？那么1当时是怎么打开3号门杀死他以为的2的呢？如果9号是6号，3号门是打不开的。
2. 在3号门里死的那个人有表吗？已知最后表是和2一起在棺材里的，如果表有且只有1个的前提下，那么3号门里死的那个人的表是哪里来了？（当然以上两个bug都可以以表不止有1个来解决）。
3. 2和7记忆的矛盾，虽然男主说2眼睛看不见，但是2的嗅觉是灵敏的，空烧和烧人的味道还是有区别的。而且最后茜跑出来抱着她哥哥说的话2也听到了，这边2和7的记忆紊乱无法解释。（7失忆了，2可没失忆）
4. 男女主到底是怎么心灵感应的？如果按照作者说一切因为爱的说法，这也太扯了，还不如说男主给的那个巫毒娃娃中蕴藏了泰国的神秘力量呢。 [/spoiler]

最后，999虽然不是神作，但是是个好游戏~

What Danganronpa games should've been.

To those who have played Danganronpa and didn't like how utterly ridiculous the game gets after a while: 

This game fixes those issues, it's a lot more grounded, with a deeper story that has no plot holes. Everything makes sense in this universe.

To those who have played Danganronpa and liked it:

Definitely give it a try, it's a better experience in almost every way. Writing, graphic design, shock factor.

To those that played neither:

Did you ever play a Visual Novel? Then check this out, it's one of the most well known VN on the west, and it's a very fun experience. The game is a mixture of room escape, choice making, and novel. It does it well, and it has lots of endings, which you'll have to unlock to reach conclusions. It sounds boring, but the game does it so well that there's no wasted time, since you can select where exactly you want to go back in time.

Görüşlerimi bildirmeden önce bir kaç not :

1)Nonary Games iki oyundan oluşmaktadır. İlk oyunun ismi kısaca 999, ikinci oyunun ismi ise virtue's last reward.

2)İki oyunun toplam oynayış(gameplay) süresi yaklaşık olarak 50-60 saat.(Eğer bir perfectionistseniz.)

3)Oyunda Türkçe dil desteği yok ve a1 a2 seviyesinde bir ingilizceden daha yüksek o yüzden ingilizceniz çok iyi değilse oynarken sözlük kullanmanızı(ben chromedan tureng kullanıyordum) öneriyorum.

4)Nonary Games oyununun devam oyunu vardır ve ismi Zero Time Dilemma'dır.
Görüşlerim :

Oynayacak olana oynarken kesinlikle not almasını öneriyorum. Birinci oyunda beyniniz allak bullak olsa da ikinci oyunda cidden beyin denen bir şey bırakmıyor oyun.Kısaca beyninizi yok edecek bir oyun arıyorsanız KESİNLİKLE oynayın.
 
Ostlarını çok beğendim, mesela onlardan biri [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EjQfY47pFNs] biri [/url]

İlk oyunu tamamen visual yapmışlar ki gayet muhteşem olmuş ama ikinci oyunu 3d yapalım derken görüntü kalitesini becerememişler.Karakterlerin diyalogları sırasında yaptıkları hareketler, mimikler kötü olmuş.(İkinci oyunu oynarken Pembe saçlı kızın yüzünü görünce anlayacaksınız veya bazı diyaloglarda kahverengi saçlı kızın suratını.)

İkinci oyundaki 3d animasyonlar bazı yerlerde o kadar uzatılmıştı ki oyun beni bir çok kez üff hadi ama geç işte dedirtti. Örneğin kapıların açılma animasyonları ve ÖZELLİKLE haritada ilerleme animasyonu.

Oyun başarımlarını gayet mantıklı buldum.Saçma sapan şeyler istemiyordu.(Mesela Forager oyunu ne kadar güzel olsa da oyunda bir başarımı kazamak için grind yapman gerekiyordu 1 gün boyunca ki bu da ÇOK sıkıcıydı.)

Oyunu indirimdeyken almıştım ve tabii ki siz de indirimde alın. İndirimdeyken fiyatı 10 tl KESİNLİKLE fiyatına 100 kat değer.

999'da çok güzel diyaloglar bulabilirsiniz bazı ögelere birden fazla tıklarsanız kesinlikle kaçırmayın bazıları efsane :)

Dipnot : İkinci oyundaki Tavşan kılıklı hologramın konuşması çok hoşuma gitti, tavşan candır.

Sonsöz : 

Oyunu kesinlikle alın hüç şüpheniz olmasın. Puanım 10 üzerinden 8.5
Yazımı okuduğunuz için teşekkürler, iyi günler dilerim :)

This is a visual novel with old school adventure game DNA (think Myst). It's two games in one, and both are very good.

There is a lot of dialog, so I wouldn't recommend it to anyone that wasn't in it for the story. The story has multiple branching paths, with multiple endings. The 'true' ending for the games usually involves completing multiple paths. There is a very handy scene chart that you can use to jump to any story section you have completed previously.

The games can be played with mouse+keyboard or a controller. For the second game, it is good to mention that you can pan the camera with Q and E. You can skip dialog you have seen before by using ctrl.

2 oyundan oluşan bu oyun paketi gayet güzeldi. Bildiğimiz odadan kaçış oyunlarını çok sürükleyici bir hikaye ile desteklemişler. 
-İlk oyun Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors (999), hikaye anlamıyla daha ön plandaydı ve bence daha sürükleyiciydi. Çizimleri, diyalogları hoştu ve ana konunun açıklanması ile başarılı bir giriş oyunu olduğunu düşünüyorum. Oyun süresi olarak da dengeliydi. Oyun içerisinde belirli aksiyonları gerçekleştirerek doğru sona ulaşabiliyoruz. Geri kalan sonlar ise yanlış son. (Puanım 9,5/10, bulmacalar biraz daha zor olabilirdi -0,5)
-İkinci oyun ise Virtue’s Last Reward (VLR). Bu oyun diğer oyuna göre daha farklı bir gidişata sahipti. 999'dan sonra yeniden aynı mantıkla gidilmemiş, oynanan Nonary Game kuralları değiştirilerek oyuncuyu aynı şeylerle tekrara düşürmemiş. Ayrıca ilk oyunda olan 2 boyutlu çizimler bu oyunda 3 boyuta çıkarılmış. Diğer oyuna nazaran konu, karakter hikayeleri tabanlı gidiyor, yani doğru son veya yanlış son yok gibi. Aynı zamanda seçtiğimiz bir sonun bitebilmesi için belirli diğer sonların da önceden bitirilmesi gerekiyor. Bu oyun içerisinde "Lock 1,2,3 vb." şekillerde zamanı gelince belirtiliyor. İki oyunda da olay örgüsü içerisinde istediğiniz kayıt noktaları arasında geçiş yapabiliyoruz, dolayısıyla oyun performansınızı etkilemez. Daha fazla farklı son ve daha fazla farklı ve uzun süren bulmaca mevcut. Oyunun bu kadar uzun olması kimine göre eğlenceli ve ben dahil kimine göre ise sıkıcı hale getiren bir etmen. (Puanım 7,5/10, bulmacalar ya çok kolay ya çok zor -1, grafikler -0,5, oyun gereksiz uzun -1)
A VN masterpiece.

This is two games packaged together, so although my recommendation applies to both, I will comment on them separately. 

999:
999 is a perfect little gem of a game. It is strange and at times confusing but thats all part of the experience. 
Gameplay
The game is split into visual novel and escape the room puzzle segments. I found the puzzles fairly easy, but more than anything they are there to support the story, and they are well designed to do that. 
Visuals and audio
I really enjoy the graphics and music in this game. The music moves between offputting, emotional and stress enducing in a way that really adds to the atmosphere. Voice acting was something added for this version and I don't think the game really needed it but the only time it took me out of it was when I realised one of the actors was one of the people who voiced like 30 minor npcs in Skyrim. (You'll hear it, just wait) The 3D environments are basically what you would expect for a game initially made for DS, its not bad, but its pretty bland. The character art is fantastic, and really conveys the personalities of the characters. The only one I dont like so much is Lotus. I love her as a character but I thought at some point it was going to make sense why she is wearing what looks like a belly dancing costume. It doesn't. 
Story
Story is the main reason to play this game, but I can't same much beyond what the game summary already says without spoiling it. It is weird as hell and I love it. 

Virtue's Last reward

Compared to 999 VLR is a much larger game, and in my opinion most of what is great in the first game is expanded on, but also what wasn't as great. 

Gameplay
VLR is almost identical in gameplay to 999 but there is a lot more. I noticed a lot more sliding/pushing/rolling puzzles in this, which I personally dislike, but to each their own. A memo function was added, supposedly for keeping notes for puzzles, but it was far easier for me to stick with pencil and paper. I used it once, and covered three A4 sheets of paper with what looks like the scribblings of a madwoman. One feature I really could have used was some way to fast forward through dialogue I had heard before. I had to hear SIgma have the same monologue complaining about being here six times. Six. 
Visuals and Audio
I did not find the audio in VLR quite as striking as 999, it appears many tracks were reused. Still good music though. The was some really great voice acting in this one, it was one element improved from 999. The visuals, I felt, were a downgrade. Environments were largely the same, but this time characters were usually rendered as 3D models that are not the most appealing. It did mean more interaction between the characters and environment was possible, but I really miss the 2d art. Similar to my comment about Lotus, Alice appears to wear an open cropped jacket and a necklace. It makes no sense and I kept thinking about how and whether she prevented nip slips. 

Story:
All the same things I said about 999s story but bigger. Bigger weirdness, bigger confusion, bigger awe at someone coming up with this batshit plot. I love it.

999是在模拟器上玩的，当时就被打越钢太郎的剧本震惊，马上找了模拟器来玩善人死亡，可没想到打了十几个小时的档居然坏了（没错，说的就是你啊该死的减压室存档导致坏档！），于是就弃了。
后面入了正，终于等到出了汉化补丁，但是却一直没打，直到最近才打完。毫无疑问，我享受到了打越一贯以来优秀的叙事性诡计（在这一点上，个人觉得虽然没有ever17和999带给我的震撼大，但确确实实给予了我一种“啊，这就是打越的诡计，真爽”的感觉。）
在已经玩过的几部作品中排个名的话，那我会选择：ever17>999>善人死亡，remember11这部我并不能很好地理解，所以我虽然觉得它是一部超越了以上故事的剧本，但是在叙事性诡计和剧情流畅度、被接受度来讲有所欠缺，因此不计入排名（事实上，我还不太能理解这个故事）。也许是因为知晓了诡计，虽然999是我第一部玩的游戏，理论上来说，排名应该是999 = ever17的，但ever17的剧情多出了一些[spoiler]  meta内容  [/spoiler]（剧透），因此让我更加震撼。
最后还是要说一句，打越钢太郎，永远的神！！！！！！！！

I like these two games. The first two thirds of the Zero Escape Trilogy are a pair of visual novels where the player is trapped with eight other contestants in a deadly game and have to journey through a series of escape rooms in order to flee the prison they are locked away in. 9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors is the better of the two games, in my opinion. Though the game is rather short, I enjoyed the puzzles and characters, and was able to complete the game in just over 20 hours. The FLOW system added into this re-release definitely helped lessen the backtracking in this game, and I think I'll be counting digital roots in my head for quite some time now. Virtue's Last Reward did admittedly disappoint me, but there is still plenty of good in it. While I didn't like the characters in this game as much as the first, the puzzles and plot twists are still just as effective as before. That being said, Easy Mode is made pointless due to the FLOW system, and the Safe mechanic could potentially let lazier players bypass the main meat of the game with a quick online search. That said, play the game as intended, and you'll still be in for a fun and exciting game. Even despite my ups and downs with both titles, I do still very much recommend this pair of games. Do be warned, though, that these two games are very text-heavy, meaning at many times, it will feel like you are watching a movie instead of playing a game. Also, for the best possible experience, you MUST play these two games blind (and preferably in order). Many of the story elements and plot twists will not have the same experience on someone who knows it in advance as someone going in without any prior knowledge. With that said, I must bid you adieu. Have a nice travel!

とりあえず、1作目『9時間9人9の扉』終了。
複数ENDの謎が分からんが、それは2作、3作目終了後に考えることにする。

レビューなんかよりも、ゲームの不具合と解消方法がメイン。
今作はマウス＆キーボードかコントローラーのどちらかの操作が選べる。
私はマウスを使っていたが、マウスを動かす度にFPSが極端に下がる現象に見舞われた。
1作目はそれでも終えられたが、2作目はちょっと耐えられないレベル。
調べたところ、海外の方で「PCにコントローラー刺さってたらそうなった」と情報アリ。
解消方法として、デバイスマネージャーのヒューマンインターフェイスデバイスから当該コントローラーを無効にする方法があるらしい。
……いや、私のPCにコントローラー刺さってないし。昔使ってインストールしたのが残っているのかもと探したが、よく分からず。
とりあえず、Razerのヘッドホン (USB端子用)を引っこ抜いて開始したら、FPSは正常になっていました。
原因分からないけど、PCのUSB端子に余計なものが刺さっていたら同症状が出現するのかも。
忘備録として、解消方法記載しておきます。

目前2打到一半，这个游戏1代还是很不错的，剧本和关卡难度都很好，而且操作起来也没什么问题。
2的关卡，总感觉关卡设计没有一代合理，有的就是纯排列组合试错，或者是背单词，而且有的难度也过高了，个人觉得3D的画面反而不如1代的好看，而且PC上操作手感极差，我记得医务室转向特别恶心，剧情方面打完再说。

Okay, so, when I started playing Zero Escape Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors, I had no faith that it'd be a good game, I actually thought it'd be terrible and that I would hate it, but it didn't turn out like that.
So, I started to play 999 and my first instinct was to try and skip all the text because I only wanted the achievements, but I couldn't. I was like "Oh... Looks like I'll have to play this stupid game reading all dialogues, huh." and I really did. It started and when I first heard Junpei's voice I was like "OKAY, This game may be good, since the voice acting for the main character seems amazing." And it really is! In both English and Japanese, this game's voice acting is just SO. GOOD. IT'S AMAZING, JUNPEI'S ENG VOICE IS JUST. AMAZING. THANK YOU SO MUCH, EVAN SMITH. But, back to the point, I continued my playthrough and I ABSOLUTELY fell in love with Junpei. He became my favourite character so, so quickly and, trust me, it's IMPOSSIBLE to hate him (and, later, he became my favourite character of the world). 999 has AMAZING plots, awesome characters (like Junpei, Santa and Lotus, for example) and a lot of different endings, let aside that it'll surely teach you something new. Like. Definitely.
Okay, so I finished playing the first game and headed straight to the second game, Virtue's Last Reward. I started it and. Damn. Fell in love with Sigma Klim, the protagonist, aGAIN (and he eventually became my second fave chara in the world™) and it's just as good as 999, in my honest opinion. It has 9 or 10 endings, I think. It has a lot of amazing characters, like Sigma, Phi and Luna, for example. It's totally worth playing, but it has a LOT of dialogues and 16 doors to open and escape. Yeah, it takes time but playing and replaying VLR is worth it, without a doubt (just like playing and replaying 999), and it is also fun to do.
The Zero Escape Series is definitely something that I'd recommend to any and everyone. The game that I didn't even care/wanted to play at first and tried to skip all the text before actually became my favourite game ever, just like it's characters (Jumpy and Siggy) became my favourite characters in the entire world.
Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is DEFINITELY worth playing and buying. It's just amazing. And also, it has funny jokes.
Thank you, Junpei, I love you.

I bought this alongside danganronpa and it was available as a bundle, I have finished this game in offline mode and the ending I got was inconclusive and a sad ending. I think the puzzles aren't too complex and you'll figure it out eventually, but in my personal experience this lacked any psychological horror that will shake you or disturb you, I think if you start this game fresh off of danganronpa and expect the same uncertainty and shock value then you'll be disappointed.

I won't recommend this to people who are just starting off in their visual novel journey or are escape room game enthusiasts, this game is more like a collector's item if you want to complete your spike chunsoft collection or just want to support the developers in some form.

I would love to explore the different endings, but I would have to force myself to do that, the humour gets stale fast and the characters aren't likable at all, and frankly I wanted to escape from these characters more than the ship itself.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games offers the first two releases in the Zero Escape trilogy, presenting the most up-to-date version of each of them. This was my first introduction to the first game, 999, and my second play through of VLR (previously played on the PS Vita). I played the first game around the steam release by myself and was amazed. Then got a couple of friends together to do the true ending in one go. The second game I had already played substantially on the PS Vita however, since I had already gotten all of the achievements for the first game, I played it to completion here on steam.
I think for full asking price, you're getting a hell of a bargain, if you like mystery thrillers with a sci-fi theme and a whack ton of what can only be described as, "insane over-the-top Japanese plot twists" then this is the game for you.
This is true for both games but I feel more so for the second game but just when you feel you figured out how its going to end, these game take you expectations, crumples them up into a little ball and shoots a three-pointer with them. You may not like the endings but you sure as hell will be surprised by them. Whatever you do, do NOT look into this game if you ever plan on playing it, it is best experienced blind.

I think the first game did the visual style a tad better but you get used to the second game after a bit, though the crappy lip sync never gets any better...
The music adds amazing amounts of atmosphere, they really did a bang up job on the sound track. I have it downloaded onto my computer and listen to it sometimes.
The puzzles in the games are great, with a few exceptions, and they really make you get invested in the game, they vary in difficulty and generally get harder as the game progresses, though not in every case.

Note: (The Nonary Games is a bundle of the first two games in the series; 9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors (999) and Virtue's Last Reward (VLR). I have 100% completed both games and will reviewing both separately.)

TL;DR: Listen, if you like visual novels, well-written characters, and experimental successes, this is for you. 

It was any other Steam day scrolling through games. I loved the Danganronpa series, despite all of its flaws. It was a great quarantine escape from reality. I happened to find the Nonary Games, and at the time, the whole trilogy was on sale for under fifteen dollars. It was a steal. If I didn't like it, there wasn't much to lose. Not sure what I expected, I prepared for the worse. I was more than surprised by the end and my 83 hour playtime reflects my loyalty to this series I slept on. 

999 REVIEW: 

This game is one of favorite games of all time, let alone one of my favorite visual novels. It may not be everyone's cup of tea, but if you have any good taste, I would hope it is. 999 seems to have its own admirable, small, cult following over the years. It's popularity never soared, which is quite a shame. To give you an idea of how obsessed I am with this game, I bought the physical version of original Ds version, which I honestly kept having to restrain myself from playing it a third time in a row. Oh, and also the Nonary Games PS4 version. Without giving spoilers, I completely understand the people upset by some of the plot twists and build-up for this game being majorly defeated on its remaster. I won't give any reasons, but anyone who has played the game would know what I mean. Personally, I think it's a shame, but the remaster did its best and by remaking it, it becomes more accessible for people to purchase. 

...

999's visuals are experimental and effective. The classic style of the 2D sprites look amazing, and although I mainly direct this comment towards the original Ds version, they are still great in this remaster nonetheless. With most likely a tight budget, this first game takes its limitations to its advantage. (Almost) Each character has their own set of  animations. They are just as memorable as the classic Ace Attorney and I'm a sucker for these character sprites.

The characters in the first game are wonderfully written. I was quite scared and on my guard, as-is with me and many "anime-looking" games, but despite what its character designs may seem (which are still great), these characters are very much real. Each are guided by their own pasts; each have their own weaknesses, strengths, and mostly importantly, values. Although this game has a "choose your own adventure" idea, it is more so that the player gains more information to lead to the climax, or main route of the story.

The game's, well, gameplay is probably the most unique thing about this package. Some may not find the item-looking life to their liking, and whether one likes it or not, at one point I'm sure most people borrow some help from a guide. I did my best. I think the escape rooms are very fun and are able to have a balance between story and gameplay. Stories are woven into the rooms themselves. I think that even if you don't like that "gameplay," you'll grow onto it, and even if you don't, the story is worth sticking around for.  

The numbered doors/bracelets are a really cool idea and allow players to grow onto and learn about each character more depending on the current route. Genius.

OH, I CAN'T FORGET. The voice acting for this game is great. The dialogue is also good and the voices fit their characters and their expressive traits perfectly. I played the game in the dub, which after listening briefly to the sub, I think the dub is superior. If there is one really good thing about this remaster, it's the added flowchart and voice acting, which feels very authentic and refreshing. One of my favorite dubs of all time. 

There are so many things I could say about this game, but I'll leave with the last point being that it is written beautifully. Fun fact: it was also written backwards, which would explain the keen attention to detail. There are some things that don't particularly make sense here and there, but some of the (keeping this spoiler-free) sci-fi elements I personally enjoyed, especially after thinking back on the whole experience. I wouldn't change anything. I replayed this game twice, again only a week after I finished it for the first time, but I did that partly to escape a certain something....

VLR Review:

Where do I begin? I don't really know. After I put a good amount of hours into this game, I found myself disappointed. The middle was hard to get through. And the end was... alright. This game is mediocre at best in my opinion, and almost everything about it is worse than the game previous before it. So let's get started. I also don't really want to compare it to 999,  because they are quite different, but I will say some similarities because it'll keep this review from becoming a book. 

My only real positive for VLR is that it's a game.  I think it's puzzles can be slightly better than 999's. But they also took out story segments in escape rooms, which really sucks. Also the AB Game... It was cool at first, but gets boring real quick.

VLR's characters are a massive down-grade. The characters are not nearly as complex or interesting. The visuals to this may not be the ugliest thing out there, but after seeing them for hours with their sometimes glitchy animations, it lacks. The ending may be the best part of this game, besides the fact that it's over. 

To give an example and avoiding spoilers, I bring attention to one of the most disappointing parts of this game; who also summarizes why I kinda hate this game so much: 

Clover. Regardless that she was my favorite character in the first game, her second iteration is nothing more than a fanservice tool for the main protagonist. Without getting too side-tracked speaking of which, this game's protagonist, Sigma, is pathetic in comparison to Junpei. Junpei feels real and *is* a character and not some self insert. Sigma is a horny, mind-numbingly boring character and he made the game also that much worse. Even Junpei can be horny at times, but it's actually quite funny.

Clover is probably one of the fan favorites because her story, motives, and personality are charming and memorable. Although it makes sense and is fine for a character to change, if they change without any apparent explanation... what's the point in including them? As many refer to her as VLR Clover, so will I. So why is she so bad? Besides the fact that she's full of fanservice, her personality also does a 180. She used to be smart in the first game and in the second, she becomes dumb as f***. Her design is also a major down-grade.

Still somewhat related, even Clover's voice acting lacks in VLR. But that actually makes sense. The original game had no voice acting, so when they remastered it back in 2018(?) they got returning voice actors from the series that voice acted for the second and third Nonary Games. Some characters were all voice acted in another game before the first. Pretty weird, huh? But I'm glad the voice actors got better over time, since it improves 999 all the more. 

Another reason VLR sucks is because all character are at face value and the game feels very gimmick-y. By the end I feel the game just wanted to be a mindfuck for no other reason than to just be confusing. I don't care about these characters. And *this* game is a actual choose-your-own-adventure story, because it is so damn repetitive and long. I spent probably 60 hours on the second and only 20 on the first. Wow. Now if VLR was actually valid for all of those hours, fine, but it's not. 

I would love to keep ranting, but I'm not going to. 

Final Review:

999: 9/10 (I am not sorry)

VLR: 6/10

I liked 999 better than Virtue's Last Reward but I liked the plots and the storytelling of both Nonary Games more than the Decision Game (I played ZTD first by mistake before playing any of the Nonary Games hahaha). The puzzles in the Nonary Games are also easier than the puzzles in the Decision Game. I also liked the art style of 999 better. I was actually disappointed that some elements in VLR weren't incorporated into ZTD even though in VLR, they were said to be key elements for the success of one of goals in ZTD.

[h1] Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors [/h1]
[list]
[*] The story is absolutely amazing. Initial intrigue, mystery, horror moments and great plot-twists. All of it is done masterfully.
[*] The dialogues are very well-written with some good humour and great emotional moments, but there is that irritating thing where characters repeat the same thing at least 3 times, which is kinda irritating when you play through multiple scenes at once.
[*] Graphics are good, I personally loved character models, they are very well-drawn and detailed. The location design is fascinating.
[*] The music is very good and fits perfectly to each scene, and voice acting is nothing short of superb throughout the entire game.
[*] The puzzles are pretty easy, never really found myself thinking about the solution. I guess that there are just too many hints in dialogues and character's thoughts. It'd be a better idea to let the player decide if they want them or not.
[/list]

[i] One of the best puzzle games/visual novels I've played. [/i]

9/10

[h1] Virtue's Last Reward [/h1]
[list]
[*] At first, I thought that 3D character models in this game suck in comparison to 2D sprites from 999, but they grew on me by the end. [spoiler] Clover [/spoiler] has this creepy bug when she's always smiling. The general location design is not as entertaining as in 999, the puzzle rooms are good, though. In those rare moments 2D sprites do appear, I'm asking myself: “why don't use those more?”.
[*] There are long transitions when your character is going somewhere, AND THE GAME SHOWS YOU EVERY DOOR OPENING AND SOME OF THEM CLOSING (btw the doors it shows are wrong, considering the map), and it's incredibly frustrating. I get that it makes the player feel the size of that place, but it could've been achieved with less suffering for the player. Doors opening-closing shouldn't have been in the game.
[*] The puzzles are more interesting to solve because the game doesn't hold your hand (on hard mode at least). Some of them are really hard and make you feel super smart for solving them (and when the player character screams: “I solved the shit out of this puzzle!”, you feel just the same).
[*] The voice acting is good at emotional moments, but the usual dialogues feel kinda flat. The music is still great.
[*] The overall plot is more complex and fascinating, but less emotional. The characters feel not as fleshed-out and less interesting (they're still pretty good, though). If you look at it independently of 999, it's a great story with a lot of details and complex narrative, which unfolds at a good pace (depending on your choices).
[*] This may come off as I think that VLR is a bad game, when this is certainly not the case. In fact, I liked it a lot, I just expected much more. At the end, you feel like the game is great, but the overall experience was not as enjoyable as it could be.
[/list]

[i] At its core, it's a great game, but a lot of details take from experience [/i]

This is a game, where you put your life on the line

These are two of my favourite games of all time, 999 is worth the price alone but you get two fantastic games remastered for the price of one. They are both pretty simple, well made puzzle games with a lot of story in between. The puzzles aren't groundbreaking but they do require you to think which is honestly better than 99% of puzzles you get in video games nowadays. The multiple timelines and different endings are worked into the game so well and your choices really do matter, your actions actually have consequences and you feel it. The best part of the games is just going through all the different endings and seeing all the different outcomes. The writing is fantastic, there is an incredible amount of detail and depth when it comes to the storytelling. 

Sadly not many people are aware of these gems because they originally only came out on the Nintendo DS, but they really are fantastic games so I feel like I should recommend them. The English voice acting is truly wonderful, make sure you play with the English voices instead of the Japanese ones, you can tell the voice actors had so much fun making this. Its got a perfect balance of playfulness, humour and seriousness. Give it a shot.

"Do you know what the Updog Theory is Junpei? The Updog Theory originated when scientists put 2 individual test subjects in an enclosed room lets call them person A and person B, they were both assigned very specific roles, person A was told to just answer person B's question, now person B was told to say the word, updog. Now this experiment was meant to determine what parts of the brain were used to detect wordplay and jokes and what parts were for serious thoughts and concerns. As you may have guessed the experiment was a major success because person A answered the question by saying and I quote "whats updog" and so this produced shocking results, half of person A's brain determined it was wordplay and the other half showed concern for the question. Maybe the nonary game is an experiment to find out what parts of the game we consider it an actual game and what parts are concerned about our safety and urge to get out." - Lotus from 999.

In questo gioco visual novel, impersonate una delle 9 persone che si trova intrappolata all'interno di una nave. Il vostro obbiettivo sarà quello di fuggire da quel luogo, il problema è che non sarà facile. Incontrerete porte numerate in cui decidere da che parte andare per proseguire la storia e incontrare i vari puzzle all'interno di varie escape room. Si, ogni porta numerata vi porterà ad una o più stanze da dove poi fuggire, previo la risoluzione di vari puzzle all'interno delle stanze. Fortuna che, una volta finito il gioco c'e la sezione flowchart, dove poter partire da un bivio precedente e fare un'altra scelta, di norma scegliere un'altra porta. Invece il gioco, oltre alla montagna di dialoghi (in inglese) e enigmi (Logici) nelle varie stanze da affrontare, non ha altro. Il problema è che anche se la storia vi potrà prendere, specialmente una volta incamminatovi al vero finale, il gioco è per pochi, vuoi i dialoghi tutti in inglese, e vuoi  la tipologia di gioco, non è di azione, solo puzzle logici da superare per poter aprire la porta della stanza in cui siete rinchiusi. Le musiche sono adatte alla situazione. Ah, questo titolo da la possibilità di giocare a 2 due giochi della stessa tipologia: 999 e VRL (che non ho ancora iniziato.) La longevità è alta intorno alle 10-13 ore per il primo titolo ma solo perchè per vedere il vero finale bisogna rigiocarlo più e più volte fino a sbloccare 5 dei 6 finali e poi rigiocare, partendo dal bivio delle prime 2 porte e continuare una certa sequenza di bivi senza saltarli, per sbloccare il vero finale. ^^; Personalmente, do voto negativo, la lingua potrebbe dare un ostacolo per la comprensione della storia che non è così semplice come si pensa all'inizio. Buone le musiche e i puzzle piuttosto logici. Ma la mole di testo in inglese potrebbe far scoraggiare i più, graficamente è adatto allo scopo ma nulla di più, il fatto che non c'e un metodo più veloce di saltare testi già letti, a parte premere continuamente il tasto del joypad/mouse. ( Il forward non funziona tanto si sta il suo tempo a saltare i dialoghi. ) Mi fanno dare un voto negativo a tutto. Almeno per chi vuole un gioco più d'azione o chi non capisce tanto l'inglese. Per tutti gli altri specialmente agli appassionati di visual novel, potrebbe piacervi. Ma solo il fatto di dover saltare i dialoghi del bivio solo per cambiare scelta, anzichè darvi subito la schermata di scelta, potrebbe venirvi a noia. ^^;

Invece il secondo titolo, ha il pregio che si può saltare subito al bivio di scelte, graficamente hanno creato modelli 3d anzichè 2d del precedente titolo. Musiche carine, ma gli enigmi delle singole stanze sono piuttosto cervellotiche anche se logiche. Sono pochi gli enigmi logici si ma meno dispersivi in quanto la maggior parte di loro bisogna leggere i vari manuali per capire come affrontare gli enigmi. ^^; Quindi per certi versi il primo titolo è più fruibile del secondo riguardo gli enigmi che mettono in campo. ^^;
