Plot Twist: the game

The Nonary Games combines the first and second entries in the series. Escape Room Puzzles always keep the player entertained with their variety of mechanics. 

Story is the main selling point of the series though. a confusing beginning slowly but surely starts to make sense as the plot line begins to unravel. Story will keep the player hungry and intoxicated to learn more about the strange events that occupy throughout the games.

mix a little psuedo-science (i.e. like Sheldrake, morphogenetic telepathic fields, numerology), a bit of real science (i.e. prosopagnosia, base-9, digital root), a bit of mysticisms (i.e. Amun-Ra and the Egyptian Mummy's curse), the majesty of the titanic, a bit of Jigsaw/Saw style sociopathy, insert archetypal characters and the zeitgeist of early 2000's touch interface escape roomness and voila! a perfect storm of a wonderful video game, I played this on the ds in the early 2000's and i can't wait to finish this again because of the wonderful music, it's great to chill to it, forgotten most of the puzzles so it's nice to play again, but this version has quite well done voice acting which gives this game a new varnish to it. 
I'm very much looking forward to seeing how they resolve the final conceit which was a genius move in the ds days. I think this game pioneered the branching, string theory-ness and using this to tie perfectly into the narrative which has spawned games further to this series but also books like 9 1/2 lives of Evelyn Hardcastle.

Two games packed in one, 999 and Virtue's Last reward.

First things first, if you think that this review is too long, you probably shouldn’t play this game, as this game is filled with VN like storytelling with walls of texts with puzzles thrown out between the sections of the story.

I've said I'll update my review after I finish the VLR, so here it goes:

After playing the VLR, my score for this game is went up from 5 to 6/10 and not recommended to recommended. (I rate Not Rec. for 1-5 and Rec. for 6-10)

The reason being, the VLR mostly fixes the conversation issues of the first game and makes this bundle a worthwhile play. I would score it higher, if they didn't change some other things though.

First issue of the VLR is the unnecessary animations. You have to watch door opening animation and map animation every time it becomes just a time waster. I wish there was an option to skip those. Second issue is, story. While they have fixed the storytelling issue in VLR, I liked the 999's story better, this one is just sound bonkers, to me at least. Third issue is the character models. They changed from 2D sprite art to 3D models, which feels off. And they didn’t even use benefits of 3D models enough to make this change reasonable.

Puzzles and storytelling are improved. And even though I guessed why we were playing this Nonary Game in my first playtrough, it still had me interested in the story and the characters, (you will have to play like 20 different timelines to get this answered by the way). I felt like I should take notes and those notes really helped me later in the game.

So, here is a bundle of games that one has a good story, good puzzles but has bad storytelling and another game that has good puzzles, good storytelling, but somewhat bad story. I would say in the end that this games worth a play if you like puzzle solving and can tolerate the issues they have. I probably will play the next game as well.

Final notes: Alt+Tab issue of the 999 was solved in the VLR by the way, I couldn’t fit this any other place in my review :P

Below is the original review:

All of the conversations in the game are like this, it’s written like as if you are trying to tell a story to a 5 years old or a really dumb person. After a while I just started to mash the mouse button to advance through the text to finish the game.

Other than that, I did not encounter any major issues. The game was not buggy, or I did not encounter any glitches. Only issue that I encountered was, if I Alt+Tab the game, sometimes it stopped responding. And because there is no autosave, I lost some progress and had to play same parts again. But that was not a major issue.

Puzzles and general gameplay was good, that’s why it’s not rated below 5, good gameplay, bad storytelling.

In 2020, what can I say that hasn't already been said a dozen times over a dozen different ways? Two of the best visual novels I've ever had the fortune of playing. Every character is engaging. Every puzzle is intriguing. The story is rich and flavorful. It's all just so good. If you haven't played these games yet, and the idea of a fantastic story with some delightfully constructed puzzles is appealing, you need to have bought this game yesterday.

It's basically my favorite game of all time. This PC version has some nice additions to it (higher-res images, voice-acting, more robust "skip" options, time-line view to make it easy to explore all of the routes) and it's generally a good buy.

The only issue I have is with the first game. The first game was created with story-features that cannot be fully actualized without the original DS hardware. I won't get into spoilers or specifics but...

999's PC port simply lacks the impact of the original. I'm sure that the developers had a hell of a time trying to get around this limitation. Generally, they did a good job. However, the voice-acting creates a problem with the story (and eventually, they remove the voice-acting by the end of the game....for a good reason) and the original game has something happen on a hardware-level that cannot be replicated on PC. I do appreciate the effort, but this is not the best way to play 999. 

Virtues Last Reward works flawlessly here though and I would consider it to be the definitive experience.

[h1] You have been chosen to participate in a game! [/h1]

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games - переиздание двух первых частей трилогии игр, посвящённых Nonary Games - Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors и её продолжение, Virtue’s Last Reward. Описывать сюжет игр - удариться в ужаснейший пересказ и раскрытие всех спойлеров. 

Можно только сказать следующее: главный герой обеих игр похищен незнакомцем и помещён в замкнутое пространство в компании ещё восьми товарищей по несчастью. Им предстоит пройти серию головоломок и выбраться из ловушки. Можно идти по головам, принося в жертву своих напарников или вытащить всех на свободу. Можно просто сбежать или узнать истинные причины своего похищения и что связывает этих девятерых. Все персонажи хорошо прописаны. У каждого своя история, свои скелеты в шкафу и каждый может, под давлением обстоятельств, всадить нож в спину. Или заморочить голову себе и окружающим каким-нибудь мистическим или квазинаучным бредом - чем страшнее обстоятельства, тем бредовей мысли приходят в голову. Пока ищешь выход из очередной комнаты, тебе могут рассказать об альтернативной причине гибели Титаника или начальный курс квантовой физики. Или шутят и подкалывают друг друга, пытаясь разрядить обстановку.

Вот так болтают-болтают, а потом бах - и у тебя топор в спине. 

В первой игре 6 концовок. Сильно влияет, какой путь ты выберешь для побега, какие напарники у тебя будут и станешь ли ты им доверять. Что характерно, большая часть концовок - "плохие"... но в них не сомневаешься - понятно, почему тебя решили предать или убить. К хорошему же финалу вопросы имеются.

Во второй же части почти три десятка концовок. Тут уже огромное количество скрытых механизмов получения концовок, тайные ключи и игры с законами физики. 

Обе игры - неплохой аттракцион головоломок и сюжетных завихрений конспирологических историй. Мне понравилось, что далеко не весь бред, который несут персонажи в конце концов бредом так и остаётся. И большое количество сюжетных линий в финале сплетаются в единую канву. Не будь тут таких культурных завихрений мысли, получил бы ещё больше удовольствия...
...just play it...honestly don't know why this game isn't more popular than danganronpa.

Very good visual novel series, the two games included here are both 9/10, though personally I prefer Virtue’s Last Reward

First off, this purchase is the first two games in a trilogy which consists of 999, VLR, and Zero Time Dilemma. ZTD would need to be purchases separately. Obviously, you can try these to see if you like them before trying ZTD.

I will say now that this series has the most complex storyline I've seen since the Danganronpa and Phoenix Wright games; possibly even more than those games. 999 has a colorful cast of characters who don't trust one another, put into a game that will likely end very badly. It consists of still images of characters talking to you with mostly-voiced lines, the voice acting was enjoyable to me, and you go from reading/listening to dialog to choosing between 2 or 3 doors, then solving intricate puzzles inside those rooms, more dialog, choosing between 2 or 3 more doors, solving the puzzles in those, and repeat until you get a bad ending. Then you start over, mix up the doors you picked, solve the puzzles again, and get another bad ending, until you've seen all the endings, and can then go back through one of the paths, making correct decisions, and getting the good "true" ending.

Technically, the sequels to this game do very similar stuff, but 999 really rubbed me the wrong way in that you MUST complete each puzzle room to progress. Skipping the dialog only takes a couple of minutes or so between rooms for stuff you've heard before if you put it on the skip/fast-forward option, but the puzzle rooms are a real slog, and that's coming from someone who tends to enjoy puzzles in games. I'm not amazing at them, but they're generally pretty fun. The puzzles are fun the first time you solve them, but even if you use a walkthrough, you will have to solve most of the puzzle rooms 2 or 3 times each, and I just wanted the game to be over by the time I had seen half of the endings. I think you can bypass some content/endings and still get the "true" ending, but oh well.

Effectively, 999's story is pretty darn good when the puzzle rooms and duplicated dialog-skipping aren't bringing the game down to a slog. There are a couple of holes/contradictions near the end that nag at my enjoyment of the plot, but it's worth playing 999 to play VLR. I think some people may prefer 999 due to the sometimes-odd-looking character models in 3D, but VLR fixed everything that put me off on 999. In VLR, I *eagerly* explored each branch of the "flow" of events and different decisions. New dialog comes up very, VERY often even in similar circumstances in VLR, and you will regularly learn really interesting stuff on one path to a bad end that you never knew in another path, and - more importantly to me - changing between one decision and another is actually a part of the story! 

I can't explain how, exactly, without ruining the storyline and such, but there was a constant feel of PROGRESSION in the game. Getting every bad ending or coming across a "to be continued" was awesome. Although there is ultimately only one correct path to the "true" ending, the uh..."false" endings often matter and in an on-going basis that regularly comes up in the storyline. In 999, on the other hand, something like this only happens once, and I didn't really feel like I earned it so much as I was tortured for it. One thing I will complain about in VLR, though, is that the puzzles are - in my opinion - exponentially harder than the puzzles in 999 or even the third game in the series, ZTD. There were almost no puzzle rooms in VLR that I was able to complete without looking at a walkthrough at least once. And unless you play on "hard" you will miss out on some ending content, or so I've read.

In closing, I will say that 999 was kinda painful for me to play. I enjoyed the story in spite of the redundant puzzle rooms and no new dialog most of the time. VLR, however, was a thrill ride that I couldn't put down, as they say. It took me a few more hours to complete it, but I'm pretty sure I played it about 3X more often. I'm not exaggerating when I say that I had to convince myself to continue playing 999 a few times. VLR, however, I had a tough time stopping to go to bed or to eat. And yes, you definitely should play through 999 or else so much VLR (and ZTD if you play it) content won't make sense or won't have the proper emotional effect. These stories really are pretty great. Oh, and just grimace through some of the pretentious pseudo-science and philosophy dialog. Some of it's good, and some of it made me roll my eyes pretty hard.

[h1]Spoiler Free Review[/h1]

I don't typically play a lot of visual novel games, but what attracted me to 999 back when I first played it on DS was the puzzle/escape room aspect of the game.  I first played the DS version in 2014.  I completed the PC version today (10/17/2020).

[b]Story[/b]
The story is eerie, mysterious, charming, and touching all at the same time.  I especially enjoyed the science fiction lore elements that are presented so realistically that it made me question whether some things that were presented in the game are indeed true.  This background information was what kept me so engaged in the story.  I didn't understand where it was all heading until towards the ending when more information is revealed and you are able to slowly piece together some answers to the questions presented throughout the narrative.  That information is important to understanding the story and sucked me as a person who is interested in science fiction.  The characters all have their own distinct personalities and motivations many of which are kept secret and slowly uncovered throughout the story.  You learn more bout each character throughout the story.  It will take multiple completions to unlock the story behind each character.  There are a fair amount of surprises for each character.


[b]Puzzles[/b]
The puzzles were interesting, but weren't a major selling point as I had expected.  My favorite puzzle in the game was the final puzzle in the DS version, and it was replaced in the PC version in order to adapt the game to not having dual screens and a touch screen even though players have access to a mouse.  I have to admit that I am unhappy with the changes to the puzzle.  The emotional impact and the presentation of the final puzzle in the first game was spectacular, and much of that was lost when switching to the PC version of the puzzle.  In general the DS version of the puzzles is the best way to experience the puzzles because the game was originally designed for dual screens.  I feel like that aspect did not translate well to PC.  I didn't have a second screen to take notes or a calculator that I could whip out to crunch some numbers.  I found myself having to memorize information for a puzzle from one menu, close that menu, and then go into the puzzle and input the information all at once and hope that I remembered it correctly.  Every time I exited a puzzle to check the information files, they player would receive a slight hint from others.  It was frustrating to unintentionally receive hints when I wanted to try to solve the puzzles without help.  There is also a hint button at the top of many of the puzzle screens.  In some cases, it may have been impossible to solve without the hint button due to the changes that occurred when switching from two screens to one screen.  Overall, the puzzles were so-so in my opinion.  It did feel satisfying to complete some of the tougher ones that required some thinking, but the experience was noticeably better on the DS version.


[b]Controls[/b]
The basics are pretty simple.  You just point with your mouse and click on something.  Some of the controls are not so clear.  There is a story branch menu to keep track of your progress and decisions throughout your play throughs.  This was very confusing for me to figure out, but essential for unlocking some of the endings.  I struggled navigating this for quite some time trying to figure out why I couldn't unlock certain endings.  

[b]Sound[/b]
I enjoyed the voice acting in the PC version.  It was great getting to hear the emotions of the characters as the cursed, harassed each other, flirted, and made innuendos.  I found my self laughing out loud at some of their comments.

As a visual novel, the main draw will be the story.  999's story does not disappoint.  Exploring the rooms, uncovering the lore needed to solve the puzzles was enjoyable, but was frustrating at times due to the change in format from two screens on the DS to one screen on PC.  The changing of the final puzzle was a disappointment, and took away from the climax of the game, in my opinion, but I still recommend this game.  It was a wonderful journey.  

I will update this review after I Virtue's Last Reward.

For anyone who's seeing this, please don't hesitate to buy this game. The game may seems old but it is definitely worth your time. This game is very unique and one of the kind. It is truly one of the masterpieces itself. 
It left quite a huge impression to me after playing it a few years ago. It is also one of the games that kept me bamboozled throughout the whole game. When you thought you know how the game gonna to end, that is the moment you are gonna to get mindfucked by those plot twists. [h1] When Jigsaw plays math
★★★★☆ -  9.5 / 10[/h1]
[b][i]Zero Escape : The Nonary Games[/i] [/b]is divided into two games:  [i]Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors[/i] (999) and [i]Virtue’s Last Reward[/i] (VLR).

[b]Characters / plot [/b] 
At first, both games tend to follow similar patterns: People were abducted by someone named Zero; The prisioners wear life-threatering bracelets that force them make part of a twisted game (The Nonary Game); There's an unique way out (Door number 9).Characters may lower to their worst side in order to survive or fulfill personal goals, so the evil vs good dichotomy is not obvious. Later you'll find out that The Nonary Game is way beyond a psychological playing - It carries a very deep plot full of surprises. 
Characters concepts are great, all of them got complex and misterious backgrounds. Unlike horror cliches, the worthless who dies first is almost nonexistent. Each one matters even though the superficial appearance says otherwise. 

[b] Visual / sound content [/b] 
In 999, all characters are 2D drawn and partially animated (VN sprites), fitting the dialogue context decently, the CGs aren't rich in details though very well drawn. In VLR, there’s a mixture of 2D and 3D CGs. The 2D is still high quality (except for minor details) as 999’s, on the other hand the 3D got some downgrading points, like the static scenes, the characters' textures and rendering slighty drop in quality when comparated to animated models at visual novel mode. The animation itself is fine though doesn't always match character's mood properly.
On the other hand, most of voice acting is high quality (I played english version), special rewards to Junpei’s (999 main character) and Zero III (VLR).
The two titles share sounding similarities. The soundtracks are so peculiar and enjoyable to listen to and fit gameplay atmosphere perfectly.

[b] Gameplay [/b] 
The gameplay is a pretty mixture of escape room and visual novel genres. The important choices for both games are based on what door you pick and whose you enter with.The routes and endings archieved are precisely organized in flow chart, unlike several VNs there’s no need to save every single choice made. In order to unlock the real ending, you must play all routes.
The escape room’s puzzles got a pretty balanced difficulty: it may take longer if you don’t explore the room properly, but it’s not considered a headache. The 999's puzzles are easier than expected, because there's always someone helpfull in the rooms giving some solving hints. In VLR game the puzzles are okay to solve even on hard setting. 
The game time is pretty extended, at least for me, It took me 35 hours in 999 and 60 hours in VLR.

[b]Cost x Experience[/b]
The [i]Zero Escape[/i] series are developed and distributed by [I]Spike Chunsoft[/i], the ones behind of popular VN titles like [I]Dangaronpa[/I]. This Steam version is cheap for a [i]2 in 1 [/i] pack that will give you a bunch of hours of gameplay content, featuring good visuals, great audio work and rich mind blowing story. It definitely worth the $$.

[b][Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors][/b]

Ya sólo por ''[i]Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors[/i]'' merece totalmente la pena. 

Nota: Recomiendo poner el juego en modo novela, en vez de adv.
Nota: El juego no está en español. 

[h1]APARTADO TÉCNICO[/h1]
El juego está en inglés, y personalmente recomiendo poner las voces en japonés, ya que el doblaje me parece el mejor.

Es una versión mejorada de la versión de [i]Nintendo DS[/i] y eso se nota. Las ilustraciones tienen su propio encanto y te adaptas enseguida, la banda sonora es muy buena y saben qué melodía encaja mejor dependiendo de la situación en la que estés, con lo cual ayuda a que te adentres más en la historia.

Los controles pueden hacerse un poquito liosos si es tu primera novela visual, pero a la que avances un poquito ya te acostumbras y no se te hace nada pesado, al fin y al cabo no tiene unas mecánicas complejas.

No he encontrado ningún tipo de bug, aunque me gustaría decir que el apartado donde guardas las partidas puede liarte un poco, ya que al guardar, a no ser que finalices una de las varias rutas que puedes hacer, el icono no cambiará y tendrás que recordar el slot que usaste para guardar, aunque abajo te saldrá la parte en la que estás. Aparte de esto, a nivel técnico el juego me parece muy bien hecho, teniendo en cuenta el género que es.

[h1]TRAMA[/h1]
La trama es el punto fuerte de las novelas visuales, y este no iba a ser menos. La historia es atrapante desde el principio, dónde empiezas solo en una sala que está hundiéndose y necesitas resolver el puzzle que se te presenta para poder salir y finalmente empezar, oficialmente, lo que son los Nonary Games.

Tienes varias rutas a tu disposición, como en casi todas las novelas visuales, que pueden llevarte a hasta 6 tipos de finales distintos. Voy a decir, de entrada, que el juego tiene un final verdadero que necesita otro final para desbloquearlo. Sin ese final verdadero te vas a sentir perdido en cuanto a la historia, ya que es esencial para poder jugar a la próxima entrega de la saga, la cual está añadida en este mismo pack ([i]Virtue's Last Reward[/i]). Tienes guías por internet de cómo conseguir todos los finales, pero te recomiendo encarecidamente que al menos la primera vez que juegues lo hagas a ciegas.

Los personajes están bien elaborados y son complejos e interesantes, y cada uno te mostrará parte de su historia, hasta que poco a poco, estos junto con la historia te harán entender exactamente qué está pasando y qué son los Nonary Games. Es probable que la historia, una vez llegues al final verdadero, te impresione y te den ganas de saber más y más, porque desde luego la historia es MUY atrapante y satisfactoria. Una genialidad.

Recomiendo tener un bolígrafo, un papel y una calculadora para tener una mejor experiencia. Una de las mejores cosas de este juego es conspirar y teorizas en el transcurso del juego. En mi caso lo jugué, además, con otra persona, lo cual fue muy enriquecedor por parte de ambas, aunque solo se disfruta mucho también. Depende de cómo te guste jugar a este tipo de juegos. ^^

[h1]DIFICULTAD[/h1]
La dificultad recae exclusivamente en los puzzles que hay a los largos de las diferentes rutas. Hay de todo, pero en general diría que la dificultad, basándome en mi experiencia, ronda entre media-alta. Hay unos puzzles que son bastante sencillos de resolver, ya que tienes varias pistas, pero en cambio hay otros puzzles que pueden dar dolores de cabeza si no te gustan muchos los números. Ahí lo dejo.

A pesar de la dificultad media-alta que le pongo, son muy disfrutables todos y cada uno de ellos, ya que en medio de estos puzzles también puedes desbloquear diálogos muy interesantes, y no sientes que estás resolviendo simplemente un puzzle para poder avanzar.

[h1]CONCLUSIÓN[/h1]
Las novelas visuales no son un género muy popular en occidente, y este juego en concreto no está en español. Aun así, si tienes dudas y sabes un mínimo de inglés, te recomiendo mucho que al menos pruebes este juego, porque es toda una experiencia y un soplo de aire fresco.

Si te gustan las historias intensas y toleras los puzzles, o hasta te gustan, como a mí, estoy segura de que este juego te va a encantar. Es una de las mejores experiencias que he tenido con un videojuego, sin duda.

[b]VERDICT[/b] : An excellent SciFi Thriller visual novel, taking advantage of video game as a medium to tell an engaging story.

TL;DR: These games are awesome, and if you like story-based games you should definitely check these out. You also get more than 40 hours of gameplay for 25 euros, which i see as a great deal. 

INTRODUCTION
First of all, i HIGHLY recommend this title, especially if you like mysteries and a focus on storytelling. Also, this title costs 25 euro, but provides AT LEAST 40 hours of gameplay, and considering how much i like these games, i think that's a crazy good deal.

This title actually contains two games, "999" and its sequel "Virtue's last reward". This is a very good pc port of the games (it adds both english voice actors, updated graphics, and other cool features), which were originally released on the ds and 3ds. I played both of them on the 3ds years ago, and they were, and still are, FUCKING GREAT!

GAMEPLAY
Both of these games are visual novels, though they do also contain a lot of interactive escape rooms, and a lot of choices that you as the player can make which heavily impacts the story. Therefore, the game is not just about reading, even though you will also be doing that a lot. 

STORY
The escape rooms are fun, but what makes these games so great is the story. The only thing i will reveal about it, is that both of these games are about 9 people (different people in each one) who are kidnapped and forced to play a dangerous game in order to escape. IF YOU THINK THIS SOUNDS INTERESTING, PLEASE JUST BUY IT, INSTEAD OF READING MORE ABOUT THE STORY! DON'T WATCH THE TRAILER OR ANYTHING ELSE. I think the less you know about these games when you buy them, the better they are. The reason for this is, that there are a lot twists and revelations in these games, which work great when they catch you off-guard.

THE GAMES
*Mildly spoilery stuff begins here*
"999" is the first game in the series and one of the two games included in this title. It is about 1/3 the length of the second game, which is cool, since it doesn't drag out its own story more than necessary this way. Imo it's not overly complex, and tells a compelling story, that will leave you guessing throughout. The characters are also all prety memorable, though some are of course cooler than others. It's a solid and original game all in all. 7.5/10

"Virtue's last reward" is the second game in the series, and the other game included in this title. Personally, i think it's amazing. It expands on some of the things introduced in the first game, but also brings a lot of new stuff to the table. It is a lot more ambitious than the first game, but i really think they manage to pull it all off. Imo the ending is one of the best endings i have ever seen in a video game. I think this because they manage to perfectly bring together all the different mysteries they introduce, and tie it all together in a way that you could have never seen coming, without making you feel cheated. They also manage to hype up the third game so much during this ending. The game is more complex than the other game, but i just think that makes it even better. The only drawbacks to this game is that it can feel A BIT repetitive at times, probably due to it being longer than the first, but it usually manages to introduce something new and exciting before you become bored. The characters here are also a mixed bunch. Most of them are more fleshed out than the characters in the first one, which is also due to the longer play time of this game. This makes some of them very interesting, but i do still think that A FEW of them are just plain unlikable most of the time. Basically, some of them are better than in "999", some of them are worse than in "999". All in all, the many good parts of this game outshines the few bad parts, and as i said, the ending is just fantastic. It is not a perfect game, but it's pretty damn close. 9/10 

The third and final game in the series, "Zero Time Dilemma", is also on steam, but make sure to complete the other two games before you check out that one. The third one is considered by many to be the worst out of the three, and i will admit it has several differences from the others. I liked it, even though it is a bit of a dissapointing ending to the trilogy. EVEN IF YOU DON'T PLAY THE THIRD ONE, I WOULD STILL RECOMMEND YOU TO PLAY THE FIRST TWO THOUGH! Hell, some would probably recommend you to not play the third game at all, and just think about a fulfilling ending yourself. Personally, I would recommend you play it if you liked the overall story up untill the third game, but that's up to you though! 

CONCLUSION
Imo you could buy this title, with its price tag, for the second game alone, but the first game is also really good (and not too long) and will make you appreciate the second game even more when you play it. I think i have written enough to describe what i feel for these games, but just to conclude this review: The two games in this title are great entertainment, especially the second one, and its cheap price makes it all the more worth it to buy it.

999: I would have no aversions paying the full price just for this game. Beyond phenomenal. I would recommend it to pretty much anyone who isn't totally averse to doing some reading.
 
Virtue's Last Reward: There goes everything that made 999 good. There's some cool stuff here, but it really doesn't live up to 999. I heavily dislike this game, but I am in the minority on that. Not all that bad after seeing how it all connects to Zero Time Dilemma, though.

999 is one of my favourite games of all time. If 100%ing a game is something you're interested in, it is necessary for playing it. It has great characters, a great standalone plot, and decent puzzles. There is some repetition, but it's not too bad if you remember what to do in the puzzles, just be ready to click for a few minutes at the beginning of every run.

Virtue's Last Reward is good. The animation is a bit jarring at first, the characters are still good and the repetition isn't as bad due to the jump feature. The game expands on the first and is kind of a lead in to the third. The puzzles are a bit weird, but still relatively okay, I just wish I could rotate the camera faster. You can feel that this is kind of a forced sequel, but for that it's decent.

Id say this game is worth it just for 999. If you like it and want more then continue the to the second and third.

Visual Novels, Escape Rooms, Murder Mysteries? SIGN. ME. UP. 

A few years back I had watched someone play a piece of the first game (999) on Youtube, and I was hooked. The plot goes in such interesting and weird directions, and that makes you stop and really think about stuff on a philosophical standpoint. The characters in the first game were expressive, albeit a bit corny with their dialogue on the English dub. Puzzles were unique and actually tied into the plot and reasoning behind the story. The true ending left me jaw dropped, and my emotions were shook to the core on one of the other dramatic endings. You'll have to see how emotionally charged they really were.

Second game (Virtue's Last Reward) threw a curve ball at us. The 3d models instead of 2d sprites was not my preference, but it was tolerable. I typically prefer my visual novels with 2d sprites, but the characters had some intrigue to them. The puzzles ramped up difficulty A LOT MORE, but there was an introduction to an easy mode where characters aid you on your attempts at getting through all the routes. The plot itself is a bit twisty turvy, but the true ending has such a twist that I didn't see coming AT ALL. The game itself was a rough gem, but it still shone through.

All in all, this isn't a game style for everyone, but it's one of my favorites of the moment. Check it out if you want to get your brain flipped on its end!

To give context to this review, I have played these games in every available Western version to date, except for the mobile app ports.

The PC version of 999 & VLR has come out really well. The resolution works excellently to highlight the beauty of 999's art, although it also ends up making the weaker implementation of VLR's 3D models more noticeable. The PC controls have been implemented relatively well, though there were one of two aspects which weren't necessarily intuitive (flipping between inventory items without going into the invetory screen comes to mind. However, as the game is able to switch seamlessly between a controller input and a mouse = keyboard input, it's easy enough to use both in combination to get the best of both worlds should you want.

One disappointment I have with the PC implementation is that the game in Borderless or Fullscreen modes is locked to the primary monitor and will not change (even with Windows key shortcuts that normally move windows around). This is a real disappointment as I use a dual screen setup and often switch games back and forth between them.

This release features the same achievements as the PS4 port, and even uses the same bronze-silver-gold-platinum trophy colours.

In terms of story, I have a soft spot for this series. Zero Escape is one of my favourite franchises of all time, and I am so happy it received a PC release. If you want challenging yet solvable escape room puzzles, and a branching story which incorporates its flow chart system into the lore itself, then you will not be disappointed. These games also do not shy away from character death, suicidal themes and some gore (though any major gory moments are off-camera). The dialogue and characterisation in this game I have found to be a little like Marmite: you either love it or hate it. Characters will often go off on a tangent about some obscure event or theory that seems totally out of place at the time (but all of which of course foreshadow the later plot reveals), sometimes in the middle of life-or-death escape rooms. Those who like this style and enjoy using these moments as plot clues will love this, but others do find it sucks them out of the moment and irritates them.

Like the PS4 port, this PC release combines the first two games of the trilogy together: 999 (Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors) and Virtue's Last Reward. 999 notably originally released for the Nintendo DS, and made use of its dual screen format for a major plot twist. This release has included the same solution as the PS4 version, which switches 'modes' between Adventure and Novel- each representing one of the original DS screens. While VLR did have a 3DS release, it was also originally released on the PS Vita at the same time, and so no changes were acquired for a single-screen port on PS4 or PC.

One touch I do particularly like about this PC release is the option in the Nonary Games menu (where you can configure options (display, etc.) and select which game to play) to change the button prompt displays between Mouse + Keyboard, Dualshock (PS4 controller) or 'Gamepad' - which is an Xbox One controller. The inclusion of the Xbox controller button prompts is a very nice touch which I was not expecting and for which I am incredibly appreciative.

Overall, I highly recommend this release for both series fans and for anyone who enjoys puzzle games, Japanese storytelling, escape rooms and death-game games.

This got its hooks in me fairly quick. Playing 999 for the first time in Japanese with English subs was a lot of fun. The cool art style and typical anime personality tropes made it pretty easy to get immersed in the story. The puzzles were challenging but for the most part, very solvable with no real sticking points. The back and forth nature of the plot flow took some getting used to but once I figured it out, it was amazing.

I was slightly less impressed at first with VLR. The shift in art style was initially a little jarring and took some time to warm up to. The lack of voice acting for the main character was an odd choice too, coming from the first game where the protagonist is voiced. However, that all fades away once you actually get playing. Some of the puzzles are much harder and at least once I had to go look up what to do because it wasn't even remotely obvious (Exiting the PEC). The branching mechanics go one step further. The story takes crazy turns when you least expect it. It's so compelling that when I hit my first dead end I was immediately leaping back to the first decision point, full of plans of what I wanted to do different but even then it keeps surprising me. I also love the Zero rabbit. :D I'm a big fan of comedy villains with sinister undertones and the rabbit nails it.

All together, the experience is amazing, like a combination of the mechanics of The Crystal Maze with the kind of bizarre storyline you get in an anime. This is one of those times when I'd love to wipe my mind and go at it again just for that experience.

"Ничего не понял, но очень интересно" (с)

Эта, слегка измененная ради цивильности обзора, цитата описывает 90% моего опыта с этой серией игр. Остальными 10% были понимание и последующее взрывание мозга от хитросплетений сюжета, ибо он тут редкой степени закрученности. Базовый концепт легче всего сравнить с фильмами "Пила", но с меньшим упором на ужас и жестокость, и с большим - на загадку. При этом, игры дают ровно столько информации, чтобы можно было строить теории о дальнейшем сюжете и мотивах персонажей, но угадать что происходит на самом деле практически невозможно. Да что уж там, даже когда все карты уже выложены на стол - чтобы собрать полную картину придется нехило пораскинуть мозгами.

Геймплейно же каждая игра разделяется на 2 жанра: визуальную новеллу и пазловый квест, которые очень хорошо друг друга дополняют, не давая игроку потерять интерес. Стоит отметить, что в первой игре большинство головоломок проблем не доставили, а вот во второй все-таки пришлось взять ручку с бумажкой, ибо в уме их делать уже было сложновато. Но, благо, для тех, кто не хочет заморачиваться, есть легкий режим, где игроку подсказывают что делать, если тот упрется в стену. Ну а визуально-новельная часть, ожидаемо, дает нелинейную историю аля интерактивное кино.

Возможно это из-за того, что я ни разу до этого не играл в визуальные новеллы, но то, как эти игры практически полностью состоят из концентрированного сюжета, чувствовалось глотком свежего воздуха по сравнению с тем, во что я обычно играю. Годный и довольно компактный опыт, который на постоянной основе интересен, если вы устали от гринда в очередной сессионке или ожидания следующей сюжетной подачки в очередной рпг, но нет настроения на что-то вроде книги.

Если моё описание вас зацепило, то смело берите, вас как минимум ждет незабываемый опыт, это я гарантирую.

P.S: Хоть эта серия игр и от тех же Spike Chunsoft, что и довольно известная Danganronpa, Zero Escape не снискала такой большой славы и русификатора на первые 2 игры (коими и являются Nonary Games) до сих пор нет, так что нужно будет либо знание инглиша, либо желание лезть в переводчик.

The Nonary Games es un paquete que comprende las dos primeras entregas de la trilogía llamada Zero Escape, así que lo justo es analizarlos por separado. Podemos decir que tienen en común que pertenecen al mismo género y su jugabilidad es muy similar salvando las diferencias en el estilo artístico(novela visual y puzzles). Recomiendo estos juegos a cualquiera que disfrute tanto de las novelas visuales como de los puzzles tipo "escape-room" ya que esta última es la mecánica principal en torno a la que giran ambos títulos.

[b]999(Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Hours)[/b] es un juego que fué lanzado originalmente para la Nintendo DS. Aquí tenemos un remaster con las mejoras pertinentes para que no se vea con píxeles como puños cuando jugamos a resulución Full HD, aparte de eso, se han añadido voces en inglés y japonés. 
En cuanto a la historia, consiste en que encarnamos a un joven que es secuestrado y se despierta en un barco junto a otras 8 personas. Son obligados a superar una serie de puzzles y a seguir una serie de reglas, o morirán. No quiero contar mucho más al respecto, porque la historia creo que merece la pena. Lo más interesante del juego, es que aunque te permite seguir varios caminos durante la historia y tiene varios finales, hasta que no has completado todos los finales no consigues el "final auténtico". Esto, que puede parecer que no es demasiado novedoso, pues te alucina ya que las diferentes "lineas temporales" están relacionadas y lo que hagas en una termina influyendo en otra. Personalmente he encontrado esto muy disfrutable.

[b]Virtue's Last Reward[/b] La segunda entrega de la trilogía, similar en cuanto a jugabilidad a la primera fue lanzada para la siguiente generación de la portátil de Nintendo, la 3DS. En este caso tenemos una propuesta que usa los elementos que gustaron de la primera y los lleva más allá. Los gráficos se actualizan ahora totalmente y tenemos personajes y entornos en 3D. Hay más personajes, la historia que está relacionada con la primera parte de algún modo es mucho más compleja(demasiado en algunos puntos) y hay muchísimos más caminos que recorrer hasta el punto que este juego dura el doble más o menos que la primera entrega(si quieres completar ambas entregas al 100%).

First things first, this game is a mind****

Well, technically games, if it wasnt obvious this is both the original 999 and its sequel Virtues Last Reward. 999 is retextured and upgraded from its original ds version, and it honestly looks great. 

I enjoyed both of these games completely, and  I recommend them for anyone who enjoys a great story with time travel. The gameplay consists heavily of visual novel cliche, peppered with escape rooms and a smattering of choice and consequence. The real twist is both games mulitude of endings, which all tie into eachother in just ridiculous ways. To get the full story and understand whats really happening, you HAVE to go through every ending. Which is both a slog and entertaining.

Overall, the endgame for both games were entirely worth it, and the road there is a hell of a trip. If you like a good story and mystery I highly suggest giving these a playthrough.

If you are wondering whether there are any good visual novel type games, here it is. The puzzles are fun and really intuitive, they all flow really well with only one or two nitpicks I could make in either game. The characters are all enjoyable and diverse, the dialogue is great and I don't mind talking to literally everyone. Play this game, tell your friends to play, play any of the other games made by this studio.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games contêm dois jogos da franquia Zero Escape: Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors, e a sequência Virtue's Last Reward.

[h1] 999 [/h1]
Basicamente, 9 pessoas foram sequestradas e estão sendo forçadas a jogar um jogo. Eles têm de achar a porta com o número 9 para poderem escapar.
O motivo real pela qual eles estão sendo forçados a jogar esse jogo vai ser explicado durante a gameplay. O backstory dos personagens também vão ser explicados.
Também há o flowchart que você pode usar para escolher diferentes caminhos (há múltiplos finais e eu recomendo você conseguir todos para entender a história 100%).
Você pode escolher entre o modo Visual Novel e o modo Adventure. Um problema que eu tenho com essa versão remasterizada é que o jogo raramente troca entre esses dois modos. O Visual Novel é muito importante e eu recomendo que você escolha esse modo pra entender mais a história.
Os puzzles não são tão difíceis e na maior parte do tempo são divertidos de se fazer.

Em conclusão, 999 é um ótimo jogo que não é muito conhecido, mas que deveria ser pela sua história perfeita.
10/10

[h1] Virtue's Last Reward [/h1]
Essa é a sequência de 999. Novamente, 9 pessoas foram sequestradas e estão sendo forçadas a jogar um jogo, mas com diferenças, como o método de como eles podem escapar.
Os puzzles são muito mais difíceis do que os do 999, e o jogo é mais longo (50+ horas com todos os finais). A história também é mais detalhada com vários plot twists.
Também tem mais finais, e novamente recomendo você conseguir todos se quiser entender mais a história (sim, até os Game Overs).
Alguns caminhos no flowchart vão ficar bloqueados e você tem de conseguir outro final pra poder continuar a história. Também há uns caminhos que precisam de uma senha que só podem ser conseguidos por meio de outros finais, então se você não sabe a senha, recomendo que você faça outro caminho e não pesquise a resposta na internet. Se algum personagem te dizer alguma senha, anote em algum lugar, porque o jogo não vai memorizar.

Esse é o meu jogo favorito de toda a franquia, por causa da história mais detalhada, personagens melhores e puzzles mais desafiadores.
10/10

Absolutely phenomenal mystery games with the mind-blowing plot twists that Uchikoshi is known for. In all my years of reading mystery novels and playing visual novels I have never encountered anything quite like the Zero Escape games, both in the themes that they deal with, and in their absolutely mind-bending narrative structure. These games exemplify what video games as a storytelling medium can do that other forms can't: they provide interactive means of telling extremely complex and immersive stories. I'm not kidding about the complex part. The plot threads of these games tangle in on one another, loop around, then loop back to create absolutely colossal mysteries that you must pick apart, one ending at a time. You are constantly learning new information, using this information to solve previous mysteries, only to run into more mysteries, etc etc. Buy these games. Play them. Let them absorb you into their dark and strange world.

(Reviewing after completing the first game and not starting the second)

Changed my mind on this one.  I was borderline ready to quit when I got to a repetitive element of the gameplay and thought I had to keep slogging through content I'd already seen before.  Then I looked up how to properly use the controls for the flowchart and the dialog, and learned that you can zoom in to specific scenes you may have missed in prior rooms (the pink rooms on the chart), and fast-forward through dialog you've seen before, and suddenly it wasn't repetitive at all.

Ended up finding the story decently interesting, even though I leaned hard on walkthroughs for several of the puzzles because I didn't have the patience for all the math and hidden-object hunting and plotting a path through the flowchart. The game's not a bad choice if you don't mind a degree of violence happening in your story outside your control and you enjoy some "like, woah, man" kind of flavor to your speculative fiction.

Note: there is some representation of neurodivergence & disablity here and part of it seems okay but one or two elements of it are Not Ideal.

Well, what can I say about about this set? First off, it's not one game: it's two, like it says on the tin. It's also... kind of complicated. I'll tackle each game on its own, but I'll say off the bat that I recommend this collection.

Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors is arguably the stronger of the two games included. As a game, it is *miles* above VLR, with puzzles that feel more fair and more fun than those in VLR, for the most part. I only turned to a walkthrough twice, first because I was dumb and didn't look somewhere I thought I'd look so I missed a clue, second time because it turns out of you choose exactly the wrong route, you don't get the proper signposting that makes it possible to work out the solution to the tile puzzle in the cells on your own. That's... not good, but I wouldn't say it's a dealbreaker: Most of the puzzles are fair and well designed, and while a few old classics appear later (magic square, a rather nasty sokoban puzzle that thankfully has a mechanic to reduce the difficulty if you start to get frustrated, and a few other gems straight out of your favorite puzzle book or physical set), the game is mostly good. The puzzles collectively help to signpost the big twist ending and the puzzle rooms help give you insights into the characters who are in them with you. It's already become one of my favorite visual novels I've played and while the puzzle design isn't at the level of the truly great, it was never a frustration either.

There is the question, however, of whether this is the best way to play 999. It's definitely the *easiest* way to play 999 (in more ways than one: getting the DS version means buying a used copy, emulating, or shelling out for an R4 so you can pirate it...), but is it the best version of the game? I've technically never played the DS version, but what I know about it means I can tell you that in some ways, yes, it is better: the DS version of 999 uses the dual screens in a number of novel ways to progress the plot and make the Big Twist just that much more of a big deal (basically there's no switch between adventure mode and novel mode: they're both on at all times, just on separate screens), and a different final puzzle that I personally think might be better (keep in mind I have yet to play it). However, the DS lacks a flow screen. That means if you want to play through another route, you may find yourself solving the same puzzles again, and mashing frantically through dialogue you've seen before. This also means that there's more of a puzzle to finding the true ending, which I might take issue with normally, but the decision junctions in 999 are fairly few and it's quite so much blind groping to get the right ending that I think it would be overly frustrating. In fact, I'm a little disappointed at the degree to which the flow screen shows you what to do here: I think I'd have enjoyed figuring it out for myself. 

That flow screen and the degree to which it shows you what to do, however, was backported from Virtue's Last Reward, where the larger story and sheer explosion of options makes it necessary, as does the fundamental conceit. What is that conceit? Spoilers. You'll find out when you play. 

Virtue's Last Reward is a massive leap forward from 999 and also a giant step back. Gone are the beautiful 2D sprites, replaced with ugly 3D models, and the environments are less distinctive and appealing as well.  The puzzle design is falling back on classics (or twists on them) a lot more often, and is often hard because of combinatorial explosion with no clear way to eliminate possibilities (as classic puzzles often are). Maybe you enjoy solving that sort of thing, but I don't. Even the non-classics are hard in a way I don't think is necessarily good and I feel like the design is just generally maybe a bit off there.

Buuuut, this is made up for by some absolutely stellar writing. I suffered through VLR's bad puzzle design, occasionally googling answers as I went, because that writing was just so very good. The characters get better development, the writing is as nail-biting as ever and the plot is totally and utterly off the wall but I still believed every second of it. For some people, VLR might be too much: too wanky, too complex, too big, whatever. But I found it very satisfying, even if as a game it was definitely weaker than 999.

Neither 999 nor VLR are perfect, but both are excellent and I highly recommend them.

Puzzle is quite ok; easy and clear, but the story and characters are very underdeveloped.

The characters are very unrelatable. Junpei and Akane are childhood friends, first love, blablabla and they may have feeling left for each other, I get that. But they are adults now, in college and working (Junpei mentioned), they never saw each other for like 10 years or so. Yet Junpei gets so desperate to protect Akane, even willing to sacrifice his and others lives to save her, and trusts her so much without a reason. What made him go so crazy about her all of a sudden? He didn't even realize it was her right away when he first met her again, and there seems nothing that special about their childhood memory... But like, okay, I do think there wasn't enough of explanation or development shown for their relationship, but some people don't have reason all the time, esp when it's about love. But how about other people? Others didn't show relatable reaction at all either. The reason Akane did all this is selfish. Maybe Ace and ninth man and Junpei were meant to come for revenge and her rescue. But what about Seven? He is her and her brother's life savior and what she returns to him is this? And what about Lotus? She really didn't have any reason to deserve such game. She is rather unrelated to the past incident. Only thing that connects her to the past incident is that her children were also victims of that incident... and why is Akane making their poor mother suffer the same thing? What she do to them cannot be justified. Yet no one even mentions the unfairness of this game or criticizes her or even get slightly mad at her for making them go through such thing, which makes no sense. Who would not get mad at someone who put them into a life-or-death game? Well! Characters in this game do! Why? Who knows! I have nothing personally against revenge plots, evil characters, etc, but no single victim acting or speaking against main villains' malicious actions is just really unrelatable and strange to the point the whole thing's just creepy. Feels like they are just all one person speaking using different characters' mouths as no one is against each other (even when they kill you or put your life at stake).

刚刚趁 Steam 打折通关了著名的 999，感觉它至少可以进入我心目中最值得推荐给别人的文字解谜游戏的前五，原因如下：

1. 游戏进入之后非常友好，直接从一个谜题开始，不啰嗦。谜题难度不高，至少前三个迷宫都会给人一种「凭着自己的智慧一定走完全程」的感觉，而且实际玩下来也确实如此，即使不是非常擅长解谜的人也可以轻松搞定这个游戏中的谜题。

2. 游戏的主线基于一个根植于玩家心中的「密室逃生」的固有观念，游戏中的谜题在不断强化玩家这个观念的同时，它的情节却在不停地通过进程推进，在打破这个观念，以至于玩家会逐渐感觉到「剧情是本体，谜题只是这个游戏的赠品」。第一次通关（我是潜水艇结局）之后，大概没有人会相信这是所谓「真结局」，回到之前的选择枝（Steam 版可以直接选择，不用反复开多周目了）重新开始游戏几乎是一个必选项。

3. 这是一个即使关掉游戏窗口，还会让玩家在脑子里反复思考情节和关联的游戏。不同结局之间是有关联的，即使打通真结局，再反过来看其他结局，你依然可以得到更多的信息。这种类似于「剧本杀复盘」的工作虽然需要玩家独立完成，但对于享受情节的人来说真的很爽！

打算缓几天，继续开「善人死亡」。

Well, now that I've played this game for 99 hours, I guess it's time to leave a review, isn't it?  This review is spoiler-free.

The Zero Escape series is a science fiction visual novel, combined with escape room style gameplay.  It provides many different branching paths, and your decisions affect the way the plot progresses.  This is a trilogy with 3 distinct but connected stories.  I'll cover the first two games here since they're included together in this release.  The third (Zero Time Dilemma) is broken out into its own game on Steam.

The first game definitely feels like an initial attempt at the concept.  The branching paths don't always make the most sense, and while there are multiple good and bad endings, sometimes the reasoning behind why your choices were "wrong" won't always be clear.  These bad endings exist more as a way to cut you out of certain paths the writer didn't want you to go down.  There are a few exceptions, but most of the time it felt as though there was one “right” path and one “wrong” path, instead of two equally right choices that led to different outcomes.  However overall the story is solid, gets more complex and throws some curve balls at you, and thankfully does a good job at tying up most of the open questions by the end.

The second game (Virtue's Last Reward) feels a lot more polished.  This game made the move from 2D snapshots of the room to a rendered 3D environment, allowing you to freely rotate around the room on rails.  There are many more branching paths, and the branches feel more meaningful.  Each path you take gives you fragments of the overarching story and uncover various secrets about the facility, your companions, and other things.  You're expected to explore many different possible paths to piece together the whole story, and unlike the first game, most of these endings hold some sort of meaning or relevance to the overall plot.  The puzzles themselves also didn’t feel crammed in, but instead linked back to the story, and vice versa.  Each and every puzzle has an additional solution that gives some additional notes from the developer, which isn’t required but gives incentive to revisit puzzles you’ve already cleared to find that second solution.

Both games provide pretty clear and solvable puzzles, with critical thinking required but no guesswork necessary.  I rarely felt like I didn’t understand a solution, and when I did, it was almost always me misunderstanding the information provided, rather than an actual lack of information.  In both games the plot starts simple, but adds in more complex science and philosophy concepts later.  However, it does a pretty good job at explaining the concepts and assuming the reader knows nothing about them.

Overall the game was well worth the money, and I’d recommend it to anyone who is a fan of both puzzles and science fiction.

Fucking brilliant. This bundles two games from the three volumes and you're getting a really great deal out of this, completely worth every single hour you put into the game. The stories told from these two games are a masterpiece and you probably wont be forgetting it for a while.... The characters too each have their own unique side stories to them as well. For me personally I enjoy the cast and puzzles more from the first game, while the story on the second game once you get into it completely hooked me to the point where I woke up from my sleep only to play the game immediately! Let's not forget the updated art/graphics, and even voice acting in this version of the game and the ability to switch between English/Japanese voice. This is easily the superior version compared to the 3DS one. Now I'm really eager to play the third installment of the series, Zero Time Dilemma once I've finished writing this review. And sometimes after that AI: The Somnium Files as well... whenever that game got regional pricing.

I've only played the first out of the two games that are in this package. The first one is absolutely legendary. Get all the endings, and DO NOT LOOK ANYTHING UP or spoil yourself, and just enjoy the ride!

I'm currently playing the second game (VLR). The graphics put me off a bit at first but I'm slowly getting used to it. I'll revise this review when I finish it. Even so, the first game alone is all it takes for me to recommend this.

EDIT: I just finished the second game and here's a couple of thought:

1. It felt like a huge chore to get all the endings because of so many paths to take, and not every path felt that satisfying. In the beginning I wasn't really interested in the characters or setting, but that changed once the game progressed.

2. HOLY COW I was blown away by the real ending!!  It literally made me feel like an Einstein too because there's some really crazy stuff in here. That's all I can say without spoiling anything really.

3. If you played the first game YOU HAVE TO play this game because, without spoiling, it basically develops and explains lots of things about the world and events of first game which completely change your perspective about it. Do not play this without having played 999.

All in all, awesome package and I'm moving on to the third game.

[b]Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors[/b]

Ritengo che sia un gioco valido con una trama ben scritta, con rarissime "forzature" che comunque non hanno un impatto considerevole sullo sviluppo dei fatti(credo di averne trovata solo una). Pertanto lo consiglio a chiunque piaccia il genere.


[b]Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward[/b]

La trama del secondo capitolo, ben scritta e articolata, è collegata al primo, quindi sarebbe una buona idea informarsi almeno sugli antefatti per una totale comprensione delle vicende. Le pochissime "forzature" che ho notato (due, massimo tre) non hanno un impatto notevole sullo sviluppo della storia. Personaggi ben scritti, titolo abbastanza longevo (oltre trenta ore di gioco circa). I puzzle sono di media difficoltà, ma anche in caso di necessità è possibile selezionare la difficoltà "facile", senza subire penalità che possono inficiare sul proseguimento dell'avventura, ricevendo quindi più indizi (oppure consultare le guide di Steam complete e chiare).  Il finale è aperto (così come nel primo capitolo) e fa capire che ci sarà un seguito (Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma). C'è da sperare che sia all'altezza dei primi due (soprattutto del secondo, che secondo me è il migliore dei due, dove tutto accade per un motivo, e qualunque dubbio viene chiarito fornendo sempre spiegazioni dirette, semplici dove non c'è spazio per equivoci o confusione. Queste qualità sono presenti anche nel primo capitolo, ma nel secondo hanno raggiunto livelli ancora più alti).

Naturalmente consiglio anche questo titolo a chiunque piaccia il genere ed abbia apprezzato il primo capitolo della saga.

目前就玩了999，感觉作者真的很牛逼，这么大的脑洞，而且最后所有事情都串起来了，伏笔也都回收了，我在玩的时候也猜测过剧情，但是真的玩到真结局才发现完全猜不到，整个过程特别是玩到真结局的时候，我虽然在大夏天的空调房里面，但是玩的手心已经全是汗了，这个剧情真的神了，我游玩途中的疑问到最后也一一解答出来了，本作的核心玩法数字根和进制数也很不错，特别是没想到最后的最后数字根和进制还结合了一波，属实精彩，上次玩到这么精彩的作品还是弹丸论破了。可惜2代在PC上没有汉化，仅有3DS汉化，希望2代能给我更好的游戏体验！

P.S.: Расшифровка:

Трэш — знакомиться с игрой рекомендуется исключительно тем, кто в диком восторге от описания, скриншотов и продолжительности. Остальным, из контакта с этой игрой, только тыкать палкой, как ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ку на дороге.

Так себе — в основном, эта игра предлагает меньше, чем вы увидите из описания и скриншотов. Рекомендуется только тем, кому вышеперечисленные критерии окажутся «зашибись».

Нормальная — неплохая игра своего жанра. Сами судите по описанию, скриншотам и продолжительности. Игра, примерно, соответствует своему наполнению.

Хорошая — весьма неплохой представитель своего жанра. Многие могут найти тут «свой шедевр». Зачастую, игра приятно соответствует своему описанию и скриншотам.

Отличная — эти игры, зачастую, превосходят свои первые впечатления, основанные на описании и скриншотах (в расчёт не берём репутацию, ибо «тот кто знает, тот поймёт»). Хорошие представители своего жанра.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is actually a bundle of 2 games (999 and virtue's last reward)
Zero Escape has a very interesting structure for a visual novel as parts of its are not reliant on flags (This is explained in a GDC conference named: "Visual Novels: Narrative Design in Virtue's Last Reward")
Apart from the interesting structure of the routing, the premise revolves around a sort of mystery trapped room game, but with lives on the line like Danganronpa
Without giving away too much, each of the stories consists of 9 characters involved in the game and your goal is to find a way to escape from rooms and fulfill a condition to escape the location.
If you are interested in mystery novels this is certainly something you should pick up to play through as the ambience of the backgrounds and music really sets the mood of the situation that you find yourself in

999は強くお勧めします。魅力的なキャラクターとストーリーと謎解きを十分楽しめました。エンディング回収も楽です。

　善人シボウデスは絶対にお勧めしません。スキップ不可な無駄な演出がこれでもかとちりばめられており、ストーリーを読みたいプレイヤーを苛立たせます。
　また９９９は２Dのアニメーションでしたが、善人は３Dのアニメーションになりました。２Dのままで良かったと思います。
　アイテム欄も不便になりました。９９９は一覧からアイテムを直接選択できたのですが、善人では回転させなくてはならないので直接選択できなくなりました。
　無意味な改変と改悪にまみれた善人シボウデスはやらなくていいです。９９９だけやってください。

数年前「善人シボウデス」をVITAでプレイして、
前作の「9時間9人9の扉」をプレイしてないのを思い出して買いました。

【9時間9人9の扉】
・ストーリー　◎
　ジャンルは「SFミステリー」でしょうか。
　序盤は正直退屈ですが、だんだん謎が明らかになっていき、
　プレイヤーは「ゼロが誰か？」「目的は何か？」などを考察しながらプレイできます。
　なので、話を理解できればだんだん面白くなっていきます。

　バッドエンドをいくつか見る → 脱出エンドなので、ストーリーは1つです。

　フローチャートの分岐(アイコン)はわかり辛かったです
　「ロックアイコン」が解除状態になっていれば正解です(たぶん)。
　
　ストーリ―の不満点は、最初からノナリーゲームが破綻してしまうことくらいですかね。

・キャラクター　△
　ストーリーは良いけどキャラクターは中途半端で特に印象に残らず。
　個性的なキャラっぽいのに個性を出す場面が少ない。

　ついさっき死者が出たのに探索パートに入ったら急に会話にギャグやネタを挟んできたり、
　あと数時間で死ぬ人達に見えない。
　ネタ自体は面白いけど、「ネタ担当」がいるわけではなく、その場にいた人が適当にネタを挟むという感じ。
　
　会話中の絵柄から緊迫感がよくわからず、
　4と7、3と8の喧嘩は深刻なのかギャグなのか。


・謎解き　△
　アイテムや資料を見るためにキャンセルすると勝手にヒントを出してきてかなりウザい・・・。
　ほぼ答えに近いヒントを出してくるので注意です。
　これのせいで謎解きの達成感はかなり減っています。
　たぶんUIがDS(2画面)前提のままなんじゃないかと。

　謎解きに使う資料とゲーム説明が同じメニューに入っていて、
　しばらくは手に入れた資料がどこから見れるのかわからなかった。
　
　小さいものを調べるためにカーソルを合わせるのが難しい。
　画面上小さいアイテムが多く、少しカーソルが外れていると調べたことにならず、アイテムを取れない。
　「ドア」と「ドアについている装置」が別判定になっていて、装置の方を調べてもドアを開かず、詰みそうになった。
　他にも「テーブルの上」と「テーブルの上のもの」が別だったりわかり辛い。

　紙とペンが無いと厳しい問題がいくつかあり。

　作中に色々な用語は出てくるけど、謎解きは、
　「マップを隅々まで調べる」「意味の無い数字を覚える」がほとんどで、
　プレイヤーの知識や能力が高まるものが少ない。
　ストーリー上は時間制限があっても、解けるまで終わらない。


・クリアまで12～3時間程度


【善人シボウデス】
正直名前でかなり損してると思います。
プレイのきっかけは偶然、PSプラスの無料体験中に出会ったからなので、
たぶん無料じゃなければスルーだったでしょう。
というか、続編なのにタイトルもハードも変わってるのはどうかと・・・。
調べないと前作のタイトルわからないですし。
さらに続編(刻のジレンマ)が出ていたことはここで知りました。

はっきり覚えていないので細かくは書けませんが、
全体的に999と似たような感じですがストーリーは「一捻り」あります。

[999からの改善点]
・3D化で探索中に視点を自由に回せる。(ただしスピード感は下がった)
・難易度制になり、勝手にヒントが出ないようになった。
・資料が分類されるようになり見やすくなった。
・スキップが高速(でも速すぎても困る・・・)
・キャラクターの見せ方は999よりだいぶ良くなっている。
・メモ機能がある(ペンと紙が不要。背景を見ながらメモできる)

[999からの改悪点]
・999はキャラの立ち絵や一枚絵がイラストだったけどこっちは3Dポリゴン。
　さらに3Dポリゴンをキャプチャして一枚絵にした場面がたくさん。
　撮り直しはせず引き延ばしたんですかね・・・、かなり画質が悪いです。
　一部、動画になってるところも。3Dの意味がほとんどないです。　
　明らかに改悪でしょう。

・主人公のボイスが無く、3Dポリゴンも無い。
　主人公＝プレイヤーというわけではなく、主人公の顔、体、設定は決まっています。
　このゲームの都合とはいえ、他のキャラクターはボイス付きなのでイマイチ。　

・999→シボウデスの順にやるとハッキリわかりますが、進行が遅くてストレスが溜まる。
　ストーリー上、移動するときは何故か2Dマップ画面になり、
　マップ上に書かれた●がノロノロと移動、
　何故かドアを開くシーンは3Dマップに戻り、また2Dマップ画面に戻る。

　会話の途中に突然、辺りを見回す(？)「謎の間」が入る。

　探索中、移動する度に　ドアを開ける→ドアを閉める　を何度も見るハメになる。

　3つ並んでいるロッカーを調べる場合は、
　ロッカー1を開ける→ロッカー2を開ける→ロッカー3を開ける(ここまでは普通)
　調べ終わったら、ロッカー3を閉める→ロッカー2を閉める→ロッカー1を閉める。
　などいちいち意味の無い動作が挟まる。
　

　マップ移動に関しては設定を変えて「未読スキップ」をすることで早送りできます。
　しかし、未読スキップにすると今度は「未読ストップ」しなくなります。
　マップ移動は移動終了に合わせて手動でストップさせることもできます。
　でも、どのルートにもある「共通の会話」が大量に仕込まれていて、
　選択肢によって僅かに変わる部分はあるものの、
　ほぼ同じ内容なのでスキップしたくなります。
　未読スキップすると当然、いつ既読部分が終わったかわからないので、
　未読部分もスキップしてしまい、読みたいはずの重要な部分までスキップしてしまいます。
　クソ仕様としか言いようが無いですね。

　移動シーンは本当に酷い。
　「ノベルゲーなのに読む文字が無い」
　「脱出ゲーなのに考えることもない」
　「ただのマップや扉の開閉なので見応えもない」
　「キャラクターも表示されない」
　「ローディングしてるわけでもない」
　ただ無価値な時間が流れるだけです。

　個人的にはスキップしないとやってられないので「未読スキップ推奨」です。
　スキップしすぎてしまうのは諦めましょう。

　確か初プレイのVitaでも未読スキップしてました。
　プレイ後に999を買おうと思わなかったのも、
　こういうのであまりやる気が出なかったのを思い出しました。

　動作が遅いのが嫌になって辞めた人、スキップしすぎて意味不明になった人は多そう。
　移植やらリマスターでここら辺を改善しようと思わなかったんだろうか・・・。
　ここで売る以上、今からでも修正した方がいいと思いますよ・・・。
　「移動だけ全てスキップ可能」にすればほぼ解決です。


　999だけなら間違いなく「おすすめ」なんですが、
　シボウをやったら「いいえ」にしようか迷います。

・選択肢でいくつか分岐するのはいいが、どの分岐でも「to be continue」になり、
　戻って他の選択肢を選びフラグを立てないと続きを見れない。
　「428」というゲームでも交互にストーリーを進めて行く手法はあったが、
　今作だと「登場キャラが同じ」「ストーリーの流れもほとんど同じ」なので、
　フラグを立ててから再開しても話の内容を思い出し辛い。

・「自分は赤のペア」「私は青のソロ」「俺は～」
　「パターン1はAとB、CとDが組む、パターン2は～」
　というどうでもいい解説にもの凄く時間をかける。しかもボイス付きで。
　なのに、前作のラストから今作に繋がる重要な話はボイス無しだったり謎すぎる。

・治療室のすごろくに謎解きに納得がいかない(一応、伏せました)
　[spoiler]
　１．駒＝すごろくというのがピンと来ない
　２．第1、第２のパスワードという単語が出てくるけど、No1、No2（1文字目、2文字目）のことに思える。
　　「第１のパスワードは駒が4つ、第２は駒が1つ」←答えを聞いてもピンと来ない。
　　すごろくの絵には駒が4つあるから、あの絵からは「第１パスワード」しか取れないことになる。
　　他にすごろくの絵も無いし、No1の時刻が7：15→時計の針だと7，3になるから、何かしら関係あるかと思った・・・。
　３．３つがアナログ時計だから、当然、分を時計の数字に変換するのかと思える。
　４．No3がレーザーで表示が変わるが、変わる前の時刻には全く意味が無い
　５．すごろくの開始地点がどこかわからない。自分はスタート地点から開始すると思った。
　６．答えの4文字に意味が無い(たぶん)

　考えられるパターンが多いのに、考えが正解か全くわからない、
　正しい答えの時でも数え間違えたらアウト、
　回答入力のパターンはほぼ無限にあるので運任せは無理。
　
　他の謎解きと比べて異様に難しく感じました。(EASYにして答えを聞いた)
　[/spoiler]


続編の「刻のジレンマ」をプレイ後のネタバレ感想
　[spoiler]
2のおまけ(カイルの体に入った謎の意識)を見た感じだと、あの意識はプレイヤーのことっぽいですかね。
刻のジレンマにはカイルらしき人は出てこないので。　

そして、四葉とアリスは「トランスポーター」で過去に戻ることは可能だけど、
これだとオリジナルの方は結局取り残されるわけで、BAD ENDです・・・。
　[/spoiler]

No one will ever truly know my adoration of this series, especially for 999.

I first heard about this series in... 2009, probably, when I was an avid reader of Nintendo Power (RIP you beautiful magazine). I never picked it up because it just didn't interest me. Also, I was one of those good girl types who didn't start playing M-rated games until I was 15. Eventually, I just forgot about the series.

A couple of months ago, one of my friends urged me to play the game, especially since I'd played and loved AI: The Somnium Files.

This series has helped me get through the pandemic. The characters are so fantastic. The story is INCREDIBLE and consistent. The puzzles are challenging without being mind-breaking. I love everything about this series, and Uchikoshi Kotaro is now my favourite writing director in the video game industry.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who liked visual novels, escape rooms, and/or puzzle games, and also to anyone who just appreciates a good story.

脱出ゲーム+AVGのZERO ESCAPEシリーズ3部作の1と2のセット。
好みの分かれるシナリオだとは思いますが、個人的には好みだったのでお勧めしておきます。
ただし、2作目は次回作へ続くで終わるので買うなら完結編『刻のジレンマ』もセットで購入がお勧めです。
1作目の『9時間9人9の扉』は沈みゆく船からの脱出というシチュエーションも好みで、最後に一気に伏線回収されるカタルシスもあり満足でした。
2作目の『善人シボウデス』は続編前提とはいえシナリオは相変わらず良かったのですが、
移動シーンの怠さと出来の悪い3D描写がマイナスです。
あとABゲームは1回で0にも9にもならない仕様上、裏切りのリスクが高すぎて協力安定のような…

色々と書きましたがAVGの肝であるシナリオは面白いので、少しでも気になったのなら買いましょう。

打越钢太郎代表作之一，虽然比不上ever17给我带来的震撼（可能是因为ever17是我的入坑作），但比起ever17的慢热，极限脱出系列更适合刚入坑的萌新，它秉承了打越钢太郎一贯的核心诡计并且将三部曲非常合理的联系在一起，密室脱出也有着很不错的游戏性，多周目的设定一点也不会觉得无聊，每打完一个周目都能有新发现，通过一次次失败最后解开true end真的能让人大呼过瘾，绝对是日式AVG的天花板。我最喜欢的是系列第二作善人死亡，它不仅仅是一部密室逃脱大作，更是一部对质疑人类世界观的佳作。直到我玩到最后一个结局之前，我都不知道到底逃出这个世界是为了什么，到底是为了满足自己对自由的追求，还是只是出于对于人与人之间关系的恐惧。所谓Zero Escape, 不光是主人公，也就是Zero的逃脱，更是对人类社会性矛盾的放大。（希望打越老师日后能和小高做出更多好作品！）

Before you start reading reviews you have to remember this is bundle with two remakes, so I will talk a bit about both separately.

999: I played the original DS version (released in 2010) and thought It was a masterpiece, and this version is even better, with some quality of life improvements and better graphics (some cool features from the original are lost because It is played on a single screen, but nothing deal breaker).
This game is full of cool puzzles that always have some relevance to the plot, usually you complete a puzzle and a character will tell a story related to the puzzle. 
The gameplay is simple, the characters, graphics and voice acting are great. The plot is a bit weird, but It is really interesting.
Overall It is a great experience, a fun and easy game to play.

Virtue Last Reward: This one I didnt play the original, released on the 3DS (2012) so I cant talk about the difference between versions.
This game is way bigger than the last one, more endings, more puzzles, 3D environments and characters, etc...
Some improvements from the last game are that the scape sections are way easier to navigate, and you have a draft screen, where you can write notes or draw something to help with puzzles.
IMO this game is not as good as the first one, here are a couple reasons:
- Most puzzles are hard and annoying, and they usually have nothing to do with the plot, It is just some random puzzle in the middle of the kitchen or something.
- The plot is a cluster fuck, I wont spoil anything, but the ending is too complex for my taste.
Overall It is a good game, not as good as the first one, but still a good game.

tl;dr: If you like Visual Novels and puzzles, get this bundle.

999 is a decent 12 hour sci-fi story, VLR is a 50 hour train wreck.
999 has beautiful and timeless visuals, VLR's visuals are so bad, that they made me laugh out loud multiple times.
999 has mediocre puzzles, VLR has tedious puzzles, including the worst puzzle I think I've ever seen in a video game period (the dart board) and uses it twice!
999 has ok characters, VLR has terrible character.
999 has 6 varying story paths, VLR has a ton of paths, that all play out the same except for their conclusion.
999 has choices that influence the future events in a somewhat logical fashion, the consequences for your actions in VLR are completely random.

Only get this for 999 and disregard VLR, unless you are either deeply masochistic or morbidly curious.

Two great stories involving quantum mechanics, branching timelines, escape rooms, and a definitely unique experience. I played this on other platforms, so my playtime is low, but I've gone all the way through both of the included games, and they're both awesome.

These Visual Novels both 999 and Virtue's Last Reward are masterpieces, 999 being the superior, but Virtue's Last Reward not trailing far behind. Kotaro Uchikoshi is a master in the mystery genre of visual novels, if you played Ever 17 i don't understand how you still haven't played this gem. I wanted to revisit and see how well the story had aged and i have to say both game aged really well like fine wine. If you haven't decided to delve into the visual novel genre these are good games to try for the first time, it is full of lovable characters and an engaging story that will keep you on your toes from beginning to end. The only negative is the ports have some issues, but nothing that make the game unplayable. 999 gets a 9/10 and Virtue's Last Reward gets an 8/10. If you are interested in continuing the series Zero Time Dilemma is also available on steam. btw remember that 999 was released on the DS in 2009 and VTL in 2012 for PSVita and 3DS.
