以下为测评内容
私以为是打越钢太郎私在ever17后最棒的作品。
我心目中的打越钢太郎部分作品主观排名：ever17>善人死亡＞999＞＞AI梦境档案
《极限脱出999》是整个系列的开端，讲述普通大学生淳平被绑架参加九人游戏，与青梅竹马仓式茜重逢发生的故事。哪怕没有续作，单这部就已是堪称神作的精品。密室难度尚低，各角色拖出过程中勾心斗角，互飙演技，六个结局用时大概20h，打出真结局时诡述揭露让人直呼卧槽，震撼脑髓，张着嘴半天说不出一句话，默默看着幕后黑手零与主角淳平的同台演出。(强烈建议用nds模拟器玩获得最佳体验)
第二部《极限脱出:善人死亡》是三部里综合方面最优作，以跳线收集情报为特色，前期因为剧情锁设定，让人摸不着头脑，能发现密室难度比起前作高了一个档次，需要40h才能打出全结局，可是在突破烦人的剧情锁打出第一个BE后就开始高信息量的连续神级转折了，九人游戏发现的第十人的尸体？除两位主角外其他人物全部死亡，凶手是谁？一个个谜题让人忍不住玩下去，想尽快得到答案，而当打越式的述诡视角揭开后我忍不住浑身起了鸡皮疙瘩，得到了超过第一部的震撼与毛骨悚然，原来伏笔可以挖这么深而毫无违和感吗？不禁感叹打越老师惊为天人的脑洞。
两部作品偏向悬疑风，角色勾心斗角让人深感人性黑暗，可又有着温馨治愈的部分让人得到肝出真结局的动力，精致的bgm也是游戏亮点之一，赶紧入手吧！
这个系列，真的，别错过了。人生能有几部ever17啊
This game makes you go o_O to o_o to O_o to ;-;

Zero Escape games offer a good mix of reading and actual gameplay compared other VNs I've read in the past ( such as Steins;Gate). The first game is the best of the bunch in my opinion. The 2D graphics aged well compared to the cheap 3D graphics of later episodes, and it tells its story in a concise and well-paced manner unlike - again - its sequels.

About this, LVR drags for way. too. long. The idea of re-iterating through different timelines to unlock new information and new chapters is interesting on paper, but the execution makes it a complete bore. I spent most of my time skipping through dialogs and wishing I could skip the super annoying transit animations. Seriously, how much time does this game make you sit through the same door opening, corridor traversing animations? Still, there is an interesting story and some interesting characters to be found in the game. As its often the case with VNs, the "true ending" makes it worth sitting through some uninspired bits.

If I could review the two games individually, I would probably not recommend VLR. But I think 999 is good enough in itself to recommend the bundle.

god my brain HURTS after playing this.. what a ride. i really thought my theories might be on to something but then another plot reveal and bAM i realised i have been a buffoon all along.,., 12/10 recc for the story, seems long but every bit is worth it!!!
Both games included are amazing. The premise, cast, narrative, puzzles, plot twists, mysteries, and voice acting are all incredible.

One of my favorite point-and-clicks I've played. The characters are really enjoyable, and it's a pretty good port. I especially appreciate adding voice acting into the 1st game-- I think that really enhanced the experience for me.

[h1] Начало истории. История, конца которой нет  [/h1]
[b]  [h1]  [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/RythmSadist] КУРАТОР RHYTHM GAME FOREVER ПРЕДСТАВЛЯЕТ  [/url]  [/h1] [/b] 

Spike Chunsoft на удивление делают игры, в которые погружаешься с голой в сюжет на множество часов. Невероятная 1 Danganronpa с интересной идеей убийственной игры и Абсолютных подростков - прогрессирующими по ходу сюжета персонажи, со временем они начинает открывать себя совершенно с другой стороны. 2 Danganronpa, которая смогла раскрыть идею более глубже, предоставив интересные убийства, больше end game контента и даже даёт возможность побыть в шкуре другого ученика, где нужно совершить побег из комнаты, прямо как в Zero Escape: The Nonary Games. Ах да, к слову о ней

[b]   Zero Escape: The Nonary Games [/b]  Это смесь новеллы и головоломки, с чётко разделяющими этапы между чтением историй и прохождение головоломок-комнат. Сама по себе она является сборником переизданий двух игр - Zero Escape  Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors (999) и Zero Escape Virtue’s Last Reward (VLR) и по большей степени в этом обзоре я буду говорить именно о Zero Escape 999. Эта игра была у меня  на слуху, всё никак не решался её купить, но когда купил, понял  насколько же крутые раньше делали игры. Zero Escape (999) давит в индивидуальность каждого из участников нонарной игры. 9 человек попадают на корабль и их цель крайне проста - Сбежать, но проблема заключается в дверях и особом устройстве около них и браслетах на запястье каждого участника. Для открытие любой из дверей нужно набрать нонарную комбинацию в сумме дающая число 9 и минимум 3 числа. Например числа 4+5+9 в сумме дают 18, 18 по нонарной системе исчисления, это 1+8 = 9 При присутствие всех браслетов участники могут разделить на 3 группы в сумме дающие эту 9-ку. Проблема только в том, что один из участников умирает в самом начале игры, что в свою очередь усложняют доступ к некоторым комнатам, а это не позволит вам изучить все 9 двери. Придётся делать выбор, куда идти а что оставить не тронутым. В целом задача нереальна и проблема даже не в том, что вы банально не успеете изучить все комнаты при таких обстоятельствах, а в смертях большинства участников умирающих при странных обстоятельствах.

Есть один такой британский писатель, теорема которого взята в основу всей серии игры с некоторыми изменениями. Руперт Шелдрейк - Писатель, Биохимик и парапсихолог, который ввёл термин морфогенетического полей. Как это работает ? Приведу самый популярный пример:
 
[quote=...] В начале прошлого века в Англии молоко стали разносить в бутылках, закрытых картонными крышечками. Бутылки ставились перед дверью, у порога. В городке Саутгемптон местные синицы быстро использовали это новшество. Они легко проклевывали крышечки и пили молоко. Скоро эта  стало известно синицам всей Британии, а потом и большей части Европы. С началом Второй мировой войны, когда появились карточки на продовольствие, бутылки у порога молочники уже не оставляли. И только восемь лет спустя вернулись к прежней практике доставки молока. И что же? Синицы сразу же принялись дырявить картонные крышечки...
В чём подвох всей этой истории ? Синицы живут всего 2-3 года и они никак не могли перенять опыт своих предков [/quote]

В целом Zero Escape: The Nonary Games говорят о том же самом, но происходит всё совершенно по другому, я не буду спойлерить сюжет (каким образом всё это происходит) и оставлю этот участок на вас. Переигрывая все вариации путей и при правильных выборах вы сможете получить различных концовок (в первую очередь отрицательных) , в этом и заключается весь смысл игры - Пройти по всем путям решив все головоломки и найдя правильный путь выйти на истинную концовку

[h1] Новельная составляющая  [/h1]

Как я и говорил ранее, Zero Escape 999 в первую очередь делает акцент на раскрытие личностей персонажей, потому что у всех них за плечами есть большая история и выдают они себя не за тех, кем являются на самом деле, некоторые это забыли, а не которые просто "забыли" ради личной выгоды. В ходе прохождения участков историй между комнатами-головоломками и даже во время, либо же в конце прохождения головоломок персонажи начинают раскрывать себя как личности, а само повествование достаточно серьёзное и даже в некоторых местах научное. История о льде-9, восприятие картин,парадокс носка Бертлмана и многое другое. Хоть эти история в наше время многим могут быть известны, читать про них лично для меня было самым настоящим удовольствием. Новельная часть, это не просто множество букОв которые нужно читать, но и сюжетные выборы напрямую влияющие на концовку игры, лишь при правильном выборе вы сможете получить истинную концовку и поверьте мне на слово, ради этой концовки можно и даже нужно запариться с правильными выборами в диалогах. Концовка Zero Escape 999 это не просто захватывающий финал, но и шикарная загадка заставляющая не просто думать а в целом расширить свой кругозор при её решение, ответ был в ней настолько нестандартный, что при её прохождение я испытал самое настоящие удовольствие

[h1]Головоломки  [/h1]

9 комнат - 9 совершенно разных по интерьеру и решению головоломок с поиском предметов и решением загадочек, причём решать её вы будете не одни ! Для открытие доступа к комнате с головоломкой нужно как минимум 3 участника, командная работа, ваша логика и находчивость помогут решить головоломки. В целом загадки не сложные и самое главное разнообразные! Даже если вы застрянете на одной из них, вы всегда можете поговорить с другими напарниками в комнате и получить совет. Если решение головоломки СОВСЕМ не даётся, другие герои будут буквально разжевывать вам ответ

[h1]Музыкальное сопровождение [/h1]

В своих обзорах я очень люблю говорить о музыке, музыка даёт очень большую отдачу, позволяя ощущать различные ситуации в полную меру. В Zero Escape 999 просто шикарный саунтрек для своего времени, когда на звуки и музыку некоторые не обращали особого внимание и в большинстве случаев она оставалась лишь на втором плане https://youtu.be/K9yoeUXJvmA?list=PLza0P8ARMqvgUEFHHV_uf7Bcfo4Qjl0X3 В ситуации с Zero Escape 999 мне даже не стыдно слушать его вне контекста игры, она умеет и делают свою работу - передаёт нужные ощущения и подогревают память

[h1]Вывод [/h1]
Zero Escape: The Nonary Games конечно же понравится любителям новелл и головоломок. Если вы все ещё не играли в неё, то я настоятельно рекомендую в неё поиграть. Разнообразные головоломки, интересный сюжет и множество сюжетных поворотов, отношение между персонажами и их разлука, боль поражения, чувство отчаяния и под конец облегчающая победа. 

Крайне рекомендую к ознакомлению

The Zero Escape series starts with 999. An amazingly captivating story, you'll find yourself sucked in and later having easily forgotten just how long you've been playing. I clocked 10 hours on my second session the day after I bought the game the night before and tried it out for about 3 hours. It can be quite addicting, and I think it's just easier to play longer as it's not very physically taxing on the body- just the mind. 

First thing first I wanna mention is;
MUSIC: 11/10 
Straight from the get go, the aroma that surrounds the room when the soundtrack of 999 starts playing hit's like a train of pleasure for the ears and the mind. Soothing melodies and heart racing themes that reoccur as you play through out the VN. Hearing the song for each changing room is a very welcoming array of sounds that will keep your brain neurons aroused while you delve into 999's--

STORY: 10/10 - BLEW ME AWAY.
 9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors is a series of wicked events that derive after the mysterious Zero kidnaps 9 individuals for a game. The Nonary game. It is a game where you (Junpei, the Player Character) awake aboard a strange vessel unaware of where you are or how you got there. Immediately a challenge arrives for the Player and Junpei. You must work with your limited surroundings to find clues to help get through the door... A Numbered Door. 

REPLAY VALUE: 
There are many routed endings. After some hours, all routes can easily be uncovered over time. Unless you really love the game that much, once having beat all endings- I wouldn't see much value in returning to 999- (Besides them waifu titties and the fire soundtrack of course.) As you will have seen every scene, and route played out. 


EDIT: I have beat 999; I've watched / read / played out every scene. and with that, I can fully say that I enjoyed the game. Lot's of "Oh wow." moment's, with a pleasantly answer fulfilled  ending that didn't leave me pissed off after the fact. Game completion time took me just under 23 hours to 100%. 
25 hours to 100% VLR. I can say that in the end I truly believe this series is one of the greater works of art on the market. So many mind boggling things take place. Putting it into words would be spoiling it, all I can say is you have to play both games and you have to do all endings otherwise you won't understand jack! overall. 10/10

Do I recommend this game? Yes. Yes I would. Maybe wait for sale if you think $30 is too much- just think there is two games so the devs are honestly giving a decent deal for the price they are asking for. They even updated some graphical things from the DS version.
If you buy the big bundle deal for all 3 of the Zero escape games- you save $10 instead of buying them individually.
真的牛逼

My brother recommended this game to me. I started playing it at 1pm on my day off. By 1am, I had almost completed the first game. I don't know where the time went. I can't wait to start the second game when I get home tomorrow!

Essentially a visual novel with "escape room" puzzle elements, the games also have a compelling story (the first is good, the second is AMAZING.) regarding the Many Worlds interpretation of String Theory and Schrodinger's Cat, Chaos Theory, and an interesting take on time travel.

Highly recommended, was glad to have picked this up. It runs along the same vein as Phoenix Wright and Danganronpa, but is fundamentally different enough to where it can stand successfully on its own.

10/10 would search up Ganzfeld experiment and Schrodinger's Cat to pretend that I'm an expert in metaphysics

[I]Zero Escape: The Nonary Games[/I] is visual novel/adventure game hybrid, in which you have to solve escape room puzzles. It is actually a collection of two games: [I]Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors[/I] (a.k.a. [I]999[/I]) as well as [I]Zero Escape: Virtue’s Last Reward[/I] (a.k.a. [I]VLR[/I]) both of which have their roots in handheld console platforms (Nintendo DS and 3DS, and PlayStation Vita). With that, even with some polishing for the PC port, [I]The Nonary Games[/I] retains some graphical and technological limitations of the handheld versions.

[B]Dated Graphics and Technology[/B]
In [I]999[/I], navigation around escape rooms is similar to that in [I]Myst[/I], with you moving or turning to pre-determined spots, and examining still images of 2D art or pre-rendered 3D objects and environments. While escape rooms in [I]VLR[/I] are not pre-rendered, you do typically examine your surroundings from a fixed spot, with the camera zooming in on certain objects for closer inspection. These designs choices were clearly made due to the limited processing powers of handheld consoles.

[I]999[/I] benefited from having its hand-drawn art and pre-rendered 3D background animation remastered. In fact, I find them more appealing than the 3D graphics in [I]VLR[/I], which suffer from low resolution 3D stills and background textures, which are particularly apparent during close-ups. While these graphics may look fine on 3DS and Vita screens, they are merely passable on modern PCs. The fact that [I]VLR[/I] has smooth looking 3D character models make the low resolution textures and stills more glaring.

[B]Gameplay and Stories Still Shine[/B]
Graphical and technological limitations aside, [I]The Nonary Games[/I] truly shines in the gameplay and story departments. I bought [I]The Nonary Games[/I] for the escape room challenges, and they did not disappoint. Puzzles are varied and on-theme. The solutions are, for the most part, adequately hinted. I found the puzzles in [I]VLR[/I] to be slightly more challenging, with some demanding more time to figure out the math. With exception to the very last escape room in [I]VLR[/I], I do not recall seeing puzzles repeated in the two games.

When I bought [I]The Nonary Games[/I], I thought the stories of [I]999[/I] and [I]VLR[/I] -- like most visual novels I know of -- are merely fluff that loosely tie the puzzles together. I was wrong, and soon found myself intrigued by the intricately woven science fiction narratives. In fact, I would argue that [I]The Nonary Games[/I] is more of a visual novel than an adventure/puzzle game. Still, the escape room challenges are not arbitrarily included, for they are key plot devices. The grand designs of the Nonary Games in [I]999[/I] and [I]VLR[/I] are also very well thought out. It was impressive to see how the mathematics and various permutations of the Nonary Games work out.

[B]But, Be Warned! [/B]
There is [B]A LOT[/B] of reading in [I]999[/I] and [I]VLR[/I]. Even if you love reading, you will likely find the places where the writing could be trimmed. Again, the games’ verbosity is likely due to the limitations of handheld consoles. Instead of simply [B]showing[/B] us information, the designers need to [B]explain[/B] all details. That is all fine if the writing is good, but there are moments when the quality and quantity of text become too much to handle. It was hard for me to ignore characters making inappropriate jokes, talking endlessly, explaining (pseudo)scientific theories and philosophies when they are in peril and have limited time to solve puzzles.

You are expected to play each of the two games multiple times, and revisit certain scenarios more than once. I naively thought [I]999[/I] and [I]VLR[/I] would be linear experiences, but they are anything but. In fact, you need to fail, die, and explore various avenues to ultimately succeed, similar to [I]All You Need Is Kill[/I] and [I]Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow[/I]. This is needed so that your in-game character can gain the necessary in-game insight to win the Nonary Games. Because of that, you will often find yourself re-reading the same text, especially in [I]VLR[/I]. By the third time I heard and/or read the unchanging rules of the Nonary Game in [I]VLR[/I], I was ready to punch my monitor. It would have been nice to be able to skip some parts completely without needing to press ENTER or click repeatedly to advance to the new content.

[B]Final Thoughts[/B]
Yet, I consider all of the negative points I mentioned to be minor inconveniences to enjoying the escape room challenges and the overall narratives of [I]999[/I] and [I]VLR[/I]. The mysteries of both games are engaging. Despite the premise of the games is based on pseudoscience, I was impressed by how game director and writer, Kotaro Uchikoshi, incorporated philosophy and advanced scientific facts and theories into the stories. I truly did not expect the Schrödinger’s cat thought experiment, Minkowski spacetime, and Isaac Asimov’s Laws of Robotics be respectfully and thoughtfully referenced in a visual novel.

I highly recommend [I]The Nonary Games[/I] in spite of the dated graphics and technology, as well as the wordiness. It is a highly enjoyable set of visual novels with fun puzzles, and is full of surprises and twists and turns. Simply the stories and game mechanics are worth of your time. You just need to be patient and wait for the secrets of the Nonary Games to unveil themselves.

This was my second foray into the visual novel style of game (the first being Danganronpa) and I beat the series in about 70 hours total. The Nonary Games comes with the first two games in the series, 999 and VLR. ZTD can also be found separately on steam but plays out differently than the first two, having more of a cinematic experience rather than the visual novel style of the first two. In terms of enjoyment, I think for me: 999 == VLR > ZTD. That's not to say that ZTD is a bad game, but the experience in the first two was memorable to say the least. After playing it I would say that buying it at full price is good value, however I DID pick it up on sale personally.

과거 DS와 3DS로 발매된 방탈출 게임 극한탈출 시리즈 중 첫 작품과 두번째 작품의 합본판. 지명도가 낮은 편이고 덕분에 좌초될 뻔한 작품이지만 망할 뻔한 것이 믿기지 않을 정도로 잘 짜인 SF. 크고 작은 단점도 많은 작품이지만 계속해서 궁금증을 불러 일으키는 스토리는 단점을 회수하고도 남는다. 방탈출 게임 자체는 바이오해저드 수준의 난이도로 공략없이 가볍게 클리어 할 수 있는 난이도이다. 핵심은 되려 스토리로, 시나리오 라이터가 고전명작 에버17의 작가인 우치코시 코타로의 작품이다. 성향이 기존작과 비슷한 자가반복적인 부분도  꽤있지만 죽지않은 필력을 보여준다.  
첫 작품인 999는 스토리가 초반에는 강한 흡입력을 가지고 있지만 설정 구멍이 워낙 크고 많아 용두사미로 끝나는 아쉬움이 있다. 다만 길지는 않은 편이라 다음편의 프리퀄 정도 이기에 적당했다.
본편이라 할 수 있는 두번째 작품 선인사망의 경우, 반대로 비슷한 루트가 많아 플레이 시간이 길어져 중반부가 조금 지루하다. 하지만 후반의 노도와도 같은 전개와 복선회수는 독특한 쾌감을 선사한다. 
강추하는 작품이지만 여러가지 이유로 후속작과 함께 3부작을 같이 구매하는 것을 추천.

Would I recommend these games? Absolutely. I originally played them on my 3ds and loved them so much that I bought them later on Steam. The escape rooms are really well thought out and fun to solve, the writing and stories are well woven and are a ton of fun piecing together, and the character voice acting isn't bad either. The music is great as well, although it can get a bit repetitive with such a small OST and a lot of tracks being reused in both games. The only real complaint I have is that the mouse controls can be a tiny bit annoying at times, and that they worked better with the 3ds touch screen, but that's an incredibly minor complaint. 

Specifically for each game in this collection though. 999 is what started it all. It's fun and exciting and unraveling the larger mysteries is a ton of fun. It's written in a way that seeds of hints and solutions throughout all the different endings, making each path unique, enjoyable, and interesting. The addition of the flowchart to 999, which wasn't present in the DS version, is also very useful as you can skip to wherever you want in the story that you've been before to make different decisions, instead of having to play through the entire game ever single time. No more having to become a speed runner at the #5 cabin escape room. Some of the dialogue can get a bit repetitive at some points, and sometimes the explanations can be a bit long-winded, making you go "We Get It! Just Hurry Up!" Despite that minor complaint, this is easily one of my all time favorite visual novels, and a must play/read for any visual novel fan, or any fan of good storytelling.

VLR is also great, it just doesn't quite live up to 999, as most sequels don't. It has a very different feel from 999, and leans into a lot more fantastical elements as major plot devices compared to 999 using them a lot more subtly. It also is a lot longer with more escape rooms and story paths. This also means that the paths have a lot more overlapping elements with one another, but they can usually be skipped if they've been read before. This game also makes you think, and is a horrific mind bender. I get a headache whenever I try to figure out the ending. This may sound bad, but it's in a very good way. Some characters return from 999, but don't really feel like they did in that game, but are still enjoyable. While it's not as good as the first, it's still a very good game in it's own right, and one I highly recommend as well. 

Both games are fantastic visual novels with incredibly fun and puzzling escape rooms. If you want a bit of a brain bender, or just a fun story, 999 is for you. And if you want your brain to be tied up in noodles, and thrown in a tumble dyer, and to completely challenge your concepts of causality, morality, and linearity, play VLR. And if that's not your thing, play it anyways. I'm pretty sure you'll still enjoy it.

Definitely enjoyable experience playing through both games. The graphics aren't anything insane being ports from DS, but it still looked great in 999 and was mostly fine in VLR. It took me about 15 hours to beat 999 and a bit over 20 to beat VLR.

Puzzles: Nothing insanely difficult, but still challenging enough to be fun to play instead of tedious. Very few instances where I got stuck because I just hadn't clicked the exact right pillow or book to get the next clue as is the problem with a lot of point and click puzzle games. Biggest complaint would be the controls in VLR, it's just incredibly clunky to move around the rooms with the mouse and very slow to do it with arrow keys. Some of the dual solutions in VLR also feel kinda like I was just guessing to get the second one (looking at you cyan door).

Story: Kinda out there, but enjoyable if you like sci-fi storylines even if a lot of how it's explained can be a bit confusing. I enjoyed the puzzles more, but the story still had me guessing most of the way and definitely added to the overall experience. I played with Japanese voiceover and the voiceacting was great.

A warning about 9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors:

This game is not just a port, but an adaptation, and not a very acceptable one at that.

There are two modes that the game can be played in, "ADV mode" and "Novel mode". Unfortunately, the default mode is ADV. ADV mode removes all of the narration and replaces the most important parts (like descriptions of actions and events) with the protagonist, Junpei, thinking aloud. These soliloquies are often unnatural and feel tacked on, but they are necessary without the narration. Even then, presenting the story in this manner is like adapting a novel into a screenplay, but without any additional visuals. All that is left are voiced dialogue boxes and the original mostly static visuals.

Much of the suspense and horror is found in the visceral narration. For example, the description of violence and gore is often done using vivid similes that create disturbing and memorable imagery. Instead, the graphic description of a corpse is replaced with the protagonist simply saying "Blood...Blood and...pieces of flesh..." out loud, along with a picture of blood which was already present to supplement the narration. The atmosphere is also adversely affected in more subtle ways. A scene near the beginning where a character opens a door is written as:

"Then he slowly..

lowered...

the lever..."

Staggering the sentence like this is a simple way to add tension. A simple way to adapt this into a screenplay would be to show the character slowly reaching for the lever, perhaps cutting back and forth between the lever and their face. Without any added visuals, the tension, suspense, and horror in this game is almost completely lost. The characters' additional voice overs are simply not written well enough to replace the narration. Therefore, the only way to experience the story properly is to play in "novel mode". At the very least, the game forces you into novel mode if the narration is too important and complex to be re-written as a soliloquy, although this is only done for story purposes and not for atmosphere.

Novel mode is not perfect either. For one, it adds a blue filter around the screen to show that the protagonist is thinking, which distracts from what visuals the game does have. More importantly, and more adversely impactful, the jarring soliloquies are still present in novel mode, so you have a perfectly fine description followed by a character saying basically the same thing, but worse, out loud. For example, the narration describes a character body slamming a door, followed by the protagonist exclaiming that they body slammed a door. This late voice over would feel tacked on even if this was the only way to experience the story, but because the audience knows that it is an artifact from "ADV mode", they are being constantly reminded of the poor formatting of the narration.

This release is still worth playing simply because it is an amazing story with awesome characters, writing, and music. That being said, it is not a definitive release of the game despite the enhanced visuals, sound, and game mechanics.

Amazing games. It's best to use an ending guide for the first game (999) so you get the bad endings first and reveal the story better. This is not an issue in the second game as routes are locked until you should see them.
The storytelling here is great, as are the characters. It keeps you guessing and theorising as you discover more. VLR is a lot more complex though. The puzzles are generally good, although I prefered 999's a lot more. VLR has extra puzzle solving in each room, as you can find an optional secret file in each one. However, I do not recommend reading them until you finish the game as they contain light spoilers and ruin the flow of the story.
I also found VLR's rooms to be a bit repetitive in appearance compared to 999's, which I thought had more charm. On the other side, VLR is a lt longer than 999 with many more storyline branches. They kinda balance out.
The soundtrack is also very good, some tracks are very memorable. It really helps set the atmosphere.
My biggest complaint is that the Japanese voices and English text often don't match. Some characters have had even had their names changed to make them easier for a Western audience. The English dialogue lines can be quite different for characters, which gives you a different view of their character. In some cases they completely changed some lines.
There's a 3rd game which should answer questions at the end of VLR, which is Zero Time Dilemma. I'm looking forward to it, but hopefully they didn't change the dialogue as much.

I think my hours alone and even profile picture show how much I love these games!
999 was a phenomenal game to experience, and I constantly hope I was able to experience it for the first time again! There are many different puzzles all with varying difficulty, and I mainly adore the varying plot points and how they all connect to one another! The voice acting in English is also pretty on par as well, some good direction going on, along with some familiar names in the roster such as Wendee Lee, got a lot of respect for her! The flowchart system is a nice touch that won't force you to play through the game again and again from the beginning each time just to obtain each ending, so it doesn't feel as repetitive. Adventure Screen (ADV Screen) is totally the way to go with the game since they sort of fibbed up the Novel Screen, trying to replicate it as close to the DS version as possible. All in all, great experience, every ending is worth it!

Virtue's Last Reward is also a great game as well, but it can be more tiresome as there's a LOT more endings in comparison to 999, but they're still all worth it regardless! Something that can be odd to get used to at first though, is the different art style and direction of the game, though you get used to it over time, I swear it! Once more the game refers to a lot of different plot points and then seeing the connection is simply *chef's kiss* beautiful. 

All in all, if you enjoy escape rooms, a bit of mystery, a story with a bunch of plot twists, along with character interaction/development, this is definitely a game for you!

999: Overall, I really enjoyed the process of finding all the endings. The puzzles are relatively simple and don't require you to work through mountains of logic. At the same time, the room details appear to contribute to the overall story and makes playing a point and click puzzle quite engaging. I also enjoyed that you were able to deduct some clues about the story based on the nonary door mechanic and each person's number. Still, the story/game does most of the heavy lifting, you don't have to look up a guide just to find everything.

One thing that I think might be blasphemous to say is that I sometimes hate the writing and pacing of anime and/or VN. When characters pause too long between sentences/emotions, there sentences are unnecessarily long, or they elaborate on one idea for 2-3 minutes each, it puts me off. 999, for the most part, doesn't suffer from that and is mostly about the "Nonary Game" story and escaping the rooms, but it does kind of do it near the end.

The puzzles weren't arbitrary, but they also weren't deeply rewarding. They were just enough to continue and link the story together. And despite it being relatively easy, I kind of liked that because I care more about the story and its twists.

VLR: At the core, VLR stays true to the series. But on the surface, the use of 3D made everything look cheap and unfinished. The dialogue almost seems to double and is full of fluff, but ironically it appears to be done on purpose? There were a few times where it pokes fun at its own dialogue. I skipped almost none of the 999 writing. I suggest you skim on VLR, if you want to save a few hours of time. I just don't understand why they pumped this sequel full of useless dialogue. Once you have read them once, skip Zero Jr. announcements, skim them bickering about who is the bad guy and who is the killer.

In 999, the nonary game aspect was actually somewhat strategic. You could deduce some things based on the events that occur. In VLR, the AB game is largely speculative. Your bracelet is not tied to where you can go anymore, it's just whether you die or not. Some motives were kind of random... The latter half is worth it, but just take the conversations in the first half with a grain of salt.

With regard to most of the puzzles, they was slightly more math and logic involved, but not in a good way. They were much less intertwined with the story itself, compared to 999.

If you're reading this, I want you to know that I have only played the first game (999) as of me writing this review, after I finish the second one, I will edit this and have a different section for the second game. So, depending on when you read this, this review may contain a review for only one or both the games. So, let’s get on with the review.

If the word "bullshit" was a game than this would be it. 999 tells the story of 9 people stuck inside a ship who are forced to play a death game of sort to escape. It's not a new or original premise but I don't care much for originality. The story by itself is pretty interesting and if it was told well enough it could have worked out, but the problem is that it wasn't, not at all. There are so many 'how' and 'why' moments but none of them are answered, the game picks the most convenient answers for itself without considering how stupid its being, add a very weak cast of characters in and badabing-badboom you have a visual novel experience that lacks structure, wit, or any kind of genuine entertainment. The music is generic, character designs are ridiculous and tell nothing of the characters, dialogue is weak and the logic at the 'true end' is just... uh.

The one thing this game does good is confidence. It throws a huge amount of information at you without hesitation, which creates this illusion of logic and structure. You only need to think for two seconds to find out that all that information is crap but at least it’s trying. The puzzles are also pretty nice, there is a lot of variety and its always pretty clear what you have to do while at the same time not making it too obvious.

Now I've shit on this game a lot, so why am I recommending this? Well that's cus I see the appeal of it. If a story is stupid I want it to go all the way with it, if a story is serious I want it to grip me. Stories like this that TRY to be serious are stories I hate but at the same time I know that not everyone is like that, in fact I know most people enjoy this weird middle ground. That's not for me but it is for a lot of people and if you're someone who doesn't need every detail fleshed out like me, then I believe you will enjoy this game. If it wasn't for that full of shit 'true end' even I would have admitted that I had a little bit of fun with it, but that ending ruined the whole game for me.

There is one thing that I think is so bad that I can't see anyone defending it, and that is the forced labor this game puts on the players if they want to reach the 'true ending'. You can't see the true ending until you lose at least once, which by the way is after hours of playing this game. Game if you want to waste my time, waste it by being fun. I think replayability should be a player's choice not a chore. It's okay to have multiple endings and bad endings but it should still be possible to reach the true ending on the first playthrough, after that it should the player's choice if they want to unlock every other ending so that they can know more about the different routes. But having me play through the same story again with only the ending being different - which by the way isn't even an hour long if you read fast and finish the puzzles well - you're just taking away the power of choice that visual novels depend so much on.

That's 999 for you, a game that's not for me but is for a lot of people. I write this review for people who are not sure about buying this game. After reading my review if you think our views are similar, then don't buy this game. If don't like your games becoming a chore, don't buy this game. If you don't want "just because" elements, don't buy this game. But if you're someone who sees the complete opposite of me and you don't mind the things I mentioned and just want a thrill ride, I think this game has things to offer for you, so go ahead. 

Depending on how the second game plays out, I might change my opinion on if I recommend this bundle or not. Till then, see ya.



EDIT: So.. yeah I played the second game which is named Virtue's Last Reward and uh... uhh... my head hurts.

I put this game right above Metal Gear Solid in terms of confusing timelines but also just below Kingdom Hearts. Well in the end my opinion on the second game is almost the same as the first game. There is a lot of bullshit expository dialogue, bad music, bad character design or dare I say even worse (I'm looking at you Alice) and just abysmal dialogue. But a few things have changed for the better even if just a little. First of all, the characters here are more interesting than the first game, I have to applaud this game for using its previous installment to up itself. From the start this game makes it very obvious that the current Nonary game is related to the previous one, but we never know to what extend until much later. It makes you curious about how the stories are connected and that curiosity makes some of the characters here interesting. I was surprised to find myself actually care about some characters here. But ho-ho while some things did get better, some others downgraded hard.

This game looks horrible, it is probably one of the ugliest Visual Novels I have ever played. The first one actually looked good; the character designs might have been bland but the drawings themselves were well done. Clean, simple and had a few frames of animation in there too, like what the hell is wrong with that? With this one they tried to take the modern route and went CG and it looks horrible, when the characters speak they look so goofy that I could not take this game seriously. Also, the controls... ah the controls. Now you can't change scenes with just one click, instead you have to drag the whole screen which feels so slippery. In the previous game if you wanted to face a screen four screens to the right, you click four times to the right, here you have to drag the whole screen to get where you want to, and if you get motion sick easily like me, have a dustbin or a paper-bag near you. Also, I have dual monitors so it was really annoying when my mouse went from one screen to the other cus for some reason the game doesn't keep your mouse inside the game screen. And remember when I talked about how you were forced to replay the game in the first one? Well things just got way worse. Now you don't play this game twice to get the true ending, you play it a million times and it’s so fucking cryptic about it. Get a guide if you want the true ending and if there is anyone who says they reached the true ending without a guide, believe me they're lying. There is no way unless they jumped their consciousness from the future to the past (ahem!).

I've shit, a lot on this franchise again but I still have more nice things to say about it after playing the second game. I think when you look at the story in a grander scheme and not individually, this franchise has a pretty good story overall, it’s a shame that the storytelling for both the games individually are so bad, like realllllly bad, but if you look at it from a franchise point of view it does a pretty good job at making you curious. I'm actually kinda looking forward to playing the third game now cus I am pretty interested about what’s going to happen next, and the puzzles here are nice. They tickle my brain and feel satisfying to solve without them being overly complicated and frustrating, there is a good flow to the puzzles cus each one in a room connects to another until you finally get the password to the safe.

Overall, I'd say that I enjoyed the second game a little more than the first. I have found a new appreciation for the story of the whole franchise but it came at the cost of shutting my brain down for a few hours cus if you think about the whole Nonary game thing, it doesn't make sense cus like what if instead of creating a death game with lives at stake you just.... Talk?

I give both 999 and VLR a 4/10 individually but together I give this franchise a 6/10. So far that is...
good

"Zero Escape" é aquela saga que te faz querer ficar com a bunda na cadeira por horas a fio, querendo saber como que vai se desenrolar o enredo.

A narrative masterpiece, all hail Kotaro Uchikoshi.

善人死亡我强推！！
1.叙事精彩，人物对话，故事背景，环境渲染都写得超棒
2.有的线直接真的让我落泪，人物刻画太棒了
2.我玩的是英文版，英文配音非常amazing，给优秀的叙事和描写画龙点睛。高水准的英文配音是让我从头到尾耐心听完每一句话的最大理由。
3.核心设定和idea非常有趣（打越的正常操作）。当你在什么都不知道的情况下第一次触发主人公的技能的时候，真的会起鸡皮疙瘩。更不要说最后一条线某个地方，震撼我全家的程度。但回忆起之前种种铺垫，又全部在情理之中。
4.密室逃脱的解密并不难，但能恰到好处地让你从长时间的被动信息接受模式，转换成主动探索解密模式。
5.耐心玩完整个游戏真的会收获很多，不仅是核心设定，对话中有非常非常多哲学性的思考，我特别喜欢

btw 我对善人死亡的喜爱要远大于前作999，但它和999的故事连续性还是蛮高的，最好玩完999再来玩善死。

By far my two favourite games of all time. Certainly a unique format of game play combining narrative and problem solving elements. The plot twists in 999 & VLR were so unique and clever that I have struggled to find any book/movie/game that lives up to the complex narrative standards set by Uchikoshi. Agatha Christie's "And Then There Were None" or perhaps David Fincher's "Fight Club" would probably be the closest pop-culture comparisons I could draw, in order to set the stage for what kind of narrative to expect. If you enjoy mysteries, puzzle solving and philosophical conversations then I would strongly suggest this title to you.

I 999! The art, the story and mystery and the mechanics... So unique and intriguing! I was going on to my family about it before I finished it!
.
.
.
And then I started VLR. I... Can't say I liked it as much. The ways of getting around were so lost and it was impossible to finish the game without a notepad and pencil and considering what the game is about, remembering things through transferring your memory and all that... I liked the idea but the execution was definitely lackluster. As well as the art. Or lack thereof.  Using 3D models and such in a game that the previous was 2D is- bold to say the least. At least the models were pretty though, and not funky. 

And a last thought, there were so many ideas and things tossed around in the first one that was completely ignored in answering, such as Alice and a bunch of other things (I only just now recently finish ZTD and I wanted to finish that one first before reviewing, so my apologies for not remembering. It's been well over a year since I finished 999.) My point- the first one was so good! As much as I would have loved answers to the unanswered, I think keeping the mystery would have been 100x better. But... That's just my opinion.

Серия Zero Escape достаточно уникальна в своём роде. Если просто - то это визуальная новелла + escape the room (рекомендую всем людям, любящим загадки, пазлы)
Суть серии игр:
Каждый раз наши герои оказываются заперты в определенном месте и их заставляют участвовать в игре. Зачастую герои не знакомы, и им приходится выбирать - кому доверять, а кому - нет. И так, в борьбе за жизнь, они ищут выход и ответы - почему они здесь оказались.
Плюсы:
+Интересный сюжет
+Множество головоломок
+Визуал 999 (1-ой части, хотя это больше личное, наверное)
Минусы:
-Визуал VLR (2-ой части, 3D модельки очень слабые)
-Соотношение текста к геймплею в VLR (Читать в VLR придётся очень много, но она же раскрывает почти весь сюжет Zero Escape)

Если вам понравилась игра - обязательно поиграйте в Zero Escape: Zero Time Dillema

何を書いてもネタバレになってしまいそうで怖いのですが、緊張感が高いシナリオでストーリー性重視のADVが好きな方にはおすすめできると思います。
シナリオが気になるけれど謎が解けなくて先に進めない、という箇所が全く無かったわけではないですが、自力でなんとかできる難易度でした。

This series has one of my favourite story lines. The gameplay isn't amazing but the story is. I've played these games to 100% multiple times and each time I pickup on more things I missed the last go around.

I definitely recommend both of these games in the series. What is even better is that this game feels totally natural on PC. When i originally played the first game in the series, i played it on my 3ds and i liked the touch screen controls. When i played Virtue's Last Reward on my PS Vita, it felt like a chore sometimes to move around during the puzzle sections. When i started it again on the PC, it felt 10000x better then before. If you are playing these for the first time, then this a great way to go through them.

So far I've only played the first game and i have to say that the story is simply amazing and has plenty of turns and twist. My only complaint is that the dialogue is sometimes a bit unnatural and most of the puzzles in my opinion are way too easy (although this is a mostly story driven game, so the gamplay isn't that important). Also you can definitely tell that this is a port and it is a bit janky, but its nothing game breaking. I very much recommend this game, unless you really hate reading.
我 爱 了

Много я был наслышан об этой игре, но долго откладывал ее из-за английского языка, но наконец-то я созрел и окунулся в эту замечательную атмосферу. Пока я закончил играть первую часть этой игры, поэтому обзор пойдёт от первой части под названием "999". Английский оказался простым, т.к. игра видно рассчитана на подростковую аудиторию. Сюжет обалденный. Запоминающиеся персонажи и они будут полностью раскрыты. Вся сюжетная линия героев озвучена на профессиональном уровне. Музыка своеобразная, но подходящая. Напряжение и интрига держится до самого конца игры. "Что это за игра?", "Почему я сюда попал?", "Кто убийца?"  - будут терзать эти вопросы до самого конца и чтобы получить ответы на все вопросы и расставились их по полочкам на свои места,  придется пройти игру несколько раз, причем сюжет начинается развиваться совсем в другую сторону. Поэтому у игры большая реиграбельность. В сюжете много отсылок к настоящим научным и философским фактам и они очень интересные и заставляют задуматься нам ними. Все это разжевывается и в конце игры ты будешь удовлетворён от целостности и законченности произведения т.к. сюжет очень хорошо проработан. Много интересных головоломок, но они  мне показались простыми, но это не портит впечатление от прохождения, а наоборот заставляет двигаться с интересом по игре дальше. Мой палец однозначно ставит лайк вверх. Игра шедевр. Говорят, что вторая часть будет еще лучше и после прохождения продолжу обзор.
Продолжаю обзор. Пройдена вторая часть Virtue's Last Reward. Разработчики пытались усовершенствовать сюжет и вроде бы у них получилось, но правда слишком накрутили и перемудрили, усложнили события сюжета, что уже сложно все уложить в голове. Новые персонажи, новые мелодии, которые уже стали более атмосферны. Прохождение у меня заняло около 75 часов! Перебор! Честно говоря, под конец я уже устал, но добрался до интригующего конца. Головоломок стало больше и чуток они усложнились - над некоторыми уже пришлось посидеть и попотеть, но проходимы. Захожу вперед - в третьей части пару головоломок мне показались еще сложнее, но опять-таки проходимы. Опять все понравилось. Однозначно рекомендую к прохождению.
Great story, unique puzzles, and an interesting obsession with the number 9. Quickly became one of my favorite series of games alongside Zero Time Dilemma.

Edit: Turning this into a proper review. Up front, the scores are 999 -> 9/10 (kek), VLR -> 11/10.

This is two games, about which I have different thoughts. I will discuss spoiler-free points about both games in bullet points, and then each game individually, with spoilers.

-Escape room gameplay: should not be a selling point. It's not shoehorned in at all, thematically the game is designed around it (see the "gameplay" of danganronpa) but it still runs into every problem that naturally follows from fusing escape rooms with a story. The whole point of story games is that anyone should be able to finish them, so the escape room "puzzles" can never be too difficult or interesting without risking the player getting stuck and very frustrated. It's a lot of find code, decode, enter code. Find everything with point and click, combine items. The second game is better about this but I still got stuck once or twice.

-Art and music: the sprites in 999 still work despite their age because of the nostalgic quality the style carries. I would say I like the 3D models in VLR more than others did, but there are some strange details that are hard to unsee, and could have used polish. The music in both games is fantastic.

-UI/technical: more than serviceable. Fast forward is good to have, but I never even used it, even at points where everyone would. The downtime let me ponder the story because it throws enough burning questions for waiting to be bearable, but if you don't want to wait, you always have the fast forward. Save systems are also good.

-Story: the reason it's 10/10.

[b] FULL SPOILERS BELOW [/b]

[999]

[spoiler] I really did like the twist that basically everyone other than Junpei knows what's going on. It makes some scenes less believable though, as methinks the cast is a bit TOO good at acting. Would have liked to see a bit more inexplicable antagonism as cast members tried to assert power and control of information, but I'm happy with the amount we get. I also liked the introduction of paranormal/pseudo-scientific elements, and it made it less jarring to just accept those things when they were confirmed in-universe. The ending revolving around "boy save girl" for emotional power is a bit corny, but not offensively so. -1 from best expectation. [/spoiler]

[VLR]

[spoiler] This story is the pinnacle of being terrified of what the answer might be, and the fact that you do not know. The answer delivers, everything is believable in-universe, everything is adequately foreshadowed (in ways so subtle they will fly completely over your head the first time without fail), and you are misled completely to the wrong conclusions by what you *are* given over and over again. When K's mask is removed for the first time, I was dealt critical damage. +1 from best expectation, expanded my horizons. The best plot twist(s) in any story ever. [/spoiler]
Support the developer of this game. The series is awesome. A compelling story to say the least.
goood

首先感谢汉化999的汉化组，让我可以完整体验到游戏带来的乐趣
999为该系列的第一部，难度不大，很多地方瞎猜都能过，制作组还特别贴心地给了很多提示，就生怕你卡关过不去（善意满满，对比隔壁某魂）。剧情尚可，逻辑无硬伤，解密部分也比较有趣，另外建议没通关的玩家千万不要手贱百度，一来是少了很多自己解密的乐趣，二来百度一不小心就被剧透了，少了很多悬念。
比较可惜的是第二部善死没有汉化补丁，网上找的都不太好使，没办法只好啃生肉，但还好文本不太复杂，少数几个不会的名词也可以查词典（我用的日语版，不清楚英语版的文本难度）。解密难度第二部新增简单和困难模式，困难模式过不去还可以切换简单模式（从来没见过这么体谅玩家的制作组），打越的剧本一如既往地优秀，可以说善死是三部曲里剧情最好的一部。
最后推荐要入坑的玩家一定要从第一部开始玩，善死如果外语苦手可以找找3DS版，话说这游戏本来就要用3DS才能体会它的精髓吧

(This is only a review of the first game contained in this pack, 999. I haven't finished Virtue's Last Reward so won't comment on it yet. I've kept this review spoiler-free, since this game is best approached with... "zero" knowledge ;) .)

Impressively well-crafted game.

The meat of it are the numerous room escape puzzles, mixing point&click games-style item combination with math, logic and memorization. The puzzles can be tough but the game is generous with hints if you fail repeatedly.

What kept me going until the end was the story though. It's gripping, tense and sinister. There are multiple endings which lets it explore multiple gruesome scenarios. After reaching one or two endings it starts showing you forking points in the story where you can jump to play the small sections which alter the course of events, to go down the paths you've missed. In that way it's very respectful of your time despite requiring multiple playthroughs to see the true ending, since you can also auto-skip all the text you've already seen.

Once the full story is revealed you realize it's impressively well put together, but also very convoluted. Expect having to bend your brain around it. There's also one story element and character which doesn't seem to have a real purpose in the story, slightly detracting from the impact of the final reveal.

I highly recommend it overall, but here are some details that might annoy you depending on your tastes:
- Characters are mostly Japanese manga stereotypes (I did grow attached to them nonetheless)
- Voice acting when it's present is pretty high quality overall, but can get weird sometimes... such as the Nth time when everybody takes turns *panting* or saying *huh* or *hah*.
- Dialogue gets weird at times with everybody spouting out "facts" out of the blue about pseudo-science experiments, alternate history, and other strange topics. Impressively, everything ends up being linked to the story, and you can kind of justify why those people are touching on these topics, but it does feel a bit forced when it happens.

Títulos indispensables que salieron en su momento y no vendieron muy bien. Recomendable a todo el público pero con matices, es decir, si bien ambos títulos son accesibles, el segundo es bastante mas complejo y requiere de más atención, cosa que no es estrictamente negativa. 
Aunque hay que tener en cuenta que este no es para todos los públicos, ya que la mayor parte de la partida, solamente lees texto. Pero de eso tratan las VN.
Además para los que quieran obtener los logros no es nada complicado, solamente con pasarte ambos juegos lo tendrías hecho.

Aunque no todo es positivo, ya que el port es bastante regulero, por no decir mediocre. Que si bien, no tiene bajones de frames, algunas cinemáticas se entrecortan y alguna que otra vez se puede quedar colgado en mitad de la partida. Por otra parte, al parecer, en la segunda entrega, las animaciones parecen inacabadas, como si se cortaran, algo que en su versión original de 3DS y PS Vita no ocurría. Aunque esto no daña la experiencia sino que la entorpece.
Ambos títulos están en perfecto inglés, pero no es nada difícil entenderlo, aunque entiendo que a mucha gente esto le puede echar para atrás.

Por lo demás se puede disfrutar sin problemas, ya que tanto a nivel argumental como sonoro está a la altura de otros tantos títulos. Su ambientación es increíble.

This package includes two games, Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors (999) and its sequel, Virtue’s Last Reward. I've already completed 999 on another platform, so the current playtime is for VLR only, but this review generally applies to both.

In short, the games are very repetitive and poorly written. They constantly pull that annoying anime trope where everyone in the cast says the same thing, just slightly paraphrased, and then the protagonist sums it up for good measure, which not only wastes a lot of time as you have to click through each line but also comes off as incredibly patronizing, as if the author has no faith at all in the audience and keeps beating you over the head with the simplest of concepts. For example, you pick up a key and everyone has to comment on how it is indeed a key and it can be used to open doors, and hey look there's a door over there, I wonder if it's locked and can be opened with the key you just picked up. And then the protagonist goes, okay I'm gonna open it, are you guys ready? I'm really gonna do it, 3... 2... 1... Everyone ready?!

Worse yet, the game telegraphs its twists way in advance, yet the characters keep ignoring important clues to drag it out. Oh, doesn't this look like just the thing we were searching for? Nah, let's toss it. Oftentimes you can easily guess what's gonna happen next, but the characters will still willingly walk into a trap and waste a lot of time. The breaking point for me was when they showed a super obvious clue at a scene of murder, pointing to pretty much the only likely culprit, yet the cast was all like "I wonder what can it mean, this is such a puzzling mystery, who could be the killer?!" And of course it took them hours to put 2 and 2 together, sheesh.

Despite some gore and fanservice and thus the M rating in the West, it does seem like the game was mostly aimed at a younger audience. I can't explain such heavy handed approach otherwise.

Bottom line, if you've already watched your fair share of anime and/or played some other visual novels, then this will only feel like some bottom of the barrel stuff. These games came out almost ten years ago, and I suppose they were somewhat novel back then, hence the people with nostalgia praising this series.

These two games destroyed me and i wouldn't have it any other way. The story told in each of them is masterful; the characters are super emotionally engaging, the plot twists hit real hard, and the suspense and stakes throughout the story kept me on the edge of my seat. I should also mention the second most important part of these games; the puzzles. They're generally pretty tricky and some had me stumped for quite some time, but finally completing them is deeply satisfying. PLEASE buy this, you won't regret it.

I absolutely adore this game, It has an interessting and catchy story to tell as the visual novel part and gameplay wise makes use of an escape room concept. The story also includes quite alot of philosophical subjects.

刚通关999，虽然打越的套路还是和ever17时类似，但不妨碍剧情本身带来的震撼与满足。（貌似nds的上下屏幕能带来更好的游戏体验[spoiler]更方便施展诡计[/spoiler]
因为是冲着剧情来的，感觉部分密室逃脱的解密和剧情本身关联不大，不过后来也圆了回来，[spoiler]为了[灵光一现]嘛[/spoiler]。

最后我永远喜欢田村大魔王（四叶）!

[i]这是头骨厂的又一经典之作，时间与爱的永恒主题，却卓尔不凡[/i]

[spoiler]强烈建议CET6级能没到400分以上的同学买来玩玩，可以练习听力和阅读[/spoiler]

推荐点：
1、系列作品都是基于一定的[spoiler]伪[/spoiler]科学依据所设置的，虽然有些听起来鬼扯，但能自圆其说。
2、作品三部曲衔接的非常出色，能比较完整地将剧情的坑填好。
3、令人惊异的解谜游戏世界观，打破线性叙事规则，借助剧情背景，将玩家的代入感拉满。
4、感人至深的剧情，你会被震撼到，堪比命运石之门的剧情制作。

一些缺点：
1、999（第一部九人游戏）的纯动漫画风很不错，但后面的善人死亡（第二部）和零时逃脱（第三部）均采用3D化二次元的形象，第二部3D建模做的非常劣质，第三部好了一点，但依旧表现力不足[spoiler]Akane黑丝还是香[/spoiler]。这一点相比绝对绝望少女来说有些遗憾。
2、解密内容基本属于智商测验题，本身新意不足，当然不排除有些做的不错的关卡。
3、本游戏在游玩过程中一定要备好纸笔，因为很多时候要记的东西很多，为了通关这个系列我写了十页32开草纸。
4、至今无汉化，但可以寻到补丁。

作为游戏史上不可多得的解密神作，强烈建议大家玩一玩，与其耗散时间做些重复工作（肝网游），不如静下心来泡杯咖啡，用三四个小时的时间沉浸在一段惊心动魄且感人至深的故事当中。如果你同时也是解密爱好者的话，你会感谢我的推荐。

I want to make something perfectly clear. If you're here for puzzles and escape rooms, then I can wholeheartedly recommend both of the games in the "Zero Escape: The Nonary Games" bundle. [b]However,[/b ]if you want the classic "Spike Chunsoft" intrigue you got from, say, a Danganronpa game, then I can only recommend the first title. (Not Virtue's Last Reward)

I'll admit to not having finished the game (VLR) yet, and post this with the understood risk that it could get better later, but the things I want to gripe about now aren't justifiable even if the game hands out sugar-coated apples and blowjobs at the end.

First of all, the repetition. Jesus Christ, the repetition. This game remained conscientious of the player's experience and gave us a 'skip' function for dialogue you've already seen before. Great! Except that sometimes it blatantly doesn't work. Sometimes you've already played through the other route where your [spoiler]watch's color and solo/pair text[/spoiler] change to the exact same thing you're seeing now. And still, if there is a single character of difference between that route and the one you're on now, the game forces you to space through it in real time. It doesn't help that, too, that [spoiler]over half of the endings in VLR are 'bad endings'-- which wasn't a problem in the first game, because there were like 7/8 unique ones, and even the bad endings add something to the story.[/spoiler] But in VLR, that isn't true. Most of them add absolutely nothing to the story, and just kind of seems like a punishment for curious players, or people like me who aren't satisfied until [spoiler]they've seen all the endings.[/spoiler]

And, and this is major spoiler territory for something about the nature of the game itself (up to approximately 2/3 of the routes completed) so if you don't want anything spoiled for you, don't click on the upcoming black text. Without spoilers, let me just say that this game treats its characters with so little  care or attention to detail, it's hard to decide if they're trying to justify all the route-y spouty bullshit, or just jerking the player around. [spoiler]And what I mean by that is that characters in the game vote however is most expedient to the plot of the game. For instance, Tenmyouji, in the route where you choose the middle-most door as your first door, will choose 'Betray' if you choose Ally (and I haven't tried it yet, but I'm damn certain he probably chooses 'ally' if you choose betray.) But what gets me is... this is the ONLY time Tenmyouji is a solo player and chooses betray. NEVER, IN ANY OTHER ROUTE DOES HE DO THAT. And the explanation he gives for it is 'How did I know I was supposed to trust you when I've just met you?' To which I audibly slammed my hands on the desk and said "For fuck's sake! you trusted Clover, Luna  AND Dio (admittedly, probably because Quark had teamed with Dio and he wouldn't expect Quark to vote against him.) and you've never met any of those three!"

Then there's also the bit where 'big puppy energy' K will betray you to get out of the game early, when even if he's given chances to do that to other people, he chooses not to. The ONLY person who acts consistently throughout every single route (and yes, I'm aware that I've not completed every route, so they still have time to fuck this up too.) is Luna. In pairs, it may be different, but when she's alone, every SINGLE AB game, she chooses ally. [/spoiler]

TL;DR: I can recommend the first game in this two-pack no matter what you're expectations are. VLR, however, drops the ball and never picks it back up with inconsistent characters, contrived connections between routes, and way, WAY too many bad endings that do nothing for the greater plot. Game 1: 4.5/5 Game 2:3/5

Deux excellents visual novels, à l'intrigue aussi tordue que fascinante à suivre. Les rebondissements sont légions et invitent toujours à essayer les nouvelles routes, pour découvrir les secrets cachés derrière cet univers et ces personnages qu'on apprend à adorer progressivement. Les parties "escape room" sont quand à elles très bien dosées, toujours équilibrées pour nous donner de quoi suffisamment réfléchir sans passer des heures à tourner en rond. 

Il faut bien entre 65-70h pour compléter les deux jeux à 100%, ce qui en fait en plus de ça un investissement très rentable.

Un des bémols que je retiendrais tout de même, est l'aspect visuel de Virtue's Last Reward, dont les graphismes 3D vieillots font assez tâches sur grand écran à côté de 999 ; ce qui n'empêche pas, une fois lancé dans l'aventure, de pleinement profiter du titre.

Zero Escape é uma série de jogos que misturam  o gênero visual novel com puzzle, tornado o game uma experiência única.
Não tenho muita experiência com visual novel porque nunca senti muito interesse no gênero, entretanto, achei a ideia da série ZERO ESCAPE muito legal e resolvi jogar pra ver como era.
O resultado foi que não me arrependi nem por um segundo. A história é uma das melhores que já vi em jogos de videogame, é impossível você saber o rumo que ela vai tomar e como vai tudo acabar, simplesmente sensacional.
Devo avisar que apesar de ser um jogo muito bom, também é complexo, sendo necessário entender sobre alguns conceitos de física, matemática e afins para compreender completamente. Além disso alguns puzzles são bem complicados, sendo assim o jogo não é para todos.
Se você busca uma história surpreendente e que desafia o convencional, esta série é pra você!
Agora só me resta jogar o último jogo da trilogia, que infelizmente não está incluso no pacote do Nonary Games.

After only finishing 999, I can say that this is a phenomenal game. Everything about 999 lands amazingly. It's story made me want to play through all the endings, and the final ending was one of the best endings ive ever seen. I can't recommend 999 enough. If you like visual novels full of mystery, interesting random facts, cool puzzles, good characters, huge plot twists and lots of shenanigans, this is the perfect series of games.
I started these games as a recommendation for liking Professor Layton and Ace Attorney games, and I am glad I did play. The games are quite distinct but both share the puzzle, mystery, visual novel type.
The characters are sometimes serious, sometimes hilarious, which brings some comic relief giving how dark are the stories. I really love the main characters, especially the main character from 999, Junpei. They have some relatable traits and don't present themselves as godlike characters. They are human like any of us.
In 999 you are stuck with eight other people in a boat, and you have to look for the 9th door. Each one of you has a bracelet with a number. In order to accomplish that you have to search all the possible doors and seek a way out. Each door you search has a number in which only a certain amount of people may come in, following the rule that the digital root of their numbers is the number on the door. There are some possible combinations and the goal is to get out alive. But who is behind this kidnapping and what was the intention? Those are important questions that slowly begin to be answered. The clues are there but the twist is marvelous.
Virtue's last reward follows a similar logic but in this game you don't search doors with number combinations, but with colour combinations. After each round you need to vote an ally or betray game in which your lives are at stake.
Your main character is Sigma, a pervert guy with a good heart. You also have my favourite character from the whole series, Luna. The endings have each character name, and Luna one really made me cry (prepare the tissues).
This game is really good and the longer from the series. There are also some challenging puzzles and a special non canon ending if you play on hard and get all the gold files. This game has a really mind blowing twist I wasn't expecting, especially because 999 was already really good. But damn, Uchikoshi really managed to surprise me again. Not all the characters were as likeable as the first game, but I liked them, nevertheless.

In terms of visuals I would have preferred if they could have stayed as in 999 ( I really love Kinu Nishimura character design), but despite the 3D in VLR, I really enjoyed the game.

The ost is marvelous. In 999 it was perfectly used, and because of that, I was really scared all the time, especially when "Trepidation" started playing.

I really love the series and I love to talk about the characters and the story. 
I even bought 999 for the DS and I plan to buy the other games physically because I really love Zero Escape.
It is my favourite game series and I hope you enjoy it too!
Please play Zero Escape (and AI: The Somnium Files!)!
One of the most interesting ludo-narrative experiences out there, no other visual novel series impacted me deeply the way the Nonary Games did.

Nonary game è composto da due giochi.

Il secondo (per quanto mi piacciano fino alla morte gli escape room game) lo detesto con tutto il cuore. Non sono riuscito a finirlo non tanto per la difficoltà del gioco, ma per la LENTEZZA che mi ha accompagnato per tutta la durata del gioco. E come se non bastasse è presente un backtraking assurdo. Questo vuol dire che per andare avanti ti devi sorbire gli stessi dialoghi e anche vederti tutte quelle C***O di transizioni da una stanza all'altra (le quali possono essere accellerate....ma dato che ce ne sono un botto sono comunque un enorme spreco di tempo). Se poi ci aggiungiamo una storia poco avvincente...ho droppato il gioco senza pensarci due volte.

In 999, the characters and mysteries are very flat. Character's will ramble on and on about extremely specific psuedo-science they just so happen to have read in a book. Everything feels very shoehorned in. The only good payoff is identifying the murderer. Escape room puzzles are exceedingly easy.

VLR is a huge improvement over 999. Characters feel fleshed out, and the mysteries and twists have excellent payoffs. There were several problems I had with the game while playing, but they were answered by twists. There are a lot of very cool aha-moments in this game. Escape room puzzles are much better and the bonus puzzles within in room were a cool idea.

The biggest downgrade is in the art. The first game has great 2d anime sprite with low-poly 3d environments. I love it! The second game is all 3d models which haven't aged well at all. Characters look very ugly and are less expressive [spoiler]Seriously. Clover bizarrely smiles even when she's extremely upset[/spoiler].

So, what can I say...
I indeed had fun with these two games, but not as much as I would like.
Although the 999 and Danganronpa series are similar, they feel quite different. 999 is more about puzzles and Danganronpa is more about investigation. Maybe that is the reason but I found Danganronpa to be the more enjoyable of the two. 

Both "999" games in this package have a deeper/harder to grasp story that, for me at least, is a positive. The problem is that it becomes too complicated for its own good, and that is not to mention some existing questionable issues plot-wise. VLR particularly felt a bit too long, and by the end I was just storming trough the puzzles, using a guide, in order to reach the endings. You add that to the bad graphics, annoying scenes of "map walking" and doors opening and closing, and quite a couple of jokes that really ended up feeling out of place, and I can argue that VLR is the weakest game here (if comparing it to the 2 first Danganronpa's and 999, but that doesn't change the fact that Danganronpa 2 is pretty bad when it comes to it's background plot too).

Even after saying that, I would still recommend this package, but not as strongly as I would like. Maybe a good way to express my thoughts is by saying this: I'll surely buy the third installment in the Danganronpa series but only maybe buy the third one in the 999 series.

It has:
- a compelling story that touches on sci-fi and philosophy
- colourful cast of characters with depth (some more than others)
- escape room puzzles (second game's ones are harder than the first but they have an easy mode)
- around 50 hours of gameplay for both games
- so many twists and turns that if the puzzles don't give you headaches, the plot twists will
- AND a cute mascot in the second game!

Keep in mind that while it's a puzzle solving game, majority of the time it's a visual novel so there will be a lot of reading in between gameplay. If you're not a fan of that, you might get turned off. But if you don't mind that sort of thing as well as love a mystery sci-fi setting, I'm sure you'll enjoy this game.

游戏是好游戏，强烈推荐在模拟器上游玩！
那么……为什么不推荐呢？
不推荐只是针对steam这个版本。

玩的是999。

原作是nds平台上的游戏，利用了nds上下双屏的特点，上屏主要展示人物对话，下屏主要展示细节描写，例如人物动作描写，环境描写。
steam版只有一个窗口，不能同时显示两个屏幕，玩的时候可以点击按钮，在冒险屏幕（类似上屏主要显示人物对话）和小说屏幕（类似下屏显示细节描写，但是也会显示人物对话）之间切换。

冒险屏幕看起来有点第一人称的感觉，游戏体验上会好点，但是会漏掉很多细节描写。
小说屏幕看起来完全就是第三人称叙事，玩起来会有怪怪的感觉，尤其是玩过打越钢太郎其他作品的人一定明白这种怪怪的感觉是什么。
如果来回切的话……实在是太麻烦了。
原作利用了nds上下双屏叙事就没有steam版这种割裂感，更加自然。

当然了，如果只是这样倒还不至于不推荐。


更关键的是，原作上下双屏叙事可以让故事更加……再说可能要剧透了，原作玩到结尾会明白整个故事的来龙去脉。但是steam版玩到结尾只能让人一头雾水，因为只有一个窗口。

说的不是很清楚，为了不剧透只能打个不太恰当比方：
假如有红色颜料和蓝色颜料。
原作既能看到红色颜料，又能看到蓝色颜料，还能看到红色颜料和蓝色颜料合在一起后形成紫色。
steam版只能看到红色颜料 或 蓝色颜料，而且不能混合。虽然能想象出来紫色是什么样的，但是不能实际体验到蓝色和红色混合后形成紫色还是很遗憾，总感觉体验上缺了什么。

所以说，这个不推荐就来自于体验上的缺失。


第二部打算在模拟器上玩好了，而且steam版也没有中文。

首先，吹爆

其次，感想

一代全结局通关二十小时左右足矣

即使卡关也会给出由浅及深的点播与暗示
当然理科储备“过硬”应该不会“宕机”（笑）
体验完整剧情建议攻略所有结局

I've been a fan of the series ever since I played it in High School on the DS, by which I mean 999. As a fan of mystery stories, supernatural, and escape games, the Zero Escape series easily filled up all my requirements. While I have a few issues with the save and reload function, it doesn't really lessen the enjoyment I felt while playing this game. The replayability value also makes it worth the full price as you uncover the mystery with each replay. All in all, I recommend this game.

3DSでの販売時から気になっていたけど、未プレイだった本作。セールを機会にようやくプレイしました。
本作の評価は、他の方々がすでにレビューしている通りですが、私もいくつか挙げておきます。

*******

【999】
キャラクタに愛着がわく作品です。
セブンのやたら文語的で長ったらしい状況説明を聞かされるのだけはマイナスポイントですが…。時間ないっていうのにいつまで喋り続けるんだあのオッサンは…。
クリア後に感想サイトをめぐっていたときに、ノベル文体とアドベンチャー文体での表現が違うという記載を見て、実際に確かめてみて、鳥肌がたちました。善デスよりも「指摘されてから気付く伏線」が多い印象がありました。

【善デス】
拙いＣＧは、最初こそ違和感はあるものの、慣れたら気にならなくなりました。
最大の問題点は「999」よりも冗長な演出が多かったことです。正直に言うと、そのせいで退屈で仕方なく眠気が増してきて10分もプレイできないときもありました。謎が判明しだしてからは画面に食いつくようにプレイし続けましたが…。
逆に、脱出ゲームの面白さは確実に「999」よりもパワーアップしていました。「999」とは違い、必要な情報を実際にメモしなくてはいけない場面が数多くあります。ノートにパスワードをメモしておいたり、考えうる組み合わせをいくつも書き出して計算してみたり…　個人的には、すごく楽しかったですね。
フルボイスをうたってるくせに主人公にはボイスつかないのかよ？手抜きか？と思っていたら、まさか最大の伏線でありネタバレであったとは思いもしませんでした…。どうりで全員揃っているはずの場面でシグマの姿だけ描写されないはずだ…。

*******

総合的に評価するとオススメな作品です。スパチュンは定期的にセールもしてますので、そこを狙ってみたらいかがでしょう。
I received this game as a gift, but would buy it myself in a heartbeat. I grew up on puzzle games like Myst and Portal, so this is a fun visual novel twist on that genre. Highly recommend!

Recommended because I enjoyed 999 a lot for its solid gameplay and mind-blowing twists. Not sure if everything holds up under scrutiny, but it's the sort of game where the momentum and atmosphere pull you along for the ride well enough that you don't question it in the moment.

Unfortunately, that kind of falls apart when it comes to the sequel, Virtue’s Last Reward. Hopping around timelines with the flowchart creates a sense of disorientation that works to put you in the mind of the protagonist, but the branches are too wide compared to 999's tight plotting, and the twists are just too much to maintain suspension of disbelief. The gameplay also felt less fun and I found myself looking up puzzle walkthroughs a lot, but I'm not sure if that was an issue with the puzzles specifically or just that the length of the game got tiring.

So 999 hits a sweet spot, and I highly recommend it for fans of visual novels and adventure games, but VLR gets kind of annoying and ridiculous as it goes on, and feels like it really needed someone to dial things back. Since it's a longer game, it also accounts for almost two-thirds of my 42-hour play time. I'd still say this is worth getting on sale, but maybe assess the price as if it's just for one 15-20 hour game.

One of the most fun Escape games out there! Yes it is a two in one special. 9/10!!!

[h1] TL;DR [/h1]
This series combines both Visual Novel and Escape genres and twists the way they normally play out. Anyone that is a fan or is in the mood for Escape games or Visual Novels will definitely love this series.

[h1] THE PLOT [/h1]
The story of this game is what kept the 10/10 rating for me. I was able to tell between who is the "bad guy(s)" & "good guys" very early on in the game. Moreover, there were several holes in logic after viewing the ending for 999. However, that doesn't mean that this game's plot is average or bad in any way. In fact, the ending(s) blew a lot of what i had in mind out the window.

[h1] GAMEPLAY [/h1]
The gameplay follows a variety of puzzle solving mechanics. With certain mechanics that is consistent throughout the various puzzles, every puzzle is still unique in it's own way. While playing the game, you will never feel any repetitiveness nor feel completely lost without any hints.

I can recommend this bundle, at full price, purely for the first game it contains: 999; 9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors. It's, simply put, an excellent piece of story-telling that makes use of not just its setting and characters, but also its very medium. The room escape games in between are pretty good as well, though they fall into a trap of a major theme of the game always being the answer.

This port is in some ways better than the original DS game, and worse in others. Technically, it's a bit of a hack-job, with settings menus only accessible in odd ways, but it includes a much-needed jump feature to go to any point in the game you've already seen. The writing also suffers a bit in this port, though not to such a degree that it affects the story. This port does have voice-acting, though. Overall, I recommend this port over the original, but you really can't go wrong with either.

Things get a bit more complicated with the second game: VLR; Virtue's Last Reward. First, the good. The puzzle design is much improved. No longer are the solutions identical. You actually have to think your way out of the boxes you're put in.

If you'd like to avoid some vague story spoilers, just know that I ultimately can recommend VLR, though not as highly as 999.

[spoiler]Right, the story. 999 is largely played not unlike a straight mystery. However, throughout the game there are hints of something supernatural/sci-fi. VLR steers into this direction, hard. This isn't bad, per sé - I certainly had fun with it - but it takes something away from the relatively down-to-earth plot of 999. Play VLR only if you like or don't mind the supernatural elements from 999.[/spoiler]
Good VN/puzzle games, 999 becomes a bit inconsistent towards the end but VLR is great.

算上999,104小时全成就通关，不过总感觉差了一堆东西没讲。（以下涉及部分剧透）




999就先不说，虽然我999也没玩太懂，主要是剧情到了出沙漠就没有后续了，就算是分离的故事你好好把故事讲完好么，善人死亡感觉也是这个尿性，西格玛是个色老头这事儿刚爆出来，剧情都感觉正在热点，高潮上疯狂开始蹦跶了，结果突然就我去拯救一下世界回到了过去就没了。
没了？？
这感觉就像我满脸笑容拉了一半的⑩突然卡在中间不再前进。


好了说回剧情，我不明白的最关键就是ファイ（法医？），虽然身为女主位，戏份也是女主的戏份，不过到最后我连她是来干啥的都不知道。看了他们的解释感觉都没对她有所提及，最后化身成K（克隆那个西格玛）去找她谈话也是，结果她到底是个啥身份也还不清楚，感觉这计划有她没她关系不大，为什么必须要让她和西格玛一起去打基地也不知道，带我四叶妹妹一起去不好么，关键时刻还可以看豹纹。
（剧透结束）




其他感觉解释得很暧昧的地方也有几处，总之就是游戏爆点让我非常爽快，我只能说不愧是平成莎士比亚的打越钢太郎，不过你要让我爽就让我一直爽到来一发为止好么，这结局结得简直是PC搞到一半说时间到了一样让人难受
下一个，应该是第三部把，不知道零时困境和前两作关系大不大。总之今晚决定先下来试试。

首先是关于剧情部分

（[b] 以下内容含有严重剧透 [/b]）

先说一句，这剧情我是真的服，各种细节，各种伏笔，还是各种隐藏的线索。而游戏过程就感觉自己是在砌一座金字塔，一开始分散开来的各种线索就是金字塔的基地，建的时候完全不明白这到底是啥，建成后有什么用，到底为什么要把这一块砖摆在这，但是一旦最后一块砖砌上去了，你才会发现这到底是一个怎样的庞大的精美的建筑物（感觉打越都要把时间线玩出花了，以至于善死后面讲述穿越原理的时候基本没懂emmm）。不过总的来说感觉个别设定还是扯，999还好，毕竟ice9什么的确实挺符合打越宇宙的，但是善死的病毒就有点一言难尽，思考速度变慢就算了，为什么还能引起自杀冲动？？？完全理解不能。

除了整体剧情强到炸之外，有一个人真的要拿出来说一说的就是淳平，感觉淳平和茜真的就是一段孽缘，从最开始茜因为淳平给的玩偶死亡，到后面茜为了被拯救欺骗淳平，再到淳平发现真相去解救茜，最后茜的身影消失在沙漠，淳平则是找茜找了一辈子，以至于后面因为想见茜，参加了第3次9人游戏，讲道理，在别的世界线，淳平又一次的见到被杀死的茜到底是怎样的心情简直完全不敢想象，即使是真结局，淳平见到了茜，已经认不出原来身影的茜，和完全变了的淳平见面的时候，两者又是什么心情呢，真结局最后，看到淳平拿着那张茜小时候对着他笑的照片，说[b] 这已经不是那个时候的茜了，那个时候的茜已经哪里也不存在 [/b]的时候真的要哭出声，心疼我淳平工具人，而且看最后剧情，零之困境怕不是淳平又要参加一次。

就游戏性来讲，整个游戏的解谜成分非常强，各种谜题层出不穷，奇怪的知识也增加了很多（虽然总是在seek a way out 和梦境扫描开始窜频），但是有几个瞎几把乱点的小游戏我是一定要吐槽一下的，没错我说的就是善死的骰子骰子和骰子（其实还有食材库冰块和监控室的颜色点点点），感觉这种小游戏就是完全不知道原理是什么，只能在那瞎几把点，靠运气，特别是Q的房间里面那个骰子，我都要点吐的都没点出来，点出数字的话滚多几下就行了，但是方向都是要一致的就是真的难搞了，不知道easy模式是不是也要求方向一致，毕竟我当时点嗨了忘记换模式了（虽然最后还是找了攻略，并且还找到的是成功最短路径emmm）

总的来说，神作不愧是神作吧，让我喊完这一声打越nb之后就去玩零之困境了。

最后

Tu fui, ego eris.

I was you.
You will be me.

终于1+2白金了。
首先这个系列绝对是值得一玩的游戏。
打越的游戏之前玩过很多，所以对于核心诡计有种“啊果然是这样”会心一笑的感觉，但仍有很多感到惊喜的意外设计，方便的Routes系统也是剧情相关的一部分，让人代入感很强（我希望所有带分支的游戏都有这么方便的系统x），开始玩2的时候我还在想为什么这一作主角没有配音了，最后才知道这应该也是诡计的一部分，打越真是太棒了！
游戏画面来说，我觉得1要优于2，虽然现在的潮流是全3D，但2的建模真的是太惨裂了，相比起来1的立绘+动画就体验极佳。
解谜方面，1有点过于简单和重复（16进制你要玩多少次），2总体比较适中，其中hint视角和玩家解谜视角的差异误导还是蛮惊喜的（比如鸡尾酒顺序）
剧情方面，1一气呵成的紧张感真的太棒了！作为一个故事紧凑且完整。2的坑挖得太深了导致篇幅大幅长于1，剧情锁导致玩家反复经历前两轮游戏，走地图开关门之类的演出又很冗长，完全没有紧张感。最后紫色美少女（x）那段话本应是让玩家头皮发麻的打算吧，但对于经历了这么多打越剧本的人来说就。。。有种“行了行了知道了，对没错是我本人”的感觉吧。
投票时无论是选择背叛还是被别人背叛，感觉都很难受，尤其是被刚以为建立了信任的角色背叛;_;会让人痛感副标题“善人死亡”其中的深e意yi。
打越知道剧本比较长怕玩家无聊，在里面插入了很多搞笑剧情（和冷笑话x），笑果还蛮好的233（ゼロウサ的羊応答和執事応答233）
虽然对2提出了一点不满，但前提还是瑕不掩瑜，如果你还没玩过，不要犹豫，买就对了！

最后，说好的ファイ和四葉的スク水呢？
