Great writing, great characters, great music, and great puzzles - both games are a blast to play through, with lots of memorable moments and insane twists. A lot of the plot points and conversations seem like nonsense at first, but that's part of these games' charm - at the end of each game all of the pieces come together in a beautiful way. The 3D models in Virtue's Last Reward are kind of a step down from the 2D sprites in 999, but VLR definitely has the better puzzles. If you like visual novel puzzle games like Ace Attorney or Danganronpa, give these games a go.
补票党，非常出色的密室逃脱+推理解谜类作品，推荐把所有结局都走一遍，每个结局里都有对真相的一部分解释，将所有结局的事实拼凑起来就能察觉到真相，这个核心的叙述诡计真的是太强了！

Premièrement, cet article ne contient pas 1, mais 2 jeux: 

1-9 Persons 9 Hours 9 Doors (999)
2-Virtue's Last Reward (VLR)

Les deux sont du même type, à savoir un mélange entre le point and click et le visual novel.

Petite mise en place du scénario (no spoil)
Dans ces jeux d'enquêtes vous incarnez un personnage qui pour une raison que je n'avancerais pas ici pour vous garder la surprise, se retrouve coincé avec un certain nombre d'individus. Votre objectif est évident:
Comprendre comment vous vous êtes retrouvés ici, pourquoi vous, et qui vous a foutu dans ce bourbier (ah ouais et vous devez vous tirer de là).

Pour moi, ce bundle est un pur chef d'oeuvre, et je ne peut que conseiller l'achat si vous êtes un fan d'enquête, d'escape game ou simplement si vous appréciez les histoires bien écries. 

Les illustrations sont soignées, la musique sait marquer les mémoires et l'écriture ne vous laissera pas de marbre face aux choix que vous devrez faire dans votre aventure. Car oui, ce jeu ne se joue pas qu'une fois. Si vous voulez profiter de l'expérience à son maximum, vous devrez le finir en suivant plusieurs chemins possibles.
Le mieux dans l'histoire? Vos choix mènent VRAIMENT sur des fins différentes (HEIN TELLTALE GAMES!!!) et toutes vous accorderons ce petit frisson. Un must have: 19/20 - achetez la suite bordel

Debido a que esto es un "pack" con 2 juegos, iremos por partes

999: Obra maestra, probablemente de mis juegos favoritos, todas las sensaciones hicieron click de forma constante, las escape rooms fueron divertidas y traían situaciones y personajes entretenidos, fue un buffet de principio a fin, literalmente tengo 0 problemas con este juego y a cualquier persona que quiera empezar una novela visual interesante se la recomiendo de forma instantánea.

VLR: Mientras que no fue un mal juego, el buen sabor de boca que 999 me dio durante TODO el trayecto, no fue nisiquiera parecido. Exactamente lo mismo me pasó con Danganronpa 1 y 2, siendo el primero mi favorito y el segundo mi DR menos preferido.

Tuve bastantes problemas con VLR, especialmente con el protagonista, quien era muy blando, hacía las típicas bromas de mm tetas (por que sí, es un juego de 2010, bear with it), Clover no era quien conocía, y los personajes recurrentes de 999 no eran quienes recordaba,eran personas totalmente distintas, a diferencia de [spoiler] Junpei [/spoiler] quien se notaba que era el mismo, pero mucho más maduro.

Las escape rooms eran estúpidamente complicadas de entender, y súper fácil de resolver comparadas con el primer juego, donde literalmente creabas una bomba de hielo juntando componentes químicos
en VLR es literalmente TODO matemática.
Y mientras que no es algo del todo malo, es una forma "cheap" de hacer puzzles, el mismo problema lo tiene el primer juego del Profesor Layton, donde su mecánica base es hacer puzzles, pero ya en los siguientes juegos eso mejora.
En 999 los puzzles eran más interesantes, daban interacciones con los personajes más allá de "mm tetas bikini jaja tengo un tic que digo meow cuando hablamos de gatos lol" como hacen en VLR. En 999 podías investigar el mismo objeto 30 millones de veces para que te den un diálogo estúpido que te saque una sonrisa, aquí no, como mucho te dan un hint que te confunde más

Pero la peor adición de todas, sin duda fue el hard/easy mode, limitando tus ganas de querer hacer un puzzle, para esto hicieron un band-aid fix que son los golden files, que solo dan información que ya viste, intentando meter bromas pero ninguna de ellas son graciosas o siquiera se consideran bromas, por que es texto. Las bromas no funcionan igual cuando un amigo te lo cuenta con una sonrisa intentando aguantarse la risa, que cuando uno lo escribe y dice "jaja es broma
en realidad es X
nooo mentira ¡¡¡XDD!!! en realidad es esto
LOL YOU TOUGHT!!!"

like
dude, stop

igual soy consciente que le tiro mucha mierda, pero es por que lo que amaba a 999 y lo diferenciaba de otros juegos era eso. Aquí se centraron en hacer una historia complicada y mostrarla de forma complicada, nisiquiera te muestran los locks como hacían en 999, aquí tienes que clickear manualmente y revisar con tu propia memoria si X camino cambió, algo que nunca tuve problema en hacer, pero me alegraría ver el sistema de 999 otra vez.

El final y la trama en sí, es algo complicado de analizar, y esto es por que Kentaro AMA escribir el plot twist y de ahí sacar varias ramas para que se acomoden con el ending, como hacer un laberinto alrevez. Que no está mal, pero una vez te das cuenta, se nota y puede llegar a agobiar. Especialmente la puerta cyan, donde habían varias partes donde se olvidaron en poner el botón de skip por que ya lo habías visto, cuando las otras si lo tienen

Luego, el sistema de puertas cromáticas a diferencia de los números, fue más aburrido e innecesariamente complicado de entender. Sí, Phi te explicaba los ordenes so, ¿Por qué deberías hacerlos tú en tu cabeza? además, ya no había tanto riesgo como en 999 so tampoco es que te moleste con quien entrarías más allá del ending que te toca. Está bien, pero a diferencia de Lotus, Phi toma AÑOS en explicar quienes van por cuál puerta, y uno solo spamea el click hasta que le dejen elegir, ya que de por sí las opciones salen como "ENTRAR A LA PUERTA ROJA CON JUAN Y JACINTA" o "ENTRAR A LA PUERTA VERDE CON JACINTA Y PABLO". No era para nada necesario hacer eso.

¿Pero saben que más era innecesario? la hora y media de cinemáticas (en total) que NO se pueden skipear y ves más de una vez si quieres obtener el true ending. de verdad, fue MUY agobiante y asqueroso quedarse quieto sin hacer nada durante 46 segundos seguidos, y tampoco habían diálogos, solo era para que aprendas a ubicarte en un mapa...
¿Puedo preguntar para qué? la única razón que le veo el "ubicarse" en el mapa, marcando el recorrido, es por que 
1: Se planeaba hacer una parte jugable como danganronpa despair girls, donde era en tercera persona te movías y bla bla bla
2: Querían hacer como las otras novelas visuales populares, que sí tenían un mapa
3: Querían que algún fan recreara su mapa en Roblox o algún lugar similar, ya que daban hasta los planos.

Realmente ESO si fue una pérdida de tiempo.

Ya con la mente calmada, puedo decir que SI, Si recomiendo ambos juegos, el final de VLR es fantástico y da pié a Zero Time Dilemma, y 999 que sucede antes que VLR (y es el primer juego), tiene un final incluso mejor, donde realmente se nota el amor que se le puso al proyecto.
Altamente recomendado, lo único, ten en mente que son juegos bastante viejos, 2007 (versión remake) y 2009. Tendrán algunas cosas mal, pero no es del todo su culpa.
If you like visual novels and puzzles, then this is for you.

So far I have only played 999 through twice to get the true ending and I can only this so far.
WOW. This is a masterpiece. Thoroughly gut wrenching until the end.

The only really disappointing thing I can say is that playing through the whole thing twice, to get the "Safe ending" and then again to get the True Ending you learn pretty much the whole story and about all the characters and why they are there...except Lotus. Apparently you can only learn her backstory by getting one of the other bad endings. I wish I had known about that. I could only think at the end. "Wait, what about Lotus? She's the only one I know basically nothing about..." During the flashbacks of the true ending you get glimpses of something that provides a hint but nothing direct.

Other than that, I am completely blown away and can't believe it took me this long to finally play this series.


My one technical complaint:
[list][*] This is "Remastered" but clearly it seems like all the assets were remastered for 544p and the PSVita release and then just upscaled for the PS4/PC release. The other major problem with this texture compression (and the resulting banding)
This is unfortunate because the original DS game's character sprites (Much like Ace Attorney on the GBA/DS compared to the 3DS Trilogy release) don't have any texture compression at all. Meaning You have completely clean 1:1 pixel art. While the "remastered" versions suffer from typical heavy DXT5 compression artifacts that leave a lot of rough edges on the character art, UI assets and background art. 
I hope someday there can be a 2nd re-release that fixes this.

You can use Reshade to help with the banding (don't go crazy though)
[/list]

Also: I'm not going to lie. My primary motivator for finally wanting to play this game was the sweet sweet promise of a fantastic Shinji Hosoe soundtrack.

EDIT:

After finishing both, man VLR leaves a  mind f***ing bitter taste in your mouth. It is dark, and has no qualms about making you feel, sad, confused and wondering what the hell is going on at the end. There is no real payoff. I mean, supposedly VLR is supposed to be "lighter" in tone compared to 999. And it feels completely the opposite. In one word, VLR is despair. lol

In that respect 999 is a better game on it's own. (Aside from the lack of a real happy ending for a certain pair of people). I hope ZTD is more like 999.
算是跨了挺久的补票，pc版999的处理比我想象中的要好，打越的剧本还是如此优良，也感谢汉化组的辛勤付出，能够让我再度回味这两款作品
This is a very good set of games. Worth the purchase

Waiting till I finished the whole trilogy before I wrote my review. As a whole, i think the series is great with this bundle of the first two games being the strongest part. They are games that need time to get going due to the VN nature of the story and game play outside of the puzzle rooms, but if it hooks you, you are in for a crazy and fun ride. 999 is a great start to the franchise and it is the smaller of the two games here. Keep that in mind. If you play 999 and feels too long or slow, that is the short game. VLR is probably the strongest of adding more mystery and sleuthing to the VN portions of the game so it didn't feel too much like long pauses between puzzle rooms. I would say it's definitely worth the full price, and on sale it's a must buy, even if you just play one of the games.

For 999, I really enjoy the experience I got from playing this title. The flow of the game, along with other elements like characters, soundtracks, the mystery, and the suspense, feels well thought-out.

However for VTR, the game double downs with its multiple story timeline and the flow seems much more slower with lots of breaks during the game, which is meant for better character development (not really that engrossing IMO) and moar info exposition (which doubles the mystery with lots of details to remember).

But anyway, it's Uchikoshi, so the plot-twists and reveals of both games are so shockingly good and there's no way you will be able to guess it correctly.
Two games in one. 999 is substantially better in its simplicity but VLR is pretty good as well. Play these games if you like puzzles and story.

As much as I can appreciate this game not being to everyone's liking, I believe that the first two games of this series are underrated and underappreciated. The writers mixed subtle character building and extensive world building to build up scenarios of mystery and intrigue, and that's just scratching the surface of why this game is one of the most interesting, mystifying, and mind-expanding games I have ever played.

There are many concepts in this game that have been heavily explored in media nowadays, but when it first came out the concepts it was playing with still had significant room to be fresh. Even replaying it nowadays, the ways in which it explores causality, the mind and physics from the direction of videogame players who may have never tackled those subjects before in their lives really brings what the games are trying to portray to life. You can really believe in the unbelievable for a while, and the games get you genuinely excited about concepts that are already familiar to sci-fi and fantasy fans.

While some characters can be found to just be filling in gaps, after thinking about the role each and every character plays, they are all very necessary and gives a wide variety for every kind of character lover. Even characters that some people may find grating at first tend to find a place in the player's heart as they show more and more of their vulnerability or hidden strengths, or just plain heart-felt sides to the player.

It's hard to continue explaining why I love this game so much without giving away spoilers, but simple things like how the multi-ending mechanic fits into the storytelling and the little details for the attentive player are definitely things to note. The puzzles are almost consistently fun, and although some can be considerably difficult there's no shame in the community about getting a little bit of help for the tougher ones. The satisfaction of figuring something out, puzzle or story, is always fulfilling with the in-situation responses from characters, helped by the well (though sometimes too much) thought-out dialogue writing.

I will full-well admit there are flaws to this game. Some are more famous like talking for hours on a time-limit, some are down to player preference. Even so, I found that every dull moment was not-too-long followed by something that drew me in once more. I only have two regrets about playing these games. One is that they are very long, and after finding them again for so long it's hard to have time to appreciate them in the fashion like I did once before - though it doesn't really take much away from the experience. The other is that this series didn't get the ending it deserved, but honestly if you just take the ending of the second game it wraps most things up anyway, and the ending monologue has given the player plenty of confidence in their knowledge of how the in-fiction universe can resolve what it has presented to them.

If you read all of this, have a nice day :)

Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors, or 999, is the first game, and Virtue's Last Reward, VLR, is the second game.

I really love these games, they're captivating. Stick with them, and they'll give you interesting stories, characters, and really thought-provoking topics.

Some things to be aware of though:
999 has a nice art-style, but then in VLR they switch to these 3D models which is like, why?
VLR can be glitchy and laggy
Some of the puzzles are really tough. Most of the ones I looked up the answers for were definitely doable if I just was patient, but some of them are really cryptic.

If you're not afraid of text heavy and slow games (obviously, VN like) and like some nice escape [room] puzzles, go play these! The plot is pretty "down the rabbit hole"-y and drags you into it.

Just be aware that I unfortunately strongly advise against playing the final instalment (Zero Time Dilemma) despite the potential urge to know the end of the story after ep. 2 (present in the Nonary Games). The [b]burden[/b] is not worth the reward.

Zero Escape: 999 Endings
foda

This pack features two games. 999 (Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors) and Virtue's Last Reward. They're part of Zero Escape series, which is a trilogy. The third game, Zero Time Dilemma is also on Steam.

999 was originally a DS game, so its massive plot twist relies on two screens to make sense. However, this version has a flowchart and voice acting, so it's more pleasant way to experience the game.

Virtue's Last Reward was originally 3DS/Vita game, so the 3D models might look a little bit rough.

Since there doesn't seem to be great differences between different console versions and since the whole Zero Escape trilogy can be played on Steam, therefore I recommend it.

This pack includes 2 games: 999 and VLR. Both games start out rather slow but gain traction and develop into something promising as the time goes, only to fall flat on their faces because of the ridiculous endings.

999 is the duller one out of the two. For a while, the plot doesn't seem to go anywhere, and even when faced with imminent danger to their lives, the characters prefer to stand around and argue instead of doing something productive. Most of the puzzles are ridiculously easy and can be solved by randomly clicking everything. However, the story becomes increasingly engaging towards the end, and just as you start feeling invested in it, it ends in a way that leaves you largely confused. To avoid spoilers, I will try to be vague: the game tries to tout a certain character the whole time, shoving them down your throat without any subtlety, only to throw it all out of the window at the end by framing them as a clearly horrible person while you're still expected to sympathise with and care for them. The ending doesn't have any conclusion or lesson to it, it's simply there so the story could be wrapped up, even if it comes at the cost of common sense.

Despite all its flaws, I still prefer 999 to VLR, because at least 999's ending doesn't give you the same distinct feeling that the writers think you're an idiot as VLR's ending does.

VLR, for the most part, fares better than 999. Characters finally have a sense of urgency and act reasonably most of the time, excluding puzzle rooms, when all of them suddenly become braindead. I'm not kidding, in 9 different routes you have to go through the same conversation, which is: "Take this" "Why?" "Because you need it for X" "Oh, right". Or every time you escape a room, you get showered with praise even by characters who are supposed to dislike you. Despite that, the story is engaging, the puzzle rooms are a major improvement from 999 with some of them being fairly tricky, and even though you can see some of the "plot-twists" coming from a mile away if you're observant enough, the game still manages to pleasantly surprise you at the end... before it tries too hard to shock you and goes way overboard with all the twists, turning a well-planned believable story into a jumbled mess, riddled with plot-holes and bad writing. I think this is where "writers think you're an idiot" truly shines, as the game expects you to accept that poor excuse of an ending and to believe that none of the, supposedly very intelligent, characters noticed or commented on these plot-holes that are so obvious to you as a reader. And this is why I can't recommend these games to anyone except maybe diehard escape room fans that can simply ignore the absurd story and enjoy the ride, as there are many better games that respect your intelligence.

花10个小时左右全通了999，剧本不用说确实很强，按照流程适度放出线索，让玩家有种面向真相抽丝剥茧的感觉，直到结局的豁然开朗却又埋下另一个伏笔，游戏流程紧凑人物刻画细致，这作绝对属于AVG类作品的top级别。
不过看评论发现大家可能在通带剧情锁的后置线时没发现可以跳过重复的密室解谜过程只走剧情，因此会觉得操作疲劳冗余。其实只要在flow里看到右上角提示有剧情锁的框双击再双击，选择右边弹出的剧情选项，就能直接跳转到关键剧情避开密室环节，这样对于避免重复解谜有所帮助。并不需要强行重复之前玩过的剧情和密室逃脱，毕竟这游戏的skip确实挺慢的...只要从有红白锁的框开始，再将下面相应钥匙剧情依次解锁就能很快到达不同结局。

Just finished 999. Honestly one of the best stories I've ever seen in a game. Such great characters and plot twists and unexpected things happening throughout the entire story. I would absolutely give this a 10/10. Some of the puzzles were kinda annoying for me, but nothing felt particularly unfair or TOO hard, this opinion is also completely subjective, and you might have a much easier time than I did on the puzzles depending on how you approach them. With that being the only gripe I have, and with it being entirely personal bias, this is an absolute masterpiece of a game. Side note: the OST of the game SLAPS and the voice acting was surprisingly good as well. I usually prefer sub to dub but the English VAs in this did a fantastic job voicing each character and no one really felt out of place at all. If you play it, get every ending. It is absolutely worth it to get the full story of what happened and see the entire picture for each character in the game. They all have something interesting about them and you won't see everything unless you get every ending. I did this in about 25 hours. definitely could have been faster, but I'm not the best at puzzles to be fully honest. Give this game a shot if you haven't, it is absolutely phenomenal. 

(Will update this review when I 100% VLR)

Update: I recently finished Zero Time Dilemma. The reason for this, is because I wanted to see how it expands upon Virtue's Last Reward before forming a full opinion of it. After finishing VLR, (100% playthrough clocked in at 42 hours) I still had a lot of questions that, obviously, I won't get into here. Without spoiling anything, just know that VLR expands upon ideas introduced in 999 while adding in some brand new ones to some absolutely INSANE levels. The stakes feel a lot higher this time around and the gimmick of AB games was a lot more intense than that of the Digital Roots. Once again, I highly recommend getting every ending for the best experience with this game. It has some crazy "what the hell is going on" moments and the reveals that happen are so incredibly clever that I sometimes had to pause and take a minute to just try to process what I had just seen. The OST this time around is even better in my opinion, and also has some pretty solid remixes of songs from the 999 soundtrack. The voice acting is, once again, top notch. Every VA did a fantastic job portraying their character and I was absolutely hooked during the heights of this game. All of this, in theory, should make for an even better game than the first, right? Well...

VLR has a few glaring issues. The first, is the pacing. There's a lot of waiting you have to do just watching unskippable cutscenes that, in some cases, you've already seen before. The beginning of the game also takes about 1.5 hours before getting to the main story where you make your first decision. It doesn't really detract anything from the story, but it definitely did take quite a bit longer to get invested in this one than 999 did for me. The next of the issues I have with VLR are the puzzles. OHH BOY. The puzzles in this game are SIGNIFICANTLY harder than the ones in 999. I had to use a guide on several occasions. This might not come as an issue to people who enjoy the challenge they bring but, in my opinion, some of these puzzles simply go on for WAY too long. There were multiple times I thought I was at the end of a puzzle only to be introduced to another gimmick that is pretty difficult to figure out, or I got the wrong safe code and had to keep solving the room until I got the correct one. Maybe I'm just not as smart as some other people who will play this game, but the puzzles definitely began to become tedious and more of a nuisance that I HAD to get through in order to get back to the story rather than a fun challenge in-between rooms like they were in 999.

The final issue I have with VLR is the entire reason I held off on making this review in the first place, and that is that it feels OVERLY ambitious. Almost to a fault. I won't spoil anything here but it tries to do SO much that it almost, at times, felt like it was trying too hard. Fortunately, ZTD expands upon these twists and new concepts in a way that help them feel less far-fetched and I was able to appreciate them much more in retrospect, despite the fact that they are a far cry from the somewhat grounded nature of the twists of 999.

All in all, VLR is a fine addition to 999 that is bogged down by a couple of issues that, in my opinion, keep it from being quite as good as it's predecessor. 8/10

TL;DR buy this bundle. These are really REALLY good games.

999 & VLR - Two must-play games if you spend way too much time thinking about the "what ifs" in life. Brilliant twists and storytelling in both games.

Worth every second.

Серия Zero Escape состоит из трех игр (Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors (999), Virtue’s Last Reward (VLR) и Zero Time Dilemma (ZTD)), первые две из которых продаются под одним именем - The Nonary Games, хотя логичнее было бы объединить вторую и третью, т.к. они сильнее связаны сюжетно. Все игры игры имеют один формат - визуальная новелла с относительно простыми головоломками формата побег из комнаты. Сильная сторона - интригующий сюжет с кучей тайн и неожиданных поворотов. 

999 мне понравилась больше всех. Минимум логических ошибок и сюжетных проколов, продуманная история, которая складывается в красивую и законченную картинку, к ней не остается вопросов. Загадки слишком легкие, но это не портит впечатление. В общем, если нравятся тайны и хорошие сюжетные повороты, то эта игра обязательна к прохождению.

VLR вызвала смешанные чувства. После первой части у меня были крайне высокие ожидания, до которых игра не дотянула. Во-первых, дурацкая анимация перемещения между комнатами. Она затянута, она не нужна, но ее очень много. Во-вторых, из-за формата игры ГГ по нескольку раз оказывается в одинаковых ситуациях, но с небольшими отличиями, из-за чего диалоги технически считаются непрочитанными и не проматываются. Из-за этих двух факторов сюжет уже не так держит в напряжении, как в первой части, и хочется поскорее все промотать, чтобы получить ответы на вопросы и забыть этот день сурка. Кроме того, концовка... пожалуй, не дает такого удовлетворения, как в первой части. Не все тайны объясняются, делается задел на следующую часть. Не знаю, стала бы я играть, если бы знала это наперед. Но и не могу сказать, что не рекомендую играть. Как минимум, понравились головоломки, которые как раз правильной сложности, да и в совокупности с третьей частью (которая-таки дает ответы на оставшиеся вопросы) сюжет неплох.

У третьей части полно своих проблем, но если играть во вторую, то третью 100% тоже надо пройти. И если вы собираетесь играть в VLR, совет: после прохождения 999 не стоит ничего искать в интернете (если остались какие-то вопросы или какую-то дополнительную информацию), т.к. легко нарваться на спойлеры по второй части, которые не отделены от информации о первой игре.

震撼，再无别的形容词

       最开始了解这个游戏是在小学，当时游戏风云的休闲街区做过这个游戏的实况。
       我是在电视上看完的全流程，但是当时是小学3 4年级，有的地方无法理解，而且很多情节到后来也都忘了，但是我在steam自己玩之前一直都有一个印象——就是震撼。
       对我来说，这个游戏对我的影响不可谓不深远，尽管我觉得这个可能是巧合，但我还是愿意相信这是这个游戏给我的震撼： 我在上初中上高中时候，一直心里有一个关于人生世界的究极思考（尽管特别中二），但是在亲自玩完之后发现，这个想法居然是来自于这个游戏里的一个情节，小小的剧透——就是Lotus在实验室对男主说的主体意识（Body Mind）！我游玩时really astonished! I cant even say a single word!我下巴都掉到桌子上了。我脑子里居然被一个游戏从小学开始种下了一个想法，长达十年，都没有被遗忘。
       这就是这个游戏在我个人经历中特别加分的地方。

主观的评价：
剧情：震惊于剧本写作：1.这个游戏剧本和数字有很强的联系，首先先抛开故事是否吸引人，单单是把数字的游戏在多条故事线里面统一合理，就已经非常不容易了；再者，故事真的十分吸引人，尽管我在碰到选项时会按照自己喜好，选一些很糊逼的选项，但是尽管如此，这个游戏引导我完全按照该进行的结局线——先假结局，再好结局，最后是真结局，分毫不差，引导我体验了整个游戏的味道。
音乐：不是很会评价，但是True Ending的BGM我贼喜欢。
文字：由于这游戏最开始是日文版，steam这个又是英文版，所以会有翻译上的问题，有的情感色彩不是很到位，推荐有一点点日语听力基础，依靠日语语音感受剧情。其次，这个英语翻译个人感觉是日本人自己翻译的，有的讲法很奇怪，并且还有一些翻译错误，比如人名少假名，Ice9的熔点明明36却写了96。最后，虽然有很多问题，但是都能接受，并且在阅读上，不会有很大的障碍，有高中英语水平基本就能进行全流程畅快体验，其中可能会有一部分要自己用手机现场查一查，但很多都是通俗易懂的表达方式。

以上，目前仅玩完了999，另一个叫啥 Virtue那个，还没打，打完再补全评论

第一部游戏作为一个系列开端交出了不错的答卷，出色带有新意的密室逃脱再加上打越钢太郎喜欢玩视角的诡计，放在当时确实很惊艳，但如果纵向对比整个系列来说可能就有点素质平平或者较无从轻重了吧，因为从第二部善人死亡开始才开始侧重大量他擅长的穿越，轮回等要素，世界观也由此展开。但也造成了时间线过于复杂，最终解密想要捋顺前后关系真的是要烧脑一番。[spoiler]结局有些要素过于相似打越02年的ever17，所以震撼程度上差了一点意思[/spoiler]

作为一部穿越剧，善人死亡的剧本无疑是优秀的，但整体来看，打越钢太郎是真的不太擅长写日常，前期铺垫过于冗长，加上游戏机制问题，各个路线也存在一定的重复度，所以除了快到路线结局开始了解真相外，其他时候总是会不知不觉陷入瞌睡状态。
不知道制作组是太过执着于2代必须要进步还是其他原因，非要将2D立绘画面升级成拙劣的3D图像，导致游戏画面极为丑陋，影响观感浑身不适。[spoiler]2代销量不佳肯定跟第一印象不讨好玩家有关[/spoiler]

密室谜题由于善人死亡没有中文所以玩起来比较费劲，有些密室单靠直觉是无法解密的。不过直觉告诉我在整个系列中善人死亡应该是最难的吧。

虽然有各种各样的小缺点，但质量如此优秀的穿越剧情游戏着实不多，小众归小众，还是很值得推荐一玩的。

题外话：由于善人死亡没有汉化，我是看B站剧情视频慢慢推的，到解密部分再切回游戏能解多少是多少。虽说确实对剧情理解不存在问题，但游戏沉浸感却大打折扣，这可能也是前期玩着犯困的一大原因吧。

[b]NO SPOILERS[/b]

Where do I even start.

These two games are honestly masterpieces, but I will be doing two mini reviews so not to generalize.

-------------------------------
9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors
-------------------------------
This game is remastered from the DS version, therefore it is more aesthetically pleasing than VLR. The soundtrack is very good and you'll get to enjoy the beat as you solve you way through all of the puzzles.

The plot is extremely interesting and further enhanced by the flowchart system, making it so you don't have to restart from the very beginning every single time you end a route (This is how the DS version worked. I'm amazed anyone even finished it like that). You are trapped on a ship by a person named Zero. You must find the number 9 door in order to escape. Why are you here? Who are these people? These will be answered in due time.

I really can't go into detail without spoiling the game, all I can say is that you will love nearly every character and every plot twist that comes out of this game.

-------------------------------
Virtue's Last Reward
-------------------------------
This is a straight port from the consoles, no real remaster here. The models generally aren't very detailed and the animations aren't too fluid, but it's something that will quickly grow on you. Plus, the story is what really matters.

And god damn is the story good. It expands on 999 but introduces many more plot points. Although you may be heavily confused coming into it, mostly everything will be explained by the end of it. This game also changes up the bracelet system, which makes it even more unique. The soundtrack in this one is also very good. I'd say the characters in this game are tied with the characters in 999. I enjoy both casts and it's really hard to pick a 'better' cast for me.
-------------------------------

Overall, these are two amazing games. If you're interested in VNs in the slightest, make sure to pick these up and give them a shot.

Nonary Games contains two games: 
[olist]
    [*] 9 Persons 9 Hours 9 Doors (999)
    [*] Virtue's Last Reward (VLR)
[/olist]

I've spent some time reflecting on them and I've come to the conclusion that they are my favourite games perhaps of all time (999 for sure is) so it means that this review is biased. These games are first and foremost mystery games whose gameplay mostly consists of solving puzzles (escape rooms) and reading through story in visual novel format. 

[h1] 999[/h1]

This game is fully voice acted and animated in 2D in visual novel parts and works as 2D point and click in it's puzzle solving parts. For a game from 2009 made for NintendoDS it's graphic style really seems old. This PC version breathes some life into graphics with voice acting and animated sprites which make it much more enjoyable. The game is voiced both in English and Japanese (Japanese voice actors hired are all top of the bill). Puzzles mostly aren't that hard and eventually other characters will help you if you're stuck. The story is perhaps it's strongest part and it is best experienced going in completely blind and playing it at night for maximum immersion. If you like mysteries I have no doubt in my mind you will like the story. For visual novel part there are 2 ways of experiencing it: Adventure mode and Novel mode and I'd recommend switching from one to another and reading through everything. 

[h1] VLR[/h1]

VLR was made in 2012 for 3DS and PSVita. It is fully voice acted 3D game (3D even in puzzle sections). It's graphics are fine for the time and hardware it was made. It aged somewhat okay mostly due to anime inspired art (while 999 is more in the middle this one goes closer to anime). Just as 999 it is voiced both in English and Japanese, this time both versions have top tier voice actors. There are also 2 difficulties for puzzles: hard and easy. On easy, other characters are more inclined to help you when you're stuck. On hard mode you're on your own. Puzzles themselves are harder than in 999 and I personally struggled with some of them. Hard mode is required for some of the extra content and I'd advise starting the game on hard and switching to easy if you get stuck. VLR is almost twice as long as 999 so the story progression might feel slow and boring from time to time if you play VLR right after 999. It's mainly story focus is mystery also. Story is very close in quality to 999 so it comes down to personal preference where I give slight edge to 999. Visual novel doesn't have modes this time around.

For the sake of story progression I'd advise you not to look up how much playtime you need for completing the games. If you really want to know how much time you can expect from these games In my case for 999 [spoiler] it took me around 17 hours to complete [/spoiler] and for VLR [spoiler] around 35 hours playing on hard mode from start[/spoiler]. I've bought Nonary Games in a Zero Escape Trilogy bundle on a sale but I can recommend Nonary Games at full price (25 euros at the time of writing this review).

之前在模拟器上通关了一遍，时隔多年，pc补票。
相比原版，无论从配音，画质，pc版毫无疑问有了巨大提升。pc版流程图的设置也大大的节约了多周目的时间，增强了游戏体验，可以说十分人性化了。然而，取消了分屏设定对于结局的体验来说其实有一定的影响。
不过瑕不掩瑜，999依然是值得入手的神作。毫不夸张的说，999是我玩过的多线剧情做的最好的一个，没有之一。精妙的数字设计，耐人寻味的剧情选择，支线与主线之间巧妙的关联，绝对的精彩。
从游戏性来说，游戏主体就是由一个个密室构成，密室难度不算高，相比深红之类的经典密室，999远远达不到经典，最多就是及格。不过密室终究只是载体，无与伦比的剧情绝对值得花时间体验。

Pretty good game. Haven't played many Visual novels in the past, but I really enjoyed my time with this one. All the characters were great, the writing was brilliant, the soundtrack was good (which is good because you'll be hearing the same tracks over and over), the escape rooms were fun.

Both Zero Escape games are not respectful of the players time though, they're expected to invest a lot of time into these games, and backtracking is a recommended part to the experience.

In Virtue's Last Reward was quite exhausting to play, when the player reaches a climactic point the game will frequently stop, and you get sent back earlier in the game. After going through that so many times it felt tiring, and keeping track of all the things you learnt becomes difficult. But that's part of the charm of the game, I wouldn't have it any other way.
Awesome story and ok puzzle.

Reasonable visual novels with OK puzzles. The biggest problem is that all three games (This product includes games 1 and 2) in the series get very repetitive and time consuming, While I enjoyed the series at times, I think if I had known ahead of time how long it would take then I would not have played through. A big portion of the games revolve around trying to find out who Zero is and the games do a pretty good job of keeping the big reveals secret while giving you clues to figure out other plot elements out in advance.

999: 7/10

Plot has better pacing and manages to stay interesting at most points. More aspects of the game's story can actually be figured out before the big reveal with regular logic which is a plus. Some of the characters are reasonably interesting and turn out to be different than they give the appearance of being at the start.

Virtue's Last Reward: 5/10

Really long and repetitive. You will have to watch some of the same scenes upwards of 8 times to complete the games (obviously you can click through to skip some of the reading). Too much of the plot relies on science fiction to make any sense at all. After doing about half of the escape room puzzles, I just wanted to get through the game and be done with it. The character models and animations are hilariously bad - Like REALLY bad. Some of the character's teeth can be seen visibly detached from their mouths.

I already got acquainted with the Danganronpa seies before taking myself on a journey with Zero Escape, so I sort of knew what I'm going to see. Here are some thoughts about the two games you are going to see here.

999 was a great kickoff and absolutely love the pacing of the game. It's a good balance between the narrative and mini-escape games in between. The way it intertwines the story is just amazing and you can't wait to see where it will bring you in the next title.

As soon as you arrive in Virtue's Last Reward, it starts to slow you down[spoiler]just like the brain in the game[/spoiler], since there is a lot more text rather than actual gameplay. In a way it is great, since you can relax and enjoy your deep dive into the complex story, but it will start to get annoying if you haven't read long VN games before (which was my case). Since this game is much longer than the first one, I only got really engaged in the process at the last hours of the game, where all the dots begin to connect so to speak. Nonetheless, it was a great time and I wish Spike Chunsoft the very best in their future endeavors.

Oyun paket olarak geliyor, yani bunu alırsanız 2 oyun almış oluyorsunuz. 

1. Oyun daha çok görsel roman tarzında, çok beğendiğim bir "odadan kaçış" oyunu. Grafikler 2 boyutlu anime tarzında, bu stilden hoşnut olmuyorsanız bile almanızı öneririm. Yapbozlar oldukça eğlenceliydi ve her seferinde düşünmeye itti beni, odadaki her eşya önemli bir ip ucu olabiliyor ve her birini incelemeniz, üzerinde beyin fırtınası yapmanız gerekiyor. Ortamlar çok iyi bir formatta kullanılmış, gerçekten oynamaya değer bir oyun. Hikaye açısından bakılırsa, bu oyun ikincisine kıyasla daha akla yatın ve basit. Oyunun bittiğinde aklınızda pek fazla soru işareti kalmıyor. 

2. Oyunda grafikler 3. boyuta geçiyor ve karakter modelleri katılaşıyor. Daha bilim kurgu tarzı, klostrofobik bir ortamda geçiyor. Bu değişim herkesin hoşuna gitmeyebilir fakat gameplay açısından pek bir farklılık yok, bu oyun daha uzun ve karmaşık olması yönüyle de hoşuma gitti diyebilirim. Bu oyunda hikayeyi daha karmaşık hale getirmişler, birinci oyunun sadece buzdağının görünen tarafı olduğunu gösteriyor.
Tavsiye ederim, en yakın indirimde alın gitsin, aldığınıza değecektir.

This bundle includes the first two games in the Zero Escape trilogy and boy, it's a doozy! It features one of the worst games I've played, and also one of the very best. Do read on.

- 999: 9 hours, 9 persons, 9 doors - Personal score of 3/10
I was surprised at how bad this game is, given how on paper it's a mix of a bunch of things I like. There's puzzles, check. There's locked room mysteries, check. There is a killing game mystery thing going on. But the execution is so poor in so many ways.
It has abysmal writing where everyone is a raging imbecile and no one acts or talks the way people do. They do the stupidest things and gloss over obvious stuff, and sometimes they flip from being idiots to being total savants and leave the reader in the dark with their logic leaps, all in the service of contrived plot progression. 
It also features poor translation - not in the sense that it's too literal, as they actualized didn't shy away from localizing it and I like that - but the resulting script seems like it never saw an editor, and it reads terribly. 
Then, the puzzles. One of the biggest problems with them is that they have nothing to do with the plot. You get into a locked room and you're trying to get out, but the puzzles are about totally random things that have nothing to do with the mystery of the story. Not only are they totally unremarkable, but they make the story feel slower and more disconnected.
The story tries to amend this by periodically having a character do a random info dump about something, but it's always so drawn out and uninteresting and out of place, and with the aforementioned poor writing it makes it torturous to play through.
Another problem worth mentioning is how poor the game is at conveying its geography. Given you're trying to exit an enclosed space, you should have a good idea of what it looks like and how the characters are moving through it, but you never do, and it feels very disorienting. There is no map menu that you can conveniently access and the game does a bad job of conveying where the characters are at. Inside escape rooms, it functions like a point and click, and you click buttons on the left and right sides of the screen to snap to different points in that room. This shouldn't be a problem, but the layout of the rooms gets so convoluted, and the snapping points are so strange, that something you click to go left/right and you find yourself in a place that doesn't even feel like it's in the same room you were before. 999 is originally a DS port and this was one of the constraints of the console that they had to work around, but the designers should've done a better job of designing the rooms with regards to this limitation.

By now you might be wondering why this is a positive review, and why I would still say it's worth putting yourself through it. Well, in a bizarre twist of fate, its sequel turns out to be one of the greatest games I've ever played.

- Virtue's Last Reward - Personal score of 9/10
Holy cow this game is good. Right off the bat, the script is the total opposite of 999 - it's downright excellent. So much will happen with simple conversations. Just the characters taking a moment to stop and think and talk to each other about what's going on. It never resorts to external events or contrived bullshit to do exposition and story progression. It's always logical and natural and makes for an amazingly enjoyable read. This is remarkable on its own, but it's mind-blowing when you consider it's a sequel to 999. The only parts where the writing dips are during bad ends, where characters act with unnatural aggression toward the protagonist, but fortunately those are very short and have little impact on the experience.
The plot is consistently surprising - shocking, even - with new unforeseen twists dropping on regular intervals and flipping everything you thought you knew upside down. It's on par with the best of games like the Infinity series (Ever17, Remember11) and Root Double.
Gameplay was immensely improved too. You have way better geographical awareness both in and out of rooms. Puzzle rooms are more contextual and better designed overall, and they never repeat (in 999 you were sometimes forced to redo some rooms). One really cool piece of flair is how every puzzle room has its own completely distinct piece of background music, and they're all banging tracks. It makes them feel so much more fresh and unique.
And that's kind of it. There's not much more I could say without spoiling, and is this one of those games that are best experienced with the less you know about it.

If you enjoy mystery stories, puzzles, and good writing, then you must play this. It's worth it to stick it out through 999 to play the masterpiece that is VLR.

I usually don't have a high opinion of Visual Novels. I thought Danganronpa was an exception. I was wrong. Very wrong.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is a compilation of the first two of currently three Zero Escape games. In a sense, they are puzzle heavy games that can really get your gears grinding but what they truly and absolutely excel at is storytelling.

I wasn't hooked until about 75% into the first game, but it took so many completely unexpected turns that ultimately, from the games point of view, made absolutely sense and blew my mind away. By the time of finishing Virtues Last Reward I can barely contain myself from not instantly starting up the third game because I was so hooked on the story. Even although I have to admit that the semi-3D look of the second game was a step down to the comic look of the first game in my personal opinion.

Expect at least 20 hours each for both games, they are really long and contain lots and lots of story. What's great about this is the fact that about 75% of the entire story is voice acted, something which practically never happens in the genre and was highly refreshing.

The difficulty of the puzzles ranges from easy to brainbusting. I did finish the first game without any clues, almost failing at the last puzzle, but I needed to get some pointers several times during the second game, even although in retrospect, all puzzles were perfectly logical, just not very obvious.

Before I played these two games I had never heard of the series and I am not only positively surprised, I was swept off my feet.

Truly deserving of the label "story rich". The mechanics of especially the second game can be a bog though, especially the "door opening" animations, which will drive you crazy after the first third of the game, because they cannot be skipped, but all the same I just couldn't stop myself from waltzing through the 22 hours of that playthrough on a single weekend.

You have to expect to play all of the games several times though. On the upside you'll only have to do the puzzles just once and can skip all already seen content, but because to fully enjoy these games it is absolutely and 100% necessary to literally see all endings because they are the only way to unlock the true endings. And these are vital. Not just just average "get another 30 second cutscene"-scheme you know from other games. The true ending of the first game adds about 20% of the entire game until that point on top of it and the second game isn't any different. Both games combined, there's about 20 endings you'll have to unlock.

Also I would like to point out that I'm raving about how good this experience was and I say that as someone generally negatively jaded towards Visual Novels. You absolutely must be a fan of logical puzzles though, otherwise this will feel tedious.

Product contains installments 1&2 of the series. This review covers both.

Pros:
~Artwork in game 1 is good. I was pleasantly surprised to see character animations.
~Puzzles. The puzzles and traps are all loads of fun. Only a few were somewhat difficult.
~Story. You're in the dark until you figure out the true routes, but it's quite a ride and a complex plot they wove.
~Story consistency. For each route you take, there's remarkable consistency (in a good way), particularly considering the type of plot they chose to go with.

Cons:
~Not a huge fan of the art in game 2. They went from 2d drawings to low-res 3d block characters.
~Cliffhangers. Both games end in cliffhangers and don't have the endings you were expecting/wanting. I believe it's all set up for the final showdown in game 3?
~Movement during the puzzles is clunky in both games.
~Game 2 in particular has lots of unskippable deadtime where they show your character moving through doors and traveling throughout the map. Some cases there might be 5+ minutes of you just sitting there with nothing happening. I can understand why they might show it, but it should be skippable.

Overall: I quite enjoyed these games, and I think anyone that likes an ever17-type storyline along with some escape rooms or puzzle games will enjoy this as well. Definitely worth nabbing.

Two of the best games i ever played when speaking about puzzles/Visual novel.
Don't miss these perls.

Antes de empezar, deberia decir que son juegos que no van para todos. El contenido del juego es, basicamente, texto y puzzles. Pueden parecer pesados, pero confia en mi cuando te digo que son dos juegos altamente subvalorados dentro del genero de "visual novel". ¿Por que no es más conocido? pues, es una pregunta que no te la puedo responder. Lo que si te puedo responder es que estos dos juegos se caracterizan por tener una trama atrapante, grandes personajes, puzzles ingeniosos e informacion de teorias filosoficas y cientificas como para romperte un poco mas la cabeza. 

La historia es de alguna manera similar en ambos juegos. 9 (un numero que lo vas a ver muy seguido) personas se encuentran atrapadas y deben buscar una manera de salir. ¿Suena simple, no?. El jugador ira viendo y tomando decisiones que llevaran a distintos finales. Una vez terminado un final, si quieres saber mas, vas a tener que seguir jugando. Creeme que vas a estar enganchado por querer buscar explicaciones hacia ciertos acontecimientos. Los personajes que nos acompañan en esta tensa aventura son altamente rememorables, cada uno con sus personalidades definidas desde un primer momento. Amalos u odialos, ninguno de ellos me hace pensar "Este juego seria lo mismo si tal personaje no estuviera".  

Con respecto a los puzzles, los del segundo juego son un poco mas dificiles que del primero. Aun asi, ambos te pondran a pensar en buen rato para resolverlos. 

¿Vale la pena comprartelo? Absolutamente. Yo tuve la suerte de encontrar la trilogia a precio ganga y debo decir que es una de las mejores ofertas que he podido comprar. 
Por las cosas que no me gustaron lo primero que me salta a la mente es el cambio a modelos 3D en el segundo juego, que con el tiempo te acostumbras y, ademas, la historia lo compensa todo.
¿No has jugado ningun juego de este tipo de genero? Te invito a que lo pruebes. No se si sera el inicio perfecto para alguien que quiera saber mas del genero de visual novel pero debo decir que te lo recomiendo encarecidamente.

¿Que esperas? Preparate para quedarte estupido por los giros argumentales. ¡Preparate para los giros argumentales de los giros argumentales! Misterio, ciencia ficcion y demas te esperan en este juego.

I finished 999 last year, and halfway through VLR now.
These two games are my first in the Visual Novel genre and I think they are a good intro for this genre.
The story is intriguing. There will be many times in the game where you will be setting at the edge of your seats waiting to see how the story unfolds.

These two games are meant played multiple time to unlock every path. How these paths interact with each other is one of the coolest things in the story.

The only gamey thing about the Nonary games is the puzzles, so if the story doesn't grab and you're not all about solving puzzles then these two games are not for you.

If you are a fan of murder mysteries, tales of betrayal, the paranormal and heart-wrenching backstories, you will love these games.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games reúne dos de los videojuegos más sobresalientes que he jugado en lo que llevo de 2019, y de los mejores juegos que he jugado en los últimos años. La premisa en ambos es clara: 9 personas son secuestradas y forzadas a jugar a un juego que les obliga a poner sus vidas al borde de la línea. ¿Por qué están aquí? Quién es la persona detrás de todo esto? Cuál es el propósito de todo lo que están haciendo? Estas y multitud de preguntas más son las que poco a poco tenéis que ir desentrañando a medid que avanzáis en sus historias, las cuáles están escritas de forma fantástica, hilando cada suceso y conectando cada ruta de forma que te termina volando la cabeza. Por no hablar de que los personajes que conocerás en ambas historias están diseñados con mucho cariño y para que realmente crees un vinculo con ellos, un vinculo que puede llegar a ponerte bajo presión en decisiones que quizás no quieras tomar. ¿Hasta que punto un juego puede llegar a crear un vinculo emocional contigo cómo para hacerte sentir horriblemente mal por realizar según que actos? Este juego llega hasta ese extremo hasta límites insospechados.

En términos jugables son juegos fáciles de dominar, pero no por ello la dificultad para superar los retos será menor. Tendrás que pensar con lógica y solucionar puzles que desafiarán tu mente de multitud de maneras. Lo importante, sobretodo, es que te fijes en cada detalle y siempre busques la lógica en la resolución de los retos.

¿Y que decir de la banda sonora? Ambos videojuegos rozan lo sobresaliente en términos musicales, aunque pondría a su primera entrega levemente por encima. ¿Y su doblaje? Fantástico, con una interpretación al inglés que realmente sientes que está hecho con esfuerzo y pasión para que sientas que esos personajes están vivos detrás de la pantalla.

Visualmente son juegos que son agradables a la vista, aunque viniendo de consolas muchísimo menos potentes y siendo adaptaciones directas con mejoras que no van más allá de la remasterización, no puedes esperar portentos técnicos ni nada por el estilo.

La verdad... Pasará mucho tiempo hasta que encuentre otro videojuego que me haga sentir lo que me han hecho sentir estos dos. Dos experiencias maravillosas en todos los sentidos, con una historia y personajes que te harán reír, sonreír, enfadar, llorar, desconfiar... Es increíble. Dos obras maestras que espero que algún día sean altamente reconocidas en la industria de los videojuegos.
视觉小说，解谜游戏，有点无聊，玩着玩着就困了。。。

[h1]Сейчас я буду проходить все руты![/h1]

В этот сборник входит 2 игры, а именно – Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors [i](999)[/i] и Virtue’s Last Reward [i](VLR)[/i].

Чаще всего эту серию игр сравнивают с серией фильмов [i]"Пила"[/i] ввиду похожих [i]сеттингов[/i]. Группу [i](казалось бы)[/i] случайных людей замыкают в помещении и заставляют [i]"играть в игру"[/i]. Позже, игрок понимает, что абсолютно все случайности, что происходят в игре далеко не случайны.

При этом в ходе прохождения, как и в большинстве нелинейных новелл с выбором, формируется так называемый flowchart, представляющий собой огромную паутину событий, которые происходили при тех или иных выборах. 

Оба тайтла геймплейно представляют собой смешение жанров [i]визуальной новеллы[/i] и [i]"выберись из комнаты, решая головоломки"[/i]. Разберем игры по отдельности.

[h1][b]Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors[/b][/h1]

Вступительная часть трилогии, где нас знакомят с основными персонажами и постепенно вводят в суть конфликта, раскрывая характеры персонажей и ситуацию в которой они находятся. Для полного прохождения, как и в большинстве подобных ВН необходимо пройти все руты, чтобы после выйти на истинную концовку.

Прекрасная графика с простенькими 3д пререндерами на фоне и милыми 2D спрайтами.

Прохождение занимает примерно 16 часов и оставляет после себя [i]"вау"[/i] эффект от того, как в итоге складываются все пазлы.

[b]Рекомендую к прохождению![/b]

[h1][b]Virtue’s Last Reward[/b][/h1]

Вторая часть трилогии, во всем наследует первую часть, но пытается быть лучше. [i]Пытается[/i] тут ключевое слово.

На смену милым спрайтам пришли достаточно своеобразные 3д модельки (к которым в итоге привыкаешь, но ближе к двадцатому часу чтения).

Да, историю расширили, мир игры тоже, рутов стало намного больше, но от этого ближе к концу игры начала чувствоваться какая-то затянутость и на судьбы персонажей, о которых ты изначально беспокоился, становится  плевать. ([i]В начале игры печешься, пытаешься никого не предавать и играть хорошего парня, в конце игры – "Пффф, предать, что там дальше по незакрытым рутам?")[/i].

В игре всё также много бэктрекинга и помогает только пункт [i]"SKIP"[/i], для пропуска текста, который уже прочитан. Прохождение игры заняло у меня 45 часов, что ощутимо больше, чем первая часть. 
Да, вау эффект в итоге был не меньше, плюс за это время привыкаешь к персонажам и несколько тяжело закрывать игру в последний раз. 
Но ощущение того, что все эти 40+ часов можно ужать и укоротить совсем не покидает.

[b]Тем не менее, к прохождению рекомендую.[/b]

[h1]Как итог, [b]2 гениальные игры[/b] переполненные твистами, секретами и тайнами, которые только предстоит открыть. [b]Приятной игры! [/b][h1]

So first of all let me tell you, that my review will compare VLR to 999, focusing on the former. That’s because I played 999 a long time ago, but it was my first time to play VLR now. So be aware this review is about VLR only so to say.

Just one thing I have to say about 999 separately: WHERE IS MY UPSIDE-DOWN SUDOKU? Why did they take that one out? It was a lot better than the new puzzle… and I could solve Sudokus in elementary school, so “it’s too hard for some players” is no reason to take it out. Everyone who plays such games, can figure out how Sudokus work… and some of the other puzzles are harder than that Sudoku.
Now let’s continue with VLR.

Characters:
Here I have some mixed feelings. To cut it down: I really enjoyed the new female main character: Phi. That whiny, shy and annoying Akane chic in 999, whom I really dislike, is nothing compared to her. Phi is pretty, smart, sassy, sarcastic, in short, I really fell in love with her over the course of events. But considering the other characters I couldn’t really care less. Most of the females were too cliché: conceited, revealingly dressed or shy. But the male characters weren’t so much better in this game (excluding the main character). A suspicious robot, an arrogant circus-dressed guy, who shows you he’s an a**hole in the first minutes you play the game, an old fart and a kid. Man, I wished Snake or maybe even Santa were back… hell even Ace and Seven might’ve been better. Anyway, carrying on…
Also Sigma, the main character you’re playing, is a huge pervert, oof.

Story and overall atmosphere:
The atmosphere when I started the game was almost relaxing actually. Sure, you were captured in a death trap, but for me it was nothing compared to 999. That’s probably because VLR is studded with jokes… the files in the archive for example are doing puns by using s*x innuendos. Or the rabbit-KI which greets you at the beginning of the game and speaks in a very dramatic, exaggerated way (I bet the voice actor had a lot of fun though). Furthermore, I didn’t feel that anxiety when confronted with deaths like I did in 999. Maybe because I didn’t care that much about the characters or because of the different prevailing mood. Nonetheless I experienced suspense here and there and looked forward to some of the endings. And the AB Games added to the excitement, guessing if a specific character would betray you in this path or not was fun (and sometimes frustrating, when you see the results). Compared to 999 the endings weren’t that shocking though. They entertained me but didn’t thrill me. While in 999 I was like: “WTF! Why her/him? How did it come to this?!” (and crying like a baby at the safe ending e.g.), here I was rather like: “Okay, that makes sense. Go on, I want to know the rest of it.” Part of that fault belongs to the storytelling, because you have much more different paths than in 999 and you feel like you’re right in “Groundhog Day”, going over and over the same story, just with a few changes and new information. And some things were really predictable sadly. Still I don’t regret playing through all paths at all. I just wasn’t that thrilled as I was in 999. But the ending and the solution were a real mindf**k and you shouldn’t even try to get the timelines and the logic behind them right or it will crash your brain. Also, the overall background story was much more depressing and sadder than the one in 999. Still the individual endings of 999 shocked me harder.

Gameplay:
Just a few words: Too. Many. Hallways. And why is there no button to skip the endless walks through those? Why do I even have to watch the characters go through them again and again. Can’t they just skip to the room, I’m supposed to be in next? Gosh that was annoying. And the control in the escape rooms took a bit time to get used to, especially moving around. You can’t do a 360° turn, no. You can go like… 300° and if you want to look at the other side, you must turn your character ALL THE WAY to the other side. But I must give this game credit for making the flow chart really easy to follow. I had some troubles in 999, because there were overlaps with other paths and I wasn’t sure how to reach certain endings… but in VLR that was no problem. Got every path without looking up an external flow chart. Other than that, it’s mostly just “escape the room” mechanics. I liked the puzzles, point. And they have that memo-notebook which makes perfect sense on a 3DS I guess, but it’s not that handy on a PC, unless you really like scribbling notes with a mouse.

Music and graphic:
I’m really happy they brought the music and sounds from 999 back that gave me some nostalgic moments. And it's a joy that you can play this whole game either in English or in Japanese. I will definitely replay it, when I know some more Japanese.
While in 999 they used pictures for significant scenes and animated sprites for the characters, the graphic in VLR uses 3D models nearly all the time. They don’t look that smooth in my opinion, but they could be worse.

Recommend:
So much for that. Even though I’m criticising the game a lot here, I really like both games and would recommend them. I’m just good at complaining about first world problems. ;)
Btw. It took me 33,5 hours to complete VLR while taking my time and exploring 100%. 999 took me like 11,5 hours, but that was already my second time playing it. Probably took longer when I first played it.

**NOW SOME SPOILERS BELOW (also one spoiler for ZTD)**
I also have to rant a bit for a moment. What the f**k has gone wrong with Akane and Junpei. I didn’t even recognise them after I knew that it IS them. I already suspected the old geezer, but I was like: No, that can’t be, he totally wouldn’t look like that, when he gets old. Well… Junpei has become as annoying as Akane. And Akane literally accepts that people get killed? Seriously what… And it’s always “Quark here, Quark there”, I don’t even care about his character. 
And what’s with Sigma? I shipped him with Phi all the way along the game, because they were kinda cute together and totally completed each other (also the names). And then he turns out to be an old man too (at least in that timeline) … and after I finished the game, I read, that he is actually Phi’s dad, which is declared in Zero Time Dilemma. What are those guys from Spike Chunsoft smoking? They made a romantic relationship possible the way they portrayed those two characters in VLR and then they suddenly give them this relation. You know what, I don’t care. I continue shipping them. I just pretend ZTD never happened and that they aren’t blood-related. I heard ZTD isn’t that good anyway for different reasons, so I will probably not play it.
Cheers.

[b]999[/b]

Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors je přesně ten typ adventury, který mám v oblibě. Koncept "exit room" je tu přenesen do prostoru velké zaoceáncké lodi, máme zde záhadu, proč bylo uneseno devět osob a přemístěno do této lodi, a také, kdo to provedl a jaká byla jeho motivace.

Pokud se koncept tvůrcům z Chunsoftu povedl, tak ani obsah a forma nepokulhávají. Prakticky jde o ideální provedení vizuální novely, jelikož zde máme přímo oddělené části hratelnosti. Za prvé hádanky, aneb přímé řešení jak se dostat z nějaké místnosti (viz název titulu). Obvykle jsou zábavné a někdy představují i trochu větší výzvu. Jde o ideální přestávku mezi čtením dialogů a příběhu. A tím se dostáváme ke druhé složce hry, seznamováním se s postavy a rozmotáváním mystéria zahalující důvod tohoto "testu", nebo co to vůbec je. Devět osob neví proč tu jsou, nebo si nemohou být jisti, zda třeba ostatní nejsou spolčení proti němu samému. Paranoia a napjaté vztahy tu jsou vykresleny na jedničku, a právě interakce mezi devítkou postav, kdy se tvoří přátelství i nepřátelství, roste důvěra i nedůvěra, jsou tím nejlepším na 999. Kotaro Uchikoshi, tvůrce hry, je mistr v oblasti napínavých detektivek a zvratů v příběhu, a ukázal to již ve svých předchozích dílech (doporučuji výborné Ever 17). A pak tu máme poslední složku hry, a to stromový vývoj událostí a tedy dopad vlastních rozhodnutí na konec hry. U Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors to není nijak kosmetická vlastnost, ale zcela zásadní ve smyslu nadcházejících událostí a jednoho z možných závěrů. Rozsah naštěstí není nijak velký (přibližně dohrání trvá ne náhodou také devět hodin), takže vícero průchodů je smysluplné.

Tvůrci vytěžili myslím maximum, obsah je napínavý a udrží hráče v pozornosti a technická stránka je na poměry NDS i mimo něj (hrál jsem na PC) velmi dobrá - zvláště soundtrack. 


[b]Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward[/b]

Pokračování dnes již kultovní adventury na NDS 999 (Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors) Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward bylo jednou z nejlépe přijatých vizuálních novel. Vysoká hodnocení (kotaku, destructoid, rps) byla určitou zárukou kvality, ale až nadšené ohlasy hráčů o překonání 999 poskytly definitivní jistotu. Ano, VLR bude skvělé (a také je). Nicméně, šlo o exkluzivitu na 3DS, takže reálné vyzkoušení bylo v nedohlednu.

Jen u méně her bych čekal port, než právě u trilogie Zero Escape – v mých očích striktně handheldové sérii. Nicméně Chunsoft se, díky za to, rozhodl pro PC port v reakci na windowsové vydání Time Dilemma, a tak jsem mohl pokračovat tam, kde jsem skončil v Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors.

Děj je pro sérii typicky zasazen do určitého komplexu (zde určitá opuštěná výzkumná laboratoř), ze kterého není útěku, a zaměřen na několik osob (devět), které se zde zdánlivě náhodně ocitnou. Hráč se může těšit na až detektivní odhalování toho, kdo, co, jak a proč, a také spletité příběhy a historii jednotlivých charakterů. A v režii zkušeného designéra a scénáristy Kotaro Uchikoshi (Ever 17) jde o velmi kvalitní četbu. A této aktivitě zdárně sekunduje adventurní část, zde především ve smyslu "escape-the-room", u kterého je třeba najít různé indicie, používat předměty a zodpovědět různé hádanky. Tedy vše, co zpříjemní nějakou tu chvilku od neustálého čtení. Oproti minulému dílu se tvůrci rozhodli přidat malou, ale o to výraznější pomoc hráčům – flowchart. Ten dokonale ukazuje rozvětvenost příběhu a monitoruje jednotlivé rozhodnutí. Konců je mnoho, a rozhodnutí mají dopad. Při prvním průchodu je ovšem lepší, nekoukat příliš na rozvětvenost a volit jen dle sebe a svých sympatií/antipatií (volí se zde v binárním modelu ally/betrayl) k dalším postavám. Ty tvoří protipól ke zdejšímu matně šedému prostředí a minimalistickému zabydlení – jsou výrazné a výstřední. A také nemluví o banalitách, ale naopak. Podobně jako v minulém díle, i zde je řešena řada témat a sociálně psychologických jevů (vězňovo dilema, čínský pokoj…).

Prakticky každý aspekt hry je zde dotažený, a od 999 se zlepšily především animace postav (a tedy jejich živější emoce) a i samotné hádanky a překážky. Jsou znovu striktně logické a zábavné k řešení. Technicky jde o bezproblémový port. Negativa jsou tak spíše subjektivní, než že by výrazně ovlivnila zážitek a hratelnost. Hudba opakuje několik motivů, ale vzhledem ke skvělému dabingu (japonský) to není ani negativem – jako podkres funguje velmi dobře.

Virtue's Last Reward je jedna z nejlepších vizuálních novel, a to i vzhledem k velké míře interaktivity, tak i kvůli příběhu a postavám. Celá série Zero Escape (ovšem i Danganronpa) posunuje žánr (pro západní publikum) do více tradiční, adventurní, podoby a na ohlasech to je znát. Takže vyzkoušení jen doporučuji, moc lepších adventur konec konců od roku 2010 nevyšlo.

Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors and Virtue's Last Reward are two of the best games that I've ever played so far. I went into the series just expecting a nice puzzle game, but I definitely got that and a lot more. The story from beginning to end is one that you're always invested in, and solving the secrets of the game, especially in Virtue's Last Reward, is very enjoyable. I could honestly write 5 pages worth of words about why these games are great, but all I have to say is that if you're looking through reviews and deciding whether or not to play this game, definitely play it. It'll be a great experience.

Отличная серия вн, в которой все капканы и рояли расставлены очень равномерно. Естественно, чтобы добраться до сути происходящего, придётся пройти все руты, и бэктрекинг по истории тут объясняется, причём в обеих играх он одинаковый. Все персонажи как всегда глубоки и представляют из себя не то что кажется на первый взгляд, но все их действия весьма логичны, если делать скидку на происходящее. 

Единственное что очень сильно не понравилось, так это переход на 3д анимацию в VLR, это просто кошмар, у спайков до сих пор (2019 год) огромные проблемы с анимацией 3д персонажей. Зачем нужно было отходить от канона 2д рисования я не совсем понял. Единственное объяснение - разработчики хотели прогресса и 3д персонажи хорошо вписываются в головоломки. На самом деле нет, многие сцены это хреново прирендеренные 3д модельки персонажей, у которых на лицах выражаются чёрти какие эмоции. У меня всю VLR очень кринжовые чувства вызывала Кловер, которая, почему то, во всех ситуациях выражала непомерную радость. 
Вобщем, зря спайки ушли в 3д, на мой взгляд, ведь есть же концепт-арты персонажей и они выглядят просто супер! Почему бы не заменить ими модельки персонажей? Зачем вы ушли в 3д? Я не могу придумать причины.
Great story

This was my first ever visual novel played and wow what a great introduction into the genre! The games plot line and twists will keep you playing and the charmingly bad voice acting will keep you smiling. There is, I believe 7 different endings, so there plenty of replay to be had with this game. Worth the price, worth the time!

Awesome!
Awesome to the max!

"Сначала я ничего не понял, а потом кааак понял!" - примерно так написан сюжет в Zero Escape. Прямые ответы игра дает только в самом конце, и это позволяет в полной мере насладиться этим будоражащим желанием узнать правду. Ты думаешь "ну вот сейчас наверняка что-то прояснится", но получаешь еще больше загадок и вопросов. И так на протяжении всей игры, интрига не отпускает ни на минуту, а великолепный саундтрек отлично передает мрачную, порой трагичную, и смертельно опасную атмосферу. Визуальная составляющая 999 настолько хороша, насколько это вообще возможно, чего, к сожалению, не могу сказать про VLR с ее нелепыми 3d-модельками, и еще более нелепыми катсценками. Впрочем, это не помешало с удовольствием пройти игру, так что вердикт:

9 из 9

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is a bundle of two games of the Zero Escape trilogy; 999 and Virtue's Last Reward. I adore both of these games. 

- People often compare Zero Escape to Danganronpa, and I do see the similarities with plotpoints and character tropes and such, but overall the experience is very different. Although I certainly do think that if you enjoyed Danganronpa, you're going to like the Zero Escape franchise as well. Just be warned that despite the similarities these are totally different games. I went it expecting "more Danganronpa", but stayed for Zero Escape.
- The games do have their problems: plot-wise, and also bug-wise (nothing game-breaking, it was fixed with closing and re-opening the game), but it didn't really bother me.
- As you can see, I've spent quite a while playing these games, and got them both to 100%. I've read that a lot of people think especially Virtue's Last Reward gets repetitive, but I don't agree (the skip -button truly saves the day).
- You will feel exhausted at times with the amount of information and theories and everything, but I didn't mind it at all. It was the good kind of exhaustion. In fact, I found the info very interesting most of the time.

Overall the whole experience has been amazing. The Nonary Games is certainly among my favorites right now, and after this I'm off to play Zero Time Dilemma. Zero Escape is very underrated and often in Danganronpa's shadow, but I recommend to at least wait for a sale to get this game, if you don't want to pay the full price. I got it from a sale as well, but even if I paid the full price, I wouldn't be disappointed. It's basically two games for the price of one even without a discount.

I truly recommend this bundle!

《极限逃脱》系列是我个人玩过最好玩的推理游戏系列之一，和《逆转裁判》系列不相伯仲。
本来已经全部玩过汉化版了，在Steam买了只为了补个票，支持一下制作方，顺便可以写评测。

三部曲《999》《善人之死》和《零时脱出》都是满分的作品，满分的剧情，把伪科学玩得太帅了。
本来以为第一部就已经很难超越了，没想到第三部依旧精彩。后来又玩了日语版第二部，居然也完全不逊色，只能说制作方太强了！

希望有生之年还能继续玩Chunsoft 出的好作品!

Note: these are my thoughts on the whole series. 

I played 999 (zero escape 1) on the DS around 9 years ago. Maybe this was my fate, maybe it was the gods telling me to!. Probably not, but I recently purchased the entire series on sale for closure on the story. The story is out there filled with psuedo science based on  a few books but the series does do the concepts justice. The story overall gets more intense with every game and doesn't leave (too many) loose ends. Overall was quite enjoyable and very interesting. 

My biggest problem with this was the changes in art style from basic drawings to CGI, It was different with every game and hampered the sense of continuity and honestly I personally did not like the CGI it was quite bad (What a surprise it was a case of BAD CG). Isn't going to stop me from recommending this series though.

The first game is really special, I highly recommend it. If you are unfamiliar with the series, then all the better. Honestly the less you know going into it the more enjoyable the well crafted story will be for you. It's not a perfect game though and at times, both the gameplay and the dialogue can drag a bit. But a little padding short of a perfect game is still pretty stellar and worth a try.

Unfortunately this is one of those series where the quality declines with each entry. One thing that made the first game more compelling is it's care for suspension of disbelief, only easing in the more far-out elements after you've already began accepting the story. The second and third games are a lot more careless with this and I can't hardly take the stories seriously. Also 2D > 3D, at least in this series. The graphics haven't aged well on the later two entries.
