Recommended: Yes, but..... 6/10

The Nonary Games port is actually two games in one, with the first game being a remaster. They’re both pretty good ports. For the ease of tracking, I’ve split the games apart:

[b]999: 6/10[/b]

So, 999 is the first instalment of a trilogy. In 999, you star as Junpei, who wakes up trapped in an escape room in the bowels of a ship. Suddenly, water starts flooding the room and you have to get out. This provides the meat of the game; Investigation and puzzles in an escape room sort of environment. If you’ve played an escape room IRL, it’s much the same in game, minus any time limit though. If you haven’t done an escape room IRL, give it a go, it’s good fun with a few friends, if you lack friends, buy this instead.

Once you solve the first room, you find out that you’re there with 8 other people and you all have been given 9 hours to get out, or the ship sinks. Hence the title; 9 rooms, 9 people, 9 hours. You all need to work together by use of technology in order to get through other escape rooms and hopefully, escape the sinking ship.

Dialogue is good, voice acting is solid. 999 is very serious, jokes are often downplayed or dismissed as inappropriate. If you’re not a fan of over-the-top dramatics (i.e. Danganronpa), you won’t really find it here. There is though, a cliched childhood melodramatic romance thing going on, which is pretty boring at this point in time for me... The plot is wrapped up in pseudoscience, it is thoroughly researched, a lot of the concepts presented within are readily available up on Wikipedia etc if you ever want to do a bit of extra reading!

None of the escape rooms are particularly hard. Where I was stuck, I ended up realising the solution was staring at me in the face and I just was blind to it because I got fixated on the wrong clue or method.

There are multiple endings here, six in total, with credits rolling for three of them. Several endings are ‘bad ends’, but the ‘normal’ ending isn’t really that satisfying a conclusion anyway. You need to pass through all of the endings to piece together the mystery. Fortunately, the game includes a flowchart and skip text feature so you can bum-rush through to see the more relevant scenes. The multi-playthrough is justified via the plot, so I can’t really go in depth about it without spoiling things. Some issues though; localisation is USA centric, which can throw you for a loop if you’re a non-US English speaker, since they use a lot of the Imperial measurements sometimes. Having dialogue chat about the melting point of water in Fahrenheit did have me running for my phone calculator for the more widespread Celsius measurement. An odd oversight, given only four nations in the world officially uses Fahrenheit. I bring it up because there’s a pretty important plot point and conversation based around this entire temperature, so it’s not a minor issue for me.

Additionally, the game misuses its time limit. There’s 9 hours as a time limit, yet a long-winded exposition dump takes up 2 minutes in one scene and only one sentence takes up 2 minutes in the next scene. 

Still, it’s a decent game, though I was getting tired after the fifth run through towards the “True” ending, each run was about 2.5 hours of playtime, so it is short in a sense depending how quick you solve the escape rooms, though the True End is a bit longer.

I recommend it, tentatively as it is a decent game, but I wasn’t massively blown away by it, the story ending in particular was underwhelming.

[b]Virtue's Last Reward: 5/10[/b]

A tricky one to review;

VLR is a direct sequel to 999, taking place one year after the events of that game.

You star as Sigma, a University student who gets kidnapped and put in an elevator with a lady called Phi. It is an escape room and you have to work together to get out or the elevator crashes and you all die.

If you’ve played 999, then VLR is more of the same. You have a visual novel portion, now with 3D graphics, which aren’t as good as the 2D sprites, which tells the story. Then you have an escape room portion where you solve puzzles and try to escape the room.

In 999 you worked together to seek the number 9 door to escape. In VLR this door is already provided to you from the start. A twist on the game is that you all start with the number 3 on your bracelets and you must play an AB game, where you vote Ally or Betray with your team-mates. This voting raises or subtracts your points total. Get over 9 and you are home-free. (Oh, the door only opens once, so…)

VLR’s story centres around time and is a complex one that spans 28 hours’ worth of reading. It is also a multiple route mystery, much like 999. However, where 999 focuses its story over 5 endings (4, with 1 ‘true end’) VLR goes big and hits it out of the park with 9 core endings, only one which is the true end, but multiple bad ends. There are over 20 endings when bad ends are included.

To add to the complexity, each of the 8 story ends must be seen in order to see the true ending. However, on top of this, you must see the endings in a certain order or you will be barred from progressing through each route. This ‘soft-lock’ is not presented to you until you hit the lock itself, which means that you should expect to jump around the story a lot. You can do this via the use of an in-game flow chart though.

This is unsatisfactory to me, so I went ahead and used a guide to unlock each ending in the ‘correct’ order. This streamlined my gameplay, and still clocked me in at nearly 30 hours, so I imagine if you played it blind you would be pushing easily 40+ hours and potentially would be bored or tired of the game by then, especially if the story didn't click for you. Even with a guide, by the end of this game I was exhausted by the constant jumping and solving of the storyline. It is a great storyline but it makes several sacrifices.

Firstly, it neglects the characters quite a bit in order to focus solely on the plot. 999 had a better balance in my opinion, with most of the cast having their moment in the limelight. VLR’s characters don’t really get to shine outside of a select few, and even on their unique routes tend to exposition dump their life story at the end rather than tell it more organically.

Secondly, it spreads that plot far too thin. Did we really need 8 different routes and endings to see the True ending? Did we really need over 20 endings anyway? A lot of the bad endings are pretty dull and tame considering. For those two reasons, I consider it a flawed game. I was genuinely interested in the plot, and the twists towards the finale of the True end were great, but they suffered similar issues to 999’s endings; Firstly; Exposition dumps in explanations and reveals, which I don’t think is good storytelling at times. Secondly, huge cliffhanger sequel-baits.

However, there’s another two or three negatives;

Firstly, the main character has no voice acting, in a game where everyone else is voice acted. That makes conversations seem odd, especially as everyone had voice acting in 999.

Secondly, executive meddling resulted in the game being ‘lighter’ and ‘funnier’ than 999, something the writer admits in a public interview, and I think that tainted his artistic vision somewhat.

Thirdly – and this has been admitted officially by the writer as a bad mistake -, after you finish the ‘true end’ there is a bonus ending that is officially NON-CANON and it leaves on an even more unsatisfying cliffhanger and then basically craps the bed on the entire journey.

After 28 hours and with the ending building up and surprising me with clever twists, it all came crashing down to a ‘is that it?’ 

I stress again, I loved the story concept, but the ending demolished all his good work getting there. I will be playing the third game, as I hear there was no executive meddling and that it concludes the series, but still, I feel this was a flawed and bumpy title, which is a great shame.

Uchikoshi Koutarou is a weird author: he has a knack for writing some engaging character driven dialogues and a vast knowledge about physics and philosophy that he loves to implement in his games, although he tends to recycle a good deal of its own ideas and tropes. And by that, I mean all of them. Always.
Yet it is rare to found an author with a knowledge so vast and so little clue as to what to use it for.

The Zero Escape series is probably one of the better examples of this duality.

As for the gameplay, each one plays like a classic point and click adventure with minigames, investigation and logic to be used to solve progressively challenging rooms to find clues to solve the immediate puzzles and the overall mystery. Be aware though Monkey Island it is not, and every enigma in each game will prove less challenging the more the players are proficient at remembering easy details and checking the in-game encyclopaedia. It feels rewarding solving these puzzle rooms on your own but the challenge bar is set very low and accessible for everyone who doesn’t like being stuck thinking too much.

What really buggers these games although is the absurdity extremes to which the plot and the characters are being constantly driven to, often writing themselves into a corner that progressively gets narrower at each game. The premise isn’t even that bad, without spoiling anything the first title, 9 Hours 9 People 9 Doors, is very engaging, the outset might be silly and cliched – group of people trapped in a death or life situation and restrained in a close environment surrounded by the sea, the Infinity series is calling and wants their synopsis back – but still it presents a serious life or death situations with different colourful and charismatic characters. They are memorable and the banter is great between some of them, you are invested and want to discover what they hide under the surface: why they were kidnapped and brought here?, how come they know so much about complex scientific and philosophical topics?, is one of them secretly helping the mastermind villain and if so why?, what are the ultimate motives to bring some apparently unrelated people together and constantly try to murder them but always leaving a fair chance to escape unscathed? The finale is silly but it revolves around these same characters the players have grown attached to, so even if the story leaves some holes, unfinished plotlines, weird narratives and cliff-hangers, there isn’t any real feel that any of these questions need to be answered to feel a proper closure.


Then Virtue’s Last Reward happens. It seemingly starts in a very similar vein to 999 but despite some more challenging puzzles and complex multi-layered plot structure, it goes where the story shouldn’t have never gone: focusing on the sci-fi mumbo jumbos rather than the likable characters. There is still some hilarious banter and relatable moments thorough the story but, rather than with the purpose of escaping and survive, everything is now done for the sake of playing with a straight face through absurd plot twists and world-threatening menaces that never feel real or immediate, as the characters are still trapped in a locked environment with only newspapers and some scattered info about what has happened outside, far from them.

The recurring characters are underused or completely different from what they were in 999, most of the cast is either expendable or plain useless to the story, being there just for the sake of being there, and the unlikeable twat that looks like the villain since the beginning of the game is, in fact, the villain. At a certain point it is clear that all seemingly importance given to the characters is being replaced by the exaggerated need to surprise the players but the punchline is akin to having someone set up a surprise birthday party so meticulous and contrived that they eventually get the date wrong.

Moreover, VLR also throws away a great deal of the charm from 999 by replacing simple but detailed 2D sprites with horrendous 3D models with comically hilarious and stiff expressions and stock movements that resemble more underproduced robots than animated characters. You can turn off the voice acting, which is amazing in both games, but you can’t turn off those models from showing at every turn and being still in idle animations with an unconcerned face about their death or life situation.

I still recommend both games because the immersion is equally strong in both of them – until the latter stages of Virtue’s Last Reward at least – and, even if it doesn’t mean much as a compliment, in no part of that game they will sunk as low as in the third instalment, Zero Time Dilemma.
Two fantastic experiences.

[h1]ПАЖЖИТЕ, ТО ЕСТЬ КАК ЭТО У МЕНЯ НЕТ ОБЗОРА НА ПЕРВЫЕ ДВЕ ИГРЫ НОЛЬПОБЕГА?[/h1]
За менее чем десять часов до выхода новой, решил я посмотреть на старые игры чунсофтов в целом и заметил, что на эту пару-игр-в-одной у меня нет обзора. И это несправедливо, потому что она заслуживает своего плюса. 
Я бы мог повторить свой обзор на Нулевую диллему и ни разу бы не покривил душой. Эта, к сожалению, на данный момент трилогия, прекрасна в своем полумертвом жанре квеста. От задачек и саспенса до сюжета, который хоть местами классически по-японски бредов, но затягивает. Неплохая музыка и неплохо прописанные персонажи дополняют картину и несмотря даже на отсутствие жестокости, коей в третьей части в изобилии - обе игры все еще мрачноваты. И история их тоже достаточно грустна, поскольку в девичестве обе части находились в жутком, абсолютно не сексуальном, рабстве у одной из страшнейших кар всея гейминга - Корпорации Зла[гром на заднем плане] [b]НИНТЕНДО[/b][крики боли и мучений тех кто пострадал от рук их], но теперь всё хорошо и в побегайку-безвремянку можно поиграть и на вашем прекрасном мастер-рейс компухтере и даже более того - бандл стоит менее одного килорубля. 
Хотя есть три противопоказания к покупке - незнание английского, ибо текста много, так как это всё ещё на 1/3 визуальные новеллы, нелюбовь к квестам и/или японской анимации. Все у кого этих противопоказаний нет - рекомендую таки брать.
[i]Большинство людей в нашем мире абсолютно не ценят хорошие игры. Но только не мы и не теперь...[/i]

No hay nada que pueda decir sobre estos juegos que no haya sido dicho ya. Los recomiendo de corazón, son juegos extraordinarios.

999 es una obra maestra. Lo jugué por primera vez es un emulador de NDS hace muchos años, y su gran narrativa me cambió la vida. Virtue's Last Reward es un excelente juego también, aunque un poco inferior.
Son novelas visuales y juegos de puzzle, donde constantemente se jugará entre la vida y la muerte, mientras se resuelve el misterio de quiénes son todos y por qué están ahí.

Estos juegos tienen dos cosas a considerar: La primera es que solo están en inglés. La segunda es que tienen múltiples finales, y, por lo tanto, requieren ser jugados varias veces para entender la historia completa.

Si entiendes inglés y tienes paciencia para leer mucho y encontrar diferentes finales, no dudes ni un segundo en jugar estos juegos. No te arrepentirás.

A Masterpiece of a Game!

I just discovered this gem recently and had a really great experience playing it! Didn't play any game until I completed both 999 and VLR. It is quite addictive due to a good progress of the story and the storyline itself. 

999 Review:

This game has the better artwork, soundtrack and ambience. It really delivers the suspense and chills. Voice acting is great! Enjoyed playing the puzzles too, well except the ones that involves too much mathematics/numbers as I suck at math. But I guess the puzzles in 999 are easier overall. I also prefer 999 for the gameplay on how to search a room compared to VLR.  999 is more simple and neat. Oh and I won't ever get used to the nerve racking  feeling everytime a door opens. Overall this is the better game of the 2.

VLR Review:

At first I was dissapointed a bit with the change of artwork and gameplay, spent some hours before getting used to it. Voice acting is great too but there are times when the backround music has annoying sounds, I actually had to check my speaker a few times to check if it is getting faulty but It seems part of the game. As the story progresses, I feel like this is more of a complete game than 999, Aside from the fact that it is a sequel. VLR offers more explanations for everything and the story bit by bit completes a bigger picture. The plot is more complicated than the first one but I feel more satisfied with this. This game has more math and number puzzles though. Harder puzzles too and some requires you to jump into different flowcharts to discover an answer to different timelines and scenarios, But that is the beauty of it. You need to complete the whole story bit by bit and the truth will slowly form.But I don't like the part when characters travel from one place to another, so much time is wasted waiting. I think this game has the better dialogues and plenty of hilarious conversations too compared to the first. I prefer this game than the first mostly due to how the storyline/progress is designed. 

Both games are amazing! Easily one of my favorite games ever played!

I'd been wanting this series for a while, it originally started with "0 Time Dilemma" and one fateful day a friend gifted me this combo pack of the first two games. I'm not going to talk about the story in detail because any details revealed will wind up going into spoiler territory. I will say this though; if you enjoy a game that leaves you in the dark until the very last moment and finally reveals the grand scheme of the story to blow your mind, buy the games. It took me roughly all the recorded time on my files (~55 in 999, ~40 in VLR) to not only understand the story in full, but make the connections that branch between both games, see all the tie-ins and link the stories together. All of that is with contextual clues and 0 theory crafting. The story for these games has almost 0 plot holes, no loose ends, and in my opinion is very well written. There's little jokes here and there to keep you entertained through the serious tone, and puzzles to keep you thinking without boring you. I genuinely have fallen in love with this series and will be purchasing 0 Time Dilemma when I get the chance. If you wish to understand what happens in that game you must play these two first to fully grasp the sequence of events. Please, just buy the games, they're definitely worth your time and money if you like theoretical science, philosophy, latin, and lewd MCs. 

10/10 I wish I could go back to the past and re-play this series....or could I?

Ho giocato 999 per nintendo DS nel lontano 2013 e finalmente ho recuperato il sequel, consigliatissimo. La Spike Chunsoft non sbaglia

999の方も、シボウデスの方もどちらも完全クリアしました。
コアのストーリーはとても面白いです。よく練られていると思います。
ただ、肝心の面白い部分は本当に後半（85%以降くらいから）になって一気に出てきます。
面白い部分にたどり着くためには何度も同じような構成（でも微妙に掛け合いが違う）を繰り返し見る必要があり、そこを超えられるかどうかで大きく評価が異なると思います。もう少し小出しに面白い部分を明かしてもいいと思うのですが...

DSではチャプターセレクトできなかった？という噂を聞き、チャプターセレクトできなければ確実に積んでいたと思いました。
未読スキップのオンオフがタイトル画面でしかできないところが少し不便です。
シボウデスの方は、プレイする時に3つの大きな分岐を一通りクリアした後は未読エリアのスキップありの設定にすることをお勧めします。（冗長な移動画面も速くできます。）
（私はラスト2週くらいでその設定にしましたが、快適度が全然違いました。）

私は、アドベンチャーゲームは基本自分が最初に選んだ選択肢が正解で、1週クリアしかせず、気に入ったら2週目をプレイという感じで遊ぶことが多いです（トゥルーエンド見ないことが多いので、このジャンル好きな人からは批判きそうです...）が、このゲームは1週クリアだけでは物語の3%くらいしか分からず、かといって2週目のモチベーションも薄いというところが辛いです。
その点、ダンガンロンパの方が物語の起伏のバランスは良いと思います。

長くなってしまい、悪口ばかりに見えるかもしれませんが、私でも完全クリアできましたし実際にストーリーは面白かったので、アドベンチャー好きにはお勧めです。是非完全クリアまでプレイしてみてください！
（プレイ時間はつけっぱなしで放置していた時間も含むので参考になりません。）

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games includes the first two games of the series; 999 and Virtue's Last Reward (VLR). The genre can be described as a visual novel but has many challenging puzzles amongst them. The Nonary Games have thought provoking and mind-blowing stories with plenty of twist and turns throughout. It has a way of entrapping players' brains, drawing you deeper and deeper into the mystery, until you simply MUST uncover the answers to your many questions. If you're like me, expect a few late nights once you start this one up. 

I had not heard of this title until recently, so I seemed to have missed the initial hype when it was released on Nintendo DS in 2009. I do not normally play visual novels nor have an interest in anime titles and yet, I simply am obsessed with these 2 games. Highly recommended for anyone even considering it.

[u]Pros[/u]
+ Absolutely breathtaking plot for each game. One that will keep you on your toes with ample plot twists that you will never see coming.
+ Excellent voice acting (I played with English VO).
+ Challenging and immensely unique puzzles that are [b]extremely[/b] rewarding to complete.
+ Remastered graphics for 999
+ The two games are linked in the most profound ways (recommend playing in order).
+ Many endings. Replayability is encouraged and needed to fully understand the story.
+ Requires notetaking and concentration. 
+ Different choices lead to different outcomes.
+ Striking characters with unique personalities.


[u]Cons[/u]
- It took me a while to get used to the graphics downgrade from 999 to VLR, as only 999 has been remastered.
- I found the travelling in VLR excessive and annoying, forcing players to watch characters move from room to room on the map, stopping  here and there for door-opening cutscenes.
- Moving around puzzle rooms in VLR was much more difficult than in 999. You must drag the sides of the room to turn, compared to 999's easier method of using arrows on the sides of the scene.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Where do I begin? Anyone who is familiar with these games will know that there is just no easy way to explain the story without dropping huge spoilers. 

Both games feature 9 people who have been kidnapped and brought to an unknown location. They must complete puzzles and follow a somewhat complex sets of rules to escape.. or face potentially deadly consequences. Watch how the choices of these 9 individuals change in response to these dire circumstances and how tensions rise.

Why are they kidnapped? Why are there puzzle rooms? What is their connection to each other? Who kidnapped them? Where are they? 
These are just a fraction of the questions which will arise through the typical playthrough. All will be uncovered ... eventually. 

The story is addictive and with so many layers to uncover, I struggled to press 'quit' many, many times. I found myself compelled to complete all endings. A very important note for this series is that you cannot play them just once. It is pointless if you do. Players can only understand everything if multiple endings are reached. If you are reading this and are only planning to play the game once, for maybe 10 hours or so, then I do not think this game is for you. However, the more hours you put into this series, the more answers you will get and the more rewarded you will be. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Majority of both games are played as a visual novel that has subtitles and is fully voice acted (except the main character in VLR). Players can use M1 to skip or speed up the dialogue pace. 

There are many puzzle rooms throughout each game, and these took a while for me to get used to, as I have not had much experience in similar titles. They usually involve many different aspects and mini puzzles to obtain an object to be used in another puzzle in the room and so forth. These are continued until the escape password is retrieved and then it will return to being a typical VN. I found the puzzle rooms to be a nice break from the bizarre story and immense reading, but were also quite challenging, probably more so than any other game I have played before. The feeling of the screen 'you found it' when you finish the puzzle room, gave me huge feelings of satisfaction and I knew that I was one step closer to all the answers I sought. 

In both games, there is a much-needed flow chart that portrays all the pathways that players can take. These exact route endings are not revealed until after playing them, but it gives an idea of what is coming. Along the way, there are many 'locks' that disable players from continuing with that route in the flowchart, most likely because to continue it, another route is needed to unlock the answers in the first route. Slightly confusing, but this is just another reason of why replaying the game is vital to its understanding, and to appreciate its ingenuity. 

In the first game (999), players can choose and switch between the adventure mode where game characters speak and have voice overs, or the novel mode where players read what is happening like a book, with no voice overs. VLR does not have this option but instead incorporates both aspects into the game well.

Due to replaying the game so much, it is important to note that you do not have to sit and read through all the same dialogue as before. There is an option to skip/ fast forward all previously encountered dialogue which is extremely useful. Although, there is an extraordinary amount of dialogue and even though there are so many different paths and endings, not too much of the dialogue is actually repeated when exploring different routes. Still a handy feature nonetheless.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
[b]999[/b] has been remastered and  the graphics are modernised with today's anime style, conveying more realistic looking characters.

[b]VLR[/b] took a while for me to get used to its dated graphics, as opposed to the first game. They are more cartoon-like and pixelated than the first. Nevertheless, after a few hours of playing I completely forgot about this contrast and it had no impact on my opinion of the game. 

[h1]Sound[/h1]
[b]999[/b] has full voice overs for each character. The characters and their voices are expressive and drew me into their individual stories.

[b]VLR[/b] as stated before has full voice overs except the main protagonist. Once again, the voice overs are extremely well done with a special mention to Zero Jr. whose spectacular voice acting and incorporation of different accents/tones will not be easily forgotten and never fails to make me laugh.

[h1]Price and Content[/h1]
Completing these two games can easily take up to 60 hours and is definitely an experience like no other. I picked this bundle up on sale, however $AU42.95 is an adequate price for the number of rewarding hours that it encompasses. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
I have over 40 hours clocked on these two games and I can say one thing for sure, they both have crazy, mind-boggling stories that actually make a bit of sense. They are extremely well thought-out and almost every question or plot hole is discussed. I am typically not someone who fully appreciates the VN or anime titles however, I truly appreciate The Nonary Games existence and it remains an example of the brilliance that can be achieved in the genre. Even after debuting on Nintendo DS, 10 years ago, the series stands strong. I recommend it to anyone, even those with a slight interest in the genre like myself, you may be surprised by how much you enjoy it.

I've finished 999 on the DS and VLR on the 3DS before, and after playing through both again, my stance on the games is still the same. IMO, VLR is the best VN I've ever played and 999 is a close second.

Both are as much visual novel games as they are puzzle games. The puzzles are challenging enough to be a relevant part of the game yet simple enough to still be enjoyable.

The story is just amazing. It's intriguing. Sometimes it's very confusing, but the confusion just makes you all the more curious about it. Minor spoiler: [spoiler]Bear in mind that the series makes use of bootstrap paradoxes a lot, so if you get frustrated by those, then this probably isn't for you.[/spoiler] That being said, it's one of those games where explaining the story to someone would take hours to tell because of how complicated it is, so you tell the person they should just play the game. (Fun fact: I really tried this. I think it took more than an hour just to explain the third game to someone who'd already played the first and second. And that was just the simplified version.)

I really appreciate that they added the flowchart to 999 that wasn't there in the DS version, making replays much less tedious. In fact, the stellar story and gameplay isn't just why I'm recommending this. They added a feature that would make it more convenient for the players, and since the games are from the DS line, they had to switch up one of the puzzles to accommodate it for the PC version.

My only comment would probably be that the last part of 999 is a better experience in dual-screen, but we can't really do much about that since this is a PC port.

極限脫出三部曲在steam上分為兩項產品販售，並且都有英日配音和文本
Zero Escape: The Nonary Games是一代《九小時九人九扇門》和二代《好人不長命》的合輯
Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma則是三代《刻之困境》


這三部作品的開場，都是有九名幸運的(?)參賽者被迫參加自稱為「零」的人所舉辦的遊戲，且每次遊戲的主題都不同
在《九小時九人九扇門》當中，參賽者要湊出對應的數字根進入密室，以此逃脫即將被淹沒之船的「九人遊戲」
在《好人不長命》當中，參賽者分組進入相對應的色彩門拿到鑰匙卡，之後返回投票室進行合作或是背叛隊友的「雙面遊戲」
在《刻之困境》當中，參賽者要在記憶每隔一段時間會被消除的情況下破解密室之謎，緊接著面臨攸關生死的「抉擇遊戲」


這系列在一二代是由視覺小說與密室脫逃兩部分組成，三代則由過場影片與密室脫逃兩部分組成
密室謎題的設計並不會乏味，但劇情正精采時突然切換成解謎讓人很著急啊
三代雖然人設走味，但因為劇情設定與演出方式改變的緣故，解謎時的掃興感沒有前兩代重，遊戲體驗較佳


由於後續作品都會提及前作的大爆點，如果有心入坑還是建議依序一路玩下去
如果是不喜歡視覺小說類型的玩家，直接把《刻之困境》當成單一作品遊玩也是不錯的

Both games are good, but my only gripe with VLR it is too "flowcharty". The way the game structured is you can get through 75% of it consisting nothing more than dead ends and "to be continued" screens and then get bombarded by endings in succession. Which is a shame because some of them are pretty touching, but the "I have to get through this route to unlock another one" feeling can deflate the impact they have pretty hard.

Considering this version is the only feasible way you can experience the story of 999 nowadays (which I consider to be a fantastic visual novel), and you get a fairly good sequel to it in VLR along with it, makes it a worthwhile purchase for me.

I still think that the PC version of 999 is far inferior to the original version, but it adds one or two good new things and still manages to preserve most of what was good about the original luckily. The PC port of VLR is mostly completely fine aside from a glitch that was kind of weird but is minor in the grand scheme of things.

Two games, two reviews. Here goes:

NINE PERSONS, NINE HOURS, NINE DOORS
Great game. A visual novel with room escape sections. In this game, nine people are put on this ship and told they have nine hours to find the door with a nine before the ship sinks. There are some interesting plot twists and you will be enjoying seeing everything come together in the end. The puzzles are good, not too hard or too easy, and the characters will keep you interested until the end.

VIRTUE'S LAST REWARD
Like the last game, this is also a visual novel with room escape sections. This game takes another set of nine people and puts them in another game with their lives on the line. It takes the best parts of the first game and improves and expands on them for a worthy sequel. Gameplay-wise there are some improvements, most notably an in-game notepad to keep yourself organized. The puzzles are harder, but not overly difficult (with a few exceptions.) Overall, an improvement on the previous game.

So many puzzles.

Both 999: Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors and Virtue Last Reward are hard as hell, in my opinion VTL is harder tho. These games are simply amazing, best visual novels that i could ever play, the story, the characters, the music and the gameplay is so good, i cant even explain you how well the story is (you'll have to discover it yourself), there're so many plot twist and great moments in it. 

And as i said before, the puzzles are not easy, you'll need some marker and a paper to remember everything that you do, they are so well made and they are so entertaining, is hard to get bored honestly.
Anyway if you like this genre and love a good science fiction story (and puzzles too), you should totally play this game.
Great story and characters, multiple endings, interesting puzzles. It's really hard to stop playing this game, you always want to know what happens next.

Let me get the worst parts and cautionary warnings out of the way first:
1. There is some anime cliche in both games. I found it annoying because I don't like really any of those tropes. An example of this is at one point in Virtue's Last Reward (henceforth abbreviated as 'VLR') the protagonist asks one of the women to promise dress up in a swimsuit if they solve the puzzle correctly. It's usually played off like "doh, you perv". Still, all of the jokes around this combined make up maybe 1-2% of the game's dialogue, so while it is present, it is not anywhere near dominant (very much unlike the Danganronpa series).
2. You need to some tolerance to accept psuedo-science as a storytelling aspect. This is common in science fiction, but this series especially embraces it, even around a few contemporary topics.
3. The cyclic nature of some of the situations and challenges means you will see some dialogue lines many times. The games both have a 'Skip' setting that appears when you've seen a scene before, but it's not perfect. Sometimes, it won't properly enable itself. In VLR specifically, the slow and methodical tracing of map paths (how it visualizes the protagonist's movement) can start to wear on you.
4. Exploring every path in these games is often important. Especially in VLR, this means you will sometimes have to take actions you may find distasteful. You may need to betray friends or help enemies, regardless of your feelings towards the character. These games are about choices, but they are not about choosing.
5. The ending of the second game has some cliffhanger aspects. This is not a large deal as the third game exists, so this is just a warning that if you play these two games, you'll probably want to pick up the third one as well (Zero Time Dilemma).
6. Puzzles are a dominant part of both games. You may need to look up a solution to one or two of them at one point if you fail to derive the answer from the provided clues. The characters in the story do provide useful hints, and VLR has an 'easy mode' for the puzzles which simplifies them and increases the level of hints offered by characters.

With everything negative or warning I just said taken into account, I strongly recommend these two games. The puzzles are great. Almost all of them really challenge you to better yourself and to think in unconventional ways. Despite that, they managed to find the sweet spot in difficulty that the puzzles are usually not a stumbling block for players (with one or two potential exceptions). The storytelling in these games is fantastic. They tell a story that challenges many aspects of morality under life-threatening situations, explores the concepts of destiny and fate, and delves deeply into the inner workings of causality. The games' endings are impressive (and some are mind-blowing), but what is really interesting is the care that is put into building the structure required to get to those endings. The characterization of each participant over the course of the journey is fantastic, as is the way the games establish mystery and build intrigue through slight deviations in the routes. Altogether, the three games (these two plus Zero Time Dilemma) form one of the best stories ever told.

Two games in one, 999 & Virtue's Last Reward.  Both games are very good.

In both games, 9 people are kidnapped by an unknown person and forced to play a game where they need to work together or die.  Both games are visual novels with escape room puzzle games sprinkled in to break up the reading sections.  In 999 you get to make choices about what rooms to enter which branches the story off in different directions.  VLR allows you to make choices about what room to enter as well as whether you want to ally with or betray the people you went into the room with.  These choices branch the story off in different directions.  Each game features a bunch of different endings depending on what you've chosen.  VLR has 20 different endings.  Both games have a flowchart system once you reach an ending that allows you to jump back into the past to make different choices and get to different endings.  Both games have a skip dialogue option which will skip through all dialogue you've seen before until you reach something new.

Positives:  Interesting plots, good stories, decent if somewhat cliche characters, good dialogue, occasionally humorous, bunch of different endings, puzzles range from really obvious and easy to some that'll make you think for a bit, combined both games will probably take 50 hours or more to complete.

Neutral:  VLR uses 3D models for the characters which I found a bit jarring and didn't particularly care for at first, but you get used to it after a bit.  Occasional abrupt changes of tone/lines of dialogue that come out of nowhere and don't really fit the situation the characters are in.  A couple puzzle rooms are a bit slow/annoying to move around in.

Negatives:  Some unnecessary and repetitive dialogue making the games a couple hours longer than they needed to be (No game, I haven't forgotten what happens when someones BP goes to 0 or negative, it's a fairly important and easy to remember plot point.  You don't need to flash back to that discussion on every pathway).  A few obtuse puzzles where a little more information would've been useful.  Also a couple annoying puzzles.  999 has a somewhat complicated lock system that isn't really explained at all and if you happen to accidentally pick the right options each time like I did, you'll have no clue what they mean.  That said, it's pretty easy once you know how it works.

VLR has scenes where your character walks around to different rooms and it shows this by popping up a map of the facility so you can see where you're going.  Unfortunately this quite often takes an annoyingly long time, especially when they remove the map just to show you a scene of a door/elevator being operated and then pop the map back up again and watch your character continuing to move around only to watch another scene of a door/elevator being operated and then the map pops back up again to you moving.  They really could've made the movement quicker and cut out the door/elevator operation scenes.

Do you like reading and escape room games/puzzles?  You'll probably like these games.  These games probably aren't for you if you don't like to read, have ADD, or don't enjoy escape room/puzzle games.

初作「極限脱出 9時間9人9の扉」は元々NintendoDSで発売された脱出ゲームとノベルゲームの融合。
この作品中に重要になってくるのが「数字根」。
簡単に言えばいくつかの整数を足して、2桁以上になればそれぞれを1桁の整数として新たに足し、最終的に1桁にする。
例えるなら誕生日を使った占いで「あなたのラッキーナンバーは！？」的な時によく用いられてる。
と言えば「計算メンドクセ…」と思うかもしれないが、この手の算数は全てノベルパートで全説明してくれるので一切気にしなくていい。「ああ次のパートナーはコイツラか」が事前にわかるレベル。

で、ノベルパートと脱出ゲームパートを繰り返していき「最終的な真相に辿り着く」のが目的。
製品紹介にもあるが、1作目からしっかりとしたフローチャートが用意されてるし、既読スキップはしっかり早いのでダレる展開はほぼ無い。
脱出ゲーム部分も基本的に一回クリアすれば2回目をやる必要はない。「基本的には…」

この手のゲームはシナリオが肝だが…。
確かに気がついたらどこぞに閉じ込められて、ルールに従わないと殺す…なんて話にリアリティはないし現実離れしてる内容ではあるが、「この作品の終盤以降で語られる内容」が、ゲームの完全攻略の説明において上手い事言うなぁ…と思う反面、急に「ナンノコッチャ？」な展開になってしまう。
その為、「これはこういう世界観なんだ」と受け入れる感性がなければ正直厳しい。
なるべくそうスムーズに思えるようにシナリオ展開してくれてはいるんだが…

なのでラストまで遊んでこのシナリオ展開に違和感を感じなければカップリングの「善人シボウデス」も楽しめるでしょう。
唯一自分がケチをつけるとしたら、ムービーパートがいくつか差し込まれるが「DS用の動画を引き伸ばしただけ？」というぐらいムービーが汚くなる。
30分・1時間と長丁場のムービーならともかく、数秒程度の差し込み動画なら作り直そうよ…
そのぐらいの手間は掛けようよ…。
こういう所が本当に残念だった。

-----
次に「善人シボウデス」のレビュー。
前作の正当進化という感じ。
変わらぬノベルパートと脱出ゲームパートで構成され、フローチャートも非常に便利。
それに加えて、前作は基本立ち絵だったキャラクターが、ポリゴンキャラで描かれそこまで派手に動かないが（日本語版なら？）リップシンクも結構頑張ってる感じでちゃんと表情と口パクが合ってるように見える。
また、脱出ゲームパートも数が増えた上に前作が難しいと感じた人がいたからか、今作では「まずはHARDモードでチャレンジし、どうしても解けない場合はそのパートに限りEASYモードに落としてプレイ」が可能になってる。
「兎に角脱出ゲームが邪魔！俺はノベルパートが楽しみてぇんだ！」という人はこれも活用すればいい。

シナリオボリュームも増えて、前作が上記に書いたようにシナリオ展開を受け入れられた人にとっては楽しい…と思えるはずだが、「前作のあの設定有りき」で物語が当たり前に進むので、「そう言えば昔前作遊んでたから善人だけでいいか」と思う人もやっぱり前作からやっておく方がいい。
じゃないと話に全くついていけなくなる…ってか、一旦見誤ったら「こいつらどこの国の言葉話してんの？」っていうぐらいSF作品バッリバリの展開になるので…
（後半部分はかなり詳しく図解入りで解説してはくれるけど、やっぱり話についていけなくなってしまったらノベルパートは苦痛以外の何物でもない）

最後に。
自分は初作を遊び、善人は体験版の操作性が悪くて未プレイ。
現時点で最終作（後にレビュー書きます）となる刻のジレンマが昔安く買えたのでプレイして
「全く話の意味が解らん！」と特に最終作はシナリオ部分はほぼ無視してた（おかげで終盤の謎解きが読み返しの繰り返しで地獄だった）が、ZERO ESCAPE三部作の1・2作目はなんとか話も掴めて結構面白かった。
残念ながらセール期間が終了し元の価格に戻ってしまったが、セール期間に気になってたけど積みゲーあるし、興味はあるけどなんだかなぁ…と思ってたら千円以内なら激安！と思って間違いないです。というか、普通にSteam定価で買っても損とは思わない内容だと思います。

Классическая новелла от Spike Chunsoft. Начинается чёрт знает где, на голову сразу сваливаются толпы персонажей и ставится ЗАДАЧА: сделать ДЕЛО или помрёшь. В процессе выполнения ЗАДАЧИ начинает твориться некая шизофреническая бредятина, граничащая с магией, градус неадеквата повышается до предела и в этот самый момент игра делает умное лицо и толкает гигантскую псевдонаучную лекцию о том, как из-за кота Шрёдингера можно менять прошлое. Добивается лекция волшебным словом: [SPOILER_REDACTED].
"Ну как, всё понял?" - спрашивает игра. 
- А? 
"Умница, а теперь начнём реальный сюжет"
- Не-не-не, подож...
Тормоза окончательно сносит, и бешеный сюжет пробивает границы слабого человеческого разума, улетая сквозь время и пространство, пока пустая оболочка несчастного гамера раскачивается взад-вперёд в кресле, время от времени глупо хихикая.

А, ещё в игре были головоломки.

𝒬𝓊𝒶𝓃𝓉𝒾𝒸 𝑀𝒶𝓈𝓉𝑒𝓇𝓅𝒾𝑒𝒸𝑒

 This is a collection of the first two games of the series, 999 and Virtue's Last Reward.
  Partially a mystery-horror Virtual Novel ,with a magnificent & engaging story, that will probably make you question life & existence, intriguing characters with good punch lines, 
plot twists that you won't see coming and a dozens of references to actual historical paradox events,which are literally mind blowing,
  ·partially an escape room puzzle, that require searching for clues & items in a small area, that you either use, examine and/or combine, & solving some provoking and challenging brain stimulants that require logic , observation and a bit of math. I find quite balanced the time transactions in witnessing the story - searching & solving riddles and vice versa. 

  The voice casting is outstanding and adds a lot of depth.
 (At least in Japanese which was my take). You can feel the emotional & psychological tension of each character in every single line. 999 is 95% voice covered if not more , while for Virtue's Last Stand i'd say 85-90% since everyone is voiced except the protagonist.
 
  The Music is pretty neat, adds a really great deal to the overall atmosphere , but its not one of the game's strong parts.
Don't get me wrong there , it's more than decent , just overshadowed by game's plot, gameplay and voice casting .

I haven't written much about the Story which is what makes the Nonary Games the masterpiece it is ,only cause i wanna keep it as spoiler free as possible. To keep it simple , it's about 9 persons getting trapped in a facility & have to go through trials so  that only a handful (and thats an if) will escape.
Expect to challenge your mind, while also your perspective and your beliefs with this one.

  Took me roughly ~75 hours to 100% complete both 999 and VLS and i can say that every second of it was totally worth it.
 
 It's one of these few games that you'd want erased from your memory so that you could experience it once more.
 Surely a captivating trip!!
 
 Don't Skip it!!

[h1]概要[/h1]
9人のキャラクターで繰り広げる、脱出ゲーム＋サウンドノベルゲーム。家庭用携帯機で出た『9時間9人9の扉』と『善人シボウデス』の2つのゲームが入ったパックとなっている。

[h1]評価[/h1]
[b]おすすめ度：★★★☆☆（3点 / 5段階）[/b] 
購入価格：￥2,902

脱出ゲームパートは基本的にストーリーとは独立しており、時間制限も無く、間違えたらヒントも出される適度な難易度。なかなかの楽しさで、ノベル部分との相乗効果を生んでいる。

それよりも、終始「謎」が存在するノベルパートの魅力が大きい。閉鎖空間を舞台としたサスペンスチックな趣きとなっており、重くギスギスする部分もあるが、時折アッと言わせるような展開がある。特に終盤にはまず予想できない劇的な展開が用意されていて、強く印象に残った。

これだけで2作品分のボリュームがあるため、コスパも悪くない。『ダンガンロンパ』とは似て非なるゲームではあるが、そちらが好きならきっと楽しめると思う。

[h1]実績[/h1]
35時間で全実績解除。ルートを全部埋めていけば良いのだが、ゲーム内にフローチャートもあるため比較的簡単。元が家庭用なので、攻略サイトも充実している。

玩完了999的真结局过来评论一下，最后的关卡和nds不一样，所以找不到攻略只能自己想，其他基本有攻略，不行可以找视频。
给大家一个提示就是让周围的黄框数字的根是9，也就是点hint所有蓝色数字为9就行。最后的密码是一位数字，别被英文骗了！！
再说一下剧情感想，我觉得本身剧情说的就是一个挺不符合实际的理论吧，所以最后很难解释一些现象的发生，挺有趣的。像打真结局就必须先经历某个结局，真结局的时候会想起某个结局的线索，这是为什么，对于我来说就比较像世界线记忆混了。不过也有人说是男主和玩家的信息传达，可能这个说法比较接近游戏理论。每个人都有自己的经历，虽然不会去详细说出来，但很连贯，也没必要知道每个人的身世呀经历。所以说总体还是很赞的，我喜欢这种烧脑剧情游戏！可惜的是结局不完美，可能是给第二部留下悬念吧，但我真的很遗憾，那种没玩到结局的感觉，很难受，说明商家成功了，我赶紧打完所有结局玩第二部去了~

Interesting games. I really liked the Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors (999) part.
The Virtue's Last Reward (VLR) felt like a downgrade, from the story - to choices - to the visuals.
I recommend this game to those who enjoy escape room puzzles.

Don't get me wrong, I think both of these games are solid, and are the best games of it's type that I've played. It's no Danganronpa, don't go into this thinking you're going to get a trial experience with investigation in one go, this collection is a visual novel with escape-room puzzles at it's core, and deserves to be held to it's own expectations rather than Danganronpa's expectations. Also, don't expect to only play one playthrough. Zero Escape games MUST be replayed many times in order to get a full experience of the story, and it really only truly comes together as a narrative after each timeline has been explored. If you're only willing to play once, this isn't the game for you (even though Zero Escape does provide tools to make subsequent runs much much simpler, with options such as skipping previously read dialogue and returning to specific key events). I do think these games are both extremely enjoyable, and if it weren't for a few things, I would feel no issues with giving these games an overwhelmingly positive review. 

As well, as a thing to consider before purchasing (with many other reviews complaining that there is too much dialogue) this game is a VISUAL NOVEL at it's roots. There is a lot of reading. This should be obvious, but other negative reviews of the game failed to pick up on this simple fact (even when the first and second user-defined tags relate to visual novels, and the screenshots showing typical visual novel dialogue boxes). If you go into Zero Escape expecting a complicated story with puzzles in between, you will be satisfied, but if you go into Zero Escape expecting only puzzles, you will be disappointed. As well, Spike Chunsoft's visual novels tend to be LONG. Please be aware of this before purchase. All Danganronpa and Steins Gate games exceed 30 hours, and this collection is NO EXCEPTION (with the FIRST game taking ~20h on it's own to beat, as the shorter game). This game requires massive time dedication. I feel, in my opinion, this time dedication is well worth it, especially for Zero Escape, which has a much slower burning story than Danganronpa, while still not feeling too long and arduous.

However...

The PC port comes with multiple serious problems. Within just casually playing the games, I encountered MULTIPLE game-breaking bugs that were fixed without any inclination to what fixed them, causing a lot of frustration. The first bug caused a launch loop between Steam and the game, crashing the game's launcher without launching the actual games. The second bug prevented me from clicking the save button in 999, causing my progress to be lost for a few endings, when the game just simply refused to save them at the very end. As well, in VLR, I encountered a bug that prevented me from loading my saves at all, where the mouse would click and the cursor would move, but the game itself would simply refuse to load the saves. There is also a well documented save corruption issue, and for a long visual novels like these, especially with Zero Escape only letting you skip text after you've seen it before, losing your saves means losing TENS of hours of progress. The PC port is broken, but after googling crashes and issues, it is NOT JUST the PC version that STILL has multiple, game breaking, common bugs, which haven't been fixed over the time this game has been out, and likely will never be fixed. I have never had a game give me as much trouble as this collection has.

I cannot recommend this game even though I adore the actual gameplay and story due to these game breaking issues. It felt to me like the game was actively trying to prevent me from playing it. If you want to experience Zero Escape on PC, you should be aware that you may have to deal with game breaking problems on a platform that contains the least of the fanbase, and consequently, the least available solutions to these problems.

(So far I've only played 999 I'll come back after VLR)

In general, this game is weaker than most of the Danganronpa titles, but it's made up for with significantly better puzzles and a cohesive ending.

The puzzles are amazing and flow so well, the only bad puzzle is the new one introduced to make the "twist" from ds work better.
The ending is great, but knowing the game was on the ds will make you sit through most of it going "oh that was probably really clever on the ds", which does take away from the ending.

Flow chart, HD graphics, and a dub make up for what was lost in translation from the ds to pc.

After playing VLR I was going to update this review to be positive because it's much better than 999, but an ending can really ruin a game for me and the VLR ending dragged on for way too long. Added multiple twists and turns at a point where the game was already done and it made the decent, simple story into a convoluted mess. 

At the end of it all I'm not sure who I would recommend this to. It's at best a mediocre visual novel experience, with pacing so bad that at the end I was sick of playing it.

The good things about VLR:
- The puzzles are often pretty challenging and sometimes very rewarding
- Voice acting is much better than 999
- The flowchart is something I really wish I'd see in more games, even if it's not part of the story

The bad:
- The visuals really suck
- At times the puzzle controls are really annoying
- The last strech of the story is way too long


== Original 999 review === 👎
Finished 999 and it just wasn't very good at all to me. 

I feel like I already played it before by playing Danganronpa and a few other visual novels because it mostly uses same old common story points. So the story might be enjoyable if you don't play many Visual Novels, but otherwise there isn't really anything interesting here.

The gameplay between the story are easy puzzles that don't really offer anything worthwhile, you just find objects until a character tells you to use them.

On the technical side the game is pretty weak too. The graphics are ugly, the voice acting is bad and the controls are very frustrating in some puzzles. One thing I did appreciate is the flowchart screen.

Fantastic games.  

For anyone who's never played them - it's a very bizarre, choose your own adventure story with scantily clad women, crude jokes, random gore, complex maths, frustrating puzzles and star trek level science mixed with enough reality to make you think, huh? 

Played 999 on the DS and so happy to finally get to play the sequel.. got it on sale but would have paid more.  

Initially hated the art of VLR compared to 999  but eventually got past that.  I personally liked the story progression mechanics in VLR more than 999 as it meant I missed less and all the note taking was to solve the puzzles, not to keep track of where I was.

My only complaint is that in VLR, when I attempted to skip the dialogue I'd already heard it skipped everything! It just auto skipped on and on till the next decision.  This isn't how it worked in 999 on the DS and it's not how it's supposed to work in VLR according to the instructions...

The Nintendo DS and 3DS had extensive libraries, yet 999 and Virtue's Last Reward stand out as two of the very best games in the two systems, respectively. I think this says a lot about the the two games included in this package. There is some occasional jank; originally these were controlled through touch screen, and some of the puzzles don't work as well with mouse & keyboard in my opinion, but that's a very small annoyance - the story is so good that you won't even notice. I really enjoyed these ports and I want to thank Spike Chunsoft for giving me the opportunity to play these games again from the comfort of my laptop, and Kotaro Uchikoshi for writing these amazing stories to begin with.

So far, I've only beat 2 endings of 999, so, this is kind of an early impressions review...? I'll be analysing the gameplay loop, and the story without spoilers, of course, as far as I know it

So, the gameplay loop? Visual novel broken up by interactive escape the room segments

The VN (AKA, the story):

Pretty good. It develops naturally and really makes you think in anticipation about what's to come. And the way you piece things together feels pretty good too. Characters react mostly in a rather... dare i say, "realistic" way to everything that's going around them, and most of them don't really feel one note for me, except for June (Who is basically the kind of smart but defenseless girl trope). The rest of the characters? Amazing. Like them a lot, specially Lotus, Seven, Santa and Clover. Ace's pretty cool too. I will reserve my comments on Snake, but he seems pretty... fishy.

TL;DR: The story's worth your time, as far as I know, as long as you don't mind BS pseudoscience thrown in the middle of it.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The Escape Rooms (AKA, the gameplay itself):

Pretty cool too! I love me a puzzle game that lets me figure things out on my own without needing to be SHERLOCK FUCKING HOLMES. The puzzles may make you feel pretty smart, but none of them are REALLY that hard. It's a good time, and a good break form the whole story thing, making you eager to uncover more about those people and whatever the hell is happening.

TL;DR: Good, not hard, and a good break from the VN-style story segments. Worth it

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Conclusion: If you're into puzzle games and don't mind the BS explanations for some of the story segments (AKA: don't mind some sci-fi), buy it. totally worth your money. On writing this review i see that i already spent 7.5 hours on it, and holy shit, it felt like 2, because i was so into it

Well done, Spike Chunsoft. Well fucking done. And thank you for bringing this to Steam. I don't own a DS and would never play this if i hadn't the opportunity to play it on PC
Has no weeb tropes so its a damn good game.

I think the best way to describe the Zero Escape games is that they are visual novels with some room escape puzzles thrown in. The ratio of visual novel to puzzles is what I will guess to be 60% visual novel and 40% puzzles. If you don't like reading for extended periods of time then this might not be the game for you. However if you don't mind reading for a bit then the Zero Escape games can offer a pretty wonderful experience.

The Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is a combination of the first 2 games of the series: 999 (9 hours, 9 persons, 9 doors) and Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward. Both are great games in their own right, but due to circumstances during development there is a change in atmosphere and art style from the first game to the second. Some people might be a little turned off by this. However at their core both games have fascinating plots with some very clever plot twists. I'll try to give an overview of the core elements of the 2 games:

[b][u]Plot:[/u][/b] As visual novels, the games are driven by the story. The basic plot for both games involves the protagonist of their respective games being abducted by an unknown figure to participate in a life-threatening game: the Nonary Game for 999 and the Nonary Game: Ambidex Edition for Virtue's Last Reward. As you play through the story, the plot begins to unravel, and soon you'll be learning about the different backstories of the characters  and the truth behind the events leading up to the games. There is also some fictional sci-fi elements thrown in that may require some suspension of belief. 

[b][u]Gameplay:[/u][/b] Aside from reading the visual novel elements, most of the gameplay comes from the puzzles of the escape room sections. This usually consist of collecting objects from a room and interacting with the objects in said room and occasionally triggering special mini-games. If you played the Ace Attorney games, then you might find some similarities in the escape room sections to the investigations of the Ace Attorney games. Occasionally the player will also have to make choices during the visual novel sections which can cause the story to branch down different paths.

[b][u]Audio:[/u][/b] Both games have very good soundtracks, and both feature Japanese and English voice acting. While not every line in the games is voiced (for example dialogue boxes during escape rooms), most if not all of the visual novel sections are voiced, and I personally found both dubs to be pretty good.

[b][u]Difficulty:[/u][/b] I found both games to be pretty fair when it comes to the puzzles. As long as you pay attention to the hints and do some thinking and note taking then you should be able to escape the rooms in both games. In general I did find that the puzzles in 999 are easier than those in Virtue's Last Reward. At worse if you do get stuck there is always google.

[b][u]Replay value and length:[/u][/b] Each game features multiple endings based on the choices made during the game. Both games also include a flow chart to help players see which route they are currently on. For a first time player, I think each game will take at least 15+ hours to 100% complete, if not more. Due to the multiple endings available in both games, there is a good amount of replay value. However going for all of the endings can get tedious when you need to re-traverse some game routes to reach specific endings, especially in Virtue's Last Reward. Overall I would say that once you 100% complete both games, there isn't too much motivation to come back unless you just want to relive some of the more intense moments of the game, but the journey there is amazing and should give at least 30+ hours.

[b][u]999 specific note:[/u][/b] The game offers two formats for the visual novel sections of the game. You can play in either Novel mode or Adventure mode. Novel mode has the text appear over the background sprites, covering most of the screen as they appear from top to bottom, while Adventure mode has the text appear in a small text box at the bottom and not covering the background sprite as much (similar to how the text box in Ace Attorney games act). While at first the 2 modes seem to only offer an aesthetic change, there is actually a significant difference between the two visual novel modes and this is due to the game's original release on the Nintendo DS. Originally the top screen of the DS featured character dialogues in the text box, and the bottom screen featured narration by the narrator. However due to porting it over to PC, players are now instead given the choice of switching on the fly between the top or bottom screen of the DS. [b] What this means is that if you play in Adventure Mode, there will be somewhat less reading at the cost of some narration details. However there is no need to worry about missing important story points in the narration, as the game will forcefully switch into Novel mode at points where the narration is significant to the understanding of the plot. [/b]


Possible spoilers regarding what seems like a glitch for 999:
[spoiler]Tied to the Novel and Adventure Mode is an interesting glitch that some may have observed. Whenever the player starts an escape room sequence, a sprite of the main character's face is shown. However, if the player was in Novel mode prior to an escape room sequence, the sprite of the main character will appear to be missing. Without spoiling too much, let's just say that this was done not as an oversight but as a use of the DS's dual screen capability. Once you get the true ending everything will be clear.[/spoiler]

[b][u]TL/DR:[/u][/b] Both games are great story driven visual novels with some escape zoom sequences. Both games have very interesting plots and is well worth the time. Definitely get it on sale if you can. Just be warned that there can be quite a bit of reading involved.

And finally as an advice: Please do not look too much into the game's plot before you play through the game. Avoid any spoilers if you can. The game's unravelling plot is a treat to experience first hand. Disregard even the small spoiler I left in the review, as the experience of being mind blown by the plot reveals is something each player should experience for themselves.

[h1]999:[/h1]

At first this game annoyed me, but as I played more of it I began to enjoy it more. My biggest complaint is that there's way too much talking; half of the things that the characters talk about is just contrived nonsense that doesn't matter. These things do eventually end up being important to the story, but in the beginning of the game it's just really annoying and time consuming when all you want to do is solve some cool puzzles and June won't shut the fuck up about mummies or some shit.

The puzzles are good, if a bit too simple at times. There are definitely several head-scratchers, but many of them just end up solving themselves if you have half a brain.

I love the characters in this game, they ended up being very memorable to me. 

tl;dr GOD I DON'T FUCKING CARE, JUNE. JUST LET ME DO THE FUCKING PUZZLE.


[h1]Virtue’s Last Reward:[/h1]

The puzzles are MUUUUUUUUUUCH harder. The dartboard puzzle made me feel like a complete idiot. It's also easier to complete all the paths, as you don't have to replay from the beginning each time. 

The voice-acting isn't bad; I would even consider some of the performances to be great. The environments are fully 3D now, and they scroll smoothly, which makes spatial awareness much easier. The human models sometimes look a little too chunky, but the art direction and good character design makes up for it.

The story is just as deep and multi-layered as 999 was, even more-so in fact. The stories of Metal Gear Solid and Kingdom Hearts are cakewalks compared to this. It really feels like you're peeling away layers from a huge mystery.

This series is a lot of fun if you're a fan of visual novels or puzzle games! Dialogue-wise, it's very campy. There are lots of bad jokes and a huge lack of tone throughout both games (especially 999). However, while it's hilarious to make fun of that, the games are still thoroughly enjoyable. The strength of this series relies not on the dialogue, but on the plot itself, which is quite creative. I can't go into further detail on that front-- you'll have to figure out what's going on with Junpei and Sigma's wack-ass brains for yourself. As for the puzzles, the ones in 999 are relatively easy (sometimes a little challenging), whereas the puzzles in VLR are generally much harder. Regardless of difficulty level, each and every puzzle is satisfying to solve. I would definitely recommend getting this series now while it's on sale!

I think my review disappeared or didn't post right. Bah. I am not retyping all that, either.

I have only played the first game (999) so far. It is absolutely amazing. The story is great and the music and sound really draws you in. The visuals are acceptable (not super, but you don't expect it from a visual novel anyways).

The puzzles are a mixed bag, but all are quite doable. Some are really hard to figure out, others are far too easy for where they are in the game. All the puzzles as well as room escapes receive plenty of hints in the form of the other characters giving advice.

It was like riding a rollercoaster: lots of ups, lots of downs and a great many epiphanies and plot twists. Some of it comes out of nowhere, but the game offers you so much information that you'll always feel after the fact that you could have known. And in fact, I actually predicted quite a few plot twists because I paid great attention to all the information offered. To me, that was the best part of the novel: almost every twist you ended up experiencing is something you could have seen coming to some degree. Compared to many mystery or detective novels (visual novel or otherwise) where you as the reader are completely in the dark or expected to make deductions on the level of Sherlock Holmes and Poirrot having a love child, everything here is in reach.

If you think you see a red flag, it just might be important rather than just being a plot hole caused by some silly author oversight.

If I could go back in time and convince myself somehow, I would tell myself to buy this for the full price. 999 alone is worth the full price for the experience it offered, and even if VLR is a dumper fire, it would still be worth the money. Alas: I got it for an 80% discount, and I actually feel ashamed for paying so little for such a great experience!

This is not a game for people looking for a game play rich game. This game is strictly for the story but what a story it is. It will suck you in and not let you go until you've explored every option and gotten every ending. Even then you'll want to start the next one as soon as you finish the first one. With a complex story that evolves over 3 games this game has huge replay value with multiple endings and every choice you make matters changing the story drastically. I can not recommend this game enough one of my top 3 all time favorite game series.

I played 999 and VLR on DS and these are some of the best games I've played in my life. The gameplay is pretty basic but the story and writing are amazing. I was captivated until the very end. I played the games without looking up any spoilers and I was taken by surprise at the directions the plot went. There is an unsettling feeling I get while playing the games, because they don't give you all the information you need to piece everything together in one playthrough, leaving the game feeling mysterious like you were actually there playing the game yourself. I highly recommend giving these 2 games a shot even if you've never played a visual novel before

"damn anime keeps getting in the way of my point & click adventure games"

that was my original review, 2 hours in. I've now completely finished both of the games and how naive I was. First game took me 18 hours to 100%, Second game slightly less than 30. 

The games tell a surprisingly beautiful narrative about love, death, and everything in between. 999 is definitely the better and more complete game than VLR, and it tells a much more coherent story with a lot less suspension of disbelief required. Both are worth going through 100%, if you have the time, as anything less will leave you in the dark in one way or another. The same experience cannot be achieved by watching a playthrough or reading a plot summary, trust me. 

Only downsides are that the final puzzle of 999 went from a complicated sudoku in the DS version, to an extremely simple "puzzle" that you will solve without knowing how you did it. Final puzzle of VLR has an encyclopedia of text that can only be reread once, to play the world's most confusing game of minesweeper.

also probably don't play in public because there's a woman in VLR who just doesn't have a shirt on the whole game and it's never explained

Probably worth it in the sale, at least.

Those games are not what they seem. 

Those are adventure games, true. Those are very Japanese games. But you might think it's Saw or And Then There Was None rip-off. It's not. 

Puzzles are not remarkable. There are lots of words in those games, a lot of them are not directly connected to the main plot. The full walkthrough requires some backtracking, so to say.

The closest thing to it that I might think of is Metal Gear Solid. Only instead of action and stealth, there's puzzle-solving. It too tries to be a very Western game, inspired by Kurt Vonnegut and the like. Still very recognizably Japanese.

I regularly despised the idea that gamers have to play through the same game multiple times, get to different endings to understand what the story is actually about. I have the impression that developers use this technique to familiarize players with characters, humanize them, and make players care about them so they may stage the final scene in a grand, meaningful and potentially “emotionally appealing” way.

That being said, this is one of the games that does the above technique and while I’m not particular happy about it, one must recognize the time of publication and how I just came from the Danganronpa trilogy and had such a astronomical expectation. This is nowhere a bad product, the game is well worth the price and I can’t really nitpick more.

If you like a good, complex and mind-blowing narrative, this game is for you.
If you like riddles and mysteries, this game is also for you.

I really like the whole story of the Zero Escape trilogy. It is really well-built, the mysteries are presented in a way that makes you want to continue playing at every moment of the narrative, while avoiding to make the ending of each game obvious. There rarely is a moment where you think: "Ok, this is getting boring, I might take a break." The characters are very unique and all of them are important for the story, which make them all interesting.
YOU FOUND IT!

The Nonary Games is two games in one bundle, of course: 999 and VLR. So, this review will be binary. You could say it comes in... Part [i]A[/i] and a Part [i]B[/i]. Disclaimer: I have not played these games on the DS, just this port. It is my opinion that both ports work perfectly well, without any significant flaws. Also good with Steam controller ✔

[b]999:[/b] The intrigue of both games lies largely in their sci-fi plot and life-and-death suspense. 999's strong points were the well-designed, rewarding puzzles and well-written and understandable plot, with good pacing. The conclusion is really cool and well done. The cast of characters is diverse and interesting, and each player gets some love in terms of backstory and personality. The English voice acting is also good. A lot of people have praised Junpei's voice in this one—I actually found some of his lines a bit harshly interpreted, but by no means an unpleasant experience overall. The soundtrack is also good in 999. The various escape rooms have several themes, each of them good. The soundtrack does a good job of emphasizing plot and adding depth to certain moments. I very much recommend this game. 

[b]VLR:[/b] This game did not shine quite as much for me. The story is truly good, and easily matches the brilliance of the first game's. A few things did stick out that made it a bit hard to sit through compared to the first game: first is the art style. While 999's visuals were stylish and clean, VLR's mediocre 3D graphics are the slightest bit awkward and not nearly as pleasing to the eye. Secondly, the story's pacing wasn't as satisfying as the first game's. VLR includes much more backtracking. The amount of play it takes to fill out the flowchart can be tedious, especially when a lot of important information is discovered at the end of a route instead of all the way through. Finally, there is more waiting than there needs to be. The text skip function prevents you from skipping narration that is nearly identical to narration from other routes. Also, there are many segments where you're waiting for a door to slooowly close, or watching a dot move across the map. It gets annoying. [i]But...[/i]
These are not deal-breaking flaws! The story is still incredibly intriguing, and the payoff at the final ending is super cool. It'll take a bit more effort to wrap your head around when you get really into it, but it's all tied together nicely. I would say the puzzles in VLR are about the same caliber as in 999—that is, very good. Maaaybe a tinge harder. Cast: similarly good and diverse. The soundtrack is also good, but not quite as good as the original's (except "Clarification". I love this track!). It should also be mentioned that VLR is longer than 999. Despite VLR's aesthetic drawbacks, the gameplay is perfectly fine, and the plot is really great.

In short, both games: great puzzles, voice acting, and plot. VLR, however, suffers from tedious moments and an art style that is grating if you play after 999.

Bought on sale, but worth full price. Recommended!

I can only recommend this bundle because the 999 game isn't sold separately. 999, is great. Virtue's Last Reward, however, is just painfully boring. One moment it's just purely a visual novel, another moment it's an actual escape room game. Those two different sections don't play well together so the transition between the two is jarring and off putting.

So I kinda do not know how to review this so I prepared useful checklist to determine if you will like this game or not:

1. Are you prepared for not only standart escape room puzzles, but also ridiculously complex math puzzles that you will have to make notes for?
(Because I wasn't and it was fine in 999, the puzzles there were mostly enviromental and made sense, but the combinatory mathematical problems from VLR were just painful sometimes (but I am stupid so).)

2. Are you prepared to be confused with like trillion different story paths and timelines?
(This is not as much of a problem in VLR, because it makes sense story-wise and it's kinda interesting to piece together the different information you have from different timelines, but in 999 it's really confusing and honestly, I still do not have any idea what is supposed to be canon and I got tired of it pretty quickly.)

3. Do you mind pseudo science?
(This is really important because the whole story is based on really far-fetched "science" stuff and if you by any chance have PhD in quantum physics, it can be quite ridiculous.)

4. Are you annoyed when someone is saying totally obvious things or is repeating the same thing over and over again?
(Like really, the characters have the worst habit of dramatically exclaiming something that is totally obvious and also you will have to go through some scenes several times and it gets really tiring.)

5. Did you come here because you loved Danganronpa and want something similar to play just as I did?
(Because while the setting and overall the type of the game might seem similar, unfortunately Zero Escape lacks the thing I loved Danganronpa the most for, which is a roster of different, carefully created characters each with their own personalities and touching stories.)

Idk, decide for yourself, I personally had a good time ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Zero Escape: 999 is an amazing gateway into visual novels for people just off the Danganronpa series. It has a tight story with massive amounts of mystery and intrigue. Then, just when you think it is going a certain direction generically, it hits you with something akin to Higurashi. Solid story, mechanics, and puzzles. A really awesome and character based whodunnit with a dash of science fiction.

However, Zero Escape Virtue's Last Reward is a mess. It is by no means a bad game, but it has so much content in its story that it gives headaches to its players. There are so many high level theories and concepts into this potential collision of a narrative. The puzzles are so much harder and abstract with high levels of memorization and taking notes. The route system is much more confusing and can stop story progression and pacing with its constant "to be continued" or "bad endings." Much of the routes are super hard to predict and the general main story involves a really good understanding of quantum mechanics. Still good, but definitely complex in a bad way for some kinds of people.

9/9/9 is amazing: it has great voice acting, a really fun story, smart dialogue, and a friendly design so you can skip dialogue you've already seen, jump back to any previous scene at any time, and keep a bunch of saves. I'd definitely reccommend it for anyone interested in the Room Escape/ Mystery/ Death Game genres. Pretty much my only complaint is that while they stress the time limit and death game aspects at first, it turns out soon enough that you have limitless time to do every puzzle, none of the puzzles are dangerous at all, and the stakes kind of flatline until the bizarre and incredibly fun final act.
Virtue's Last Reward decides to have around a million endings, is far slower in pace, and dumbs down the dialogue a ton. The UI and overall design is still pretty player-friendly, but the writing/characters/dialogue are worse and the game just looks awkward with the 3D models. Can't exactly recommend by itself, but I'm still playing it because the story is interesting and I'd say it's worth five to ten bucks to check out.

Not to mention an almost full voice acting for all the dialogue, and a pretty good one.

All in all, great story, great execution of it, worth the buy.

ZLR:

They replaced the decent low-res art with awful 3D graphics. That said, I enjoyed this more than 999. There are a lot of problems here, and the character writing is awful in places, but it kept me in genuine suspense for 40 hours and I have to credit it for that. I didn't like the room escape puzzles at all. The ending was awful, laughable even. Until the end it was great, though.

There are two games in this pack, 999 and its sequel, Virtue's Last Reward. In each game, nine seemingly random people have been abducted, given numbered bracelets, and are forced to work their way through a labyrinthine location full of puzzles. The story is split through visual novel segments and room-escape point and click adventures, and you have to choose your path, uncover the mystery and hopefully reach the best ending... but it might not be quite as simple as that. Nothing and nobody is quite what they seem in the Nonary Games.

999 is one of my favourite games ever, the story and characters are really captivating and unique, there are some great twists and turns and it has just enough weird science to make things interesting without going overboard. It's best to play it on the DS if you can, because it does some great things with the screens that don't quite have the same impact on the PC, but this version is still amazing! It really is worth the price for 999 alone.

VLR is a more futuristic sequel, and the weird science is turned way up. It's still a great story with even more twists and turns, but it's not quite as grounded as 999 which might put some people off, and it's very long with a lot more branches in the story, but if you're into it it's a very fun ride that will keep you guessing all the way to the true ending and beyond.

On the puzzle side, they're nothing super difficult and it's rare that you'd get completely stuck, but they're still a good challenge with s. In VLR each room has a puzzle to reach the exit as well as a bonus puzzle which is more challenging and often pushes the elements of the main puzzle a little further than you might have needed to just to escape.

As for Zero Time Dilemma... maybe don't just play that one.
