Zero Escape is easily one of my favourite franchises and I think it's one most people can get into. Both games have amazing writing, with a lot of the appeal coming from the mindfuck twists near the end which really enrich the story an extraordinary amount rather than just being there for shock factor. As the plot unravels, it becomes apparent that what's taking place reveals itself to be much larger than the player initially comprehends, and this is really a testament to how effective Uchikoshi's writing method is.

The first game features a lot of the scientific and philosophical themes that the writing relies upon without being too complex or convoluted. The twists are still very satisfying and enthralling without feeling too far fetched or convoluted for the player to follow. The writing in the second game makes it quite apparent that the developers were trying to outdo the fantastic plot twists in its predecessor, which might be what leaves some people with the impression that the writing in that game is far too convoluted and and trying to outdo itself to the point of incomprehension, but it's really a matter of taste an opinion. I personally still really enjoyed the writing in the second game and the twists definitely stuck with me and left a significant impression, even if they did feel quite overwhelming and incomprehensible.

The plot is really the main event when it comes to Zero Escape and I would probably rank this franchise as having my favourite writing of any video game, but my praise has to be toned down a notch when considering the writing of the characters. The characters aren't exactly bland but they're not as interesting and likeable as they could be. Each character serves a very clear function to the plot and takes on an interesting role in this respect, but the personalities and designs of the characters themselves can feel a little lacking at times. The writers do a good job of making you distrust virtually the entire cast, but this isn't the reason I think the characters feel weak. Virtue's Last Reward probably improves quite a bit when it comes to character interaction, but there's still something that feels lacking and the characters don't feel as human as they could be. Regardless, I don't feel that this takes away too much from the experience.

As for game play, this series primarily relies on escape room type puzzles for the player to solve. They utilise mathematics and logic but nothing too advanced and I find that solving the puzzles is very enjoyable. If you're into puzzle solving and logic, the game play in Zero Escape should pose enough of a challenge to be enjoyable without being ridiculously difficult. The puzzles in Virtue's Last Reward are more difficult than those in 999, but you can always use a walkthrough if you're just playing for the plot, or set the difficulty to easy and then come back later on hard mode once you have the answers to the puzzle to acquire the bonus golden file you receive as a reward for completing the escape room on hard mode.

The games each branch out into different routes and this route system supplements the plot extremely well. It's not just written in to give the player more options, it really plays into the meta of the writing extremely well and is utilised perfectly. The addition of flow charts also makes it extremely convenient to jump to any point in the story so you can move down another route without having to replay entire escape rooms you've already had to sit through (unlike the DS version of the game).

Ultimately, this pack of 2 games is great value for money and the trilogy is definitely something I think everyone should try out. The first game was written as a standalone game, so if you don't enjoy Virtue's Last Reward, your experience doesn't have to be soured at all if you just want to finish at 999. The writing in these games is absolutely fantastic, the first game builds a great horror atmosphere and tension through music, scenery and text alone and both are an extremely enriching experience that no doubt will teach you about some interesting real world phenomena if nothing more.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is a bundle containing the first two games of the Zero Escape Trilogy. The first game: Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors (or just 999) is relatively short, with only six endings. The second game: Virtue's Last Reward, is much more complex, with numerous endings and plenty of story locks, meaning that in order to complete the game, you have to go back to different choices and complete that branch. This game is where the bulk of my playtime in this game is from due to the sheer scope of the game.
The best way to explain the series is that it is a series of visual novel puzzle games, during which nine people (which is where Nonary comes from) are abducted and forced to participate in a life or death escape room style game. If you're a fan of escape rooms and/or puzzle games, this is definitely a game series worth checking out.

Visual novel/puzzle - adventure game similar to Danganronpa. Both the first and second game of the zero escape trilogy are included in this purchase. Both games have a interesting story that really sucks you in with lots of plot twists and unexpected reveals.

I usually don't have much patience for Visual Novels because of how much time they take to complete. But with this one I don't regret any hours spent on it. It's definitely worth completing all the endings which doesn't feel like a chore thanks to the flowchart system.

Die Escape Rooms sind ein elementarer Bestandteil der Reihe und meistens einfach zu lösen.
Man möchte bei beiden Spielen auf 100% gehen, um den Plot der Story besser zu verstehen.
Der dritte Teil der Reihe, Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma kann hiervor gespielt werden, ist jedoch nur empfehlenswert wenn man mit textintesiven Spielen, so wie es diese beiden hier sind, wenig anfangen kann.
Jeder Teil ist für sich Spielbar jedoch sollte vor Virtues Last Reward der erste Teil, Nine Hours Nine Persons Nine Doors gespielt werden, da hier ein paar massive Storyspoiler vorhanden sind.
Ich kann die Reihe jedem ans Herz legen, selbst wenn man eigentlich keine Textintesiven Spiele mag.

These are both fantastic tragedy-loop styled mystery games, a beloved genre to me.

You wake up with an ominous chunky wristwatch strapped to you as part of some kind of SAW-esque death game, amidst 8 other people each claiming no idea why they’re involved. Who did all this and why?

Gameplay is a mixture of visual novel and 3D escape room puzzles, with a branching story you’ll need to explore to make sense of what is going on. The mechanics of the nonary games are complicated to put in a few words but easy enough through the games’ explaination, and immediately you can see how your choices will drastically affect each route. Because of the rules, the doors you choose affect who goes with you and what other teams will be formed and that is a wonderful way to feel like you can really work out how to juggle the choices you make to make situations happen on the next run.

You will need to take some suspension of belief in with you, some of the twists are a bit fantastical, but they make a good enough story to earn a pass for that. 

This is a combo pack of 9 hours, 9 persons, 9 doors, which is the first game, and Virtue’s Last Reward, the second.  Zero Escape Dilemma is the third and is available separately.
Great game, fun mystery, and 'replayability' that doesn't just drag through the mud. You can *skip cutscenes* :O

Zero Escape is Visual Novel series which alternates between VN storytelling and "escape rooms" where you must solve a puzzle to gather information and otherwise progress the story. Many reviews show around 50 hours played - that's a good estimate for 100% completion of both games included in "Zero Escape: The Nonary Games". 

The puzzles are fun to complete, and though 'time is of the essence' to the story, most tasks do not have any time restriction and so you can complete them at a leisurely pace. You can also revisit novel and puzzle segments via a flowchart.

The narrative spanning the series is interesting if you don't mind some pseudoscience and "philosobabble". It reminded me a bit of Steins;Gate in that respect. The art style changes after the first game, which is actually a negative. The first game had a 2D artstyle while the later games had weaker 3D art and animations.
This is still the best game I've ever played.
LOVE IT!

It is all well thought out and I love the links to Zero Time Dilemma.

The story is very interesting and doesn't shy away from putting on a tinfoil hat giving it the opportunity to follow a cleverly designed story line that takes aspect from real life especially philosophy, psychology, mathematics and physics and meshing it with a fictional story. Sure there are some minor plot holes but the concept seems well rounded and very clever and stimulates to further think about certain topics.

The graphics are nicely drawn and don't consume too much, so the game can be played on a potato-pc without lowering the overall gaming experience. Since the second game (Last Virtue) is a handheld port the 3D-models might seem a little weak compared to the first one (999).

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is fully voice acted despite the protagonist in the second game (999).

Sadly most of the escape rooms are a little too easy, so there's not much of a challenge to it. The puzzles are still cleverly designed.

This review is made before playing VFR But After Playing 999

Characters 7/10 :  they were good and serviceable but some were a either a bit flat and some were pretty good but none were exceptional none were horrible

Gameplay 8/10 :  Somewhat clunky but fairly easy to learn and solving the puzzles was very engaging. I was stumped on several of them but not once was a guide required. Most puzzles can be solved with enough brute force for finding key items or thinking up all of the general possibilities for answers. The worst puzzle I ran into was a puzzle I had solved but needed to spend time converting the answer to the proper escape code. It however only took around 5 minutes. Numbers and letters are a common theme in the game and the game definitely does get easier with experience as a lot of factors are re used. Namely the DIGITAL ROOT of numeric sequences. However, it does this in a way that mostly avoids any repetitiveness in the puzzles. Its Very good for a puzzle game and honestly would be rated higher but it isn't perfect and tha comes from being a port or remake or whatever you may call it. However the gameplay is good enough that these issues hardly mattered

The plot is 9/10 : Good an Interconnected, It can be summed up as a roller coaster. Down moments, tense moments. Satisfying moments, they are all done and timed quite effectively if you are the average player which I would consider myself. There is exactly one plot hole I found that effectively was answered by the game in a vague does it even matter? sense. Honestly it didnt. It didnt affect the quality of the main/true story. 

The other endings or the SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS. Were all quite effective at suprising me in interesting ways. They showed off some of the more inventive or out of the box ideas for endings. The other endings were not as good as the True ending, but they did make it more satisfying. In my playthrough I all of the paths baring one midway segment choice and one ending. However, this left me with 3 other endings to enjoy aside from the main one.

This series is awesome. If you like psychological thrillers that unravel their mysteries one bit at a time while leaving intentional dramatic discrepancies between the info given to the player and the info given to the characters in the world, you'll love this. It's best to go in blind.

Pros:
The writing is great, very ambitious plot and few minor plotholes
The music is crazy good, creepy ambient/techno/percussive OST that goes great with studying
The game is good length: the playtime you see is for 1 playthrough of the Nonary Games
There's few games like it. The story of Zero Escape couldn't be told in any other format than a video game and you'll see why.
The puzzles are challenging but not frustrating.

Cons:
Animation in Virtue's Last Reward and Zero Time Dilemma is bad.
Some annoying unskippable animations.
There's one particular plot point that is built up in 999 as being very important and then it ends up being totally irrelevant in the rest of the series (spoiler: it's [spoiler]All-Ice[/spoiler]).

I can't give this game an objective rating out of 10 because I love it so much, but I seriously recommend you pick it up if it at all interests you, especially on a sale (also pick up Zero Time Dilemma, my favorite one).
the two nonary games, conceptually and gameplay-wise, are fantastic.  I highly recommend it to anyone who loves a good puzzle and the visual novel genre.   It's a must play!

二代《善人死亡》前半段游玩可能会有一些重复和冗余感，毕竟每一轮 组队开门进房间-密室逃脱找钥匙卡-投票 的流程基本相同，而每次投票完之后配置随机打乱，各种不同人员组合分别去往不同的房间的剧情流向可能会给人有一点“强行”的感觉（不像初代是数字上的设计）。但慢慢地，剧情展开、伏笔收回、各结局人物真实身份开始揭露，到最后结局得知世界的真相时真有种拨云见日的感觉，大脑在颤抖，打越脑洞之大和高超的圆故事能力不得不服。回过头来再看看一看，缺乏设计感的毛病似乎也变淡了(实际上是被打越说服了x

[h1] Pros: [/h1]

+ Pretty great value even at stock cost, both games are interesting to experience and are fully fledged in playtime. My total playtime was 41 hours, with a majority taking place in the second title.

+ The characters really start to branch out the further you get into the story. Some of the designs are intentionally pretty insane, but all of them are interesting to look at for the most part.

+ A series with a lot of intrigue and many mysteries to unravel, the Zero Escape series is definitely worth some of the hype. It pulls you along and constantly subverts your expectations on what will happen.

+ Gameplay is focused on the escape room segments for the most part, which can vary in terms of difficulty. The 2nd game, in particular, can cause some headaches during certain segments. If you like puzzles, it's definitely the right game for you.

[h1] Cons: [/h1]

- [Both Games] Pacing is a big problem. The open paths, open choice system sounds really nice on paper, but it's very easy to see things in an order that can take away from the experience. It's also unclear, especially in the first game, what you're supposed to do to progress the story.

- [2nd Game: VLR] The visual style of the second game is absolutely ugly. The pre-rendered still shots look like something straight out of the early PS2 era, or like something generated in Second Life or a DeviantArt's screenshot gallery. Some characters are designed well, but are represented extremely poorly. 

- [2nd Game: VLR] Animation. Holy hell, the animations are something else. The first game's simple style is actually the best the series gets. The second one avoids animating as much as possible, many of the facial expressions are broken (in particular Clover, who is basically always smiling), and the Lip Sync is nowhere close to correct. When it does do full animation, it is generally very quick and heavily using loops.

- [Both Games] The story takes a very, very wild turn from the semi-grounded feeling you get in the first game. The scenarios in VLR and the future Zero Escape Dilemna get outlandish compared to the first game.

[h1] Overall: [/h1]

I got the game on sale, interested because many people have said "If you like Danganronpa or Phoenix Wright, you have to play this series!" I love both series so I figured I had to give it a whirl. Overall, I think Danganronpa is a stronger series by far. BUT that doesn't mean the 0E series was unenjoyable. It's far from perfect and has a lot of issues as a series, but I overall felt extremely curious and invested in the universe of Zero Escape. It's impossible to ignore the glaring animation and the weird story, but it still pulls you in despite that. if you're a fan of Visual Novel games, it's definitely worth checking out Spike Chunsoft's first titles.

こちらのOSはwindows 7 SP1でそのような不具合に遭いましたが、999の実行ファイル「ze1.exe」で右クリックして、互換モードにチェックを入れて「windows 7」を選択したら、普通に遊べるようになりました。

[h1] If you can't play Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors	[/h1] 

If your game crashes, let's give it a try.

1.right-click on ze1.exe and select properties. 

2.select the compatibility tab, then check the box next to "run this program in compatibility mode for: windows 7".

I hope it will help you.

This game has been out for a while so I'm just going to mention the best parts about each game. 999 starts slow but has one of the best endings I've ever seen. VLR is just all around amazing and is a must play if you even have a passing interest in visual novels. 

The only parts about VLR that would be a negative for me was that I made a correct guess about one of the major plot point fairly early on (where the base was located) and I got the Dio ending as my first ending (almost everything about Dio is explained in it). If they made that plot point much less obvious (like in 999) or they only told a small amount about Dio in that ending and let the player piece it together then the game would've been the best visual novel ever. Instead it's only the best visual novel for now. 

My rating for this collection of games is 10/10 and VLR is definitely my favorite game as of writing this review.

ゲーム内容はアドベンチャーパートと脱出ゲームパートを交互に

[b]※注意点[/b]
この作品には非現実要素が含まれます。
牛批

If - like myself - you are not a fan of visual novels, [b]Zero Escape: The Nonary Games[/b] might actually be a good match for you: for these particular [b]text-based titles[/b], it is the [b]puzzles that push the narrative forward[/b]. 
[b][i]999[/i][/b] and [b][i]Virtue's Last Reward[/i][/b]’s plots are [b]tightly interconnected[/b], and despite their wackiness, I fell hard for its [b]far-fetched pseudo-science[/b] and [b]philosophical babble[/b]. It is important to note that most [b]characters[/b] feel [b]fairly flat[/b], drawing inspiration from worn-out tropes, which explains why a huge chunk of the story's [b]humor[/b] is [b]poorly placed[/b], ranging from [b]childish[/b] to [b]outright inappropriate[/b].
Luckily, the [b]dramatic bits[/b] carry almost the entirety of the [b]actual weight of the story[/b].
Visually speaking, [b][i]999[/i][/b] had a [b]much nicer, refined 2d-style[/b], as opposed to [b][i]Virtue’s Last Reward[/i]’s dismal 3d animations[/b]. However, they compensated that with [b]higher-quality voice overs[/b]. 
The [b]escape rooms[/b], where various types of [b]well-designed puzzles[/b] can be found, are [b]incredibly fun[/b] to complete, and even though time is of utmost importance in the series, there is actually [b]no time limit[/b] for any area. [b][i]Virtue’s Last Reward[/i][/b] ups the challenge by adding the [b]option[/b] to clear them out in [b]hard difficulty[/b], a mode where you barely get any hints. 
Both games are [b]easily replayable[/b] by using the [b]flow chart[/b] as reference, although its [b]interface[/b] is [b]far more intuitive in the second installment[/b] as a result of adding coherent, retrackable story lines that do not depend on random decision for them to advance. [b]Dialogue[/b] is [b]skippable for replays[/b] too, although certain animations cannot be fast-forwarded. 
If you are considering picking these games up, ask yourself: do I want to puzzle my brains away while trying to figure out what is going on? If so, then it is time for you to join these [b]Nonary Games[/b], my friend.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1743512258
Excellent small-budget game with likeable characters and interesting plot that will require you 200IQ to get the good endings. A must-have for all the VN consumers out there.

Tl;dr 999 is a beautiful story that’s worth the whole price; VLR has some good moments but is crippled by scope creep and atrocious graphics.

Gameplay-wise, the puzzles are fine in both. I look at them as more story pacing tools than as challenges, so I’m not the best to comment. It shouldn’t bring you to the game nor push you away.

Nine Hours Nine Persons Nine Doors is a damn good game.
The cast is great. Some are better than others, but there’s not a single character I disliked by the end of it. The protagonist, who’s too often a boring blank slate in this sort of game, has an entertaining personality sold by excellent voice acting. It’s also nice that the characters are not high schoolers (it’s been a while, Japan).

You will need to play through multiple times to get the true ending. Blessedly, there’s a feature allowing you to jump to any scene you’ve already seen, making this a lot quicker than it sounds. The game is at its core a mystery: what does Zero want? Why were these people chosen? Who can you trust? It all slowly falls into place as you explore the various routes. The supernatural elements are built up to slowly, only really coming into play in the finale when you finally discover what this weird pseudoscience the characters have been going on about all game has been for. It feels written solution-first, and the rest of the plot coalesced naturally around discovering and harnessing this power. Especially coming off Danganronpa, it’s nice to see a game that really sticks the landing. 

The problem is... it's one game. Standalone. It really didn't need a sequel. Villains foiled, people saved, character arcs completed. The few remaining questions were ones that didn’t need to be answered.

Virtue's Last Reward is... eh. The main problem is scope creep. *More* routes, *more* twists, *more* powerful supernatural nonsense. Liked the character-focused, extremely personal stakes of 999? Well have a save-the-world plot instead. And let’s retroactively make the villain of 999 part of this nebulous conspiracy to end humanity too! The compulsion to add more endings makes for a lot of rehashing the same plot points through different routes, and seeing characters die over and over makes it hard to care when they're in danger: when your reaction to "someone was murdered!" is "ugh, this again", something's gone wrong. Supernatural power creep makes the story a lot more convoluted than the very tight 999. That's not necessarily a bad thing! What is a bad thing is the fact that it ends on a sequel hook, and that sequel is awful.

The switch from sprites to 3d models does not go well: you’ll look at the gross plastic dolls with hands clipping through their clothes or resting their chins on nothing and yearn for the days of pixelated portraits.

There are some damn good character moments (Phi, Sigma, and Luna in particular make the game worth it in my estimation), but it's hidden behind a lot of cruft. It takes time and effort to extract those nuggets of gold, which could probably be better-spent on less bloated media.

So for all that... 999 is worth the entry price. If you're hungry for more puzzles or willing to do some slogging for the good stuff, give VLR a go while you're at it.

I'm not a fan of Visual Novels, but these two names 999 and VLR, had the pace, interesting puzzle solving, and really great story that kept me engrossed. I'd recommend it, 999 can be a little slow at the start and VLR slows down towards the end, but they both really do a good job of keeping you invested in the story by drip feeding you the right amounts of intrigue. Once you get to the first twist, I guarantee you'll be hooked to find the answer or twist, it's a topsy turvy ride that I recommend completely

TL;DR: Setting is great. Feeling of mystery is cool. But the endings are contrived, and replaying a bunch of scenes sucks badly. Finished 2 endings, then I googled the True ending. Unsatisfying experience. 

The feel as you progress towards the first ending (whatever that first ending is) is great, things move really fast, and you're soon finished through most rooms and the finale is fast approaching.

Then you encounter the first ending. And that's it. You barely understand how that ending came to be, many things don't make sense, your character does illogical moves, other people somehow didn't do things they should've been able to, etc. The only way to get a better understanding of an ending, and eventually to understand the whole game, you have to replay a bunch of routes and rooms. 

The setting is great, and the mysterious tone is cool, but the endings are in my opinion unpolished (they're not nearly as thorough as endings in Dangan Ronpa for example) and contrived, and having to replay a bunch of scenes and scenarios is too much for me. I ended up googling the True ending. That's 25 dollars for 10 hours. :(

I can't say much about the games without spoiling something, but here's a few things I can:

-A FLOWCHART IN A VN WITH BRANCHES THAT YOU CAN JUMP TO HOLY COW
-Actually manages to explain what would be BS

A must have for fans of escape rooms, sci-fi, and dispair.

Review for 999, update for VLR below
[list]
[*]Gameplay: A visual novel mixed with escape room game. The puzzle part is quite easy personally, but sometimes I must click around a lot to find the missing components which is pretty irritating. The "who can be trusted" in the game description is just bullshit since the choices you make are just irrelevant to whom you decide to trust. The consequence is just way out of hand LUL. Luckily it has a flow chart system which allows us to load to a specific part of the game, and the little key symbols to mark which part we need to trigger an important event. It's a plus point if you want to play the game without checking out walkthroughs.
[*]Plot: Is interesting enough. The science introduced in the game is sometimes too fictitious but I'll allow it. I don't know if it's intentional or not but at some points characters behave out of character (Clover, Lotus).
[*]Characters: Design is not very appealing, and they're also not very likable IMHO.
[*]Voice acting: I have to change the voice language to Japanese only a few minutes into the game because the English monologue is just unnatural and painful to listen to. The Jap voice expresses the emotion well. However it gets from mildly irritating to super annoying when it doesn't match the text namely Junpei-kun to Jumpy, Akane to Kanny, onii-chan to whatever makes sense in English. And the voice for the alert is just goddamn terrible.
[/list]

The plot and puzzles are significantly better in VLR. Main character is more likable, and everyone actually needs to compete in order to win unlike in 999. Supporting casts are also  better, but the writer managed to make me hate the double-faced grumpy old Tenmyouji even more than Dio. Design wise they are also more appealing, though it would be better if they were in 2D. Only a big flaw is Clover's smiley face as default even when she's sad or upset. Don't know how the devs can leave it like that.
Overall VLR improved a lot from 999.

Definitely a strong recommendation for visual novel lovers and highly viable for escape room fans who are willing to read long text.

Wow, where to begin the Nonary Games. 999 and VLR are both amazing games [i] if you like their genres [/i]. It's hard to describe them without spoilers, but I'll do my best.

Both 999 and VLR combine the style of Visual Novel, with meaningful interactive choices, and escape room puzzle segments. And are, of course, anime-esq. They both have complicated stories that take time and thought to understand, and both require you to replay the game several times and make lots of different decisions to find all the endings and the true, canon, ending. There are differences between the two games though.

999 is far more like a horror game than VLR. In point of fact, I wouldn't consider VLR scary at all, whilst 999 had it's moments of horror. You can tell that the horror was toned down in VLR.

999 is also more of a enclosed, shorter story. It has more of a neat beginning, middle and end and half a dozen clear endings. It is a fantastic murder mystery esq story.

VLR on the other hand is a more sprawling and complicated story. It is an amazing and somewhat mind-screwy storyline if you can invest enough in it - there is a lot more replaying and going back and forth in VLR to get all the endings and travel down the right paths than in 999, and admittedly there were a couple times where that did get a little tiresome, but the payoff is worth it and then some. If you can get past this repetition, which is helped massively by a skipping feature, you'll really enjoy VLR.

999 and VLR are interlinked and very good games, and getting them both in the same package is awesome. If you're a fan of this genre, anime-esq interactive visual novels, and escape rooms, you'll like these games. If you enjoy huge, overarching stories and don't mind playing the games several times over to get different endings, you'll love these games, especially if you can get past VLR's slightly repetitive replaying and don't mind 999's psychological horror elements.

I love these games far more than I thought I ever would, and I really do recommend them strongly if you are a fan or are interested in this genre. You won't regret it.

很不错，如果能有中文的话，就更好给别人推荐了。

第一部从剧情到画风都是系列最佳，第二部解密很有趣，但在伏笔过于明显的同时，硬要让我打通所有结局才能看到最后的真相，说实话打通有点累。

虽然在NDS和3DS上已经通关过全系列，但看到上架Steam的重制版，还是想支持一下。

这次的重制版合集包括了三部曲的前两作，原NDS平台的《999》和原3DS/PSV平台的《善人死亡》。加上之后的《零时困境》，三部曲构成了一个连续而完整的故事链，剧情人物皆有所关联。

其中999是开山之作，确立了整部作品的一系列背景设定（九人游戏、密室脱出、手环、形成场等）。即使距离此作发售已有十年，依然不能忘记当年这部NDS末期的大作横空出世时的震撼。
NDS可以说是任天堂的一代巅峰，华丽巨作数不胜数，而999和动物之森、机战W等作品一起，构成了我对这个平台最美好的回忆。

第二作善人死亡承接了999的剧情，系统复杂度、剧情长度都有了进一步的提升。尽管主流风评不如前作，但我对这部作品的喜爱比起999更甚。三部曲的核心概念之一形成场理论在本作中开始大放光彩，编剧打越阐释理论的能力也有所进步。缺点是，剧情挖坑太多，很多最后自己都填不上了，只好交给续作继续填。

打越就是打越，从Ever17到极限脱出三部曲，尽管每次都知道你要玩穿越，但还总能玩出花来，实乃剧本鬼才。

其实原作有多棒已经毋须赘述，再说说对重制版的看法：
画面经过重制，至少在解析度方面算是有所提升，但毕竟是从掌机上移植过来的作品，还是不能强求了。
尽管离开了掌机的触摸机能，但操控方式针对PC作过调整，并不会影响游戏进程。
999的系统经过大幅改进，比起原作添加了全程语音，还加入了类似于后两作的Flow功能，提升了不少游戏体验，这点值得一夸。
补票，希望有大佬能弄出汉化

沒有密室逃脫的標籤嗎?

Zero Escape系列一共有三個遊戲, 互相是有關連的, 此遊戲The Nonary Games已包含了最初的2個遊戲: 999和VLR。聽說VLR是三個遊戲中做得最出色的。

999:
此為多結局的遊戲, 故事非常緊張刺激, 9個人被禁固在郵輪內, 須要在限時9小時內逃生。Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors (999), 有著一大堆9的物語。
謎題不算太簡單, 但提示超多, 主角身邊的人很多話說(就差沒有直接告訴你答案), 這是普通的室密逃脫遊戲不會遇到的。
有6種不同結局, 差別很大。
真結局非常精彩, 但須要有重玩幾次的耐性才能看到。(就算沒有後續的2和3也能成為完整的故事。)
注意: 大多數的遊戲時間都是在看視覺小說! 講了很多冷知識、和一些匪夷所思的故事。

VLR:
同樣由密室逃脫和視覺小說組成, 人物和場景完全3D化, 世界觀跟1代有關係。
故事結構比1代更離奇, 被迫參與的遊戲、信任與背叛、兇殺案、殺人病毒等各種看似不相干的事情, 全部混在一起, 相當複雜。
解謎方面的出題比1代難, 答案往往要思考一番。今次有難易度選擇, 一開始不會直接說出太明顯的答案提示。
每一輪的故事比一代短很多, 流程分支極多(劇情略有不同, 有流程圖看, 可直接跳劇情), 結局有9種以上。
注意: 想解開所有謎團須要玩很多輪。不建議只玩一半。
(遊戲中有一部分內容劇透了1代的重要情節。)

結語:
這是2個遊戲, 如果你喜歡看緊張刺激的視覺小說, 是非常值得入手的。
這系列一共有3代, 在Zero Escape Trilogy組合包內能看到最後一個遊戲。聽說第3代不及第2代VLR出色, 但是由於在故事上是有關連的, 沒理由不一起打包購入。

First of all, if any zero escape fans, did not possess a 3ds, you can play 999! Which I have to say. Was nice. 

But I'm more interested in Virtues Last Reward. The game that felt like a total punch in the gut emotionally that I played on 3ds several years ago. If you have taste this game if for you!!!!!!! Honestly. If I could rate this 10/10 I'd be lying. It's more like .13/10 but that's against the rules and I will be PENALIZED! :D

本游戏包括极限脱出前两部的合集，以下分别评测。

[h1]極限脱出 9時間9人9の扉（9 Hours 9 People 9 Doors ，999）[/h1]
游戏性： 2 / 4
我就喜欢这种和数字挂钩，需要动动脑又不是特复杂的谜题[strike]，逃离一个房间总有种自己很聪明的错觉[/strike]。
但谜题的机巧性明显不够（和the room相比），脑洞性也不是太强（和the witness相比），中规中矩，但是作为吸引玩家注意力的手段已然足够；毕竟，游戏性的相对黯淡只是为了剧情的高光炸裂铺路而已w

剧情： 2 / 3
如果你冲着打越钢太郎的名号推的本作，那么你大概率经过了E17震撼脑髓的洗礼，999就像是一场作者与玩家时隔多年的再战，打越还能够骗过这群被养刁了的、有所设防的玩家们吗？
答案是：能，只在NDS上能，如同当年打越创造出那个非视觉小说媒介所不能呈现的诡计一般，这次他又带来了非NDS平台所不能呈现的诡计。
[spoiler]双屏翻转所带来的震撼，伏线一口气回收的酣畅，尽管步步为营却仍被狠狠欺骗的不甘与钦佩，这些感觉是移植版本无法复现的，正如E17永远也不能被动画化一样，999经过移植也失去了最核心的光彩。[/spoiler]

画面： 1 / 2
毕竟移植的是2009年的掌机游戏，在现在看来也算是时代的眼泪了（笑）；
嘛，大家都长得很有特点就完事了w

音乐： 1 / 1
渲染气氛方面还是不错的，尤其一些清冷阴森的音乐。

综合： 6 / 10
我推过本作的三个版本，分别是ios版，nds版（模拟器），和steam版，
相比之下，nds >> steam >> ios （ios版连密室部分都阉割了），
鉴于本作的特殊体质，移植真的会让体验大打折扣呢。

[h1]極限脱出ADV 善人シボウデス（Virtue's Last Reward，善人死亡）[/h1]
游戏性：3 / 4
相比999，密室和谜题真的足够多，也足够难。除了最后一个房间对谜题的重复使用别有用心之外，其余谜题的重复度并不高，但解谜过程有些繁琐。好在AB Game、输密码和jump的部分刺激十足，基本抵消了密室逃脱的冗长感。

剧情：3 / 3
999的豪华加强版，无论是动机、手法、世界观都恢弘到了需要单独画一张图表才能解释清楚的程度。[spoiler]“未来的选择能够影响过去”其实早在e17,999中都已经用烂了，但是打越就是能创造出些新的花样，还能自圆其说。[/spoiler]那些神棍理论，大而无当的世界设定，看似随意编出来的数字，这些乱七八糟的信息竟然能结合得分毫不乱。在破除了所有剧情锁，经历了照镜子的当头一棒（熟悉的一棒w）后，不由得让人感叹：虽然知道作者是在胡说八道，但这真的是一个精彩的故事。

画面：1 / 2
比999质量好些，但是3DCG实在有些残念…人物的一些动作建模极其僵硬，已经有点零时困境的倒霉德行了×

音乐：1 / 1
有些对于999的沿用，整体质量仍然不错，对气氛的把控非常好。

综合：8 / 10
打越自我抄袭的集大成之作，我认为质量高于999和零时困境。开放式的结局设计大概是打越真的填不上坑了吧www 但你要是问：极限脱出超越e17了嘛？那我只能说：很遗憾，还没有。999是低配e17，善人死亡是高配999，都是优秀的作品，但当初那种好像头盖骨被掀开的瞬间却再也回不来了。

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games - это вещь, которая просто поразила меня. Признаюсь честно, я не знала об игре ничего, и первое время думала. что это чем-то, но напомнит мне небезызвестную Данганронпу. Ох, как же я ошибалась. Итак, давайте же поговорим обо всем по порядку.

В данной ситуации мы имеем две игры по цене одной - 999 и VLR. Nine Hours, Nine Person, Nine Doors и Virtue's Last Reward соответственно/ Первая часть более приятная глазу за счет классных, местами анимированных спрайтов персонажей, и имеющая потрясающий сюжет, вторая же подкупает более высокой продолжительность приключения и опять же потрясающим сюжетом. Честно говоря. я очень долго не могла приступить к VLR - эти модельки персонажей сделали свое дело, и анимированные... как это назвать, катсцены? Они выглядели топорно и деревянно, что вызывало лишь легкий смешок. Ко всему привыкаешь, и как только сюжет начал набирать обороты, я уже не могла оторваться. Увлекает так, что больше не можешь ни о чем думать

Само собой обе игры связаны: общей идеей, персонажами и завязкой (девять человек заперты в каком-то здании, вынужденные участвовать в игре). Первая часть больше опирается на математику, а движение по различным веткам в основном не поможет открытию истинной концовки кроме как определенного пути. Вторая же часть куда более запутанная, и рано или поздно ты начинаешь теряться в таймлайнах - вот только истинная концовка этого стоит.

Геймплей почти одинаковый: режим визуальной новеллы переплетается с "побегами" - головоломкой в запертой комнате. И если в первой части в них нет совершенно никакой сложности, то во второй уже появляются затруднения. Правда в том, что некоторые вещи реально можно решить наугад. просто случайно ткнув туда, куда надо. Говоря об отличиях, во второй у нас добавилась AB Game - выбор между доверием и предательством. который выведет вас на очередную ветку. 

В первой части сюжет менее глобален, и направлен скорее на определенную личность, во второй же части у нас... а впрочем, узнаете сами. Некоторые персонажи перекочевали из первой части во вторую с кое-какой сменой внешнего вида, и безумно хочется узнать, кто же из них все-таки добрался до Zero Time Dilemma.

Проблема у игры всего одна, и относится она к русскоязычным пользователям, не владеющим английским в достаточной мере. Хотела бы я сказать, что язык тут легкий, но это не так. Масса моментов, что в 999, что в VLR, когда персонажи поясняют многие аспекты, когда идет разъяснение правил головоломки, когда в принципе что-то объясняют. Это реально тяжело читать, и когда будет дело касаться простых диалогов между персонажами, то сложности никакой нет, но вот в остальном... Нить сюжета скорее всего потеряется, и игра будет лишена смысла. 

В целом, я оказалась приятно удивлена, и теперь с нетерпением жду возможности купить ZTD. К прохождению просто обязательно.

P.S. Было порождено огромное количество шуток в духе "Это был я, Дио", но не я первая, и не я последняя, так что тут ничего не поделать.
Great puzzles and story
One of the best games on steam

Well, I really loved both [i]Nonary Games[/i]! After completing Danganronpa series, I came to conclusion that I need to play Zero Escape one day. I was not wrong, and I'm a big fan of this type of games - escape games.

I love how Zero Escape plays with some subjects, such as telepathy and time travelling. They're put in a very easy way to understand, just like a part of pop culture (this is unlike for [i]STEINS;GATE[/i], a game where time travelling is involved too). In both games there's no boring storytelling at all, and I guarantee you to enjoy every minute of it.

The escape game itself is represnted by numerous puzzles which are fun to solve. In the second game you can fix the difficulty if you like. In VLR you also have to solve additonal puzzles in order to get a special reward. Puzzles are very different, from mini games to some logic stuff.

One of my favourite things about these games is characters. They all are individuals, which I love, and all of them are very different from each other. Some characters are espers (you'll find out who as soon as you play the game) and some are simple human, but important ones (and not only that - some of them are more mysterious than it seems in the beginning). Anyway, I love Santa and Prince from 999 and Sigma and Dio from VRL. Sigma is a good type of main protagonist - not so certain when you only start to play, but the more you complete the plot, the more you find out about him.

One important thing about Nonary Games is that your choices in little things (like, which door to enter and how to reply to certain phrases) affect the ending a lot. Both games have multiple endings, and you can change your choices to find out what's going to change if you take another route. If you complete ALL of them, you'll get a True Ending in VRL (in 999 you don't have to do so, but you may try different choices to see where they gonna to lead you). Also, in VRL each ending tells more about one of nine characters, so you won't have to complain about completing all of them.

[i]I highly recommend Nonary Games to everyone who loves escape games, solving multiple puzzles and visual novels. As for me, that's one of my favorite games for now.[/i]

Первая часть радует атмосферой и сеттингом.
Вторая часть по объему намного превосходит первую: еще больше головоломок, завороченного сюжета и разных мыслей о вечном.
В обеих частях добротная английская озвучка.

Deux jeux géniaux pour le prix d'un !
Si vous aimez les séries Ace Attorney et/ou Professeur Layton (ce qui est mon cas), il y a de grandes chances pour que vous appréciez ces jeux ! Les deux se passent dans le même univers et demandent au joueur de résoudre différentes énigmes par pièce pour faire avancer l'histoire. De nombreuses fins sont disponibles sur les deux jeux (dont des Game Over), toutes les faire est important pour comprendre toute l'histoire ! :) 
Le truc le plus chiant cela dit est qu'il faut souvent relire des passages similaires ou que vous avez déjà lu auparavant, afin d'accéder aux autres fins.

I would say at a base line 999 would be worth it (thought at $30 it may be a bit much for just the one). The story it gives is a pretty solid and you can peace things together and guess bits of the ending. The puzzles are over all pretty easy going, and the characters are enjoyable.

Virtue’s Last Reward is a different beast. first off VLR has a ton of branching paths and you will need to go through most of them to get all the data you need for the true ending. I suggest if you play this game you a note pad to keep track of password. I didnt do this and got minor spoilers looking the up. Also some of the puzzle can feel hard to flat out illogical at parts. Also most of the characters can feel like total ass, and it feels like there is a double standard that if the player does a slight against the others you will get punish.

Also there is alot of waiting and backtracking in VLR. More then what I would say is good for the fun of the game. As you will have to see the same event in different flavors like 6+ times.

All this said VLR did one things that I loved. The Ending. The ending is bat shit insane and the logic can be a little weak. But being spoil on it, it still left me shock on the twist it made.

if you like classic puzzle adventure games 999 is good enough to carry this purchase. VLR is like a crazy bonus that takes alot of investment in for a pay off that may not be your cup of tea (but for me it was very sweet).

Amazing game, plunges straight into a puzzle escape type of game with excellent plot, discussing interesting theoretical physics principles that are relevant to the plot. Choices matter, and every ending was very well thought out. Taking your time to finish every ending is recommended, and a guide could be used to ensure the proper pathways to the endings. Another amazing game under Spike Chunsoft.

i'm loving the game and the fact it that has so many endings but i just don't get one thing 
does this first game also includes the vlr one?

999 Provides a great cast of characters and a very well put together mystery that only gets more intense as it continues on. The artstyle is the best and I wish it stayed, the music is great, and engaging. By itself it's easily the only game you need. One of the tracks in the game called Digital Root, actually changes feeling when the real freaky shit happens or rather gets explained. You'll understand what I mean later on, it's not everyday you can find a game where a song can actually add a different impact than before when the context has completely changed.

VLR is the most convoluted, if not maybe the worst written story I've ever experienced. Instead of keeping the artstyle from the previous game, they've changed to this ugly 3D modeling, probably to cut cost and time. I assume they never bothered much with their writing team either. A lot of pointless banter that adds absolutely nothing to the story, and really does waste your time. The worst part is you have to experience more routes to get the true ending and when you have to deal with just one route filled with dialogue trying to act like it has anything profound to say the experience is needless to say draining and infuriating. The game's core mission was to take everything you loved about 999 and destroy it.

I recommend this for 999, and 999 alone. Whether you suffer VLR is up to you.
Dos obras maestras.

ノベルゲームと脱出ゲームを交互に繰り返していき、ストーリーを追っていくゲーム。
チュンソフトが作ってるだけあってノベルゲームパートはほとんどかまいたちの夜に近く、
分岐ルートが初めから表示されていて、既プレイのシーンからいつでもやり直せるのは高評価。

ただ、肝心の脱出ゲームパートの難易度が低く、はっきり言ってあまり面白くない。
謎解き自体に難しいものがないのに加えて、何回かパズルをやり直しただけでほとんど正解に近いヒントを仲間が勝手にしゃべるなどの点は、むしろ馬鹿にされているようで不快だった。

また、シンプルなゲーム性のわりに、ゲームとしての操作性があまり良くなく、
そもそも基本的なUIの設計が悪いので、その部分でもマイナス。
特にテキストを決定ボタンでしか送れないのは今時のゲームにしてはありえないレベルで、
ボタン連打してると選択肢を間違えて選んでしまうのが本当にダルい。

ストーリー自体はなかなか凝っていて、凡百のデスゲームものにはないものを感じさせたが、
いかんせん登場人物にあまり魅力を感じなかったため、そこまでゲームにはのめりこめなかった。
性格的な意味でもそうだが、単純にデザイン面でのキャラデザが好みではなく、
以前にダンガンロンパシリーズをプレイしているとどうしても劣ると感じてしまった。

総合的に見て65～70点くらいのゲーム。セールで買うのがちょうどいいと思う。
极限脱出前两作真的是神作，从剧情和游戏来说都没的说，第三作倒是见仁见智了，这么一说打越钢太郎跟小高两个人凑一块还真是巧了

Absolutely loved both games! The puzzles can be challenging but there are different modes, many involving numbers although I have to point out that while I personally HATE math, these moments were quite tolerable and are more common in the first game. Great, mysterious story, interesting and unique characters. The flow charts can be a bit of a pain to follow but there are guides and whatnot that make it easy to figure out what you need to do to get different endings. Definitely worth the price considering the abundance of content, and has me sold on the next game already.

I've been a fan of the Zero Escape franchise for years playing then on the DS/3DS and I can say without a doubt that this collection might be the best way to play them.  First with 999 there is a massive improvement to this flow of the game with the addition of the scene flowchart introduced in VLR, making it easier to navigate the multiple endings.

From what I can tell VLR doesn't appear to be too different from the PSVita version and I don't know if the old save corrupting bug ever got fixed, to be safe though one should never save while solving a puzzle segment in VLR.  It also appears that a couple puzzles have been reworked in both games, this most likely due to the lack of 2 screens on the DS/3DS, saying any more is a potential spoiler.

If you're looking for a VN series focused on puzzles and a very complex lore that will make your head hurt look no further.  Just do yourself 2 favors, buy the bundle and save some cash.  And wait until you complete all three games before you try to additional information on the franchise's lore if you don't want spoilers.

[b]Quick Summary:[/b]  PC users might easily forgive the dated graphics, but they will still find The Nonary Games to be crude and in terms of puzzles, plot and dialog.   At their best, The Nonary Games are still far less interesting than similar games released 10 years earlier (e.g. Myst, Obsidian, Shivers, 7th Guest, Harvester, Amber: Journeys Beyond, Fahrenheit/Indigo Prophecy) and they don't hold a candle to games released since then (Heavy Rain,  Amnesia: The Dark Descent).  If you're looking for visual novels with puzzles, skip Nonary and check out games like Catherine and Doki Doki Literature Club. (DDLC is even free.)

[b]Details:[/b]
[u]999 - 9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors[/u]:  An OK adventure/visual-novel game with interesting philosophy and overall premise but mostly average puzzles (though the puzzles often feel more contrived than thematic).  Unfortunately, the characters are rather bland and most suspense is undermined by too much pointless talking.  

[u]Virtue's Last Reward[/u]:  ABSOLUTELY TERRIBLE GAME.  Even if you can get it for free, don't waste your time playing it.  Most characters are so annoying and prattle so incessantly that I would have happily thrown them (or myself!) out of an airlock just to shut them up.  The dialog varies from silliness to pseudo-intellectualism to juvenile humor that you would expect from kids just hitting puberty.  Most puzzles are grossly contrived and there are a couple that are the worst I've seen in 20 years of playing computer games.  The story is meandering and needlessly convoluted (and this is from a guy who enjoys movies like Primer and Time Crimes).  Worst of all, VLR completely undermines both the premise and the victory achieved in 999. [u]Spoiler[/u]: [spoiler]In 999, the morphogenic field allows experiences in the future to influence actions in the past while still maintaining a single timeline.  In VLR, the past isn't changed but a new parallel timeline is created when a different action is taken at a decision point.  According to VLR's premise, in at least one timeline in 999, Akane is still burned to death.[/spoiler]  A life is a terrible thing to waste.  Don't waste the precious hours of yours here.

Mais comment j'ai pu laisser dormir ces 2 merveilles dans ma bibliothèque si longtemps .J'étais loin d'imaginer qu'il y avait de si bons jeux sur DS. Coup de foudre , j'ai même mis de côté "tales of vespéria" que j'avais entamé pour me lancer dans la trilogie des "zero escape", c'est dire. C'est l'anglais qui m'avait sans doute freinée puisque qu'il n'y a que le troisième "zero dilemna" qui dispose d'un patch fr excellent (bravo et merci à l'équipe de traduction) . Mais finalement, n'hésitez pas à vous lancer si vous avez un anglais niv BAC, même s'ils sont tres bavards, ça roule tout seul, d'autant plus que vous pouvez vous même au choix cliquer pour passer d'une phrase de dialogue à l'autre, et donc n'êtes pas pris par le temps. Et on peut même remonter en arrière. Pour le reste, matez l'excellente éval de "John Beaver" qui m'a moi-même décidée à franchir le pas. Elle vous dira tout bien mieux que je n'aurais pu le faire. Dernière chose, surtout ne pas faire la trilogie dans le désordre. J'ajoute qu'elle devrait plaire aux fans de "point and click" classique.
C'est parti mon kiki, j'attaque "zero dilemna" et en français en plus. Yes !

If you like games that you have to play multiple times to get a "perfect ending", if you like point and click adventures, and if you'd like to hear a narrative based on time travel, philosophy and paradoxes then this series of games may be for you.

If you like sleeping, then you may not like this game as they are very hard to put down.  Page turners in every sense.

I have at least played both of the games in this package twice. I would literally pay 100 dollars to experience all I have with this game. Buy it. It's got twists, turns, emotions, and fear. Wonderful story telling.

Highly recommended, but beware. The structure of the games can result in some tedium.

[url=https://maxsgameshed.com/2018/12/30/the-zero-escape-franchise/]If you would like to see a more detailed review of both games, you can find it in an article on my website that includes my thoughts on the third game[/url]

Este juego me encanta porque es la polla, y ya esta. La primera parte, 999, es la puta hostia, la historia es maravillosa, pero es super aburrido conseguir otros finales, ademas de que cambiaron el puzzle final de la versión de DS, que era un Sudoku. El Virtue Last Reward es el mejor de la saga, ya he jugado Zero Time Dilemma y es simplemente maravilloso, ademas de que algunos finales son super emotivos y los Ambidex Games son simplemente una idea super maravillosa, aunque me gusta mas la mecanica de Zero Time Dilemma, me siguen encantando los Ambidex Games.

[h1]In General[/h1]
Excellent story, excellent characters, great puzzles, good music and a very enjoyable time playing this game. If you're a fan of visual novels with very intricate and deep plots, these two games are a must.

[h1]999[/h1]

Excellent story, excellent characters, puzzles are a little too easy at times and good music. The only thing that I would change would the UI, it's too reminiscent of a touch screen which it's a little difficult to navigate with a mouse and the explanation of the locks in the flowcharts. Regardless of this, it's still a great game to play.

[h1]VLR[/h1]

I would say this one is the better game, excellent and deep story, excellent characters, great music, puzzles this time are a little harder (which is good) and the UI has been improved but it still could be better. All in all, an excellent game and a great experience.

Amazing Storyline and challenging puzzles, loved every minute

I really have no words for Zero Escape; it's simply a fantastic saga with an intriguing plot, great characters, breathtaking plot twists and challenging yet fair puzzles.
It's one of those games that use the medium to tell a story and it does it in the best way possible.
If you're going to give these games a try, whatever you do, do not get spoiled and enjoy the wild ride.

I'd highly recommend the Zero Escape Trilogy together as a whole, but there is no doubt that this combo game has the top two games in the series. Virtue's Last Reward is by far my favorite, but you couldn't get a better start than 999. I will admit that the price is pretty steep, but in my opinion it's worth the money. If you like visual novels and the thriller genre, I can't imagine a better pairing.

This is easily one of, if not [i] the most [/i], complex and interesting narratives I have ever experienced. 

Regarding the quality of the Nonary Game remaster, 999 and VLR have never looked and played better. That being said, [i] 999 is still best experienced in its original Nintendo DS platform [/i] since there's a certain... "story experience" you could only have with two screens (then again anything is better than the puzzle-less mobile verison I was introduced to). The new English voice acting in 999 was great (especially Junpei's) with a few exceptions that I eventually warmed up to.

I strongly recommend this series to anyone that isn't turned off by visual novels and puzzle solving. The way the devs created this incredibly complex and beautiful trilogy (including ZTD) while taking advantage of the video game medium itself is nothing short of amazing. This series is best played blind and while avoiding google searches or fan wikis like the Radical-6 virus.

Personally I didn't find 999 that interesting, it was more of a concept than an actual game. That's why I was hesitant to continue playing and experience Virtue's Last Reward (VLR), but now I am incredibly glad that I was pushed into it.

VLR expands on everything the first game introduces and offers so much more, however I would not advise playing it without experiencing 999 first. It offers a genuinely great set of characters, choices and puzzles. I think I was most intrigued by the real-life paradoxes the game introduces the player to. The game also offers a plethora of different options and individual stories and I must say, I was engaged from the very start until the very end. In fact, I ended up so enchanted by this title that I bought Zero Time Dilemma right away after finishing VLR. I completed it over the next two days.

Due to its intriguing storytelling that might or might not blow your mind at one point or another, due to its unique set of characters that will most certainly surprise you in the end, due to its setting, due to its fun escape rooms and dialogues, Virtue's Last Reward has become one of my best gaming experiences ever. When I went back to 999 afterwards, I had a newfound appreciation for it as well. Perhaps VLR simply had to open my eyes to see just how brilliant this game series is.

Strongly recommended.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games nos brinda 2 juegos que son practicamente como leer un libro interactivo, estos son 999 (9 personas 9 puertas 9 horas) Y VLR (Virtue's Last Reward), las historias se nos cuentan mediante la mecánica general del género Visual Novel, es decir, personajes en el centro de la pantalla que van cambiando sus poses mientras que sus palabras son reflejadas en una caja que aparece en la pantalla. El único personaje que no vemos en pantalla con su respectiva sprite es el protagonista, ya que todo se ve desde su punto de vista para poder sentir que eres él. Los juegos cuentan con varios finales que serán determinados según nuestras acciones alterando la historia, siendo estos finales buenos o malos, y una vez se tengan todos los finales se abrirá la ruta a lo que se llama el True Ending del juego, que es el final oficial y definitivo de la historia. 

Estos juegos en su parte jugable consiste en distintos puzzles en el que el objetivo es encontrar una salida para escapar de unas habitaciones investigándolas a fondo y encontrando objetos y pistas para salir. La mayoría de los puzzles no son muy difíciles, pero te puedes quedar fácilmente media hora pensando en como salir. Son unos puzzles muy interesantes, con mucha lógica y realmente bien planteados, sobretodo por el como incluyen matemáticas y química a parte, no tienen desperdicio las divagaciones de los personajes a la hora de investigar.

La historia de ambos juegos es lo que, a mi criterio personal, fue lo que me hizo seguir jugando hasta completarlos, en resumen y evitando spoilers, en ambos juegos hay 9 personas secuestradas por la mente maestra autodenominada "Zero", donde el objetivo de estas personas es encontrar una puerta enumerada con un "9" para poder escapar del lugar, y en torno a esta trama gira una historia que mezcla toques notáblemente psicológicos con el frenesí de que tienen tiempo limitado para escapar, adicionando el terror de estar encerrados en un lugar desconocido sin saber que les espera o si hay algo más.

En conclusión Zero Escape: The Nonary Games te ofrece dos de las mejores visual novels que podrás encontrar en el mercado, aunque tiene el problema del idioma , pues no está traducido al español, únicamente textos en inglés, de un nivel no muy alto, pero que cierra la puerta a muchos jugadores que de estar en español quizás se atreverían a adentrarse en la saga de Nonary Games, pero eso sí, si disfrutaste con estas 2 primeras entregas de Zero Escape, no te puedes perder el final de la saga en Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma.

Zero Escape is easily my favorite visual novel.  The first game has been changed to add the flowchart, and it makes it more in line with the later games.  It's very much the best way to play this game now.  I played the second game on 3DS ages ago (and it's my favorite of the trilogy), and got this primarily for the first game (I haven't actually played through the second one with this version).

Overall, there are excellent games.  The story is very engrossing, and the puzzles are my favorite I've played in a VN.  You should expect 20-25 hours overall for both games.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games
เป็นเวอร์ชั่นที่รวบเกมจากซีรี่ย์นี้มา 2 ภาคด้วยกัน คือ 9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors (ภาคแรก) กับ Virtue's Last Reward (ภาคสอง) เนื้อหาต่อกัน เดิมสองเกมนี้เคยอยู่บน Nintendo DS กับ 3DS มาก่อน อันนี้ก็เป็นเวอร์ชั่นพอร์ตแล้วปรับนิดหน่อยมาอีกที

เนื้อหาคร่าวๆ จะเกี่ยวกับคนทั้ง 9 ที่ถูกจับตัวมาให้เล่น Nonary Games ไขปริศนาเพื่อหาทางออกให้ได้ แต่จุดประสงค์ของเกมคืออะไร ทำไมแต่ละคนถึงถูกจับมา ใครเป็นผู้อยู่เบื้องหลัง เป็นสิ่งที่ผู้เล่นจะต้องหาคำตอบไปด้วยค่ะ

- ด้านเนื้อเรื่อง ให้คะแนน 10/10 เอาคะแนนเต็มไปเลยกับส่วนนี้ ธีมเรื่องจะออกแนวปริศนา กึ่งสืบสวน เอาตัวรอด บวกไซไฟไปด้วย (บางทีก็ปวดหัวกับทฤษฎีนิดหน่อย 555) เนื้อเรื่องของเกมจะเปลี่ยนไปตามทางที่เราเลือกและนำไปสู่ฉากจบที่แตกต่างกัน แต่ละทางเลือกก็จะมีเบาะแส คำใบ้ เฉลยปริศนาบางส่วน หรือแม้แต่ตั้งคำถามใหม่มาให้ ซึ่งตอนเล่นก็รู้สึกว่าเข้มข้นและขนลุกสุดๆ อยากให้มองว่าการเลือกเป็นวิธีหนึ่งในการเล่าเรื่องของเกมนี้ค่ะ เพราะสุดท้ายเมื่อเราได้เล่นครบทุกรูทแล้ว ก็จะเห็นภาพรวมและคลี่คลายปริศนาได้เอง

- บทบาทและมิติตัวละคร ให้ 9/10 หากเล่นไล่ไปแต่ละรูทก็จะรู้เรื่องราวของตัวละครแต่ละคนมากขึ้น แต่ละการกระทำมีที่มาที่ไปและเหตุผลอยู่ ตรงนี้ก็ถือว่าทำได้ดี โดยถ้าเทียบกันแล้วส่วนตัวคิดว่า VLR จะอธิบายได้ลึกกว่า 999 หน่อย อาจเป็นเพราะตัวเนื้อหาเกมยาวกว่าก็เป็นได้

- ระบบเกมและปริศนา ให้คะแนน 8.5/10 ลักษณะเกมเป็นแนวสำรวจห้องปิดเพื่อแก้ปริศนาเพื่อหาทางออกจากห้อง เช่น หยิบของมาประกอบกันแล้วใช้ให้ถูกที่ ปริศนามีตั้งแต่ระดับง่ายไปจนถึงยาก สำหรับ VLR สามารถปรับเลือกให้ปริศนาเป็นระดับง่ายได้ ส่วนเนื้อเรื่องส่วนอื่นจะเป็นแบบ visual novel คืออ่านไปเรื่อยๆ ใน 999 ขัดใจหน่อยนึงตรงที่มันเลือกให้ skip เฉพาะส่วนที่อ่านแล้วไม่ได้ (เหมือนมันจะเซ็ตไว้เป็น skip all) พอมา VLR ตรงนี้ตั้งได้แล้ว แต่เวลาไขปริศนาในห้อง ต้องลากเมาส์เพื่อเปลี่ยนมุมกล้องในห้องแทนที่จะกดลูกศรเหมือนภาคแรก ฮ่วย 555

- เสียงประกอบ ให้คะแนน 9/10 เพลงฟังแล้วระทึกดีค่ะ ตอนลุ้นก็ลุ้น ตอนหลอนก็หลอน เสียงพากย์ก็ดี

- ภาพ ให้คะแนน 9/10 สำหรับ 999 จะเป็นภาพอนิเมชั่น 2 มิติ ไม่ถึงกับสะดุดตามากนัก แต่ซีจีสวยดี ส่วน VLR ตัวละครกับซีจีจะเป็นโมเดล 3 มิติเลย (น่าจะเพราะลงใน 3DS มาก่อน) แต่อยากให้ปรับตรงโมเดลตัวละครบางคน เวลาเครียดๆ ไม่รู้ทำไมถึงเป็นหน้ายิ้มซะงั้น เลยจะรู้สึกขัดอารมณ์หน่อย

รวมๆ ให้คะแนนเกมนี้ 9/10 แนะนำสำหรับผู้เล่นสายเสพเนื้อเรื่องแบบซับซ้อน (ซ้อนหลายชั้นหน่อย 55) และผู้ที่ชอบแนวไขปริศนาค่ะ เนื้อหาหนักพอควร ถ้าชอบแนวนี้อยู่แล้วก็น่าลองมากๆ ค่ะ ^^

[Spoiler-free review] 

Let's start with the cons:

- The games were made for the Nintendo DS. This makes some operation difficult, such as writing things down, or one or two puzzles. However, if you want to remember things outside of the 'memo' feature, just use a pad and paper. I should note that I used a controller for 999 and the keyboard+mouse for VLR and I was fine.

- These games need a lot of patience. You'll play through many puzzles, and replayability is a huge factor as some endings are needed for the true ending in 999, and VLR requires ALL endings to unlock the true ending.

- I loved the art style in 999 and was sad to see it go in VLR. The characters are now 3D models which aren't stunning, although they do the trick.


The pros, now:

- I found that 999's story was good. It wasn't the best thing I've every encountered, but the twists were fun and the true ending, after spending time in this death game, was a satisfying conclusion and left me excited for the sequel. But VLR? The story is stellar. Seriously, this game has just made the top of my favourite VNs list. It's difficult to elaborate without spoiling many things, but there is gratuitous use of concepts such as mortality, morality, time travel, responsibility, the role of fate and reasoning, and lots of sciencey mumbo-jumbo, all fitting together nicely to tell an amazing story. I'm intensely impatient to play the sequel now, and after I finish writing this review I'm going to go lie down and give my brain a break.

- The puzzles are a lot of fun and very satisfying. I played the entire game of VLR on hard difficulty and only required help one or two times, but it took quite a bit of creative thinking to make my way through them. 999's puzzles are similarly difficult. It especially reminded me of escape rooms, which usually provide you an out in the perspectives of those playing with you; if you can't figure out a puzzle, another point of view is provided in easy mode if you need it (in VLR). 

- I love the character design in these games! Might cosplay some one day, since they seem like a ton of fun.

- The music and art is really cool. The BGM lends itself to the mysterious/ominous feeling, and fits the setting well (ship/warehouse). The art style (in 999) is similar to anime yet retains a cooler appearance in the thick lines and flatter shading, and the animations are wonderful.


Overall, the games are some of my all-time favourites, and this story will stick with me for a long while. The price might seem a bit steep, so if you're resistant to a splurge you could wait for a sale, but I'd like to point out that this is a package of two games - a great one and an excellent one, at that. I got a good ~24 hours out of each game. It's redefined how I see games can be created, and specifically how game mechanics can work as an integral part of storytelling. I'd highly recommend these, and if you're willing, you might want to pick up the sequel, Zero Time Dilemma, as well, since VLR might leave you on a bit of a cliffhanger.

[u]Two Brain-Benders for the Price of One[/u]

Two excellent visual novels. 999 is pretty good, with some very novel (and confusing) ideas, but it's Virtue's Last Reward that really stands out. VLR takes everything that makes 999 so intriguing and ramps it up by 100. The mechanic of only being able to progress further down certain routes after taking certain other routes is very clever indeed, and a great way to ensure players remain hooked. The puzzles in both games range in difficulty, but they never felt unfair: There's always a hint or clue to point you in the right direction, you never find yourself in a situation where the only way forward is to randomly guess.

If you enjoyed the DanganRonpa series you'll love this. Lord knows how the story will end in Zero TIme Dilemma, but I for one cannot wait to find out

I recommend both games, I'll tell why below. 

9 Hours 9 Persons 9 Doors - Start of the series, everything seems unique and bizarre. The puzzles are wonderful, story's mysterious and it draws you in rather quickly. The fact of the matter is, at least in my eyes, this game doesn't have a mindblowing story, nor the most fun characters, but what it offers is one of the best settings of a visual novel I've seen, alongside a few good mentions of real events and real facts in different types of scientific fields. The art is rather serious, the characters are drawn in a much more mature and refined way. It makes it easier for people that do not have much interest in the anime industry enjoy it. Replay value is... rather mandatory to get the full picture, though. So it might get a little bit irritating at times.
Setting, art, decent storywriting and challenging puzzles these are more than enough to keep you intrigued. 

Virtue's Last Reward - A little bit of a downgrade in terms of an artistic approach, I didn't like how the characters were not drawn anymore, excluding some cutscenes. Again, same thing applies here - replay value is mandatory and it can come across as a bit irritating. Now that pretty much all the negatives, or rather things that can be seen as negatives, have been said, the story's much more well-thought of than the first game, the thought behind this game is different, hence the approach is different, although there are still different types of locked doors that only specific combinations of people can enter, so the format is still untouched. Puzzles are a tad more difficult than the first game. Unraveling some of the game's mysteries provided with a more satisfacory revelation.  Overall, a much more preferred Zero Escape, I've liked the philosophical approach much more here. 

You get two games instead of one, the price might be a tad much, but it's definitely worth it if you can swallow the expense.

Good games, definetly worth the price. Story is amazing, and I enjoyed the puzzle solving too. If you want a well written visual novel that isn't 100% reading, you'll probably like this.

My major complaint is that the models in VLR are... so god damn ugly. It's especially jarring after playing 999, where they use nicely animated drawn portraits instead. It's kind of a small complaint for what is now one of my favourite game series, but still a bit dissapointing.

An entertaining start and midgame falter as both the story, characters and puzzles get worse deeper into the game, finishing on a mess of an ending. The fun is not worth the disappointment, and I cannot endorse buying this.

对于没有接触过同类型作品的玩家而言，极限脱出系列是一部可以为他们打开新世界大门的杰作，可能在之前你永远也没想过故事居然可以有这种讲法，原来世界上还存在这种游戏。在历尽千辛万苦解开密室抵达结局时，却发现谜团并没有得到解决，甚至像雪球一样越滚越大，只得带着更多的疑惑进入下一个周目的游戏。在数次，甚至十数次重复这个过程之后，在你终于拿着在别的路线中收集到的钥匙，打开那扇名为真相的大门的那一刻，你才会发现，之前的一切费解、迷惘、压抑、徒劳都是值得的，打越钢太郎就是这样一个编剧，无论前期的铺垫如何冗长，流程如何复杂，如何让玩家一次次生出弃游之心，只要你能克服这一切，坚持到最终的真相路线，就一定会为这绝妙的谜底所叹服。
不过，对于从KID时代就一路追随打越过来的老玩家而言，又是否会是同样的感受呢。
无论999还是善人死亡，打越都给出了一个与复杂的流程相称的，足以令人拍案的真相，但对于玩过Ever17的玩家而言，虽然他们也同样会被折服，但同时，也会不由自主想起曾经攻略Ever17时的感受，在解开谜底时，那个仿佛脑浆都开始沸腾的瞬间，而极限脱出系列与之相比，显然还差点什么。
999和善人死亡都是KID解散以后由打越所主导的作品中的佼佼者，但很遗憾，它们并没有超越自己的前辈Ever17，曾经最接近它的作品是infinity系列的第三部作品Remember11，但因为没有正式的解谜篇最终也难以撼动Ever17的地位，果然即使天才如打越想要超越自己设下的极限也并非是轻易能做到的事，不论如何，极限脱出系列至少向我们证明了这个已经年近知天命的编剧脑洞和笔力都不减当年，但他是否真的还能再一次像当年的Ever17一样技惊四座呢，恐怕这一点谁也不能保证吧。

[Story Spoilers Free]
[Short Version]
   Zero Escape: The Nonary Game is a combination of the first two games in the Zero Escape series, 999 (2009) and Virtues Last Reward (2012). The gameplay is essentially a series of escape the room type puzzles with an interesting story presented to us throughout. 

[b]Port[/b]
 These are ports from the Nintendo version and while little work is done to hide the fact, they were designed around a touch screen, they still work fine on PC if using mouse. If you played 999 [ first game] on Nintendo, you will notice they incorporated a more condense version of dialogue along with voice acting on certain lines for this version. Though you can easily switch from new dialogue to original at the cost of seeing background due to the fact Nintendo DS had two screens to work with. The voice acting is tolerable though not every line has a voice clip. Besides that, and a certain scene being different due to not having duel screens, these are quality ports.

 [b]Gameplay[/b]
  The puzzles range from easy to moderately difficult. The first game has a small selection of puzzle types, mainly consisting of find object and use it in right spot. The second game has a much wider variation of puzzles, ranging from classic sliding blocks to math problems. Like myself, may end up struggling with one puzzle that your friend found easy but blitz through another they spent an hour on. With second game, if you keep messing up on a puzzle, the characters will provide hints to solving it depending on hint level set in options. Since this game is part visual novel, you do have an option to skip text/scenes you have already seen, which is useful in second game. Lastly, in both games you switch views by clicking arrows, there is no freelook option.

Note: if need a guide for puzzles, make sure its spoiler free.

 [b]Story[/b]
  The story is broken up in different branches, branch you end up going down depends on your choice. While in first game could end up beating it while missing content, second game does a nice job of preventing that. Without getting into spoilers, your choices do matter and effects game but not fully how you think. This series isn't exactly a choose your own adventure game, it is trying to tell a narrative. There is no correct first choices in these games, especially in second game. This series has a mystery story, with clues appearing depending on your choices. Some may say making a certain choice first will ruin others but that is true for any choice. For second game, no choice will completely ruin another part of story. Though same can't be said for first game since as mentioned earlier, could 'beat' it without seeing all content. Reason I am being so vague is I do not want to spoil story but want encourage players to choose whatever they feel like without worry.

   The stories in this series are very nicely put together and planned out. The second and third game (not part of this one) have decent amount of replay ability if enjoy spotting things didn't first time around.

[b]Final Words [/b]
   The second game of this series Zero Escape Virtues Last Reward is one of my favorite games of all time due to brilliant story, interesting cast of characters despite some being stereotypes, and challenging but enjoyable puzzles. While $45 may seem steep, remember it is two games in one. Second game is where you get your money’s worth but need to beat first to completely enjoy second.

Get ready to loose all sense of time and your mind with Zero Escape: The Nonary Games.
The Nonary Games is a mix of a puzzle solving game and a visual novel. There will be a lot of reading involved but it is worth the time as the story will captivate and pull you in to the game's world almost instantly with puzzle segments starts out easy but gets fustratingly hard over time.
The Nonary Games's story is easily the most attractive and interesting thing about the series. The first game, 9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors, sets the stage as you suddenly wake up in a sinking ship with eight others trapped onboard with you. You learn that a person named 'Zero' had kidnapped everyone to force them to play a game, very similar to the Saw movies. However, instead of tourture and gore, there is a layer of mystery you are trying to solve while wondering if one of your fellow survivors will betray you. The pacing of this game is very well done as it doesn't drag out certain parts of the story unlike the second game, Virtue's Last Reward.
Virtue's Last Reward starts out similary like the previous game with you trapped in some kind of facility with eight other people. You are forced to work in a group setting, trying to earn points to be allowed to escape. However, you have to worry about being backstabbed and betrayed by people that you wonder if you can trust. The story is a lot longer and certain parts are dragged out but do serve a purpose to the story as a whole.
The main aspects both games share are the puzzles. They are fun to try and solve and can get difficult to the point that it can be fustrating. Thankfully, you can adjust the difficulty of the puzzles but it is a lot more rewarding solving at its most difficult setting.
The package as a whole is worth the price, even if it is rather expensive. If you see it on sale, pick it up as soon as you can. It is one hell of an experience.

Having played throguh this game twice now (once on Steam, then on PS4) I can without a doubt recommend this game.

The gameplay uses classic visual novel style for the story parts, but the n switches it up entirely once you hit the "escape rooms". In these, you're presented with more of a point-n-click style gameplay, combined with interesting puzzles and characters.

The story is absolutely amazing. Across both games. Without any spoilers, you wake up in both story, having been kidnapped and is now forced to play the potentially lethal Nonary Games together with the other victims. Who lives and dies rests heavily on your choices, so pick carefully!

This means there's also multiple ending, with one canonical "good" ending, and several "bad" endings. An additional mechanic that this game uses, is to make it so that reaching some endings isn't a "waste", as much as it will unlock the ability to go down other routes on subsequent playthroughs.

The game requires you to play it multiple times, but because some of the paths can differ so greatly, it doesn't feel like a drag. It also helps that they allow you to "Skip" things you already read, and then automatically stops when new dialogue is encountered.

Especially the second game had multiple endings that left me in tears.
A wonderful game to play on your own, and just as good to play with a friend who you like to see struggle with puzzles, haha!

Without a doubt the best "visual novel" game with gameplay segments. Some people may try to persuade you that Danganronpa is better, but those people are more interested in the murder mystery segments (which are admittedly fun), while ignoring the overall story, which Zero Escape blows out of the water.

Simply put, one of the best modern sci-fi stories ever told. And while the conclusion to the trilogy could have been better, there's just so many twists, turns and mind-melts that even just playing the first two alone would satisfy.

An astonishing achievement. Such a shame that it never did well in Japan, as that would have made for a surge of these brilliant games throughout the decade

My one complaint about this game, as someone who played 999 on its original handheld release, is that the final puzzle was changed to make it so easy that it's unbelieveable. Do I think this ruins 999? Not really. The rest of the game and its story is absolutely stunning, and will make you keep playing to see what comes next. VLR, while a bit lighter and softer a la Danganronpa (yes, really), provides us with another great story, and makes us really question what happened to set that game's storyline in motion, all the way up until the end, a truly amazing mind-screw that wholly embraces the thoughts behind both that game, and the rules of the series' universe.

This isn't the place to review ZTD, but it does very well to top off the trilogy started by these two games, and I recommend that, if you have these, you get the third, and play them all through. Although, maybe make sure it's not too dark out when you do.

[u]Zero Escape: The Nonary Games [/u]: Tout simplement une des plus belles découverte vidéo-ludique de tous les temps !

Je ne connaissais pas du tout la série des Zero Escape (999, Virtue's Last Reward, Zero Time Dilemma), n'en n'ayant entendu parler que de cette année (honte à moi!), étant tombé par hasard dessus sur Steam en utilisant la fonction "explorer".

Je ne connaissais pas très bien les jeux de type "visual novel" également.

Ces deux jeux (999, Virtue's Last Reward) sont clairement des gros coups de coeur pour moi!

[u]Tout d'abord, 999 (à faire en 1er avant VLR)[/u]:

Le jeu vous met dans le bain tout de suite: réveil dans un endroit inconnu, énigmes à résoudre, rencontres, escape game, puzzle,angoisse,découvertes,décisions...

L'histoire/narration est excellentissime, les rebondissements sont légions, vous ne serez pas au bout de vos suprises! Les thématiques abordées sont complexes, intelligentes (bien qu'hypothétiques scientifiquement parlant), mais l'inspiration est géniale!

Des choix anodins que vous ferez auront pour impact de changer l'histoire de manière importante (dans le bien ou le moins bien^^) Il vous faudra parcourir les tréfonds de 999 pour connaître la vérité/true end. 

Vos choix, bien que décisifs dans le cheminement de l'histoire que vous parcourerez, ne sont pas si irréversibles...

Les musiques sont quant à elles géniales, et collent parfaitement à l'esprit du jeu.

Bref ce premier opus vous mettra une grosse claque et vous emmenera au summum du visual novel et de la réflexion!

[u]Ensuite, Virtue's Last Reward (VLR)[/u]:

Changement graphique déjà (perso j'ai une légère préférence pour le style 999, mais on se fait rapidement à la charte graphique de VLR).

Nouveau Nonary Game, nouvelles règles, nouveaux bracelets, nouveaux fonctionnements...), pour encore plus de surprises!

VLR est plus long que son prédécesseur, plus verbeux.
J'ai trouvé les puzzles un peu plus difficiles que 999 dans l'ensemble, vous allez vous prendre la tête comme il faut sur certains!^^

Les musiques sont excellentes, à l'instar de 999.

L'histoire est également très complexe, sur fond de théorie quantique/chat de Schrödinger.
Quel excellent choix de nous emmener dans ce type de reflexion! Clairement j'ai adoré ! 
Par ailleurs, il va falloir trouver votre chemin, afin de comprendre le pourquoi du comment de toute cette histoire (accrochez-vous, la route sera encore plus longue que celle de 999!).

Dans ce second opus, vous serez étonnés, troublés, émus, et vous foncerez acheter Zero Time Dilemma à la fin de VLR!

[Tu fui, ego eris.];-)

[u]PS[/u]:
Le seul reproche que l'on pourrait faire aux deux titres concerne leur absence de localisation française (un niveau d'anglais correct est exigé, 999 et Virtue's Last Reward étant assez "verbeux").
Pour deux titres d'anthologie pareils, c'est vraiment dommage!

Cependant, moi qui ne suis pas fan de l'anglais et assez réticent à cette langue, cela ne m'a pas empêché d'aller jusqu'au bout de 999 et Virtue's Last Reward (c'est dire la qualité des deux oeuvres, qui m'auront accrochés de bout en bout!). 
Avec google trad à portée de main, on arrive à comprendre à peu près tout sans être bilingue.

Ceci dit, pour comprendre toutes les éléments scientifiques/hypothèses évoqués dans leurs moindres détails, le français serait un atout non négligeable (au moins les textes, le doublage anglais étant très bien réussi).

En résumé, si vous aimez les histoires intéressantes, intellectuellement captivantes, sur fond d'escape game/résolution d'enigmes, foncez!

Ce sont des bijoux comme on en voit peu de nos jours!

I played a lot of escape flash games in middle school so i feel like I know what I'm saying when I say these are the best of the genre. This bundle includes 999 and Virtues Last Reward. Virtue's last reward is probably the better of the two in regards to puzzle and game play but 999 has better plot and characters.
