Saw + Anime = Zero Escape

This game is like The Stanley Parable without the comedy, and with much worse writing. Seriously the writers treat you like a complete idiot and literally everything said by every character is repeated multiple times. Painfully obvious details are spelled out to you multiple times, like there being symbols next to keyholes, but then they don't even matter because as soon as you get the key you're cutscened through the characters running to the right door and opening it. Lots of dumb tangents into conspiracy theories and ESP etc. so if that's your kind of thing you might enjoy this more than I did.

I think my favorite thing about the Zero Escape games is that you have no idea what you're going to get into once you start it. Sure you got an idea of what will happen, but before long you'll find that things are more complicated than it looks. To go into those details consists speaking of spoilers, so I won't. But both games are very solid, but flawed.

The first game is 999, a remake of the DS visual novel with escape room puzzle elements. It's pretty wordy, but a complex tale about trying to escape a deadly game that goes wrong. It balances the gameplay with choices and visual novel elements pretty well as you explore the ship with an interesting cast that you'd probably see anywhere else. Being grounded in reality, it makes the bizarre pop out all the more. You don't even get to see what the game's big twist is until 75% through the game. However I feel that you first have to overcome its first impression; which if you choose certain paths is going to be 33% visual novel, 33% puzzle, and 33% sudden science lecture out of nowhere trying to seem casual but has "this is very important to the plot and its themes" in big bold letters over its smug head.

The second game, Virtue's Last Reward, manages to pace itself a little more believably, going for a longer approach and not killing you with science lectures every 5 pages of character dialogue. Its twists are placed in three different "main branches" that go off into several other branches. Meaning that one branch may not lead to the same story being told, having some of its own subplots and risks. It's highly recommended you play 999 first, as its gimick involves a major spoiler from 999. However this isn't a problem as you can play and finish 999 completely in about 8 hours or less. Virtue's Last Reward however is nearly four times the length of 999 - for better and for worse. Its puzzles are considerably more difficult and the plot is a serious escalation over 999, overall it's just more of what 999 gave. Again for better or for worse.

I think the biggest issues both games suffer from is pacing. 999 is trying to tell a complex story in a condensed format. While it provides a very interesting story, with characters you can care about (or not), the necessary science lectures do come out of nowhere. Nearly every escape room will have a lengthy pause in the middle to discuss mathmatics or some unrelated topic that might actually be important to the story later. And since you can skip around on different paths to see everything, the game doesn't drag its feet too much. At least not until the end game, where you suddenly realize that it's trying to fit 50 pages of dialogue into a single "chapter" on its flowchart.

Virtue's Last Reward is longer, considerably, and thus can pace its science out a little more (until the end where it can't help itself and it absolutely MUST EDUCATE YOU). And again, a single "chapter" on the flowchart can suddenly turn into VERY long conversations that gives a poor image of how much is actually left on that path on the flowchart. Which since there are so many paths you HAVE to take, it gets exhausting and a little demoralizing. Not to mention the game's insistance on breaking up the action with lengthy animated sequences showing your character going from one room or floor to the next - something 999 doesn't worry about in the slightest. These sequences by themselves add another half hour of gameplay time that cannot be skipped unless you have seem them previously. And on a related note, did you know that almost a quarter of Virtue's Last Reward is recycled? Like it's necessary, much like the lectures, but it's annoying to go down each path to see "oh joy, I get to spend ten minutes listening to these people talk about this person dying - again". Hint: after you've seen a scene once, you can use the Skip button by changing the text scroll mode. Skip does NOT skip dialogue you haven't heard yet, even if it's phrased slightly differently.

In terms of strengths, 999 has interesting jackasses who prove to be good friends in some way, its plot is complicated but interesting to follow with a very good "murder mystery" as well. Virtue's Last Reward has a better soundtrack, and its plot is a huge escalation, but its characters aren't as mysterious as they appear, especially compared to the first game. And given enough time (which you will have) you can find out its major twists earlier than it'll want to show them. However the pacing of its major elements is a bit better. Not to mention its puzzles which are more difficult and enjoyable as a result.

The Zero Escape collection is still a very enjoyable Visual Novel game, despite a few weirdly placed pacing issues. And for that it does get my recommendation, but you should be ready to note that you may not be as close to the end as you think for a majority of the experience.
They are both good games in terms of story.

9時間9人9の扉のみ、トゥルーエンドクリアしました。善人シボウデスは未プレイです。

レビューの中に簡単過ぎるとの意見が多いですが自身普段頭を使ってなかった為か脱出パートを苦痛無くクリア出来る様になるまで時間がかかりました。

脱出パートは予め用意されたアイテムと算数のみでクリア可能です。余計なアイテムがありません。アイテムを入手したら持った状態となり、調べる為にクリックしたのに勝手にアイテムを使用し展開が進む場面が数回ありました。個人的に脱出パートを解いても面白さも達成感も全く感じませんでした。


序盤はバッドエンドにしかいけないので途中でやめるプレイヤーが出そうで勿体ないなと思いました。エンディングまで５ルートあり周回前提のゲームなので再度同じ、脱出パートをやらされるのは作業でしかありません。先のストーリーが気になる程度にはストーリーが面白かっただけに残念です。脱出パートは性質上初見プレイでしか楽しめないです。調べず自力でクリアした方が良いかもしれません。ただトゥルーエンドの条件は分かりにくいので、ネタバレの無い攻略サイトを見るのが良さそうです。

ノベルパートと出来の悪い脱出パートが繰り返されるので物語に期待して購入すると肩透かしをくらうと思います。ストーリーだけ楽しみたい人にとって脱出パートは邪魔でしかありません。

ダンガンロンパ同様、慟哭そして…を意識して作られる感じを受けました。それと比べるとどうしても完成度は低いです。ストーリーの出来に関しても、名作EVE burst error、この世の果てで恋を唄う少女yu-no等と比べると見劣りします。

非常に好評とありますが個人的には凡作です…厳しめに評価してオススメしないにしました。ストーリーはそこそこ面白いのでPVを見てどうしても気になるなら、セール中に買いましょう。

善人シボウデスは未プレイなのでクリアしてみて評価が変わったら、追記します。

I thought Danganronpa's story was mindblowing enough, but the two games in this bundle proved me wrong.
The next and last game in the series, Zero Time Dilemma, was also a great game.
Please try out the series, I guarantee there's no game with a story so beautifully written like this.

剧情非常精彩引人入胜，使用的诡计也让人拍案叫绝，各个结局的联系环环相扣。
  此外作为解密游戏，999的密室解密难度适中，恰合剧情发展。但是善人死亡的密室就不怎么样，与剧情衔接不大就算了，关键是有些谜题的解法毫无提示，或者是知道了解法也是无从下手（说的就是那个坑爹的推冰块），玩到后期看到那些谜题就头晕想吐。
  不过善人死亡的系统比999有改善，不过善人死亡过场跑地图实在是恶心，还不能跳过。
  整个故事中女主的动机实在让人无法理解，999中策划的九人游戏大部分结局都是男主或自己死亡，还要加上自己的亲朋好友。因为女主能策划九人游戏就证明女主活了下来，而整个极限脱出世界观的各个历史都是平行世界，也就是说女主活下来后为了拯救平行世界的自己，搞了一个有极大可能让自己和自己最重要的人死光光的局，而且女主通过自己的超能力是完全知道这一点的。如果说999中的女主这么圣母是为了报答平行世界另一个无私的自己，而且确实有一个皆大欢喜的结局。但是善人死亡的女主就是圣母到脑子有问题了，为了拯救平行世界，她牺牲了自己一生的幸福和自己的生命，并且把自己的朋友和恋人整的死去活来，结果自己的世界仍然是悲剧。尼玛龙珠中的特兰克斯穿越是为了找到人造人的弱点来拯救自己的世界，算是一种互惠互利，而女主是牺牲自己的来拯救其他世界，这是一种什么样的精神。
  最后我很想知道善人死亡里面其他人是不是早就知道男主的真面目了，要不为什么男主要逃走其他人跟见了杀父仇人一样拼了命拦着他，而其他人背叛跑路其他人就放水让他跑。
吐槽完毕，以上就是这两款好游戏的瑕疵，也算是爱之深责之切吧。
999 Is utterly amazing and stunning.

Two of the very best games (bundled up in one awesome bundle) that I've played in a long time. Mind you, I'm not a huge fan of visual novels and I (gasp!) don't really even care for story that much when I am playing a game but Zero Escape: The Nonary Games had me on the edge of my freaking seat the entire time while playing it. The surprises, the atmosphere, the characters, the locations, the wicked twists and turns. Everything just worked so damn well together. I blew my mind how both parts of the Nonary Games formed a bigger, complex narrative and had so many elements connecting the two stories. 

I could have done without the escape rooms though. There is a great explanation for them being there but to me it still felt a little bit tacked on. I also didn't care (at all) for the dreadful, maddening transition screens. And how I wish I would have known how to skip entire parts of the story that I'd already played before ending the game (spoiler alert: there is a button for that, don't be dumb like me and look it up!). But man, this was just an excellent, completely satisfying experience overall. 

If you like you like your games experimental, if you love visual novels, adventure games or are looking for a story that really draws you in, do yourself a favor and go get this! 9/10

It's so god damn good.
I just...cannot emphesise how much I recommend this. It is a game that requires you to solve puzzles, yes, but it is also so much more. You'll see when you get to the end.

I Looooooove these games.  Pick them up if you like puzzles and weirdness.

Virtue's Last Reward is the best one, in my opinion.
999 is pretty good too, as it's carried over some of the quality of life features from VLR. It's hard for me to say if 999 is better on DS or better here, because some of the changes on the Steam version are not as good as the original. But since the QoL stuff really helps the gameplay I guess I'll call it a wash. Regardless, if you're new to the series, it makes sense to start at the beginning.

For a review of Zero Time Dilemma, read here: http://tap-repeatedly.com/2016/07/zero-escape-zero-time-dilemma/
Just play it. It's amazing.

I only played 999 as I didn't enjoy it enough to play VLR.

999 has a concept similar to great sci-fi films like Cube. You take a bunch of people, lock them in a place and see what happens. With Cube you get an amazing character piece. I was hoping 999 would deliver the same, but with the puzzle solving and choice & consequence that a game can deliver.

The problem with 999 is it's a visual novel with bad writing. Like, really bad. The characters are flat and uninteresting. You don't learn much of significance about any of them until very late on, which means there's little to fuel any drama, tension, or suspicion. Characters will just dump exposition on you out of nowhere. It makes a mockery of the tension the time limit is supposed to bring when not one character in the game seems to be in a hurry.

But it's not just the characters, it's the general narrative. The game loves to make everything take twice as long as necessary, and the text was in desperate need of an editor. It will constantly reexplain the digital root concept, showing you the workings of tough equations like 2+3+5 to ensure that no one is left behind. Characters will regularly repeat what someone said back at them as a question. More than once someone explained something, then explained the same thing again in the next line in a slightly different way.

You have a number of different endings, which you need to work through to unlock the true ending. But they feel arbitrary and pointless. They don't develop your understanding of anything or anyone, and you have no real opportunity to even see them coming. A quick Google reveals that a lot of people were as confused as me about what even happens in one of them.

But you push through all this because the puzzles are OK and you want to try and figure out who Zero is. Unfortunately you're doomed because the game will suddenly dump a huge narrative turd on you and change the rules of the game out of nowhere. I was looking forward to seeing how it all fit together, and then it decides to redefine even its already pretty out there ruleset to make its own narrative work.

I can't really recommend this as it's not a strong puzzle game, and the great scenario is ruined by terrible writing and underdeveloped characters. It's also burdened with some of the fanservice elements to be expected from this style of Japanese narrative game. The true ending isn't worth the slog and is really a giant mess.
Why did you make me so attached?

I started with the Zero Escape Series in 2016 and played the whole series on my 3DS.
'Til today, there was almost no day, where this game didn't cross my mind in any way. 
The characters, the story, the emotions, the music, the puzzles. Everything is this game is so memorable and I truly think that this game is one of a few, which i will remember many many years to come and I can say from my heart, try this game for yourself. If you can get into it and take your time wih this game, it will be an experience you won't forget.

What you get here is:
- A twisted, interconnected and deep Story where every little detail matters and everything has a purpose. 
- Fleshed out and interesting characters (i've never seen such a long wiki summary of video game characters before)
- "Escape Rooms" are the main puzzle sections you have to solve, each time with different settings and all kinds of different puzzle elements, mathematical, logical and sometimes even something special, which will surprise you.
- There are puzzles outside of these escape rooms. These are the most interesting ones in my opinion, where you need to concentrate on the things, the characters say or get hints from your enviroment.
- The details about the mystery. This game gives so much little details and subtile hints for you to solve the great mysteries. In my first playthrough I made like 20-30 pictures of (for myself) important text lines, connected the dots together and thus got a better understanding of the whole plot, before it was explained later on. It's not a mystery, which gets thrown at you out of nowhere, it all makes sense and can be figuered out if you really think about the details. I highly recommend to focus on the game, if you play it and not getting distracted, while you're on it!
- Virtues Last Reward's "Trust or Betray"-Game really gets you involved with all the other characters on a level, i've never experienced before towards fictional characters and it's of the highlights in the Second Zero Escape Game.
- Many interesting scientific and philosiphic topics will be discussed in this Series. Stuff, which will get you to think.
- It's a matter of taste, but the Soundtrack is phenomenal! Situation-fitting and many memorable songs you get here. I get goosebumps listening to the Soundtrack.

Are there cons? Yes, the game isn't perfect, but most things got better with this remastered version.

- You have to replay some sections to progress in the story. You can jump to any point in the story, that you have played before and can fast forward the text, but sometimes, it still takes long and can get annoying. So be prepared for it. It won't happen to often, but unfortunately, it's required.
- Some puzzles are just too difficult to figure out, just because it isn't explained properly in the game, i mean, the basics of the puzzle itself, so you have to trial and error until you figure it out. It rarely happens, but if it happens, you will get stuck for a while. Don't be ashamed to use a guide for some sections There are puzzles, i don't even know how to figure out, even after watching a guide. 
But most puzzles are clear, what you have to do, so please, i don't want to scare you off :D
- You've got a ingame "memory board" where you can draw stuff on it, which you want to remember. But it's too little space and really not working too well, for such an important feature. 
I highly recommend, having a camera and/or pen&paper while playing this game, otherwise it will get pretty hard to beat, because you have to remember so much stuff at times!

Other than that, I can't remember anything else, which annoyed me or was kinda inconvenient.

I really hope, I got you interested in this game and if you want to buy it, i wish you the same experience, that i've had on my first playthrough!

Virtue's last reward - это самая продуманная, глубокая и полная неожиданностей визуальная новела, в какие я только играл. Не смотря на огромное количество бэктрекинга и получения концовок в стиле to be continued... это гениальная игра. советую всем центелям жанра. 10/10
神作！但是善人死亡要是能删减三分之一的剧情对话就好了（像999一样精炼一点）

These couple games are real odd ducks for me. Introduced to me via NicoB, there was nothing in the Let's Plays (besides his personality, of course) to really suck me into the stories, at least starting with 999. But then I picked up ALL Spike Chunsoft had to offer with Steins;Gate and Zero Escape during a big sale they had, being a big fan of their Danganronpa franchise. So, I started them for myself.

This bundle contain the first two games of the series, 999 [9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors] and Virtue's Last Reward. 

There is a lot to appreciate here, but for story and gameplay. While mostly a visual novel, there are fairly complex Escape Room puzzles throughout, puzzles which I really appreciate. I feel like they got significantly more difficult in the second game, but that could just be my brain juices running on empty playing these games back to back.  I also appreciate the branchiing paths, all accessable through a timeline flowchart (something Steins;Gate could have made use of in my opinion, if only to help me follow the worldlines easier, but excellent here nevertheless) which is also integrated pretty deeply into the story in a way which I adore. 

However... the story has indeed lost me on some points. I've grown to enjoy all of the characters, but the plot itself is so busy it's hard to process it all. 999 was fairly straightforward and, even with the timeline plot in the mix, I didn't feel overwhelmed. VLR on the other hand not only had more difficult puzzles I needed to look up sometimes, but the story itself goes through so many time jumps, so many [spoiler]shifts in both time and a person's body having a consciousness from either the future or the past[/spoiler], that it became difficult to fully understand what the ending was trying to do. 

I believe my lingering questions will be answered in the next game in the series, Zero Time Dilemma. Until then I can at least say that I really enjoyed the ride all the same.

(This is a 999 review)

Ostensibly an escape room game, 999 is more accurately described as a visual novel with point-and-click adventure game mechanics peppered throughout. The main difference with other traditional point-and-click games is that 999 is mostly on rails, with little to no room for exploration or backtracking. There is a lot of branching though, as you'll be prompted to make decisions that affect where characters go and therefore what events unfold in your playthrough. 

Unlike Spike's Danganronpa games, 999 does have multiple endings and multiple ways to reach different story resolutions. However, as is usually the case with games with this kind of progression, this means that there is only one true ending that is considered canon, while the rest are all just bad endings that end the story prematurely. In order to get the true ending, you are required to first get all other endings. This sounds bad on paper but it's actually pretty rewarding since every ending has a piece of information about the plot that is crucial to understand the bigger picture. 

The plot itself is pretty good, if a bit straightforward. There's the usual twists and turns that all good mystery games have, but the real meat of the game is in the characters. Unlike Danganronpa, there isn't an immediately present murder threat that is constantly biting away at the relationships, and nor are there easy identifiers such as 'Ultimate' traits. Instead, all characters are pretty much enigmas, and seemingly unrelated to all that is going on. Their visual design is not nearly as polished as what Spike would put out later on, but it gets the job done in terms of fleshing out their personalities and traits. I'd say I enjoyed what this game does with its characters quite a lot, with the possible exception of a couple ones which I thought were short-changed. That's 7 out of 9 characters done right though, so it's still a big win.

The meat of the game is in the escape room puzzles. At least, that's what the marketing tells me. While there are indeed some fine puzzles in there, to me it always felt like the game dragged whenever I had to stop and solve an entire room (or even two rooms) before the story could progress. I know it sounds like a weird complaint, since it is that gameplay that you're paying for (mostly), but I found the game was a lot more enjoyable whenever the plot developed, and when you had to make choices that affected the characters. This problem gets compounded much more when you're going back to get all the endings, since you'll most certainly be doing the same puzzles two or maybe three times over. The game should really give you an option to skip puzzle rooms you've already completed, just for convenience sake. I can definitely see many people not wanting to deal with the slog required to get the true ending (which is pretty great, all things considered).

All in all, a solid mystery game guaranteed to engage you, but maybe also annoy you a bit. If nothing else, you'll come away an expert at calculating digital roots. That's worth at least $20.

This is absolute gold. The premise is a little weak, but the actual story more than makes up for it. If your old like me, you remember the movie Titanic, with Leo and Kate Winslet, now take that movie and smash it up with DanganRonpa. And you have the Nonary Game.

This is a spoiler-free review.

This game is actually two Nintendo DS games that have been ported to PC: 999 (Nine Hours Nine Persons Nine Doors) and its sequel, Virtue's Last Reward.

The games are basically the anime version of Saw - you've been caught by a mysterious person named "Zero" and forced to play in a death game.  Your wristwatch is rigged to kill you if you fail to escape in time, and you'll have to solve several fiendish puzzles in order to meet your goal.  Adding to your problem is that you've been trapped with several other people - can you afford to trust them?

The game is split up into chunks.  There are "story" portions that play out like a visual novel, where you make choices about where to go and who to team up with, and "escape" portions where the emphasis is on solving puzzles.  Both parts are pretty well-done: the stories are dramatic, the characters interesting, and the puzzles delightful.  But there is one thing that may be a drag for some people which is that the games are structured more like VNs - and that includes "multiple ending syndrome."

Essentially there are many routes that the story can take, but sometimes endings are locked and require you to get ANOTHER ending to unlock them.  This means that you have to make multiple playthroughs no matter what.  It's good because it gives you ample reasons to try out the different choices, but sometimes it can get frustrating to go so far and only wind up dead for your troubles.  Thankfully the game allows you to rewind to various points in time once an ending is reached, and you can skip over text you've seen before, but some people will find this more tedious than enjoyable.  Consider this a warning in that regard.

Otherwise, the plot is dense and enjoyable, though it requires some massive suspension of disbelief to work at points, and the endings sometimes feel a bit ridiculous (one in 999 in particular has the MC make a ridiculous logical leap).  That having been said, the premise itself is ridiculous, so you may want to go into this series more for what it represents (a good pair of tense puzzlers) rather than for any semblance of realism. The puzzles themselves are very fun, though I would issue a warning here as well: many of them in 999 involve math, so you'll want a pen and paper handy if you're bad at doing math mentally.  Also be prepared to click literally everything when you're stumped to try and find a clue, as is the great puzzle game tradition.

Overall, these games have been a blast to play.  There are some issues with this being a port for a pair of DS games (the control scheme is awkward, and camera movement in Virtue's Last Reward is wonky at best) but overall I've enjoyed this series immensely.  Buy this if you have any interest in a dramatic puzzle game.

PS: In 999, the art is all 2D, but in Virtue's Last Reward it swaps to 3D rendered models, which can be a bit jarring at first.

-------- ESTA RESEÑA NO CONTIENE SPOILERS ----------

The Nonary Games son una serie de juegos tipo novela visual que se mezclan con un estilo de gameplay donde tu función es escapar de una habitación cerrada buscando pistas y resolviendo puzzles que te permitan abrir la puerta de turno.
Las escenas de NV consisten en hablar con los personajes y resolver el misterio de Zero (el antagonista) y el juego "macabro" que les obliga a jugar. Narrativamente es excelente, y aunque puedas imaginarte quien es Zero aún así te va a sorprender el como y el porque hace lo que hace gracias a los plot twist al final del juego. 
Los demás personajes son variados y entretenidos y si bien no se ahondan tanto en sus personalidades y sus pasados como en Danganronpa (una saga similar creado por la misma compañia) todos cumplen su papel en la trama, nadie esta ahí porque si, y todos están involucrados de una u otra forma con lo que sucede.
La otra parte del juego, los puzzles que tienes que resolver para escapar, si bien me parecen excelentes, podrían alejar a mas de uno porque necesitas pensarle un poco, especialmente porque varios de ellos son numéricos. Aunque bueno, hoy en día está el internet y puedes buscar la solución a cualquier puzzle con solo googlear un poco.
El primer juego se ve gráficamente muy bien gracias al estilo artístico que usa en 2D, pero el segundo juego usa muchos graficos 3D que ya se ven algo viejos para los estándares de hoy en día.

Personalmente el primer juego se me hace excelente y su trama es casi perfecta, y el giro argumental aún siendo una obra de ficción sientes que es algo que podría pasar en la vida real. Pero el segundo juego debo decir que me decepcionó, siento que se pasaron con los giros argumentales y varios de ellos se sienten forzados o incluso "fantasiosos", además me deprime este juego, no por la trama ni nada, si no porque siento que trata mal a los personajes que regresan del primer juego. No es mal juego, pero el primero se me hace mucho mejor que el segundo por lo menos en cuanto a trama y desarrollo de personajes.

Por cierto, ambos juegos solo están en inglés lo cual podría ser un problema para los que no lo dominen porque hay mucho texto además de que las explicaciones de algunos puzzles necesitan entenderse para poder resolverlos.

I've only completed 999 so far, yet this package already feels totally worth it. (To be fair, I did get it at 40% off.)

999 appeals to me as a fan of puzzle games, point-and-click adventures, and narrative-focused games. It has numerous enjoyable escape rooms, and an intricate puzzlebox narrative that kept me guessing the possibilities behind its mysteries. I feel like the designers understand the aesthetics of "science" and puzzles, and how they can be fun.

It is a relatively "light" game -- it doesn't take itself super seriously, and the escape rooms aren't too difficult nor complex (especially if you're familiar with some basic puzzles) -- but it is a light game that is simply satisfying to get through. It's a bit of a bummer that most of the puzzles are basic abstract puzzles, though I guess they kiiinda thematically make sense.

Side note, this remaster/PC port makes a few awkward technical compromises. They are thankfully not too distracting, and the improvements totally make up for it 👍
Also PPS the English translation is pretty good, props to Aksys

One of my childhood FAVS for DS translated into a beautiful PC landscape and currently on sale. I couldn't say no. Also let me breakdown how amazing this installment is and only for 999:

PROS:
- You're getting a game and its sequel. TWO games and stories with crazy flowcharts, puzzles, and multiple endings
- The puzzles are neither so easy that you finish them in half a minute nor so hard that you spend over one hour mulling over how to beat them
- The voiceacting for both the English and the Japanese is on point and immersive in either language
- THE PLOT TWISTS >>> even though you pick up bits and pieces from every ending; only the true ending will give you the full details of what's happening in enough depth for you to connect the pieces
- The relationships between the characters feel real for the situation
- Honestly perfect for mystery and escape room enthusiats AND makes it hard for me to pick whether to play DGR or one of these installments.

CONS:
- Music and visiuals aren't the best, but let me restate this one fact: THIS WAS BASED OFF A DS GAME. For the most part they really only added extra story and revamped the drawings, they didn't change the style - so it might seem out of date, but it's timeless to me (I still love it and I love to be biased)
- I finished it too quickly. I became immersed and a coach potato for this game

****Now take everything I just typed and get rid of the cons and times it by like 5 and you get how amazing VLR is!!!

BUY IT WHILE IT'S ON SALE BECAUSE YOU WANT THIS GAME (MOST LIKELY).

This is a game that I can play over & over and still feel like the game played with me instead.
11/10 recommended

These games were very fun and interesting to play! I loved the combination of real life facts and myths with fiction in the game, since it added a sense of realness to the game. The characters are all really interesting, as they are realistic enough to be interesting but exaggerated enough to be interesting. The story is really good and definitely kept me interested. I'd definitely recommend this game if you enjoy story based/puzzle games with minimal gameplay

[h1] 終盤のどんでん返しに驚愕せよ[/h1] 

昔、Ever17というノベルゲームがあって、私は今でも傑作だと思っているのだが、そのシナリオを担当した打越鋼太郎氏の作品である。

氏の作品は、
大げさなほどの舞台設定、
そこに集うユニークなキャラクター、
進むほどに深まる謎、
極限の危機と緊張感、
合間に挿入される奇怪な科学談義で構成されており、
そしてそれらの全てが集束する終盤のどんでん返しでプレイヤーを驚愕の渦に叩き込み、
そこから全ての伏線とトリックが怒涛の如くつまびらかにされていく、
そういう作品である。（全部ではないが）

様々なゲームのストーリーを追っていくとき、いい話だなぁと幸せな気持ちになったり、血の沸くような展開にワクワクしたりすることはそれなりにあるが、ディスプレイの前で「えぇぇーーっ！？　そういうことなのーーっっ！？」と絶叫する体験はレアだ。あまりない。数えるほどしかない。
そういうふうに、爽快に騙されたい方は、このシリーズをやるとよい。

作品自体はZERO ESCAPEシリーズと銘打たれた3部作になっていて、

１．極限脱出 9時間9人9の扉
２．極限脱出ADV 善人シボウデス
３．ZERO ESCAPE 刻のジレンマ

で構成されいてる。
特に2作目をラストまでやると3作目をやりたくなるようなシナリオになっており、セットが安ければ最初から3部作をそろえることをお勧めする。
なお、前情報を調べない方がいいタイプの内容である。特に2作目をクリアするまで3作目の「ZERO ESCAPE 刻のジレンマ」は公式ページにさえ行かない方が良い。SteamのPVを見るのはよいが、公式ページのキャラクター紹介がすでに1～2作目のネタバレになっており危険である。

舞台はPVにある通り、3作ともが極限のデスゲームだ。
だれかの死、殺し合いを前提にした緊張感の絶えないストーリーが展開される。
ゲーム自体はアドベンチャーパートと、脱出ゲームパートが交互に現れる構成になっており、3作ともマルチエンディングの形式をとっている。
そしてSF。サイエンスフィクションである。
私は、SFとは「抗いがたい世界と科学に翻弄されもがく人間を描くもの」だと勝手に思っているのだが、まさにこれはそれである。極限まで追い詰められた登場人物たちが何をしでかすのかが描かれる。
時に醜い、異常な行動さえ現れる。
だが、世界がどれだけ抗いがたく、それにどれだけ翻弄されたとしても、最後に物語を進めるのは人間の意志だ。そういう物語と人間を見るのが私は好きである。
そういうのが好きな方にお勧めしたい。

────
蛇足だが、一応悪いことも言っておく。
まず絵。1作目はキャラクターがアニメで絵が描かれているので9年前の作品なのにあまり古くは感じないのだが、2作目から3DCGを採用しており、これが現代のクオリティから見るとかなり古臭く感じる。なお3作目は格段に改善しており問題は感じない。
表現。3作目はゴア表現が厳しい。CEROで17歳以上と付いているとはいえ、3DSなんてコンシューマー機で出ていた意味が分からないレベルである。ヤバい。
操作性。携帯機器のベタ移植といった感じのUIであり、キーコンフィグができない、スキップがもたつくなどの問題がある。これも3作目はそこそこ改善されている。
シナリオ。極限まで整合性が取れていないと興ざめしてしまう人には向いてない。たぶん粗はある。多少のことはエンターテイメントだと割り切った方が楽しい。
以上、一応だがご留意いただきたい。

『9時間9人9の扉』のみプレイしました。

ゲームは探索を行うアドベンチャーパートと、ストーリーが進行するノベルパートに分かれます。
自分を含めた9人のキャラクターたちにはそれぞれ一つ数字が割り振られ、9つの数字を駆使して扉を開き、ゲームから脱出を試みるというシナリオ。

自分がプレイしたのは1週目の8割くらいの地点でエンディングまでいけませんでした。
悲しいくらい謎解きがつまらなくて、頭を使うシーンがありません。順番に調べればいい小中学生でも解けるというか、「解く」という感覚がないです。
また、個性を出そうと服装や設定には工夫を感じるものの、魅力的なキャラクターがいないのも残念。
ゲーム進行で最も興を削いだのは、おそらくこのゲームのオチに繋げるつもりであろう強引な知識共有（数字根は…。昔の文献では…。古代なんとかでは…。）というフラグというにはあまりに不自然なキャラクターの長話。真面目に聞いていても直後にその知識を使って謎解きを行うわけでもなく「何だったの今の？」という感じで非常に疲れる。
長話が多いのに、フルボイスなので待ち時間に耐えきれず喋っている途中でスキップしてしまう。話が面白ければ聞けるんですが、声優さんに申し訳ない気分にもなる。

また、脱出の謎解きもなければ、推理要素がないのも致命的。
「あの人だったら、あの犯行ができた」みたいな要素が全員に当てはまるため、予想し甲斐がなく、私は「もうこれ誰が犯人でもいいよ」となってしまった。
謎解きもノベルも作業と化してしまい、ゲームを進行するモチベーションがなくなってしまったため中断。
非常にがっかりしてしまい『善人シボウデス』についてもプレイする元気が出ません。
買おうとしている友人が居たら止めます。

999 aka Zero Escape One aka Disney's Saw The Movie The Anime The Musical On Ice aka  Escape 0.0 You Can (Not) Escape is the first game in this bundle. It's whatever.

Seriously, after having spent something stupid like 200 hours on Umineko way back in the day, the pseudoscience aspect of 999 really grated on my nerves and felt almost forced, like if Kotaro read Umineko too (he did) and wanted to do something similar but was really stumped for ideas. Hell, one of the pseudoscientific setups doesn't even have a payoff! Not even into the second game! I don't know, that shіt really annoyed me and I couldn't shake it through the entire playthrough. It had a pretty good twist going for it in the end. Get used to twists if you get these games, and get ready to ~theorize~

The characters were fine, I can't say I was really in love with any of them. The big oaf going by the name of Seven is probably my favourite character. He's a dork. Also the first in a long line of amnesiacs for this series (who also tend to be some of, if not the, strongest characters in their respective games). Other than Seven I guess I liked Ace for second place, he's a really swell guy. The protagonist comes in third, and he really shines toward the end.

The soundtrack for 999 is fantastic, Shinji Hosoe fuсking killed it. Really good emotive music. I'm not a composer so I don't know the proper terms for this stuff but when the score wanted me to feel tense, it made me feel tense. When it wanted my hair to stand up, it made my hair stand up. Very good at putting you into the proper mood that the scene is calling for. He makes great usage of noise and experimental clipping/popping in the sounds, and I love shіt like that.

The art is passable. I've seen better art and I've seen worse art. The character designs are all over the fuсking place, as is the case with the state of weeb trash in the new millennium. You have this gravity defying half naked milf in your crew and you KNOW she's on the verge of needing spine support rod, and I think she MAYBE gets one or two passing comments on her appearance, while I'm sitting here going "uhhh so nobody's gonna bring it up huh?" You can tell that it started on an underpowered overambitious handheld console, there's animation but only a few frames worth, and the sprites themselves are weirdly detailed. Thank god it isn't ZTD. The setting takes place entirely on a big passenger cruise ship so it has a bunch of weird shіt like captain's quarters and lifeboats and junk. I found it to be a pretty boring setting but it passes for a realistic enough boat if you're into that sort of thing.

The gameplay, for me, was the weakest aspect. It got to the point where the puzzle sections were interrupting the plot sections and not for the better. When I'm going to a guide to get the stupid escapes over with so I can get back to reading, that's when you know there's a problem. I'm not exactly sure whether it's genuinely poor gameplay design or if this room escape puzzle stuff just isn't for me. Probably the latter. In the game's defense, there are plot reasons for the rooms to be there at all in the first place, plot reasons that go beyond "hey you've been kidnapped you gotta get out!", so I guess I'll give it that.

999 has this absolutely fuсking awful, unintuitive gimmicky plotline flowchart that makes you go down specific routes in order to reach endings with weird confusing icons on the plot "map" that will take a guide to figure out what to do with it and I absolutely hated dealing with it. Be warned.

999 gets 69/420, simplified into a solid Sherry Jenix 7. You really should read it to prepare for the next game in the bundle, and imo the real reason to buy this bundle at all.




Virtue's Last Reward aka Time Travel 2 Electric Boogaloo aka Air Purification Simulation aka If I See That Fuсking Rabbit One More Time is the second game in this bundle. It is by far the superior game of the two you can buy here.

The story picks up a year after the events of the first game, 999. You follow a 22 year old PhD hopeful named Sigma as he tries to figure out why his car is busted. It is readily apparent that Kotaro turned it up for the writing in this one. The pseudoscience I complained about in the 999 section is still here, but it is toned way down and/or mixed in with sufficiently plausible "real" science that it didn't bother me. Remember how I mentioned Umineko earlier (which you should also totally go spend 3 months to read)? Yeah, get ready for a (really basic) crash course in quantum physics principles like Schrodinger's cat, and mystery novelist laws like Knox's Laws. Did I mention Kotaro had read Umineko? Have I mentioned that you should read Umineko?

The characters are also way better in VLR compared to 999. For one, the protagonist is an endearing goofball dorm cutie. Sigma just oozes Joe Everyman. The quips you think would be appropriate in the situation? He's gonna make them. The questions you think you'd ask in that situation? He's gonna ask them. The moral dilemmas you think you'd face when doing what he's doing? He'll mull over them. The reactions to getting unexpectedly bamboozled by people when you think you know what they're going to do that you start cursing at the screen as it happens? Yeah dude he knows exactly what you're saying and he's gonna say it too. Sigma is the perfect husbando for this story and the quality of his writing really made me enjoy this VN a lot.

The rest of the characters are also stronger across the board than the ones in 999. You're going to hate one for the entire length of the game, I GUARANTEE IT. You're going to recognize one who now dresses like a thot, and you're going to think you recognize another who also dresses like a thot. And above all, you're going to want to protect one. Protect Phi with all you have. Never betray Phi.

The soundtrack for VLR is superior in every way to 999. Again I'm no composer so I don't know the terminology, but there's remixes? Remasters? Remakes? of the tracks heard in 999, with higher quality and subtle changes, such as extended sections, condensed sections of other songs keeping the signature sound (hook? chorus?) of that song and cutting the unnecessary fat... It's great enough that I found the soundtrack and have given it listens outside the game itself, which doesn't usually happen. It does even better with setting the moods than even 999 did, and the soundtrack was the strongest part of 999.

The art in VLR shifted from the 2D anime sprites of 999 to mid-tier quality 3D models with about as much animation as before, which is to say a few frames worth. Those few frames are pretty emotive though. One guy is in a mask the entire game and sometimes his eyes turn into crescent moons when he's having a giggle, and that was pretty endearing to me. The designs are, again, all over the place, except a little more toned down this time around. You have two thots dressing like a cavewoman ready to breed, and some Egyptian cosplay LITERALLY CONSTANTLY on the verge of a wardrobe malfunction (she lays down a couple of times and I swear you should be able to see some teets at the angle you're looking), you have a circus troupe leader, and you have the Tin Man. The rest are actually pretty normal, though Sigma looks like he's dressed to be a mechanic, which is weird because he's absolute trash at fixing his car.

The setting is way more interesting this time, taking place in a giant facility with a bunch of industrial and modern motifs, with a couple post-modern ones thrown in too because why the hell not. I can't say anything else about this because that is spoilers.

The gameplay was still the weakest part of VLR, the same as 999. Stuff was better this time around but I still didn't care. There's still plot reasons for having them so that's cool.

Долго, слишком долго я откладывал прохождение первых двух частей Zero Escape! После прохождения третьей части я всё ждал и надеялся на скорый выход перевода первых двух частей, но так и не смог дождаться и решил пройти на английском. Изначально я думал что это затея быстро выгорит и я снова отложу первые две части на неопределённый срок, но этого не случилось. В самом же начале я уже был неслабо так вовлечён в историю, что в итоге переросло в своеобразный марафон, из-за которого про остальные игры я крайне редко вспоминал. Под конец даже не удержался и устроил себе финальный заход на 8 часов вместо сна! Это при том что я уже давненько понял как Котаро Учикоши выстраивает свои истории, но всё равно они мне очень нравятся и я продолжу всем советовать его работы!
If you value story in a game at all this is for you

Dvě výborné příběhové hry za cenu jedné. Myslel jsem si, že to bude něco jako filmová série Saw, ale mýlil jsem se. Je to o dost lepší. Devět lidí je uneseno a musí řešit hádanky a dostat se k východu. Očekávejte hromadu voleb, které větví příběh a díky tomu nabízí oba dva tituly hodně konců. Díky zabudované mapě, kdy vidíte postup hrou, můžete přeskakovat a volit jiná rozhodnutí, čímž odkryjete další skutečnosti a pozadí postav a právě díky této unikátní funkci si můžete odemknout další konce, z nichž je pouze jeden ten správný.

Jednička je kratší, nabízí kolem 13 hodin. Příběh je takový uzavřenější a postavy jsou všechny v pohodě. U dvojky se herní doba natáhla na 30 hodin, což se bohužel negativně projevilo v tom, že se hraní může zdát místy i nudné, když procházíte podobnou dějovou linkou. Naštěstí již viděné dialogy jdou přeskočit, takže aspoň, že tak. Dvě ženské postavy mě tu dost štvaly, ale příběh je komplexnější, hlavní hrdina je více zajímavý a jednotlivé konce jsou díly do skládačky jménem příběh. Hra končí dost otevřeně, takže nezbývá, než si poté pořídit ještě závěr trilogie, který by měl objasnit vše a uzavřít tak celý děj.

U dvojky mi ještě vadila změna u grafické stylizace, která byla taková amatérská, ale zvyknete si na to po čase. Na co jsem si ale nezvykl, bylo neustálé cestování, které nešlo nijak zrychlit a furt čumět na mapu a vidět pohybující se tečky, to je něco, co člověka po pár viděních otráví. Jenže příběh je opravdu dost propracovaný, zvraty jsou mnohdy nečekané a postupné odkrývání jednotlivých střípků příběhu a dávání si informací dohromady, to je něco, co jsem snad nikde jinde neviděl tak dobře zpracované. K tomu si připočtěte parádní hudbu a pokud vám jde hlavně o nervydrásající příběh, kdy vám nevadí prvky scifi, rozhodně popřemýšlejte o tomhle balíčku.

PS: Kdo na konci ani jednoho z těchto dvou dílů neuroní ani jednu slzu není snad člověk, ale robot... :D

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games consists of the first two games in the Zero Escape series.
9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors, originally for the Nintendo DS, and Virtue's Last Reward, originally for the 3DS and PS Vita, in an updated PC rerelease.

The basic gameplay of the series is split into two parts: Visual Novel and Room Escape. Room Escape segments have occasional VN portions to them, advancing the plot as you interact with your partners in each room. In each game, players are trapped in an unknown location, desperately searching for a way out. They learn early on that they are part of a larger game, in which they must work together to open the final door.

Each game has multiple endings, and some endings require you to have completed other endings. The original 999 had a fast-forward option that let you skim through visual novel segments that you've already seen. The Nonary Games versions of 999 and VLR have replaced this with a storyline diagram that lets you jump from any point in the story to any other branch you've unlocked.  Don't like the results of a choice you made? You can jump back to the choice and see the alternate timeline immediately without having to sit through all prior choices.

This makes the game a LOT faster, and helps keep interest up as you explore branching timelines, trying to find the one where everything works out.

999 has updated high-definition art for the rerelease. Having never played the original Virtue's Last Reward, I can't say if that, too, has been improved in any way, but the replacement of hand-painted full-color manga-style art with 3D models allows for more animation but cuts back a little on the character of the game in my opinion.

The games are fun, although, as combination visual novels/room escapes, once you've seen the (fairly numerous) endings, you've pretty much seen everything the game has to offer, limiting replay value.

If you like story-driven games and room escape puzzles, you should love these.
んまあそう・・・よくわかんなかったです

J'ai acheté ce jeu car fan de la série des Danganronpa.

Ces jeux valent clairement jusqu'au moindre centime ce qu'ils m'ont coûté. Les énigmes (escape rooms) sont très bien réalisées, et s'intègrent bien à l'histoire.

L'histoire, en ce qui la concerne, est juste exceptionnelle. Elle permet de lier tous ces éléments ensemble, et d'en faire un ensemble commun. Elle s'appuie également sur des théories scientifiques existantes, ce qui donne ce dernier élément de crédibilité qui rend l'ensemble cohérent.

En bref: Si vous cherchez un jeu avec un histoire complexe mais qui vous tiendra en haleine, ce jeu vaut clairement le coup. A notez que vous voudrez probablement faire le 3e volet de la trilogie (Zero Time Dilemna) un efois ces deux là finis.
I still believe this is one of the greatest VN ever created.

5/5

直接买steam没玩过NDS的新粉，33小时通过999全部结局。以下感想：

剧情非常好，4.5/5。果然是ever17的编剧…这节奏，这心理描写，这时不时插入的神话传说，这未来科技感，除了立绘换了个画风，而且这次的知识点我都没有听说过了（因为那个比较老…这个知识点比较新吧）之外，其他的和ever7一模一样啊。玩下来感觉要比EVER7爽一点，可能是节奏稍微好了一些？[spoiler]不过诡计似乎没有那个惊艳……[/spoiler]

人物塑造也不错，4/5。唯一不太满意的就是女主角的塑造……也不能说不好，两个人的感情其实也蛮感人，就是女主太花瓶了…这么多年了，编剧你对女性的塑造一点进步都没有啊喂！！完全赶不上男性的塑造啊！到底是有多喜欢这种大和抚子类的完美人设的角色啊！一点意思都没有啊！明明兄妹情塑造得那么好！我敢赌十包辣条这编剧绝对是个男的！！而且估计还是没有什么女性经验不咋受欢迎那种！而且不知道是不是我太敏感了，就游戏都能看出来日本女性地位不行啊，连个长得不好看的女性角色都不敢画吗？明明男性有各种各样的类型的！[spoiler]你看看やしろ那胸那身材那颜值，哪点像个バーさん啊喂！[/spoiler]
其他人的塑造都不错，性格多样也比较立体。[spoiler]金库结局都给我看懵了……这兄妹情好感人。另外哥哥太帅了！！！[/spoiler]

解谜几乎完美，5/5.类型丰富，难度适中，几乎像是真的在玩密室逃脱。像我这种对解密类不太感兴趣的都玩得很开心……[spoiler]不过最后一关算了一下时间，没有在5分钟内解出来！あかね对不起！！[/spoiler]

其他。没有查声优是谁，但是配得很不错，到最后感情很带入（日配）。
系统只能说合格吧……读档只能回到标题画面，很麻烦。而且像我这样一开始没看攻略自己走的人就不得不把一些谜题重复玩两甚至三次，玩过的谜题为什么不能跳过啊……
没有中文翻译。语音在游戏里改，文字语言在steam上右键改，进度不互通。我一开始日英两种（文字）语言都玩了一点点，发现有一些需要用到日语的关卡连内容居然都改动了，很良心。因为换了语言之后进度不能共通，所以最后我看的是英文文字日语语音，总得来说是对得上的，一看就是人翻的，而且很用心。比如说把一宫翻译成了ACE，把八代翻译成了LOTUS，都挺有创意的啊。看到评论里有人说英文翻译很差，我可能是因为自己水平有限看不太出来差在哪里，反正比看那些轻小说腔超级重的汉化感觉要好，代入感高多了……

总的来说，如果这是个小说的话我只能给4分，而且女主角塑造还要再减0.5.。游戏的话给4.5吧，这么完整、节奏棒、剧情也可以的文字游戏真的不多见啊。

（第二部还没玩，若要讨论请勿剧透啊~）

The dialogue... omg. Completely over the top lots lots and so stupid! There are also no "opt out of conversations" options, just to shut them up - especially when you replay some legs to get to a different ending. I'm OCD so I wanted to do all the puzzles and endings, but I just couldn't listen to the drivel again - I didn't want to, plus I just didn't have the time! The sheer volume is mindboggling. uchi my nibba
While the twists don't have as much weight as the DS version due to the way the system worked, it's still a really good port. I'd recommend this game just for 999 alone.

There are two major portions to this series:  The escape sections, and the novel sections.

The escape sections are basically "escape the room" sequences, like what you would find in old flash games.  However, they are well presented.

The novel sections are where the story progresses.  It basically takes the form of a "choose your own adventure", where you can make decisions that influences the branch you take, similar to a lot of Visual Novels.  You can and are encouraged to go back and play the different branches (and not doing so would be a huge mistake).

I personally did not like the escape sequences that much, but they are not my style of game.  The story for this game, however, is fucking amazing and the reason you buy it.  It beats out the strories of AAA games.

The series deliciously mixes science fiction, drama, game theory, mystery, and puts a beautiful bow on top of it.  Pacing is perfect.  If any of those topics appeal to you, you will enjoy this.

Definition of a Hidden Gem.

I like trapped in a place kind of games so I liked this game. It has a nice plot. Plot twists suprises you sometimes. I loved some of the characters I hated a lot of them tho. The second game's graphics are shit. I don't understand why they choosed to make it 3d. Maybe it is for more cinematics or maybe for making my eyes feel sorry for existing

Jumpy kun my ass just kiss me already June

After many recommendations, i finally tried this supposedly amazing Visual Novel. I am very dissapointed.

Negative things:
-The user interface. My god, how can you even fu*k up something so basic? It's a visual novel, not an action game. This shouldn't be so difficult. It looks ugly and everything just feels slow and clunky. The "skip" option is the worst of all. I can feel myself die while "skipping" something. That's how slow it is.
-The story is not very deep or interesting.
-Almost no likeable characters.
-The game treats you like a complete idiot, who doesn't even know how to tie his own shoes, by giving you "hints", that are almost always obvious.
-The puzzles are a bit too easy for a game of life and death.

positive things:
+you can always go to a certain point in the flowchart, no matter what.

Why do so many people have this game in their top 5 list. Seriously? There are so many well written Visual novels out there, and THIS is the one they keep recommending? I thought this was going to be a deep story of a criminal mastermind with tons of character developement and interesting plot twists. Instead, it is a shallow story of boring characters with some bullsh*t telepathy supernatural "plottwist". No, thanks.

总评分6.5/10 游戏画质8.0/10 
人物立绘5.0/10 角色配音8.5/10
游戏整体来说很好，开头视频，画质，脱出时候开门的CG都很赞，但是人物立绘这方面却很不尽人意
说难听一些，整个人物的脸都是崩掉的，和原版差距很大，而且人物开口讲话的动画甚至还不如NDS原版好，刚玩完nds版就买了pc版打算看看重制版，但是没想到人物崩成这样，如果注重剧情的话比较建议入手游戏在游玩上有了一些新的变化，剧情也有些更新
但是老玩家如果注重人物立绘的话就没必要入了，人物真的崩坏到无法直视。已经申请退款了

I'm not that far into the game, but I cringe whenever I play it. The writing in this game is atricious. The game treats you like a child explaining the most basic things, which could easily be seen at a glance. Many characters are stupid, and make unbelievably nonsensical decisions. Also the writing is way too long-winded. And lastly, it doesn't even have options for changing the text speed, which is a weird omission in visual novel style games.

Being a huge fan of the original DS version of 999, I couldn't help myself but to buy this game and play it again on PC. As a bonus you get its sequel, Virtue's Last Reward, which is also awesome. The Zero Escape series has it all, a brilliant story, lovable characters and good puzzles. Trust me, if you like reading, you absolutely NEED to play this. 

The ZE series is the perfect example of the superiority of visual novels over conventional novels at story telling, you won't want to go back reading a paper book after this (I'm not exaggerating). 

Extremely recommended.

9 Hours, 9 People, 9 Doors is an absolutely excellent visual novel and probably the best I've ever played.
The blending of both traditional "reading" sections you'd find in VN's, along with the combination of interactive, brain-teasing puzzle sections creates a real sense of progression and learning, similar to games like DanganRonpa

The plot is great, with plenty of twists, turns and also a branching path system, [spoiler]Which is actually utilized as a plot device in the True Ending[/spoiler]

Overall, this game is a definite buy, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good mystery VN
Both 999 & Virtue's Last Reward are such good games! The puzzles are challenging and the characters are so memorable. Would definitely recommend! :)

Bought it to play Virtue's Last Reward, since I already played 999 in the DS.
999 and VLR are great games, they kept me interested from start to finish and I would easily recommend them to everyone who likes visual novels, puzzles and a narrative filled with questions and mystery. They do go a little too far in terms of logic and plot development, lots of things are too far-fetched. They also get a little repetitive when you have to go through the same route to get another ending (you need to get all the endings to unlock the real ending and understand the story as a whole, in both games), but you can skip the dialogues you already read! Nonethless, you have memorable and well-constructed characters and an engaging narrative that will keep your attention throughout the game. Worth it!
P.S.: Out of the two, I personally prefer 999
Very good verions of these games. The new voice acting in 999 is really good.

Впечатления от этих двух игр у меня стопроцентно совпали с другой серией от этого же разработчика - Danganronpa. 
Если первая часть, Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors, была камерным триллером про группу запертых\выживающих\психующих людей с минимумом японщины и максимумом адекватности, с реалистичными персонажами и логичным финалом, то вот вторая, Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward - полная её противоположность.
Сюжет понесло в глобальность, необъяснимой японской дичи выше крыши, героями стали фрики всех цветов радуги, а финала так вообще нет, в лучших традициях его заменяет To Be Continued, ждите третий выпуск. От полной скуки спасают только редкие финты ушами, что делают сюжет еще более отмороженным, но хотя бы куда-то развивающимся.
Один в один как в Данганронпе и её продолжении. Сможет ли третья часть обеих серий вернуться к истокам или еще дальше уйдет в себя - скоро я это узнаю.

Captivating stories with great characters, suspense, puzzles and writing. If you like mystery/sci-fi novels or visual novels, there is a great chance you will like these games. The way the stories unfold are fantastic. There are branching paths in both games which offer different sequences of discovering information and, in both games (at least in my experience), it was well explained and it wasn't possible to play them in any "wrong" order. You don't need to like anime to like these games. If anything I think the anime artstyle is a reason some people would disregard ever playing this game, and I think that's a real shame.

Fantastic games. I loved both of them. If I had to give a score, it'd be 9/10 for both.

If you love visual novels and branching storylines, you'll love these games. Try to get into it spoiler-free, because i think that makes the story so much more riveting. You'll want to play until all the pieces fit togetherl.

10/10
These are some of the greatest games I have played! They have a great story , fun puzzles , and great characters.

This game series is amazing. Highly, Highly Recommend those who enjoy murder mysteries and escape rooms.

This release comes with both the original 999 and the sequel, VLR.

9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors
This game is a great start to the franchise. The puzzles are well thought out, and the story is excellent. Various scientific and pseudoscientific concepts are applied in ways that actually make sense. Each character is very well developed. Although, it is very clear that the ending was built with the original DS version in mind. Overall, this is one of my favorite games ever.

Virtue’s Last Reward
The story does a very good job of escalating the stakes. The puzzles are still excellent, although some were a bit too... terrible (the dice puzzle in the final room can go die. I don’t know how to kill a puzzle, but I am willing to learn). The concepts introduced in 999’s true ending are expanded in interesting ways.

Overall, these games would be worth this price individually, so having both in one pack is great.

Wenn man ein Fan von "Escape the room" Spielen ist kommt man um diese Spiele nicht herum. Es handelt sich hierbei um ein Bundle der Spiele "Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors" und "Virtue's Last Reward" welche ursprünglich auf Nintendo DS bzw. auf 3DS/PSVita erschienen sind. Dass die Spiele schon ein paar Jährchen auf dem Buckel haben sieht man trotz aufpolierter Grafik deutlich.
Trotzdem haben beide Spiele (besonders der erste Teil) eine anfangs verwirrende und später absolut geniale Story und die Escape Passagen sind auch sehr unterhaltsam. Wenn ihr den Visual Novel Aspekt des Spiels und interessante Charaktere mögt dann kauft diese Spielesammlung!
A seriously amazing game with a captivating story. I'd highly recomend it any time. It's a shame it's so underrated compared to to oher games.

因《秋之回忆》系列和《Ever17》而扬名立万的打越钢太郎新作《极限脱出》系列，《9人9小时9扇门》和《善人死亡》合集。
作品延续了KID社《Infinity》系列的科学幻想风格，从剧本到作画都十分优秀。如果说《999》是打越在《Ever17》的基础上加快故事节奏的一次尝试，那么《善人死亡》则是对剧本高度的又一次挑战。总之，绝对是值得一玩的游戏，对英文和日文水平的提高都有很大帮助。喜欢《Infinity》系列、《命运石之门》和《弹丸论破》的童鞋千万不要错过。

So good that I bought and played this game 3 times (DS, iOS and this).

Two brilliant games with a focus upon pseudo-science and time travel. Interesting stories and characters though the second game is seriously lacking, it was far too long and repetitive; but the first game does not have this issue.

The Zero Escape series is an amazing ADV game with a really interesting story. I'm a huge fan of the Danganronpa series, so I decided to give this a try after friends recommended it. This quickly became one of my favourite series, it has a mix of everything from scientific fields and actually got me more interested in reading up on the different ideas that the game brings up. The characters really grew on me, their interactions are great and some scenes got me bawling like a baby while others had me in stitches. 999 had a really "comfortable" artstyle compared to VLR which took some time to get used to, the sudden change from 2D to 3D. But the quality of the storytelling didn't change extremely, the puzzles were fun and I truly enjoyed it. Even if you're not much into science then the games are easy to follow, the explanations were really good and it didn't require you to actually look anything up in order to understand the things they were going on about. 

I'm excited to see more of Kotaro Uchikoshi's writing in the future!

Amazing games with great stories full of plot twists! Maybe the best games in the "Scape the Room" genre. 999 has more of a SAW (movie) feeling to it. Virtue's Last Reward feels a little clunky at times because of its controls, but it's not that bad. This are Text-heavy games, so take that  in mind. 

Lots of replayability due to the design of the stories and multiple endings.

很好玩的密室解谜游戏，spike的弹丸论破三部和和极限脱出三部曲可以说是最出名的AVG之一了，一代九人之门最早出在nds上。二代三代3ds和psv都有，后来移植了pc和主机，该作是极限脱出的1和2带合集，其中一代增加了语音，谜题适中不太难，剧情很有意思也有深度，多结局很不错，不过我也是最近才开始接触这系列神作，只通关了一代，还是bad end，难受，在pc上去年买了两作极限脱出，纯当给我的破解3ds补票了。

I would recommend buying a helmet as well cause you're gonna have your gosh dang mind BLOWN.
great addition for fans of Zero Escape series!

I've spent 17 hours completing multiple endings in 999. In all that time I haven't figured out how the save system works. There are 6 saveslots but somehow when you've reached one ending you always have to start from the very beginning? There's no way to skip puzzles and there's no way no skip story segments you've already seen. So those 17 hours could have been less then 10 hours if this game didn't waste my time so much. It's a remake of an older game though so I guess some things can be forgiven. However, because of the weird save system that I still don't understand, right before going for the true ending I somehow deleted all my savefiles. As a result I didn't get the true ending but the coffin ending. 

Sick and tired of having to do everything all over again I just looked up the true ending on youtube. Problem is, somehow even after seeing multiple endings and spending that many hours... I somehow still missed a lot of crucial information. They were bringing up names and events that were only half explained throughout some of the endings. And just like the Danganronpa series this game doesn't really have an ending, it's all up in the air for a sequel. I've had a hard time forgiving Danganronpa for being so anticlimatic and seeing it here again is not helping. 

If this game was just called "Zero Escape: Part 1" then it would have been clear to anyone that you'll have to play through multiple games to get the full story. However, for the same developer to do this twice without giving the consumers any insight is just a disgusting marketing trick in my book and there's no two ways about that. 

If you must play this and you have an ios device I would recommend playing that version. It doesn't feature any puzzles which makes seeing multiple endings less of a drag.
Absolut großartiges Spiel <3 über 77Stunden mit vollem Spielspaß !!!!! Sigma ist einfach der beste prot  ever

I'm still working my way through these, however at first glance they appear to be a very good port of the 3DS/DS game series.  In particular the graphics for 999 have been very well upgraded/upscaled.

Incredible writing, intelligent story, had me on the edge of my seat constantly-- in both games! Just when you think you've solved the mystery, another cog gets thrown in. 999 is a little clunky since it's just a remaster of the original title, but VLR does well to improve on the shortcomings of 999 in both narrative, gameplay, and user friendliness. A diamond in the rough, and definitely in need of more glory than it has received.
Pretty good story, the puzzles aren't impossible but sometimes it definitely feels that way
Mükemmel bir kurgu ve hikaye kesinlikle Zero Escape'in bende yeri ayrıdır. İngilizceniz var, bulmacaları seviyor ve aklınıza güveniyorsanız alın...
999 is excellent, VLR has some strange presentation but it is great regardless

I have very mixed feelings about these 2 games, but since there's no 'mixed' option, I'll give them a positive review for the entertainment value. I'll review each game separately below, but as a common factor it should be noted that "action mystery" is clearly not Uchikoshi's forte, and the storytelling becomes more convoluted the further you follow this particular series. Also, you should know the puzzles of the game are outsourced and of varying quality - some very easy, most pretty decent, and a few with such bad conceptual errors that they made me rage at the QA that let them pass.

It is very easy to identify Uchikoshi's downfall as being more hung up on coming up with a new pseudo-scientific twist to each game than writing the actual story, with characters that the player can become invested in.

999 
A short, entertaining game in the vein of (and likely influenced stylistically by) Phoenix Wright. With room escape puzzles taking up the majority of the experience, expect to spend around 10 hours 100%'ing the game.
If you've read/seen some anime/manga in this genre (of people being thrown into a death game), it doesn't hold many surprises, with characters being very rough stereotypes and their roles being almost instantly obvious the moment you learn anything about them. Story's alright, but a critical reader will shake their head at the conclusion. Just don't expect stellar writing and enjoy the ride. 
Visually, the character art is great but you can plainly tell the Nintendo roots in the looks and the UI. 

Pros
+ Nice character art
+ Mostly fun puzzles
+ Good voice acting

Cons
- Predictable


Virtue's Last Reward
A significantly longer game (expect 20-25 hours to complete) than 999. The writing quality has been improved with characters becoming more solid in their own right, and some of the barter is genuinely delightful. The art has been "upgraded" into animated CGI models that mostly look very nice, but some cutscenes randomly use low-resolution still shots of them that look terrible. 
While I say the writing quality has been improved, the story itself is of significantly lower quality and couldn't really engage me at any point, failing to establish the setting, any motive, and a clear goal for anything that's happening. I was simply meandering along and following the events with detached curiosity. 
As a significant point of contention, some characters completely break character on occasion, with no cause beyond 'we wanted something different to happen on this route', and the whole story is extremely convoluted from beginning to end in the way that 999 only suffered at the end. Once I got to the end, I was already so numb to the writing that the lack of any conclusion didn't even particularly bother me anymore. Also, the game features prominently what I call "a**ho*e choices" - obviously bad choices that only an a**ho*e would make, but you have to take for branching purposes. Most characters, including Zero, were still fairly identifiable simply by knowledge of the genre.
The puzzles are more enjoyable thanks to the new 3D environment, but some of them had much more glaring issues than anything in 999 - I'll give a special shout out to a puzzle that requires you to read the time of [several clocks] in an exact, specific way. I'm sure it never occurred to whoever designed the puzzle (again, no doubt outsourced) just how many ways there are to read those numbers.

Pros
+ Nice character art
+ Mostly fun puzzles
+ Good voice acting
+ Fun banter

Cons
- Overall story
- A**ho*e choices
- A few major oversights in puzzles

So in summary... an entertaining ride of 30-40 hours total, with pretty good art, weak writing and a varying quality of escape room puzzles. Oh, and voice acting is quite good in both games.
