These 2 are Visual Novel style adventure games with some puzzles. You talk your way through the story solving the occasional puzzle to escape the current room, while making decisions that decides the fates of the characters. The story heavily branches and it has a really novel and brilliant use of storytelling devices, seen in no game before it.

Be warned though, Zero Time Dilemma which is the final instalment of this trilogy is a big letdown, but after playing the first 2 games you will definitely want to play it.

ABOUT THE PORT;
999 (the first game) is a ds game ported to PC, and it shows at times. The best moment in the entire series for me is ruined because of something that the DS could do but a PC can't, but if you have no access to a Nintendo handheld then the PC version would have to do.

VLR though works well in multiple platforms and is the best game of the series by far.
Interesting storyline and I like how both stories connect.

He jugado a Zero Escape 76465 veces. Desde que lo jugué por primera vez veo al gato de Schrödinger de las pelotas hasta en la sopa. 

Estoy enamorada de esta saga, la recomiendo mil. No olvidéis darle una oportunidad a Zero Time Dilemma para cerrar la historia!

999 blew my damn mind. Best implementation of multiple endings and choice I've ever seen in a game. Glad I played this version so I coulkd see the "tree" though because having to go through the other way would probably have annoyed me. VLR was good too, but there were a few design differences which annoyed me. it felt like they had worse implementation of watching the same scenes over again. There were more branching paths, meaning that many of the same scenes were retread several times. At some point the puzzles started to feel tedious too just becuase of how long the game was getting. Still enjoyed the hell out of VLR though.

I absolutely love this series.  This is a wild ride through puzzles, choices, timelines, quantum physics, Shrödinger's cat, and A LOT of history.  There are two games in one here.  There is 999:  Nine hours, Nine persons, Nine doors, and Virtue's Last Reward (VLR).  Between both of them, I enjoyed 999 more than VLR, and that was due to the fact that 999 took a lot less time to complete than VLR.  It took well over 20 hours to complete VLR which probably could have been cut in half had they cut out minor annoyances like the blip on the map travelling through doors OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER.  And even though VLR had the skip button that allowed you to skip over dialogue you had already read through, some of these scenes could have made a drastic cut in filler conversation.  There was enough historical and game related content that we did not need needless dialogue inserted.  But I guess that is the world of the VN.  I do not play many VN's.  In fact my VN experience is mainly VNs that have game content like Phoenix Wright.  

I love choices matter games, and your choices matter in every instance.  What you do definitely affects what happens later in the game.  If you are a 100% achiever, you will appreciate that there are twists in here because you will be repeating this game over many times.  And while it may seem tedious (and in VLR at some points it did get to that point), the fact that the choices you make lead to differences in the story, you are not going to be reading the same thing over and over again (for the most part anyway).  I bought this game when it was half price, and it was well worth the 50% off tag.  Honestly, with as much time as you will invest in this game getting every bit you can out of it, either price tag is decent.   I mean, you are getting two full games in here so the price really is not that steep.

Original 999 (Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors) was released back in 2009 on Nintendo DS to very positive reviews on how it tackled the mix of virtual novel and "escape the room" puzzles, while also using it's branching narrative, common for visual novels, as a plot point for many worlds interpretation influenced plot. It was also one of the first attempts, to my knowledge, to bring the Cube (the movie) ideas to video game format, mixing horror, thriller and mystery novel and becoming somewhat of the "What if Cube, Saw and Agatha Christie's "And Then There Were None" were anime". Virtue's Last Reward followed 3 years later on PS Vita and 3DS, and then in 2016 Zero Time Dilemma was released as a final chapter of the plot on the same systems, but also on PC.

As mentioned, all games are made with the same basic structure: most of the story is told via visual novel segments, which tend to have no puzzles or choices (though that gradually changes with every next game), while at times game switches to the escape the room puzzles, which require you to solve puzzles, find items and do the usual puzzle game stuff to get to the next visual novel bit. Another common concept is the idea of branching timelines and multiple endings. First game had very few of them and, as such, in the original version didn't have a Flow Chart for "jumping" between the timelines, but starting with the second game the timelines and jumps between them become much more complex. Being influenced by Cube and Saw, games also tend to deal with pretty dark themes and while it varies from game to game, it is common to expect lots of characters dying in horrible ways in different timelines with the main goal, usually, being finding the best possible solution where no one should die. Finally, I should really mention that the entire trilogy has absolutely amazing soundtrack by Shinji Hosoe and while very few tracks seem to be exclusive to a particular game and most themes repeat from game to game, the themes themselves are really good and it is a real shame that the soundtracks are not sold alongside the games. Now onto the Zero Escape: The Nonary Games.

Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors is genuinely amazing. It's probably the simplest game in terms of the plot and the stakes, but is also probably best told story in the series. Originally intended as a one-off, it tells a more personal story and tries to keep its plot and characters more or less realistically. While there's still lots of philosophical and pseudo-scientific banter and sometimes characters over-analyze something, while some characters still look ridiculous and some scenes with them are just absurd, it's more of a strange anomaly in the otherwise tightly written mystery tale. The Nonary Games remake of the game also features the much needed improvements to the title, like the completely not obvious ability to "jump" between story segments - you need to click a segment 4 (!!!) times to jump to it, something that works differently and more obviously in later games. At the same time, the remake sadly almost completely looses one creative storytelling trick that originally utilized the dual-screen nature of the DS and a few puzzles that also utilized the 2 screens are remade. They've been updated in a really good way and overall improvements in this version are very much worth it, but it still makes the original DS release its own thing. Highly recommend playing The Nonary Games version (though note, it's 1080p max for whatever reason).

Virtue's Last Reward is where things get quite a bit crazy. The plot goes into a very global and more sci-fi direction, characters are a bit more ridiculous and over the top than last time and unlike a more straightforward storytelling of the first game, with few branches, VLR is all about constant jumping from timeline to timeline. On one hand, characters still manage to be interesting, plot is still curious and puzzle rooms really well done for the most part. On the other, there's a lot more completely inappropriate joking, out of nowhere "wacky" scenes, dumb plot developments, ridiculous philosophical and pseudo-scientific bantering and, most importantly, the amount of plotlines and jumps between them gets genuinely overwhelming. There's no "good way" to experience the game, since in most cases you won't be able to actually get to the end of the storyline without jumping to another and with them being so many things get really confusing and tiring. It's still a really good game and is part of The Nonary Games that I highly recommend (even despite the mentioned 1080p resolution limit), but don't feel bad if you'll get over the game before it's done.
This was an amazing game. From the beginning of 999 to the ending of VLR, this has cemented a place as one of my favorite games.

Oh man, so great to have two of my all time favorite visual novels on PC! And most of the things are still the way they were when I fell in love with them: batshit insane stories, ridiculous but lovable characters, incredibly atmospheric music and really entertaining puzzles. The first game did get some new additions, and even those are mostly good things: voice acting and flow chart of the story's timelines are especially invaluable. More questionable changes were made to the game's graphics, text modes (they had to sort of mash up the two screens of DS into one, and I don't think the solution they went with is the best possible) and one important puzzle. If you haven't played the original version none of these things are likely to bother you, but I personally was a bit irked by them. But still, even with some minor flaws, this package is an absolute piece of gold among the visual novels! I definitely recommend checking these games out.
GOD BLESS THE FLOWCHART

This game tells a captivating (and occasionally confusing) story that is woven across two games (and a third seperate conclusion game) in truly astonishing ways. It's a game split 60/40 between visual novel storytelling and room escape point and click puzzles. The puzzles are fine ranging from easy to pretty challening, but the story is what will keep you hooked. These games are a series of butterly effect storylines where one decision made early on will seriously affect the rest of that current playthrough (sometimes in seemingly arbitrary ways). These games are designed to be played through repeatedly- minimum 2 or 3 times for 999, at least 10 times with Virtue. Each time through, you find out more about the cast of characters you're trapped with, their backstories, and just what in the hell is going on in the world around you. These games (especially Virtue) are master classes in drip feeding new informaiton causing you to constantly re-evaluate what you know about the story and characters. With that said, if you want to enjoy these games at all, DO NOT read story spoilers. DO NOT read wikis about the characters, DO NOT read plot summaries, DO NOT read analysis of the stories until you have COMPLETELY finished all of the playthroughs. I was left dumbstruck no fewer than five or six times going through these stories due to awesome and well established twists/revalations. There are multiple events that are intentionally presented in misleading ways until you finish those multiple playthroughs.

If you want a truly exceptional story experience with some reasonably good puzzles, buy this game.

This pack contains 2 games, 999 and VLR(Virtue's last reward):

999 is pretty great even if the puzzles are a bit too easy.

VLR puzzles are perfect but the presentation is pretty terrible.
The developper seems to have a special fetish for unskippable door animations in VLR which annoyed the hell out of me.
Also some things are repeated several times in different branches which can also be a bit annoying.
Overall it felt like it had a bit too much filler.
So happy that I finnally completed 999 after so many years! Love this game, easily top 5 material.

999 and VLR. Two of the most games I thought I would not have enjoyed...

I was sadly mistaken. 

Normally, I'm not one for puzzle games so I have to admit, when I first heard of anything of the Zero Escape franchise, I was thinking, maybe not. The first time heard was the advertisments for Zero Time Dilemma here and I thought, pfft. Another puzzle game I would not be interested in. When I watched a youtuber play a bit of it, I was then thinking, looks interesting and searched up the franchise. I then found out that after a bit after the release of ZTD, they would then remaster the Nonary games on Steam and PS4. I decided on the whim to get Steams version because they had a sale recently to get the the bundle. Anyways, this isn't the point!

The point is that I normally dislike puzzle escape games, any puzzle games in general really. However, 999 changed that for me. It was fun and creative in how you would escape the rooms. As well as that, there were creative paths for the many different endings. The other thing is this. If you have played Until Dawn, then you will know about the Butterfly Effect (also can be referred to Ripple). Your decisions change the outcome in the games. It was interesting to see that incoporated in the game, and how you would have to alter your decisions to make sure you make the good endings. 

VLR also incorporates it. As well as that, there are more puzzles to go through. However, not goijng to lie. Some of the puzzles in the second game got harder and more challenging, so sometimes I got stressed out and had to take a break, especially when finding the secondary passwords to unlock the "Redacted" achievment. I managed to get through the two games in 52 hours with 100% achievments. I have to admit, it was also quite challenging needing to go back to certain points or finding clues that would unlock other points as you could not continue without certain passwords or whatever. That's about the only thing I didn;t like about the game. The constant returning to areas to look for things you should have noted down, whereas in 999, the things you unlock does not need passwords. 

Despite this, this game has made me slightly interested more in puzzle games. The game can be played in English and Japanese (in my case, I played the game in English with Japanese voices). It was interesting to see some of my favourite voice actors here in a few anime and different games (in this case, the voice actor for Quark was the VA for Alhonse Elric from Full Metal Alchemist, and Zero Junior's voice was done by the VA of Monokuma (can't remember if it was the game or anime though). 

This game is great for both puzzle and anime enthsiasts, and those that like games that involve changing futures with the butterfly effect. 

My personal rating of the game: 10/10, despite the reptitiveness at times.

I will only recommend this game to a very specific group of people who:
[list] 
[*]Desperately want to have their time wasted and have no problem dealing with the morning-after regret.
[*]Have an inhuman level of tolerance for verbose and childish writing.
[*]Believe in pseudoscience and don’t even bother looking up the validity of it.
[*]Are gullible and believe whatever bull**** people throw at you.
[*]Can turn a blind eye to any ridiculous plot hole and deus ex machina scenario as long as the story moves forward.
[*]Don’t mind their elaborative faculty being questioned and taunted by the devs again and again.
[/list] 
If you find yourself fit in at least four(4) of the categories above, go give it a try, you may have an incredibly fun time with this game. Otherwise you may just end up like me, tortured by regret and fury for all the wasted time and anticipation.
 
I know, Japanese visual novels (also Japanese literature in general) are well known for verbose writing, I had this in mind before stepping into this game.  However, its excessive verboseness still overwhelmed me somehow. You might think I am exaggerating and overacting at this point, so, to sufficiently prove my points, I am going to give a demonstration of two techniques used in this game, two techniques that stretched this game from a story that could have been properly told in 5 hours into an endless marathon.



[h1]Technique 1:[/h1]
I don’t know if this game was made for kids or not, but considering it is rated M in many countries, my suspicion might be incorrect. Anyway, the devs seemed to have highly underestimated the elaborative faculty of the players to an almost offensive degree. 

As if describing a fact or ratiocination that sticks out a mile by the narrator wasn’t enough, they just have to recapitulate the same thing (indeed, the exactly same thing, no Rashomon effect involved) through the mouth of every character available at the scene again and again, and eventually, to have the protagonist to sum it up one extra time…

Here is an example:
[b](Note that it’s not an excerpt of any actual in-game scene, but a simplified demonstration of how this “technique” works, as is the example in the next part)[/b]


[quote=Example 1] 
You rushed to the door only to found its handle missing. 
Where the handle was supposed to be, left only an empty socket behind.
You tried to force it open *BAM* *BAM* of no avail.
People gathered around to investigate it. [b](“narrator describes the situation” Check ✓)[/b]

Character 1: “What are you doing? Let’s open this door and proceed!”
You: “I just arrived and found its handle missing.”
Character 2: “A door can only be opened by rotating its handle, I guess we cannot open the door then.” 
Character 3: ”Let me handle this, I’m full of muscle! *BANG* *BANG*”
You: “I tried, it didn’t even budge.”
Character 5: “Let me give you a hand!”
Character 3: “Rawr… Doesn’t work!”
Character 6: “We can’t open the door normally, nor force it open. I figure this door is off-limits to us.”
Character 2: “That’s what I’m thinking, we cannot open this door at this moment.”
Character 4: “Then we are trapped! This is the only door we haven’t entered!”
You: “Maybe there is some other ways to open a door?”
Character 6: “Like teleporting through?” 
Character 4: “How is that possible!?”
Character 2: “How about lockpicking?”
Character 1: “Without a handle, there isn’t any lock to lockpick I’m afraid.”
Character 4: “So we are trapped! We are going to starve to death!”
You: “Is it possible to find some explosives to breach it?” 
Character 2: “Whew! Yes, we can plant some explosives to breach it through. Why haven’t I figured that out.” 
Character 6: “Indeed, it’s a tough door no doubt, but I don’t think it can stand against explosion.”
Character 3: “Good idea! I know I can count on you.”
You: “Is that truly the only way?”
Character 1: “Or we can find the missing handle to fix the door, and open it the way a normal door would.”
Character 5: “Exactly what I was thinking. We can also try finding the missing handle.”
Character 4: “Does that mean we don’t have to die here if we can find the missing handle or get some explosives to breach it?” [b](“every character recaps the same thing at least once” Check ✓)[/b]
You: “So our current objective is clear, we either find the missing handle of the door, or get our hands on some explosives to breach it open. Everybody clear?” [b](“protagonist sums it up one extra time” Check ✓)[/b]
 [/quote]

Did you get how painfully annoying it is?
Also note that since every line is accompanied by voice over and character animation, any simple scenario like this one could easily last ages.



[h1]Technique 2:[/h1]
As you might have already known, the game is consisted of two parts. One is the “
Visual Novel” part, in which you simply read the story, and sometimes make decisions to push the story forward. The other one is the “Room Escape” part, which plays just like any other room escape game, except for the puzzles being mind-numbingly easy and straightforward.

What truly bothers me is that every character keeps saying sh*t that are either too intelligent and informative, or embarrassingly flirty (both from male and female), which is totally out the realm of their character personas and the overall atmosphere. There is one scene where they were just screaming and vomiting after the discovery of a bloody dismembered body, the next minute, they started flirting and recollecting childhood memories right beside the corpse!?

And that isn’t even the worst part, the worst part is that every character keeps commentating before/during/after your every single action! It might be hard to understand how, so here comes the demonstration. 

Imagining yourself entering  a room with two other characters, the room is completely empty except for a tea table in the center and a key atop it. The exit is on the opposite of the room, locked. The solution here is quite self-evident, you grab the key, unlock the door and get out, not much to talk about really. However, such simple scenario would evolve like this in this game:

[quote=Example 2] 
(Just when you enter the room, game freezes.)
Character 2: “Oh, this room is so empty, can we just chill out here for a while and take a break?”
You: “Time is running out, I’m afraid we can’t afford the luxury.”
Character 1: “Yeah, let’s find out the solution to this room.”
Character 2: “You men are always this rushy.”


(Game resumes control, you start to explore the room)


(Just before you are about to grab the key)
Character 2: “Look! There is a key on the table.”
Character 1: “Yeah, I saw that too, I wonder what it opens.”
You: “Let’s take a closer look.”

(Right after you pick up the key)
Character 1: “Hey, what’s that you’re holding? A key?”
You: “Yes, I just found it lying on the table.”
Character 2: “Oh, it looks so stiff and hard.”
You: “Wait, can you say that again?”
Character 2: “Say what again?”
You: “The one you used to describe the key.”
Character 2: “Oh that’s awkward, please forget about it!” 
[b](“ridiculously unnecessary flirting” Check ✓)[/b]

(While you attempt to further search the room)
Character 1:  “Since there are only two doors in this room, one is the one we just entered, the other one must be the exit, why don’t we check it out.”
Character 2: “It looks locked though, but maybe you can unlock it with the key you just found?”
You: “Only one way to find out.”

(When you approach the door.)
Character 1: “Oh, this door is so strongly fortified, there’s no way we can force it open, got to use a key.”

(After you insert the key and open the door.) 
Character 1: “Man, you are such a talented door-opener, I love the way you insert the key into the lockhole, how fierce.”
Character 2: “You guys are disgusting!” 
[b](“ridiculously unnecessary flirting again, seriously?” Check ✓)[/b]
You: “Just shut up and let’s get out of here.”
 [/quote]


Are you feeling it now?

[this is a review of 999; I have not played VLR yet]
I'm not a fan of anime. Not of the art style, not of the peculiarities of storytelling, and I'm very far from a Japanophile in terms of culture. Thus, as you may guess, I approached this game with some hesitation. 
But a good friend recommended it, and so I decided to try it. And of course the japanese animation traits that annoy me are here - ridiculous outfits, ridiculous character designs (how am I supposed to guess this sexy looking chick is around 18 years' old and the other one is at least 40? they look the same! and this guy looks old-ish - but no, he is also 20-something), exasperatingly awkward flirting and people make a huge deal out of things like "a girl being in the same elevator as a guy", ugh. 
But the plot and the gameplay are so good that I was quite willing to overlook them. The puzzles are nice - require some thinking, but everything is solvable without a walkthrough. The secrets within secrets are delectable, and while the game will explain everything if you finish, it's extremely satisfying to figure out plot points for yourself. Delightfully, the game allows it and gives you just enough clues to feel smart. The voice acting is acceptable, and the way player is allowed to skip over parts they have played through when discovering all possible endings is wonderfully made and meshes perfectly with the game. All in all, this is a brilliant adventure game.

There was a lot I had issues with when it came to the writing of the game like how a lot of the characters felt completely off besides maybe one or two of them but I really did enjoy this game. Much like how Danganronpa is based around surviving a killing game, this offers a much more complicated path of beating the killing game and saving all the participants you can. The game focuses on puzzle/escape rooms that you need to solve in order to leave the room and progress the story. In each game, there are multiple escape rooms with different kind of puzzles.

All in all, it's a fun mystery and puzzle game that adds a lot of personality thanks to some characters and the problems they face in and out of the killing game.
thumbs up

Probably one of the best visual novel type games I've ever played. Several interesting concepts and mechanics blended with an intelligent story and decent voice acting. The only thing that I absolutely hate about 999 so far (Haven't played VLR yet) is the writing, specifically the dialogue between characters. The game seems to be pretty mature, so I'm not sure why it treats the audience like they're children. Characters constantly repeat the same exact thing that your character said a few seconds earlier in 5 different ways like they don't expect the player to remember even the most basic details. It's so annoying and so frequent that I have to actually skip dialogue for some scenes. For example:

You: "Wow, would you look at that stick over there!"
Person 1: "That stick over there sure is interesting"
Person 2: "There's a stick over there? Woah!"
You: "The directions say to throw the stick into the water and we'll summon a zombie shark."
Person 1: "So what you're saying is, if we toss the stick over there into the water..."
Person 2: "A SHARK will show up!?"
You: "Let's do it!"
Person 1: "Alright!"
Person 2: "Ok!"

Like seriously, if I wanted to be treated like a mentally disabled toddler with the attention span of a fly I would watch sesame street or listen to some Snake dialogue from MGS3. What's almost as bad is when you figure out something plot related from an obvious clue, and then you have to wait an agonizing three scenes while your character thinks to himself like a mumbling idiot, using all of his peanut brain to figure out what he just saw. Currently the only thing that really bugs me about that game, but overall its a really great experience.

Le package "The Nonary Games" contient les deux premiers jeux de la série, et ils sont excellents !

Le principe est le suivant : le jeu alterne entre des phases d'énigmes sous formes d'escape rooms (vous êtes enfermé dans une pièce et vous devez trouvez la sortie) et des phases de dialogues avec les personnages du jeu qui vous font découvrir peu à peu une histoire géniale et complexe (et très complexe pour le second opus).

Attention : pas de langue française disponible actuellement, il faut comprendre l'anglais (au moins à l'écrit)... mais ça en vaut la peine.

Dans le second jeu, n'oubliez pas que vous pouvez passer en avance rapide les dialogues "délà vus" avec un raccourci (oui c'est mystérieux, mais vous comprendrez plus tard...)

If you want to have to take a break from everything else after playing a game just to try to figure out what the fuck just happened, buy these games.

9時間9人9の扉は次作"善人シボウデス"のプロローグ、いわゆるこの世界のシステム(ルール)説明のための作品で、
善人シボウデスの方ではそのシステムを利用した面白いストーリー展開がありました。

ご都合主義で進む9時間9人9の扉に対する評価は変わりませんが

"過去の選択肢が未来の結果に影響する"ノベルゲームは沢山ありますが、
"未来の選択肢が過去に影響する"タイプのノベルゲームは希少ですので
ノベルゲーム好きの方はぜひ善人シボウデスまでプレイを進めてみることをお薦めします。

-補足-
ダンガンロンパ2は好きだけれども1は嫌いだ、という方がもしおられれば
9時間9人9の扉と善人シボウデスも同じような関連性の作品だといえば分かりやすいでしょう。

Score: 7.5/10 (8/10 for 999, 7/10 for VLR)
Time to 100%: 40 hours (20 hours each)
Similar games [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/413410/Danganronpa_Trigger_Happy_Havoc/]Danganronpa[/url], [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/288160/The_Room/]The Room[/url]

The Nonary Games are two games in one, including both 999 and Virtue's Last Reward. They are story-rich, mystery visual novels where their core emphasis is on trust and betrayal. Locked in escape rooms where you must solve puzzles to survive, can you depend on the kindness of strangers? Or stab them in the back before they do so to you?

Pros:

[b]The Rabbit Hole[/b] - Despite the differences between the two games, and there are quite a few, something they both share in common is their trippy writing. The games are meant to be played multiple times, as they have various branching storylines, each of which helps to further explain plots within the game, uncover mysteries and motives of the characters who are with you. 

[b]The Unusual Suspects[/b] - Speaking of characters, these games also do a great job of unraveling these mysterious people over the course of the gameplay. 999 in particular did a great job in this, as several of the characters I didn't like in the beginning I ended up liking more as the game progressed, while others did a complete 180 by the games final credits. In a good way.

[b]Puzzles[/b] - The gameplay is your standard locked room puzzle fair. The kind of gameplay you would expect to see in games like Myst, The Room or many other point and click games of their ilk. It's your usual - Find key for the box/Open the box to find a red thingy/Put the red thingy in the red thingy hole - you know.  In 999 they are not too taxing, in VLR the puzzles can be a little bit trickier, and if you are doing hard mode expect to be caught out a couple of times. 

Cons:

[b]The Art Style[/b] - Most of my cons, and there are not many of them, mainly come from the second game. Personally I think the art style of the first game (999) holds up better than the second (VLR) as in the original they use animated sprites for the characters, whereas in the second they use 3D rendered characters, which look like something I'd see back in Playstation 2 era. It's a small gripe I have, I'm not sure why the developers chose to go in that direction. But it's nothing major, anyway.

[b]Transitioning[/b] - This wasn't a problem in the first game but in the second one expect to see a map with a blinking dot and slowly opening doors MANY, MANY TIMES.

All-in-all a good series that I had found after looking for something to scratch my Danganronpa itch, which this had done and then some. I look forward to playing the third installment.

The nonary games consists of 2 games in 1.

999 zero escape.
+ Puzzles. 
+ Characters.
+ Plot twists
+ Multiple endings. Drastically increases the playing time.
+ Main character. I like his lighthearted sense of humour and reactions. Like when he first named the characters in his head. Mountain, silver, dancer, lion and so on.
~~~~~~~ 
Virtue's Last Reward
Better user interface compared to 999. You can smoothly jump anywhere you want on flowchart.
You also get a notepad on which you can note stuff for puzzles, no more scribbling on paper!~
Also you get different puzzles each time you strive for a different ending.
Different art style. Preference is a personal matter.
~~~~~

Pros: 
Horrifying death game (I know how much you anime fans love horrifying death games)
Intricate well-written plot
Solid voice acting
Likeable characters
A fair amount of playtime (Maybe around 50 hours for both games, though some of that is filler)
The "true" endings are among the best in the genre.

Cons:
Some pacing issues. Virtue's Last Reward especially feels a bit like a "hallway walking simulator" after awhile.
Virtue's Last Reward's graphics aren't super great
Puzzles are just OK.

Verdict:
A cult-classic entry in the visual novel genre with it's own unique flavor. It's carried by a good story and good voice acting. While it drags on in parts, it did manage to keep my interest for like 50 hours. The "true" endings to the two games are enjoyable, and make the hours worth it.

Buy if you like VN games, sci-fi, and have enough patience to power through the less interesting parts.

I finished this game in my 3DS and I still absolutely love it. I really enjoy the mechanics of the Nonary Game and the interesting characters in it.

The only thing I don't like about this port is the English voice over for Junpei - although that's slightly a nit-picking on my part I guess. I would suggest playing with Japanese voice overs.

I guess it's common for sequels to be worse than earlier work, but my goodness I've never seen that effect be this extreme.

The first game in this bundle, 999, is outstanding, one of the best visual novels I've ever played. Without spoiling anything, the story explores a clever central mechanic in an original way. The cast of interesting characters develop well - you'll feel like you're solving the mystery along with them, as clues are slowly revealed and you're kept guessing up until the thrilling conclusion. Gameplay-wise, the story is punctuated with escape rooms, with puzzles that are mostly fair and full of "aha!" epiphany moments. A little bit of pseudoscientific nonsense slightly mars the story, and some might view the puzzles as too easy, but I was more than prepared to forgive both of these points. I also found the voice acting a little wooden, but changing the voices to Japanese solved this problem instantly.

In contrast, Virtue's Last Reward is a huge let-down. The opening puzzle is particularly weak (it invites you to make a subjective judgement of someone's terrible drawings, ambiguous enough that I felt compelled to brute force the solution), and later puzzles came across as equally unfair. The 3D character models used throughout look awful, and they seem to have had personality lobotomies, lacking the clear motivations and characteristics that the characters in 999 had. Meanwhile, the central "ambidex game" mechanic is the sort of fare that's been done to death on daytime game shows across the planet, and yet the writers still don't seem to understand it. You'll get subjected to a long judgemental lecture if you don't agree with the game's flawed reasoning. The dialogue is boring, with a lot of time wasted on convoluted explanations - a particularly stupid example is when the rules of the ambidex game are explained at length, and then a character pipes up with "Hey! This is just like that famous problem in mathematical game theory! I will now spend a similar amount of time explaining that problem's rules in an identical fashion." Arrgh! Whatever happened to "Show, Don't, Tell"?! Meanwhile, unlockable secrets seem to reward you with spoiling the upcoming part of the story. I'm struggling to think of something the game did better than 999 - perhaps the ability to get hints by switching to "easy" mode, but frankly these hints were not helpful.

In conclusion, this bundle is worth it for 999 alone, but I'd have preferred to have purchased 999 by itself!

Completed run review of both 999 and VLR

---- Zero Escape 999 ---

+Excellent Story                                                
+Excellect Characters
+Great PC Port
+2D Characters & Art (personal bias)
+Math based puzzles (again personal bias)

Overall 999 is a great VN and definitely worthwhile to play (which needs all routes to be 100% completed to understand the whole story). The math-based puzzles are really fun to work on, which compliments the story quite well - the 2D art and animation along with the excellent (japanese) voice over really makes the 25 hour-or-so play through an absolute blast. Personally had no complaints about 999 as it genuinely had my attention from start to finish, with very well polished writng and interesting subplots. 


--- Virtue's Last Reward ---

+Great PC Port
+Puzzles are challenging and plentiful
+Excellent Characters
+- Story is slightly more convoluted
- 3D graphics (personal bias)
- Really inconsistent presentation

Unfortunately VLR have to be compared to 999, if you haven't played 999 then VLR holds up on its own but definitely not as good (in my eyes) as 999 once you have played the first game in the series. Unlike 999 the presentation on VLR uses 3D characters and animated cutcenes which are not that great, but they do their job to convey action. This is also the part where VLR feels inconsistent in terms of production and presentation, there are some 2D cutscenes much like 999 at some parts which makes the 3D ones extremely jarring to say the least. However if you like puzzles that are genuinely challenging VLR definitely has you covered, along with a likeable cast, the 30 hour or so full run through was enjoyable (but definitely not as engaging as its prequel).

--- Overall Verdict ---

Definitely a must buy if these 2 title-bundles are on sale to anyone who likes (math) puzzles and VN, even if just to play 999 alone. In my personal opinion to a new player it might be of interest to play VLR first since the two titles can be played technically in a non-chronological order.

A collection of two great games, Zero Escape: 999 and Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Rewards, full of mystery. There are plenty of choices and plenty of endings for you to explore, while an interesting story unfolds.

Review for 999:

This was enjoyable, with decent escape rooms and a good story.  The overall mystery is a good one with a good, satisfying solution, and the story resolves itself very well. 

On the negative side I personally found the character art to be noticeably mediocre, and actual choices available are fairly arbitrary in the sense that their results are (with one exception) entirely unpredictable when first making the choice.  

8/10.  

Review for VLR:

A really, really fantastic game, far superior to its predecessor.  The alternate-solution mechanic to the escape rooms is awesome and adds a wealth of new content to the escape rooms.  Choices don't just matter, they sometimes have reasonably predictable results, too, a welcome change.  The character art is also substantially improved from 999.  

I would talk about negatives, but there really aren't any substantial ones.

9.5/10.

A++ mind bending narrative, plus puzzles that never get stale through replaying. Played the hell out of Virtue's Last Reward on the 3DS. The Japanese voice acting is amazing, full of expression and representative of each character.

I do recommend this game.

This package contains two games. 9 Hours 9 Persons 9 Doors and the sequel Virtue's Last Reward. Both games are visual novels. it's like reading a interactive book. Genre would be something along the lines of a thriller.

I'm not gonna spoil the stories so lets just say its 9 people traped together in the veins of the SAW movies, exept less shock value in blood and gore, instead it's filled with tons of actual story that makes you care for the charaters. Oh! and the translation is realy good, something these games often suffer greatly from. I didn't have any problems with the english dub, all characters sounded fine to me and believable enough. But I gotta mention there is one character/voice actor in particular that is absolutely amazing, you will know when you get hare.

The puzzle are also amazing brain teasers. You may get stuck for a while (or a very long time), but soon realise that this is actualy just logic and not that hard when you think back at it. Maybe a bit of an unpopular opinion, but I liked the puzzles in 999 better than VLR. I can defently see why some may like the puzzles in VLR better, but the very much highlighted theme in 999 made it a bit better in my opinion.

999 uses 2D pictures of the charaters, while VLR uses 3D characters. and let me just say some of these animations and shots in VLR look very uncanny like. But I guess it did not look that bad back on the 3DS and Vita as they have much smaller screens. But if you can look past some of these visual horrors you will have a blast with some of the best writting the game medium have to offer.

999: 

At a glance, you might see this game on Steam and go: "Eh, just another one of these things, I know what to expect".

Well, take everything you expect, throw it out the window, and get a notepad. 

This isn't some trope-filled game, even though it may look like that. I know that's what I apprehensive about. But I'm a puzzle junkie, so I gave it a shot anyway.

I AM SO GLAD I DID.

It. Blew. Me. Away.

If you like a great story, play this game, If you like a great puzzle, play this game. If you like enjoyable characters, play this game. If you like getting mindf*cked, play this game. If you enjoy the impending state of doom, play this game.

If you don't like math... well, the suffering will be worth it.

The Zero Escape is a a long and incredibly cryptic Visual Novel series with puzzle solving elements. Took me ~65hrs to 100% both games(The Nonary Games & Virtues Last Reward)

Requires multiple playthroughs (with repetition-skipping option) to see the 'True Ending'. The series references previous games, so it is best to start from square one (Zero Escape: The Nonary Games). The games are mostly voice-acted during cutscenes, but requires reading during puzzle scenes. They also have an anime feel to them, visually and story-wise. The series isn't overly-gorey, but thematically involves death so age discretion is advised for younger players.

Aside from that, the twists and turns the story takes, the 'aha!' discovery feelings, and the sci-fi dystopian feel kept me hooked throughout my playthrough. Would highly recommend!
9/9/9 Game.

If you like visual novels, You've probably heard of Ever17.  This is written by one of the same guys, Kotaro Uchikoshi.  That should be all you need.

If you don't like visual novels, this is not an anime dating simulator.  This is not an excuse to see anime girls with their clothes off. In fact, no anime girls will remove any clothing over the course of the entire experience.  This is what a visual novel is supposed to be - a well-written story, told with visuals alongside it.  I promise that this one is different from whatever turned you off the genre.

It also has some room escape elements that are tied into the story.  Like you probably saw above, a bunch of people are trapped against their will and forced to solve puzzles to escape.  Rather than being told how clever your character is, you get to talke over and solve the puzzles yourself.  You will be pixel hunting to some degree, but the other characters in the room with you will make jokes and tell stories about the things you clicked on.  There's a pretty good chance that you'll end up clicking things that are obviously useless just to see more of the side dialogue.  For example, I highly recommend clicking the bed in the first class cabin five or six times.
you should buy it
Yup, still great!  Watched my wife play through them this time, and they still hold up.  Love, love, love this series.

不能双视角同屏差评

Un pack que combina dos juegos de puzzles y point and click con una larga e increíble trama. Aunque más bien, debería decir que son dos novelas visuales con elementos de point and click y puzzles, que se combinan de manera sublime en una saga que, hasta ahora, si bien de tanto en tanto puede resultar repetitivo y tedioso, termina siendo una experiencia única.

Ambos juegos no son actuales, por lo que no esperes grandes gráficos. De hecho, el primero (999) no tiene animaciones sino dibujos semi estáticos, mientras que el segundo tanto los personajes como el entorno están hecho con gráficos 3D más algunos dibujos estáticos, pero los NPC sólo tienen animaciones cuando se refieren al protagonista y no cuando interactúan con el entorno, mientras que el protagonista sólo es visto en dibujos estáticos.

La música es verdaderamente buena y acompaña perfectamente los diferentes momentos del juego (novela narrada, interacciones, situaciones de puzzles, etc.). Las voces son excelentes y se asocian perfectamente a cada personaje. Se extraña una voz para el protagonista de VLR...

Los puzzles son buenos (algunos son clásicos en P&C) no son difíciles en general pero algunos, en especial los finales, pueden tenerte un buen rato dando vueltas. El juego tiene una opción para bajar la dificultad de los mismos, en los cuales los NPC que te acompañan te darán más pistas para resolverlos, pero eso derivará en que no podrás encontrar la totalidad de documentos e información sobre el juego que el mismo puede dar.

Lo mejor de todo, sin duda, es la jugabilidad, la manera en que los puzzles se acoplan al juego y la HISTORIA, que es sublime en en muchos puntos te tendrá en el borde de la silla, con la boca abierta, absorbiendo la información y los giros de la trama.

Absolutamente recomendado para los que gustan novelas visuales, y también para los que gustan de los P&C. Eso sí, para estos últimos, tener en cuenta que hay más tiempo en modo "novela" (donde se cuenta y desarrolla la historia) que en modo "puzzles". Pero vale la pena, ya que el resultado es una experiencia gratificante.

These games are great. If you like a complex story with hard puzzles, then this game is for you. I'd probably get about 50 hours from this if i played through the original, 999 again. I already played it on the DS though. The original was remastered with hd stuff and full voice acting for the cinematic areas, which is really nice. VLR has this automatically, as well, and is just as good a game as 999, given a slightly more complex story.


Overall, these are really fun games and i would recommend 10/10.

If you want to explore these games, let me give you three essential pieces of advice that will help you traverse the plotlines in a TIMELY manner.

1) Pressing enter will complete the dialogue without skipping.
2) Pressing "ctrl" twice will activate auto-skip mode, rushing you quickly through all the text. You need to turn this feature on in the options, you can stop it by clicking the stop icon to the right or adjusting the rate in the menu.
3) Use the flowchart to navigate any instance you've already seen (i.e. branching, or returning for gold files in VTR)

As visual novel types go, I found this very enjoyable -- but I HATE having to go through dialogue I've already seen. I had wasted 2 hours quickly spamming enter to get to new text; had I known these tricks beforehand, I would not have dispised this aspect of the game.

One of my absolute favorite games ever! 

+ It may not look like it due to my hours, but this game has a ton of replayability between the branching paths and different endings (I put a lot of time into the DS/3DS versions).
+ the voice acting is solid all around (and new to 999), which improves the atmosphere of the game.
+ enhanced visuals make this game very appealing to the eyes as well, where as the DS/3DS versions felt grainy due to the low resolution screens.

Overall, this is a must play for fans of visual novels. The story telling is well done, you can feel the suspense as you play, and the characters are all charming in their own way. Even Dio, in a loveable tightwad kind of way. (I recommend starting with 999 first, or you may have a bit less clarity when playing Virtues Last Reward.)

I played 999 on the DS and got VLR on the 3DS when it came out. Then, when I got a Vita, I got VLR on it again and played through it again.

You might see negative reviews for this game based on the fact that you have to play the story multiple times to get the true ending [spoiler] a design choice which has a story reason, which is hype as heck. [/spoiler]. I think that it is fair to say that the people complaining about that shouldn't be complaining, since the DS version didn't have a flowchart to teleport to different scenes and you had to fast forward through all of the scenes to continue onto a different path. 

There are two modes to play the visual novel parts of the game. The base mode, Adventure Mode, cuts down on a lot of the reading and the exposition of the story. The Visual Novel mode, however, recreates the novel as it was on the DS, meaning a lot more descripitions and exposition.

I can't really comment on the Escape Rooms, as the way that the DS version made you play required you to play through every room multiple times, so I am unaware of the difficulty, since I am a legend at doing most of the rooms now.

I recommend this game with all of my heart.

9.7/10

This is a fantastic collection of games. From the writing to the structure of the many puzzles there is little to be criticized I am simply amazed by the hard work that must have gotten into making these games.

The games are part visual novel, part 3D point and click-puzzle games with an enormous emphasis on story. The two games follow a handful of people who are kidnapped and forced to play a game with their lives on the line with the purpose to escape... Or so you think hehehe.

Since the story is so complicated and important I won't go further into it. I will just say that you will HAVE to play the games a few times to get the full experience and you are heavily encouraged to do so.

The presentation is fantastic for what it is. The games function and look almost identically so I will review them as a whole. During the visual novel parts you simply click to progress and the HUD looks and functions as you would expect. If you come to a part in the story that you've already encountered you can skip through it in a matter of seconds if you want. This happens a lot and the solution works perfectly. During the puzzleparts you work in a semi-3D environment to solve different puzzles and at the same time interact with the fun characters and items around you. Works perfectly
The world is presented in exactly the right way, with environments and characters with a lot of depth and mystery behind them.

The writing is absolutely spiffing, I cannot stress this enough. I envy the writers ability to write such complex stories and still make them make sense to the player with almost zero loose ends. This is really the selling point of the game. If you want a fantastic and complex story in a style that only the Japanese people can do: look no further.

Can I say anything bad about the game? Well, they don't really look that great graphics-wise and the english voices are mediocre at best (except for Zero III omg she is so talented). Luckily you can choose to play with japanese voices and english text. Problem solved.

Onto the graphics then. These games claim to be "remastered" in this new amazing bundle. Well, yes and no. The first game looks great for what is is compared to its original DS release. The second game does not. I really feel like the developers could have put more effort into making the character-models and the "cut-scenes" look better, they still look like they were made 2003.

My conclusion is still that these are hidden gems, invaluable treasures among modern puzzle/story driven games. The may not LOOK like it, but these games are a true work of art in story-telling. They changed the way I think about time and space, the way I think when I interact with other people and my standing point of swimsuits forever. Love it

(Rating edited, please see comments for more details)

This review is for the first game, 999.

There were good things about the game, but overall I have to say I was disappointed because of the pacing, the story, the puzzles and the game design.

The pacing was pretty slow. The writing style was not very good (both the translation as well as the Japanese) in that there is too much explanation going on. Everyone has to explain everything instead of showing their character through their actions. And the intro, which should be the hook, gets bogged down.

I personally didn't find the story interesting at all. It had an okay premise, but it failed to capitalize on the drama of internal strife within the group. The danganronpa series had much more tension between the characters and the recurring theme that the greatest threat is not from the outside, but from within. I mean they have this great idea that only a certain group of people would be able to pass through a door, but none of the characters really think through to the end game which is probably one of the first things any normal person would do. 

The puzzles were too easy. There isn't any part where you really have to think, you just have to click everywhere to serch for parts. It isn't a clever manipulation of inventory or lateral thinking, it's just a chore. This isn't a terrible spoiler, but just to be fair I'll put up spoiler tags: [spoiler] You have to put out a fire. Search around the room for a vase, and then fill it up with water in a tub and throw it on the fire. That's not a particularly inspired puzzle. Turn on two light switches and a bag of coins drop. Use those coins in a slot machine to get a card. [/spoiler] Those aren't puzzles. They're just a waste of time.

The problem with the game design, and this is just a personal peeve of mine is that you have to play the game through several times to get the 'good' ending. I played 4 hours and got a bad ending. And it's not because I made any bad decisions, it's just that to get the good ending you have to choose a certain path. That in and of itself wouldn't be so bad, but you aren't presented any information that would make one choice seem better than another. Basically, you have to choose between entering three doors. No one door is any more appealing than the other. And if you choose the wrong door, you end up playing for three or so hours only to get a bad ending. Sure, you learn a bit about the story, but it still leaves a bitter taste in the mouth. You pretty much have to use a walkthrough to find the correct path, unless you want to do trial and error with hours of your time.

I'm going to play a bit more to get some of the other endings and maybe my opinion will change then. I don't know. But I just wanted to put in my two cents since the game got such glowing reviews, and I think it is far inferior to say: Danganronpa, Phoenix Wright, The Walking Dead, Root: Double etc.

The very first game that got me into VNs in the first place - the masterpiece called "999" for the original DS. Now that the two console games are available in the Steam store, one just has to have them.

Shortly put, this "Zero Escape" series, of which "999", "VLR" and the newest (after being in developement hell), and the last part of the trilogy, the "ZTD" are part of, is a trilogy of visual novels, that have traditional VN novel-segments and branching story via players' own choices shown by a flow chart, but also room escape -segments, where you need to solve puzzles with point-and-click and crafting/inspecting mechanics to continue story.

I recommend this to those who like VNs, scifi and philosophy, room escape -gameplay, atmoshperic story and good soundtrack.

Have good time, people! Find the exit!
