I should have left a review when I've finished these games. It deserve all the praises it's getting.

There are three things I enjoy the most in media entertainment; puzzles, mystery and "last man standing" genre. This game has it all. Great story, educational and I was certainly invested for the characters, the voice acting is fantastic. I'd be lying if I say I didn't cry a few times. My favourite aspect in this game is the science bits, they threw in interesting theories and lectures here and there (which is relevant to the story), particular stuff like quantum physics and philosophy, which is interesting because you don't see subjects like this a lot, it's not something that is often explored in video games. Don't be afraid if you think you're not a smart cookie, I didn't go to university myself and I understood the story just fine.

Regardless, everything that was made into these two games, it was done right. And it is perfect.
An extremely well told story with satisfying puzzles. I reccomend tracking down the original zero escape 1 on DS because the story is better told but the PC port is absolutely worth your time.

So I don't normally write reviews seriously, most of the time it's for a joke or something silly I wrote when I was younger. Now I won't pretend that these games are flawless. The dialogue can drag on at times and the english voice acting for 999 personally was a hit or miss for me. Virtue's Last Reward has significantly better voice acting in my eyes yet I know some people might be put off by this odd cast of characters. At first glance, this seems like any other visual novel game with seemingly stereotypical characters due to design. I mean, you got the fanservice character, the "bland" protagonist, the edgy mysterious man etc. But if this is the case, why would I write about a collection of games positively if I seem to be pointing out what is wrong with it right off the bat? Because quite simply it's my favorite game.

 Yes, I know this seems like an odd choice for anyone's favorite game. I mean, if you are looking for steller gameplay and/or a compelling story, there are obviously more well known titles to choose from. E.g, Dark souls, The Binding of Isaac, TF2, even Danganronpa for the visual novel fans. It's weird to say that a game can affect you as a person due to how cringy that can be interpreted depending on the person. However I can confidently say that this series is pretty damn special despite outdated graphics and average voice acting. It's almost impossible to describe the plot without spoiling anything, much like how the other reviews list the pros and cons while still remaining vague about what the story is actually about. 

Despite this, i'll briefly state a few things about why this game is special without giving anything away which will hopefully get you to consider buying this hidden gem. Personally, while I wouldn't say that I love every single one of the characters, there is still enough development to let you appreciate most of them as a character. Don't misunderstand, this doesn't mean I actually dislike any of the characters, it's simply I like a few of them more as people. What I mean by this is while I might not actually "like" some of them, I can still respect them as an individual and understand their motivations. In addition, the introduction of each character in my eyes, shows you enough personality to be invested. 

However, the main point of the game is gameplay obviously, so I'll attempt to briefly explain how the game works. It is split into two different sections. Novel and Puzzle. With the Novel side, it's almost exclusively reading so if you ain't a fan of reading, then you might not like this game. You can read it in two different styles but I strongly reccomend reading it in "Novel" rather than "Adventure" as it adds more description to your surroundings whilst still showing you the decent artwork. I know that sounds really vague but it will make more sense if you actually play the game. Anyways, the puzzle section is an "escape the room" scenario in which you solve puzzles, kind of like Professor Layton if I had to describe it. The puzzles are sometimes decent and sometimes they will stump you. Admittedly there are a few moments where one could call "bullshit" and I would fully agree that a very small amount of puzzles can get rather illogical at times. I don't mean the room you are trapped in, but rather the puzzles themselves. If you like puzzle games, chances are you will find this enjoyable.

 To sum it all up since admittedly I can be seen as just a fanboy due to a lack of knowledge in writing game reviews, this review might just seem to you as the ramblings of a weirdo on the internet who has a fondness for a game you most likely never heard of. I must clarify how important this game is to the fandom and why this is personally my favorite game series. Back in 2012 when Virtue's Last Reward was released, the sales in Japan were awful. Because of this, the idea of a third Zero Escape game seemed like a fairytail. However, because of the fanbase's extreme love for these games (Myself included), they created a group called "Operation Bluebird" to grab the attention of the creators of Zero Escape, Spike Chunsoft to point out that there is a fanbase demanding a last installment in the series. After approximately 3 years of waiting, we finally got the finale we were desperate for. So yeah, this review might seem a bit cringy or even pointless to some yet I simply wanted to spread the love for this game series. There's a reason this is the only game I actually bother people to buy. That and Danganronpa but that's because Monokuma rocks my socks. If you read the whole thing, thanks for listening to the ramblings of a dumb fanboy.

TL:DR Good game, buy game. Favorite game for a reason. Gogogo.

Edit: Made it into paragraphs because my main boy Monokuma said so.

Si vous ne connaissez pas le genre visual novel machiavelico-dilemno-psychologique, je recommande plutot les Danganronpa, du meme studio et réalisés apres cette série des Nonary Games. Mieux foutus, jubilatoires, éclatants, tordus, loufoques et boulversants, les Dangonronpa sont supérieurs en tout points. Attention néanmoins, l'anglais est impératif pour ces 2 séries.

Ce bundle incluant les 2 premiers opus, cette évaluation les traite indivuduellement.


999 :

Le premier et le meilleur des 2 titres. Les différents concepts et énigmes autour du chiffre 9 sont très bien pensés et autant satisfaisantes à comprendre qu'a déchiffrer. Il y a de l'action et du mouvement, meme pour un visual novel; les multiples fins et scénarios reposent sur vos choix, cornéliens, et le jeu n'a aucun mal à vous faire recharger une sauvegarde pour choisir une alternative différente, ce qui est une bonne chose. 
Le scénario est très bien foutu, lisible mais pas trop, l'ambiance est oppressante sans etre étouffante, les personnages sont intéressants et la trame de fond, meme un peu trop versée occulto-mystique, saura capter votre interet et votre attention. Le rythme action-énigme-conversation est équilibré, les difficulté des puzzles va crescendo et globalement, vous serez tenus en haleine jusqu'a la fin.


Virtue Last Reward :

Il s'agit d'une suite, l'histoire reprenant concepts et personnages présents dans le premier volet. Contrairement au premier, cet opus propose une 3D propre et lisse, ce qui de mon point de vue amoindrit le charme et l'ambiance, et rend les personnages moins sympathiques et identifiables. Toujours sur la meme idée de choix influencant l'histoire, vous avez le visu sur un "arbre" des alternatives du scénario, ce qui invite évidemment la replay value. Néanmoins le rythme est beaucoup plus lent, et vous vous taperez de longues dizaines de minutes de dialogues déja entendues maintes et maintes fois dans vos sauvegardres précedentes, ce qui est un premier grand défaut du titre.
Deuxième problème, le connerie-mètre explose. La trame de fond est pétrie de concepts ésotériques fumeux qui ne manqueront pas de vous faire perdre le fil et votre attention. Le scénario progresse de découvertes d'inepties absurdes en révélations d'absurdes inepties, ce qui finira par vous faire immanquablement décrocher, dépité de ne plus rien capter.

Au final, je dirais que seul 999 vaut le coup, Virtue Last Reward ne mérite pas forcément votre attention ni votre fric.
Sinon, Danganronpa.

Do you like escape rooms? Thinking about the metaphysics of quantum theory? Games whose gameplay mechanics are actually integral to the plot? Complex characters and multiple interwoven storylines? Unexpected twists? Then the Zero Escape series is for you! 

The entire trilogy is a work of art. I don't know if I've ever played anything else quite like it, or if I ever will. Totally worth the experience.

A hell of a incredible couple of games that play with some interesting theories I've never heard of before, but needlessly, make a far more interesting interaction all together. These two games were out before the other Zero escape game that was released first on Steam.

Not only due to have multiple paths based on your choices and where you go, but due to the Morphagentic Field, it makes perfect story sense that you could view one timeline, pick up some information, then take with with you for consecutive timelines to unlock the true ending.

Both games have very interesting set ups and some very difficult puzzles, though not unfairly difficult. I recommend this to any fan of the escape room kind of game where you need to look around and attempt to find a way out of wherever you are trapped.

I skipped over this game when it was on the DS when I was younger. I didn't know if I would like it or not. And now I wish I would've had a chance to play it back then.

I have only played 999 so far, but wow was that intense.

Update: I am now about halfway through Virtue's Last Reward. I felt that it started a bit slower than 999, but once you get close to one of the first endings, it starts to pick up. BTW, if you plan on playing these games and just beating the first ending that you get and not playing anymore, this is not the way the game is meant to be played. I knew that when I played 999, all endings would be important and show me information that I wouldn't get from the others, but VLR takes this to a new level. In VLR, not only does each ending matter for you to play, but you can't get all the way through some endings without beating others. Also, you will see things happen in your current timeline that wasn't supposed to happen, but you seen it in another timeline. You will know what I mean when you see it. This is the best explanation that I can give while keeping my review spoiler free.

Final Update: Finished the second game. I am a little underwhelmed by the ending. It was really cool how they finished the game up, but they left a big plot hole that left me feeling uneasy. But they did provide tons and tons of story before then. I just really hope that Zero Time Dilemma clears up the questions that I have.

I bought the Zero Escape trilogy, because I had already beaten Danganronpa and I wanted something similar to it. Little did I know that it was the same developers. About 30 minutes into the game I minimized and had to go check to see who made it because it had way too many similarities.

The first game was great and I am looking forward to the second and third games. $45 should be about spot on for what I think the first two games are worth. Well worth the money and a great experience.

There are multiple endings and when you get the ending that you didn't want (And I promise you will) you can start over at pretty much any point in the game.

The story was very intrigueing and it seems like they used theories and philosophies that had actually been discussed in real life. And for the first time in a long time, the good ending was fulfilling. 

I think it would be great to see an anime adaptation to this game just like they did for Danganronpa.

All of your decisions will effect the ending that you get. This is one of the few "Choices Matter" games that actually have real effects from what you chose to do. As you are playing, you may miss a few conversations that are really important and when you play to go through each ending, you will get more back story. I believe each ending was as needed as the true ending. There are 6 different endings in 999 and either 18 or 19 endings in the second game.  You are able to pull up the flow chart, as I mentioned earlier, to see which ending you are progressing toward or to rewind time to fix something that you messed up.

If you are a fan of Danganronpa, psychological thrillers, great story, or visual novels, this game is a must (even at full price). I have already gotten my money's worth at full price $44.99 with 49.3 hours. If I had to guess, I will have about 65 to 70 hours total when I am finished with both games. I am not a person who likes paying full price for games, I love sales. But, if I had paid $65 for this game, I wouldn't have been mad at myself for making a bad decision.

If you are on the fence about this game like I was when I originally seen it for whatever reason ($45 is a lot of money or you aren't the biggest fan of what I mentioned above). DON'T SKIP THIS GAME! Add it to your wishlist right now and watch for a sale.

Holy shit lmao here we go

999 and Virtue's Last Reward are visual novels with various puzzles throughout, where numerous branching paths are possible depending on what choices you make. Both games feature a number of participants who are trapped in scenarios where they are forced to play deadly games, in which the deception of other participants is encouraged. No one in either of the games are quite who they seem, and while most participants may not know it, they all have a reason for being there.

While the story in these games are intriguing and the mystery is great, the explanations are incredibly complicated. Two thirds through 999 and think you've figured out the twist? You are wroooong. You'll have logic thrown at you that you never imagined would be a possibility. And if you thought 999 was convoluted, VLR has so many curveballs that it's literally impossible to preemptively guess what's going on. I still don't know wtf Phi's deal is. Maybe Zero Time Dilemma will answer this. 

While the information that the "game hosts" give you is all [i]technically[/i] true, a fair portion of that information is misleading, and the few hints you are given as to what's actually going on are exceptionally subtle. In this way, the games kind of cheat out a lot of their big reveals. On the other hand, some of the mid-way reveals are very fair and are extremely exciting once they "click" in your mind.

Good games.



Sidenotes
[list]
  [*]play 999>VLR>ZTD, because there is a lot of continuity between these games.
  [*] btw if you don't like reading, I don't recommend playing these lol
  [*]Whether it's VLR or JoJo, Dio did nothing wrong :9
[/list]

I've put 45 hours into these two games and I can honestly spend more, it was worth every penny and I don't regret buying this on a whim at all. They're amazing games and I would honestly 100% reccomend them. I did have trouble getting used to the fact they changed styles of the games but it was charming after a little while, and I loved them so much. If you're debating buying these because they're your style of game, please do!
Still a great game.  There are some finer points missing from the 999 experience which seem to have been lost in translation into a voiced piece but this is still a fantastic game.

Oh my god did they butcher an amazing puzzle game.


First, everyone needs to play "no-one has to die", the free flash game on kongregate.com. It does a very similar insane, mind-bending story with no plot holes or improbable moments. It came out after 999 and probably inspired by it, but it addresses a lot of the issues I have with 999's plot.


What seperates 999 from "no-one has to die" is the amazing puzzles. But 999 has an inexplicable urge to give away the anwser at every turn. Sometimes it's the way they present the question. Other times you fail at a puzzle and a hint comes down whether you like it or not, you won't even know it's a hint until it's too late.

This would all be solved by putting a hint button in the menu, or having a hard mode that disables hints. It's such a simple fix that I'm baffled by its absense. It's like sitting down with a really good book only to have the author come in and spoil everything.

Then there are moments where the game just explains things to you without ever making a puzzle out of it.

There's a really good game buried here. And that last puzzle UGH it's soo good! Yet ultimately, I can't recommend a puzzle game that's afraid of letting the player get stuck. That's the whole point of a puzzle!

The 2nd game, Virtue's Last Reward, thankfully tucked away its hints into an easy mode. But I got 2 hours in before realizing that it shares with 999 the same plot issue of fundamentally misunderstanding human nature. 2 hour spoilers ahead.

This game tries to recreate the prisoner's dilemma. In real life if you betray your crime partner you better hide when they get out. In this game you literally end up in the same room as the person you just betrayed! And with nowhere to run. The game keeps touting that betrayal is the logical choice, when in actuality the most logical thing you think about in such a vulnerable situation is the fear of retaliation. It's human nature to seek revenge and to fear the vengence of others. Every tribe to modern civilization has a system of punishment. It's absolutely idiotic to betray someone unless there's a chance you get away with it. The situation set up in this game leaves you zero chance of getting away >:( I cannot forgive a psychological story for ignoring a fundamental part of the human psyche.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is a bundle of remastered PC versions of the first (999) and second (Virtue's Last Reward) games in the Zero Escape series. If you enjoy 999, then you'll enjoy Virtue's Last Reward because it is very good sequel that follows in the footsteps of its predecessor thus I'll be focusing my review on 999 for the most part to avoid spoiling anything for Virtue's Last Reward.

In 999, you play the role of Junpei, a young man forced into playing a game of life and death called the Nonary Game with 8 other participants whereby everyone must solve puzzles and escape from their predicament before the time's up, however not everything is as it seems.

999 is a thriller puzzle "escape the room" visual novel where you as the player must solve "Escape the Room" style room puzzles whilst piecing together the overarching plot of the game over the course of multiple playthroughs.  

Pros
- Puzzles are fun, they are just hard enough to be interesting and rewarding while not being frustrating.
- Piecing together the intriguing overarching plot and learning more about various the characters is very enjoyable.
- One scene in particular near the end was one hell of a rollercoaster that I won't be forgetting any time soon.
- Fully voiced English VO is very well done and the script/dialogue is well written.

Cons
- Using a Keyboard and Mouse in Virtue's Last Reward is playable but a little awkward, I'm assuming because the game was originally developed for the PSP whereas 999 was developed for the more PC-like (at least in terms of controls) DS.

If you enjoy intriguing stories, good puzzles and/or unique Japanese games then you can hardly go wrong with Zero Escape: The Nonary Games.
If your still trying to decide if to get this, Get it it is well worth the money i'd even pay more. 10/10 perfect games
Brain bending puzzles, an extremely engaging and original story, and some epic plot twists that will haunt you. This is one game franchise that I cannot recommend high enough.
Clover is best waifu.

Two good VN games with some unfortunate issues that hold them down from being really incredible.

Starting with 999 i found it quite disappointing. The writing is inconsistent - some parts are very tense, others don't fit at all: jokes that just don't work, huge info dumps out of nowhere and ridiculous fictional story bits that you can't take in seriously. Characters are mostly bland too and the true ending doesn't really explain all that much in the end, so you are left wondering what the hell really happened. 
Puzzles are fun enough for player to rest a bit from all the reading, they aren't too tough if you search for a challenge though. 
Navigating through the novel in the remastered version was made to be especially easy and fun, so in order to reach new routes and all endings, you don't need to replay any puzzle or to start the game from the very beginning several times. Voiced lines for the characters also is a fantastic addition. 
 
Virtue's Last Reward fixes the problem of previous game with incosistent writing. What you will get is some of the most incedible writing i've seen in gaming with an ending that will literally blow you away with how smart it really is. The concepts that are presented in the game are more or less believable and there are no more ridiculously unbelievable tonal jumps. 
The problem is the very tedious way you will have to take in order to reach that satisfying ending. Different routes have too much of the same story bits and walls of the same text and going through all of them sometimes really bored me. You can use "text skip" function to go faster through the parts that you've already read, but it's not the most comfortable tool to make use of. The game literally is too long to remain enjoyable in all its routes and things like unskippable map travels just waste your time.

Even with their flaws, these are enjoyable visual novels with a bit of puzzle solving for variety reasons. The story that is presented in both games is pretty interesting and have some clever ideas that you'll soon be checking on google to find if they really exist (and for the most part they do except some really ridiculous ones). 
But as i mentioned, inconsistent writing in 999 and tedious structure of the game in VLR stops me from recommending this bundle to everyone. Still if you enjoy twisted, clever stories you should give these games a try, just don't expect a masterpiece like many people suggest that these games are, have moderate expectations and you might have some incredible time with these two games.

数学的なパズルを楽しむためのゲームに壮大なスケールのお話がついてくる、脱出ゲームとして非常にクオリティの高いものだと感じました。

過去にいくつかのハードでリリースされた『極限脱出ADV』シリーズをPC版にリメイクしたもので、ボイスの付加、グラフィックの高画質化、プレイアビリティの向上などが成されているようなので、単純にゲームデータとして見るならばこのバージョンが決定版になっている感じでしょうか。


ただ、これはオリジナルの仕様からそうらしいですが、『善人シボウデス』に関して移動演出の冗長さと操作のレスポンスの悪さを感じました。
また、よくジョイスティック系のドライバーと変な競合を起こしているようで、スレッドを見ると公式がやたらに「vJoyのせいです」の一点張りなのですが、私の環境だとLogicoolの左手キーボードG13と競合を起こしていました。
競合が起きるとゲーム進行に割と大事なフローチャート機能などが上手く動かないのでその辺は注意が必要です。

あと、難易度HARDモードでクリアした『善人シボウデス』に関してクリア後にいろいろレビューを見ていると、HARDだとヒントだけでなく他愛のないキャラクター同士の掛け合いなども大分削られている、とのことだったので
設定ファイルを多めに拾うのか、キャラクターの会話をより楽しむか、の兼ね合いで難易度【HARD/EASY】を決めるのも大切なのかなと思います。


などなど仕様の面で不満点は多々あったのですが、
非常に気合いの入ったゲームだったのは間違いないのでおすすめです。

Where to begin?

If you're a fan of puzzles or mysteries, or just want a good story, this game is for you. If you want great, memorable characters, top tier comedy, or a dark narrative, this game is for you.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games is a masterpiece in every sense of the word. Both the games in this collection are mindblowing. I won't go too deep into the games, but just know that this series has some of the best storytelling to come from a video game. It `combines elements of horror, mystery, sci-fi, psychology, and comedy all the while telling a narrative that is out of this world.

I absolutely recommend this game to everyone, and I hope that one day we'll get another mystery visual novel as good as this.

[spoiler] Tu fui, ego eris. [/spoiler]

我是因为零时困境才接触这系列游戏的，零时困境中的决策游戏，平行世界理论，以及出色的密室逃脱推理都很合我的胃口。作为零时困境的前作，999和主线故事关联不大，更像是这一系列的前传。而对于先接触零时困境的我来说，善人死亡中的很多剧情都可以预料到，这确实少了许多趣味。999的数字根游戏和善人死亡的AB游戏很容易让人理解，也更加有趣。这系列的作品更像是一部软科学佳作，它对于科学方面不够严谨，但故事中两代主人公的经历确实很大程度上填补了这方面的不足。总的来说这还是一款不可多得的佳作。但是有一句话我一定要说，一定不要先玩零时困境，这会极大影响游戏体验。（本人亲自体验）

在经历了48小时的听力，以及数万字的英文阅读理解后，我竟成了一个解密游戏迷
精彩的剧情，神奇的展开，一定要拒绝任何形式的剧透
不入后悔，入了，你就脱不了坑了
不多说，剁手第三部去了

got these games as a present and i was HOOKED from the very start. at times i had to slog on through the masses and masses of scientific babble but that's just my terrible attention span. totally would recommend!

借着移植的机会重温了一遍999+善死，虽然有些坑确实没填好，但依然是很棒的游戏。即使知道了剧情，谜底揭开时仍然有寒毛倒竖的感觉。999新加了配音很良心，美雪姐姐的幼茜真是太棒了！[strike]所以什么时候动画化，好想看会动的phi酱[/strike]

[spoiler]999分成ADV模式和NOVEL模式还是没有NDS的双屏直观，不过考虑到平台因素也是无奈的选择，还是能表现出双视角的概念的。但是最终谜题为什么要改，数独有什么不好的吗……[/spoiler]
If you like puzzle games, vizual novels and drama/murder mystery this game is right down your alley. Great game for those interested in the genre.

An amazing game filled with so many twists and turns

10/10 would reccomend
gud games would reccomend

I’m not sure I’ve ever been so disappointed in a video game series ever.  The general plot is that 9 strangers get trapped in basically a Saw like death game, except there is actually a story unlike Saw. 

999 is for the most part a fantastic game.  The puzzles are well designed and although the plot gets bonkers at points the actual murder mystery is very well constructed.  The mystery relies on actual things like motive and evidence.  You could literally use clues to solve the mystery.  It was so competently done I was quite impressed.  Most games botch telling murder mysteries to an insane degree…because they will rely on ludicrous twists or information that is never conveyed to the player.  Everything that 999 does right the 2 sequels do wrong to just a stunning degree.

I will say I disliked the very animey tropes in this game.  Clover and Lotus are just horribly handled from the way they are dressed to how infantile Clover is made…despite the fact she is supposedly 18.  June comes off as a psychopath.  I think they were trying to make her flirty…but that came across as disturbing when you are trapped in a death game.

[spoiler] The time travel elements are handled well.  I enjoyed how it worked, but I did not like the ending that this paradox existed where June is both alive and dead…sigh.  Also the True Ending where Alice shows up is just weird.  [/spoiler] If 999 was a stand alone game I would definitely recommend it though, because it’s part of a series and literally ends on a cliff hanger I simply can’t.

Virtues Last Reward on the other hand is just a blatant mess.  The puzzles are all terrible.  The solutions are either utterly devoid of logic or extremely complex math puzzles.  I solved every puzzle in 999 and enjoyed them, in Virtues Last Reward I just used a walkthrough on every puzzle, they are just awful.  The only thing worse is the plot.

[spoiler] What can I say.  This plot is a train wreck.  I also solved basically every single thing within the first hour and the game is a good 40 hours.  So it was a grueling slog, trying to get through, hoping that the game would pleasantly surprise me.  It did not.  Dio being the murderer was blatantly obvious, like seriously the guy constantly betrays everyone of course he’s the murderer.  I guess I sure didn’t see it coming that he worked for a secret cult that was bent on wiping out everyone in the world and helped release a virus that killed almost everyone on planet Earth and now the survivors live on the Moon.  I thought it was very obvious they lived on the Moon…so that wasn’t a surprise, but the fact that a bio weapon wiped out Earth was just stupid…they then say, well it wasn’t really the bioweapon, but the nuclear reactors of the planet being overloaded. Ugh, it’s so painfully bad.  It was also obvious Luna was a robot and that Tenmioji was really Junpei from the future, and that the old woman was Akane.  It was painful waiting 40 hours for the characters to reveal what was so obvious from the start. [/spoiler]

It was just so disappointing.  I was hoping for a competent murder mystery again, what I got was an insane scifi story that never managed to capture my interest.  The fact it suffers from the same anime tropes of the first game did not help.  Why for god sakes does Alice only wear a necklace as her clothes, why is Clover in a bikini, why does Clover still act like a child despite being 19, why did the game think they needed some weird kid character running around.  Ugh, I guess this series was not meant for me.

Also, I’m not sure if the game creators never actually read what the prisoners dilemma was…or if they just meant for the characters to be stupid.  So, the main death trap in the game involves the prisoners dilemma where people have to vote Ally or Betray and those that vote ally/ally are rewarded a little and the those that vote betray/betray get nothing and those that vote ally/betray have the ally punished and the betrayer rewarded.  So I of course picked Ally…but then all characters flip out on you for being stupid and not understanding how the prisoners dilemma works…except that is the correct choice.  This game isn’t the regular prisoners dilemma scenario, it’s the repeating prisoners dilemma.  In the repeating prisoners dilemma the only solution is to ally/ally.  Whole books have been written explaining this…so either the creator didn't know this…or they purposely meant for all other characters in the game to be idiots.  The whole time I was waiting for someone to explain how in a repeating prisoners dilemma scenario those that pick betray always lose.  I guess it doesn’t matter, because in the end it really had nothing to do with the game because it really has no impact on it. You have to go down all the paths anyway and there is no actual right choice, but it sure disappointed me.
Amazing visual novel. Great stories especially, you won't be disappointed!

Great story. Played 999 on DS, VLR on Vita and now both of them on PC.
Won't recommend it because it's a very bad port, with all sorts of nuisances, like bugs, freezes and crashes. Devs are kinda slow, as there are very few fixes and updates.
In my case, on VLR, every few minutes played, the sound mutes, and right after that, the game freezes and all that's left to do is close it. [not solved yet - aug/2017]
The point is, I payed full console price for a game that's full of bugs and almost unplayable. Will japanese devs ever going to learn how PC gaming works?
Grab it on a sale <75%

While I enjoyed both 999 and VLR, I would have to say that VLR has been my favorite in the series. 999 is a good introduction to characters and the premise of the nonary games and character Zero, which is adopted in VLR and Zero Time Dilemma. 

The story in 999 kept me wanting more and striving to get every ending. However, it was frustrating for me because I couldn't jump to points in the narrative to change my decisions. You have to sit through the whole story over again and skip through bits you've already heard. I understand the mechanic, because you need to make some decisions during dialogue which affect what ending you get, but it was still frustrating having to listen to the same beginning of the game over and over again. Granted, there is a feature where you can skip the dialogue, but it isn't as convenient as in VLR. 

VLR, on the other hand, allows you to skip directly to decision-making points in the game to alter the histories (thanks for the change on that, Spike Chunsoft!). Moreover, the story is much more compelling and kept me on the edge of my seat. The ending could use some work, but I understand why the devs may have left it at such an anti-climactic point. 

Anyway, go ahead and get this package and play both these games. It provides over 50 hours of content that you won't regret.
剧情紧凑，情节出人意料，如果你喜欢烧脑的科幻和悬疑题材，请不要错过这款游戏。

一切开始于从同学那里借来的3DS，在找游戏的时候正好ACG汉化组出了善人死亡的汉化。再一查，才发现前作是大名鼎鼎的999。于是乎就在ACG汉化组的指引下玩完了三部曲（笑）。
言归正传，这次steam的重制版是一二部的合集，我买的是三部曲的合集，刚出的时候还附送ost，就怀着补票的心情买了。和原作最大的不同就是999追加了声优（美雪姐姐的声音太好听了=w=），在没有中文的情况下为了声优硬是啃了下来，二三部和原作没有差别就没有再玩过了。还有就是999加了流程图，唯一的好处就是流程解锁后不用完全重玩，不过为节省时间还是查下攻略比较好。最后结局的解谜真的莫名其妙，相比原作逊色很多。
从游戏内容来说，个人认为是打越最成功的作品了，相比之前的名作ever17来说，极限脱出对不同世界线的解释更加清楚（尤其是善人死亡和零时困境），代入感也更强。游戏里时不时的强行科普一些似是而非的理论，给我的脑袋造成了很大的负担（笑）[spoiler]打越你要负泽[/spoiler]。这也是玩这部游戏的乐趣之一。
总的来说这是一部很有趣的作品，喜欢解谜的一定要来试试。
[h1]八卦[/h1]

『9時間9人9の扉』と続編の『善人シボウデス』がセットになったゲームです。
DSなどの携帯ゲーム機を持っていなくてもプレイできるのが素晴らしいですありがとう感謝！

■9時間9人9の扉
ゼロと名乗る謎の人物に拉致された9人の男女が、命懸けのデスゲームに挑むADVゲームです。
キャラクターが会話しながら進んでいくノベルパートと、パズルを解く脱出パートを交互に繰り返していきます。
ゲームのギミックとして「数字根」を取り入れており、若干頭を使わせながらも、デスゲームによくある不自由さや理不尽さをうまく表現できているなと思います。
脱出パートのギミックは難易度が低めではありますが、どちらかというとストーリーに重きを置いているようなので、サクサク進められてかえって良かったように感じました。
ストーリー上の仕掛けも凝っており、盛り上がりやそこに至るプロットも面白かったです。賛否はありそうですが…。
今回のダブルパック収録に当たって、解像度の向上やボイス追加、フローチャート実装などのプレイビリティの向上も図られており、かなりプレイしやすかったと思います。

■善人シボウデス
ゼロと名乗る謎の人物に拉致された9人の男女が、命懸けのデスゲームに挑むADVゲームです（2回目）。
基本的な流れは前作と同じです。ギミックの難易度が若干上がったかな？くらいです。
ストーリー的には前作以上に賛否が分かれそうな感じがしますが、「ダンガンロンパ」のようなケレン味のあるゲームが好きな方にはウケると思います。
あらゆるところに伏線が張ってあるので、タネ明かしシーンは驚きの連続でした。
ただ、演出が冗長なところや、似たような展開のルートを何回も通らないといけないところはちょっとストレスがたまりました。
なお999は単作でも一応の決着がついていますが、シボウデスは999のストーリーを前提にしている上、結末も「続編へ続く！」という感じになっているので、続編であり完結編の「zero escape zero time dilemma（ZERO ESCAPE 刻のジレンマ）」も必ず買いましょう。Steamで売っています。
Stop wasting your time reading pointless reviews. Just play it.

I give this game a 10 out of "Kyu".

999 is a great game, and so is VLR.

If you're a purist, or want to play the game as it was originally intended and in its completely unaltered form, make sure you play 999 on the DS. Don't look into why, just do it. If you find voice acting and having a flowchart to be vital to your experience, then go with the nonary games, but make sure that you play it in "novel" mode the entire time, or you'll miss over 3/4 of the text and ruin the experience for yourself.

That being said, don't play 999 for its gameplay/puzzles. They are terrible for the most part and essentially solve themselves. Play it entirely for the story. 

Play VLR for its story and gameplay. Buy this collection for VLR alone if you've chosen to experience the DS version of 999 through *other* methods that I cannot discuss here.

Unfortunately, there's not much else to say without getting into spoiler territory. Both are fantastic stories, but only VLR has consistently good puzzles (save for a few). Do play ZTD when you finish VLR, as well.

Absolutely phenominal. I love the story so much. It gave me literal shivers down my spine. I recommend playing in Visual Novel mode however because it narrarates extra things that advanced mode doesn't pick up. Literally the best visual novel I have ever played.

10 "третьих глаз" из 10

This is definitely a recommended purchase; when you buy this bundle, you are receiving two of the most mind-blowing adventures you will ever play through.  Both games feature an overarching theme of multiple timelines, as well as the question of what would happen if one could access infomation from these sorts of parallel universes.  The entire Zero Escape storyline is a classic tale that will certaily withstand the test of time, and it is the type of story that is best left unspoiled.  The best thing to do is to go in blind and let the mysteries be discovered on your own.

Since this is the first time either of these games have been released on a platform other than a handheld, they have been adequately optimized for multiple types of HD displays.  999 in particular has been given a fine-tuned remaster, with crisp HD artwork and solid voice acting for all of the characters.  To sum it all up, this bundle is well worth the price, regardless of whether or not it's on sale.

[h1]Zero Escape: Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors [/h1]
also simply call as 999, is the first entry of the Zero Escape trilogy, the next two respectively being Virtue's Last Reward and Zero Time Dilemma.

The Nintendo DS version, the first version of the game, was developed by Chunsoft and published in Japan by Spike on December 10, 2009, and in North America by Aksys Games on November 16, 2010. On March 24, 2017, Zero Escape: The Nonary Games, a bundle pack containing a remastered version of 999 with voice acting and a port of Virtue's Last Reward was released for the PlayStation Vita / PlayStation TV, PlayStation 4 and PC.

[h1]Synopsis[/h1]
The story follows Junpei, a college student who is abducted along with eight other people and forced to play the "Nonary Game," which puts its participants in a life-or-death situation, to escape from a sinking cruise liner. The gameplay alternates between two types of sections: Escape sections, where the player completes puzzles in escape-the-room scenarios; and Novel sections, where the player reads the game's narrative and makes decisions that influence the story, making it branch into six different endings. The whole plot is not revealed in just one playthrough; the player has to reach the one "true" ending to get all the information.

As for 9 Persons 9 Hours 9 Doors I'd give it a 8/10. 
I originally played this one to completion on the DS. I loved it! The puzzles well thought out, it fit the tone of each area of the game. The story, being trapped on a ship with 8 other people and slowly piecing together why each person is there and how to escape (Preferrably with as many people as possible), was a great concept as a narritive visual novel. As for this version of the game, I love the voice casting for this one a lot, I appriciate that the voice actors voiced all of the lined of dialouge outside of the escape sections, just like VLR and ZTD. The improved UI, but most importantly (Especially if you intend on running through all of the endings) is the inclusion of the flowchart introduced in Virtue's Last Reward. (I think) they changed several lines of dialouge from the original, (or I SHIFTed to a universe where the dialouge is initially different), but I suppose doesn't matter overall.

Virtue's Last Reward... I think it's a 10/10
I LOVED that game, perhaps it was the inclusion of more psuedoscience, more quantum physics/ quantum mechanics, paradoxes, and much more difficult puzzles than the first, accompanied by the same intriguing premise, being trapped, and needing to escape. However, the most intriguing part of VLR (In My Opinion) is the inclusion of the Ambidex Game. The Ambidex Game is a simple voting game based off of The Prisoner's Dilemma. I think this one improved so much over the first.

Really well made game!
100/10!
Would recommend!

I didn't know what to expect when I bought the Nonary Game pack, I mostly wanted to see why the reviews were so high from the public at over 90%...I'm so glad I decided to play these two games! The sci-fi twists and nods to theories from fiction books and scientific theories began to make sense as you delve deeper into the game, and overall it made for an entertaining and fun experience.

I highly recommend the game to any puzzle, sci-fi or story-themed game enthusiasts and Zero Time Dilemma is a delightfully scary way to end the series!

Zwei Spiele zum Preis von einem. Hörte sich nach einem guten Deal an. Jetzt wo ich beide durchgespielt habe, wäre mir eines der beiden sogar den Preis für zwei Spiele wert.

Um etwas Verwirrung aufzuklären: 999 und Virtue's Last Reward sind die ersten beiden Teile der Zero Escape Reihe. Der dritte Teil - Zero Time Dilemma - ist zwar schon letztes Jahr auf Steam erschienen, allerdings handelt es sich bei The Nonary Games um einen Port älterer Spiele. Besonders bei 999 merkt man an einer gewissen Stelle auch, dass es eigentlich für die zwei Bildschirme eines Nintendo DS ausgelegt ist, weswegen hier gesagt sei: Der "Adventure Mode" war auf einem Bildschirm zu sehen, der "Novel Mode" auf dem anderen. Meine persönliche Empfehlung ist hierbei, das Spiel auf "Novel Mode" zu spielen.

Aber worum geht es bei Zero Escape eigentlich? In beiden Teilen werden 9 Leute entführt und gegen ihren Willen von einem gewissen "Zero" dazu gezwugen das Nonary Game zu spielen, wobei sich die genauen Regeln in den beiden Teilen unterscheiden. Eines bleibt jedoch gleich: Regelverletzungen führen zur spontanen Exekution! Das hält die Spannung während beider Spiele konstant aufrecht, insbesondere dadurch, dass es für die Spieler von Vorteil sein kann, ihre Mitspieler zu beseitigen.

Beide Spiele bestehen haupsächlich aus Folgendem:

[b]Escape the Room[/b]
Löse diverse Rätsel in einem abgeschlossenen Raum um dem Schlüssel zu finden, der die Tür öffnet.
Die Rätsel gehen von einfach bis mittelschwer, wobei das größte Hindernis nicht die Rätsel selbst sind, sondern die eigene Müdigkeit, wenn man mal wieder bis spät in die Nacht einfach nicht aufhören kann, da man wissen muss, wie es weiter geht.

[b]Entscheidungen[/b]
Entscheidungen treten immer wieder auf und verleihen dem Spiel durch die vielen darauf basierenden Enden einen sehr hohen Wiederspielwert. Der soganannte Flow-Chart erlaubt sowohl einen guten Überlick über alle Wege durchs Spiel, als auch das direkte Springen zu bestimmten Abschnitten, wodurch man nicht für ein alternatives Ende von Anfang an neu Spielen muss. Sieht man trotzdem etwas zweimal, gibt es die Skip-Funktion, die ab Teil 2 automatisch jeden Dialog vorspult, den man schon gesehen hat.

[b]Visual Novel[/b]
Mit Text-Boxen als Untertitel und detailierten Charakter-Modellen wird die Geschichte voll synchronisiert erzählt. Das ist der eigentliche Kern des Spiels: Die grandiose und spannende Geschichte. Wer steckt hinter den Nonary Games? Was ist deren Zweck? Wer meiner Mitspieler plant einen Mord? Das ganze Spiel über stellt man sich Fragen und die Antworten sind fast nie das was man erwartet hätte.

Hier kommt auch schon der Hauptunterschied zwischen den beiden Spielen, was es etwas schwerer macht, beide auf einmal zu bewerten: Die Geschichte.

[b]Die Geschichte in Teil 1[/b], so spannend sie auch sein mag, ist voll mit diversen Plotholes. Insbesondere gewisse Enden ergeben auf den zweiten Blick sehr wenig Sinn. [spoiler] z.B. warum niemand auf die Idee kommt, die Armbänder der Verstorbenen zu verwenden NACHDEM es schon erwiesen ist, dass dies funktioniert.[/spoiler] Auch gewisse Enhüllungen stören mich enorm beim "True Ending". [spoiler]Die Anzeige eines gewissen Armbands hat überhaut keinen direkten Bezug auf dessen wahren Wert, es gibt ein paar Armbänder doppelt und der wahre Wert eines Armbands impliziert, dass die Person Zero ist, während die andere Person mit dem gleichen Armband es nicht ist. [/spoiler] Dennoch ist man quasi an den Stuhl gefesselt und muss einfach wissen wie es weitergeht. Ein Aspekt sticht hierbei besonders hervor: Die Spielregeln des Nonary Games erlauben es, auszurechnen, wer einen Mord begangen haben könnte. Nicht selten saß ich mit Stift und Papier vor dem Computer und habe herumgerechnet und es letztlich auch herausgefunden, ohne das es im Spiel schon erwähnt wurde. Das war eine faszinierende Erfahrung, die ich so noch nicht erlebt habe.
Ein weiterer erwähnenswerter Aspekt war die Schwierigkeit des allerletzten Rätsels. Ich persönlich habe die Lösung sofort gesehen, was an sich ziemlich schlecht wäre, würde es nicht so hervorragend in die Geschichte rund um [spoiler]danger und epiphany[/spoiler] passen. Falls es also mit Absicht so konzipiert war, dass man sofort die Lösung sehen kann, dann Hut ab!

[b]Die Geschichte von Teil 2[/b] setzt Maßstäbe sondergleichen. Ich übertreibe in keinstem Maß, wenn ich sage, dass sie jegliche Geschichte die ich vorher erleben durfte bei weitem in dem Schatten stellt. So viele Plottwists und Überraschung selbst im wer-weiß-wie-vielten Durchlauf sind einfach nur Atemberaubend. Zum Teil rechnet man damit, dass eine Stelle genauso seien wird, wie im letzten Durchlauf und dann ist sie komplett anders. Und kennt man die gesamte Geschichte, ergibt es durchaus Sinn, warum es komplett anders ist. Aus diesem Grund ist [b]das mehrmalige Spielen ein absolutes Muss[/b] um auch nur im Ansatz in den vollen Genuss des Spiels zu kommen. Auch überrascht das Spiel an mehreren Stellen, an denen man endlich die Antwort auf Fragen wie "Wer ist Zero?" oder "Wer ist das unter dieser Maske?" erwartet mit komplett anderen Enthüllungen, die nochmal nochmehr Fragen aufwerfen, die letztlich im "True Ending" beantwortet werden.
Das beinhaltet noch nicht einmal die nervenaufreibenen Entscheidungen, die man im sogenannten Ambidex Game, ein Minigame im Nonary Game, treffen muss, welches auf dem berühmten Gefangenen-Dilemma basiert. Und obwohl das Ambidex Game immer nur die selben zwei Möglichkeiten anbietet (Ally und Betray) ist die Situation jedes mal eine andere, was jedes einzelne Mal zu einer nervenaufreibenden Angelegenheit macht.

[h1] Fazit [/h1]
[b] Positiv [/b]
+ Sehr spanndene Geschichte, der zahlreichen Plotholes zutrotz (999)
+ Mit weitem Abstand die beste Geschichte, die ich je erlebt habe (Virtue's Last Reward)
+ Plottwists ohne Ende, selbst bei vermeitlich ähnlichen Abschnitten
+ Zahlreiche witzige Dialoge
+ Voll synchronisiert in Story-Abschnitten und mit exzellenten Synchronsprechern
+ Zahlreiche nervenaufreibende Entscheidungen mit zahlreichen komplett verschiedenen Enden
+ Skip-Funktion zum überspringen bereits gesehener Dialoge
+ Enormer Wiederspielwert
+ Stellenweise sehr gute musikalische Untermalung der Szenerie
+ Funktioniert ausschließlich als Spiel. Buch, Serie, Film etc. könnte der Geschichte niemals gerecht werden

[b] Negativ [/b]
- Rätsel manchmal zu leicht
- Keine Hotspot-Anzeige wenn man etwas nicht finden kann
- Plotholes
- Nur in japanisch und englisch
- Nicht einzeln erwerbar
- Sorgt für Schlafmangel

Stunning! I was initially sceptical to the high asking price, but very few games has kept me going for 50 hours, and I am likely to give this one another spin in a few years.

999 has a very unique charm. The animated 2D sprites, handpainted backdrops, simple numeric rules and strong cast is incredible. That is not to say that VLR is anything less than amazing though. The 3D animation and scenery is rather sterile in comparison, the rules are overly complicated and the cast is somewhat unlikable. But the story is more focused, the voting feature continously sparks tension and keeps the game alive for a staggering 30-40 hours.

The fact this bundle has both 999 and VLR you are in for a serious treat! They really are both high tier visual novels with a well thoughtout plot and one that will keep you guessing. If you aren't familar to VNs you may find it hard to get into, I remember first playing 999 and struggling, but stick with it you will be treated with a series with some serious wows and wdfness.

So I hesitated to buy the game since even in sale it did still coust 31 Euros. After 17 hours I have now completed 999 with all the endings and I can say that it's money well spent! It's a visual novel so there is a lot to read but it's never boring (during the replays you can fast skip through conversations so it doesn't get too annoying) and the puzzles in between mix it up a bit. Those are interesting and neither too easy nor too hard I think. Now the story is the really interesting part: during the game you are able to make decisions and you can follow your progress in a flowchart....you should play all the endings to get the full experience and that works together really great! For each way you gather different information and once you get the real ending it all fits together and makes (somewhat) sense! I was blown away and couldn't stop thinking about the game.....so yeah that's why I write the review. It is maybe a bit pricy compared to other games but I didn't regret it since it was a unique game and an unforgettable experience....can't wait to play through VLR!

This game surpasses all my expectations. I completed it 100% in 2 days because I was so addicted to it. Honestly, I was startled with how the game was done. Everything was perfect. From the characters to the complexity of the plot. At first you may think: "These characters have nothing to do with each other and wtf are they doing here?" But as the story progresses, everything becomes clear. I had so much fun playing it. The interactions between the characters, the thoughts of the main character, the "escape the room" scenes, all the mysteries... This is definitely a must-play. The best visual novel type game I've played so far, and I doubt anything will be better than Zero Escape. If you played Danganronpa and enjoyed it, you might as well try and play Zero Escape, the main plot is similar (but totally different in some aspects) and if you're looking for a more mature storyline, then Zero Escape is the way to go. 10/10 ♥

I've put 17 hours into this in less than a week just to complete the story of the first game (all endings, including the true ending), and even with that I would probably consider this package to be worth the money based on the quality of the writing by itself, let alone the puzzles and gameplay, and I haven't even touched the second game yet!

Okay, when I say gameplay, I really do mean just the puzzles, since this is VERY heavy on the "novel" side of "visual novel", but the puzzles do keep things interesting. Either way...

If you've ever wondered what Saw would be like if it were an anime that also had a weird obsession with history, conspiracy theories, and philosophy (a combination I certainly couldn't have come up with) then this is the game for you. And if not, well, how about an extremely tightly-written choose-your-own-adventure book, but written for adults that has breaks in the narration for you to excape death traps and locked rooms?

I'm not quite as good about commenting on the visual novel aspect since I don't really PLAY visual novels, but, again, 17 hours in the first game alone in less than a week. I can safely say it's been a while since an actual novel was that engrossing for me.

Which isn't to mention the enhancements to both games from their originals, at least as far as I'm aware, since I never played the originals. Based on what I've read about them, this is definitely the definitive package with quality-of-life enhancements (a flowchart of choices and rooms for the first game, for instance), fixing of typographical errors, and the addition of full voice acting in both English and Japanese (prefer dubs over subs or vice versa? Who cares?! Both are here and both are actually pretty good).

I'd have more to write, but I still have to play Virtue's Last Reward, which as far as I'm aware from most accounts is an even better sequel to an already amazing game. As said before, the first game by itself with these enhancements is worth the money, especially on sale, but stacking on top of THAT an even better sequel? Highly recommended.

Para comenzar en el mundo de las novelas visuales, puede que estos títulos (999 y VLR) sean un poco pesados, pero vale la pena intentarlo.
Deberás usar la lógica todo el tiempo para resolver los diversos puzzles que encontrarás, y deberás leer atentamente murallas y murallas de diálogos para entender lo que está sucediendo o te perderás por completo. 
Lo bueno, es que la forma de narrar las cosas está muy bien hecha, y si no te pones a presionar rápido el botón para saltar los textos no te perderás en ningún momento (de todos modos el juego te da la opción de leer los diálogos que pasaste recientemente por si acaso).

¿Giros argumentales? Los hay, y valen la pena. Pero deberás terminar el juego varias veces para encontrarlos (que está diseñado para que sea así, no hay de otra).
¿Una buena trama que enganche? Claro, aunque hay algo a destacar. Todo comienza de una forma bastante realista, donde te puedes poner en los zapatos del protagonista, pero a medida que avanza la trama te van metiendo un montón de cienca ficción propia del juego, y cuando veas que están ocurriendo cosas que en la vida real no son posibles pues... deberás aceptarlo y ya, seguirle la lógica. Pero la sensación de inmersión en la historia puede que se pierda un poco en ese punto.
¿Lo vale? Totalmente, los puzzles son unos buenos desafíos mentales acompañados de una trama llena de preguntas que se van aclarando poco a poco.

Si puedes manejarte leyendo inglés, y estás dispuesto a ser paciente y un buen lector, no puedo ver que alguien termine sin gustarle esto.

I've played these games before on DS and 3DS, they're great games if you like story and puzzles surrounding a murder mystery. Is it worth $40? I don't really think so. If you are the type that thinks about plot holes too much, it could sway your opinion of the title, but I really enjoyed it. Wait for a sale.

Edit:
-A change in 999 from DS to PC

One of the puzzles had been completely changed in the port. Without going into spoilers, I was okay with it at first, but reflecting on it, it felt as though it was insulting my intelligence-- not just my intelligence but a child's intelligence. Imagine a word with one character replaced with a number, and without looking for more than a second, you knew exactly what word it was spelling. This makes any remaining numbers or letters inside the cells above have almost no use or meaning. Afterwords, imagine having all the pieces of a hidden puzzle, and nowhere have you been given an extra password to fill in this box. It wasn't a problem that existed in the original, but perhaps since it was a popular puzzle, the developers maybe assumed it could easily be done by anyone at ANY age in a given TIME LIMIT.

Junpei acorda numa cabine de navio que está sendo tomada pela água. Ele descobre uma maneira de escapar de lá dentro, mas percebe que o navio inteiro é uma prisão. Junto com outros 8 estranhos, ele se vê colocado em um jogo macabro montado por uma pessoa mascarada chamada Zero. Ele avisa pelo sistema de som que o navio irá afundar em 9 horas e que eles estão em um jogo de vida ou morte. Cada indivíduo possui um dispositivo com um alagarismo e para sair de lá, eles precisam usar seus dispositivos como chave para passar pelas portas do navio. Quem conseguir passar pela porta de número 9 estará livre.

Ao longo da noite, Junpei e os outros descobrirão que eles foram escolhidos por um motivo para estar lá. Cabe ao jogador fazer as escolhas como Junpei e tentar sair vivo de lá. As escolhas levam a diversos finais, e achar o verdadeiro final depende de aprender com os erros das escolhas passadas. A história é recheada de momentos onde teorias científicas são discutidas e fatos históricos reais norteiam alguns momentos. O clima é de suspense. Algumas revelações te surpreenderão, você se sentirá compelido a entender o que se passa e provavemente vai se pegar refletindo sobre os acontecimentos durante algum tempo depois de concluí-lo. Este é um jogo que provavelmente figurará entre as melhores histórias que você já jogou.

O jogo é basicamente uma história que vai se desenrolando e você acompanha o ponto de vista de Junpei. Você tomará as decisões por ele e resolverá os quebra-cabeças que estão por trás de cada porta que seu grupo abre. E enquanto desvenda os quebra-cabeças, lê os diálogos que as situações trazem, se envolverá com os personagens e se identificará com alguns deles.

Este é um port remasterizado de um jogo original do Nintendo DS. As músicas e os efeitos sonoros colocam você no clima perfeito. As animações são simples, mas não prejudicam sua experiência, que trata de você entrar na história e se envolver com a trama e os personagens. Recomendo que você jogue usando o audio japonês (detestei a interpretação dos atores em inglês).

I refunded the game thinking they removed so much of the narrative but I was wrong, the game has now 2 different types of screens, the "ADV screen" and the "Novel screen". Make sure you switch to "Novel screen" as soon as you start playing and stay on that screen as the "ADV screen" only displays dialogue and NOTHING ELSE, if you stay on this screen you'll miss all the extra bits that can help to figure out certain details that allow you to find all the endings and figure out the entire story top to bottom.
Happy gaming.

Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors and Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward, released together on Steam as Zero Escape: The Nonary Games, comprise the first two thirds of the Zero Escape series, and story-wise, they are a pair of really fascinating sci-fi thrillers. Granted, parts of these games can be dull, such as when you are repeating events that happened slightly different in other timelines, when the games beat the player over the head with basic, obvious explanations, and the oddly frequent amount of padding. When these games excell in the story department, however, they really excell.

Mechanically, they are also very much worth playing. These games exploit branching storylines in a way not seen in many others, and the adventure game and puzzle segments are consistently top notch.

If you're willing to invest the forty or so hours that these two games last, they come highly recommended.

Zero Escape: The Nonary Games est une compilation de deux jeux initialement sorti sur Nintendo DS (le jeu 999) et sur 3DS (le jeu VLR : Virtue's Last Reward). 
 On a ici deux jeux de type Visual Novel (VN) avec quelques phases de puzzles et d'énigmes plus ou moins corsés, ceux ci sont assez accesibles dans 999 et plus corsés surtout vers la fin pour VLR. Ce qui va faire la force du jeu ce sont les différents choix et chemins  possibles qui vont former le scénario : il sera nécessaire de faire TOUT les embrechements et choix possibles pour pouvoir comprendre l'histoire dans les moindres détails. Si vous vous contentez que d'un chemin vous n'allez pas comprendre certaines situtations nécessitant d'avoir fait d'autres choix dans le passé.

 Je vais éviter de trop parler du scénario qui est le point fort de ces deux jeux et surtout pour des VN. Mais celui ci est tout bonnement génial pour les deux jeux, la première fois qu'on fait une des fins on se pose pleins de questions ce qui va nous "forcer" a faire les autres fins pour trouver des réponses et un conclusion a tout ces événements. Il y a beaucoup dé révélations innatendus avec un rythme bien soutenue et servi par une histoire haletante et des personnages charismatiques, un des meilleurs scénario que j'ai vu dans ce type de jeu.

Le portage des deux jeux est assez bons, les deux jeux tournent a 60 fps sans gros soucis. On a le choix entre diverses résolutions courantes et quelques options graphiques pour VLR.
Les sprites de 999 ont été revus pour s'adapter a nos résolutions sur PC, celui ci étant sur DS a la base, sa aurait pu etre mieux détaillés mais sa reste très correct. Pour VLR, les contours des personnages sont soignés et les textures revus a la hausse, par contre vu que c'est un portage d'un jeu 3DS les personnages manquent d'animations de de détails mais cela ne gache pas le plaisir du jeu. Par contre j'aurai aimé qu'il garde les "dessins en 2D" comme dans 999, question de préférence.
 Par contre je trouve dommage que l'interface n'est pas été mieux revus, on sent qu'on est sur un jeu DS avec certains onglets trop gros pour nos écrans mais passeraient bien sur du tactile et la résolution de certains puzzles qui seraient plus pratiquent sur un écran tactile. J'ai jouer a la majorité du jeu a la manette qui est plus agréable pour le coté VN mais j'ai du passer a la souris sur certains puzzles ou je devaient déplacer des objets ou rentrer des chiffres/lettres, la sensibilité et la précision de la manette n'aidant pas pour ces phaes la.
On notera que les deux jeux sont doublé de voix japonaises (surement en anglais aussi), ce qui est pas mal pour l'immerssion.

A conseiller a tout les fans de VN ou a ceux qui cherchent un excellent scénario avec un gameplay simple basé sur des puzzles.A signaler que le jeu est intégralement en anglais et demande un bon niveau pour tout comprendre.

Points positifs :

-Deux jeux avec des scénarios complétements dingues.
-On est obligé de faire quasiment toutes les fins pour comprendre toute l'histoire.
-Une liste de personnages attachants et ayant chacun une personalité bien différente
-Dans 999 les puzzles sont très accessibles, ils sont un peu plus corsés dans VLR mais ne gachent pas le scénario.
-Possibilité de reprendre une scène deja débloqué a tout moment, pratique si on veut voir les différentes fins. A noter qu' il est aussi possibble de "skip" les scènes deja vu ce qui est présent dans tout les VN de nos jours.
-L'abre narratif est très utile poru ne pas s'y perdre et c'est quelque chose que j'aimerai voir plus souvent dans les VN. Sa et la possibilité de "voyager" dans l'arbre.
-Excellent durée de vie, 999 est assez court 20-25h et VLR plus long 40h. Sa dépendra de votre vitesse de lecture et de la résolution des puzzles.
-Un portage de bonne qualité avec un doublage inédit pour 999 et toujours présent dans VLR.


Points négatifs :
-Dans 999, en mode Novel les textes qui se superposent au fond ou il y a les personnages, pas terrible niveau visuel.
-Visée a la manette pas très précise et lente, j'ai du passer a la souris selon les cas.
-Dans  VLR, l'inventaire est très bordélique : les items sont rangés sur une ligne et on doit les passe en revues un par un. pas très pratique quand on a plus de 10 objets dans l'inventaire selon les puzzles.
-Dans VLR, quelques "pièces" ne sont pas très explicatives aux niveaux des puzzles, on doit y aller en essayant des interactions au hasard.
-Dans VLR, je ne suis pas très fan des personnages en 3d, j'aurai préféré de beau dessins en 2d comme dans les autres VN ou 999.
-Dans VLR, Il manque le doublage sur certaines scènes a la fin du jeu.

This is the first two thirds of one of the greatest story trilogies in gaming, finally on PC after a long time! 9 Hours 9 Persons 9 Doors (or 999) and Virtue's Last Reward (or VLR) are both amazing Visual Novels, and were critically acclaimed when they first came out. 999 has been remastered with brand-new voice acting and other changes, while VLR hasn't changed much (which is fine, it's already an amazing game as-is). You can choose to have the voices in English (which is fantastically well done and very convincing) or, for those who prefer subs over dubs, the original Japanese audio is available as well.
For those who might think the asking price is too high I say, this package includes TWO whole games, both of which have over 80% aggregate scores on Metacritic, and take at minimum 37 hours to beat both, though you're much more likely to spend 55+ (stats pulled from howlongtobeat; for comparison, they say a completionist run of Nier: Automata is around 56 hours).
So go on, treat yourself to the story of a lifetime, filled to the brim with Sci-Fi and Pseudoscience, Philosophy and Morality, Horror and Paranoia, Difficult Decisions, and plenty of excellent escape-the-room puzzles along the way, all with mood-setting music. This game will leave you sitting at the edge of your seat at 2:00 in the morning because you just want to know what comes next!
Absolutely Fantastic.

VLR on the other hand i have no complaints about. A total masterpiece! Every second i spent in this game was worth it. A true gem in my eyes.
Both games are a must play if you are into adventure type "choose your destiny" games with amazing storys and plot twists that will leave you SHOOK.

**Spoiler Free Review**

Zero Escape series is a series of puzzle-adventure games deverloped by Spike Chunsoft, and written by Kotaro Uchikoshi. Zero Escapes: The Nonary Games packs up with two classic games from its series since 2009 on DS, and 2012 on 3DS. These two games are: Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors (2009) and Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward (2012). 

All Zero Escapes feature nine characters who are kidnapped by an unknown individual refer themselves as "Zero". They are forced to play a "game" which involve risk and danger. All the participants must do every means necessary to survive the game, even it means "killing" people. All the participants will have one thing in common, the bracelet. The bracelets serve as the mean to complete, and win the game. As well as the mean to execute the players, should they lose a game, or violent the rules.

=====Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors=====

Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors is the first installment in the Zero Escape series. The game is played similar to visual novel adventure game with puzzle game to solve. The gameplay could be divided into two types: Novel and Escape. Novel is played exactly like the Visual Game. The player assumes the role of a man named Junpei, and progresses through the storyline and converses with other characters. During Novel sections, the player will sometimes be presented with decision options that affect the course of the game such as choosing which door to go with. The decisions made result in one of branching storylines in game, which player will end up with different ending.

In between Novel sections are Escape sections, which occur when the player finds themselves in a room from which they need to find the means of escape. These are presented from a first-person perspective, with the player being able to move between different positions in each room. In order to escape, player will need to find various items and clues, then solving puzzles. At some points, the player may need to combine objects with each other to create the necessary tool to complete a puzzle. The non playable character who're teaming up with player will sometimes give a hints when player seems to struggle for too long.

Unlike the DS version. The player has access to a flowchart that allows them to immediately revisit or "jump" to any previously completed Novel or Escape section without replaying the game from the beginning. This allows the player to transition to an earlier branching point in the story and choose a different option that causes the story to progress in another direction. The PC version now also include voice actors for a game.

Story is excellent well written. Every details and lores in this Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors game are thoughtfully created to be related to Nonary game or a game of "9". The story also gives a sense of horror and gruesome, the fear of finding out the truth/secret behind each door. Although in between hopeless situation, there's relationship and encouragement from characters. This game is the most beautiful, amazing piece of narrative, every moments are memorable, either it's good or bad. On top of it, are the well composed original soundtracks that fit incredibly well within the situations in game.

However due to terrible sale of Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors in Japan. Because of many complaint about how cruel and gruesome the game was, Spike Chunsoft changed, and tweaked a theme of Zero Escape into new direction, the result was Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward. Including Distrust, the Danganronpa beta game, which was turned into the well known Danganronpa Series nowadays.

=====Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward=====

Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward is the second installment in the Zero Escape series. It follows the storyline after the event of Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors. The player now assumes the role of a man named Sigma in this game. The game is played similar to visual novel adventure game with puzzle game to solve. The gameplay could be divided into two types: Novel and Escape, much similar to the first game. In Novel sections, the player advances through the storyline and converses with non-playable characters through visual novel segments. These sections require little interaction from the player other than reading the dialogue and text that appear on the screen. The player may be presented with decision options that affect the course of the game during the Novel section mode such as choosing which door to go with, and a decision option is a prisoner's dilemma-type choice where the player must choose to "ally" or "betray" the characters they are pitted against.

In between Novel sections are Escape sections, which occur when the player finds themselves in a room from which they need to find the means of escape. These are presented from a first-person perspective, with the player being able to change angle, and investigate in each room. In order to escape, player will need to find various items and clues, then solving puzzles. At some points, the player may need to combine objects with each other to create the necessary tool to complete a puzzle. The player receives hints to the puzzle solutions from the game's characters, a more direct hints are received if the player changes the puzzle's difficulty level from "hard" to "easy".

The flowchart in this game is much bigger than the first game. The player has access to a flowchart that allows them to immediately revisit or "jump" to any previously completed Novel or Escape section without replaying the game from the beginning. This allows the player to transition to an earlier branching point in the story and choose a different option that causes the story to progress in another direction.

Story is excellent well written, and even more big "twist" than the first game. The story still gives a sense of horror and gruesome events but not to extent of the first game due to the complaint survey they did in japan. There're more light-headed moment, and a more happy situation in this game, as a characters in game seem to easily adapt into situation unlike the first game. But they don't forget to include the sorrow moment that could easily rival the first game. The story is more well balanced this time. The game also has some of old reuse original soundtracks from the first game, including the large number of new ones. They're all memorable, and they fit the entire theme of Zero Escapes game, including puzzle rooms and an events after them. They manage to keep people excited throughout the whole game with perfect balance in story depiction. Some particular event is simply amazing piece of narrative.

In conclusion. Zero Escapes series is very good game. The PC ports are also very well done. With keyboard/mouse support, they also don't forget to include the controller support for preference choice.

Since Spike Chunsoft has finally added the first two games into steam, including the third game, Zero Time Dilemma, you better start the series now or miss the entirely masterpiece.
